Subject: Corvette

Steve, looks like I lied again (you gotta watch me like a hawk...). I found a 
text copy of the message afterall, so here it is... and the flying attempt was
only successful for 254 ft, not 600...

In message <199408022215.SAA09335@mandrill.lmc.ericsson.se> Andre Rotchel 
writes:
> 
> Hi everyone,
> 
> what happens if one is to have an unfortunate 
> mishap and roll-over with a 993 cabriolet?
- ------------------ original posting -----------------------
> Do Porsche engineers recommend crossing our fingers
> and wishing very hard that a roll-over would never occur?

It's just my HO, but I believe that Porsche engineers recommend keeping the 
rubber-side down.  If they don't, I certainly do.  ;-)

It's pretty hard to tip a Porsche, but sh*t happens, so I suppose it can
be done if you try hard enough...

A few years ago (11/5/66) when I was a bit less wise and more intemperate, I 
unwisely went out on an all-night beer-drinking, skirt-chasing safari with 
a young Luftwaffe Feldwebel who was temporarily stationed at Fort Sill, 
Oklahoma.  

Unwisely, we took my '66 Corvette.  Unwisely, I let him drive when we returned 
to the Fort at 0500.  Unwisely, I slept while he drove.  Unwisely, he ran a 
red-light.  Unfortunately, a policeman observed this and started to pursue 
with lights flashing.  *Very* unwisely, the driver decided to take the on-ramp 
to the Turnpike to Oklahoma city and try to out-run the cop.  

I awakened when the car violently slewed out of control and launched itself 
into space as a speed the Oklahoma Highway Patrol report estimated to be in 
excess of 145 mph.  My eyes *popped* open to see nothing but brown, dead grass 
in the headlights, from what looked to be about 3 meters up in the air.  

The next thing I saw was a Nurse, 3 days later in the  Intensive Care Unit 
at the Ft. Sill Army Hospital, where they brought me.  I was brought-into the 
Hospital listed *Dead-on-Arrival* and left on the gurney for the 4 plus hours 
that they worked on the driver.  By the time they were done with him, they had 
typed a name tag for me and placed it in the holder on a drawer in the morgue.

The car, according to the OHP, cleared an AARMCO steel guard-rail, went some 
254' thru the air, landed on the nose, and went end-over-end for more than 
600'; coming to rest right-side up (*rubber-side down*, if you will).

> Is there any chance of surviving the crash?

Yeah, there's always a chance...  ;-)

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 94 10:15:27 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Double Clutching ... try thinking with a picture

Let's see if we can picture the transmission is ASCII
There are three rotating assemblies that can be either
coupled or de-coupled:

   1. The engine with RPM controlled by your foot
      when decoupled, by the road when everything
      is connected.
   2. The output section of the transmission with
      different RPM's for each gear connection point
      (lower gears turning faster) which is controlled
      by the road speed.
   3. The transmission 'input shaft and gears' which can
      be linked to either or both ends (clutch to engine RPM) or
      (synchronizers and dogs to a gear connection point).
      Left to itself, it will lose momentum and stop.

Connection points are indicated by '> >'.

                                   >   > first (rotating fastest)
                                   >   > second
ENGINE  > > Input Shaft And Gears  >   > third
         ^                         >   > fourth
         |                         >   > fifth (rotating slowest)
      clutch                        ^
                                    |
                           synchronizers and engagement dogs
                          'select one at a time except in neutral'

The game of preserving clutch and synchronizer friction surfaces is
to have the two sides of each connection point turning at the same
RPM when you connect them.  Shifting up, this means a pause for
the input shaft and gears to bleed off just the right amount of
RPM before engaging the next gear.  Shifting down, you have to
use the engine (throttle blip) to speed up the input shaft and
gears as they are turning more slowly than the lower gear they
are to engage.

That's the mechanics.  The technique has been described again and
again recently.  Go practice ... or just rely on you synchronizers
to do the job (as long as they last).  Note that it is good
practice on the road, not just in races or race simulation.
Just pause when upshifting and double clutch when downshifting
always.  If you anticipate downshifts (aware driving) you usually
don't need 'heel and toe'.  It's good machinery.  Be kind to it.

Rick Dill

------------------------------

Date: 31 Dec 94 12:48:15 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 828 and Pacer lineage

 
Hi, Richard.
 
If Tony Lapine really said that, I guess we have to take it at face value.
Tony is a real character. If he was quoted directly, then it MAY be true.
Otherwise, it may be some hack writer's revisionist interpretation of
history. The trouble is that people think anything in print MUST be true, or
they wouldn't be allowed to print it.
 
In the book "Projekt 928" by Julius Weitmann and Rico Steinemann, there are
styling studio concept sketches of the 928, one of them very close to the
final form, dated Nov. 19, 1973.
 
Does it say if the air sickness bag that spawned the Gremlin was full, or
empty?
 
I find it a little odd that of all the hundreds of thousands, maybe more
than a million, Hornets, Gremlins, and Pacers built, you never see any on
California's roads. (Nothing ever rusts away here.) But other cars from the
same era, or even older cars, are fairly common. Same thing goes for Vegas
and Pintos. Hey, these might be future investment items -- just think of it,
if we act now, we each could own "one of only six Chevrolet Vegas known to
exist." Which should make them as valuable as, say, a Bugatti Royale. Then
we could sell our two Vegas to Rick Cole, who will then own ALL of the Vegas
known to exist, and he will confidently predict that the price of Vegas will
be going even higher. Want me to start looking for good, one-owner Vega GTs,
low mileage, owned by little old ladies from Pasadena? (I did a story on the
Cosworth Vega a few years ago for Automobile Quarterly. There is an active
club, which trades parts back and forth and tries to keep the things
running. It's still a Vega, spiffy cylinder head notwithstanding.)
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 94 01:15:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re 911 engine stand and 914 shifting


Hi gang,

Occasionally, I had a similar problem with my 914 grinding when
trying to shift into 1st at a dead stop.  I found that by shifting into 2nd
and releasing the clutch to barely move the car then shifting back
into 1st worked for me.  Don't know why....it just worked.

About building a 911 engine stand from a domestic V8 750lb
capacity stand....be careful.  I know 2 guys who did this and one
guy is real happy, and the other was wondering what the hell was
going on when the engine he was working on was slowly moving
towards the floor!  Both of these stands were purchased from the
same place, but one had a drastic problem - it couldn't support
a 300 pound 911 engine!!!  Now Stu has welded 3 supports to
the main upright to make sure this won't happen again.

Kinda reminds me of the 6000 pound jackstand which broke on
me - it was only used a few times to hold up one side of my 914.
I sure am glad it didn't decide to break while I was under the car!

Take care....and have a SAFE and prosperous New Year!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 1994 18:38:40 -0500
From: Skaterj@aol.com
Subject: Decisions..Decisions...

I think I'm going out of my mind. For the last couple of months I have been
trying to decide what car to buy. I have narrowed my choices to the Mitsu
3000 GT VR4 (92-93), Nissan 300ZX Twin Turbo (91-92), and my long time
obsession, the Porsche Carrera (87-88). My main criterion is performance,
0-60 & 1/4 mile times, handling, etc. The 2 Japanese cars have gotten
excellent reviews in all the big auto mags, and I'd be looking at much newer
model years. They have alot of the hi-tech bells and whistles and nice body
styling.  The 911, as you all know, has much more simplistic styling with
alot less electronic gadgetry, and in the model years I'm considering did not
perform as well. It would probably also cost much more to maintain. But it's
a PORSCHE. I get to the point where I purge any thoughts of the 911 from my
mind, but then I'll see one on the street or on TV or read the P-philes list
and I'm back at square one. Has anyone been in a similar predicament? Has
anyone owned either of the Japanese cars? What would you recommend?

P.S. Budgeting would be a major issue in any choice I make. The car would
also be my daily driver.

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 1994 17:40:18 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Decisions..Decisions...

Sigh.... Comparison shopping at its worst.

Stan's Creed:

Owning a Porsche makes no sense if you want the best 0-60 times.

Owning a Porsche makes no sense if you want a low cost of maintenece.

Owning a Porsche makes no sense if you have real budget constraints
because when you need that $1k clutch job, that's what you need
and that's what it costs.

Owning a Porsche makes no sense if you worry about dents and dings and
little things, because all cars get them and they look exceptionally
bad on YOUR Porsche.

Owning a Porsche makes no sense if you drive like a jerk, because you'll
be treated badly for it, and it will hurt the rest of us.

Owning a Porsche makes no sense if you don't really WANT to own a Porsche.

I can't imagine owning anything else.

Stan

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 1994 18:24:59 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: re: 914 manual$ and CV joints (moderately long)

In Issue #1038 <readsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil> asked some 914 questions (some 
of which I don't have an answer for . . .)

(3)  Is $270 for aset of factory manuals a good price?  Unfortunately, yes.  
The best price I had seen was $308 and I think that supplier raised the 
price recently.  I was able to pick up an *incomplete* set from Walter 
Miller booksellers for $75, but it is missing the volumes on the 4-cyl fuel 
system and the electrical system.

(4)  How do you remove the CV joint retaining flange?  According to the 
factory manual:

        "i)  Unlock castle nut of universal shaft and loosen.
         ii)  Remove heat exchanger.
        iii)  Loosen cheesehead screws of universal shaft on universal 
flange.  Use flat chisel
               to separate universal shaft from universal flange in range of 
flange seal and
               remove universal shaft.

               *Caution*  Do not damage flange surface."

Installation seems to be pretty much the reverse after making sure all 
surfaces are clean and smooth.

        -- Bill
           wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 94 16:44:21 PST
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: double clutching/speed shifting

Someone enquired as to the relationship between double clutching
and shifting without a clutch.

If you aren't using the clutch, it is a little more difficult
getting out of the initial gear. You must adjust the throttle
so there is no load on the tranny or drive train. Then you can
slip into neutral.

Next you adust the engine speed to the appropriate level for
the next gear, then you should be able to slip into that gear
without having ever touched the clutch pedal.

If you downshift without using the clutch, you are still doing
essentially the same thing that you do while double-clutching,
i.e. you blip the throttle with the clutch out in neutral
and then slip into the lower gear.

Upshifting without the clutch is sometimes called speed shifting.

Some sports car racing drivers don't use the clutch.

I think that you can go faster IF you can proficiently shift
without the clutch, but there is very little margin for error,
i.e. if you don't get exactly the right engine speed you will
miss the shift and lose lots of time, as well as really torturing
your tranny.

I don't recommend shifting without the clutch on
your Porsche. If you are curious, try it on a beater.
(I learned it on a seemingly indestructible '62 Ford Falcon).

 -Mitch

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 94 21:07 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Head Studs

Lord, 

>I have a '72 911E Targa (2.4 liter).  I have Mahle cylinders.  Should I 
>use steel head studs or Dilavar?  Also, what is the best way to get a CV 
>joint off of the axle?

With magnesium cases, the recommendation of record is to use dilivar
all round.

With respect to the CV's, I assume you already have the circlip off
and want to drive the inner race from the splines.  I put the half-
shaft in a vice, to start.  I am generally able to remove the CV
by tapping around the circumference of the inner race with a hammer
and drift.  Once in a while, this gets me nowhere.  In that sort of
case, I douse with penetrating oil and use a gear puller.

If you can convince yourself that both CV's are junk, you might
save yourself some effort.  A lot of the time, buying two new CV's
already mounted on a half-shaft is cheaper than buying the two
separately.  (However, the supply of these set-ups has been a little
spotty in the last half year.)

Hope this helps.

Kevin Gross

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 1994 18:57:57 -0800
From: ero@ix.netcom.com (Harold Williams)
Subject: re: Z-box speakers

Z-box 
Sound Quest
2600 Commonwealth Ave.
N. Chicago, Il. 60064
Ph. # 1-708-473-1200

IMHO the nicest enclosures I've seen, and the cleanest installation. As 
I mentioned earlier, when I bought mine some 10 years ago, the speakers 
they used were pretty louisy. They've been bought out since then so 
maybe the speakers sound better. I replaced the subs with JBL 8" 
speakers and was going to swap out the mids & tweeters with Boston 
Acoustics. The mids are 4". It doesn't matter where you mount the subs 
since they are non-directional. What is important is to have the proper 
size enclosure for the speakers. What I liked about the z-boxes were the 
front satellites where mounted in the foot wells, angled up and in. The 
rear satellites were about head height and angled in. All the music was 
right around your head instead of around your knees(speakers in doors). 
The system in my '73 targa was tri-amped, 150 watts to the subs and 
100watts to each pair of satellites. Great tunes at 100 m.p.h. with the 
top out.
Harold
'78 930
'68 crewcab

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 1994 23:01:39 -0500
From: YoramGuy@aol.com
Subject: Re: traction issues, or 4wd vs 2wd and rear engine

To Sam's comments -
In principle, all other things being equal, vehicles with rear weight
bias tend to be less stable in a straight line and more "ready to turn"
(overtseer tendency).  Remember the arrow with heavy head vs.
heavy tail analogy.
Transmission of power through the rear wheels can modify this
behavior - either amplify or attenuate - depending whether under
power or overrun/trailing throttle, whether combined torque and
cornering force is high enough to cause tire breakaway, on
suspension geometry & compliance, etc.
Much of this yaw stability problem can be reduced (and in theory,
eliminated), by using unequal tracks and tires front to rear.
The main advantage of the rear engine is in longitudinal traction - both in
2WD acceleration and in braking.
The combined blessing and penalty we get is the "interesting" handling (yaw
behavior), which some people (i.e., GM after Corvair
and Nader) deem not consistent and foolproof enough for the
whole driver population, or too difficult to develop to its state
in contemporary 911/993's.
As to C4 and 959 history, I'll defer to more knowledgable
Porschephiles.

Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI
...Still looking for an '87 Carerra Coupe...

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 31 Dec 1994 23:01:26 -0500
From: YoramGuy@aol.com
Subject: One more on Double De-Clutching

To Mike Paradiso's question, in case it wasn't fully answered,
"why it is better to blip the engine with the transmission
in neutral and clutch out rather than transmission in gear
and clutch in" -
The answer is it is better if your goal is to shift a non-
synchronized transmission or to conserve your synchro's.
With the transmission in neutral and the clutch engaged,
you are able to accelerate the input shaft by revving the
engine to the target speed it should have in the next lower gear,
or slow it down by dropping engine revs to correspond to its
target speed in the next higher gear.
You need to have the clutch in to allow the engine to talk to
the transmission.
(You may need your lawyer to make sense out of the above verbage,
I don't know how to say the above more coherently).

However, if all you want to accomplish is smooth torque pickup
upon clutch engagement, it doesn't make a difference.
Yet, by using the former method (clutch engaged), you can
accomplish both.

Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI
...Still looking for an '87 Carerra Coupe...

Date: Sun, 1 Jan 1995 00:17:34 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Carerra Spoilers

> 1.  Improved stability -

At any highway speed *IF* the correct front air dam is also installed.

> 2.  Oil cooler mounted in rear spoiler 

Never seen this. The A/C condensor is usually mounted there, and does
look a little like an oil cooler.... I think the oil temps would be too
high for the ABS (plastic, not brakes).

> 1.  "Purism" - are spoilers on '87 Carerra's original equipment option,
>      dealer-installed genuine Porsche option, 3rd party aftermarket
> accessory,
>      or any of the above?  If the latter, how to tell which it is?

All of the above. And no, like many things on the 911, you can't tell
a really well done aftermarket install from a factory job, or a bad
aftermarket job from a bad repair on a factory job... The *only* way
is to run the VIN number and see if it's supposed to have the spoiler
package.

> 2.  Can a rear spoiler, once installed, be removed with no residual damage
>      to engine lid (paint, holes, etc.)?

No. Some assembly required. You *WILL* have to repaint, maybe do some
welding, etc on the deck lid, but you can make it like it was never there.
But it can look perfect.

Stan

Porschephiles #1041                         Mon Jan 2 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Sun, 1 Jan 1995 09:15:27 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Subject: traction issues, or 4wd

Samuel Halperin, SAAB driver, looking for a C4, asked :

>I have always maintained that a good safe car should have either front 
>wheel drive, or all wheel drive, as this helps to avoid spin outs, allows 
>one to drive in snow and ice, and also allows you to power out of skids.  

Sam, try to go up a slick snow covered hill in your SOB, you can't! (Unless
you
put it in reverse and go up BACKWARDS!) A rear-engine Rear wheel drive
will make it up much better than a FWD car going forward, due to the
weight transfer of acceleration and pointing up hill.

As for powering out of skids, if you apply power to a FDW car in a skid,
you will simply go straight off the road. The front end will not have enough
grip to turn the car, if it did you wouldn't be skidding!

>Howeever, as I recently became interested in Porsches, I was wondering if 
>there had been any discussion of rear engine, rear drive and its safety 
>aspects.  Do any of you porsche drivers out there have any comment on 
>this type of vehicle?  It seems to me that the traction would be just as 
>good, because you have a lot of engine weight over the drive wheels, but 
>what do I know???

A 911 will have very good traction, but needs lots more driving skill to
avoid spin-outs. But 911s have won the Monte Carlo Rally and others
in snow, so with lots of skill and a little luck, they can be fast.

Mike Piera '72 911S Targa (unfortunately never tried in snow)
AnalogMike@aol.com

Date: Sun, 1 Jan 1995 14:48:09 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Re: Decisions..Decisions

Skater,

The cars you have mentioned are all excellent choices. My recommendation to
you; don't buy the Porsche. In virtually every category of
comparison-handling, power, styling, quality, practicality, and ownership
costs-the Porsche comes in second (or worse). 

Handling: Much has been written regarding the "unusual" handling
characteristics of the 911. I think Porsche factory engineers said it best in
an internal memo that was at the center of a product liability law suit
several years ago involving a traffic fatality. The Porsche engineers
described the handling characteristics of the 911 as "viperous." For the vast
majority of drivers-myself included-that memo says it all.

Power: The low-end torque of the 3.2 engine is nice. Top end is good too. The
"kick in the butt" boost of the turbo is a thrill. Still, the Porsche will
lose a stop-light drag race to cars costing 2/3rds of what you'll pay for a
911. And if there are any turns required in your little speed contest... see
"Handling" above.

Styling: Lot's of sexy cars on the sales lots these days. The thirty-year old
styling of the 911 looks its age when parked next to some of Japan's best.

Quality: BMW, MBZ, and even Honda come out on top in this category. But
Porsche is a "hand built" motor car, right? Exactly, and the robots do it
better.

Practicality: A two-seater is never practical. Still, most modern sports cars
can navigate a moderately angled driveway without scraping the underbody. The
911 cannot. You'll work up a sweat wrestling the steering wheel of your 911
while trying to parallel park, and you'll end up three feet from the curb in
an effort to keep from scraping those $900 Fuchs. You'd better take your
buddy's Nissan to the golf course; no room for your clubs in the 911.

Ownership Costs: $250 per headlight? This is a joke, right?

I can think of a dozen reason why you should not buy a Porsche, and only one
reason why you should. You said it yourself in the second sentence of your
post. You called the Porsche Carrera your "...long time obsession." If you
have the means to purchase a Porsche and are still considering another
automobile, your obsession factor may not be sufficient to overcome the
deficiencies mentioned above, in which case, you may be happier with another
car. For those of use who are truly obsessed with the marque, there can be no
other. Good luck.

Michael K.

'87 Carrera Cabriolet

Date: Sun, 1 Jan 95 20:59 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Head Studs - correction

Oops,

I stand corrected on my earlier post.  You should *not* use dilivar
studs with the cast iron cylinders used through '73.  Stick to steel,
the dilivar is there to match the thermal expansion rates of
aluminum (Nicasil, Alusil) cylinders.

Sorry, I got my history wrong.

Kevin Gross

 spare muffler or any idea how one would test to see if it were clogged

 notice any nesting materal or any smell or anything.. I did notice that 
 on the driver side the three tubes on the heat exchanger where the converter
 bolts to the exchanger where white while on the passenger side they were 
 a dull gray... I though I may be running lean/hot on this side or in general.
 I pulled the plugs and read them.. They were all light brown.. I installed
 my CIS guages and all of the pressures are normal.. The car starts and runs
 normal (no pops,snorts backfires or anything) it just has no power. I checked
 my ingnition and it too is normal..
	I installed my test pipe in place of my converter with no difference
 in performance. I am wondering though is the white colour on the three heat 
 exchanger pipes normal?? my temperature guage reads normal.. I hear no pinging
 whe I drive.

	Anyhow I'm stumped... Unless there is somthing someone can suggest

 exhaust components...

Date: Sun, 1 Jan 1995 23:02:36 -0500
From: YoramGuy@aol.com
Subject: Re: Decisions..Decisions...

Skater, I've been subject to a similar neurotic process -
Should I sell my '86 160k mi SAAB 900 Turbo for ~$3k and get
a new BMW 325i, or should I keep the SAAB as a winter beater/
all-purpose high speed utility transport and get an '87 Carerra for
summer road/club track use?
I think my decision was cemented when BMW decided not to
offer limited slip diff as an option on '95 325's, only traction
control.

As to 3000GT VR4 and 300ZX TT vs. Carerra -
Which one do you enjoy driving the most, assuming you've tried them
all in reasonably comprehensive test drives?
If you haven't, drive all three cars, preferably along same representative
route, and let them talk to you.
Ask yourself how much power you really need to be happy, vs. what
other sensory (vehicular!!) feedback you need/enjoy equally or even more.

Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI
...Still looking for an '87 Carerra Coupe...

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 08:35:06 +0000
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Decisions..Decisions


Skater,

Stan and Michael have spoken words of great wisdom.  I have only two nits to
pick with what's already been said, and one new thing to consider.  Michael 
said:
 
> Styling: Lot's of sexy cars on the sales lots these days. The thirty-year old
> styling of the 911 looks its age when parked next to some of Japan's best.

That's truly the classic YMMV case!  I personally have found the 911 styling
to be timeless, and have been hopelessly smitten since the first one I saw,
on the streets of Wiesbaden, in November 1964 (I'm sure it was a 901, but
that's a lot of years, so...)

> Quality: BMW, MBZ, and even Honda come out on top in this category. But
> Porsche is a "hand built" motor car, right? Exactly, and the robots do it
> better.

This is another YMMV.  I've owned a couple of MBZs, and while both were
high quality cars, I've *never* seen fit *or* finish superior to my cab.

Finally, when you drive a 911, you have the satisfaction of knowing you are
driving one of a very select breed.  Along with one Ferrari or another, the
911 is the one car that will be on every knowledgable enthusiast's list of
the top ten sports cars ever made.  That's definitely a FWIW issue; which,
in the final analysis, is what the whole business of buying a sports car is
*all* about...

Bart Chambers, 
Wife Dora, 
'77 Feline Varmint Fexix, American Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Quantum Syncro, (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 09:03:55 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Decisions, decisions

Michael959 wrote:

>The cars you have mentioned are all excellent choices. My recommendation to
>you; don't buy the Porsche. In virtually every category of
>comparison-handling, power, styling, quality, practicality, and ownership
>costs-the Porsche comes in second (or worse).

I'm sorry, but in my eyes, the Carrera is not a loser when compared to a
3000GT/300ZX/et al.  As far as handling goes, if you are a good enough
driver to discern (and fret) over the small differences in skidpad
ratings, etc., then more power to you.  For 95% of drivers out there,
the Carrera is more than capable.  IMHO, the "viperous" oversteering
characteristics of the 911 is somewhat of an urban legend nowadays -
it's not really that bad.  As for the power - something to consider is
the weight of the cars.  I don't have the numbers handy but I bet the 
911 is lighter than most of its competitors - that means alot.  Styling?
Subjective category.  Quality?  Look at 10 or even 20 year old 911s.
They seem to be holding up much better than - well just about every-
thing else.  Sounds like quality to me.  Practicality?  I driven 3000GTs,
etc.  Practicality is relative (don't give me no steenking cup holders!).
Ownership costs?  Factor in resale value and the whole picture changes.

Sorry for the line-by-line rebuttal, but I found it hard to believe these
T*d-like statements came from the owner of an '87 Carrera!  Maybe I'm
a glutton for punishment, but I'd pick the pcar over anything else in the
same price range.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

------------------------------

Date: 02 Jan 95 10:53:30 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsche book recommendation

 
Hi, Sam.
 
The best car marque book ever written is about Porsches. Get Karl
Ludvigsen's "Excellence was Expected", about $85 I think, and well over 800
pages of carefully researched history. It is the standard by which all other
car histories are judged. It was written in 1978, I think, and was never
updated, but it has never been beaten either as a general history.
 
There is a new 911 history book coming out this spring, with less of the
corporate history and more specific 911 history. "Porsche 911: Forever
Young" by Tobias Aichele. Look for it around April. It is up to date up to
the 1995 Carrera 4. and Tiptronic S transmission. About 400 pages.
 
Brett Johnson's "911 Restorer's Guide to Authenticity" covers some of the
appearance differences between models and years, but not the engineering and
mechanical stuff.
 
There are other good books out there, but most were written in the late 70s
and are threfore dated. Paul Frere's "Porsche 911" is a nuts and bolts
development history. Juergen Barth's "Porsche Book" has a few mistakes but
is a rough year-by-year guide to model differences.
 
The best and just about only book on how to tweak the thing once you have it
is "The 911 Performance Handbook" by Bruce Anderson.
 
Pete

"The Used 911 Story," Bruce Anderson's book (I forget the title), the
"Upfixin der Porsche series," the factory manual.

Rudy Bartling is the only one that people I know have experience with. They
drive down from Ottawa to get him to work on their cars, which may (or may
not) mean anything.

Date: Mon, 02 Jan 1995 11:20:43 -0500 (EST)
From: "James L. Fry" <JFRY@UOFT02.UTOLEDO.EDU>
Subject: Chips for '86 928S

Hi,
I'm looking for some net wisdom on the subject of installing modified
ignition/fuel control chips on an '86 928S.  I am aware that there are
dramatic increases in power on turbos such as the 951 when chips are
used, but my understanding is that that effect is made primarily
through increase in the amount of boost and RPMs allowed by the
modified DME.  The '86 928S is not amenable to boost changes, so
how much improvement can be expected by just remapping the fuel/
ignition profiles?
Does anyone have any practical experience with chip modifications
on this engine?  Also, how do the Triad chips advertised in PANO
compare with the more common chips from Autothority?  The Triad
chips are selling for about 1/3rd the cost of the Autothority
chips.
Thanks for any information you may be able to give me.
Jim Fry
'86 928S

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 08:46:19 -0800
From: KimKnapp@ix.netcom.com (Maynard Knapp)
Subject: Re: High revving

>occasionally. The only way I could imagine them taking a "set" is if 
there
>is a carbon ridge deposited at the top of the upper ring travel, and if 
the
>car has been run exclusively at low revs and part throttle for zillions 
of
>miles (long enough to build up significant carbon) and then revved high 
and
>hard, so that intertia forces result in just enough stretch/flexing of 
stuff
>to put the top ring into the carbon by a few microns and thereby break 
a
>ring. That scenario is pretty farfetched anyway. And gas forces tend to 
act
>downward on three of the four strokes (the exception being the intake 
stroke).
> 
>

Peter,
	The way I always understood it (please correct me if I am 
wrong), carbon is a problem because it can get hot enough to glow and 
act like a glow plug causing the air/fuel mixture to ignite earlier than 
it should. This can cause knock and subsequent damage. I agree, however, 
that most modern engines have little problem running at low revs, in 
this sense, because of the EFI's efficient control of the air/fuel 
mixture such that it burns more thoroughly, even at low revs. I do agree 
with others about the bearing wear at lower revs though (due to the 
pressures of combustion at slow revs). I know that it is certain death 
to run my Cosworth engine at low revs in my 7. It also seemed to me that 
at the factory they told us not to run around in too high a gear with 
the 911(?)
				Kim

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 18:56:28 +0100 (MET)
From: Morten Christian Holmgreen <joker@diku.dk>
Subject: Decisions... Decisions...

Hi,

As to what car to buy? Since you're very concerned with acc. I've included
the test-values of a couple of the cars as well as other cars that might
be interesting. I know the 993 and a (almost) new 911C2 is quite expensive,
but it's interesting to compare these, since a few people claims the
Porsche's are the slowest in the flock, which they (in my experience)
definately is _not_. (I couldn't find the values for a stock 3.2, sorry)

The testvalues below are taken from the German magazine 'Auto, Motor und
Sport' which is the one of the most esteemed magazines in europe. (I don't
know if the BMW M3 has hit the american beaches)

All speed is measures in km/h. Weight is kg and measured in test. Price is
thousand DM and was the price, when the car was tested (without options).

(For all you americans with weird units :-) : 
 60km/h=37.3mph, 80=49.7, 100=62.1, 120=74.6, 160=99.4, 200=124.3, 
 1kg=2.2lbs. and 1DM=$0.65)

                      Porsche           Mazda  Toyota  Mitsub.  Nissan  BMW
                911C2   993     968     RX-7    Supra  GT3000   300ZX    M3

0-60             2.8     2.8                             2.9     3.1     3.0
0-80             4.3             4.9     4.6     4.4       
0-100            5.5     5.3     6.6     6.5     5.9     6.4     6.5     5.8
0-120            7.7     7.3             8.7     8.2     8.9
0-160           12.9    12.4            14.8    14.2    15.7    15.3    13.3
0-200           21.0    21.1    28.0    25.0    25.0    30.2    26.0    24.0

1Km             25.0    24.7    26.7    26.0    26.0    27.1    26.4    25.7

60-100 (4th)     6.9     6.1     9.1     6.1      -      8.7     6.8     6.6
60-100 (5th)      -      7.7      -       -      6.5      -       -       -

80-120 (5th)     9.7     8.2    11.4    10.6      -     11.6    10.9     8.8
80-120 (6th)      -     11.2      -       -      9.0      -       -       -

Topspeed        264     267     253     253     250     250     250     250

HP              250/    272/    240/    239/    330/    286/    283/    286/
by rpm          6100    6100    6200    6500    5600    6000    6400    7000
Torque          310/    330/    305/    294/    441/    407/    375/    320/
by rpm          4800    5500    4100    5000    4800    3000    3600    3600
Weight, empty   1398    1363    1412    1320    1640    1759    1642    1486

Kg/HP           5.59    5.01    5.88    5.52    4.97    6.15    5.80    5.20

Price, DM       103.5   125.7   89.8    85.5    106     98.5    88      83.0

Year/model      1990    1994    1992    1993    1994    1993    1991    1994


Compare this to for instance my 911 3.2. It's got 245HP and weighs
1250 kg. This means I have 5.1 Kg/HP - which is marginally less than a 
993, but better than a 911C2. (Agreed my car is a bit modified, but not 
much. It it, naturally, a euro Carrera (no cats))

In europe the 300XZ, 3000GT and RX-7 is normally not even compared with
the 911, but with the 968 where the performance is just about equal, 
with the 968 being a bit behind. Only the Toyota Supra is being compared
to the 911's...

I've tried a dragging against both a GT3000 and a 300ZX - none of them 
could keep up. I was about 40-50 meters in front of them when I hit 180 km/h.

On track I've also tried dragging a 911C2 and I was faster than that 

one too. Only marginally, but enough to pass him on a long straight. I won't 
begin to compare driving around the corners, since my 911 has a non-stock setup
(equally fast as a C2 with my narrow-body 3.2 targa).

I haven't tried driving against any of the other cars on track, so I will
not say anything about this..

Another thing is that it's easier (and _much_ cheaper) making a
turbo-charged car go faster. You can easily modify it by turning
up the boost preassure (Well, not all _that_ simple if you want it to
last, but you get the picture).

I'd strongly recommend trying to go for a spin in the cars you're
considering and letting the car "speak" to you.

About the price: Yes, the 911 is expensive. Yes, it's expensive
to maintain. However you also have a better resale value of the
car. The japanese metal depreciates _very_ quickly. I'm using
mine as an every day driver too, but it _is_ at a high cost.

I think that if you want better comfort, more gadgets and a newer
look (that will be outdated in 3 years), get a new japanese car.

But if you like Porsches: There can be only one...

Christian

911 Carrera 3.2 targa
911 Carrera 3.2 turbo-look coupe
- -- 
M. Christian Holmgreen / joker@diku.dk / mochmch@unidhp.uni-c.dk
M.Sc. student, University of Copenhagen, Dept. of Computer Science
"Human errors can only be avoided if one can avoid the use of humans"

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 14:02:03 -0500 (EST)
From: jjm98@acs.org (Joseph Malin)
Subject: Rain and an '84 944

I recently purchased a 1984 944.  The car has been working really well
 except for one problem.  Whenever I drive the car in the rain the floor
 becomes wet.  The passenger side is is far worse then the driver side 
and the front is worse then the back.  I have assumed since the floor 
becomes wet only when the car is driven, that the water is being splashed 
up from underneath.  Upon investigating the underbody, I saw only one 
obvious opening... but it looked suspiciously like a drainage hole.  
The hole is behind the front wheel and a bit towards the middle of the 
car.  Has anyone out there had a similar problem?  I am inclined to try 
blocking the hole, but it looks like it was placed there on purpose... 

 Any ideas would be appreciated.

Joe Malin
(jjm98@acs.org)

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 15:10:35 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Decisions...cont.

> disconcerting thing I heard was that the Porsche is not a great "dragster".
> Since this will be my fist real sports car, I wanted something to play with
> during my stoplight to stoplight hops

This is a Bad Idea in all cases. Any Porsche looks to most cops like
it has "TICKET ME" printed on the back window. It also is a sign of 
either a lack of maturity or a lack of knowledge. I'll assume it's a 
lack of knowledge, and offer something for you to think about:

True "sports cars" are all originally of European design. They were
designed around *road racing*, not drag racing, which is a purely American 
phenomenon. In road racing, where originally the goal was to cover some 
amazingly twisty chunk of European roadway, often with great elevation 
changes, between two places, you need a *BALANCED* car -- great handling, 
good power to weight ratio, acceptible acceleration, great high speed
stability. *THAT* is what the 911 has.

American "muscle cars" are designed for something completely different --
raw straight line acceleration. I once had a '73 Mustang with the '70 
Ford NASCAR SOHC 428 engine, making about 650 HP at the rear wheels as 
I was running it then. *UNBELIEVABLE* acceleration. But God help you if 
you needed to turn while underway, or for that matter STOP suddenly. 

As to your "need for speed" deal, I highly suggest that you join the PCA
and take your new 911 to autocross and drivers' education (learning to
drive at speed on race tracks) events, where you can get much more 
satisfation that you can possibly imagine. And no tickets.

Stan

Porsche dealers, even though they should know the car, can do the same thing.
 Although you have to learn the hard way, on routine things like leakers, I
remove the tire/wheel and carry it in....but they can still mess up the alloy
rims on tire removal unless you watch them.  Most "general service" shops
like Goodyear don't like customers in the service bay.

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 15:43:31 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: Carerra Limited Slip Diff

You wrote: 

>
>Another one of the "excuse my ignorance" variety:
>I thought all '87 Carerra coupe cars came with LSD as standard.
>A prospective seller claimed they were an option.
>My questions are which is it, and if it was an option, is there an
>easy way to tell whether a car has it without the original window
>sticker or a VIN check with Porsche?
>
>Again, thanks for all tips -
>
>Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI
>...Still looking for an '87 Carrera Coupe...
>
>P.S.  And perhaps I finally got my Carrera spelling right!!
>Should have stuck with "911"...
>It's like I can never remember whether it's Ferrari, Ferarri,
>Ferrarri?  What the heck, at least Phord Preaube is a no-brainer.
>
>
Quick ck for limited slip is to jack up the back and turn one rear wheel 
if the other turns is the same direction then limited slip. If turns is 
the oposite direction no limited slip. A locker will also behave this 
way.
		mike   HAPPY NEW YEAR

Sacramento, CA

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 18:52:19 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Re: Decisions... Decisions

Skater,

Bart and Mike D. speak the truth. Issues like styling, quality, and resale
value are subjective. Even performance figures don't always present a clear
picture. I think the point I was making when I suggested that you not
purchase a Porsche was that the satisfaction of Porsche ownership comes from
more then the sum of  it's parts (or performance figures). It's a visceral
thing.

In your original post, you were attempting to quantify the merits of two nice
Japanese autos with those of a Porsche. Although it is difficult for me to
admit, I believe that the Porsche comes up short in many of the categories
that you mentioned. 

A little story: I have owned (and sold) several sailboats over the years.
Owning a sailboat is a lot like owning a Porsche (stay with me on this, it's
going somewhere, honest). When it comes time to sell my boat, occasionally an
interested party will tell me that he's undecided on whether to buy a
powerboat or a sailboat. In almost every case, I'll recommend that he
purchase a power boat. You see, sailing is a lot of work. But a sailboat
owner will sacrifice things like comfort, performance, and utility in order
to enjoy this specialized vessel in much the same way a Porsche owner will
likewise make a few sacrifices. If the buyer doesn't "get it" (the visceral
thing), he/she will be disappointed.  (Once a guy told me he couldn't decide
between buying a sailboat or a race horse. I sold him my boat anyhow, but
that's another story).

I think this explains why, in my town, there are always quite a few 2 - 6
month old Porsches on the market. 1) Rich guy buys new 911 because someone
told him that they're cool. 2) rich guy discovers that his Porsche is noisy,
hard riding, and cramped. 3) Rich guy trades in the 911 for an MBZ SL.

The pleasure I derive from my '87 Cabriolet cannot be measured on the skid
pad or at the stop-light drag race. It comes from knowing that I have the
privilege and good fortune to own one of the finest examples automotive
craftmanship ever produced. I changed my mind... get the Porsche! : )

Michael K.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 19:04:23 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com

> The most disconcerting thing I heard was that the Porsche is not a great
"dragster".

 Ah, but the Porsche IS a great dragster. It just may not be the BEST
dragster. But then, 0 to 100 is only part of the equation.

Michael K.

This happened to my car also (86' 944). I had 4 dents caused by the lift.
I showed it to the shop and though they didn't deny it, they didn't offer 
to do anything about it either but sent me to one of their buddy's bodyshop.

buy insurance to cover cases like this. The shop ended up paying for any 
deductibles and I paid nothing and had it fixed at a bodyshop of my choice.

Reliable in Richmond

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 22:40:04 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Goodyear shop damage, need advice..

Guys,

This just plain sucks (pardon my language) all around.  I've worked in the
dealership retail side for about10 years, selling or servicing.  Tim, I feel
like this is a reflection on everyone in my industry.  Any competent shop
anticipates some errors and damage, we budget for it, sometimes we even feel
that we got screwed by a liberal application of 'goodwill'.  But the reason
for applying 'goodwill' is to earn your continued patronage.

The Better Business Bureau is a joke because no one check with them before
using a business.  Goodyear may have a system for resolving the dispute, but
I doubt it.  I believe you'll have to sue them, and I wish you the best of
luck (don't forget punative damages).

Perry is quite correct that a Porsche shop can make similar mistakes, but
they're much more likely to try to retain you as a customer and accept the
repair as their own, or negotiate a settlement.

Peter L

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 22:39:50 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Carerra Spoilers

According to the manufacturer. The things apparently do work.  Front spoilers
on most cars are effective at around 30 mph, the rear won't really make a
difference till about 65-70 mph.  Most people seeem to agree that there's no
sense installing the rear without the front (seems to make sense).

Peter L

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 22:44:44 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Decisions..Decisions...

In a past life I've sold both the Porsche and the Dodge Stealth (a rebadged
Mitsu).  Before you make any decision, drive the two cars, better, drive two
used cars.  The mitsu is very heavy and feels it (the RT is 3200+ lbs in
Front Wheel Drive form, 3800+ if you want to get all that power down).  But
the eye opener is after 15,000 miles, the mitsu body just plain get loose.  I
have a great deal of respect for japanese 'bang for the buck', but if you're
willing to trade new japanese for slightly used 911, go for it.  The 87 - 89
Carrera is probaby the best of the breed, enjoying the G50 trans and
hydraulically actuated clutch (there's high-tech), plenty of power, and a
blast to drive. At about 100 mph, the mitsu starts to feel light in front,
and it certainly does not brake as well (I'm not talking statistics, but
feel). 
Buy what you will, but a test drive in a used mitsu will truly open your eyes
to the quality of the product.

Enjoy,
Peter Leckband
anybody going to Portland this year?

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 08:35:06 +0000
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Decisions..Decisions


Skater,

Stan and Michael have spoken words of great wisdom.  I have only two nits to
pick with what's already been said, and one new thing to consider.  Michael 
said:
 
> Styling: Lot's of sexy cars on the sales lots these days. The thirty-year old
> styling of the 911 looks its age when parked next to some of Japan's best.

That's truly the classic YMMV case!  I personally have found the 911 styling
to be timeless, and have been hopelessly smitten since the first one I saw,
on the streets of Wiesbaden, in November 1964 (I'm sure it was a 901, but
that's a lot of years, so...)

> Quality: BMW, MBZ, and even Honda come out on top in this category. But
> Porsche is a "hand built" motor car, right? Exactly, and the robots do it
> better.

This is another YMMV.  I've owned a couple of MBZs, and while both were
high quality cars, I've *never* seen fit *or* finish superior to my cab.

Finally, when you drive a 911, you have the satisfaction of knowing you are
driving one of a very select breed.  Along with one Ferrari or another, the
911 is the one car that will be on every knowledgable enthusiast's list of
the top ten sports cars ever made.  That's definitely a FWIW issue; which,
in the final analysis, is what the whole business of buying a sports car is
*all* about...

Bart Chambers, 
Wife Dora, 
'77 Feline Varmint Fexix, American Gray Tabby
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Quantum Syncro, (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 09:03:55 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Decisions, decisions

Michael959 wrote:

>The cars you have mentioned are all excellent choices. My recommendation to
>you; don't buy the Porsche. In virtually every category of
>comparison-handling, power, styling, quality, practicality, and ownership
>costs-the Porsche comes in second (or worse).

I'm sorry, but in my eyes, the Carrera is not a loser when compared to a
3000GT/300ZX/et al.  As far as handling goes, if you are a good enough
driver to discern (and fret) over the small differences in skidpad
ratings, etc., then more power to you.  For 95% of drivers out there,
the Carrera is more than capable.  IMHO, the "viperous" oversteering
characteristics of the 911 is somewhat of an urban legend nowadays -
it's not really that bad.  As for the power - something to consider is
the weight of the cars.  I don't have the numbers handy but I bet the 
911 is lighter than most of its competitors - that means alot.  Styling?
Subjective category.  Quality?  Look at 10 or even 20 year old 911s.
They seem to be holding up much better than - well just about every-
thing else.  Sounds like quality to me.  Practicality?  I driven 3000GTs,
etc.  Practicality is relative (don't give me no steenking cup holders!).
Ownership costs?  Factor in resale value and the whole picture changes.

Sorry for the line-by-line rebuttal, but I found it hard to believe these
T*d-like statements came from the owner of an '87 Carrera!  Maybe I'm
a glutton for punishment, but I'd pick the pcar over anything else in the
same price range.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: 02 Jan 95 10:53:26 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: traction issues, or 4wd

 
Mike Piera replies to Sam Halperin that
>if you apply power to a FWD car in a skid, you will simply go straight off
>the road.
 
It seems that the lawyers who engineer our products today prefer this to
going off the road backwards. If it goes off nose-first, it was obviously
the driver's fault. If it goes off tail-first, the Killer Car did it, and
we need to get the tabloid TV news crews to the scene as quickly as possible.
 
Me, I think we can use surplus lawyers as low-cost, renewable, replaceable
5 mph bumpers.
 
Pete

Date: 02 Jan 95 10:53:30 EST

Hi, Sam.
 
The best car marque book ever written is about Porsches. Get Karl
Ludvigsen's "Excellence was Expected", about $85 I think, and well over 800
pages of carefully researched history. It is the standard by which all other
car histories are judged. It was written in 1978, I think, and was never
updated, but it has never been beaten either as a general history.
 
There is a new 911 history book coming out this spring, with less of the
corporate history and more specific 911 history. "Porsche 911: Forever
Young" by Tobias Aichele. Look for it around April. It is up to date up to
the 1995 Carrera 4. and Tiptronic S transmission. About 400 pages.
 
Brett Johnson's "911 Restorer's Guide to Authenticity" covers some of the
appearance differences between models and years, but not the engineering and
mechanical stuff.
 
There are other good books out there, but most were written in the late 70s
and are threfore dated. Paul Frere's "Porsche 911" is a nuts and bolts
development history. Juergen Barth's "Porsche Book" has a few mistakes but
is a rough year-by-year guide to model differences.
 
The best and just about only book on how to tweak the thing once you have it
is "The 911 Performance Handbook" by Bruce Anderson.
 
Pete

Rudy Bartling is the only one that people I know have experience with. They
drive down from Ottawa to get him to work on their cars, which may (or may
not) mean anything.

Date: Mon, 02 Jan 1995 11:20:43 -0500 (EST)
From: "James L. Fry" <JFRY@UOFT02.UTOLEDO.EDU>
Subject: Chips for '86 928S

Hi,
I'm looking for some net wisdom on the subject of installing modified
ignition/fuel control chips on an '86 928S.  I am aware that there are
dramatic increases in power on turbos such as the 951 when chips are
used, but my understanding is that that effect is made primarily
through increase in the amount of boost and RPMs allowed by the
modified DME.  The '86 928S is not amenable to boost changes, so
how much improvement can be expected by just remapping the fuel/
ignition profiles?
Does anyone have any practical experience with chip modifications
on this engine?  Also, how do the Triad chips advertised in PANO
compare with the more common chips from Autothority?  The Triad
chips are selling for about 1/3rd the cost of the Autothority
chips.
Thanks for any information you may be able to give me.
Jim Fry
'86 928S

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 08:46:19 -0800
From: KimKnapp@ix.netcom.com (Maynard Knapp)
Subject: Re: High revving

>occasionally. The only way I could imagine them taking a "set" is if 
there
>is a carbon ridge deposited at the top of the upper ring travel, and if 
the
>car has been run exclusively at low revs and part throttle for zillions 
of
>miles (long enough to build up significant carbon) and then revved high 
and
>hard, so that intertia forces result in just enough stretch/flexing of 
stuff
>to put the top ring into the carbon by a few microns and thereby break 
a
>ring. That scenario is pretty farfetched anyway. And gas forces tend to 
act
>downward on three of the four strokes (the exception being the intake 
stroke).
> 
>

Peter,
	The way I always understood it (please correct me if I am 
wrong), carbon is a problem because it can get hot enough to glow and 
act like a glow plug causing the air/fuel mixture to ignite earlier than 
it should. This can cause knock and subsequent damage. I agree, however, 
that most modern engines have little problem running at low revs, in 
this sense, because of the EFI's efficient control of the air/fuel 
mixture such that it burns more thoroughly, even at low revs. I do agree 
with others about the bearing wear at lower revs though (due to the 
pressures of combustion at slow revs). I know that it is certain death 
to run my Cosworth engine at low revs in my 7. It also seemed to me that 
at the factory they told us not to run around in too high a gear with 
the 911(?)
				Kim

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 18:56:28 +0100 (MET)
From: Morten Christian Holmgreen <joker@diku.dk>
Subject: Decisions... Decisions...

Hi,

As to what car to buy? Since you're very concerned with acc. I've included
the test-values of a couple of the cars as well as other cars that might
be interesting. I know the 993 and a (almost) new 911C2 is quite expensive,
but it's interesting to compare these, since a few people claims the
Porsche's are the slowest in the flock, which they (in my experience)
definately is _not_. (I couldn't find the values for a stock 3.2, sorry)

The testvalues below are taken from the German magazine 'Auto, Motor und
Sport' which is the one of the most esteemed magazines in europe. (I don't
know if the BMW M3 has hit the american beaches)

All speed is measures in km/h. Weight is kg and measured in test. Price is
thousand DM and was the price, when the car was tested (without options).

(For all you americans with weird units :-) : 
 60km/h=37.3mph, 80=49.7, 100=62.1, 120=74.6, 160=99.4, 200=124.3, 
 1kg=2.2lbs. and 1DM=$0.65)

                      Porsche           Mazda  Toyota  Mitsub.  Nissan  BMW
                911C2   993     968     RX-7    Supra  GT3000   300ZX    M3

0-60             2.8     2.8                             2.9     3.1     3.0
0-80             4.3             4.9     4.6     4.4       
0-100            5.5     5.3     6.6     6.5     5.9     6.4     6.5     5.8
0-120            7.7     7.3             8.7     8.2     8.9
0-160           12.9    12.4            14.8    14.2    15.7    15.3    13.3
0-200           21.0    21.1    28.0    25.0    25.0    30.2    26.0    24.0

1Km             25.0    24.7    26.7    26.0    26.0    27.1    26.4    25.7

60-100 (4th)     6.9     6.1     9.1     6.1      -      8.7     6.8     6.6
60-100 (5th)      -      7.7      -       -      6.5      -       -       -

80-120 (5th)     9.7     8.2    11.4    10.6      -     11.6    10.9     8.8
80-120 (6th)      -     11.2      -       -      9.0      -       -       -

Topspeed        264     267     253     253     250     250     250     250

HP              250/    272/    240/    239/    330/    286/    283/    286/
by rpm          6100    6100    6200    6500    5600    6000    6400    7000
Torque          310/    330/    305/    294/    441/    407/    375/    320/
by rpm          4800    5500    4100    5000    4800    3000    3600    3600
Weight, empty   1398    1363    1412    1320    1640    1759    1642    1486

Kg/HP           5.59    5.01    5.88    5.52    4.97    6.15    5.80    5.20

Price, DM       103.5   125.7   89.8    85.5    106     98.5    88      83.0

Year/model      1990    1994    1992    1993    1994    1993    1991    1994


Compare this to for instance my 911 3.2. It's got 245HP and weighs
1250 kg. This means I have 5.1 Kg/HP - which is marginally less than a 
993, but better than a 911C2. (Agreed my car is a bit modified, but not 
much. It it, naturally, a euro Carrera (no cats))

In europe the 300XZ, 3000GT and RX-7 is normally not even compared with
the 911, but with the 968 where the performance is just about equal, 
with the 968 being a bit behind. Only the Toyota Supra is being compared
to the 911's...

I've tried a dragging against both a GT3000 and a 300ZX - none of them 
could keep up. I was about 40-50 meters in front of them when I hit 180 km/h.

On track I've also tried dragging a 911C2 and I was faster than that 

one too. Only marginally, but enough to pass him on a long straight. I won't 
begin to compare driving around the corners, since my 911 has a non-stock setup
(equally fast as a C2 with my narrow-body 3.2 targa).

I haven't tried driving against any of the other cars on track, so I will
not say anything about this..

Another thing is that it's easier (and _much_ cheaper) making a
turbo-charged car go faster. You can easily modify it by turning
up the boost preassure (Well, not all _that_ simple if you want it to
last, but you get the picture).

I'd strongly recommend trying to go for a spin in the cars you're
considering and letting the car "speak" to you.

About the price: Yes, the 911 is expensive. Yes, it's expensive
to maintain. However you also have a better resale value of the
car. The japanese metal depreciates _very_ quickly. I'm using
mine as an every day driver too, but it _is_ at a high cost.

I think that if you want better comfort, more gadgets and a newer
look (that will be outdated in 3 years), get a new japanese car.

But if you like Porsches: There can be only one...

Christian

911 Carrera 3.2 targa
911 Carrera 3.2 turbo-look coupe
- -- 
M. Christian Holmgreen / joker@diku.dk / mochmch@unidhp.uni-c.dk
M.Sc. student, University of Copenhagen, Dept. of Computer Science
"Human errors can only be avoided if one can avoid the use of humans"

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 14:02:03 -0500 (EST)
From: jjm98@acs.org (Joseph Malin)
Subject: Rain and an '84 944

I recently purchased a 1984 944.  The car has been working really well
 except for one problem.  Whenever I drive the car in the rain the floor
 becomes wet.  The passenger side is is far worse then the driver side 
and the front is worse then the back.  I have assumed since the floor 
becomes wet only when the car is driven, that the water is being splashed 
up from underneath.  Upon investigating the underbody, I saw only one 
obvious opening... but it looked suspiciously like a drainage hole.  
The hole is behind the front wheel and a bit towards the middle of the 
car.  Has anyone out there had a similar problem?  I am inclined to try 
blocking the hole, but it looks like it was placed there on purpose... 

 Any ideas would be appreciated.

Joe Malin
(jjm98@acs.org)

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 15:10:35 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Decisions...cont.

> disconcerting thing I heard was that the Porsche is not a great "dragster".
> Since this will be my fist real sports car, I wanted something to play with
> during my stoplight to stoplight hops

This is a Bad Idea in all cases. Any Porsche looks to most cops like
it has "TICKET ME" printed on the back window. It also is a sign of 
either a lack of maturity or a lack of knowledge. I'll assume it's a 
lack of knowledge, and offer something for you to think about:

True "sports cars" are all originally of European design. They were
designed around *road racing*, not drag racing, which is a purely American 
phenomenon. In road racing, where originally the goal was to cover some 
amazingly twisty chunk of European roadway, often with great elevation 
changes, between two places, you need a *BALANCED* car -- great handling, 
good power to weight ratio, acceptible acceleration, great high speed
stability. *THAT* is what the 911 has.

American "muscle cars" are designed for something completely different --
raw straight line acceleration. I once had a '73 Mustang with the '70 
Ford NASCAR SOHC 428 engine, making about 650 HP at the rear wheels as 
I was running it then. *UNBELIEVABLE* acceleration. But God help you if 
you needed to turn while underway, or for that matter STOP suddenly. 

As to your "need for speed" deal, I highly suggest that you join the PCA
and take your new 911 to autocross and drivers' education (learning to
drive at speed on race tracks) events, where you can get much more 
satisfation that you can possibly imagine. And no tickets.

Stan

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 18:17:11 -0500

Tim:

Unfortunately, you're probably out of luck unless you can get someone who saw
the jack or lift pad placed in the wrong position.
After you've complained to the Manager, I'd suggest you ask (or call
information) for the 800- Goodyear Customer  Relations number.  It probably
won't produce results, but at least you can do some "venting" with them about
their dealer.

Porsche dealers, even though they should know the car, can do the same thing.
 Although you have to learn the hard way, on routine things like leakers, I
remove the tire/wheel and carry it in....but they can still mess up the alloy
rims on tire removal unless you watch them.  Most "general service" shops
like Goodyear don't like customers in the service bay.

You wrote: 

>

>A prospective seller claimed they were an option.
>My questions are which is it, and if it was an option, is there an
>easy way to tell whether a car has it without the original window
>sticker or a VIN check with Porsche?
>
>Again, thanks for all tips -
>
>Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI
>...Still looking for an '87 Carrera Coupe...
>
>P.S.  And perhaps I finally got my Carrera spelling right!!
>Should have stuck with "911"...
>It's like I can never remember whether it's Ferrari, Ferarri,
>Ferrarri?  What the heck, at least Phord Preaube is a no-brainer.
>
>
Quick ck for limited slip is to jack up the back and turn one rear wheel 
if the other turns is the same direction then limited slip. If turns is 
the oposite direction no limited slip. A locker will also behave this 
way.

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 18:52:19 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Re: Decisions... Decisions

Skater,

Bart and Mike D. speak the truth. Issues like styling, quality, and resale
value are subjective. Even performance figures don't always present a clear
picture. I think the point I was making when I suggested that you not
purchase a Porsche was that the satisfaction of Porsche ownership comes from
more then the sum of  it's parts (or performance figures). It's a visceral
thing.

In your original post, you were attempting to quantify the merits of two nice
Japanese autos with those of a Porsche. Although it is difficult for me to
admit, I believe that the Porsche comes up short in many of the categories
that you mentioned. 

A little story: I have owned (and sold) several sailboats over the years.
Owning a sailboat is a lot like owning a Porsche (stay with me on this, it's
going somewhere, honest). When it comes time to sell my boat, occasionally an
interested party will tell me that he's undecided on whether to buy a
powerboat or a sailboat. In almost every case, I'll recommend that he
purchase a power boat. You see, sailing is a lot of work. But a sailboat
owner will sacrifice things like comfort, performance, and utility in order
to enjoy this specialized vessel in much the same way a Porsche owner will
likewise make a few sacrifices. If the buyer doesn't "get it" (the visceral
thing), he/she will be disappointed.  (Once a guy told me he couldn't decide
between buying a sailboat or a race horse. I sold him my boat anyhow, but
that's another story).

I think this explains why, in my town, there are always quite a few 2 - 6
month old Porsches on the market. 1) Rich guy buys new 911 because someone
told him that they're cool. 2) rich guy discovers that his Porsche is noisy,
hard riding, and cramped. 3) Rich guy trades in the 911 for an MBZ SL.

The pleasure I derive from my '87 Cabriolet cannot be measured on the skid
pad or at the stop-light drag race. It comes from knowing that I have the
privilege and good fortune to own one of the finest examples automotive
craftmanship ever produced. I changed my mind... get the Porsche! : )

Michael K.

"dragster".

 Ah, but the Porsche IS a great dragster. It just may not be the BEST
dragster. But then, 0 to 100 is only part of the equation.

Michael K.

This happened to my car also (86' 944). I had 4 dents caused by the lift.
I showed it to the shop and though they didn't deny it, they didn't offer 
to do anything about it either but sent me to one of their buddy's bodyshop.
Instead I had my insurance company look at it. It turns out that these shops 
buy insurance to cover cases like this. The shop ended up paying for any 
deductibles and I paid nothing and had it fixed at a bodyshop of my choice.

Reliable in Richmond

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 22:40:04 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Goodyear shop damage, need advice..

Guys,

This just plain sucks (pardon my language) all around.  I've worked in the
dealership retail side for about10 years, selling or servicing.  Tim, I feel
like this is a reflection on everyone in my industry.  Any competent shop
anticipates some errors and damage, we budget for it, sometimes we even feel
that we got screwed by a liberal application of 'goodwill'.  But the reason
for applying 'goodwill' is to earn your continued patronage.

The Better Business Bureau is a joke because no one check with them before
using a business.  Goodyear may have a system for resolving the dispute, but
I doubt it.  I believe you'll have to sue them, and I wish you the best of
luck (don't forget punative damages).

Perry is quite correct that a Porsche shop can make similar mistakes, but
they're much more likely to try to retain you as a customer and accept the
repair as their own, or negotiate a settlement.

Peter L

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 22:44:53 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Chips for '86 928S

Jim,

Have you tried contacting Kim Crumb?  He has an uncanny knack of making a 928
gofast.  Find him at 612/881-0113.

Peter Leckband

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 22:39:50 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Carerra Spoilers

According to the manufacturer. The things apparently do work.  Front spoilers
on most cars are effective at around 30 mph, the rear won't really make a
difference till about 65-70 mph.  Most people seeem to agree that there's no
sense installing the rear without the front (seems to make sense).

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 22:44:44 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Decisions..Decisions...

In a past life I've sold both the Porsche and the Dodge Stealth (a rebadged
Mitsu).  Before you make any decision, drive the two cars, better, drive two
used cars.  The mitsu is very heavy and feels it (the RT is 3200+ lbs in
Front Wheel Drive form, 3800+ if you want to get all that power down).  But
the eye opener is after 15,000 miles, the mitsu body just plain get loose.  I
have a great deal of respect for japanese 'bang for the buck', but if you're
willing to trade new japanese for slightly used 911, go for it.  The 87 - 89
Carrera is probaby the best of the breed, enjoying the G50 trans and
hydraulically actuated clutch (there's high-tech), plenty of power, and a
blast to drive. At about 100 mph, the mitsu starts to feel light in front,
and it certainly does not brake as well (I'm not talking statistics, but
feel). 
Buy what you will, but a test drive in a used mitsu will truly open your eyes
to the quality of the product.

Enjoy,
Peter Leckband
anybody going to Portland this year?

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 00:50:26 -0500 (EST)
From: tpep@epix.net
Subject: Re: Goodyear shop damage, need advice..



On Mon, 2 Jan 1995, Joe Hunter wrote:

> On Mon, 2 Jan 1995, Tim Flint wrote:
> > 
> > I went out to my 944 after getting a leaky tire fixed and immediately 
> > noticed a dent near the area that they put the jack. The manager denies 
> > that they did the damage, but I know every inch of my car. 
> > 
> 
> This happened to my car also (86' 944). I had 4 dents caused by the lift.
> I showed it to the shop and though they didn't deny it, they didn't offer 
> to do anything about it either but sent me to one of their buddy's bodyshop.
> Instead I had my insurance company look at it. It turns out that these shops 
> buy insurance to cover cases like this. The shop ended up paying for any 
> deductibles and I paid nothing and had it fixed at a bodyshop of my choice.
>  
	During the time I had worker at a Porsche dealer one of the things
I lerned was that 944s (and 924s as well) could only be properly placed on
an asymetrical type lift by using the lift extentions that raise the jack
pad hight.  In order to accomplish this the car must be jacked up slightly
with a floor jack before the lift's arms could be swung under the car. 
Otherwise the lifts arms will contact the rockers before the pads can get
to the jack points.  Unfortunately, many shop are either ingnorant to this
or too lazy.  Yes, Porsche dealers included. 
  You may want to point this out to the service manager or whoever is in
charge before the work is done on your car. 

Tim P

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 11:48:12 +0000
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: Double Clutching Explanation


Jon gives a very clear explanation about double declutching. However, the
bit which I have never understood is why you need to put the car into
neutral *and release the clutch* while you are blipping the throttle. Why
can you not do this when you have the clutch depressed *during* the
downshift.

>    Car traveling in 4th gear approaches a 3rd gear corner
>    Driver brakes with ball of foot (toe)
>    Simultaneously depresses clutch and puts car into neutral and release
>    clutch

This is the bit I'm not sure about. Why do you have to (a) put the car
into neutral and (b) release the clutch? Why not just depress the clutch
at this point ...

>    While still braking, driver blips throttle with heel to bring engine
>    speed up to expected transmission speed in 3rd gear.

... do this ...

>    Driver depresses clutch and downshifts into 3rd

... and then just downshift (clutch is still depressed) before ...

>    Driver releases clutch and turns into corner.


	Please note that this is a request for enlightenment and is not a
flame!! Reading back, I think my problem is that I don't fully understand
the difference between "clutch depressed" and "car in neutral" and the
different effects which these two things (both of which remove the
transmission from the driven wheels) affect the cars performance.

Philip Katz                                     Katz_P_M@bt-web.bt.co.uk

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 8:42:29 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: RE: oil pressure high when cold!

  >I upgraded my '78 SC to the Carerra tensioners a couple of months ago.  
  >I noticed a small increase in oil pressure, but only up to between 4 
  >and 5, never higher.  Martin Walker noticed a similar increase to yours 
  >in a note he posted in early November.  Could be a difference between 
  >the '78 and 82-83 year engines?  I didn't hear if he found a solution 
  >or determined for sure if this was a problem.

I have an '82 911 SC, I have the pressure fed tensioners, a very clean
engine (at least inside).  It's in the low 20's today and I'm running
15w30 castrol (soon to be 5w30 for winter).  When I started the car 
this am the oil pressure pegged at above 5.  Backed the car up about
20 feet then idled for about 2 minutes - oil pressure down to 4 bar.
Oil pressure continues to drop as the oil warms.  Arriving at work
10 mins later the oil temp is 1/2 way to the first hash mark and the
pressure is 1 bar at idle, and with rpm to 5 bar near redline.  I have
noticed that above idle the oil pressure is a little higher than
before I put on the tensioners - ~1 bar more at redline.  BTW, I run
with my oil level about 2/3 of the cockpit gauge when it's warmed up etc.
