------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 13:58:23 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: RE: Double Clutching Explanation


Phil Katz writes

| Please note that this is a request for enlightenment and is not a
| flame!! Reading back, I think my problem is that I don't fully understand
| the difference between "clutch depressed" and "car in neutral" and the
| different effects which these two things (both of which remove the
| transmission from the driven wheels) affect the cars performance.

I think that the problem here is that most people think that
the clutch is the only discontinuity in a power train, however
the clutch, input and output of a transmission are all very 
seperate beasties. People tend to regard the transmission 
as an single thing rather than several systems with dual feedback
loops that relate the input and output sides in strong and weak senses.

Essentially the synchros in a transmission transmit "information" in the
form of power that syncronises the rotational speed of the input and
output sides of the transmission, two distinct sub-systems, that
have the ability to be strongly linked and weakly linked. All this
is independent of the clutch. The clutch only exists because 
internal combustion engines are crap at producing torque at
low (zero) revs. If internal combustion engines had the same power
characteristics as electric motors (max torque available at zero
RPM!), we could dispense with clutches completely. As it is the
clutch is just there to stop the engine stalling when you start off,
everything else it does is just a reflection of how inconvenient 
a clutch is, and how inadequate the ubiquitous internal combustion engine is
for road transport applications.

Consider the following model.

When the clutch is out (engaged) and the car is in neutral,
the engine is spinning the input side of the transmission.

When the clutch is in (disengaged), the engine spins the clutch plate
but it is not engaged with the transmission or the clutch.

This means that when you blip the throttle with the clutch
out and the engine in neutral, you are spinning up the input 
side of the transmission, this means that you can match
the rotational speed of the power train with the output
side of the transmission which has a direct connection to
the rear wheels. The only reason you can spin up the
input side of the transmission is because the input is not meshed with
the output because you are in neutral. The gear selector directly
meshes the imput and output halves of the transmission, when meshed
the input and output rotation speed is exactly equal. The synchros
indirectly match the rotational speed of the input and output
sides, thus when you need to engage the input and output sides,
they magically happen to be rotating at the same speed! This is
what I mean by strong and weak linkage between the input and output
side of a transmission.

The syncros bleed power across the input and output elements of
the transmission and spin up the input side automatically in order 
match the input and output rotational speed of the transmission. You might
get the impression that you are matching the engine speed with
the rotational speed of the road wheels when for instance you
change down from 5th to 4th, This is not directly true, what you are actually 
doing is matching the engine speed with the rotational speed of the input 
side of the transmission, because the syncros have spun up the input side
to match the rotational speed of the output side and thus the road wheels.

If this did not happen, you would need to double de-clutch. This means
that the input side of the transmission has to be matched with the output
side before a gear is selected. This can only be done in neutral
with the clutch out so that the engine is driving the input side of the 
transmission. Because the input and output are not meshed, there is
no strong linkage between them, and because there are no synchros,
then it is up to the intrepid motorist to perform the task of
synchronising the input and ouput sides before a gear can 
be selected.

Before someone figured out how to engineer input-output syncromesh,
all gearboxes required double de-clutching. Porsche were one of the
first manufacturers to come up with a workable syncromesh, on the
356 I think. 

The reason why people double de-clutch on a syncromesh tranmission
is to save wear on the synchros. I know that it is common for
the synchros to wear out quite fast on pre G50 transmission
911 (915 transmission), hence the number of "why is my pre-87 911
impossible to get into first or second unless stationary" posts.
The G50 is a tougher beast, but I don't know if the synchros wear out
before the rest of the transmission or not.

You might notice in your 911 owners manual it suggests that in
very cold weather that you should depress the clutch when starting from
cold. This means that the starter does not have to drive the input side of
the transmission in cold, sticky, viscous oil, and thus does less work.
It also indicates that when the clutch is engaged that the input side of the
tranmission is active.

Further, you might have noticed that it is difficult to engage
reverse while moving forwards. Well, there is no syncro for reverse
because sane people do not what to go directly from forwards to 
backwards without stopping in between. I suspect that if you did
want to, double de-clutching might do the trick. It is a matter
of academic interest to know whether anyone on the list has 
ever performed this experiment and could enlighten us with the
results of shifting into reverse at 150 MPH and dumping the clutch.
If the momentum of the vehicle was sufficient, and your clutch was very good, 
it might be possible for the engine to be driven backwards for a very brief 
instant, before the whole power train self destructed and you had a spectacular
accident. Perhaps we could get T*d to check this one out for us, but
then again he probably has a synchromesh on reverse on his 911 and therefore
does not need to double de-clutch to change into reverse at 150 MPH, and thus
is unable to prove the basis of my hypothesis, but merely the outcome.

Please note that this is a conceptual model rather than an engineering
one, so I can't promise that it matches the real world so no flames please.
I am an econmomist and computer person and would not recogise a G50
gearbox or synchro if you hit me on the head with it (ouch!) However if you are 
talking about input/output models and finite state machines you are talking
my language.

I hope that this explodes the black box of the 911 transmission
literally in the case of the "flat out in 5th, shift into reverse"
scenario, and figuratively as well.

Regards

Ben

Two cats, one Porsche

################################################################
# Ben Evans, <Ben.Evans@london.sbi.com>                        #
# Salomon Brothers International                               #
# Victoria Plaza, 111 Buckingham Palace Road, London, England. #
################################################################

For car washing purposes the the spoiler is great - its
the only flat place on the car.  I put my wax can,
Windex bottle, towel, chamios, etc  on it.

As far as a quick visual check for spoiler originality,
I believe factory installed/original always had the louvers
painted black - not body color.  I.e. a spoiler with body
colored louvers is probably not original.

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 10:14:55 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 944 windshield washer bottle


>Over the weekend I was working on the 944's dead washer system. Removed and 
>replaced the wipers, check valves, cleaned the hoses and nozzles. 
>Unfortunately, also found out that the bottle has a leak, of course 
>somewhere around the bottom, facing the wheelwell where I cannot get to it 
>without removing the bottle. From the look of it, the removal requires more 
>than just unbolting the bottle itself. The HAYNES manual is of no use for 
>this operation.
>
>Can anyone provide tips on removing the bottle? Any tips on repairing the 
>bottle?
>
>Thanks,
>
>Rolando Saldana
>
Rolando:
	The water bottle comes out by doing 4 or 5 screws. Some of these
are accessible from the bottom. I think I had to loosen the headlight motor
to let the bottle drop. It comes out from the bottom. 

I also had a leak in mine. I used a Dremel tool to actually make the leak
larger (deeper). If you try to patch it by just applying something over
it, it will leak since they usually crack and the goo will not stick to
the outside of the bottle. I actually went through the side of the bottle.

I made the crack into an elongated hole and filled it with RTV silicone
sealer. Its been about 3 months with no leaks! Make sure to realign your
headligth mechanism. I think I had to remove the HL motor. Like I said,
its been like 3 months...

Hope this helps.

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689

'85 Guards Red 944 (The Beast) Waiting for a valve transplant!
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 95 10:49:15 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: double clutching

> | From: John Lupien  <lupienj@wal.hp.com>
> | > The thread on double clutching seems to have missed the obvious:
> | > double clutching is meant to reduce the wear and tear on the
> | > transmission synchronizers.
> | And the rest of the drivetrain.
> | Clutch friction surfaces in particular,
> | but it reduces the shock loads on the
> | whole thing.
> Double clutching itself (the act of putting the shift in neutral and
> letting the clutch out, setting the engine revs, then pushing the
> clutch back in to complete the shift) does nothing for the rest
> of the drivetrain. The trans is in neutral when this is done.
> How could it affect the rest of the drivetrain?

By matching revs with it. It's the moment that you actually engage
the clutch, in the gear you want to be in, that it matters. The part
of the drivetrain between the fan pulley and the transmission input
shaft (plus whatever additional gears and shafts are connected & spinning
when the trans is in neutral and the clutch engaged) gets spun up to match
the revs of the part of the drivetrain that connects to the wheels. So when
you finally do engage the clutch with the desired gear engaged, there isn't
a mismatch to be absorbed.

> What does help the rest of the drivetrain is to set the engine
> RPM when letting the clutch out after the gearchange has been
> completed. And this can certainly be done without double
> clutching.

This does not match revs between the clutch output shaft (transmission
input shaft, clutch friction disks, etc) and everything else. Sure you can
match revs without double-clutching, but when you do double-clutch you have
already matched revs.

- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 07:58:27 -0800 (PST)
From: Megan Halstead <clyde@u.washington.edu>
Subject: RE: Double Clutching Explanation



On Tue, 3 Jan 1995, Ben Evans wrote:

> 
> Phil Katz writes
> 
> | Please note that this is a request for enlightenment and is not a
> | flame!! Reading back, I think my problem is that I don't fully understand
> | the difference between "clutch depressed" and "car in neutral" and the
> | different effects which these two things (both of which remove the
> | transmission from the driven wheels) affect the cars performance.
 
 - Explanation deleted -

> Further, you might have noticed that it is difficult to engage
> reverse while moving forwards. Well, there is no syncro for reverse
> because sane people do not what to go directly from forwards to 
> backwards without stopping in between. I suspect that if you did
> want to, double de-clutching might do the trick....

 - Transmission hash recipe deleted -
> 
> ################################################################
> # Ben Evans, <Ben.Evans@london.sbi.com>                        #
> # Salomon Brothers International                               #
> # Victoria Plaza, 111 Buckingham Palace Road, London, England. #
> ################################################################
> 
The one situation where you can (and should) double (de)clutch into 
reverse is when your car is already rolling backwards and you want to be 
able to apply more rearward power.  In this situation, the output gears 
which mesh with the input side when 'reverse' is selected are turning in 
the correct direction. 

Miklin Halstead
69 Beetle "Daily driver."
76 Audi 100LS "Send me parts-lots of 'em."
8? 944 "Not yet."

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 11:16:44 -0500
From: StreakN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porsche AG Stock


>> If it's an obsession for the marque, I'm sure many would be thrilled to
offer
>> you some  Porsche A.G. stock at original public offering  issue price. 

>Interesting stuff, this Porsche AG stock -- it offers no voting rights,
>it pays no dividends. Most of the owners seem to keep it for
>numismatic value, not as a "real" investment... Still, wouldn't
>*YOU* like to have a share -- framed, hanging over the engine >rebuild
>bench...

>Stan

Actually, Porsche AG preferred does normally pay a dividend, though it hasn't
for the past two years. However, because of nonpayment, preferred
shareholders have received voting rights. Porsche may "cure" the situation by
resuming dividend payments. Porsche lost 150 mm deutschemarks ($96+ million)
 in its last fiscal year.

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 95 08:24:40 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Seat Question

Hi All-

Is it possible that early and late 911 seats are not 
interchangeable, at lesat not easily?  Here's the situation.

The '72 911 I'm restoring has what I think are called Low-
Back
seats, made by Recaro.  The parts manual indicates that 
there were two seat types available for the '72, my Low-
Backs, and a "Sport" model.  My seats are more-or-less like 
a plush chair rather than like a bucket.

My seats need to be recovered.  However, I have an 
opportunity to buy two leather seats from an '84 911, in 
immaculate condition.  These are more bucket-like.  But the 
distance between the rails (i.e., the width) on my seats is 
about 18", while the newer seats have rail mounting bolt 
holes that are 16" apart. Thus the newer seats are narrower 
by about 2".  The newer seats also appear to be lower.

Does anyone know if there are adapters available?  Or if it's 
even worth considering buying or fashioning an adapter?

Thanks.  And Happy New Year to Everyone!

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 08:34:48 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles FAQ for January '95

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+             PORSCHEPHILES - FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS              +
+                  (last revised December 22, 1994)                   +
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This is the FAQ for the Porschephiles list.  It is posted regularly,
once a month at or near the start of the month.  There are undoubtedly
additions, changes, etc., needed.  Your input is solicited in improving
the FAQ.  Send any comments to the address at the end of the FAQ.

Changes this month include updating of some of the information about
Stan Hanks (our esteemed moderator), extensive additions to the list of
Porsche models (with special thanks to Kevin Pickell), mention of the
Porsche Market Letter, and some other minor edits of existing items.

Happy New Year to everyone!

=======================================================================

Questions answered in this FAQ:
  What is Porschephiles?
  How does Porschephiles work?
  Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?
  What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?
  How do I submit administrative requests?
  Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?
  What else is available in the tta.com archives?
  Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
  What about splitting the list?
  What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?
  Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?
  I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?
  How can I find out more about the car I own?
  What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?
  What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
  What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?
  What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?
  What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?
  What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?
  What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?
  Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?
  Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
  Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?
  Who maintains this FAQ?

=======================================================================

What is Porschephiles?

     Porschephiles is an Internet mailing list centering on the Porsche
automobile in all of its incarnations.

=======================================================================

How does Porschephiles work?

     This list is being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming 
mail to the whole list at once.  The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  To send a message to the 
whole list, mail to

                porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative 
issues, send mail to

                porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request"
address.  The list is also available as a digest, where you get a
compilation of the day's messages once per day, rather than getting
all of the individual messages. This seems to be a win for people with
slow mail links or who are just too busy to stay current. If you want
to convert to (or from) the digest, send mail to the "porschephiles-
request" address above.

=======================================================================

Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?

     The moderator is:
          Stanley P. Hanks
          Principal, 
          Technology Tranfer Associates
          P.O. Box 2087
          Bellaire TX 77402-2087

     (He got tired of living in Houston, TX and working in Edison, NJ,
so moved back...)

          Houston: e-mail: stan@tta.com, 
                   voice:  (713) 661-2084 

     His Porsches currently include:  
          '64 356 SC (daily driver)
          '74 914 2.0 (SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)

=======================================================================

What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?

     There are a lot of members on the list.  It's small enough to be 
effective, and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and
sets of experience.  You ought to be able to ask any question you like,
although it's probably a good idea to look it up yourself if you can and
save the net bandwidth.  Keep the diversity of the list in mind before 
you decide to not ask a question, or if you get flamed for asking an 
"obvious" question.  Diversity -- it's a *feature*...

=======================================================================

How do I submit administrative requests?

    Send them, and ONLY them, to the "porschephiles-request" address 
(porschephiles-request@tta.com), or to Stan directly.  

=======================================================================

Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?

     Archives are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/archives.
Archives in six subdirectories (90, 91, 92, 93, 94, 95) each of which 
has the archives for that year, in UNIX compress format.  There are no
older archives available.  While it might seem like a good idea when
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before,
there are OVER 13 MEG of archives.  DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE
TIME.  And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or Stan
may have to take access away.  Also, DO NOT ask Stan to mail you
archives.  To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY
mode in FTP.  On receipt you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program,
or equivalent, to restore to textual format.  Mac and Windows versions
of "uncompress" are available via FTP from /pub/porschephiles/programs.


=======================================================================

What else is available in the tta.com archives?

     FAQs: In the FAQs directory there is this FAQ and there are FAQs 
for specific Porsche models (so far there's one for 914s and one for 
the Carrera models -- feel free to contribute one on YOUR favorite 
Porsche).  These are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/FAQs.
 
     Images: All sorts of Porsche images for your viewing pleasure,
mostly in .gif format.  There's also a directory called "UPLOAD" where 
you can deposit your own images for inclusion in the collection.  If 
you add any images, please include a file called "from.<username>", 
where <username> is your login ID, that describes the files if possible.

     PCA racing info: The PCA Club Racing Newsletter is now on-line,
thanks to the tireless efforts of the editor.  This is available by FTP 
in the directory tta.com:/pub/porschephiles/PCA/ClubRacing.  The 
newsletters are available both in PostScript and in Windows Write 
format.  If this is useful to you, send your thanks to the editor, Tom,
at "tt911@ibm.net".
 
     MiscInfo: Various other interesting bits of information potentially
useful to Porschephiles.
 
     Survey: The questionaire and results (when compiled) of the 
membership survey.

     And as usual, Monthly-Update, RULES, and Whos-Who, which get 
updated on a monthly basis.

=======================================================================
 
Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
 
     Yes, WWW access is through http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html.
The FTP restriction above applies to major downloading of stuff from the
archives, not WWW access.  Suggestions for improving the WWW pages
would be welcomed, as well as experienced help in doing so.

=======================================================================

What about splitting the list? 

     Various proposals surface now and then about splitting the list 
into components based on car model, activity types, or other divisions?  
Stan's reply to these suggestions is as follows:  

     "I just want all you Faithful Readers to understand: there are only 
two votes that count. Mine, and anyone who's willing to pay me to change 
my mind or operation or whatever.
 
     "Posted rates around here are $75/hr for automotive engineering 
projects, $125/hr for information technology consulting, and $2k/day for 
expert witness engagements.  Just so you know where the bidding starts..."

     In other words, the list *WILL* **NOT** be split.

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?

     The Who's Who is a listing of those who receive Porschephiles and 
who have responded to the offer to be listed.  It lists the owners, 
their state of residence, their car's year and model, and their net
address.  The list is updated when people send Stan the information,
and when he has time to update the list.  He sends it out on a monthly
basis to the list.  Only Porsches are listed, so don't send your Alfa
Zagato or your Buick GN in to be included.  Send submissions or changes 
to "porschephiles-request@tta.com."

=======================================================================

Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?

     Several different clubs are available, depending on your interests
and location:

          Porsche Club of America.
          P.O. Box 10402
          Alexandria VA 22310
          Telephone: +1 703 922-9300

The main US Porsche club; see below for more information.

          Porsche Club of Great Britain
          Ayton House
          West End
          Northleach
          Gloucestershire
          England GL54 3HG
          Telephone: +44 451 860792
          FAX: +44 451 860011

The Porsche club in Great Britain, obviously.

          Porsche Owners Club
          P.O. Box 9000-277
          Seal Beach, CA  90740
          +1 310 784-5653.

Based in Southern California, the focus of POC is time trialing and 
racing.

          356 Registry Inc.
          27244 Ryan Rd.
          Warren, MI, 48092
          Telephone +1 313 558-3692

For 356 enthusiasts around the world.  $20 per year and cheap at twice
the price (Vic Skirmants' racing column is worth that, as are the
classifieds).  5000 happy members can't be wrong!

          914 Owner's Association
          100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
          Palm Springs CA 92262
          Telephone: +1 619 325-6583

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries.  Dennis Deeds published the 
club newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly.  Membership is $22 a 
year.

          Early 911S Registry
          PO Box 363
          West Point, PA 19486
          Telephone: +1 215 652-701 (day), +1-215-287-5083 (evening)

Contact Vern Lyle.  Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter.  
Dedicated to all early 911S models.

     A more complete list of Porsche US regional and other special 
interest groups, from the January 1994 Porsche Panorama, is on tta.com,
in /pub/MiscInfo/sigs.

=======================================================================

I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?

     The Club affiliates you with a local region based on where your
ZIP code falls on their territory map.  You *CAN* request to join a
specific region, and you can specify an affilate region or dual
membership in another region.  The local regions put on many different
events, some social, some educational, some driving or compeition
oriented.  The annual gathering of the whole membership, the Porsche
Parade, features competition for the national championships in many
events, seminars, a GREAT goodie store, and one of the most fun weeks
you'll experience.

     To join, you need to have a Porsche VIN number and be able to claim 
you're an owner, a co-owner, or hold a lease on a Porsche.  That may
seem restrictive, particularly if you want to join the club to get
access to Panorama, the club magazine, for purposes of FINDING a car...
In such case, it's suggested that you purchase a modest fraction of a
friend's car for say $5 or so, hence becoming a co-owner.  Just don't
tell them you did that or where you got the idea...

     Once you have a VIN number, there are four ways to join:

     1) Send a letter to the national office saying that you want to 
join, with your name, address, car info and a check for $36 to:

	Porsche Club of Americia.
	P.O. Box 10402
	Alexandria VA 22310

     2) Call them up at +1 703 922-9300, roughly between 9:00 to 5:00
EST (GMT - 6).  If you have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number
handy, you can do it over the phone.  (Otherwise, they'll send you an
application which you can mail in with your check.)  This is the FASTEST
way, and if you need to be a member *RIGHT NOW* to go to an event that
is members only, this is your best bet.  Don't count on using this
method the week of or before Parade...

     3) find someone active in your local region.  *MANY* of the regions
are represented on the Porschephiles list, so that's a good place to
start.  Once you have found someone, get them to put you in touch with
the local region membership chair, they can give you the form, and off 
you go.

     4) National membership chair Nann Weissenberger is also on the
list, and is reachable via e-mail at "nannw@aol.com".  She'd be more 
than happy to help you out.

=======================================================================

How can I find out more about the car I own?

     Porsche Cars North America, for a fee of $20, will research the 
original bill of sale for your car and give you a Certificate of 
Authenticity stating the facts and figures for the car as it was 
delivered to the dealer.  If you're interested, contact: 
          Howard Adams
          PCNA
          P.O. Box 30911
          Reno Nevada 89520-3911
Include a copy of your title or registration as proof of ownership.
It takes 2-3 weeks depending on backlog.  

     It's also possible to get dealers to run a search for warranty and
other repairs for your car.  Some authorized dealers will search PCNA 
files for warranty and other maintenance records on specific cars.  
This data base apparently only goes back to sometime in the mid-1980s.  
It's not known how widespread this practice is among dealers; some will 
search only for warranty work done, while others also provide 
information about routine maintenance and repairs.  Ask your dealer.

=======================================================================

What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?

     The following list was extracted from _Illustrated_Porsche_Buyers_
Guide_, _Porsche_Specials_, _Cars_Are_My_Life_, and _We_At_Porsche_.  
It includes only more or less complete automobiles designed by
Ferdinand Porsche or by the Porsche factory.  Components (engines,
transmissions, etc.) have not been included.  Additions and corrections
are welcomed:

      "1" - Lohner-Porsche electric car, 1900; Ferdinand's first design,
            but not part of the "official" model sequence.
       7  - Wanderer passenger car design, 1930; the first official
            model, chosen to convey impression of prior experience.
       8  - Wanderer 8-cylinder saloon with 3.25-liter engine, 1931.
       9  - Second Wanderer 8-cylinder prototype, 1931.
      12  - Zundapp small car, 5-cylinder radial engine.
      22  - Auto Union Grand Prix car, 1932-1937.
      24  - Zundapp three-wheel vehicle.
      27  - Mathis-Ford Saloon.
      32  - NSU prototype (Volkswagen forerunner).
      52  - Auto Union sports car, 1934.
      60  - Original Volkswagen prototype, renamed KdF (Kraft durch 
            Freude, or strength through joy, by Adolf Hitler), basis 
            for the postwar Volkswagen, 1934-1941; the 60K10, a variation 
            of the 60, was a sports coupe built for the later cancelled 
            Berlin-Rome race, 1939. 
      61  - Another Volkswagen prototype, a narrower version of the 60.
      62  - Volkswagen-Kubelwagen (bucket car) prototype.
      64  - KdF-based sports car, 1937-1938.
      68  - Volkswagen Post office delivery van.
      80  - Mercedes-Benz land speed record car, 1938-1939.
      81  - Volkswagen Medium Van.
      82  - KdF-based military Kubelwagen, 1939-1940.
      86  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen with 4wd.
      87  - 4-wheel-drive version of Kubelwagen, 1939-1941.
      88  - Volkswagen Bus on Kubelwagen Chassis.
      97  - Daimler-Benz heavy lorry.
      98  - Volkswagen amphibious car.
     100  - Leopard tank.
     101    Tiger tank.
     110  - Volkspflug Small Tractor.
     111  - Small Tractor (2-cylinder engine).
     112  - Further development of 111 above.
     113  - Further development of 111 above.
     114  - F-wagen, 1.5-liter sports car, 1938-9.
     128  - KdF-based amphibian Schwimmwagen, 1940-1941.
     130  - Tiger Tank (Jagpanzer) "Ferdinand".
     138  - Volkswagen Amphibious Car (version 2).
     155  - Half Track version of Kubelwagen.
     164  - Six-wheel lorry.
     166  - Volkswagen amphibious car (production version).
     182  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen (production version).
     187  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen 4wd (production version).
     205  - 180-ton Maus tank, 1942; two built, never saw action.
     245  - 18-ton multipurpose tank, 1942.
     293  - Caterpillar tractor.
     312  - Tractor with petrol engine.
     323  - 11-hp diesel tractor, 1946.
     328  - Tractor, 28 hp. engine.
     340  - Wheelbarrow.
     355  - Volkswagen delivery van.
     356  - The original Porsche sports car, the first to wear the
            Porsche name, 1948-1965; various engine and drivetrain 
            components and numerous styling variations existed.
     360  - Cisitalia 4-wheel-drive Grand Prix car, 1947-1948.
     370  - Cisitalia 1.5-liter sports/touring car, 1947.
     425  - 20 bhp diesel tractor.
     514  - LeMans car, also called 356SL, 1951.
     524  - Improved 356 prototype with mechanical injection, 1951;
            not economically feasible to take to production.
     530  - Experimental 4-passenger Porsche, 1951-1952.
     534  - Volkswagen Small sports car.
     540  - Porsche America Roadster.
     541  - Special sports version of 356.
     542  - Studebaker Saloon 1952-1954.
     550  - Mid-engine, 2-seat sports/racing car, the car that James 
            Dean died in, 1954; the 550A was a redesigned 550 with a
            tubular space frame, 1956.
     597  - Jagdwagen (Hunter) 4-wheel-drive vehicle, 1954-1955.
     621  - Porsche single-cylinder tractor (allgaier).
     622  - 2-cylinder tractor.
     623  - 3-cylinder tractor.
     624  - 4-cylinder tractor.
     633  - Studebaker saloon prototype.
     645  - Sports/racing car, "Mickey Mouse," 1956.
     675  - Small Volkswagen 1955-1959.
     691  - Porsche 550 RS (1956)
     695  - Porsche predevelopment (T7) for 911.
     702  - One man Helicopter.
     718  - Bergspyder sports/racing car (RSK), 1957; the 718/2 was a 
            1.5-liter single-seat racing car (F-2), 1959.
     726  - Volkswagen Saloon 1958.
     728  - Small Volkswagen 1957-1961.
     737  - Porsche outboard motor.
     753  - Porsche 1.5-liter 8-cylinder Formula 1.
     764  - Volkswagen 6-cylinder saloon.
     787  - Grand Prix car, 1961.
     804  - Grand Prix car, 1962.
     806  - Leopard Tank.
     814  - Leopard Tank.
     901  - Prototype 6-cylinder sports car, basis for 911, 1963; 
            changed to 911 for production because of conflict with 
            Peugeot numbering scheme.  6 prototypes built.
     904  - Mid-engine competition GT coupe, with various engines in 
            1963-1964, 100+ built, some for street use. 
     906  - Competition sports coupe (space frame), 1966-1967.
     907  - Sports/racing coupe, various iterations, 1967-1968.
     908  - 3-liter, 8-cylinder competition car, various bodies,
            1968-1970.
     909  - 2-liter hill climb spyder, 1968.
     910  - Sports racing coupe, different configurations, 1966-1968.
     911  - Porsche's flagship.  Built from 1964 (excluding the '63
            901 prototype) in numerous variations through the 993.  
            Rear-engined, air-cooled, boxer six-cylinder engine.
            Many engine variations have existed through its long life, 
            from the original 2-liter car to the 3.8-liter RS.
     912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
            in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1966 through
            1969; 912E in '76 was a revival with engine from the 914.
     914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between
            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6
            was a Porsche-built variant with a two-liter 911 engine
            inserted in place of the four-cylinder engine and other
            refinements.
     916  - Projected 2.4-liter version of 914/6, 1971.  Was apparently
            used in competition by the factory.  Also, a few examples 
            of an 8-cylinder (908-based) version supposedly exist.
     917  - 12-cylinder competition car, famous for Le Mans and CanAm
            victories; various iterations, 1969-1973.
     924  - The first of the water-cooled front-engine cars, built from
            1976 to 1988.  Originally with a four-cylinder, Audi-derived
            engine; updated in mid-86 as the 924S with the 944 drivetrain;
            has the best aerodynamic shape of any street Porsche.
     928  - The high-end car produced from 1978 to present, V8 in the
            front, water-cooled, has grown from an original 4.5-liter
            to 5.4 today.
     930  - Turbocharged 911, homologation and street version of the
            racing 934.
     931  - Turbocharged 924, sold in 1980-1982.
     934  - Group 4 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1975-1976.
     935  - Group 5 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1976.
     936  - Group 6 turbocharged spyder, 1976.
     937  - 924 Carrera GT.
     939  - 924 Carrera GT Le Mans.
     944  - Front-engined, water-cooled inline four-cylinder car, with
            nearly perfect 50/50 weight bias.  Sixteen-valve and
            turbocharged versions were produced.  Produced from 1982
            through 1991. 2.5-liter displacement, except for a 2.7-liter
            eight-valve 944 model in 1989 and the 3-liter 944S2.
     951  - The turbo version of the 944.  Built from 1985 to 1991.
     956  - GT racing car, loosely based on 911; 1982-1983.
     959  - Supercar 911 derivative; 2.85-liter, four-valve, twin cam,
            dual turbochargers, all-wheel drive; not street-legal in US.
     962  - GT racing car based loosely on 911; used in endurance racing 
            and IMSA GTP; 1984.
     964  - The 911 Carrera 2 and Carrera 4, introduced in 1989.
     968  - Rebirth of the 944 series in 1992 with revised styling.  A 
            noteworthy feature is variable valve timing.
     986  - The Boxster, due in Sept. '96, the newest hope for Porsche's 
            future.
     993  - The latest iteration of the 911, introduced in 1994.

    1764  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1834  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1866  - Volkswagen successor.
    1906  - Leopard tank.
    1966  - Volkswagen small car prototype.
    2539  - "Save" ambulance.
    2567  - "Orbit" fire fighting system.
    2708  - Cart.

=======================================================================

What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
 
     General answer:  Buy the latest one you can afford of the model you
like.  Within models, there are certain years that are generally thought
of as more reliable or otherwise desirable, and others that have proved
troublesome over the years.  If you have questions about a particular
model, ask the list.  (We are looking for contributors to write about 
specific models.  Contributions, which may be too lengthy to include 
here, will be stored at tta.com and available via FTP.  Dave Darling has
gotten the ball rolling with a summary for the 914.  Feel free to 
contribute regarding your favorite model.)

=======================================================================

What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?

     There are several kinds of events organized and run by Porsche
clubs and organizations:

     Autocrosses.  These normally occur in a large parking lot or other 
relatively flat, open area.  The lot is filled with traffic cones that 
define a course.  Only 2 or 3 cars are on the course at the same time, 
and never at the same location on the course.  You race against the 
clock, and your times are compared to others in your class.  Classes 
are organized so that you compete against similarly-configured cars of 
about equal capability, ranging from box-stock to extensively modified.
Autocrossing is probably the safest and cheapest way to go fast in your 
Porsche (or any other car for that matter).  In some parts of the 
country, autocrosses are called slaloms.

     Time Trials.  These are also timed events, but they usually take
place on an actual race course.  They are often held in conjunction
with Track Events.  The time trial, like the autocross, is not against
other cars at the same time but against a clock.

     Driver's Education.  These events are held at a race track (but not
during a formal race meeting).  Multiple cars are on the track at the 
same time.  Instructors ride with the students, who are taught to drive 
at speed safely.  The US PCA has a basic set of rules and various PCA 
regions have their own rules which don't differ much from each other.  
Usually, the only modification to the car is a fire extinguisher that is
mounted metal to metal.  Students and instructors must wear an approved 
helmet.  

     PCA Club Racing.  This is racing in the traditional sense, in that
there's a full complement of cars, a definite start and finish, and
head-to-head racing.  The concept is similar to the various vintage
racing events that are becoming so popular; the idea is to preserve your
car and those of others while racing against each other.  If you don't 
race responsibly, you are not allowed to race.  There's a policy
governing this that is referred to as the 13/13 rule.  Under this rule,
if a driver is judged to be at fault in an incident that results in
damage to his car or another (no matter how small), he's out of that
particular event  and on probation for the next 13 months.  If in that
probation period that driver is again determined to be at fault in
another incident with damage, he's out of club racing for the next 13
months.  Equipment requirements include the fire extinguisher, a cut
off switch, an approved roll bar, and a five point seat belt harness.
There are several of these around the country.  You should have 
experience with autocross and driver's education events under your 
belt before you jump into this kind of racing.  Contact your local
club racing officials to get copies of rules, needed equipment, etc.

=======================================================================

What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?

     BTDT = Been there, done that
      BTW = by the way
      FAQ = Frequently asked questions (but you knew that)
      FTP = file transfer program
     FWIW = For what it's worth
     IMHO = In my humble opinion
      IMO = In my opinion
      IOW = in other words
      PAG = Porsche AG, the mother company back in Stuttgart; "AG"
            stands for "Aktiengesselschaft," which means that the 
            company has publicly traded stock
     PANO = Not an acronym; this stands for Porsche Panorama, the PCA 
            national monthly magazine
      PCA = Porsche Club of America, the major US/Canada Porsche
            enthusiasts organization
     PCGB = Porsche Club of Great Britain
     PCNA = Porsche Cars of North America (Reno, NV), the US importer
     PMJI = pardon me for jumping in
      POC = Porsche Owner's Club, the *other* US Porsche owner's group;
            in the past they have been more competition-oriented than 
            PCA, which has many interest groups participating
     ROFL = rolling on the floor laughing
  ROFL,PP = rolling on the floor laughing, peeing in my pants (!)
     RTFM = read the f**king manual (for some, "read the Ford manual")
      TIA = thanks in advance
     TTFN = tata for now
     TTYL = talk to you later
      WWW = World Wide Web
     YMMV = Your mileage may vary
      <g> = grin
     <bg> = big grin
    <vbg> = very big grin
      :-) = Smiley face (turn your head 90 degrees to the left to "read"
            it); various iterations exist using different ASCII 
            characters
    
=======================================================================

What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?


     Excellence -
       Independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Many of the same
       authors you see in Panorama, less jingoistic in their praise
       for everything PCNA brings to market.

       US rates: $20 one year, $35 two years, $49 three years
       foreign (incl. Canada): US$27 one, $49 two, $69 three years

       Excellence
       Circulation Dept.
       P.O. Box 1529
       Ross, CA  94957
       telephone: 415-382-0580


     Christophorus -
       Porsche AG's official magazine.  Very good source of some
       technical information about their cars and technology.
       Beautiful magazine.

       US rates: US$28 surface mail, US$40 air mail

       Porsche AG
       Editors, Christophorus
       Porschestrasse 42
       D-70435 Stuttgart
       Germany
       FAX: D-711/827-6245


     European Car -
       Formerly "VW & Porsche", now devotes some bandwidth to other
       European cars, esp. BMW.  Lots of technical how-to's, but
       biased by "placed" articles from advertisers - beware!

       US rates: $18.80 one year, $28.20 two years
       Canada: $26.80 one year, $44.20 two years, includes GST
       foreign: $28.80 one year, $48.20 two years

What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?

     Be aware when buying a part in the aftermarket that it may or may
not be the same part you would get from Porsche.  This holds true even
when the part carries the "correct" Porsche part number, and when it
carries Porsche's parts trademark.  The following suppliers, listed
alphabetically, have been praised by various Porschephiles:


     Andial
     3203-3207 S. Shannon St.
     Santa Ana, CA  92704
     telephone: 714-957-3900
     FAX:       714-957-9332

     Porsche's official agent for competition parts and products in 
     the US.  Catalog $6.00.


     Automobile Atlanta
     505A South Marietta Highway
     Marietta, GA 30060
     telephone: 404-427-2844
 
     The most comprehensive catalog of 914 parts.  Higher-than-average
     prices.  Catalog $5.00.  (Also a 924 catalog?)

 
     Automotion
     193 Commercial St.
     Sunnyvale, CA 94086
     telephone: 800-777-8881
                408-736-9020
     FAX:       408-736-9013

     Wide selection of maintenance and replacement parts and products;
     sister company to Weltmeister, whose suspension kits they carry.
     Free catalog.

     3769-B Pickett Road
     Fairfax, VA  22031
     telephone: 703-323-0919
     FAX:       703-323-7325

=======================================================================

What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?

There are many books and manuals available, and the right one for you
depends a lot on your interests and your particular car.  Porsche
publishes a Workshop Manual for all late model cars, as well as
various Technical Specification booklets.  Your local dealership's
parts manager can show you a catalog of technical literature
available from PCNA.

The Porsche Club of America periodically assembles all of the technical
articles which have appeared in Panorama into a new volume of their
Upfixin der Porsche series.  These are available from PCA's executive
office.

What follows is a list of some of the more popular and often-cited
books.  This list is not exhaustive, but provides a starting point.  
If you want information about other books, ask the list.  (Note:
Information about water-cooled cars is lacking; those with favorites
should submit them to one of the names at the end of this FAQ.)

     Bruce Anderson
     Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
       ISBN 0-87938-269-4
     Motorbooks International

     Duane Spencer
     Porsche 356 Performance Handbook  
       ISBN 0-87938-417-4

     Dr. Brett Johnson
     The 356 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-08-0
     The 911 and 912 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-00-5
     The 914 and 914/6 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-01-3
     Beeman Jorgensen Inc.

     Charles O. Probst
     Bosch Fuel Injection & Engine Management
       ISBN 0-8376-0300-5
     Robert Bentley, Inc.

     Fred Puhn
     How To Make Your Car Handle
       ISBN 0-912656-46-8
     HP Books

     Harry Pellow 
     The ABC's (and 912's) of Porsche Engines
       ISBN 0-941210-04-9
     HCP Research (408) 727-1864
 

There are also Haynes manuals available for most models.  While the
Haynes manuals tend to be very weak on specifics having to do with
different model years and variations, they are good at teaching how-to
procedures for different maintenance and repair tasks.

=======================================================================

Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?

     This is Stan's response:  "Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE 
THAT ISN'T JUST PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil.  Or as Bruce 
Anderson commented about something else, "a cash flow device."  Slick-50
is *evil* if you have an engine with an aluminium case.  Guess what we 
all have, eh?  There is a bit of info on it via anonymous FTP in tta.com
in /pub/porschephiles/MiscInfo.  Additionally, many of these additives 
use teflon.  DuPont (the inventors of Teflon) have stated categorically 
that teflon is useless in such applications."
 
=======================================================================

Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
 
Yes. There are many luminaries in the Porsche world on this list.  If
something is relevant to them, they'll typically respond to you
privately.  Their participation is greatly valued, so respect their
privacy and don't try to draw them out in the open.  If they want to 
say something to the list as a whole, they'll do so.

=======================================================================

Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?

     The FAQ is stored on tta.com in the /pub/porschephiles/FAQs 
directory, filename general-FAQ.  The version stored there will be 
the same one sent out monthly.  (There's also a FAQ that's specific to
the 914; other specific FAQs are welcomed, if anyone wants to contribute
to the archives.)

=======================================================================

Who maintains this FAQ?

     The FAQ is maintained by Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil).  I have
a 1972 911T as my daily driver.  Anyone who wants to contribute can do
so.  Contributions, revisions, and suggestions for new items are always
welcomed.  I peruse the list for potential additions, but don't be shy 
about sending suggestions directly to me.

=======================================================================

Porschephiles #1045                         Tue Jan 3 15:23:10 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 03 Jan 1995 08:55:03 -0700
From: stephenk@lmc.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: RE: 2.0L rebuilds (was Double Clutching/ plus 914 questions)

Hi all

Tim writes:
>(2) 2.0 was supposedly rebuilt within last 10K miles.  I want to open it up 
>anyway to make sure everything is kosher and to make sure it seals well.  
>Anything I should specifically look for (crack in oil strainer bolt hole, 
>pounded out bearings. etc)?

Couple of suggestions.  Have your machinist pull the oil galley plugs (there 
are four or five) and tap the galley ways to accept screw-in plugs.  I had
an oil galley plug pop out (hence the rebuild...very messy and a lousy way to
start one's day).  Definitely check for cracks in the case around the oil
strainer bolt hole.  These are caused by overtorquing the bolt and can, if
severe, restrict flow to the oil pump.  You probably will need to have misc.
cracks in the head repaired; also check and replace, if necessary, any of the
valves.  The valves in mine had been bead blasted sometime in the past and
were very rough.  You might want to consider having the rotating masses
balanced.  It added $175 to my rebuild costs and seemed like a good idea.

Shameless Plug (ignore if you don't live near Portland, Oregon):

If you live near (or in) Portland, Oregon consider using Dan Hall's
Automotive Machine Shop (503) 289-5015.  They do good work, price it
reasonably, and are
experienced with Porsche and VW air-cooled powerplants and their various
idiosyncrasies.  Dan and his crew also have some experience building race
engines, but I don't know to what extent.  While I was asking around for
recommended machine shops in the area, Dan's name kept coming up: seems he's
made a bunch of customers happy around here.

Stph

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 11:57:56 -0500
From: AutoOasis@aol.com
Subject: Re: Seat Question

Bob,

Yeah the seat addapters are availble but kind of expensive. (Some places want
$75+ per side...) When I put '77 seats in my '67 i made my own and they work
just fine. I took my old seats out, got apeice of steel that was about an
1/8" thick, had it cut to the proper sizes and lined up my holes on my car
and then lined up the holes in the seats and they fit with a small amount of
filing.

It took about 2 hours after getting the metal.

Steve

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 12:16:11 -0500
From: peh1@cornell.edu (Peter E. Hillman)
Subject: Need quiet A-arm bushings for 911SC

Hello all:

I'm looking for a source of non-squeaking A-arm bushings for my '81 911SC.

I removed the four original rubber bushings from the A-arms and I replaced
them with Weltmeister bushings that I bought a couple years ago.  I was
about to install the A-arms back onto to my 911 when I heard that
Weltmeister bushings squeak like crazy.  I don't want to listen to
squeaking bushings and I'm not really that interested in the handling
benefits that Weltmeister bushings offer.  Unfortunately, I destroyed one
of my original rubber bushings upon removal, so I cannot reinstall the
original rubber bushings.  Does anyone know where to purchase the original
rubber bushings?  Apparently you cannot purchase the rubber bushings
separately from Porsche, instead you must purchase the A-arms with rubber
bushings already installed.

Alternatively, is there a source for non-squeaking performance bushings?

Thanks for your help,

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 95 09:44:00 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: Farting and hesitation


Peter Diffey wrote about hesitation and mild backfire in his watercooler 
in very cold weather.

This can be caused by:

A small amount of water from condensation in the fuel. This is passed and 
cannot burn, causing some misfire or hesitation.

A more likely cause is condensation in the distributor cap, turning to 
steam as operating temperature is reached. It can also be caused by some
coolant being forced out a hose just prior to the thermostat opening (the
point where steam pressure in the cooling system is highest). If you 
service the cap and rotor, be sure to replace the dust cover under the 
rotor.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 03 Jan 95 12:42:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Porsche AG Stock


>Interesting stuff, this Porsche AG stock -- it offers no voting rights,
>it pays no dividends.

I thought that it did pay dividends.  There was news during the last
few years that with the company's poor financial performance, they
might not pay a dividend, and that by failing to pay one, there was a
kicker which gave normally non-voting shares a vote.  I may have
this all wrong.

The interesting thing to me has been not the voting rights or dividend.
I realistically have no voting rights for any company's stock I do in fact
own, although the invitations to their annual meetings in East Dogleg
are always appreciated.  And lots of companies do not pay a dividend.
No, what is interesting is that they have such a high share price, which
effectively keeps small players out of the stock.  In the US, at least,
companies with share prices over $50 to $100 will typically split the
shares so that individual investors can buy them in "round lots," ie,
100-share chunks.  Perhaps things are different in the BRD.

Kevin Gross

Date: Tue,  3 Jan 1995 13:39:15 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: my car doesn't love me

    OK, first I'm going to apologize because I'm not subscribed to the
list anymore (I'm on vacation) but I'm still working on my 914 (big
shock) so if you could reply by email I'd appreciate it.

    Argh.. where to begin?  I got the car home, loved the way it always
started right up, but the nonfunctional throttle cable was peeving me. 
So I ripped the old one out (using a hand winch - that little steel tube
was rusted solid!) and tried to insert the new one.  No go.  Apparently
pulling the old one out didn't clean out the tube enough to let the new
one slide in.  Here's how I fixed it...  I got a 4' long piece of steel
rod, put a little blob of weld on the end, and hammered it flat to look
like a little spade-type drill bit.   Chucked it in a power drill and
ran it through from underneath the car (sprayed liberally with WD-40
first.)  clip 'n' save, if any of you guys have the same problem.  Of
course, it took me a week of screwing around to come up with this
solution, that was just the method that worked. ;)
    Oh, yeah, and the fuel line snapped (?) as did the battery ground
cable (?) at the exact same time... get the feeling I'm unlucky?  And
the first time I took it out on the road, the hood came unlatched at
about 30 MPH, so I've got a little pounding to do on the cowl. :(
    Well, here are the questions.. I've been poking through the engine,
and I've come to the realization that the vacuum hoses are all screwed
up.  Someone cut off one of the lines to the charcoal canister and
hooked up a line from the blower box to the crankcase (among other
things.)  I guess that would explain why my spark plugs are all wet. 
Can anyone point me to a good diagram for how these things are really
supposed to go?    I guess I should have mentioned that the car is a '71
with stock D-jet.
    Also, over break, I tried to put the top on for the first time and I
can't get the damn thing on.  The back latches just don't seem to match
up.  The part on the top has a hard thing about 1" long, while the part
on the body looks like there's a seat for a similar part, only it should
be about 3/8" long.  Were there two different designs for the top
latches (and I've got a different top than came with my car?)  What to
do?  I should point out that my car does "flex" a little, as it is in
need of some patching on the rockers, so it is a possibility that I just
had it misaligned.  Howevver, this is the only way that it looks like it
would go on, so if a few 914 owners could go look at your car and tell
me what your rear top latches look like, I'd appreciate it.
    Finally, is there any performance to be gained from dumping my
oil-bath air cleaner for a paper-element one?  Or is it just a
convenience thing?

    Thanks in advance,

Nate

PS-  I don't know when I'll be on again, so don't be offended if I don't
reply to anyone.

Subject: Re: Spinnin' tires...

> He said that if I hadn't spun my tire
> s so much, it might have been even closer.  
> I thought I've read here that it is
> better to squeal your tires on take off.
> Can anyone explain why?
> Sean '80 928

Squeal, yes, "spin", no. Good tires develop maximum traction at a 5-15% slip
rate (the exact rate depends on both the tire and the surface in question).
This means that the drive wheels should be rotating 5% to 15% faster than they
would if they were simply rolling at the same speed as the car. For a car with
lots of extra power, you have to modulate the gas pedal, rolling on steadily
to maintain that "just complaining" level of tire slip as the revs and speed 
mount up. For cars that don't have that kind of power, the launch can still
be improved (at considerable cost in clutch life) by starting out at peak
torque revs and modulating the clutch to maintain the desired slip rate,
and then the gas pedal if you still have enough torque to bother once the
clutch is fully engaged.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue,  3 Jan 95 13:58:30 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Electromotive ignition on 930

>From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
>Subject: Electromotive Direct Ignition?

>I am looking at an '86 turbo that has been modified with dual plug heads
>and "converted" to use an Electromotive, Inc. "HPV-1" Direct Ignition
>system. There are two of these units mounted on the shelf at the rear of
>the engine compartment (and would be virtually inaccessable after the
>engine is reinstalled. The engine is out of the car with one
>burned valve and piston (Yes, there is a huge boost control located in
>the console).
>Can anyone respond with information about these units? Are they still in
>production or at least documentation available?

>Thanks, Dave Christiano, (sleepless in Springfield, MO.)

       Electromotive's phone number is (703)378-2444. The manual is available
  for $15, and the units and parts are still available. Twin-plug setups
  start at about $1000 for the HPV-1, and run more if you want MAP sensing
  to retard the ignition upon boost.  The HPV-3b runs about $300 more but
  allows you to PC program in variable advance/retard across vacuum/boost.
       If you don't already have the optional MAP sensor and control box
  you probably should get it. They support MAP sensors up to 2 bars boost,
  the can for the HPV-1 lets you dial in what retard at which load/boost.
       I don't have an HPV-x but have heard it made all the difference on
  another gentlemans twin-distributored Ferrari 308. I'm sure its not as
  sophisticated as Motronic but it does let you fire 2 plugs and seems a whole
  lot more accurate than weights and springs on a distributor (and didn't
  that year 930 not have DME yet ? Or any kind of computer-controlled 
  ignition ?)

            Good luck--Lee






------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 95 15:10:00 EST
From: weltyc@cs.vassar.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: January Porsching Column


[ Pphiles - this is Part 1 of a many-part "based on a true story"
version of how I acquired my first 911. Permission is granted to use
this material in any publication as long as my name and affiliation
remain intact. - CW]

Porsching by Chris Welty, Hudson-Champlain Region

Subtitle: "When you wish upon a start, Part I"

When You Wish Upon a Star - Part I

Standing in an open field on a clear summer evening, I watched the
stars materialize in the darkening sky.  The first to become visible
was Vega, a corner of the popular summer triangle. At that
moment I stretched out my arm and, aiming my finger at this point of
light, I chanted an ancient spell.  At the conclusion of the powerful
verse, the magic of the moment enveloping me in a soft breeze, I
uttered the words which would seal and direct the charm: I wish I
had a Porsche. A sudden clap of thunder and a blinding flash of
lightning told me that my skills as a necromancer had been sucessful
 Either that or I was embellishing the story too much.  Ah indeed,
the latter turned out to be the case, for standing there, before my
very eyes, there was no new car.  No shining example of Ferdinands
master craftsmen.  No turbo boxer six roaring in the starlight.
Nothing.  Not so much as a Chevy.  A small field mouse darted into a
clump of grass, and overhead a bat winged its way in silent pursuit of
a nocturnal insect. Somewhere a dog was barking.  Not that I could
hear it, but I figured somewhere a dog must have been barking  in
fact, I figured it was my neighbors dog, the damn thing never shuts
up.  I hung my head dejectedly, disappointed in my inadequacy.  I
stood there a moment more, then turned to leave.  But as I was
trudging back to the tent, cursing Jiminy Cricket under my breath, I
felt a faint twinge somewhere inside me.  Looking up, I could swear
that  for a moment  Vega quickly brightened, and somehow I knew
that one day, when the time was right, I would have the power to
complete that spell (and also that I would never use the word
inadequate to describe myself again).

Two years later I was watching Bambi on video when the phone rang.  My
old roomate, John, had just returned from California with a 911.  I
put the VCR on pause, not wanting to miss the part where Bambi does
Memphis, and began a series of eager questions.  What color?  What
year?  What kind?  What condition? Do the babes really line up for
rides?

Before I answer your questions, he began, in that tone that
either meant he was about to pose a hypothetical situation or coerce
me into making a promise.  I want you to promise me that you will
go to California this summer and buy a Porsche.

OK, OK.  I promise.  I dont usually put up this much of a fight.

Very good.  I have a yellow, 1973 T targa.  No rust, perfect,
and two blondes and a brunette. He went on. It sounded great, and I
was deeply envious.  The pause eventually turned off automatically on
the VCR and Bambi finished off Memphis and even got as far as
Nashville before I hung up, too dazed to see the films climax.

A Porsche.  Just the name sparks excitement in most people.  Women
love to be seen in them, and men just...well...love to be seen in
them.  But I  I was different.  I preferred to be seen under them.
Thats not to say I could do anything there, my Porsche mechanical
expertise went as far as knowing that the engine was in the back.  But
still I persisted in feeling that eventually I would buy an old one
and fix it up. Where I would obtain the knowledge to accomplish
this was still a mystery.  Nevertheless I dreamed.  Driving down Route
2 at 900 million miles an hour, my white 911 appearing blue to
everyone in front of me and red to everyone behind me (this property
of objects moving at high speeds, known as the "Doppler Effect",
doesn't appear to work for metalic colors), hugging the curves,
tearing up the straights, wasting Detroits best, and waving to cops
whos radar went off the scale.

Well, how can a person such as myself, who would never actually admit
in public to not knowing thing one about cars, afford to buy a
Porsche?  Enter Karl.  Our eyes didnt meet across a crowded room,
nor was it love at first sight, in fact it was in my office and I
thought he was no more than another brown nosing student.  But after
only a few moments I realized I had struck gold.  With little effort
on my part, I was able to subtly maneuver him into admitting not only
that he owned a 911, but that he had taken the whole car apart and put
it together again.  Scarcely able to believe my good fortune, and not
in the least bit aware of the mystical circumstances through which
this meeting was made inevitable, I phoned John and insisted he bring
his car up to test the knowledge of this German born meister mechanic.

No sooner had we brought the car into the student auto shop, Karl was
into and under it.  John and I merely stared in astonishment, trying
our best to follow and remember everything he did.  It was true, it
seemed he must have known everything there was to know about the
car. He taught us how to use the stethoscope, with which we determined
there were two loose valves, and then how to adjust them.  Many other
secrets of 911 maintenance were revealed to us that day, but in our
minds, the crowning achievement of the day was when, in response to
Johns broken speedometer, Karl produced a spare speedo cable and
even replaced it before our very eyes.  I could hardly believe anyone
could know a car so completely that he knew how the speedometer cable
was routed.  Odd how ones perspective changes, now Id scoff at
someone lacking such a trivial piece of knowledge, but at the time it
was amazing.

That day my decision was made.  It was clear that while Karl was
around I would have the opportunity to learn all the things I always
wanted to know, from someone who enjoyed teaching it.  Karl himself
had been convinced by looking at Johns car that California was the
place to go to buy a used 911.  When Karl sold his own 911 we
immediately made plans for the big trip.  John, in keeping with his
promise, agreed to come with us.  And so, driven by theurgical forces,
yet completely ignorant to the geas that had been cast upon us, we set
out to finish what a young sorcerer had started many years ago.



=====

Christopher Welty                        Vassar College Computer Science Dept
SIGART Information Director                            Poughkeepsie, NY 12601
weltyc@sigart.acm.org                                    weltyc@cs.vassar.edu

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 95 12:19:36 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: 911 Spoilers

>
> Would appreciate any and all insights/tutorials on spoilers.
> Thanks,
> 
> Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI
> ...Still looking for an '87 Carerra Coupe...
>       

My '83 SC has the factory spoiler option, this is the "tea tray" style
rear from the >78 turbo (I think) plus a deeper front airdam.  For an
'87 Carerra I think the factory spoiler was more "whale tail" and lacked
the side fences that my later Turbo spoiler has. 

I've experimented both with and without it.  It's noticeable above 60
and a Major Asset above 90, or in any cross wind.  I think it must move
the center of pressure a little closer back to the center of gravity,
maybe even back behind the center of gravity (where it belongs!); anyway
the *feel* is just that the car is "arrowing" a little more elegantly thru
the air, and relying less on the tires to keep it pointed/going in a
straight line.  I *like* this feeling!

On the down side, this particular spoiler (factory with TUV-approved
rubber lip) adds about 50 lb 'way back and 'way up, exactly where you
don't want it.  A Major Hindrance when auto-xing or backroad blasting.
AND, though you say aesthetics aren't a concern, there is a major
effect on appearance; here in CA at least one goes from "just another
Porsche" to "boy racer", and out in the really wide open places one goes
from "CA sports car jerk" to "CA drug dealer" just by bolting 50 pounds
of fiberglass and rubber to your car.  

Conclusion?  The spoilers are *ON* the car, but I'm eyeing those carbon
fiber repros that have been popping up in Panorama...

hope this helps
 -Ed

p.s. maybe I'm a bit over-sensitive about the appearance thing... but
hey, at least *I'm* not thinkning about a VR3000, the Swiss Army Knife
of sports cars... yeccch!  Did we unload that guy to the T*d list?  I
detected certain similarities...

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 12:17:09 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Need quiet A-arm bushings for 911SC

Hi Peter:

I recently put Weltmeister bushings on both the front and rear suspension
of my 914.  I used the "grease" they recommend - it's incredibly viscous
and sticky stuff.  Anyway, I get no squeaks whatsoever, but that's not to
say that none will develop further down the road.

Andrew

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 95 12:31:09 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: My car hates me


>From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
>To: porschephiles@tta.com
>Subject: my car doesn't love me
>
>    Argh.. where to begin?  I got the car home, loved the way it always
>started right up, but the nonfunctional throttle cable was peeving me. 
>So I ripped the old one out (using a hand winch - that little steel tube
>was rusted solid!) and tried to insert the new one.  No go.  Apparently
>pulling the old one out didn't clean out the tube enough to let the new
>one slide in.  Here's how I fixed it...  I got a 4' long piece of steel
>rod, put a little blob of weld on the end, and hammered it flat to look
>like a little spade-type drill bit.   Chucked it in a power drill and
>ran it through from underneath the car (sprayed liberally with WD-40
>first.)  clip 'n' save, if any of you guys have the same problem.  Of
>course, it took me a week of screwing around to come up with this
>solution, that was just the method that worked. ;)
>    Oh, yeah, and the fuel line snapped (?) as did the battery ground
>cable (?) at the exact same time... get the feeling I'm unlucky?  And
>the first time I took it out on the road, the hood came unlatched at
>about 30 MPH, so I've got a little pounding to do on the cowl. :(
>    Well, here are the questions.. I've been poking through the engine,
>and I've come to the realization that the vacuum hoses are all screwed
>up.  Someone cut off one of the lines to the charcoal canister and
>hooked up a line from the blower box to the crankcase (among other
>things.)  I guess that would explain why my spark plugs are all wet. 
>Can anyone point me to a good diagram for how these things are really
>supposed to go?    I guess I should have mentioned that the car is a '71
>with stock D-jet.
>    Also, over break, I tried to put the top on for the first time and I
>can't get the damn thing on.  The back latches just don't seem to match
>up.  The part on the top has a hard thing about 1" long, while the part
>on the body looks like there's a seat for a similar part, only it should
>be about 3/8" long.  Were there two different designs for the top
>latches (and I've got a different top than came with my car?)  What to
>do?  I should point out that my car does "flex" a little, as it is in
>need of some patching on the rockers, so it is a possibility that I just
>had it misaligned.  Howevver, this is the only way that it looks like it
>would go on, so if a few 914 owners could go look at your car and tell
>me what your rear top latches look like, I'd appreciate it.
>    Finally, is there any performance to be gained from dumping my
>oil-bath air cleaner for a paper-element one?  Or is it just a
>convenience thing?

Nate,

    How can I say this nicely?  You appear to have what I would refer to
as a "rolling wreck".

Clue #1:  The throttle cable was rusted in.
Clue #2:  The top no longer fits.
Clue #3:  Flexing at the rocker panels.

My guess would be that the frame tubes have rusted enough to start
bending.  I have heard of 914's where these tubes have broken, and
were fixed with 4x4's (lumber).  The top would not go on unless
the car was jacked up slightly at the center.  Parts Werks does sell
repair kits, but they aren't cheap to install.

Go back under the car and check for rust damage.  You shouldn't be
able to see any flexing while the car is sitting still.


Let's assume (hope) that I'm wrong, and go on to your other questions:

I don't know of a good diagram for the hoses.  From years of smog-checks,
the hoses on my car were real messed up.  Seems that all of them thought
they "knew" how they were supposed to go, and changed them.  Your best
bet would to be to find a car that hadn't been screwed with, and copy it.
Or get George to sell you a hose kit on the condition that he provide you
with the proper diagram.  What I did was to find someone who actually did
know what he was doing, and have him fix it.

Don't bother changing your air filter.  I put the paper filter back into
my car only because I have a 1973, and I wanted it stock.  (An evil
mechanic had replaced mine with an oil bath one.)  I didn't notice
any difference, and besides, I believe that I just bought the only one
left in North America.

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 19:25:34 +0000 (GMT)

Subject: RE: Farting and hesitation

On Tue, 3 Jan 1995, James Pasha wrote:

> This can be caused by:
> 
> A small amount of water from condensation in the fuel. This is passed and 
> cannot burn, causing some misfire or hesitation.
> 
> A more likely cause is condensation in the distributor cap, turning to 
> steam as operating temperature is reached. It can also be caused by some
> coolant being forced out a hose just prior to the thermostat opening (the
> point where steam pressure in the cooling system is highest). If you 
> service the cap and rotor, be sure to replace the dust cover under the 
> rotor.
> 
> Jim Pasha
>

Subject: Head Studs/CV Joints/Oil

I have the same car.  My understanding is that steel studs are
fine.  The Dilavar is recommended to handle the different
expansion rates of later style cylinder materials.  Ours are
cast iron.

How much oil does you car take?  My manual says 8.5 qts, but
this doesn't begin to get into the middle of the dipstick
range.  9.5 qts gets to the bottom of the range.  The
meter doesn't read yet, though (and it's calibration is
apparently for an 8.5 qt capacity).  I know the meter
works because I just rebuilt it, and when it the middle
of its position, the meter reads right.

I just rebuilt the car.  Haven't driven it yet, and
would like to get this straight before I do.

I've been checking the dipstick when warm, while
idling, as per the manual.

My CV joints came off by first removing the big circlip,
and then helping them along by hammering.  It was pretty
easy.

Hi,

The electrical gremlins have invaded my car and have taken over my turn
signal relay or something. A couple of weeks ago I drove my car ( '73 911) in
a light rain. As I came to a stop at a light, I heard an intermitent clicking
noise coming from the turn signal relay.  It wasn't bad at first, it just
clicked at 3 second intervals every now and then. Two weeks later it clicks
all the time. I went to Vertex  and Mike allowed me to try a new turn signal
relay. Unfortunately the problems persisted. Is it possible that he gave me a
defective switch even though it came out of the box?

I will list the symptoms.
1. The relay clicks all the time. It now also causes static in the  radio
reception everytime it clicks, but the tape player remains unaffected. 
2. I checked the adjustment of the hand brake warning switch. The switch is
well adjusted and works as it should. I should add that the warning light
comes on as usual.

simultaneously but at a lower intensity. The blinkers outside still work
correctly.
4. The emergency flashers work correctly.

anybody has any ideas I would love to hear them. Jim Pasha, I have read your
article in Excellence concerning electrical problems, but there wasn't
anything that applied to my particular situation. Do you have any ideas? If
anybody has any questions about my problem or if I left something out please
ask me.

As you can tell I'm rather desperate to fix this so any clues would be
greatly appreciated.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 17:01:41 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 rust treatment


Dear Henry,

We always treat rust-colored metal, bare metal or freshly installed metal as
follows:

   1. Sand blast or wire brush all rust color from the metal. 
   2. Etch the metal with metal ready cleaner (POR-15 makes the product
also). This cleans any remaining rust from the metal and preps the surface
for the POR-15 rust paint.
   3. Spray or brush on POR-15 rust paint on the metal and let dry.
   4. Caulk seams (we use the excellent 3-M product).
   5. On surfaces prone to being hit by debris, we spray chipguard. This
product provides a rubbery semi-rough service so the road abuse will be
absorbed and not chip off the paint.
   6. Finally, we apply polyurethane paint in the factory color. This is the
latest and greatest paint available and provides great gloss and durability.

With each rusted area, it needs to be scraped clean off paint and rust and
sandblasted or wire brushed first. Only after this can we make a judgement as
to whether we should replace or repair the metal. The general consensus is
that if an ice pick will go through - replace it!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 16:57:51 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Towing a 914


Dear Bart,

You can tow a 914 easily on all four wheels by first removing the front
bumper and attaching the tow bar there, or just two wheel dolly it from the
front. No problem!

George Hussey
