Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 16:58:02 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 idle problem...


Dear Francis,

"Hunting" or an idle that fluxuates on its own is caused by leanness and
usually in the case of a 914, a vacuum leak. You may have a split vacuum boot
or an auxillary air valve sticking, but nevertheless, it is a minor problem.
Spraying carb cleaner (with spray wand attached) around all of the vacuum
boots and fittings when the problem occurs is the best way to begin
diagnosing your problem. Good luck!

Our rebuilt transaxles guaranteed for six months or six thousand miles are
950 + 200 core + 50.00 shipping to San Diego. We do a very careful job so you
can be assured a tight and long lasting gearbox!

Francis, I love V-8; tomato juice is very healthy! I hope you get my point!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 16:58:17 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 modifications


Dear Keith,

Two thousand dollars for a 914 is a steal! We regularly pay that for a parts
car.

The most important place to spend your money first is to make the 914 body
perfect because without a body, you don't have a 914! Four thousand dollars
can instantly be absorbed in beginning to make the body sound and I am sure
that a two thousand dollar car needs help in this area!

The next area is the interior as these parts are hard to get and will be much
rarer in the future.

We assume your power plant is relatively sound and the car will run down the
road, so the only money that should be innitially spent here is for a
thorough maintenance/service (including such things as cable renewal and oil
leak repair).

Only then after the above are completed should you think about modifications.
Too many 914 enthusiasts have spent thousands modifying a 914 with a bad body
and ended up with a hopeless mess that they are buried in. Don't become one
of them!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 17:02:32 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Idle


Dear Dan,

We are very happy to see that you are reinstalling the fuel injection and
saving a 914!

Your problem is caused by a vacuum leak. Put your hand over the throttle body
when the car is idling high and then see where the extra air is leaking in.
Possibilities are:
    1. Misrouted vacuum line  Oil filler PCV to plentum, etc.
    2. Auxilliary air valve sticking open
    3. Decel valve leaking
    4. Vacuum boot ripped

Then spray carb cleaner (with spray wand attached) around all of the fittings
and see what varies the idle.

An easy way to verify timing on a 1.7, 2.0 is to set it at 3500 RPM to the
first fan blade to the right of the big thick fan reinforcing blades (there
are four, but only one in the proximity of the timing mark!)

Vacuum leaks cause strange idle problems. Always set well and timing first,
then adjust or fix the idle problem.

A final passing note is to check both vacuum advance, mechanical advance and
vacuum retard for proper operation. (Twist the distributor rotor and make
sure it springs back, evacuate the advance and retard making sure the points
plate moves smoothly back and forth.)

Good luck, Dan! Let us know if we can help you further.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 17:02:46 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 mirror upgrade


Dear Pat,

Of course it is easy to mount a mirror on the passenger door of your 914 by
tapping out the factory nut plate (After removing the door panel) and the
left factory mirror can be reversed and used as a passenger mirror!

For years we have used the baby tornado mirrors by vitaloni. These are the
same mirrors used by the Ferarri factory and are easily mounted in the stock
914 mirror mounting holes with 6mm allen bolts. At $25.00 each, they are a
cheap alternative to the expensive ($95.00) factory mirrors.

George Hussey

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 14:28:37 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Re: Seat Question

>Does anyone know if there are adapters available?  Or if it's 
>even worth considering buying or fashioning an adapter?

Yes, they are.  I saw them in the Automotion catalog a few years ago for 
about $100, and I think that was per SIDE.

I made some for mine, by looking at the picture  in the catalog and taking
measurements on the car.  They run lengthwise, and essentially have two
sets of holes - one for the car and one for the seat.  If you can get your
hands on the seats it shouldn't take you too long to figure it  out.

BTW - I used 1/8" steel, good stuff, and grade 8 bolts.

Thom
'72 911T targa

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 95 15:41:41 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Blinking Blinker


Neil-
I just had a fairly similar problem.  In my case it turned out
to be a faulty brake master cylinder switch.  The switch on
the MC is designed to turn on the blinker if one of the
dual brake circuits fails.

Try disconnecting the MC swqitch entirely and see if the 
blinkier stops.  If it does, it's either the switch, or
indeed one of your dual circuits is bad.

You'll have to remove the protective plate under the car
to get at the MC.  To disconnect the switch just
pull the connectors off.

Hope this helps.

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 18:43:44 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: RE: Electrical help needed



Neil,

The symptoms are those of a bad chassis ground, probably back by
the tail lights. There are a couple of places to check, neither
one of which is very easy to get at:

The tail light assembly ground straps on '73's are by the towing
straps on either side in the back.

Also there is a pass-through multipin connector I think right and
left at the front close to the battery boxes and on the left rear
behind the electrical chassis that carries all the relays, ignition
module etc. (That assembly also has a ground strap) The pins on the
connectors get a little corroded and the resistance goes up. The relay
might be trying to latch and not getting enough voltage or not finding
adequate ground.

Turn your signal on and when it starts blinking dimly on both sides,
rev the engine to about 3,500 rpm and see if it returns to normal. If
it does, you have a voltage drop problem due to a bad connection
somewhere. It can drive you nuts, but if you have a good meter, you 
might be able to do voltage drop tests to isolate the problem a little
closer.


Good Luck,

Reid

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 19:40:02 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: RE: Double Clutching Explanation

>>
>>> Further, you might have noticed that it is difficult to engage
>>> reverse while moving forwards. Well, there is no syncro for reverse
>>> because sane people do not what to go directly from forwards to 
>>> backwards without stopping in between. I suspect that if you did
>>> want to, double de-clutching might do the trick....
>>
>>> 
>>The one situation where you can (and should) double (de)clutch into 
>>reverse is when your car is already rolling backwards and you want to be 
>>able to apply more rearward power.  In this situation, the output gears 
>>which mesh with the input side when 'reverse' is selected are turning in 
>>the correct direction. 
>>
>>
I remember a review of the Pegaso (a Spanish sports car) that must have
been around 1960(?). It spun 180 degrees at highway speed, and the 
tester - a factory guy, I think - calmly dropped it into 1st, stood
on it, and popped the clutch. Now that's a synchromesh! Come to think
of it, the car may have looked a bit like a 928; maybe I've been
carrying this subconscious urge all this time....

 -John White-
'84 928S



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 20:23:32 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche dragsters

Skaterj@aol.com, deciding on Japanese sports barges or Porsches, said
Porsche Dragsters

> The most disconcerting thing I heard was that the Porsche is not a
> great "dragster". Since this will be my fist real sports car, I
> wanted something to play with during my stoplight to stoplight hops.
> I don't plan on racing motorcycles, but I'd like to give the domestics
> (Z28's,Trans Ams, Vettes?) a run for their money. Oh well, I guess
> I'll just hope for a spiritual revelation..

In SCCA pro-solo autocross competition you can observe 911s against Vettes
and other fast cars. Pro-solo uses a drag-race start with timed starting
lights, and a straightaway.  With a decent driver, almost any 911 will BLOW
AWAY an american V-8 off the line, and for some distance, even if the 911
has less power. The 911 can use full throttle at launch, while a strong
V-8 will have to start at about 1500 RPM and feather the throttle for
some time, otherwise spinning the tires and going even slower. The
Mitsu AWD turbo would not have this problem, but has turbo lag and
the weight of a cadillac to contend with. The water cooled Porsches are
not great dragsters for the same reasons as above.

So, a 911 is actually quite a good dragster. Ask Scott Jessen if any car
has pulled him on the start of a pro-solo (other than a modified car).
And once you get ahead, it's very hard to catch up, and the other guy
will probably back off in a stoplight race anyway.

Mike Piera, '72 911 S, many pro-solos and one NHRA drag race. 
AnalogMike@aol.com


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 03 Jan 95 21:19:31 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.GSFC.NASA.GOV
Subject: More 951 PS questions/results


Hello All;

Last week I asked about power steering fluid leaks on an '89 951.  The responses 
indicated two potential sources for the leaks.  First, the original Porsche hose 
clamps used on the return and supply hoses at the fluid reservior are inadequate 
and should be replaced by screw type clamps.  Second, the steering rack internal 
seals can leak, especially in colder weather.  This can be checked by pulling 
back the rubber boot at each end of the rack and looking for fluid buildup 
inside the boot.

Over the weekend, I searched for the source of my leak as directed above.  The 
dealer had already replaced the supply hose from the reservior and used the 
screw type clamps.  The return hose was somewhat covered with fluid, but I do 
not think this was the sole cause of the leak.  There is just to much fluid 
collecting on the splash shield and dripping onto the floor.  I crawled under 
the car (after jacking it up of course) and removed the splash shield.  The 
right side was still wet and dripping power steering fluid.  While I was under 
there I decided to change the oil while looking for my leaks.  What I found was 
interesting.  There is one section of line in the lower right behind what I 
assume is the oil cooler which goes from solid steel to 6" flexible rubber tube 
then back to solid steel.  There seems to be a leak at one of the joints.  Why 
would Porsche not just use the solid tubing all the way?  Also, I looked at both 
ends of the steering rack.  The right side of the rack was clean and dry under 
the boot.  The left side had a damp spot around the boot junction with the rack.  
There is also a little plastic screw at this point which was loose.  What is the 
purpose of the little screw?  I tightened it anyway.  Under the boot, there was 
power steering fluid evident on the toothed steel rack that wasn't visible on 
the right hand side.  Does this mean that the internal seals are leaking on the 
left side or is this normal?

Any help would be appreciated, otherwise the car goes back to the dealer on 
Thursday.  If some of the high pressure lines need to be replaced it looks like 
no fun ($$$) because there is much disassembly required.  If this is the case I 
may be able to live with the leak and buy stock in whoever makes Dexron ATF.  
TIA

Tracy Meyer

Date: 03 Jan 95 22:46:25 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Danish cops etc.

Christian Holmgreen writes about three occasions when the Danish police let
him go, telling him "not to go so fast in the future."
 
There is a basic difference between police in Europe and police in the U.S.
(although cops everywhere seem to have the same basic mentality). In Europe,
they are civil servants, like postal workers or such everywhere in the
world. In the U.S., police are effectively tax collectors. Europeans
wouldn't expect their local tax collectors to cut them any slack, and by the
same token the money collector in uniform with the blinking lights on his
car usually won't give you a break in the U.S. either. "It's just my job,
sir. Tell it to the judge. Sign here."
 
On a similar note, as a resident of the recently bankrupt Orange County, I'm
more than a little interested to see what the SivilServantScum are going to
do with traffic violation fees to make up for their budget mismanagement.
Personally, I prefer a Stalinist approach to all this: fire ALL the O.C.
politicians and start over. You may fire some innocent ones by accident, but
at least you know you got all the guilty ones. They seem to breed like
rabbits anyway so they're not on any endangered species list. Now there's an
idea -- maybe somebody can develop a strain of mixomitosis that only affects
politicians?
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 03 Jan 95 22:46:13 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Decisions, decisions...

 
Re 911 vs. Stealth/Mitsu 3000/Z car/RX-7 etc., there is one other factor:
depreciation. Porsches don't depreciate unless you curb surf regularly, or
enjoy shooting the pipeline down at the construction site. <g>  Go to any
library and pick up the blue book, or maybe it's black book for older cars,
and check out prices. If those don't list the price when new, you can get the
original selling price from old road test magazines (C/D, MT, R&T). Plot
curves of price vs. year for the 911, and compare it to any other sports car
on the road. The Japanese cars plummet, like anything else. The only car
that compares to the 911 is the Corvette.
 
Pete

The GM F-cars aren't even in the same performance league. The Corvette is

driven has been abysmal.
 
For the 993, I measured 0-60 in 5.34 sec, 0-100 mph in 13.54, 1/4 mile in
13.86 at 101.4 mph, 100 km/h in 5.60 sec, 0-400 m in 13.81 at 162.5 km/h,
60-0 braking in 119 ft.
 
I don't have current numbers on the Corvette.

                  Ferrari 348 Spyder    Toyota Supra       993

0-100 km/h         6.07                  5.62               5.60

Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 23:36:07 -0500
From: YoramGuy@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE: Double Clutching Explanation

Philip,
I attempted to clarify your question as to "why release the clutch" in a
previous note.
You need to release (=engage) the clutch, so when you blip the throttle, the
engine is connected to the gearbox input shaft, and can accelerate the
shaft's revs to match the speed of the lower gear which is to be selected.

Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI.
...Still looking for an '87 Carrera Coupe...

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 01:50:52 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: New steering wheel leather

> Anybody have any experience with recovering a
> leather steering wheel?
 
After losing a fairly close autox when my leather wheel came apart in
my hands (made for interesting steering characteristics), I went to a
13" Dino wheel off my race car for a while. But when it became clear
that the smaller wheel, while great for me, was causing my wife to
agravate a chest cartilage tear I decided to have the factory wheel
recovered.

At first, I tried to get a friend who has a, ah, ummm, custom leather
goods business intrested in this. Sort of a sideline, as it were. No
dice. Motivating this was that I'd heard bad things about Alan Gun
Leather, the people who advertise hardest about their services.
I also tried my usual interior people, and also drew a blank. Eventually,
frustration set in and I had to ask myself, "How bad can it be?" So
off the wheel went to AGLA.

Well, it wasn't *THAT* bad, but it wasn't good. The stitching was
uneven, and somewhat amatuerish. The pieces weren't cut evenly,
and there was a little irritating bit on the spoke at 9 o'clock (this is
a 3-spoke 911 wheel). Still, it was usable, and was much better than
it was before it came back.

The foam core over the steel rim was also loose in a couple of places,
and there were other annoyances. I eventually bought a replacement
wheel that I never installed, deciding that I could live with the
original.

On the whole, I'd say that if you're going to be bothered by things like
I described, you'd be better off with a nice new MoMo or Nardi wheel.
Too bad you can't get the Personal E3 any more, or I'd recommend that...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 01:55:21 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)

> So, a 911 is actually quite a good dragster. 

In another topic I completely forgot about, there is this great older
book called "How to Make an Old Porsche Fly" that is about -- strictly
about -- how to make a 356 into a respectible dragster. And no, it
does not involve any V-8s or blowers. It's a hoot! Much akin to "How to
HOT ROD VW Engines", but different somehow.

Stan

Porschephiles #1047                         Wed Jan 4 11:16:36 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 03:13:17 -0600
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Monthly Update from you ListMeister

January 1995

Monthly Notices for the Porschephiles mailing list. 
PLEASE READ THIS WHOLE MESSAGE!!

There are five sections: UPDATE, COPYRIGHT, FTP-INFO, CLUB-INFO, RULES. Be sure
that you are current on RULES...

UPDATE

The end of a very long, not-so-great year! Here's hoping that the
coming year brings some joy to your lives...

I have a confession: driving a 32 year old car with no heat, some leaks
and a shot steering box is actualy FUN! Hard to believe this, but I'm
actually enjoying the 356SC as a daily driver more than I enjoyed
the 911. It's not even close to the same, but somehow.... Well, if
you have one, you'll know what I mean. If you don't already know,
there's no way I can tell you...

On the list, we're up by nearly 100 members from last month. Who's Who
participation is at a nearly all-time low at 33% though. I'll update it
a little later and get out a fresh edition. There are too many people
MIA due to the holidays to make it quite fair at this point.

There will also be a Porschephiles calendar coming soon too, featuring
planned stops on the 1995 ListMeister World Tour. 8{) Watch for it!
This *WILL* include the long-awaited pre-Parade First Annual Gathering
in scenic RENO, NEVADA, featuring *something* at PCNA. More details
as we go and a big THANKS! to Jim Pasha for his continuing work to help
pull this together.

Digest readers: the digest software still has one bug, that race condition 
which is hard to tickle. So if you get "doubled" digests, you don't 
need to tell me about it, I already know. It will eventually get fixed
and try not to worry about it in the meantime...

Stan

COPYRIGHT AND FAIR USAGE STATEMENT

The messages sent to this list constitute private correspondence by and between
members of a closed community. As such, the copyright for EVERYTHING that 
ANYONE posts lies with them. PERIOD. This is *NOT* a bulletin board system,
where consent for further redistribution is implied by nature of the the
system; it's PRIVATE.

If you wish to use something written by someone on the list, you must first
seek their permission unless they specifically grant the right in that
specific posting to reprint it at will. And, in general, it is a VERY GOOD
idea to *CREDIT* someone if you use something by permission "copyright xxxx
Joe Gearhead, used by permission" to keep *SOMEONE ELSE* from screwing up
down the line.

You may also solicit articles, comments, notes and expansions of previous
notes. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

Remember, when you read something on this list: what you are reading belongs
to whoever wrote it. They may have plans to publish it further themselves.
They may want to keep it "private" (i.e. just for list member use). They 
may not care what gets done with it. It's still theirs, and before re-use,
permission must be obtained.

Please respect people's rights, even if they don't make a big deal about it.
I mean it.

FTP-INFO

Archives are available via FTP, compressed, since 4/90. There are no
older archives available. Remember, while it seems like a good idea when 
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before, 
there are OVER 18 MEG of archives. DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE TIME. 
Period!!! And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or I'll 
have to take access away. We do have to get *SOME* work done around here, 
you know...  Also DO NOT ask me to mail you archives, since it's just too 
much work. Thank you.

Images from a variety of sources are available as well, in /pub/images.
There is an UPLOAD directory there as well, if you have images that you'd
like to upload. Please include a file called "from.<username>", where
<username> is your logon ID that describes the files if possible.

NOTE: To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY mode in FTP. 
Then on receipt, you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program, or equivalent,
to restore to textual format.

SECOND NOTE: if you really, really need to get a full set of archives, 
we have a business services group which could write you a tape for a fee.
Let me know if you really, really need that.

FINAL NOTE: As I noted in a prior mailing, the FTP restriction above applies 
to major downloading of stuff from the archives, not WWW access. Suggestions 
for improving the WWW pages would be welcomed, as well as experienced help
in doing so.

CLUB-INFO

Some Porsche Club info follows. IF you're not a member, PLEASE join!! 
This info is also on-line in /pub/pca/info, in case you forget to save
this message!

Porsche Club of Americia.
P.O. Box 10402
Alexandria VA 22310

Does take non-US membership. You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to join.
+1 703 922-9300, roughly 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.
Have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number handy.
Or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your check.

National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is reachable via
e-mail at nannw@aol.com.   You can ask her for info or get her to send 
you an application as well. 


Porsche Club of Great Britain
Ayton House
West End
Northleach
Gloucestershire
England GL54 3HG
Telephone : +44 451 860792
Fax	    +44 451 860011

Specialty clubs:

356 Registry Inc.
27244 Ryan Rd. 
Warren, MI, 48092

For 356 enthusiasts around the world. $20 per year for US members, $35 for
world-wide members -- and cheap at twice the price!!! (Vic Skirmants' racing 
column is worth that, as are the classifieds...) 
5000 happy members can't be wrong! 

P.S. You *DON'T* have to own a 356 to join, and if you think you want to
own one, this is the best place to buy. No one seems to expect concours
prices for their cars unless they have a real concours car.

914 Owner's Association
100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
Palm Springs CA 92262

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries. Dennis Deeds publishes the club
newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly. Membership is $22 a year.
Again, they don't require you own an 914 to join, but they are interested
in the lowest and highest serial numbers known for each year model.

"S" Registry

Contact Vern Lyle, Box 363,
West Point, PA 19486 (tele (215) 652-7011 (day), (215) 287-5083 (eve). 
Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter. Dedicated to all early
911S models.

RULES

This list is still being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming
mail to the whole list at once. The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  

To send a message to the whole list, mail to

		porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative issues,
send mail to

		porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request" address.

The list is also available as a digest, where you get a compilataion of
the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all of the individual
messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow mail links or who
are just too busy to stay current. If you want to convert to (or from)
the digest, send mail to the porschephiles-request address above.

PLEASE NOTE A FEW ITEMS:

1) There are a lot of  members on the list. It's small enough to be effective,
   and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and sets of
   experience. Remember that before you decide to not ask a question, or
   if you get flamed for asking an "obvious" question. Diversity -- it's
   a *feature*....

2) The list is maintained more regularly than it used to be. I have
   routine access and try to handle changes at least once every other
   day.

3) ONLY send administrative mail to the "porschephiles-request"
   address, or to me directly. And, you can also reach me by phone 
   at (713) 661-2084 if you have to.

4) In the same vein, if you use a "pure" System V mail system, please pay
   attention to your replies. The default will send the reply to 
   the "porschephiles-request" address, as it is the UUCP "From "
   address (first actual line of the mail header). 

   PLEASE BE AWARE THAT I ROUTINELY TRASH SUCH MIS-ROUTED MAIL!!!

5) If your mailer starts screwing up *you will be dropped from the list*
   Should you notice that you aren't getting the list any more, send me
   mail and I'll figure out why not...

Enjoy the list! If I can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to drop
me a note.

Regards From Your Moderator,

Stanley P. Hanks
Principal, OMNInet Communications
P.O. Box 2087, Bellaire Texas 77402-2087
e-mail: stan@tta.com    direct voice: (713) 661-2084

'64 356 SC  		(Daily Driver)
'74 914 2.0 		(SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 11:55:54 EET
From: Timo Karttaavi <Timo.Karttaavi@tel.vtt.fi>

You may want to check out the latest (Dec.?) issue of the british
magazine "Car". It features a comparison of the current 911s (C2,

a very small margin.

Date: 	Wed, 4 Jan 1995 15:08:20 +0200 (EET)
From: Patrick Joel Morton <patmor@utu.fi>
Subject: exhaust coatings

_____________________________________________________________________________
_____________________________________________________________________________

P O R S C H E P H I L E S

The latest edition of EC [yes, I subscribe - don't shun me] that I
received here in the Old Country had an interesting article about
updating the 914 heat exchangers and muffler.  Actually, it mirrored what
many porschephilers have posted herein.  Namely, SS exchangers and Bursch
muffler and then the, "How To" information.  Quite handy.

R U S T  P R O O F I N G

The small part of the article that flailed hard was when they mentioned
coating the exhaust for rust proofing.  They suggest an aerosol spray on
"header paint" or Automotion's <g> brush stainless steel coating.  This 
is a waste of money and time.

Rusted mufflers are a major hassle.  It looks terrible, IMHO, and can ruin
the muffler quickly.  As the exhaust is aft of the wheels, rocks and water
that are thrown up off of the wheels combined with the heating and 
cooling of the muffler, contribute to an early death of the system.

I have tried header paint and even followed the instructions for heating
it, cooling it and re-heating to get the paint to bond.  It doesn't last.
Of course, if I owned a kiln the size of a refrigerator, it would be easy
to fire the entire system.  But, I don't, and the Bursch exhaust will not
fit into my Mom's oven :)

I realize that in certain drier climates, this is not too much of a worry.
So what is the answer?  Ceramic coating inside and out?  Is it worth it?
And then who does it?  Should the heat exchangers be coated?

Anyone have an answer?


******************************************************************************
*   									     * 
*                  P A T R I C K   J O E L   M O R T O N                     *
*                   The University of Turku, Finland                         *
*                       patmor@polaris.cc.utu.fi                             *
*      		        GSM +358 (9) 40 502 2654			     *
*        	          FAX +358 21 250 1671      	                     *
*		    There I am, please, be in touch ...		             *
*                                                                            *
******************************************************************************

Patrick Morton

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 08:16:08 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Novice qq, carbs v. fuel injection


Well...for my money a late 70s SC would be a good car, since there
shouldn't be rust to contend with, and the motor is pretty good in
stock form.  If you get into it you can throw carbs on, though that's
pretty dicey from an emissions standpoint.  The 3.0 ltr seems pertty bulletproof.

With an SC you get a better interior to start, seatwise, any you
already have flares, but for me the biggest selling point is lack of
rust and still reasonably low weight and cost.

Steve

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 09:48:52 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: Novice qq, carbs v. fuel injection

Sam Halperin asks about late 60's/early 70's 911 as a learning exercise.  This
is certainly doable, especially if the car does not have to run on Monday
morning.  An earlier response mentions the 78+ SC'
s for their rustproofing --
a real good point.  I would also emphasize the importance of buying a good
running car rather than someone's shed full of problems however attractive the
price.  Believe me, you will get plenty of education KEEPING an old 911 running.
You don't need the indefinite and sometimes unbelievable expense of GETTING an
old 911 running.

Stan and others have mentioned the importance of contacts, and Porschephiles
provides some of what one needs.  The books tell how to assemble and maintain
the car assuming an inexhaustible supply of shiny new parts.  They don't tell
who to call, in your area, for a reasonably priced solution to specific problems
of rust, broken studs, metal fatigue, and the all-to-common book-says-this-
works-but-it-doesn't.  I've found the hardest part of amateur wrenching to be
finding the boundary between my own skills and what I should take to an expert,
and then finding an expert.  What really runs up the bill, in terms of dollars
and of UNfun garage time, is taking more than one try to find a solution that
works.

Anyway, get a running car.  Somehow problems are easier to solve if the pro-
blem dates from yesterday afternoon rather than the summer of 1982.  Good luck.
Try to keep a high ratio of road time to garage time.
B.

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 09:45:13 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Re: 959 sighting, car collecting

Hi,

Last year I was working in Munich. One weekend I was invited to Tegernsee by
some family friends .  Tegernsee BTW is where all the mega rich people from
Munich and the suburbs go to relax and socialize during the weekends (Yes,
these family friends were a bit on the stuffy side). Well on my way down
there, 3 959 were going back up to Munich.  It was almost perfect except
between the 3 was some random car that obviously didn't belong. If I remember
correctly there was a silver, red and I'm not sure on the last one but I
think it was blue. In any case it was a remarkable sight to me, which my
hosts couldn't appreciate. Showing interests in cars was beneath them. 

On another note. I consider myself to be an auto enthusiast and love my old
911. What is going to happen 20 years from now when C2 and 993 become
collectors' cars, much like the situation today with older 911s? MFI or
electrical gremlins are a pain in the ass, but how will the week-end mechanic
deal with DMEs and circuit boards etc. I wouldn't even think of trying to fix
an electrical problem in a new Porsche, BMW or even a Volkswagen. I think it
will make the simpler cars of th e 70's and before even more desirable
because they will be easier to fix. Well that's what I think, but I won't
pass up a 993 in 20 years if given the chance.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa- with electrical problems but no DME to fry   

 

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 04 Jan 1995 08:23:11 -0600 (CST)
From: gwj@louie.timeplex.com (Gregg Jensen)
Subject: Re: New steering wheel leather (LONG)

Howard,

>> Anybody have any experience with recovering a
>> leather steering wheel?

I am in the process of recovering mine right now.  I received a leather
cover for Christmas (it came from Automotion) and over the past couple of 
nights I have done a little bit of the stitching.  After some trial runs on
my tennis shoe I have come up with a pattern that looks very good.  When I
opened the box I noticed that they only supplied one needle and the 
picture in the instructions show two.  You need two.  I went down to Wal-Mart
and picked up a package of needles of various sizes.  What I have done up
till now is cut a piece of string (supplied) approx. 48 inches long (so it is
fairly easy to work with).  Thread a needle on each end. Then I held the wheel
between the left side of my chest and my left knee (perpendicular to my body
...yea, I pulled the steering wheel off), I started at one of the spokes and
pushed one needle through, on the right side of the wheel, from the outside
pushing the needle in towards the steering wheel.  I found the first hole on
the left side and pushed the needle through from the inside.  Then pull the
string and match up the ends and make them even.  You then have one needle on
the left side and one needle on the right side.
Then the pattern that I use is as follows:

1) Take right side needle and put it in the next available hole on the left
   side.  Put it in from the outside pushing in towards the wheel.  Push it
   in until it touches the leather on the right side.
2) Find the second available hole on the right side and push it through.  This
   will leave a hole open on the right side.  Pull the string, but don't make
   it tight yet.
3) Take the left side needle and put it in that hole you skipped on the right
   side.  Put it in from the outside pushing in towards the wheel.
4) Find the next available hole on the left side and push the needle through.
5) Pull both strings tight.  

Repeat the pattern until you get to the ends of the string or until you reach
the end of the leather (when you reach the spoke).  When you get close to the
ends of the string (when it is hard to maneuver the needle without the string
pulling out of the eye of the needle), repeat the pattern, BUT don't do step
2 or step 4. This will leave both sides of the string on the inside of the
leather (closest to the steering wheel).  You can tie off the strings in a 
knot and it won't show. You can then start the process over with another
length of string starting in the next available holes.  If you make sure
that when you begin again by pulling the string through and matching up the
ends that you do it exactly the same way as before (push from the outside in
and then from the inside out) as this hides the string and the first thing
you see on the outside is the string crossing. So far this looks really nice.

Gregg Jensen
REPLY TO gwj@louie.timeplex.com

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 15:17:13 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: 959 sighting, car collecting


NeilK relates sighting a traffic jam of 959 near Munich and says:

| Last year I was working in Munich. One weekend I was invited to Tegernsee by
| some family friends .  Tegernsee BTW is where all the mega rich people from
| Munich and the suburbs go to relax and socialize during the weekends

Bavaria is probably the most visibly affluent place I have
ever visited. Porsche (928 and 911), huge MB S Class and
SL etc seem extraordinarily common. BMW 5 and 7 series are considered 
plebmobiles and suitable for photocopier salesmen and other low-life.
Nobody appeared cheap enough to drive the 3 series. When I was there
people seemed suprised I was driving a 911 (no, not because the English
are too cheap to drive anything except a Mini Metro) but because
it was five years old..eeeww, an old car! how yucky!

God know how the Bavarians make their dosh, but they are rolling in it.

Good beer too if you like that sort of thing!

Regards

Ben

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 15:25:32 GMT
From: kh@wg.icl.co.uk (Kevin Hughes)
Subject: More on washer bottles/windscrren spray

There has been a number of mail items about the washer bottles and strange
deposits causing blockages. I checked to see if this was the cause of my poor
windscreen jet wash - no joy but examination has prompted further question. 

  On examining the screenwashing system there is one feed pipe from the washer
reservoir under the wing to the pump and one outlet which is split into two
using a "T" fitting, one side goes to the screen washer jets the other back to
the washer reservoir under the wing. I checked this very carefully and consulted
the parts explosion microfiche - yes it goes streight back. Now pardon me for 
being so dumb but surely the water will be pumped back into the reservoir - its 
the path of least resistance, I even checked thius by blocking the return to 
washer reservoir path and yes we got real windscreen spray again. Has anyone
any explanation for this odd (to me at least) design andd equally how should
this be "fixed".

Thanks in anticipation

Kevin - 1980 930 (with a dirty screen)

Date: 04 Jan 95 11:12:46 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: FAQ models list/Type 961

 
Hi, John Todd.
 
Yes, the 961 was the racing 959. I think it only ran Le Mans twice, also
once at Daytona. I have a bburago model of one Le Mans
entry. A lady I know who used to work in Styling did the graphics on that
one. I think they only built one or two of these things, total.
 
I never heard of the 953, but maybe that was the pre-959 all-wheel-drive
Carrera that won the Paris-Dakar in 1984? Don't know.
 
Yes, now that Rob Yasek mentions it, I remember the demise of one, or the
only, 961 at its second Le Mans outing, 1987. I have the video someplace, with
the sound from the pit radio patched in of I think Peter Falk telling the
driver (Kees Nierop) "Get out of ze car. Ze car ist on feier."
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 10:36:43 CST
From: jjholt@holt.b11.ingr.com (Jeff Holt)
Subject: 944 cruise control problems


I'm having problems with the cruise control on my 86 944. Sometimes
it works fine, and sometimes just won't engage. I only really use
it on long trips, and it usually either works or doesn't - in
other words if it works, it keeps working for the whole trip,
and if it doesn't, it doesn't every time I try.

The symptoms are that when you push the lever it either does nothing,
or (most commonly) starts to engage (accellerator pedal moves), but
as soon as I release the lever it disengages.

Are there any common problems that I could check? I'm thinking it
may be a relay since I've had to replace the horn relay and the
instrument relay in the last year or so.

Thanks for any hints.

	Jeff

***	jjholt@ingr.com                               FAX  730-6011     ***

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 11:47:43 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Targa top replacement

George

I don't know of a good source for a used top other than trying the normal
used parts purveyers listed in Pano, Excellence etc., but if your friends top
just needs repair or recovering there is an excellent shop in Boulder, CO
which specializes in repairing/reconditioning Targa tops. The shop is:
Dave Brown Automotive Interiors
6186 Gale Drive
Boulder, CO 80303
303-499-0110

Dave has made all his own jigs for repairing top frames and can do a
beautiful job without having the car.  (Assuming the car is reasonably
straight).

Hope this helps

Pat Moyle

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 8:24:21 PST
From: Mark Blaskovich <blaskovi@cisco.com>
Subject: RE: Novice qq, carbs v. fuel injection

I'd like to add that my '70T starts every Monday morning as well as
every other day of the week (daily driver).  The point of buying
a good car up front should be well taken.  Old 911's can be bargins
to buy and fotunes to get in proper shape.  Many folks have bought
these cars for the price of an 8 year old Accord and found that they
can't afford proper maintenance, or the car has problems which they
choose to ignore and only get worse. I bought a car in that condition
and spent more than what the cost of a "better" car would have been
in the first place to get it up to spec.

 I believe an older 911 if in good factory running condition, and 
properly maintained will be a fun and reliable daily driver.  My 
maintenance schedule?  Oil and filter every 2-3K and into a shop 
once a year for a valve adjust and a once over looking for anything 
else needing attention. Btw, my car is driven about 3-6K miles a year.

Mark

> 
> Anyway, get a running car.  Somehow problems are easier to solve if the pro-
> blem dates from yesterday afternoon rather than the summer of 1982.  Good luck.
> Try to keep a high ratio of road time to garage time.
> B.

------------------------------

Date: 4 Jan 1995 12:21:42 U
From: "Piescik, Walter" <wpiescik@mailcenter.tsmi.iitri.com>
Subject: Leather Wheel Recovered

> Anybody have any experience with recovering a
> leather steering wheel?

I had to replace the disintegrated leather cover from my three spoke 911
wheel. I chose to do it myself using the AGLA product. The results where
good, and have lasted weel, but I will caution you that it is a *great* deal
of time spent hunched over a wheel that will not sit still! I eventually took
a steering shaft out of a 356 I was restoring, mounted the wheel on it, and
clamped it in a vice. 

If you picture sitting in front of the tube for an hour or two doing this,
think again! It took about 5 hours and my back hurt like hell. If you don't
mind the lack of quality Stan details in his response, go with the service at
the hundred dollars or so that it costs, barring quality concerns it is a
good value.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 04 Jan 95 11:10:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.ncr.com>
Subject: 914   December '94 sucked.


Greetings everyone.
  I'm still reeling from last month.  Boy I hate holiday funerals in Iowa. 
 big time!
  Too expensive, too wet, too lazy and too bitchy.

  I've got some business to settle with a few of you.  I will deal with that 
shortly.
          Please Stand By.

  But I thought to share with you my latest awwshit.
  -I gotta do a floorpan on the Saga of '76 <right now!>.

  EEeeewwWW !!  I knew the car had air leaks thru a couple rust holes
but when I started on the passenger side underseat supports. . . I saw what
no man should have to see;  Fiberglass patch compound hiding missing
panel segments, you know, like where rusty metal was removed.
  Skillfully concealed mind you.  Some wiley craftsman carefully taped
cardboard from behind and troweled in copious amounts of fiberglass
filler.  This did nothing for strengthening the body (to say the least!).
  The car's frame is compromised and now I wont drive it until repaired.
  So much for making use of the holiday break.

  One thing leads to another I reckon.  What started out as a simple probe
turned into a real nightmare!  I now have a 914 Flintstone mobile, only 
problem
is that where your butt should go is where the pan is now gone. . . I can 
climb in
and out thru the opening!     Go ahead, laugh!    Hey hey hey! bummer dude!
     <G>   <G>  <G>
  Oh, look dear. . . this car has a reverse ejection seat and a special 
access
port for changing spark plugs on #2 & #3!  how quaint!

  For me, this is not a horrible thing <really>, just a damn hassle and bad 
timing.
  It is winter, and I needed the car (or I get to fix my Olds Cutlass) and I 
dont
have access to a garage to work in.  Yep, I can shivver too.  Kansas.
  I still have my dignity in that 'I did it to myself'.

  So before Dr914 and all the other 914 pundits start giving me shit, let me 
say
that this problem is in good hands (mine).  And rest assured that the job 
will be
done well and proper.   I dont mind because of all the crap I've been thru
de-rusting a couple 914's; I have never done a floorpan before, but it wont 
be
insurmountable.  (just wish my rotisserie didnt require powertrain removal).
  Its all work that pays the same.  I just have to remind myself that I 
bought it
for cheep (and I got what I payed for).

  I dont suggest you try this at home.

  BTW, we took a 900 mile trip in my Z28 IROC last month.  Kinda loud, kinda 
rough.
Kinda Hello America!   Most impressive.  I covered the distance well above 
the
speed limits, many passing maneuvers.  A few gas stations (14 Gal. tank).

  I was gratified more than once by drivers who actually pulled over to let 
me pass!
  The drivers are aware of us . . . they just dont like that arrogant ass 
thing that goes
with operating a Porsche.  I for one, can understand their position, 
uniquely so.

 PS:  The sale of my employer did not go thru because of changes in the 
Korean
Gov't.  So our email address has not gone away yet.  The sale will go thru 
and
when it does there will be a grace period extending use of our address.
  Until then a reprieve.

  Toodles,
  -kyle               <kehler@smtplink.wichitaks.ncr.com>

Porschephiles #1047                         Wed Jan 4 11:16:37 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 03:13:17 -0600
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Monthly Update from you ListMeister

January 1995

Monthly Notices for the Porschephiles mailing list. 
PLEASE READ THIS WHOLE MESSAGE!!

There are five sections: UPDATE, COPYRIGHT, FTP-INFO, CLUB-INFO, RULES. Be sure
that you are current on RULES...

UPDATE

The end of a very long, not-so-great year! Here's hoping that the
coming year brings some joy to your lives...

I have a confession: driving a 32 year old car with no heat, some leaks
and a shot steering box is actualy FUN! Hard to believe this, but I'm
actually enjoying the 356SC as a daily driver more than I enjoyed
the 911. It's not even close to the same, but somehow.... Well, if
you have one, you'll know what I mean. If you don't already know,
there's no way I can tell you...

On the list, we're up by nearly 100 members from last month. Who's Who
participation is at a nearly all-time low at 33% though. I'll update it
a little later and get out a fresh edition. There are too many people
MIA due to the holidays to make it quite fair at this point.

There will also be a Porschephiles calendar coming soon too, featuring
planned stops on the 1995 ListMeister World Tour. 8{) Watch for it!
This *WILL* include the long-awaited pre-Parade First Annual Gathering
in scenic RENO, NEVADA, featuring *something* at PCNA. More details
as we go and a big THANKS! to Jim Pasha for his continuing work to help
pull this together.

Digest readers: the digest software still has one bug, that race condition 
which is hard to tickle. So if you get "doubled" digests, you don't 
need to tell me about it, I already know. It will eventually get fixed
and try not to worry about it in the meantime...

Stan

COPYRIGHT AND FAIR USAGE STATEMENT

The messages sent to this list constitute private correspondence by and between
members of a closed community. As such, the copyright for EVERYTHING that 
ANYONE posts lies with them. PERIOD. This is *NOT* a bulletin board system,
where consent for further redistribution is implied by nature of the the
system; it's PRIVATE.

If you wish to use something written by someone on the list, you must first
seek their permission unless they specifically grant the right in that
specific posting to reprint it at will. And, in general, it is a VERY GOOD
idea to *CREDIT* someone if you use something by permission "copyright xxxx
Joe Gearhead, used by permission" to keep *SOMEONE ELSE* from screwing up
down the line.

You may also solicit articles, comments, notes and expansions of previous
notes. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

Remember, when you read something on this list: what you are reading belongs
to whoever wrote it. They may have plans to publish it further themselves.
They may want to keep it "private" (i.e. just for list member use). They 
may not care what gets done with it. It's still theirs, and before re-use,
permission must be obtained.

Please respect people's rights, even if they don't make a big deal about it.
I mean it.

FTP-INFO

Archives are available via FTP, compressed, since 4/90. There are no
older archives available. Remember, while it seems like a good idea when 
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before, 
there are OVER 18 MEG of archives. DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE TIME. 
Period!!! And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or I'll 
have to take access away. We do have to get *SOME* work done around here, 
you know...  Also DO NOT ask me to mail you archives, since it's just too 
much work. Thank you.

Images from a variety of sources are available as well, in /pub/images.
There is an UPLOAD directory there as well, if you have images that you'd
like to upload. Please include a file called "from.<username>", where
<username> is your logon ID that describes the files if possible.

NOTE: To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY mode in FTP. 
Then on receipt, you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program, or equivalent,
to restore to textual format.

SECOND NOTE: if you really, really need to get a full set of archives, 
we have a business services group which could write you a tape for a fee.
Let me know if you really, really need that.

FINAL NOTE: As I noted in a prior mailing, the FTP restriction above applies 
to major downloading of stuff from the archives, not WWW access. Suggestions 
for improving the WWW pages would be welcomed, as well as experienced help
in doing so.

CLUB-INFO

Some Porsche Club info follows. IF you're not a member, PLEASE join!! 
This info is also on-line in /pub/pca/info, in case you forget to save
this message!

Porsche Club of Americia.
P.O. Box 10402
Alexandria VA 22310

Does take non-US membership. You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to join.
+1 703 922-9300, roughly 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.
Have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number handy.
Or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your check.

National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is reachable via
e-mail at nannw@aol.com.   You can ask her for info or get her to send 
you an application as well. 


Porsche Club of Great Britain
Ayton House
West End
Northleach
Gloucestershire
England GL54 3HG
Telephone : +44 451 860792
Fax	    +44 451 860011

Specialty clubs:

356 Registry Inc.
27244 Ryan Rd. 
Warren, MI, 48092

For 356 enthusiasts around the world. $20 per year for US members, $35 for
world-wide members -- and cheap at twice the price!!! (Vic Skirmants' racing 
column is worth that, as are the classifieds...) 
5000 happy members can't be wrong! 

P.S. You *DON'T* have to own a 356 to join, and if you think you want to
own one, this is the best place to buy. No one seems to expect concours
prices for their cars unless they have a real concours car.

914 Owner's Association
100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
Palm Springs CA 92262

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries. Dennis Deeds publishes the club
newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly. Membership is $22 a year.
Again, they don't require you own an 914 to join, but they are interested
in the lowest and highest serial numbers known for each year model.

"S" Registry

Contact Vern Lyle, Box 363,
West Point, PA 19486 (tele (215) 652-7011 (day), (215) 287-5083 (eve). 
Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter. Dedicated to all early
911S models.

RULES

This list is still being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming
mail to the whole list at once. The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  

To send a message to the whole list, mail to

		porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative issues,
send mail to

		porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request" address.

The list is also available as a digest, where you get a compilataion of
the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all of the individual
messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow mail links or who
are just too busy to stay current. If you want to convert to (or from)
the digest, send mail to the porschephiles-request address above.

PLEASE NOTE A FEW ITEMS:

1) There are a lot of  members on the list. It's small enough to be effective,
   and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and sets of
   experience. Remember that before you decide to not ask a question, or
   if you get flamed for asking an "obvious" question. Diversity -- it's
   a *feature*....

2) The list is maintained more regularly than it used to be. I have
   routine access and try to handle changes at least once every other
   day.

3) ONLY send administrative mail to the "porschephiles-request"
   address, or to me directly. And, you can also reach me by phone 
   at (713) 661-2084 if you have to.

4) In the same vein, if you use a "pure" System V mail system, please pay
   attention to your replies. The default will send the reply to 
   the "porschephiles-request" address, as it is the UUCP "From "
   address (first actual line of the mail header). 

   PLEASE BE AWARE THAT I ROUTINELY TRASH SUCH MIS-ROUTED MAIL!!!

5) If your mailer starts screwing up *you will be dropped from the list*
   Should you notice that you aren't getting the list any more, send me
   mail and I'll figure out why not...

Enjoy the list! If I can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to drop
me a note.

Regards From Your Moderator,

Stanley P. Hanks
Principal, OMNInet Communications
P.O. Box 2087, Bellaire Texas 77402-2087
e-mail: stan@tta.com    direct voice: (713) 661-2084

'64 356 SC  		(Daily Driver)
'74 914 2.0 		(SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)

Date: 	Wed, 4 Jan 1995 15:08:20 +0200 (EET)
From: Patrick Joel Morton <patmor@utu.fi>
Subject: exhaust coatings

_____________________________________________________________________________
_____________________________________________________________________________

P O R S C H E P H I L E S

The latest edition of EC [yes, I subscribe - don't shun me] that I
received here in the Old Country had an interesting article about
updating the 914 heat exchangers and muffler.  Actually, it mirrored what
many porschephilers have posted herein.  Namely, SS exchangers and Bursch
muffler and then the, "How To" information.  Quite handy.

R U S T  P R O O F I N G

The small part of the article that flailed hard was when they mentioned
coating the exhaust for rust proofing.  They suggest an aerosol spray on
"header paint" or Automotion's <g> brush stainless steel coating.  This 
is a waste of money and time.

Rusted mufflers are a major hassle.  It looks terrible, IMHO, and can ruin
the muffler quickly.  As the exhaust is aft of the wheels, rocks and water
that are thrown up off of the wheels combined with the heating and 
cooling of the muffler, contribute to an early death of the system.

I have tried header paint and even followed the instructions for heating
it, cooling it and re-heating to get the paint to bond.  It doesn't last.
Of course, if I owned a kiln the size of a refrigerator, it would be easy
to fire the entire system.  But, I don't, and the Bursch exhaust will not
fit into my Mom's oven :)

I realize that in certain drier climates, this is not too much of a worry.
So what is the answer?  Ceramic coating inside and out?  Is it worth it?
And then who does it?  Should the heat exchangers be coated?

Anyone have an answer?

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 08:16:08 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Novice qq, carbs v. fuel injection


Well...for my money a late 70s SC would be a good car, since there
shouldn't be rust to contend with, and the motor is pretty good in
stock form.  If you get into it you can throw carbs on, though that's
pretty dicey from an emissions standpoint.  The 3.0 ltr seems pertty bulletproof.

With an SC you get a better interior to start, seatwise, any you
already have flares, but for me the biggest selling point is lack of
rust and still reasonably low weight and cost.

Steve

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 09:48:52 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: Novice qq, carbs v. fuel injection

Sam Halperin asks about late 60's/early 70's 911 as a learning exercise.  This
is certainly doable, especially if the car does not have to run on Monday
morning.  An earlier response mentions the 78+ SC'
s for their rustproofing --
a real good point.  I would also emphasize the importance of buying a good
running car rather than someone's shed full of problems however attractive the
price.  Believe me, you will get plenty of education KEEPING an old 911 running.
You don't need the indefinite and sometimes unbelievable expense of GETTING an
old 911 running.

Stan and others have mentioned the importance of contacts, and Porschephiles
provides some of what one needs.  The books tell how to assemble and maintain
the car assuming an inexhaustible supply of shiny new parts.  They don't tell
who to call, in your area, for a reasonably priced solution to specific problems
of rust, broken studs, metal fatigue, and the all-to-common book-says-this-
works-but-it-doesn't.  I've found the hardest part of amateur wrenching to be
finding the boundary between my own skills and what I should take to an expert,
and then finding an expert.  What really runs up the bill, in terms of dollars
and of UNfun garage time, is taking more than one try to find a solution that
works.

Anyway, get a running car.  Somehow problems are easier to solve if the pro-
blem dates from yesterday afternoon rather than the summer of 1982.  Good luck.
Try to keep a high ratio of road time to garage time.
B.

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 09:45:13 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Re: 959 sighting, car collecting

Hi,

Last year I was working in Munich. One weekend I was invited to Tegernsee by
some family friends .  Tegernsee BTW is where all the mega rich people from
Munich and the suburbs go to relax and socialize during the weekends (Yes,
these family friends were a bit on the stuffy side). Well on my way down
there, 3 959 were going back up to Munich.  It was almost perfect except
between the 3 was some random car that obviously didn't belong. If I remember
correctly there was a silver, red and I'm not sure on the last one but I
think it was blue. In any case it was a remarkable sight to me, which my
hosts couldn't appreciate. Showing interests in cars was beneath them. 

On another note. I consider myself to be an auto enthusiast and love my old
911. What is going to happen 20 years from now when C2 and 993 become
collectors' cars, much like the situation today with older 911s? MFI or
electrical gremlins are a pain in the ass, but how will the week-end mechanic
deal with DMEs and circuit boards etc. I wouldn't even think of trying to fix
an electrical problem in a new Porsche, BMW or even a Volkswagen. I think it
will make the simpler cars of th e 70's and before even more desirable
because they will be easier to fix. Well that's what I think, but I won't
pass up a 993 in 20 years if given the chance.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa- with electrical problems but no DME to fry

Date: Wed, 04 Jan 1995 08:23:11 -0600 (CST)
From: gwj@louie.timeplex.com (Gregg Jensen)
Subject: Re: New steering wheel leather (LONG)

Howard,

>> Anybody have any experience with recovering a
>> leather steering wheel?

I am in the process of recovering mine right now.  I received a leather
cover for Christmas (it came from Automotion) and over the past couple of 
nights I have done a little bit of the stitching.  After some trial runs on
my tennis shoe I have come up with a pattern that looks very good.  When I
opened the box I noticed that they only supplied one needle and the 
picture in the instructions show two.  You need two.  I went down to Wal-Mart
and picked up a package of needles of various sizes.  What I have done up
till now is cut a piece of string (supplied) approx. 48 inches long (so it is
fairly easy to work with).  Thread a needle on each end. Then I held the wheel
between the left side of my chest and my left knee (perpendicular to my body
...yea, I pulled the steering wheel off), I started at one of the spokes and
pushed one needle through, on the right side of the wheel, from the outside
pushing the needle in towards the steering wheel.  I found the first hole on
the left side and pushed the needle through from the inside.  Then pull the
string and match up the ends and make them even.  You then have one needle on
the left side and one needle on the right side.
Then the pattern that I use is as follows:

1) Take right side needle and put it in the next available hole on the left
   side.  Put it in from the outside pushing in towards the wheel.  Push it
   in until it touches the leather on the right side.
2) Find the second available hole on the right side and push it through.  This
   will leave a hole open on the right side.  Pull the string, but don't make
   it tight yet.
3) Take the left side needle and put it in that hole you skipped on the right
   side.  Put it in from the outside pushing in towards the wheel.
4) Find the next available hole on the left side and push the needle through.
5) Pull both strings tight.  

Repeat the pattern until you get to the ends of the string or until you reach
the end of the leather (when you reach the spoke).  When you get close to the
ends of the string (when it is hard to maneuver the needle without the string
pulling out of the eye of the needle), repeat the pattern, BUT don't do step
2 or step 4. This will leave both sides of the string on the inside of the
leather (closest to the steering wheel).  You can tie off the strings in a 
knot and it won't show. You can then start the process over with another
length of string starting in the next available holes.  If you make sure
that when you begin again by pulling the string through and matching up the
ends that you do it exactly the same way as before (push from the outside in
and then from the inside out) as this hides the string and the first thing
you see on the outside is the string crossing. So far this looks really nice.

Gregg Jensen
REPLY TO gwj@louie.timeplex.com



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 15:17:13 +0000
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: 959 sighting, car collecting


NeilK relates sighting a traffic jam of 959 near Munich and says:

| Last year I was working in Munich. One weekend I was invited to Tegernsee by
| some family friends .  Tegernsee BTW is where all the mega rich people from
| Munich and the suburbs go to relax and socialize during the weekends

Bavaria is probably the most visibly affluent place I have
ever visited. Porsche (928 and 911), huge MB S Class and
SL etc seem extraordinarily common. BMW 5 and 7 series are considered 
plebmobiles and suitable for photocopier salesmen and other low-life.
Nobody appeared cheap enough to drive the 3 series. When I was there
people seemed suprised I was driving a 911 (no, not because the English
are too cheap to drive anything except a Mini Metro) but because
it was five years old..eeeww, an old car! how yucky!

God know how the Bavarians make their dosh, but they are rolling in it.

Good beer too if you like that sort of thing!

Regards

Ben

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 15:25:32 GMT
From: kh@wg.icl.co.uk (Kevin Hughes)
Subject: More on washer bottles/windscrren spray

There has been a number of mail items about the washer bottles and strange
deposits causing blockages. I checked to see if this was the cause of my poor
windscreen jet wash - no joy but examination has prompted further question. 

  On examining the screenwashing system there is one feed pipe from the washer
reservoir under the wing to the pump and one outlet which is split into two
using a "T" fitting, one side goes to the screen washer jets the other back to
the washer reservoir under the wing. I checked this very carefully and consulted
the parts explosion microfiche - yes it goes streight back. Now pardon me for 
being so dumb but surely the water will be pumped back into the reservoir - its 
the path of least resistance, I even checked thius by blocking the return to 
washer reservoir path and yes we got real windscreen spray again. Has anyone
any explanation for this odd (to me at least) design andd equally how should
this be "fixed".

Thanks in anticipation

Kevin - 1980 930 (with a dirty screen)

Date: Wed, 04 Jan 1995 17:00:34 +0100

Date: 04 Jan 95 11:12:46 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: FAQ models list/Type 961

 
Hi, John Todd.
 
Yes, the 961 was the racing 959. I think it only ran Le Mans twice, also
once at Daytona. I have a bburago model of one Le Mans
entry. A lady I know who used to work in Styling did the graphics on that
one. I think they only built one or two of these things, total.
 
I never heard of the 953, but maybe that was the pre-959 all-wheel-drive
Carrera that won the Paris-Dakar in 1984? Don't know.
 
Yes, now that Rob Yasek mentions it, I remember the demise of one, or the
only, 961 at its second Le Mans outing, 1987. I have the video someplace, with
the sound from the pit radio patched in of I think Peter Falk telling the
driver (Kees Nierop) "Get out of ze car. Ze car ist on feier."
 
Pete

From: Steve Tarket <tarket@hpfcqd.fc.hp.com>
Subject: Rocky Mountain Tech

Rocky Mountain Region PCA would like to Announce the 1st Annual Rocky Mountain
Tech. This will be an all day Tech session featuring some of PCA's top 
technical people. This event will be held on Saturday March 4 from 9AM to 5pm
at the Ramada Inn, Highway 36 and Sheridan, Denver Colorado. Cost for this 
event will be less than $20 per person. Registration forms and more details 
will be available soon. If you would like more information contact Sandy 
Misura evenings at 303-530-0911 or myself by E-mail at tarket@hpfcqd.fc.hp.com

Featured Speakers

Bruce Anderson - Bruce is PCA's National Tech Chairman and author of the 
911 performance handbook.

John Paterek -John is President of Paterek Brothers, a company specializing
in restoration of unique Porsches. He is also a member of the PCA National 
Tech. Committee in charge of interiors and exteriors.

Steve Tarket

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 10:36:43 CST
From: jjholt@holt.b11.ingr.com (Jeff Holt)
Subject: 944 cruise control problems


I'm having problems with the cruise control on my 86 944. Sometimes
it works fine, and sometimes just won't engage. I only really use
it on long trips, and it usually either works or doesn't - in
other words if it works, it keeps working for the whole trip,
and if it doesn't, it doesn't every time I try.

The symptoms are that when you push the lever it either does nothing,
or (most commonly) starts to engage (accellerator pedal moves), but
as soon as I release the lever it disengages.

Are there any common problems that I could check? I'm thinking it
may be a relay since I've had to replace the horn relay and the
instrument relay in the last year or so.

Thanks for any hints.

	Jeff

***	jjholt@ingr.com                               FAX  730-6011     ***
***   CR1100,  Intergraph Computer Systems,  Huntsville, AL 35894-0001  ***

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 11:47:43 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Targa top replacement

George

I don't know of a good source for a used top other than trying the normal
used parts purveyers listed in Pano, Excellence etc., but if your friends top
just needs repair or recovering there is an excellent shop in Boulder, CO
which specializes in repairing/reconditioning Targa tops. The shop is:
Dave Brown Automotive Interiors
6186 Gale Drive
Boulder, CO 80303
303-499-0110

Dave has made all his own jigs for repairing top frames and can do a
beautiful job without having the car.  (Assuming the car is reasonably
straight).

Hope this helps

Pat Moyle

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 8:24:21 PST
From: Mark Blaskovich <blaskovi@cisco.com>
Subject: RE: Novice qq, carbs v. fuel injection

I'd like to add that my '70T starts every Monday morning as well as
every other day of the week (daily driver).  The point of buying
a good car up front should be well taken.  Old 911's can be bargins
to buy and fotunes to get in proper shape.  Many folks have bought
these cars for the price of an 8 year old Accord and found that they
can't afford proper maintenance, or the car has problems which they
choose to ignore and only get worse. I bought a car in that condition
and spent more than what the cost of a "better" car would have been
in the first place to get it up to spec.

 I believe an older 911 if in good factory running condition, and 
properly maintained will be a fun and reliable daily driver.  My 
maintenance schedule?  Oil and filter every 2-3K and into a shop 
once a year for a valve adjust and a once over looking for anything 
else needing attention. Btw, my car is driven about 3-6K miles a year.

Mark

> 
> Sam Halperin asks about late 60's/early 70's 911 as a learning exercise.  This
> is certainly doable, especially if the car does not have to run on Monday
> morning.  An earlier response mentions the 78+ SC'
> s for their rustproofing --
> a real good point.  I would also emphasize the importance of buying a good
> running car rather than someone's shed full of problems however attractive the
> price.  Believe me, you will get plenty of education KEEPING an old 911 running.
> You don't need the indefinite and sometimes unbelievable expense of GETTING an
> old 911 running.
> 
> Stan and others have mentioned the importance of contacts, and Porschephiles
> provides some of what one needs.  The books tell how to assemble and maintain
> the car assuming an inexhaustible supply of shiny new parts.  They don't tell
> who to call, in your area, for a reasonably priced solution to specific problems
> of rust, broken studs, metal fatigue, and the all-to-common book-says-this-
> works-but-it-doesn't.  I've found the hardest part of amateur wrenching to be
> finding the boundary between my own skills and what I should take to an expert,
> and then finding an expert.  What really runs up the bill, in terms of dollars
> and of UNfun garage time, is taking more than one try to find a solution that
> works.
> 
> Anyway, get a running car.  Somehow problems are easier to solve if the pro-
> blem dates from yesterday afternoon rather than the summer of 1982.  Good luck.
> Try to keep a high ratio of road time to garage time.
> B.
>

Date: 4 Jan 1995 12:21:42 U
From: "Piescik, Walter" <wpiescik@mailcenter.tsmi.iitri.com>
Subject: Leather Wheel Recovered

> Anybody have any experience with recovering a
> leather steering wheel?

I had to replace the disintegrated leather cover from my three spoke 911
wheel. I chose to do it myself using the AGLA product. The results where
good, and have lasted weel, but I will caution you that it is a *great* deal
of time spent hunched over a wheel that will not sit still! I eventually took
a steering shaft out of a 356 I was restoring, mounted the wheel on it, and
clamped it in a vice. 

If you picture sitting in front of the tube for an hour or two doing this,
think again! It took about 5 hours and my back hurt like hell. If you don't
mind the lack of quality Stan details in his response, go with the service at
the hundred dollars or so that it costs, barring quality concerns it is a
good value.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 04 Jan 95 11:10:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.ncr.com>
Subject: 914   December '94 sucked.


Greetings everyone.
  I'm still reeling from last month.  Boy I hate holiday funerals in Iowa. 
 big time!
  Too expensive, too wet, too lazy and too bitchy.

  I've got some business to settle with a few of you.  I will deal with that 
shortly.
          Please Stand By.

  But I thought to share with you my latest awwshit.
  -I gotta do a floorpan on the Saga of '76 <right now!>.

  EEeeewwWW !!  I knew the car had air leaks thru a couple rust holes
but when I started on the passenger side underseat supports. . . I saw what
no man should have to see;  Fiberglass patch compound hiding missing
panel segments, you know, like where rusty metal was removed.
  Skillfully concealed mind you.  Some wiley craftsman carefully taped
cardboard from behind and troweled in copious amounts of fiberglass
filler.  This did nothing for strengthening the body (to say the least!).
  The car's frame is compromised and now I wont drive it until repaired.
  So much for making use of the holiday break.

  One thing leads to another I reckon.  What started out as a simple probe
turned into a real nightmare!  I now have a 914 Flintstone mobile, only 
problem
is that where your butt should go is where the pan is now gone. . . I can 
climb in
and out thru the opening!     Go ahead, laugh!    Hey hey hey! bummer dude!
     <G>   <G>  <G>
  Oh, look dear. . . this car has a reverse ejection seat and a special 
access
port for changing spark plugs on #2 & #3!  how quaint!

  For me, this is not a horrible thing <really>, just a damn hassle and bad 
timing.
  It is winter, and I needed the car (or I get to fix my Olds Cutlass) and I 
dont
have access to a garage to work in.  Yep, I can shivver too.  Kansas.
  I still have my dignity in that 'I did it to myself'.

  So before Dr914 and all the other 914 pundits start giving me shit, let me 
say
that this problem is in good hands (mine).  And rest assured that the job 
will be
done well and proper.   I dont mind because of all the crap I've been thru
de-rusting a couple 914's; I have never done a floorpan before, but it wont 
be
insurmountable.  (just wish my rotisserie didnt require powertrain removal).
  Its all work that pays the same.  I just have to remind myself that I 
bought it
for cheep (and I got what I payed for).

  I dont suggest you try this at home.

  BTW, we took a 900 mile trip in my Z28 IROC last month.  Kinda loud, kinda 
rough.
Kinda Hello America!   Most impressive.  I covered the distance well above 
the
speed limits, many passing maneuvers.  A few gas stations (14 Gal. tank).

  I was gratified more than once by drivers who actually pulled over to let 
me pass!
  The drivers are aware of us . . . they just dont like that arrogant ass 
thing that goes
with operating a Porsche.  I for one, can understand their position, 
uniquely so.

 PS:  The sale of my employer did not go thru because of changes in the 
Korean
Gov't.  So our email address has not gone away yet.  The sale will go thru 
and
when it does there will be a grace period extending use of our address.
  Until then a reprieve.

  Toodles,
  -kyle               <kehler@smtplink.wichitaks.ncr.com>

Porschephiles #1048                         Wed Jan 4 16:43:52 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 04 Jan 95 16:51:01 -0800
From: "NICK BULLOWS" <bullowsn@a1larvae.larvae.ucg.MTS.dec.com>
Subject: What motivates a purist mechanic ?

[This message is converted from WPS-PLUS to ASCII]

Hello 

Do all Porsche owners, older vehicle owners in particular, "suffer", "put up 
with lousy time management", "go screaming mad","wonder why they ever bought a 
Porsche", every time they take their pride and joy to the trusted 'years of 
experience' mechanic?
 
Don't get me wrong, I've got the best man working on the job. It's not the 
quality of his work I'm upset with, it's the attitude that time is unimportant 
almost like an artist working on his masterpiece.

But when he says "one day" he means a week, when he says "3 weeks" he means 2 
months. Do they all work one job at a time. We'll build the crank case first 
then order the barrels and pistons. 3 weeks later when they arrive and you think 
the job is nearly done they say "Where waiting for 3 valves, I ordered them last 
week" I think "why didn't order the 2 months ago".

It's not a money thing, he get insulted if I suggest ordering parts in advance 
and paying of the parts early. He often doesn't bill me for a month or two if 
I'm mad with him for letting me down again.

What trick's do you all used, so that you can plan when your car might come back 
after handing the keys over?

Please, don't say "Buy another Porsche". 

Why are the best mechanics such lousy business men ?

Cheers Nick

When I bought the 914 about a year ago, the first thing someone said to me
was "I hope you like the cold, the heater system suck's!".

Well, I have the opposite problem!! I can not turn the heater off entirely!
When you are AutoCrossing and it is 100 degrees outside, the last thing you
want is the heater on!!

Someone mentioned the the heater control knob did not have enough tension on
it, but when I checked it felt like it was tight enough. 

So, has anyone had a similar dilemma?? Since the weather is cooler in
Southern California right now  - it is not urgent. But the AutoCrossing
season will start soon and I would like to fix that before then.
