Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 12:54:57 -0500
From: Beverly514@aol.com
Subject: Re: New Steering wheel leather

> Anybody have any experience with recovering a leather steering >wheel?

When the leather steering wheel on my 911 had starting coming apart, I tried
to restich it myself. This was a disaster! I am pretty handy at fixing
things, but this project really humbled me.

After looking around for a good upolsterer, I took the steering wheel to a
John Moch from Moch-1 in Orange County. The outcome was FANTASTIC!! John does
all his own work so it takes a little time, but it is worth it.

Once I decided to start showing my 911 in the Zone 8 Concours series, I have
asked John to do a few other things to the 911. He has  recovered the Targa
Top, installed new OEM style carpet and put in a speaker system worthy of any
audiophile (his design). 

When I discover a someone that does exceptional work, I like to pass the word
along. 

John advertises in the Pano, look for Moch-1, or you can contact him at:
           John Moch
           Moch-1
           1030 N. Main Street, Unit B
           Orange, Ca. 92668
           (714)744-2790 or (800)682-4071


Bev Frohm

70 911E Targa  (Street Concours & Touring)
74 914 2.0        (Daily Driver & AutoCross)
84  female cat Freckles
89  male (six toes) cat Elmer



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 09:58:41 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Bushings

[Since a couple people have enquired about my 914 Weltmeister bushings
experience, I am posting this to porschephiles, too.]

Klaus & Henry:

The bushings are Automotion P/N PB-1012P (front, $40), PB-1005P (rear,
$40), and the grease is BP-172 ($2). I don't have any swaybars
(unfortunately).

I also put turbo tie rods on at the same time, but yes, I would say that I
noticed an improvement.  For example, it was raining here yesterday, and I
was provoking the car (914) into mild spins/slides.  The transitions were
very smooth, with no feelings of a "load change", and the corrections were
equally smooth.  Put another way, I felt nothing untoward in any load
transfers or other vehicle suspension dynamics.

I put liberal amounts of grease (it doesn't take much, actually) on both
sides of the bushings and on the A-arm & rear arm.  Note that this is
different from stock, where it appears to me that the inner surface of each
bushings was immobile relative to the piece it surrounds. One nice thing
about these bushings is that unlike the originals, they're dimensioned such
that it's very easy to remove them later.  You needn't be a gorilla to
install them.

I did have one problem with the pass.-side rear A-arm bushing - I had just
had the front suspension crossmember and the front and rear bushing
brackets powder-coated, and that particular bushing, when installed, felt
like it was going in against a slight taper.  The solution was to get it in
as far as possible (there was still a 1/4" gap remaining), get the
suspension bolted up into the body, and then use a nylon strap
tourniquet-style to pull the A-arm back into the crossmember.  Then pulled
the front cup back, torqued it down and everything was nice and tight.

HTH,

Andrew


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 12:57:02 -0500 (EST)
From: tpep@epix.net
Subject: Re: Spot welding guns! Any advice?? W3 Info Too!



On Wed, 4 Jan 1995, Trond Vidar Olsen wrote:

> Hiall,
> 
> I'm thinking about getting one of them spot welding guns for about $75. 
> (Eastwood catalog.(thanks Derek!)) Anyone tried these? Instead of buying a 
> $400 spot welder I hoped the gun would be good enough for spot welds in 
> 'thin' Porsche steel?
> 
> I'm also interested in knowing what you/someone you know/other people say 
> about the quality of the hammers and dollies for sheet metal work as 
> advertised from Eastwoods.
> 
	I have tried the type of spot welder you spoke of and found it 
tricky at best.  Kept burning holes in the steel.  Mind you,  I was 
inexperienced at welding at the time so your results may vary.  I then 
tried Oxy-Acetyline having so-so results after months of practice.  Then 
came MIG.  Aahh! this is how welding is supposed to work.  I was amazed 
how easy it was to use.  If you check out Harbor Frieght Tools 
(1-800-423-2567) you will find that they have a good selection of MIG 
welders at very resonable prices as well as many other goodies for us 
tool junkies.

	I'm sure some would argue but I think MIG welders are the way to 
go for all purpose welding.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 13:07:59 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: 914 Heater cables

> Well, I have the opposite problem!! I can not turn the heater off entirely!
> When you are AutoCrossing and it is 100 degrees outside, the last thing you
> want is the heater on!!
> So, has anyone had a similar dilemma??

Similar in that on my '71 914 1.8, I had no heat at all, but when I
took it on a skiing trip, I was able to wire the heat control levers
in the "on" position, and was quite toasty warm the whole trip. VT Rt. 7
is Awesome - and on the way to it, I went through the hairpin on MA Rt. 2,
which has a speed limit of 15mph, which is actually too high for most vehicles.
The Porsche went through it at 20, which was really quite something...
there used to be a gift shop on the outside of that curve, but a tractor-
trailer took it out a couple of years back.

I would suggest that you could most likely do a similar trick on your
914 - pull (or wire) the heat control lever on the heat exchanger into
the preferred position.

- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

NICK BULLOWS said...
> Do all Porsche owners, older vehicle owners in particular, "suffer", "put up 

Well, not every time, but it is close.

> almost like an artist working on his masterpiece.

Almost? <grin>

> What trick's do you all used, so that you can plan when your car might come back 
> after handing the keys over?

Well, all the mechanics of this type that I know will go to great 
lengths to get a car ready for the track. So... when you make an 
appointment you say you've got a PCA track event or autocross or whatever 
and you've *got* to have the car for then, well. (Don't lie, of course.)

A clean, obviously-well-cared-for car also gets better service as well, 
it seems.

My 2 cents (1.5 US).

Craig.

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 11:03:03 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Pop-off valve installation...a question


My 83 911SC does not have a pop-off valve, so I just got one from
Zimms. I am looking through the installation procedures, and they
say to hole saw a 2" hole in the air box using the template supplied.
Fine. The question that comes to mind is where are all those little
plastic filings and pieces going while I am drilling this hole? Further
down in the instructions, they state "Vacuum up the chips in the air box,
and also inside the hole. A show vac or house vacuum cleaner will do".

Can you really get all the chips out? I am not concerned with the top
portion of the air box, since I can use my shop-vac and lots of protective
rags. I am concerned with the filing dropping into the lower section of 
the airbox as the hole is cut.

Any comments from people who have actually done it?

Thanks in advance.

Mike J.
83 911SC


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 11:07:35 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: What motivates a purist mechanic ?


- --Boundary-5933434-0-0

Nick:  You can have your cake and eat it too.  If you want good work on time 
you just have to find a wrench that will give it to you. Use PCA referrals, 
friends, this BB and whatever else you have to identify guys that are 
organized and keep their committments and do good work.  They're out there, it 
just takes some looking. 
 
If someone is a prima donna but does exceptional work only on  their own 
schedule then use them only if you're willing to put up with their 
idiosynchrysies.  If you can't live with their weirdness, go elsewhere if the 
quality of work doesn't offset the frustration of dealing with them. 
 
I think that what motivates a "purist" as you call him is the work.  They like 
doing the work, seeing the motor come together, caressing each part, etc.  The 
problem with this type of wrench is that they love the work process and are 
attached to it.  They're not attached to completion.  You on the other hand, 
are attached to completion. 
  
There are no artists in auto repair, only good craftsmen.  When someone adopts 
an idiosyncratic artistic attitude about fixin' a body, rebuilding an engine, 
or bleeding my brakes, I'm outta there.  Personally, the best wrenches I've 
met  set schedules, made committments and kept them.  It's what I have to do 
everyday and I demand it of anyone I'm gonna give my hard earned bucks to. 
 
So, if he makes you crazy, next time find someone else.  Nothing short of a 
frontal lobotomy is gonna change him. 
 
Ted Smith 
63 Cab 
64 Cpe 
68 912 Targa Softback.


- --Boundary-5933434-0-0

Do all Porsche owners, older vehicle owners in particular, "suffer", "put up 
with lousy time management", "go screaming mad","wonder why they ever bought a

then order the barrels and pistons. 3 weeks later when they arrive and you think 
the job is nearly done they say "Where waiting for 3 valves, I ordered them last 
week" I think "why didn't order the 2 months ago".

It's not a money thing, he get insulted if I suggest ordering parts in advance 
and paying of the parts early. He often doesn't bill me for a month or two if 
I'm mad with him for letting me down again.

What trick's do you all used, so that you can plan when your car might come back 
after handing the keys over?

Please, don't say "Buy another Porsche". 

Why are the best mechanics such lousy business men ?

Cheers Nick


- --Boundary-5933434-0-0--

Date: Wed,  4 Jan 95 13:24:34 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Eastwood spot welder

>From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
>Subject: Spot welding guns! Any advice?? W3 Info Too!

>Hiall,

>I'm thinking about getting one of them spot welding guns for about $75.
>(Eastwood catalog.(thanks Derek!)) Anyone tried these? Instead of buying a
>$400 spot welder I hoped the gun would be good enough for spot welds in
>'thin' Porsche steel?

      Trond, I cannot weld any other way but I have used the Eastwood
 spot weld gun (that attaches thru an arc welder).  It can make beautiful
 and strong welds, the hard part is that the metal surfaces have to be
 -very very very- tight and clean, otherwise it will burn thru the top layer
 only. Spraying Zinc epoxy ("galvanizing spray") helps (I guess) but I
 would only use the gun if you are trying to cosmetically reproduce factory 
 type welds. For anything heavy or structural or hidden, I used my brother 
 and  a MIG !

      You might also consider trying a tool rental or welders supply
 place to see if you can get a "real" tong-type spot welder. I have no idea
 whether these work easier. If you are interested in buying one of these let 
 me know and I'll find the address/name of a place that is selling them for
  $380 (instead of Eastwood's $500).

     As far as their "metal bumping" accessories I'm sure they are great,
  however there is a real talent there that must be acquired (and I can
  only guess how to do it well !). If you find a book that might explain
  the art of shrinking metal (esp) please let me know (eg. the fact that
  all 50s and early 60's Ferraris were made by Luigi with a hammer and a
  tree stump is pretty darned incredible..!).

            --Lee

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 14:20:43 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Crankcase assembly status


Fellow maniacs,

The most expensive way to learn the art of automotive repair is to buy a 914
that was in a fire for $200 and rebuild it from square one.  

As you may recall while assembling the crankcase the crank would bind when
torque was applied to the case studs.  After sending my last message I went
back down to the "engine room" in the basement and re-checked everything.  
Much to my chagrin, the #4 main wasn't on it's dowel pin, the torque tried to
create one, and hence the bearing was completely shot.

After getting a new *set* of main bearings, I installed the #1 and #4 on their
respective dowel pins and used a pencil to make an alignment mark on the edge
of the bearing and the crankcase.  After a more careful procedure of assembling
the crankcase - everything is great.  The crank spins wonderfully and silently. 

I did not have the galley plugs tapped for the threaded variety, but I am now
going to be installing high-pressure relief pistons and the high-volume oil
pump.  What are the chances that the plugs will take the added oil pressure?

After the oil pump and relief pistons comes the installation of the 96mm NPR 
P&C kit.  Since I am working from a Haynes and "The 914 914/6 Handbook". I am
curious as to the things to watch out for at this stage of the assembly.

I will be installing center console gauges are there any sending units that
attach to the crankcase itself?  Namely, the oil-pressure sending unit?  If
so, where?

Also, I'm sure it will be covered later in the manual(s), but there is a 
sensor mounted on a bolt(13mm) at dead center on top of the crankcase.  What
is its function?

Inch by inch, step by step, I'll get everything together eventually and 
will be bringing you all along for the ride...

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 15:42:43 -0500
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: Difficulty Engaging 1st Gear and other P related Topics

Neil,

Going from neutral directly into first is always a little difficult with most
Porsche transmissions.  To make it much, much easier, pull into 2nd gear very
slightly before engaging first.  You will find that you can slip right into
first every time.

 -Allen Henderson-
'72S, '59A

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 13:22:49 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Three-Spoke Sport Steering Wheels


Hi all,

The thread on steering wheel covers got me to remember that the three-
spoke sport steering wheels used in the late seventies to mid-eighties
can fail at the outer weld at the rim. I broke mine at an autocross. 
It needed a new cover, which I purchased from an advertiser in Pano.

The rubber around the rim at the break was carefully cut, allowing for 
a reweld of the spoke to the wheel rim. I replaced the cut rubber section 
by epoxying it to the spoke/rim. I installed the new cover (a tedious but
not difficult task). I used the wheel for a year, then found a four-spoke
sport wheel to replace it.

If your three-spoke sport wheel flexes at the juncture of one of the spokes, 
get it fixed or replace the wheel pronto. These steering wheels were used 
on 911s, 924s, 944s and perhaps a few 928s. The failure is common, 
especially with cars that have been to the track (you have to hold on to 
something-at least the passenger can scream in terror).

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 16:32:39 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Pop-off valve installation...a question


  >Can you really get all the chips out? I am not concerned with the top
  >portion of the air box, since I can use my shop-vac and lots of protective
  >rags. I am concerned with the filing dropping into the lower section of 
  >the airbox as the hole is cut.

  >Any comments from people who have actually done it?

I removed my airbox and split it into two halves - top and bottom.  Then
I drilled the hole, mounted the pop-off valve and reassembled the
airbox.  My airbox was slightly warped, but the two halves fit together
pretty well.  I used a thin bead of high temp RTV between the two
halves (there's a tongue-in-groove kind of a fit) and screwed it
back together.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 15:01:39 -0700
From: "Drew A. Spencer" <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Project 911SC - The work begins and some questions...

Hi all!  Hope everyone had a happy and safe holiday season.

Well, as I had threatened previously, this last week I embarked on my
great adventure at converting my '82 911 SC into a track/autocross car.

My initial goals are to focus on handling, safety, and reliability rather
than just horsepower while having a platform that could eventually
accomodate more HP when the existing powerplant gets too tired.

The car prep is oriented to POC J Improved classing (basically stock
w/minor performance enhancements).  I'm holding off on any performance
enhancements until I recieve the PCA club racing rules to determine
what I can do there...

What I started with:
- --------------------
'82 911 SC sunroof coupe, 130K miles (no records other than my own)

    Suspension:
       Strut/shocks: factory Bilstein (green) struts/shocks
       Sway bars: factory 19mm rear 21 mm front
       Torsion bars: ??? rear ??? front

     Engine: US Spec 3.0L (930/16?)
        Induction: Factory Bosch K-jet w/o pop-off valve
        Exhaust: Factory exchangers w/Bursch sport muffler
        Original Factory tensioners
        Leaking oil-return tubes
        

     Wheels: BBS RA in 16x7 and 16x8 (and no, they're not bent
             or gold...;-))
     

      About 40lbs of Alpine stereo gear (now piled neatly in a box)

Now, the issues:
- ----------------
Engine:
The motor runs pretty well, so I've decided to not mess with it other than
taking steps to attempt to prolong its life by performing the following
updates:
 - carrera tensioners/chain ramps
 - pop-off valve
 - radiator-style oil cooler
 - tune up and valve adjustment
 - general clean-up

After stripping off all the sheet metal I managed to get the entire exhaust
off without breaking any studs.  I owe a debt of gratitude to the kind
soul who recommended a couple of doses of penetrant on the exhaust nuts 

prior to attempting the removal.  


I proceeded to replace the tensioners (kit from AJR) and had some
general questions:

1. How much slack in the chain is acceptable?  There is about 1/4" play
at the ramp on the left side.

2. If I choose to replace the chain ramps, should they all be done at once
and, if so, is it humanly possible to get them all without splitting
the case?

Regarding exhaust:
I'm considering the purchase of the AJR RSR-style headers with both
megaphones (for Las Vegas) and a sport muffler (for Laguna Seca and
an occasional autocross).  Any suggestions as to what the right
diameter would be to use on a 3.0L with CIS?  I was thinking about
going 1 3/4" for the track, but does the CIS flow well enough to
make it work?  


Next issue: Suspension

Thanks for your help,

Drew
Drew_Spencer@novell.com
'82 911 SC
'93 RS America

   is way below Porsche specialists, BUT, he's never worked on a 944!

ere anything (other than the honing/reboring issue below) about
   removing and working on a 944 engine that should keep me from using him?
 - Although the cylinders looked good when the head was off awhile back,
   I want to be prepared in case they need work.  I haven't found a machine
   shop in central Virginia that knows what to do with the 944's aluminum
   block.  Is special equipment needed for honing?  for reboring?
   (One shop told me to find a shop with a Sunnen machine).
 - Is removal of
 the 3rd piston with the block still in the car worth
   considering?  Would that repair save enough (compared to
   a full block removal and overhall) to be worth it, or would such a
   shortcut be shortsighted?

	Mechanics! I say why bother? What, other than monetary
	motives do they have? Do they love your car? or just
	think of it as another turd in line? 

	Spending the same amount of money on tools will not
	only do you increase your stable - you vastly 
	expand your knowledge. What better way to impress that
	hot date than by doing a roadside fix? Of course, if
	your maintenance schedule is on time (lord knows mine
	is :-0) these things don't happen. Tools _never_ 
	depreciate either (sort of).

	Now, you say, I work for a living and have no TIME. You're
	still driving that 'other' car while your baby is being
	manhandled in the shop. What better way to express your
	undying loyalty than pressing your own bearings or honing 
	those cylinders?

	The whole reason I bought an older model is because I have
	it a little easier in this realm than those with FI or
	(shudder) chips. But, this is my choice and I have 
	great respect for those who tackle their SCs and Turbos, etc.

	Please, don't think I have some sort of mechanic vedetta. I
	_know_ there are honest, reputable mechanics out there that
	do _love_ all models. However, IMHO they're the exception,
	not the rule.

	In this forum, we are fortunate to be able to glean experience
	through our peers. We can request input about respected
	wrenchers in our neck of the woods or inquire about the
	idiosynchracies of certain procedures before we embark
	on the endeavor.

	PEEVE MODE OFF

	Feeling rather warm and fuzzy -

	Texas-size kudos to Stan !

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 18:33:54 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Heater cables

> Someone mentioned the the heater control knob did not have enough tension on
> it, but when I checked it felt like it was tight enough. 

Having just been through this on a 356, and having done this a few times
on my various 914s and 911s, I can assure you this is NOT uncommon. All
of the cable operated gizmos in these cars are *designed* to be lubricated
from time to time. So, 'fess up: how often have you *ever* lubed heater
cables? That's what I thought....

You need to go to the appropriate flapper box and disconnect the cables,
then do two things (in any order): 1) operate the flapper and make sure
that it's working, not binding, etc. so that it *CAN* be cable operated
and (2) operate the control to make sure the cable is moving. If it is,
squirt something like graphite lock lube up the cable housing and work it 
some more. If it's not, get a replacement cable. Once you're sure that
all of the moving parts move, the rest is simple: position the control so
that it's in the right place for when the flapper is in the "default" 
position (most are spring loaded so there is a "default"), then adjust
the cable accordingly. Then test it. You may have to fiddle with the 
adjustment.

Once you've done this and gotten it right, you almost certainly won't
have to *EVER* do it again. Unless you keep the car another ten years
or so....

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  4 Jan 95 16:43:02 PST
From: Scott Leatham <scottle@microsoft.com>
Subject: How to get a really great 914, 914/6 book...

<Sender composed mail containing characters not in the US-ASCII set.>
<These characters have been transformed into a printable form.>

Hello!  I'm new to the alias, but not to Porsches!  So forgive me if I =

don't perfectly follow the rules the first time(!)... :-)

FYI: I own two 914/6s.

With the 25th Porsche anniversary last year, interest in 914 has =

reached a post production high, heck I get high just driving my 914/6...

In honor of this, I thought that other 914 owners would like to know =

about a special book that's pretty much impossible to find in the USA =

(at least as far as I can tell).

The book is called "Das Grosse VW-Porsche-BucH" or "The Big VW-Porsche =

Book".  Unfortunately it's all written in German, but the rare pictures =

are worth getting it a lone, especially if you have interest in 914/6 =

GTs.  I first saw this book several months ago and it was a "had to =

have" item --  thanks to Don Melnick (PCA/NW region) for showing me the boo=
k!

It's the most complete documentation on 914 history that I've ever seen =

(and I've been looking for a long time).  It covers (I believe -- I =

haven't "read" the entire book yet) history of the car, manufacturing =

info and lot's of pictures that are very useful to anyone doing =

restoration work.

As for the reading German part, I've generally had no trouble finding a =

friendly German-speaking person to translate sections of the book for =

me.  Ask around you'd be amazed how people speak/read German fluently!

I ordered the book via a friend in Germany, however he discovered how I =

could order the book directly ifrom a bookstore in Germany for export =

to the USA -- I'll share this with you just because I'm such a nice guy =

(no I'm not getting a kick back!):

Here's the publisher information needed to order the book:
Title: 	Das Grosse VW-Porsche-BucH
Author: 	Michael von Klodt
ISBN: 	3-89365-137-3
Publisher:  HEEL-Verlag
Publisher Tel: 	0 22 23/23027

Here's the ordering information:

HUGENDUBEL
Karlsplatz 11-12
80335 M=FCnchen
Germany

Phone: +49-89-55225333
Attn: Mrs. Hoppe

Mrs. Hoppe is aware that USA orders may be coming in.  It would be best =

to have a German-speaking friend make the call for you -- have your =

VISA credit card number ready.

I originally paid about $68 for the book , not including shipping (I =

sent out an international bank draft to my friend who drove 400km to a =

different store to pick it up for me!).  Your price may vary with this =

store and you can use a credit card (Visa I believe)...  You could try =

contacting the publisher to see if it can be found in the UK or in the =

USA I had no luck in this regard -- it's not printed in English that =

much I know for sure -- (although in England you can buy "The Big VW =

book" by the same publisher and author  -- and it is in English, oh =

well wrong car!).

I know three people that have the this rare-in-the-usa book -- every =

time it's "shared" at local car events more people want to get it -- so =

therefore as a favor to my local 914 friends, I'm ordering about 10 =

books for people in the PCA/NW region (including one for Allan =

Caldwell, the well known PCA national contributing writer).  This is =

not a busniess for me, so I will not take more orders -- if you want =

the book you'll have to order for yourself (or like me put together a =

large order to save on shipping costs).

I haven't placed my order yet, but I will next week, so I can't =

entirely promise this will work the first time.  I'll send out an info =

update to this email if anything changes when I place my order.  If =

anyone tries it before me, let me know how it went, OK?

Email me if you want to know more about the book.

Cheers!

- --ScottLe

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 17:00:21 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: airbox installation

> From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
> Subject: Pop-off valve installation...a question
> 
   (stuff deleted)
> 
> Can you really get all the chips out? I am not concerned with the top
> portion of the air box, since I can use my shop-vac and lots of protective
> rags. I am concerned with the filing dropping into the lower section of 
> the airbox as the hole is cut.
> 

I thought those were pretty outrageous instructions too, letting all
that glass-filled-plastic dust fall into your baby's private places.
But, pulling the airbox means pulling the engine (as far as I know).

When I drilled, oops, I mean sawed that
hole, I pulled off the intake runners for #1 and #4, stuck the vacuum
hose into the #1 hole, and ran the vacuum *while* I sawed.  I don't
think any chips made it to the floor of the box, if they did I sure
couldn't see 'em.  And, no melted plastic appeared at the muffler
outlet! :-)

BTW the airbox plastic is moderately brittle, be careful of the
stiffening ribs molded into the outside of the box, they DO break!

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

> (although cops everywhere seem to have the same basic mentality). In Europe,
> they are civil servants, like postal workers or such everywhere in the
> world. In the U.S., police are effectively tax collectors. Europeans

around xmas the cops are out collecting tickets to pay for their xmas

speak to the cop if we don't want to... We most certainly don't have to 
admit the offense... (nice, liberal country... It makes a bit up for the
way to high car prices :-) )

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 19:48:46 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911: RaceForce transmission work

> 915 transmissions rebuilt so you can shift them _hard_ ?
> 
> All this double clutching stuff has reminded me of
> an advertisement that used to run in Pano.  It
> was for a company called RaceForce 

I wrote this up in '90, and again last summer. Maybe I need to
take my more popular missives and put them on an automailer...

Gist of the story is this: sure, you can do that. But you transfer
all that "wear" from the soft, inexpensive synchros to the harder,
very expensive gearsets. And the intermediate plate. And the main
shaft.

It's *ONLY* appropriate for racing applications where you have
planned to take it apart from time to time and measure wear. Or
applications where you can afford to have the transmission just
seize up on you as you drive. 

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 18:26:39 -0800
From: leedsg@halcyon.com (Leeds Gulick)
Subject: 95' 911 2wd vs 4wd

>I have recently ordered a 911 carrera 2 cabriolet, due to go into production
>in early February 95'. My dealer now advises me a that I can get this car in
>4wd if I want. Can anybody give me any help with the pro's & con's of this
>decision? Thanks!

I have 6,500 miles on my 2wd '95 911 Carrera and as an avid track driver
and autocrosser would not own the 4wd version due to push (understeer).  I
know, I know.  The automotive publications say that this is no longer the
problem it was in the previous C4.  Only the January '95 Road and Track
review of the new C4 indicates that the typical all-wheel-drive tendency to
push still exists.

   "In slow, 90-plus-degree corners, the C4 still feels stable. But it
understeers, so much so that power-on exits often found the steering wheel
reaching full lock.  What's more, throttle liftoff only slightly reduces
understeer-in contrast to the C2 in which a reduction of power brings the
tail out slightly and allows the front tires to get a bite."

The last two paragraphs of the article conclude:

   "If I were a Porsche purist who knows how to drive and enjoys doing so
every time he slips behind the wheel-and who fully understands the meaning
of rear-engine weight bias-the Carrera would get my vote. It's lively,
responsive, challenging. And a bargain at just under $60 thou.
   But if I were the same fella and realized that there's a lot to be said
for all-wheel-drive stability and all-weather traction, the new Carrera 4
would get my nod. But then, it already has."

It comes down to how you are planning to use your new 911.  For me, the
added weight and particularly the understeer (autocrossing has many slow
tight corners and race tracks often have one as well) make me favor the 2wd
version (of course that version was all that was available when I purchased
mine).  I would get the ABD and limited slip package option with the 2wd
911.




Leeds Gulick



------------------------------

Date: 04 Jan 95 21:32:15 EST
From: Byron Short <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: 914 Oil Galley Plugs

Jerry Brady says...
>I did not have the galley plugs tapped for the threaded variety, but I
>am now going to be installing high-pressure relief pistons and the
>high-volume oil pump.  What are the chances that the plugs will take the
>added oil pressure?

I bought my first Porsche, a 73 914 2.0, in 1991.  What was supposed to be
a quality, stock, rebuild, wasn't any of the three, so we set out to put
the engine together with all stock parts.  The car was to be our first
serious SCCA stock autocrosser, and as such, stock meant stock.  My guide,
Steve Compton had rebuilt many 914 motors, and his stand on oil galley
plugs was, if they didn't leak, and if they looked like they had been in
there since the good Dr. P put them there, they should be considered safe.
Accordingly, we completed the procedure.  After breaking the car in on the
street for about 1500 miles and numerous local autocrosses, we trailered
it to Phoenix for my first ever Pro Solo event.  Damndest thing.  Saturday
morning I went out and jumped in the car, hit the key, and waited for the
oil light to go off.  It didn't.  Shut the car off, restart (probably just
a loose wire, donchaknow?)  Wrong.  Shut car off again, look at wife, try
to give (fraudulent) impression that I have a clue.  Get out.  Look under
car.  Hmmm.  No wonder there's no oil pressure.  The oil is laying in the
gutter where it's subject to about 1 bar, but in no particularly useful
way.  Oil galley plug found mid-puddle.  Conclusion:  scrimping on oil
galley plugs will work just fine; that is unless you ever plan on
dragging the car 30 hours roundtrip for an important event, in which case
if you're lucky, they'll abondon ship somewhere other than on the track.

That was my first Porsche, and today I just bought my fourth!  Is this
healthy?  

Byron Short

87 944 Turbo (thought it was an autocrosser--oops)
90 944 S2    (picking it up this weekend--it better be an autocrosser!)

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 19:00:59 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Fuch mag torque settings.

>I have a set of H.R.S. Porsche lock sets for my fuch mags. They state
>that the correct torque setting (Factory Setting) is 140 Nm. for the
>wheel nuts. Is this correct, and what is that in foot-lbs (since my
>torque wrench is hopelessly imperial!!)?

Mike,

90 ft-lbs for alloy lug nuts and 100 ft-lbs for steel.

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 19:42:26 -0800
From: davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)
Subject: Re: What motivates a purist mechanic ?


>Hello
>
>Do all Porsche owners, older vehicle owners in particular, "suffer", "put up
>with lousy time management", "go screaming mad","wonder why they ever bought a
>Porsche", every time they take their pride and joy to the trusted 'years of
>experience' mechanic?
>

My mechanic is beyond reproach.  He can generally take my 911 at a moment's
notice for an "emergency" repair.  Appointments for routine maintenance are
no problem.  The final price for a repair *always* comes in less than his
quote; which is significantly lower than the Porsche dealer charges for
"similar" work.  He has my 911 ready when promised.

Now in return for this, I must trust him to make the decisions regarding
repairing my 911.  For example, about 6 months ago my alternator went on
the fritz.  I suggested a rebuilt unit, he opted to rebuild mine (saving me
lots of money BTW).  So far, so good. I don't mind giving up some control
regarding decisions since he as always been right on the mark.

Now mind you, I'm not constantly going to his shop, my 911 is an extremely
reliable daily driver,  but when I do, no problem.  I suppose it helps that
he is active in my local PCA region.

Considering some of the horror stories I've heard regarding Porsche
reparirs, I must consider myself VERY lucky!

If you'd care to have your car serviced in Santa Barbara, I'd be happy to
give you his number. :-}

Sorry to hear about your aparent frustration.

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe
"I'm not sure we understand everything we know about this".

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 03:51:21 +0000
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: Re: 959 sighting, car collecting


> What is going to happen 20 years from now when C2 and 993 become
> collectors' cars, much like the situation today with older 911s? MFI or
> electrical gremlins are a pain in the ass, but how will the week-end
> mechanic deal with DMEs and circuit boards etc.

	I suspect that each generation is more in touch with technology
than the last. By the time the 993 is 20 year sold, many of the
"enthusiasts" will consider a DME to be no more difficult to diagnose/fix
than we would consider current technology (relays?). Or perhaps they will
just swap things over (does it *really* cost more to produce a DME brain
than, say, a brake caliper) as parts become more commonly used (in 20
years time *every* car may have a DME unit) and therefore cheaper. [Note :
I really MUST make my sentence constructs simpler!!]

	Also appropriate tools will be more cheaply available. The two
things which are required to maintain a car (IMHO, of course) are (a)
education/training and (b) adequate tools.

	Then again, maybe they will follow the route of the 924 and become
"not economically repairable" and sent to the scrapheap :-(

Philip Katz                                     Katz_P_M@bt-web.bt.co.uk 

1989 911 Carrera 3.2 Sport Coupe (Taubenblau/Baltic Blue Metallic)
Zero cats (but we're thinking of getting 2 ...)

P.S. 959s are not too rare over here. My local dealer (Lancasters) had one
in their showrooms for a long time, right beside their F40! PCGB at
Reading usually have 3 or 4 being worked on at any one time, and there are
usually anything from 2 to 6 for sale in the Sunday Times, usually around
the 200,000 pound mark.

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 03:51:23 +0000
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: More on washer bottles/windscrren spray


Kevin,

	I suspect that you will find that the T-piece, when working,
contains a 1-way valve. I suspect that it opens at a particular pressure
so that, if the washer jets are frozen solid, the water being sprayed will
return to the reservoir rather than damage occuring to the pump.

	I know that when I had poor pressure to one of the washer jets on
my 944, the culprit was the 1-way valve in the T-piece. I had assumed that
it was "just" a T-piece and spent lots of time trying to figure out what
the problem was.

	The only other thing I can think of is that said tube is the feed
to the headlight washer system. Does your car have this?

regards,
Philip Katz                                     Katz_P_M@bt-web.bt.co.uk 

1989 911 Carrera 3.2 Sport Coupe (Taubenblau/Baltic Blue Metallic)
Zero cats (but we're thinking of getting 2 ...)

Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 22:26:53 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: How to get a really great 914, 914/6 book...

> 
> HUGENDUBEL
> Karlsplatz 11-12
> 80335 M=FCnchen
> Germany
> 
> Phone: +49-89-55225333
> Attn: Mrs. Hoppe

I'm sure the umlaut over the u in Munchen was lost in the translation. 
For you non Deutsch fluents, Munchen (with the umlaut, the two dots over 
the u) is the German name for Munich. Most of the umlaut sounds are 
pronounced by adding an e sound after the vowel and rounding the lips 
when spoke. 
Meine Frau und Ich (My wife and I) are off to Stuttart, et. al. in March 
, and since we also own a 914/6 will be sure to look for it over there. 
Thanks for the info.

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 00:40:30 -0500
From: MHKeller@aol.com
Subject: Blinking Blinker Problem

Hello fellow Porsche Nuts,
     I had and have a very similar problem that found to becaused by a faulty
four-way flasher unit. My flasher unit I found couldn't handle the constant
amount of electrical voltage from the use of my "ALARM SYSTEM" which lights
the lights for three seconds on activation and thirty seconds at
deactivation. This might also be your problem and is worth checking as most
alarm systems flash all parking and turn signals and tail lamps and head
lights on most auto's.
MHKeller
914-4 Daily driver
914-6 Garaged

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 09:39:46 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: TargaTop reconstruction



Not long ago, I posted what became a survey question about
a leaking targa top.  By far, the most popular advise was:
"Accept it, and carry a towel."  Being a manly man of the
male gender, this is OK...in fact, it reinforces my manliness.
However, I am still looking for that SO of the female form.
Occasionally, I even manage to maneuver one into sharinga ride
in my car.  Since these prospects don't have nearly as manly
a manner as most of us men, I've decided to fix the problem.

In fact, I also decided it is time to reconstruct the whole top.
So, I have ordered all the rubber seals, a new roof skin and
headliner.

Before I begin, does anyone have any suggestions or warnings
about installation?  What sealant/adhesive is used for the
rubber on the windshield and targa bar?  Can anyone suggest
an uphostery shop in the Houston area for doing the vinyl top?

And, does anyone know how to avoid the fraying of the cloth
covering the targa bar seal along the door windows?  I've never
seen a 5+ year old Targa that does not have this ugly problem.

Thanks.
W_Michelsen@lfhs2.hso.link.com
'87 911 Targa GuardsRed/Black

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 10:52:28 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Back on the road again...

Dear Porsche Pushers:
	Finally got my 944 on the road again. Boy it seems like forever with
the Holidays and stuff.

As you may recall, I bent a couple of valves trying to remove (drill out)
the camshaft gear. The 12 pt. bolt was stripped :(. I was in the process
of taking care of oil seals at all cams and oil pump. 

I'm happy to report, that after the valve transplant the engine started right
up! :)) Boy, was I a happy camper last night! There are no water or oil leaks
now. You never know, any time you take water hoses appart...

The pin spanner and the flywheel lock payed for themselves after this job.
I need to have the belts adjusted next week. I should really invest on a belt
tensioning tool. 

TIA

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (Beauty, nah, THE REAL BEAST!)
'85 Guards Red 944 (The Beast)

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 09:54:45 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Heat

> Does anyone out there have any experience with alternatives for 914 heat. 

I found something that I have wanted to play with, but haven't done the
work to know if it's any good or not yet...

There's an outfit that makes an oil-cooler based heater for VW Beetles.
Seems that you could mount this oil cooler gizmo in the hole
for the gasoline heater, hook up the right plumbing and have a dandy
heater. Of course, you'd *REALLY* need to have some sort of Y-valve
so you can bypass it in the summer, or route it off to another heat
exchanger that doesn't warm the interior at least...

I can find the details if you're interested. Or it should bein the early
'94 archives.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 09:59:36 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: TargaTop reconstruction

> Before I begin, does anyone have any suggestions or warnings
> about installation?  

Yes. Get it done professionally. You won't like the DIY results.

> Can anyone suggest
> an uphostery shop in the Houston area for doing the vinyl top?

If you can find them, Hinkle's is *wonderful*. They did mine in one
afternoon for about $200, including all the covering/headliner
materials (I already had new seals). OEM materials, too.

> And, does anyone know how to avoid the fraying of the cloth
> covering the targa bar seal along the door windows?  I've never
> seen a 5+ year old Targa that does not have this ugly problem.

That's a $20 fix at a competent shop. There's this black cheesecloth looking
stuff that gets glued over the seals. It's a Mercedes trick... Hinkle
can do it.

If you can't find Hinkle, shoot me a note. If you do, shoot me a note anyway
since they've moved from their old downtown location and I haven't needed
them since then. I'd like to know where they are...

Stan

Subject: Car color confusion

Hi,

I bought a '73 911S targa in August  and since I bought it I  wanted to know
what the original name paint color was. So I requested a certificate of
Authenticity from Porsche in November and got it yesterday in the mail. I
always assumed that the paint was a light yellow or beige color. When I
looked at the certificate it listed the color and code as Rose Red 4610. This
obviously doesn't match my car. The code also doesn't correspond to the
Kunstharzlack plate in my car which has 132-9-1 written on it. The car has
been repainted, but the door jambs and trunk are the same color as the rest
of the body.
So my question is- What does Rose red look like and what does 132-9-1 mean. 
Lastly, it says "Fog Lamp,White, Over Bumper".  I took the non-original fog
lights off my car. What did the old one look like? Where they like the chrome
ones but painted white?

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 09:41:36 PST
From: TSP.Henr801A@xerox.com
Subject: RE: '87' 944 GAS LEAK (4 JAN 95)

Dave O. Blanchard (blanch@capella.cup.hp:com:):  Thanks for your quick
response. I had not thought of the aluminum filler neck as the culprit. The
symptom is fuel odor in the car when I have a full tank. I noticed gas on the
outside of the tank when I removed the passenger side rear wheel and that is
what led me to the rubber filler hose to gas tank interface as the probable
cause. What I am worried about is a possible crack in the gas tank itself. I
know that if that is the case I'm probably looking at having to drop the
transmission/differential to get to the tank. I have know idea how to fix the
tank if it does indeed have a crack.

	Tim Pinckney
	Rochester N.Y.

------------------------------

Date: 05 Jan 95 13:21:06 EST
From: Nancy.O.Broadhead@Dartmouth.EDU (Nancy O. Broadhead)
Subject: Re: Bursch Mufflers

- --- Mike Dayton wrote:
Does anyone have some real world experience with Bursch mufflers?
- --- EOQ

Bursch mufflers don't seem to work well on 911s w/MFI.  (Our engine is a
stock 2.2 911E, installed in a 914-6.)  Caused a very lean condition between
2700 and 3400 rpm that could not be adjusted out.

We installed a "factory-type" muffler: ANSA, at about half the price; problem
gone.  Louder than factory, quieter than Bursch.

- --N
'67 911S
'70 914-6
someday a 356 again...
3 DSH felines

Date: 05 Jan 95 13:23:33 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Resistance spot welder, $380?

Lee Atkinson says he may know where to get a resistance spot welder for
$380.
 
Hi, Lee. I'd be interested too. The only resistance spot welder I know of
is made by Miller and it's about $500.
 
These things are slick for doing factory-like repairs. They're even neater
than using superglue to hold panels together and then painting fake spot
welds on the visible side. <g>
 
Pete

Lately I have been looking for a louder muffler for my '80 928.  I asked around

e out to check out what I had on it, he informed me that I ALREADY had an ANSA
exhaust on my car!  This upset me, finding that I already had the loudest muffl
er on my car.  What I am wondering is can I do anything to it to make it LOUDER

Date: 05 Jan 95 13:52:59 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Big Book of 914

 
Hi, Scott.
 
I have the 914 book too. I tried to interest several publishers in bringing
out an English language translation of it, but there is no interest. They
all say production would be too expensive with such a large format color
book, and worst of all, most of the automotive book publishers I've talked
to say that "914 people are cheap. They won't buy a book like this." No
flames please, I'm just repeating the story I was given.
 
I would have liked to do the translation, but you can lead a horse to water
etc.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 05 Jan 95 13:53:06 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Big Book of 914

 
David Christiano writes that he will be in Stuttgart in March and will look
for the Big Book of 914.
 
You don't need to go all the way to Munich. The biggest bookstore in
Stuttgart should have it in stock. It's Konrad Wittwer, the main store is on
the Koenigstrasse across from the Kleiner Schlossplatz. That's where I got
my copy.
 
If you continue down the Koenigstrasse, away from the main train station,
cross under street at the end to get to Marienstrasse, there is a fairly
decent model car shop in the arcade there, I think the arcade is called the
Marienpassage. The shop is Model Car Center Stuttgart, behind the movie
theater.
 
Also a general toy store, Spielwaren Kurtz, is on the market square across
from city hall (Marktplatz). Sometimes they have cars that MCS doesn't have.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 05 Jan 95 13:53:03 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Danish cops etc.

 
Christian Holmgreen writes
>Do you actually have to sign the ticket?
 
No. If you don't, they'll take you off to jail right away. Signing the
ticket means that you agree to pay the fine or appear in court to contest
the ticket. You don't have to speak to the cop here either, don't have to
admit anything. But whatever you say, he will write notes on the back of his
ticket to refresh his memory if you go to court.
 
Yes, there are more of them out there just before Christmas. Swine.
 
Pete

Subject: A/C fuse in 944S


Greetings,

I am having problems with my A/C.  Hit the switch and the fuse blows.

I had my mechanic look into the problem, bad A/C clutch.  He disconected 
the clutch until I can afford to replace it.  

It appears he used a 10amp fuse for debugging rather than the 7.5amp the
circut is supposed to have.  Question: could using the larger fuse have
caused any damage to the A/C system?

Thanks,

Steve '87 944S

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 14:32:24 -0500
From: Fred Pack <fhp@unipress.com>
Subject: 914 hose layout

Nate Nagel wants a diagram of 914 hoses.  With due credit to Dave from
"Graphics Group" <Graphics_Group@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov> (Sorry -- don't remember
Dave's last name) for this, here is an ASCII diagram for a '74 2.0L.  It may
be somewhat helpful to Nate and others.

Fred Pack					fhp@unipress.com
UniPress Software				phone: (908) 287-2100
2025 Lincoln Highway				fax:   (908) 287-4929
Edison NJ 08817					http://www.unipress.com/


                **** DAVE's 2.0L 914 Hose Arrangement ****

Disclaimer:  This text and cheesy ASCII art contains something approaching
the state of the hoses on my 74 2.0L 914 when I bought it.  Not all of the
lengths are necessarily accurate--the ones that are harder to get to are
estimates; some hoses are listed as (the length of mine + some fudge
factor because I think mine is too short).  I am not even completely certain
that the hoses in my car are connected correctly--but the car seems to run
OK.  No guarantees, allright?  Lengths will probably be updated whenever it
is that I get around to replacing all of my hoses. 


Items marked with a ***** are swapped on the diagram in the April 93 _Pano_
diagram of the 73 2.0L hoses.


General Diagrams (or: What Do You Mean By Fitting #2?) :

 Top of the Air Filter Box:         Manifold, under the Air Filter Box:
	
   #1       #2  #3                            #1
  _||_______||_//       Front of Car     _____||_
  |             \           ^           /     o  = #2
  |              = #4       |           |   O   |
  |             /           |       #3 =_______/
  --------------
                                'o' = hose fitting on top of manifold
                                'O' = throttle body


NOTE:  Front, Rear (aft), Left, Right all refer to directions as seen
from the Driver's Seat--e.g., LHS is the driver's side in the US.



    O=    "Flashback Valve" -- lives on LHS of engine, by fan shroud:
    "

13mm * 14"  from top fitting (up, not front)
            to #1 on Air Filter Box
13mm * 36"  from front fitting
            to fitting by RR spark plug
13mm * 18"  from rear fitting
            to fitting by LF spark plug


	Distributor advance and retard:

4mm * 7"    from RF side of throttle body
            to fitting on back of distributor vacc unit         *****
5mm * 36"   from LR side of throttle body
            to fitting on side of distributor vacc unit         *****


    Lines to Charcoal Canister:
    (connect in LF corner of engine compt., under relay box)

14mm * 36"  from upper line below relay box
            to "L" elbow on #3 on Air Filter Box
13mm * 36"  from lower line below relay box
            to fitting on the fan shroud on the LHS of the engine


	Deceleration Valve:
	(silver can near/below battery: one hose each end, one in the side)

5mm * 19"   from fitting on front of Decel Valve
            to "L" elbow on "T" fitting on Manifold fitting #2
10mm * 20"  from fitting on rear of Decel Valve
            to #1 fitting on Manifold
10mm * 20"  from side fitting on Decel Valve
            to #4 fitting on Air Filter Box


    Oil Filler Breather:
	
13mm * 10"  from Oil Filler neck/housing
            to "T" on #2 fitting on Manifold


    Pressure Sensor:
    (RHS, by battery, right by Decel Valve--one hose, one bundle of wires)

8mm * 26"   from Pressure Sensor
            to fitting on top of Manifold


    Aux Air Regulator:
    (Can sitting upright with a "T" coming out of the top, near LHS of
    the manifold)

13mm * 15"  from LHS connection on "T"
            to fitting #3 on Manifold
13mm * 11"  from RHS connection on "T"
            to #2 fitting on Air Filter Box

Date: Thu, 05 Jan 95 15:14:39 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: A/C fuse in 944S

> 
> Greetings,
> 
> I am having problems with my A/C.  Hit the switch and the fuse blows.
> 
> I had my mechanic look into the problem, bad A/C clutch.  He disconected 
> the clutch until I can afford to replace it.  
> 
> It appears he used a 10amp fuse for debugging rather than the 7.5amp the
> circut is supposed to have.  Question: could using the larger fuse have
> caused any damage to the A/C system?
> 
> Thanks,
> 

Hi, Steve,

The short answer is probably not.

The true test is to try to use the AC with the clutch disconnected and see
if everything else (radiator fans, heater blower, flapper valves, etc.)
works as it should.  If all that is OK, no damage occurred.

Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 15:29:30 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: Eroded 931 cam belt.

The teeth on my cam belt on my 1980 931 are deteriorating very fast - I
installed the belt 2 years ago and have driven only 3 or 4 thousand miles!
 The teeth are more than half gone and the front of the engine is coated with
the powdery remains of the belt.  Luckily I spotted the problem while
changing the water pump ... could have been disasterous (it looks as if the
cam would have started skipping soon)
The belt is made by Continental - (from Zims Autotechnik) - apparently is
OEM.
Is there a chance that I have too much friction in the cam/valvetrain
(causing accelerated wear) or is this just a bad belt?  
BTW, the belt was set at the correct tension.

Regards,

Mike
1977 924 (the daily driver)
1980 931 (not driving at all)

==  I bought one of those pistol stick welders that can be converted for
== spot welding.  I sent it back.  IMHO, the thing is too simple and
== overpriced (like most of Ewoods offerings).  I had my MAG (mig)
== welder by then, and discovered 'rosette and plug' welds are just
== as good except for needing to grind a little after the weld, and mebbe
== clamping tight before the zap.
==  Their pistol job requires [your] buzz box as a power source.
==
==  Ewood does offer some unique tools (but Gad! what prices!)
==  I have not tried their dollys or hammers, but the price you
== see is %200 of its true worth.  IMHO  <g>

== were a little dissapointing on quality.  They work great though.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 15:56:14 -0500
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: Color confusion/Fog Lights

Neil,

The "white" fog lights are most likely clear glass, as opposed to yellow
which were also available.  This makes you original factory "fog lights" more
properly "driving lights," perhaps.

These lights were mounted on special brackets where the '73's have little
black grills next to and inside of the parking lights.  Earlier cars have
chrome grills here, I believe.  In all cases these are special grills with
cut-outs to allow the fog light bracket to protrude.

Re color, someone with the color codes out there will no doubt help you right
away.  It probalby is, in fact, the rose color specified by the factory but
with the paint mfgrs code versus the Porsche paint color "part number."  And.
. .it certainly can't be yellow, I would think.  If this color code does not
correspond then something is amiss, wrong color plate, chassis number, etc.

 -Allen Henderson-
'72S and '59A  coupes

Date: Thu, 05 Jan 95 16:45:54 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Eroded 931 cam belt.

Hi, Mike

> The teeth on my cam belt on my 1980 931 are deteriorating very fast - I
> installed the belt 2 years ago and have driven only 3 or 4 thousand miles!
>  The teeth are more than half gone and the front of the engine is coated with
> the powdery remains of the belt.  Luckily I spotted the problem while
> changing the water pump ... could have been disasterous (it looks as if the
> cam would have started skipping soon)

I would look for some kind of bind in the tensioner or water pump.  Also
look for some kind of damage to the pulleys involved.  Don't forget the
crankshaft pulley.  Other than that, I would leave the belt covers off this
time, so that you can easily check on the wear of the replacement belt...

> The belt is made by Continental - (from Zims Autotechnik) - apparently is
> OEM.

Shouldn't be a problem.  I have several Audis and use Continental belts when
I get them with no problems before.

> Is there a chance that I have too much friction in the cam/valvetrain
> (causing accelerated wear) or is this just a bad belt?  
> BTW, the belt was set at the correct tension.

Probably not a bad belt, but keep an eye on the new one...

Good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ mhv.net
E-Mail: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 16:55:55 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 December '94 sucked.


Dear Kyle,

We are very glad to see that you intend to save your 914. In our zeal to save
them all we have contracted to have all of the rust area patch pnels make,
ignoring the tooling expense (it gets very tight here at times, however
because besides paying tooling costs, we have to commit to a 2000 piece run!)
However, rest assured that in the futur we will have available everything one
needs to completely restore the rustiest 914 body - and cheaply!

Thankfully, the bodies are easy to piece back together and with modern
welding and grinding equipment, anyone can be a reasonable welder in an hour.
The only problem is time. We invest hundreds of hors in 914 body restoration,
but the finished product is always marvelous. Good luck, Kyle and keep the
914 faith!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 16:55:52 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: rust repair on 914


Dear Lee, 

Rust conversion paint is available in many different brands, but POR-15 is by
far the best - we have tried them all. POR-15 dissolves the rust and dries to
a tough sealed coating ready for top coat. When glossy and dry, POR-15 will
not come off even when heated or hit with a hammer!

The paint stripper we have used for years is Aircraft Kleenstrip Remover and
it is now available in a spraycan which eliminates much of the mess!

If the Porsche factory had coated all of the 914 metal panels before and
after assembly with POR-15, they would not have rusted! Sadly, the product
was not available then.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 95 14:06:36 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Black Box troubleshooting

Re: DME 20 Years On...

> 
> 	Also appropriate tools will be more cheaply available. The two
> things which are required to maintain a car (IMHO, of course) are (a)
> education/training and (b) adequate tools.
> 

Ohhhh.   Ahhhhh.   This touches a nerve!  I know that I, and I suspect
half the folks on this list, have the training to troubleshoot DME and
other brain boxes to the component level... WITH adequate documentation!
But all you get is "no user serviceable parts inside", and a PC board
full of un-numbered ASICs.  Until someone starts up the Sam's Photofacts
of DME Boxes, *I* am going to continue to regard these things with a
good deal of suspicion.  Too obscure to fix, too expensive to carry a
spare (or troubleshoot by swapping)... pfooey!

 -Ed
'83 911SC

Porschephiles #1051                         Fri Jan 6 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 13:34:09 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: steering column lock housing

Greetings fellow fanatics! And Happy New Years!

I am looking for some used parts for my '84 944. The steering
wheel lock no longer functions on my car (is this common?)
so I want to try to rebuild it. The ignition switch contact
that opens when the key is removed also no longer functions,
and I assume they are related. Especially considering that I
have a new ignition switch. So, I want to rebuild my ignition
lock. However, I don't want to take my old one apart until I
obtain another to examine and as a source of parts. So, I
need the following:

* the steering lock housing: 321.905.851.D (the steering
   column goes through a bearing in this housing)
* the lock cylinder: 477.905.855.C (with a key so I can get it
   out of the housing).

I believe that these parts may interchange with those of a
924, since the early 944's had the same interior as the 924.

If you have these parts and are willing to sell them, please
email me directly at ericb@microsoft.com.

Thanks,

    Eric

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:18:42 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: 944 cruise

> The symptoms are that when you push the lever it either does nothing,
> or (most commonly) starts to engage (accellerator pedal moves), but
> as soon as I release the lever it disengages.

My '86 951 cruise failed (became erratic).  When I replaced it, the 
[used] replacement box also had the aspect you noticed: Pushing the 
lever accelerated the car; releasing it "hiccuped", that is, dropped 
the throttle and then picked it back up.

Normally with your symptom I'd suggest checking the steering column 
control and related wiring, but given my symptom too I'd think it was 
the box itself.  In any event, testing the column switch is free but 
replacing the box isn't, so that might be some guidance!

Also check that your clutch and brake pedal sensor switches are operational.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:26:38 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>

> I own an '87' 944 and have been having a gas leak somewhere near where the
> rubber filler hose joins the metal filler neck on the gas tank. This past
> summer I replaced the rubber filler hose and clamps but still have the leak.
> Anyone had a similar experience and how did you fix it?
I had this same leak on an '83.  Solved it by selling the car.

I examined everthing very carefully too, and never found anything 
obvious.  Tightened all the hardware to no avail.

You must use the correct, original-type clamps for one thing - standard 
clamps don't seal well in some situations.  Maybe try "gooping" 
everything too with a sealer.

Sorry I couldn't be more helpful, but it's an ugly problem!  Maybe 
compress some colored, insert gas in the filler and see where it comes out.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:30:58 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: cold knocks out electronics

> In cold weather when my 944 is started there sometimes are no functional
> dashboard electronics.  On the occasions that this happens you can't read
> tach, speedo, gas gauge, oil etc. until the engine gets toasty.  Eventually
> everything comes on at once.  Is there any known cause/solution for this?
> Anyone else experienced this?

If the symptom is common to all gauges, then so is the problem & 
solution (probably...  ;-) ).  Find the common grounding point for all 
the brown wires under the dash.  Check that the connection is very 
clean and bright copper colored.  Same for all terminals connected to 
that point.

Also check any common switched +12 VDC lines coming into the cluster, 
as many gauges have a constant hot feed and a variable ground 
connection through their sensor.

Next, check the connector on the instrument cluster itself - bad 
contacts, dirty, loose, etc.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:41:16 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: 944 engine work questions

[...]
>   Is there anything (other than the honing/reboring issue below) about
>   removing and working on a 944 engine that should keep me from using him?
No, it's pretty easy (!).  There are some special head bolts and 
tightening techniques to be aware of, and the belts must be retentioned 
properly after the job, but it's basically straight-forward.

>  - Although the cylinders looked good when the head was off awhile back,
>    I want to be prepared in case they need work.  I haven't found a machine
>    shop in central Virginia that knows what to do with the 944's aluminum
>    block.  Is special equipment needed for honing?  for reboring?
>    (One shop told me to find a shop with a Sunnen machine).
Special equipment & techniques are *required*.  The silica within the 
aluminum must be left to bear the piston ring friction after honing.  
Get someone who's very experienced in this technique!

>  - Is removal of the 3rd piston with the block still in the car worth
>    considering?  Would that repair save enough (compared to
>    a full block removal and overhall) to be worth it, or would such a
>   shortcut be shortsighted?
With a 1984, you may well have to do a lot of work down under.  I would 
*absolutely* pull the engine to enable complete access and bearing 
inspection & replacement.  It's a big job but well, well worth it.  
Then again, this assumes you'll be keeping the car and want to take 
very good care of it.

Plan on spending some serious money and finding stuff you hadn't 
planned on.  I'd be willing to wager that #3 isn't the only problem...

Good luck,

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:49:14 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: power steering leak

>Last week I asked about power steering fluid leaks on an '89 951.
> The responses

[...]

I just saw your message!  Amongst the many failures I've had on my '86 
951, I can render experience on 2 rack failures due to leaks.

In both cases, the end seals gave out, dumping fluid into the bellows 
at each rack end.  You can drive the car w/o fluid if you disconnect 
the power pump by removing the belt.  (This is easy to do and in fact 
is how I got home from a track event last summer.  But you'll want 
strong upper arms before driving the car this way!).

One mechanic suggested that the failure was caused by the rack getting 
microscopic pitting through time [and winter storage???].  Those pits 
tear at the seal, which has around 1500 psi behind it, so it leaks 
quite handily.

The first rack lasted 6 years.  The replacement rack was reconditioned 
by a Pano advertiser, but I don't think they polished that rack - they 
just popped new seals in and wham they're done.  So it only lasted 1 
year.  This gives credence to the pitting theory above (but no 
scientific evidence).

The next rack will be new, via the aftermarket to ZF.  New racks 
through PCNA are $1600 or so these days.

So, best bet is to replace the rack.  It's gonna fail sooner or later.  
Just be wary of rebuilt racks.

		JBS

------------------------------

Date:          Thu, 5 Jan 1995 16:43:19 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Re: Gas leak


> > I own an '87' 944 and have been having a gas leak somewhere near where the
> > rubber filler hose joins the metal filler neck on the gas tank. This past
> > summer I replaced the rubber filler hose and clamps but still have the leak.
> > Anyone had a similar experience and how did you fix it?

I had a "gas leak" in my '75 911.  I was autocrossing, and after 
every run I would notice a smell of gasoline in the car.  This was 
obviously rather disturbing.  I looked all over between runs for 
dripping, smelled under the car, in the boot, etc..

Turned out that the cork gasket in the gas-cap was getting old and
compressed.  Whenever the gas would slosh up the filler neck in hard
cornering, it would leak out around the cap.  I just turned over the
cork (temporary fix...) and went back to racing with no more stench.  

This is a cheap thing to fix...

Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911S Brick Shithouse Red

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 19:47:31 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Airbox pop valves

>I thought those were pretty outrageous instructions too, letting all
>that glass-filled-plastic dust fall into your baby's private places.
>But, pulling the airbox means pulling the engine (as far as I know).

Yeah, I like the part in the instructions that says "lowering the engine
may be required for installation".  I just went ahead and drilled the
hole and then duct-taped the plastic pour spout of my 2 gallon gas
conatiner onto the end of my shop vac hose and used this contraption
to suck all of the shavings out of the lower portion of the airbox.  Call
me an idiot (figuratively speaking of course - it would cost me a 
fortune to download that many email responses), but it seemed to
work OK.

BTW, an airbox can be pulled without pulling the engine.  I didn't think
so, but a shop I hang around every once and a while did it on a '77.

Good luck!

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: 05 Jan 95 20:02:23 EST
From: Triet Le <73370.50@compuserve.com>
Subject: AGLA steering wheel leather replacement

I had this done on the 4-spoke steering wheel and shift knob of my '86 951. The
leather is good quality and is a good clolor (burgandy) match. However I can see
gaps where they cut away original leather and replaced it. Ugly and noticeable
at a glance. More driving pulls the gaps apart. Perhaps, if it had been glued
down, this would not happen. The functionality is unaffected, but this ranks up
there with a chipped windshield in terms of constant annoyance. If I had to
spend the $200 again, I would have gotten a Momo Monte Carlo w/ hub and a deep
Snap-on 24mm? socket.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 95 17:17:57 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Bursch Muffler

> From: Nancy.O.Broadhead@Dartmouth.EDU (Nancy O. Broadhead)
> Subject: Re: Bursch Mufflers
> 
> Bursch mufflers don't seem to work well on 911s w/MFI.  (Our engine is a
> stock 2.2 911E, installed in a 914-6.)  Caused a very lean condition between
> 2700 and 3400 rpm that could not be adjusted out.
>

Hmmm, I'm almost tempted to take this as a testimonial in *favor* of
Bursch on cars with closed-loop fuel systems.  

Reasoning: Bosch 911 MFI is a totally open loop system; from throttle
position and engine RPM it derives engine airflow (carved into its
internal space cam) and thus knows how much gas to inject.  The space
cam is specific to the engine airflow characteristics (volumetric
efficiency) and depends, among many other things, on the exhaust flow.
Sounds to me like the Bursch flows a little more air between 2700 and
3400, allowing better cylinder filling; your MFI unit, not knowing about
the new muffler, keeps injecting the same old amount of gas.  Result: a
lean spot.

On any car with an air flow sensor (carbs, flappers, hot wires, MAP
sensors), this extra airflow would be detected and extra gas would be
injected.  Presumed result: a little extra torque between 2700 and 3400
rpm, or whatever rpm band the extra flow was in.  'Course, there might
be *less* flow in some other rpm band... the laws of physics tend to be
like that, I don't know any specifics in this case.

Anybody had a Bursch muffler on a dyno and care to comment?  I know
Pressler has dyno curves for *his* modified mufflers...

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 21:11:22 -0500 (EST)
From: samh@iglou.com (Samuel Halperin)
Subject: Buying a project car: what I've Learned So Far..

	I thought some people might find this summary usefull: (My 
alterior motive is to encourage further input into reccomendations for 
buying a early (read sub $10k) 911)...

1) The 2.7 L engine is not reccomended... basically to bbig for it's 
briches, something technical about the magnesium casing..

2) Buy a car that runs as apposed to one that doesn't.  A cheap non 
running car can quickly become very expensive.

3) Avoid very early models..  ('64-'68)

4) The '69 -'73 are reccomended as good early models.
	a) The 69 T is carbureted (weber)
	b) The 70-71 are also carbureted (zenith)

5) The 1978+ SC are reccomended because they are rustproof.
	a) The 3.0 L is also relatively "bulletproof"

6) Good Books for buying/maintaining:  The Used 911 Story" Peter Zimmerman
  				       The Porsche Book Jurgen Barth
				       Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
						Bruce Anderson
	(I only own the last one, it is great.)  
	(other book note: there were some more, but they seemed to old or 
too expensive.. see older pphile messages, or write me if you are interested)


thats it....  I am currently searching Pphiles and the Hemmings Motor 
News for a good deal.


oh yeah, one other note:


7) Bruce Anderson offers engine overhaul, tranny and other classes, write 
him for info.

Date: Fri, 06 Jan 1995 08:51:49 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: rust repair on 914

George Hussey wrote;

>far the best - we have tried them all. POR-15 dissolves the rust and dries to
>a tough sealed coating ready for top coat. When glossy and dry, POR-15 will

Did you compare it to Corroless new primer/etcher/rust killer? The red 
colored one which seem to be the most sticky paint I've come across. got 
some on my fingers while tresting my '58 356 with the product. It has 
zillions small glass particles and make one tough surface. I had 'red' 
fingers for a week!!!

I wouldn't trust any other brand until I could test it in the Fjord outside 
the town I live in; bore a hole in a 5"x5" piece of sheet metal, completely 
cover it with the rust preventers to test, drive out one sunny day in July, 
knit a solid rope through the hole of each prepared 'panel'. On with the 
scuba and down 2 metres, knit the rope. Wait. Next June, reverse the above, 
inspect panels,...this is not the time to remember you didn't mark the 
panels according to what rust preventer you used...  :-)

Trond Vidar

Date: 	Fri, 6 Jan 1995 13:22:30 +0200
From: patmor@utu.fi (Patrick Joel Morton)
Subject: Re: 914 Heat

>> Does anyone out there have any experience with alternatives for 914 heat.

>I found something that I have wanted to play with, but haven't done the
>work to know if it's any good or not yet...

>There's an outfit that makes an oil-cooler based heater for VW Beetles.
>Seems that you could mount this oil cooler gizmo in the hole
>for the gasoline heater, hook up the right plumbing and have a dandy
>heater. Of course, you'd *REALLY* need to have some sort of Y-valve
>so you can bypass it in the summer, or route it off to another heat
>exchanger that doesn't warm the interior at least...

It is a waste of money.  I used this set up in a Type I and it is a receipe
for disaster.  The heater does not put out enough heat to do anything
besides defrost your rear window.  Secondly, if not set up correctly, you
have the chance for a major oil leak.  The kit comes with cheap rubber hose
and worm clamps.  The idea is that during the summer, you move the unit out
of the interior of the car so that you have an additional "oil cooler".
IMHO, there are better, OE ways to heat yourself to toasty comfort level.

Patrick Morton

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 13:34:09 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: steering column lock housing

Greetings fellow fanatics! And Happy New Years!

I am looking for some used parts for my '84 944. The steering
wheel lock no longer functions on my car (is this common?)
so I want to try to rebuild it. The ignition switch contact
that opens when the key is removed also no longer functions,
and I assume they are related. Especially considering that I
have a new ignition switch. So, I want to rebuild my ignition
lock. However, I don't want to take my old one apart until I
obtain another to examine and as a source of parts. So, I
need the following:

* the steering lock housing: 321.905.851.D (the steering
   column goes through a bearing in this housing)
* the lock cylinder: 477.905.855.C (with a key so I can get it
   out of the housing).

I believe that these parts may interchange with those of a
924, since the early 944's had the same interior as the 924.

If you have these parts and are willing to sell them, please
email me directly at ericb@microsoft.com.

Thanks,

    Eric

Date: Thu, 05 Jan 95 15:22:38 -0800
From: lgoodwin@Blueske.apple.com
Subject: 911 suspension ?	

Howday,
We have a 74 911 that we autocross & just won a set of 22mm front adjustable
sway bars to replace
the 19mm stock ones. ( Thanks Automotion for the door prize)
So far we have lowered the car some and put in steering rack spacers and
Turbo tie rod ends.
We run 7" rims and 205x50 tires Yoko A008 tires. In this part of the world
this puts us
in the first level of modified class. We can change to adjustable sway bars
and add a shock
tower brace and adjustable rear spring plates. We can not change the torsion
bars.
The question is:
 Should (must) we replace the stock 19mm rear sway bars with 22mm to match
the
front or is this not important?
 Any great benefit from the shock tower brace and the rear adjustabel sping
plates?

Thanks for you opinions.
Larry
