- ------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:18:42 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: 944 cruise

> The symptoms are that when you push the lever it either does nothing,
> or (most commonly) starts to engage (accellerator pedal moves), but
> as soon as I release the lever it disengages.

My '86 951 cruise failed (became erratic).  When I replaced it, the 
[used] replacement box also had the aspect you noticed: Pushing the 
lever accelerated the car; releasing it "hiccuped", that is, dropped 
the throttle and then picked it back up.

Normally with your symptom I'd suggest checking the steering column 
control and related wiring, but given my symptom too I'd think it was 
the box itself.  In any event, testing the column switch is free but 
replacing the box isn't, so that might be some guidance!

Also check that your clutch and brake pedal sensor switches are operational.

		JBS

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:26:38 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>

> I own an '87' 944 and have been having a gas leak somewhere near where the
> rubber filler hose joins the metal filler neck on the gas tank. This past
> summer I replaced the rubber filler hose and clamps but still have the
leak.
> Anyone had a similar experience and how did you fix it?
I had this same leak on an '83.  Solved it by selling the car.

I examined everthing very carefully too, and never found anything 
obvious.  Tightened all the hardware to no avail.

You must use the correct, original-type clamps for one thing - standard 
clamps don't seal well in some situations.  Maybe try "gooping" 
everything too with a sealer.

Sorry I couldn't be more helpful, but it's an ugly problem!  Maybe 
compress some colored, insert gas in the filler and see where it comes out.

		JBS

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:30:58 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: cold knocks out electronics

> In cold weather when my 944 is started there sometimes are no functional
> dashboard electronics.  On the occasions that this happens you can't read
> tach, speedo, gas gauge, oil etc. until the engine gets toasty.  Eventually
> everything comes on at once.  Is there any known cause/solution for this?
> Anyone else experienced this?

If the symptom is common to all gauges, then so is the problem & 
solution (probably...  ;-) ).  Find the common grounding point for all 
the brown wires under the dash.  Check that the connection is very 
clean and bright copper colored.  Same for all terminals connected to 
that point.

Also check any common switched +12 VDC lines coming into the cluster, 
as many gauges have a constant hot feed and a variable ground 
connection through their sensor.

Next, check the connector on the instrument cluster itself - bad 
contacts, dirty, loose, etc.

		JBS

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:41:16 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: 944 engine work questions

[...]
>   Is there anything (other than the honing/reboring issue below) about
>   removing and working on a 944 engine that should keep me from using him?
No, it's pretty easy (!).  There are some special head bolts and 
tightening techniques to be aware of, and the belts must be retentioned 
properly after the job, but it's basically straight-forward.

>  - Although the cylinders looked good when the head was off awhile back,
>    I want to be prepared in case they need work.  I haven't found a machine
>    shop in central Virginia that knows what to do with the 944's aluminum
>    block.  Is special equipment needed for honing?  for reboring?
>    (One shop told me to find a shop with a Sunnen machine).
Special equipment & techniques are *required*.  The silica within the 
aluminum must be left to bear the piston ring friction after honing.  
Get someone who's very experienced in this technique!

>  - Is removal of the 3rd piston with the block still in the car worth
>    considering?  Would that repair save enough (compared to
>    a full block removal and overhall) to be worth it, or would such a
>   shortcut be shortsighted?
With a 1984, you may well have to do a lot of work down under.  I would 
*absolutely* pull the engine to enable complete access and bearing 
inspection & replacement.  It's a big job but well, well worth it.  
Then again, this assumes you'll be keeping the car and want to take 
very good care of it.

Plan on spending some serious money and finding stuff you hadn't 
planned on.  I'd be willing to wager that #3 isn't the only problem...

Good luck,

		JBS

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu,  5 Jan 95 18:49:14 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: power steering leak

>Last week I asked about power steering fluid leaks on an '89 951.
> The responses

[...]

I just saw your message!  Amongst the many failures I've had on my '86 
951, I can render experience on 2 rack failures due to leaks.

In both cases, the end seals gave out, dumping fluid into the bellows 
at each rack end.  You can drive the car w/o fluid if you disconnect 
the power pump by removing the belt.  (This is easy to do and in fact 
is how I got home from a track event last summer.  But you'll want 
strong upper arms before driving the car this way!).

One mechanic suggested that the failure was caused by the rack getting 
microscopic pitting through time [and winter storage???].  Those pits 
tear at the seal, which has around 1500 psi behind it, so it leaks 
quite handily.

The first rack lasted 6 years.  The replacement rack was reconditioned 
by a Pano advertiser, but I don't think they polished that rack - they 
just popped new seals in and wham they're done.  So it only lasted 1 
year.  This gives credence to the pitting theory above (but no 
scientific evidence).

The next rack will be new, via the aftermarket to ZF.  New racks 
through PCNA are $1600 or so these days.

So, best bet is to replace the rack.  It's gonna fail sooner or later.  
Just be wary of rebuilt racks.

		JBS

- ------------------------------

Date:          Thu, 5 Jan 1995 16:43:19 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Re: Gas leak


> > I own an '87' 944 and have been having a gas leak somewhere near where
the
> > rubber filler hose joins the metal filler neck on the gas tank. This past
> > summer I replaced the rubber filler hose and clamps but still have the
leak.
> > Anyone had a similar experience and how did you fix it?

I had a "gas leak" in my '75 911.  I was autocrossing, and after 
every run I would notice a smell of gasoline in the car.  This was 
obviously rather disturbing.  I looked all over between runs for 
dripping, smelled under the car, in the boot, etc..

Turned out that the cork gasket in the gas-cap was getting old and
compressed.  Whenever the gas would slosh up the filler neck in hard
cornering, it would leak out around the cap.  I just turned over the
cork (temporary fix...) and went back to racing with no more stench.  

This is a cheap thing to fix...

Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911S Brick Shithouse Red

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 19:47:31 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Airbox pop valves

Yeah, I like the part in the instructions that says "lowering the engine
may be required for installation".  I just went ahead and drilled the
hole and then duct-taped the plastic pour spout of my 2 gallon gas
conatiner onto the end of my shop vac hose and used this contraption
to suck all of the shavings out of the lower portion of the airbox.  Call
me an idiot (figuratively speaking of course - it would cost me a 
fortune to download that many email responses), but it seemed to
work OK.

BTW, an airbox can be pulled without pulling the engine.  I didn't think
so, but a shop I hang around every once and a while did it on a '77.

Good luck!

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

- ------------------------------

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 95 17:17:57 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Bursch Muffler

> From: Nancy.O.Broadhead@Dartmouth.EDU (Nancy O. Broadhead)
> Subject: Re: Bursch Mufflers
> 
> Bursch mufflers don't seem to work well on 911s w/MFI.  (Our engine is a
> stock 2.2 911E, installed in a 914-6.)  Caused a very lean condition
between
> 2700 and 3400 rpm that could not be adjusted out.
>

Hmmm, I'm almost tempted to take this as a testimonial in *favor* of
Bursch on cars with closed-loop fuel systems.  

Reasoning: Bosch 911 MFI is a totally open loop system; from throttle
position and engine RPM it derives engine airflow (carved into its
internal space cam) and thus knows how much gas to inject.  The space
cam is specific to the engine airflow characteristics (volumetric
efficiency) and depends, among many other things, on the exhaust flow.
Sounds to me like the Bursch flows a little more air between 2700 and
3400, allowing better cylinder filling; your MFI unit, not knowing about
the new muffler, keeps injecting the same old amount of gas.  Result: a
lean spot.

On any car with an air flow sensor (carbs, flappers, hot wires, MAP
sensors), this extra airflow would be detected and extra gas would be
injected.  Presumed result: a little extra torque between 2700 and 3400
rpm, or whatever rpm band the extra flow was in.  'Course, there might
be *less* flow in some other rpm band... the laws of physics tend to be
like that, I don't know any specifics in this case.

Anybody had a Bursch muffler on a dyno and care to comment?  I know
Pressler has dyno curves for *his* modified mufflers...

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 21:11:22 -0500 (EST)
From: samh@iglou.com (Samuel Halperin)
Subject: Buying a project car: what I've Learned So Far..

	I thought some people might find this summary usefull: (My 
alterior motive is to encourage further input into reccomendations for 
buying a early (read sub $10k) 911)...

1) The 2.7 L engine is not reccomended... basically to bbig for it's 
briches, something technical about the magnesium casing..

2) Buy a car that runs as apposed to one that doesn't.  A cheap non 
running car can quickly become very expensive.

3) Avoid very early models..  ('64-'68)

4) The '69 -'73 are reccomended as good early models.
	a) The 69 T is carbureted (weber)
	b) The 70-71 are also carbureted (zenith)

5) The 1978+ SC are reccomended because they are rustproof.
	a) The 3.0 L is also relatively "bulletproof"

6) Good Books for buying/maintaining:  The Used 911 Story" Peter Zimmerman
  				       The Porsche Book Jurgen Barth
				       Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
						Bruce Anderson
	(I only own the last one, it is great.)  
	(other book note: there were some more, but they seemed to old or 
too expensive.. see older pphile messages, or write me if you are interested)


thats it....  I am currently searching Pphiles and the Hemmings Motor 
News for a good deal.


oh yeah, one other note:


7) Bruce Anderson offers engine overhaul, tranny and other classes, write 
him for info.

Date: Fri, 06 Jan 1995 08:51:49 +0100
From: Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no (Trond Vidar Olsen)
Subject: Re: rust repair on 914

George Hussey wrote;

>far the best - we have tried them all. POR-15 dissolves the rust and dries
to
>a tough sealed coating ready for top coat. When glossy and dry, POR-15 will

Did you compare it to Corroless new primer/etcher/rust killer? The red 
colored one which seem to be the most sticky paint I've come across. got 
some on my fingers while tresting my '58 356 with the product. It has 
zillions small glass particles and make one tough surface. I had 'red' 
fingers for a week!!!

I wouldn't trust any other brand until I could test it in the Fjord outside 
the town I live in; bore a hole in a 5"x5" piece of sheet metal, completely 
cover it with the rust preventers to test, drive out one sunny day in July, 
knit a solid rope through the hole of each prepared 'panel'. On with the 
scuba and down 2 metres, knit the rope. Wait. Next June, reverse the above, 
inspect panels,...this is not the time to remember you didn't mark the 
panels according to what rust preventer you used...  :-)

Trond Vidar

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 08:54:26 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: cam belt rubbing

Hi Mike:

>The teeth on my cam belt on my 1980 931 are deteriorating very fast - I
>installed the belt 2 years ago and have driven only 3 or 4 thousand miles!
> The teeth are more than half gone and the front of the engine is coated with
>the powdery remains of the belt.  Luckily I spotted the problem while
>changing the water pump ... could have been disasterous (it looks as if the
>cam would have started skipping soon)

Having just opened and closed my 944 engine, I also noticed some ground up
timing belt. The culprit: the camshaft aluminum cover. This is the part
that is behind the distributor.

You must remove the distributor, the upper plastic timing cover and the by
undoing 3 bolts, the aluminum cover will come off. I found that there was
a strenghtenning rib that was making contact with the belt. The cover was
shinny from the rubbing. Got my Dremel out and ground it up a bit. Should
be ok now. 

Might pay to check yours. I'm also using a Zim's belt. Hope this helps!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (Beauty, nah, THE REAL BEAST!)
'85 Guards Red 944 (The Beast)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo
'88 Silver BMW 325is

       Pete, the spotwelder I saw for sale -is- the Miller "Autoarc spot

     price is the retail of $499) including 12" tongs. Its available from
     "Autobody Toolmart" (800-382-1200) under the stock number 2780. They
     also have the other accessory tongs available. Runs off 115 volts
     directly

     to body shops (not to home restorers like Eastwood does) and carry 
     a very wide range of products, from cheap wrench sets and hammers 
     to car lifts to paint booths to frame machines...their prices seem
     very reasonable.

     educating you with their catalog alone. Their prices are high (i.e. 
     repackage Krylon and sell it for twice as much) but kind of in line
     with the "tool boutique" and 6 color catalogs a year format.

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 10:17:10 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Snow chains for 944 Turbo??

Dear Patty:

Re tire chains for 944:

A really bad idea to put chains on tires that size. I can only imagine the
havoc that would result if one of those bad boys came loose.
A much better idea is to get a second set of wheels of the minimum size
available (7" all around) and put a set of snow tires on, all around.
BTW stay off the boost (g)  if you drive in the snow. With limited slip
you'll be looking out of the side window allot.
I did manage all last winter driving my 944 turbo. It wasn't always fun and I
did resort to the Subaru a few times. 

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 09:28:51 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Re:  911 Targa Ski/Bike racks


Tom,

I went through the same search and frustration.  I was searching for
a rear mounted bike rack.  One BIG factor ... Do you have a whale tail?
I do.  I ended up modifying a RhodeGear Ultra-3 (I liked the design).
The down tube is long enough to bring the multi-pivot joint above the
tail.  (In fact, I shortened it by 2").  I then created an extra long
horizontal brace out of 3/4" electrical conduit which meets the car at
the base of the rear window.  This replaces the shorter original one.
So far it works just great.  I haven't tried my skis yet.  I'm sure I'll
have to create some sort of modification for them.

If you find roof racks that mount with NO permanent car modifications,
let me know.  I would still like to find/build some.

Note:  My 911 is not only my favorite car, it is my only car.  So, no
flames about 911/truck applications please.

Wayne D. Michelsen
W_Michelsen@lfhs2.hso.link.com
'87 911 Targa [Guards-Red/Black]

------------------------------

Date: 6 Jan 1995 10:33:31 U
From: "Piescik, Walter" <wpiescik@mailcenter.tsmi.iitri.com>
Subject: Welding Class

In response to the question from Andrew Kalman,

>I've decided that I need to learn to weld, and I thought a good way to do
>it would be to take a trade/vocational class in the Bay Area (SFO).  

First bit of advice, if you can keep yourself from doing this, **stop now**.
If you need to do only occasional welding, have someone else do it. If you
are about to undertake a major restoration, have your head examined. Welding
puts holes in your body. It has **at least** a temporary effect on your night
vision. I see halos around lights at night for at least a day after welding.
I am sure that as my excellent vision deteriorates naturally with age, I will
always wonder to what extent it is because of the welding. It can produce
noxious fumes. OTOH, it provides a great feeling of accomplishment. On
balance, when I finish my current project, I intend to hang up my helmet.

If you cannot stop yourself, read on. If you are prone to hurt yourself, take
the class or forget it entirely.

My experience in self-teaching MIG welding suggests that no class is
necessary. (no pun intended) Just buy the book at the welding supply shop, (I
will suggest one if you like) some extra material, and have your air chisel
ready. Practice your lap welds, butt welds, and button hole welds, and then
destroy them to observe their strength. If you are restoring a rusty car, be
sure to experiment with partially rusted stock (cut some off the car) to know
what you can get away with. Be sure to do some long segments and observe the
distortion. Follow the directions in the book regarding tacking the work,
preventing heat buildup, and *leaving a root gap* (very important, easy to
forget)

You may need to consult with an experienced welder the first time in order to
learn what the proper sizzle sounds like, and to show you what the basic
welds are. 

Do not hesitate to use the mud dobber method. (short burst of current, watch
metal cool, as the cherry red color dims, another short burst of current) It
requires a lower skill level, and when used with higher current setting can
yeild terrific penetration.(110%) 

Do not underestimate the need for safety equipment. You will set your car on
fire at some point (undercoat, paint,whatever), be ready to put it out. Eye
protection is basic and (I hope) needs no comment. When welding on anything
other than the lowest settings, protect your arms and legs from sunburn. When
working overhead, **wear earplugs**!. That is a sizzle you do not want to
hear, and your garden variety helmet does not adequately protect. I have had
slag land in my outer ear, but was saved by the plugs. Be sure to get a
respirator that fits under your helmet, especially if you will be dealing
with any galvanized replacement panels. Gloves are a must, leather shirt is a
luxury. Spats to cover your ankles are nice, and only about $10. High boots
work as well.

Don't bother with the $200+ automatic helmet, they are for weenies. You will
learn soon enough how to work in the dark, and your eyes may be better
protected. A strong light on the work surface will allow you to see
adequately.

Use 25% Argon, 75% C02 mix. I forget which wire metalurgy, but I can
recommend one if you like. The guys at your supplier can tell you. I prefer
the thin (.024"?) wire for sheet metal.

Good luck, and "feel the burn"

Walter Piescik
Argon Junkie

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 06 Jan 95 10:50:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Rain and an '84 944


Hi Joe,

My understanding is that most leaks like yours are due to problems with
the four drain hoses that run from the lip of the sunroof opening.  With the
sunroof raised or out, you should be able to make out the four openings,
one at each corner.  All feed white plastic hoses, two running down your
car's A pillars, two running down the C pillars.  The right rear hose also
feeds a T fitting whose other input leg runs from the gas filler drain.

When the hoses fail or become clogged, rain water apparently runs to
the floor.  Not sure the exact route.  I'd start by making sure the hoses
are intact and not clogged.

Hope this helps.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 06 Jan 95 10:55:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Snow chains for 944 Turbo??


Hi Patty,

Nice to hear from you again.  The caveat probably has to do with the limited
clearance between the outer fender skin and the tires and wheels on 951S',
esp. in light of their 9" rims.  Porsche rolled the fender lip on the 951S 
to get
basic clearance, as it is.

I would guess that if you're faced with snow, you probably aren't driving on
245-wide tires anyways, which should help.

Of course, why someone in San Francisco would even own a set of chains
is an interesting question!

Kevin Gross

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 10:45:50 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: Coatings for heat exchangers


Hi all --

On Jan. 4 Patrick Morton <patmor@polaris.cc.utu.fi> asked about ceramic 
coatings for heat exchangers.

Some time ago I contacted a place that produces Jet-Hot (TM) coatings and 
while I haven't tried their product, I think most of us would wince at the 
idea of *doubling* the cost incurred to have coated heat exchangers.  Advice 
I have heard previously is get the stainless steel and be happy.

    -- Bill
       wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 11:00:47 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: re: 944 cruise control woes

There have been a couple of postings concerning the 944/951 cruise control 
system failing to hold the specified speed.

I haven't dealt with the car or system in question, *but* on the M-B 
W123-chassis vehicles the cruise control amplifier (computer, whatever you 
want to call it) routinely fails and the first line of defense is to remove 
the box from the car, carefully open it and even more carefully re-soldier 
all of the joints on the circuit board.  I did this twice on a `78 300D with 
some success before the box failed completely.  The box was made for M-B by 
VDO if that's any help . . .

If you're looking at replacing the amplifier anyway, it is probably worth a 
shot.

Good Luck,

    -- Bill
       wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 06 Jan 95 12:02 EST
From: "David_I.Johnson" <23373MGR@MSU.EDU>
Subject: Porschephiles #1051 Fri Jan 6 02

"Turbo" magazine is an excellent source for high tech engine modifications.
There have been two 944S project cars in the last year. Small turbo low end
response and big turbos for high end horsepower is the general rule. However,
variable nozzle and modified air wheels may be availble somewhere if you want
it both ways. More horsepower needs more fuel and air. Consider flow on the
intake side and bigger or additional injectors. How much boost and are you
going to o-ring the head or block? Is such a head gasket available for the 944
turbo? Is the stock intercooler adequate for the horsepower you want? And
remember bring big bucks. High tech horsepower costs big money.

If you don't do the work yourself be sure to get someone with proven
experience with turbos, fuel injection, electronics etc.

Dave Johnson
85.5 944
86 Ford Mustang SVO
85 "      "      "
75 Cosworth Vega
89 765 Volvo

Date: Fri, 06 Jan 95 09:40:00 PST

I'm helping a buddy restore an M6, and one of the things he's done is to 
have his new headers 'Jet-Hot'ted.  Not only is it a great coating, but it 
prevents heat build-up in the header material, which keeps head temps down. 
 Nice.

i also have a p-car with cruise-control schizophrenia. what my 928 ('79) does
is this:

	when i push the lever to the 'set/accell' position, nothing happens for
about 1 sec, then the car begins acceleratiing (this is proper behaviour). upon
release, however, the car acts like the cc didn't engage, and begins slowing
down (if i release the accelerator). exprimentation on deserted roads, however,
 shows that the cc DID engage, it just recorded a 'set' speed about 4mph
 below the speed when the lever was pushed. perhaps this is a related failure?

i haven't debugged this much beyond this stage, since the car is mostly driven
on rallys and short trips, and getting the cc module out of the car 
(its under the
heater core) is a real bitch.

	i'm afraid i need to remove the cc module, really understand what all
of its imputs and outputs are, and figure out which component inside went
TU.

Date: 06 Jan 95 12:56:30 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Renovating leather interiors

 
Hi, Mark.
 
Better than sending off a sample, you can probably find an automotive paint
jobber in your area that can mix SEM or DuPont dyes to match your car, on
the spot. These products are sprayed onto the surface, after suitable
cleaning and priming.
 
Even better than having a shop match it and trying to spray it yourself, you
can hire a professional to do it. The cost is very reasonable, they know
what they're doing, and they can probably come to your home to do it. If you
can't find anybody in the yellow pages, ask a higher-end used car dealer who
they have come in to repair their damaged vinyl and leather. Try the used car
dept. of your local Porsche dealer, for example. Done right, you absolutely
can't tell.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 06 Jan 95 12:56:36 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Door weight differences

 
>Does anyone happen to know the weight difference between a stock U.S.
>Carrera door and a Euro door?
 
In recent years, none. The European cars have the side guard beam required
for U.S. cars, and everything else remains the same too.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 06 Jan 95 12:56:26 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Color confusion

 
Hi, Neil.
 
I looked in my '73 Carrera RS book, and neither Rose Red nor code 4610 are
listed. It is possible that Rose Red is a bad translation of Rosarot, which
is pink by any other name. (As in the famous German Peter Sellers movie
"Der Rosarote Panther" <g>). There is no color chip shown that could be
considered pink by any stretch of the imagination.
 
The book does list a paint code (paint code and color code are different).
The paint code 132 on the plate in your car indicates ivory. That at least
matches what your car has on it/in it now. I don't know what the -9-1 mean.
 
Color name    color code    paint code   paint manufacturer
Ivory          4646          132         Lesonal (Sikkens)
 
While filling out your certificate, could somebody have mis-looked at the
4646 paint code, and written it down as 4610, which is who knows what? Sounds
to me like your car is painted in the original color, if trunk, engine bay,
under dash, under carpet, and paint plate all say ivory.
 
This is one reason I place absolutely no value on those "certificates of
authenticity." You are relying on somebody to hand copy the information from
Porsche's original cardex. The only real source of this information would be
a photocopy of the actual cardex, and Porsche just isn't set up to do that.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 13:02:37 -0500 (EST)
From: Peter J Wales <pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net>
Subject: Re: 944 turbo upgrades

Hi Jim,

The problems with increasing the boost pressure in the 944 turbo come 
from head gasket failure. We had some special ones made in Switzerland 
which would allow continuous running at 17 psi boost pressure. They are 
hand made from stainless steel and we fitted them to all of the Porsche 
turbo cup cars in the uk 2 years ago. I have one left @ $300 if you are 
interested.

If you fix that problem a different way, the other thing we found very 
useful was to keep the boost pressure constant. With that particular 
turbo/wastegate setup the boost regulation was very poor and it would 
peak at 4000 RPM and drop way back to 12 PSI at 5500 and over. If you can 
get the boost pressure up at higher RPMs you will get a dramatic increase 
in power. We sell a boost graphic to do it and HKS and others have similar 
things. The problem with changing the turbo is in the lag and the sudden 
onrush of power unsettling the car when it comes in. If most of your 
track work is in a straight line then go for a big one. if not, stay 
small and control it


Peter Wales
President Superchips Inc

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 95 10:37:09 PST
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  Snow chains for 944 Turbo??

Patty,

I've got the non-turbo, but the solution I had should work for
almost any car.  

When I run some of those all-night rallies that I've mentioned, there
is often a good chance of snow and ice.  There have even been some
places where they required that chains were carried, but being around
1am, no one was checking.  So, the solution I have used has been to
find a friend with magic chains.  These are chains that have never 
actually been used, but as long as you have them with you, you never
need them. 8-)

Pat
'86 944 Rally car.

   From: porschephiles-request

   Date: Friday, January 6, 1995 10:17AM

   Dear Patty:

   Re tire chains for 944:

   A really bad idea to put chains on tires that size. I can only imagine 
the
   havoc that would result if one of those bad boys came loose.
   A much better idea is to get a second set of wheels of the minimum size
   available (7" all around) and put a set of snow tires on, all around.
   BTW stay off the boost (g)  if you drive in the snow. With limited slip
   you'll be looking out of the side window allot.
   I did manage all last winter driving my 944 turbo. It wasn't always fun 
and I
   did resort to the Subaru a few times.

   Regards,
   Jerry
   89 944turbo S black (track Car)

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 11:04:05 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: new underwear...

My morning commute is usually a very unremarkable 10 minute drive down
a 1300 foot hill.  This morning, though, it was, er, much livelier!!

As I approached a 90 degree left turn at the bottom of the steepest
part of the hill, I applied the brakes, practicing my double clutch
downshift with the heel-toe braking (I've been doing that a lot
recently, after the discussions on this list..) and the brake pedal
sank straight to the floor, with no discernible braking whatever!

Pumping had no effect; I rounded the wet corner *way* faster than
usual, but managed to stay on the asphalt (and away from that row of
steel posts on the outside).  On the exit of the turn I realized I was
still upright, and hadn't yet downshifted *or* used the E-brake, so I
did both, and quickly sized up the rest of the drive for its
survivability.

As I limped the rest of the way to work with the E-brake and the
gears, trying to bring my heartrate back into the healthy range, I
thought back to last night... driving home, I did a panic stop at the
bottom of my hill (I do that from time to time when I'm alone on the
road, just to learn the car and test the braking system, and to bring
those long-lost coins out of the seats...). It worked fine; I made a
mental note to adjust my rear drums because they hadn't locked up.

So, at work this AM, my brake fluid in the reservoir is right up to
the top.  I assume my master cylinter is toast, then.  Gee, Automotion
just put them on sale, didn't they! 

Rather an ungraceful failure, don'cha think?  So much for dual brake
circuits...

 -mike  '80 931  (4 bolt wheels)

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 11:30:55 -0800

>better off with the C4.

>GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963

Grayson,

Where do you come up with these outlandish generalizations??

From what I understand of the AWD system used on the '95 911 C4, it is
likely that for racing purposes, certainly for autox, the RWD '95 911
is the better car.

This means that all us autox and big track guys and gals will probably
prefer the non-C4 version of the car. Does this mean we have ego or
testosterone levels that lead us to think we COULD have an FIA Superlicense?
I don't think so!

Some of us may prefer the traditional RWD for tradition's sake.

So, not all of us are better off with the C4.

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 95 12:48:02 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Targa Top Reconstruction


Wayne Michelsen asked for advice about Targa top
rebuilding, and everyone advised having it doe
professionally.  That's one way, sure.  But it
isn't a very hard job to do yourself, saves money,
and provides some inner satisfaction.  I posted
the following a while back.  (Wayne-It might be
helpful.  And to answer your question about what
glue to use for the seals, 3M Weatherstrip
adhesive is about the best.)

I didn't get an overwhelming response to my question about hinks 
and kinks for Targa Top redos.   Perhaps few tackle it for fear of the 
unknown.  My experience might help.

I completely tore down, cleaned, repainted and installed a new top 
and headliner this weekend.  It wasn't hard, and it came out fine.  It 
looks brand new, and fits on the car beautifully.  

I don't think there's any real trick to it.  Just go slowly and carefully 
and pay attention to how the old one was put together.  There's really 
only one aspect to reassembly that I would offer advice on, and it has 
to do with reattaching the "floating" plates by strips of webbing (I 
used seatbelt material, obtainable cheap from most fabric stores.) so 
as to get them spaced properly.  It's easy to do and easy to explain, 
but a pain to write out, especially if no one is interested.  If you really 
want my advice...let me know and I'll either write it out an e-mail 
version of draw a diagram and mail it to you.

If your top isn't in terrible shape, you probably won't have to redo the 
webbing.  Mine top was a disaster.  I'm sure it was the original 22 
yearold top, which the previous owner had covered liberally with 
gobs of silicon seal in a valiant effort to stem the leaks.  The headliner 
would more aptly have been called a head hanger, because it wasn't 
lining anything anymore.  Even the half roll of duct tape (applied by 
the previous owner, natch) wasn't enough to hold it all on.

Bob
'72 911E Targa

------------------------------

Date: Fri,  6 Jan 95 13:01:56 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: cam belt rubbing

There was a post recently about a belt whose excessive wear was
discovered during a water pump replacement. Well, if the water pump
was not turning as freely as it is supposed to, that would certainly put
additional stress on the drive teeth. There have also been a couple
of posts about belts rubbing on the housing. This simply should not
happen unless one of two things are incorrect: the tension or  the
rotation of the tightening idler. Some mechanics claim they can tighten
these belts without the special adjustment gauge. Always use the
gauge to do the tensioning (at least through the 86 model year on
the 944, a self adjuster was introduced in '87). Also, the idler pulley
that sets the tension can be rotated the wrong way which will result
in possible belt rubbing. If my memory serves me, it should be rotated
counter-clockwise. Nonetheless, it is pretty easy to see which way to
rotate it so that the belt is farthest from the housing. Ditto for the balance
shafts belt tensioning idler.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 16:07:20 -0500
From: NannW@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Trip (Rich Lambert)

Go for it!  Taking European delivery of a Porsche is one of life's great
experiences.  Not only do you get to drive your brand new Porsche whil on
vacation, you also get to:
1.  Visit the Porsche Museum
2. Get a tour of the factory.
3. Drive the autobahn, at speeds the Porsche understands very nicely!
4. Save enough $$ on the purchase to cover the cost of the trip.

We did it for the first time in 1990, and this is the only way we will ever
take delivery on another Porsche.  There is a lot more territory to explore
in Europe in a Porsche.  Many of our friends have gone this route also, and
love it!

You can make all the arrangements through the Porsche dealer of your choice -
they are very familiar with this program.

Good luck, and enjoy!

Nann Weissenberger
National Membership Chair, Porsche Club of America
'90 944S2
and four cats!!

Date: Fri,  6 Jan 95 13:14:48 TZ

| I think I can answer why a San Franciscan might own chains in

My brother is a volunteer firefighter in Nevada county CA.
He tells me that the roads leading to the Sierra Nevada
ski areas become very treacherous when icy or snow
covered, especially to bay area residents who are not
used to driving under those conditions. The tow truck drivers
do a real good business during the winter and lots of body
shop work is generated. So, even if you can manage to
drive your P-car under those conditions, are you willing
to be taken out by someone else who has lost control?
If not, take the Subaru.

Truly an odd quirk of human nature how flatlanders
with sports utility 4x4s think they are invincible on snow
and ice. They slide very gracefully until they hit something
hard!

    Eric

Porschephiles #1054                         Sat Jan 7 02:00:07 CST 1995
Date: Fri,  6 Jan 95 13:23:51 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: More on washer bottles/windscreen spray

| From: Kevin Hughes  <kh@wg.icl.co.uk>
|
| 	I suspect my 911 screen washer is suffering a failed one way valve - I
| will confirm this tonight.

Only one of the two windscreen washer jets was functional on my 944,
so I investigated. Turns out that one of the one-way valves was not
opening under pump pressure as it should. I carefully pulled it apart.
Of course there was a tiny little spring inside that went bouncing off
in some unknown direction. After a few minutes on my hands and knees
with a flashlight I found it. I then examined the innards of the valve. It
appeared that the rubber gasket had expanded to the point that it
was sealing around the circumference of the valve. It is only supposed
to seal against the inlet at the end, so I trimmed about a mm off of
the circumference of this gasket with a pair of scissors. After
reassembly, the washer system works great!

Good luck!

    Eric

Date: Fri, 06 Jan 95 15:29:18 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: More Welding: Metal Fabricators Handbook


     Continuing the thread on welding... Usually when there is a desire to 
     weld, there is also an accompanying desire to fabricate patch panels, 
     brackets etc. for rust repair.  Welding takes you half the way there.  
     There are two excellent books on metal fabrication called "Sheet Metal 
     Fabricator's Handbook" and "Metal Fabricator's Handbook" by the same 
     author.  There are other sources for this book but I know that it is 
     sold by Eastwood through their catalog.  The sheet metal book is the 
     one to get.  I have both and they are good reading for the apprentice 
     welder.
     
     Derek Au

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 06 Jan 95 16:46:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.ncr.com>
Subject: RE: Welding Class


Subject: Welding Class
Date: Friday, January 06, 1995 10:33AM

In response to the question from Andrew Kalman,
== and in response to Walter Piescik,  A NICE LONG TALK
   <some deleted>
>I've decided that I need to learn to weld, and I thought a good way to do
>it would be to take a trade/vocational class in the Bay Area (SFO).

First bit of advice, if you can keep yourself from doing this, **stop now**.
If you need to do only occasional welding, have someone else do it. If you
are about to undertake a major restoration, have your head examined. Welding
puts holes in your body. It has **at least** a temporary effect on your 
night
vision. I see halos around lights at night for at least a day after welding.
I am sure that as my excellent vision deteriorates naturally with age, I 
will
always wonder to what extent it is because of the welding. It can produce
noxious fumes. OTOH, it provides a great feeling of accomplishment. On
balance, when I finish my current project, I intend to hang up my helmet.

==  To Andrew I would say blow off the class if it is a full program to
== apprentice welders.  Unless it is oriented toward car repair.
==  You wont need the intensity of a formal class to panel patch a car.
==
==  To Walter; blowing holes in panels is poor technique and lack of
== practice.  Wooh! Easy now. . . that was meant as constructive criticism.
==  Ok, not flame.   Have you tried the copper spoon behind the panel
== to aid in those cases when overheating is difficult to control?  it 
works.
==
==  As far as damage to eyesight, man you've just got the wrong shield
== and helmet.  I've been using a large faceplate Jackson for over 4 years
== with no degredation (and I wear super strong contact lenses too).
==  I suggest using a shade 6 (yes 6) in a plastic,gold deposited shield.
==  These are a little special and maybe hard to find.  The upshot is that
== using these light shades that are gold filtered allows equal protection
== from UV *and* allows you to see your work BEFORE you strike an arc.
==  Caveat here being that you must have BRIGHT lights in proximity to
== the work area.  If you are getting burnt eyes there may be some back
== reflections you are exposing yourself to. (or youre squinting at the arc)
==  <g>
==  Heh, heh, I like the 'weenie' term in reference to those LCD hoods, yeah
== they are another example of 'revenue generating device'.
==  Use the lighter shade, give me a growl if you cant find them and I'll
== research the source.  (if interested, of course <g>)
==

My experience in self-teaching MIG welding suggests that no class is
necessary. (no pun intended) Just buy the book at the welding supply shop, 
(I
will suggest one if you like) some extra material, and have your air chisel

==  Well, if you have NEVER welded before, you might need a little help
== in understanding some of the principles to help you get off center.
==  I have said this many times; check out the 'Welders Handbook'
== by Tom Monroe and Richard Finch,  about $15 at bookstar.
==
==  As far as practice and whatnot; by all means burn up the steel and
== pound it apart to discover how the failure mode works.
==  This will give you the feel for penetration.  (was that a pun?)
==
ready. Practice your lap welds, butt welds, and button hole welds, and then
destroy them to observe their strength. If you are restoring a rusty car, be
sure to experiment with partially rusted stock (cut some off the car) to 
know

==  Yeah, and first thing you'll find is that rusty metal welds like sh*t.
==  There is a lot of technique.  Cleaning metal to bare is almost a 
required.
==  You will get the feel for this as practice continues.  Tough to 
describe.

what you can get away with. Be sure to do some long segments and observe the
distortion. Follow the directions in the book regarding tacking the work,
preventing heat buildup, and *leaving a root gap* (very important, easy to
forget)

==  Controlling heat buildup and warpage go hand in hand, but again there
== are techniques, like tacking panels using a 'torqueing sequence'
== similar to head bolts.  'root gap' is important in this respect.

You may need to consult with an experienced welder the first time in order 
to
learn what the proper sizzle sounds like, and to show you what the basic
welds are.

==  Walter is doing fine so far...
==  When set up properly, it sounds like  'frying eggs' and there is some
== tolerance in getting the settings right.  There is also an occurance
== to adjust the settings (heat range and wire feed rate) for odd 
situations.
==  That too, requires some time in the saddle to know when and how.
==  Generally, you use two heat ranges, medium and high.  The wire
== feed rate between 5 and 8 (on the dial).  Usually 6.

Do not hesitate to use the mud dobber method. (short burst of current, watch
metal cool, as the cherry red color dims, another short burst of current) It
requires a lower skill level, and when used with higher current setting can
yeild terrific penetration.(110%)

==  This is a good way to fill holes, bridge gaps, and otherwise pile on
== steel where you want it.  Being able to tell temperature of the puddle
== is important to controlling blowout.  This is where the gold deposited
== shade aids in determination of melting threshold.  Brightness

Do not underestimate the need for safety equipment. You will set your car on
fire at some point (undercoat, paint,whatever), be ready to put it out. Eye
protection is basic and (I hope) needs no comment. When welding on anything
other than the lowest settings, protect your arms and legs from sunburn. 
When
working overhead, **wear earplugs**!. That is a sizzle you do not want to
hear, and your garden variety helmet does not adequately protect. I have had
slag land in my outer ear, but was saved by the plugs. Be sure to get a
respirator that fits under your helmet, especially if you will be dealing
with any galvanized replacement panels. Gloves are a must, leather shirt is 
a
luxury. Spats to cover your ankles are nice, and only about $10. High boots
work as well.

==  Ok, if your setting stuff afire, then you have not cleaned the weld site
== sufficiently.  When stuff burns (coatings, rust, blood) the fumes get
== incorporated into the weld zone and contaminates the gas envelope
== and aggravating the propensity to blowout.
==  Welding with a buggery nozzle can cause all sorts of headaches too.
==  (another pun?)

==  Walter is dead on about the safety issue.  WELDING IS DANGEROUS.
==  There are many hazards associated with it.  Gloves and leathers are
== a big plus for a multitude of undertakings beyond welding.  Same goes
== for respirators and goggles/face shields.  I keep a big CO2 extiguisher
== handy at all times near welding.
==
==  Yeah, and shoe spats are a cool idea.  I have gotten slag down my
== sock.  And it always rolls into the worst spot -between the toes!  OWW!
==  Makes me dance the jig when it happens.

Don't bother with the $200+ automatic helmet, they are for weenies. You will
learn soon enough how to work in the dark, and your eyes may be better
protected. A strong light on the work surface will allow you to see
adequately.

==  Do the golden shade thing, it makes a difference in the outcome.

Use 25% Argon, 75% C02 mix. I forget which wire metalurgy, but I can
recommend one if you like. The guys at your supplier can tell you. I prefer
the thin (.024"?) wire for sheet metal.

==  I dont recall the rating now, but I use 'prep EZ' in the 15 pound roll
== at .023 diameter.  This stuff grinds off a little easier than ER71 <?>
== and is just as strong for car body work.

Good luck, and "feel the burn"

Walter Piescik
Argon Junkie

==  like he said...
==  -kyle         <kehler@smtplink.wichitaks.ncr.com>
==               'no balls, no glory'  (Eck's Saloon)



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 06 Jan 95 18:15:20 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re:  944 rear wiper failure ?

> I've been experiencing intermittent failure of the rear wiper of my 944. It
> seems to be related to temperature. There have been a few exceptions but
> the wiper usually fails in temps below 0 (C). Once the car warms up it
> sudenly works fine. Anybody heard of this or have any solutions ?
> 
> 

Any chance that the wiper is merely frozen to the rear hatch?  You may have
to pull the wiper blade loose prior to activating the wiper.

Have you checked the circuitry to the motor assembly?  Using a test light
would be quite simple, since the circuit is quite simple.

If it is neither of those two possibilities, then the wiper assembly needs
replacement.

good luck,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 95 16:17:29 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Testing 914 starter

>From: michael@helix.nih.gov (Michael A. Freed)
>Subject: testing 914 starter
>Status: RO

>Porschephiles,  I think that my starter may be bad. Even when my battery's
>specific gravity shows full charge, and produces 12 V unloaded,  the
>starter poops out after a few turns. I hear the solenoid click.  The
>accessories (lights, fans, wipers etc) seem to work ok.
>-Can a battery show full charge and actually not deliver current?
>-How best to test the starter?
>-Assuming that this is a good test, does anybody know the correct winding
>resistance (not in Haynes manual)?
>
>-Also, the alternator belt is loose. How best to tighten it? Specifically,
>how do I lever the altenator, to tighten it, with so little room? How do I
>reach the nut of the "coach-headed bolt" as Haynes puts it?
>Thanks, Michael

A battery can show full charge, and not deliver current.  One way for
a battery to fail is for the internal resistance to be too high.

Measure the "cranking" voltage at both the battery and the starter.  It
should be in the range of 8-9 volts.

   If bad at battery, replace it.
   If OK at battery, and bad at starter, suspect wiring.

Be sure to check the ground strap at the rear of the transmission!  (And
both battery connections...)

Adjusting the alternator belt is a two person job.  Half the work is done
from below, half from above.  There's a plastic cover over the access hole,
I guess that you've found that already.

Of all the work I've done to the 914, adjusting the belt was the most
frustrating.  (Working on a 914 teaches patience.)

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 18:40:30 -0800
From: branick@netcom.com (Robert L. Branick)
Subject: Re: 911 Targa Ski/Bike racks

>I know this may offend some of you purists, but I'm interested in carting
>my bike around with my 911 Targa.  Does anybody have any knowledge about
>good roof racks?  If they mount on the Targa top, do they damage the top?
>Thule says their rack will work, but Porsche says it won't.  Help!
>--
>Tom

Tom,

I used Thule's a couple of times on my Targa.  Yes, they fit in the little
rain gutter.  No, I didn't feel super secure cruising down the highway with
bikes on the roof.  You'd be amazed at the increase in peripheral vision
acuity - you notice every little wiggle of the Targa top, sure that your
bikes are about to appear in your rear-view mirror.

Maybe I'm exagerating slightly.  It also depends on the what kind of bike.
Mountain bikes are heavier, and probably have a higher drag coefficient.  A
road bike doesn't cause as much excitement.  I'd probably use one that
hangs off the back.

Bob

Bob Branick, San Francisco, CA
'77 911S Targa, brown
'89 Ninja 250R, black
3 Road bikes
1 Mountain bike



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 12:44:45 -0600
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: 928 cruise wierdness (was re: 944 cruise control woes)

Jim Harriger says:
>	when i push the lever to the 'set/accell' position, nothing happens for
>about 1 sec, then the car begins acceleratiing (this is proper behaviour). upon
>release, however, the car acts like the cc didn't engage, and begins slowing
>down (if i release the accelerator). exprimentation on deserted roads, however,
> shows that the cc DID engage, it just recorded a 'set' speed about 4mph
> below the speed when the lever was pushed. perhaps this is a related failure?

Yup, my '83 928 is the same exact way. So I need to run it up to about
75 to set it at 70.  Sometimes, I'll set the CC and then a few minutes
later I'll ask myself why am I going so slow? Look down and I'm going
5-10 mph slower than what it was set for. I'll reset it. Then notice
that it will slowly drop the speed about 1 mph per minute!  Could this
be a vacuum leak?

FYI:
A few years ago the cruise did not work at all and the vents were not
operating properly. I traced this down to a bad vacuum check valve
located near the master cylinder. This works out to be a $70 part
because you get all the vacuum lines with it. After installation (just
the check valve: the hoses went every where) the vents and cruise work
just fine.


Brian Scudder
'83 928S
'70 Old Blue Truck
'93 Redi the cat (just in for 12 month 12,000 meow checkup)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 19:43:57 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Testing 914 starter

Re:

>Adjusting the alternator belt is a two person job.  Half the work is done
>from below, half from above.  There's a plastic cover over the access hole,
>I guess that you've found that already.
>
>Of all the work I've done to the 914, adjusting the belt was the most
>frustrating.  (Working on a 914 teaches patience.)


I've never had any problems adjusting the 914-4's belt. This is my sequence:

  1) from underneath car, loosen pivot nut
  2) from inside engine compartment, remove both plastic "covers". Put a
14mm open-end wrench  through the cover onto the square nut, and put a 6m
(?) allen key on the bolt head.  Immobilize the nut with the wrench, and
loosen it with the Allen key.  Push down _hard_ on the 14mm wrench (but
don't twist the nut - you'll need a strong wrist) and re-tighten the Allen
key.  Check tension, and replace covers.
  3) Re-tighten lower nut.

Works every time, takes about 5 minutes.  I use a 1/2" socket wrench with
an Allen-key "socket" to make it easier.


 ____________________________________________
|  Andrew E. Kalman  |  aek@netcom.com       |
 ____________________________________________
|        INCLUDE std_disclaimer.asm          |
 ____________________________________________

Date: Sat, 7 Jan 1995 09:08:15 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: re: heat exchanger coatings

On Fri, 06 Jan 95 09:40:00 PST Bob Brewer <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu> 
responded to something I had posted:

>I'm helping a buddy restore an M6, and one of the things he's done is to 
>have his new headers 'Jet-Hot'ted.  Not only is it a great coating, but it 
>prevents heat build-up in the header material, which keeps head temps down. 
> Nice.

[original post]
>>[snip]
>>Some time ago I contacted a place that produces Jet-Hot (TM) coatings and
>>while I haven't tried their product, I think most of us would wince at the
>>idea of *doubling* the cost incurred to have coated heat exchangers. 
>> Advice I have heard previously is get the stainless steel and be happy.

Alright, so I'm an idiot.  I forgot to mention that the subject was *914* 
heat exchangers and that Mr. Morton's question (you'll have to backtrack if 
you want it) was about coatings to *protect* them from the elements.  In 
that respect, I stand by what I said: the cost of coating the parts 
outweighs the purpose.

I certainly hope that no offense was taken from my comments.  I have no 
reason to suspect the quality of the Jet-Hot product (if I had, I wouldn't 
have sent for the info).

BTW, it occurred to me that the coating, by removing heat from the exhaust 
system more quickly, might reduce the amount of heat available for the 
heating system.  Is this unreasonable?

Sorry for the confusion,

    -- Bill
       wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 7 Jan 1995 09:34:12 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: More cruise control (944, 928)

To those with cruise missiles --

To catch up . . .  There have been a few posts, some about 944's some about 
928's and the cruise control failing either to "catch" or to hold.

It has been suggested that it could be a vacuum-related problem.  I doubt 
this (in spite of one person's experience -- sorry :-o ) in the case of a 
failure to hold since a vacuum leak would cause a gradual speed decrease 
which the cruise control would attempt to correct by routing more vacuum to 
the system.  I think the symptom in such a case would be similar to 
"bucking".  It could, however, be the problem for those that fail to catch 
initially.  If there isn't any vacuum available there is no way the actuator 
can do it's job.

The system's failure to set at the speed you want could be because the 
amplifier isn't "trimmed" properly.  It is possible to change the resistors 
that "trim" the appropriate circuit, but I doubt it is worth the effort.

Finally, to Jim who has the idea of finding which component has gone bad:  
Good luck.  I couldn't understand everything for M-B cruise system even with 
a complete description of all the circuits and components.  What I learned 
was "Let the pro's handle it."

Please route all flames to:

    -- Bill
       wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu

Defrosting in a 914 is mediocure at best I always carry a towel with me.
One thing that will help is to use a lot of outside air to defrost with. 
slide all the levers to the right for defrosting. Once your are either 
frozen or defrosted then start moving the levers back to the left.
>
>
>        On an unrelated note: For those of you that have experience 
with
>transmissions, I finnaly have a fresh rebuild installed (long tale of
>frustration ommited) and the only complaint/observation I have is that
>there is a fairly noticable dry grating sound when I'm engine braking.

>not there when I'm on the gas, and it canges with RPM. The pinion whine 
in

>reasembled. So is this dry grating/rattle sound normal? I was told that 
I
>should expext to hear some "gear lash" but this for some reason just 
doesn'
>t sound right.
>

Sounds like a bushing or bearing. Trans should not make any grating 
noise. Take it back to "person" who rebuilt it with it in the car. Have 
them drive it.
>        Secondly, does anybodyout there have experience with the Poly
>transmission mounts (e.g. automotion). And is it normal for them to 
loosen
>after first instalation, and for the sides to bulge slightly when 
tightened
>down?

lot of torque on the bots to hold the trans in. not sure what the torque 
is.

Date: Sat, 7 Jan 1995 09:37:52 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Fwd: BFG Tires More on Tires

- ---- Begin Forwarded Message

+OK 1367 octets
Return-Path: <NoKones@ix.netcom.com>
Received: from  by ix2.ix.netcom.com (8.6.9/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id VAA29643; Fri, 6 Jan 1995 21:00:00 -0800
Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 21:00:00 -0800
Message-Id: <199501070500.VAA29643@ix2.ix.netcom.com>
From: NoKones@ix.netcom.com (Kenneth A. Mitchell)
Subject: BFG Tires
To: mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Here is the latest on the BFG Tires.

			mike

Mike:

Yes They did discontinued the Autocross tires.

I'm sure you are aware that BFG has two competition tires, one for 
autocrossing (226's); and one for Road Racing (230's). The main 
difference between the two is that the 226's have a softer compound than 
the 230's, and the casing on the 230's is just a little stiffer than the 
226's. BFG thinks, and I have to agree with them, that the 230's are a 
very competitive tire. 

Dwight said he has a handling problem with the 230's because of the 
stiff casing and that the 911's are a little light in the front. 
Apparently, the car will intend to push a quite a bit because the tire 
won't bite enough with the stiff sidewalls. I have to agree with Dwight 
because I kinda remember when the Yokohama RTU's first came out the 
sidewall was extremely stiffed and they wouldn't work very well on my 
914. I think the Mid & Rear engine cars are going to have a problem the 
230's.

Later Mike!!

Ken Mitchell
nokones@ix.netcom.com




- ---- End Forwarded Message

- --
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Date: 07 Jan 95 14:27:07 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: European delivery

 
Kirk Shafer writes
>I'm not sure dealers like the game though. They likely make NO FAT profits
>via sales of this sort.
 
I think their profit it minimal, as they basically act only as order takers
for the factory, which of course makes its profit. But I understand that
cars sold on European delivery also don't count toward the dealer's
allocation, if any. (In recent years, using up your allocation wasn't a
problem for Porsche dealers :-)  )
 
This may be why the Boxster will allegedly not be offered for Euro delivery
at first -- they figure demand will be high, so they will be able to sell
all of the cars marked for USA and RestOfWorld at full dealer price or above
right in the showrooms, with no "slack" to be delivered right at the
factory.
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 7 Jan 1995 14:22:46 -0800
From: KimKnapp@ix.netcom.com (Maynard Knapp)
Subject: Re: '95 911 2wd vs. 4wd

You wrote: 

>
>There is no question about it. If you have an FIA Superlicense, go for
>the 2wd. If you have either testosterone or ego levels that lead you to
>think you COULD have an FIA Superlicense, go for the 2wd. All others 
are
>better off with the C4.
>
>FORZA!                  Smith, Walker And Associates, Melbourne, 
Florida
>

There is no question about it. If you have the extra bucks for the 4wd 
or you just have to buy "all the options", get the 4wd. All others are 
better off with the 2wd. You will never notice the difference.
	Amazing how easy it is to generalize on these things :-).
	Seriously, driving a 2wd in a ski resort all winter, the only 
things I am giving up over my 4wd sport-ute is using engine braking 
going down very steep, very slippery hills and not going around corners 
on slippery roads quite as fast because of understeer (which I suspect 
would be a problem with the 4wd, too, since it is mostly a factor of the 
light front end and the 4wd is not that much better weight 
distribution-wise). When snow is gone, of if you do not have snow, I can 
see no practical difference. Why add weight and cost when it is not 
needed (new models gain weight almost every year anyway, without 
optioning it on).

			Kim

Porschephiles #1056                         Mon Jan 9 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Sun, 8 Jan 1995 07:54:31 -0500
From: GaryWx@aol.com
Subject: '89 944 heater


My problem may seem strange to air cooled engine boys, but my 944 puts out
too much cabin heat! With the temperature control set almost off, the heater
still pumps out lots of hot air and keeps going until you need to open the
windows! When the car is cold it will pump heat even in the full off
position. I hear the sensor clicking on and off (behind the dash) so I know
it's cycling. This unit, which samples the air temp. was just replaced. It
seems as through the temperature control is out of calibration but I'm told
it's not adjustable.  By the way, the heated air is not blended and I'm
wondering if this is normal? The heat and a/c control panel has also been
replaced.  If there is a way to calibrate the temp. control or if the heated
air should be blended or if this is the way an automatic climate control
system works, your help will be appreciated. 

Thanks,
Gary

Date: Jan 08, 1995 05:07:01
From: Gene Wong 10-06-92 <gwong2@calstatela.edu>
Subject: G-50 in place of 915?

Hello fellow Porschephiles,
    I have a 1983 911 SC and just lost second gear the other day (the
transmission will not shift into second; it seems like something is blocking
my efforts to get it into that).  The other gears work perfectly though. I've
spoke to a few Porsche mechanics and friends who say that the synchro
probably went bad.  I was wondering whether anyone knows if it is possible
for me to replace the stock 915 transmission with the newer G-50 transmission
(since I was told that these were more reliable).  If not, how hard is it to
rebuild the 915 transmission?  I've rebuilt the Borg and Warner T-5
transmission twice on my Ford Mustang (which was pretty straightforward),
so I have some knowledge of rebuilding transmissions, but don't know
if the Porsche transmissions are as easy to rebuild.  Thanks in advance
for any input.                            Gene

Date: Sun, 8 Jan 1995 07:47:10 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: 930 Cams/Porting/Bars

I am rebuilding an '86 930. The engine has been twin-plugged with an
Electromotive Crank-Fire Ignition, and has a K-27 turbo and a very large
Andial Intercooler. Apparently the previous owner made all the external
mods he could afford. Now that we have the engine dissambled (he hit a
valve with a piston... the rest is history) what are the relative costs
and benefits of regrinding the stock cams and/or porting the 32 mm intakes
(to 36 mm?) We have a shop here who has "done" the porting, but it was
perhaps a shotgun approach.  Even I have to admit I've probably got enough
HP... but then again... The car has 285/40-15's on the rear that should
reduce the effective gearing by about 5% and be very quick. The rear 
sway bar was missing when we received the car. Any suggestions on an 
other than stock unit? Depending on the higher speed stability of the 
285's, I may go back to the stock tires/wheels. This car will be driven
daily, weather permitting, so I don't want to mess up the
streetability. (I have a 914/6 for autocrossing!) Comments appreciated! 

Dave Christiano, Springfield, Missouri
1974 914/6 3.0 liter
1976 911S (soon to be for sale)
1986 930 (soon to be on the road)

Your problem is most likely the AC control.  

No way to fix them.

New ones are around 600, used for around 200.

Borrow a friend's unit to check before you buy.

Good luck,

Date: Sun, 8 Jan 1995 11:33:12 -0500 (EST)
From: tpep@epix.net
Subject: Re: No. VA Porsche Mechanic



On Sat, 7 Jan 1995, Armagan Ozkaya wrote:

> Dear Porsche fellows,
> 
> 
> I have an 85.1/2 944 which I got about 2 months ago, with 
> 66K miles. The car has been fine so far. 
> I would like to get your feedbacks on two issues :
> 
> 1-) For those of you who live in DC area, I need your
>     recommendations for a competent, reasonably priced
>     mechanic, preferably in No. VA for timing belt 
>     replacement and general check-up. 
>     What is the typical cost of replacing the belt(s)?
> 
> 2-) As a minor complaint, when I first start the engine
>     (especially in cold wheather) and sometimes when
>     idling, the steering wheel shakes and rattles. What
>     do you think the problem is ? Is it common with
>     944s ? Could it be because of engine mounts ?
>     The idling RPM is around 850. After about 1100 RPM,
>     it gets much better.
> 
	944s like 924s and VWs have the same type of problem in the 
steering column.  After some time the bearing in the part of the column 
that also houses the ignition switch becomes worn and loose thus causing 
the steering wheel to vibrate whenever the car will.  Fortunatly its easy 
to fix.  All you need to do is remove the steering wheel, the ignition 
and wiper harnesses and the allen head bolt that holds the housing in 
place and it will slide off by hand.  If you lack the proper equipment 
for the job you might want to take it to someone with a press to do the 
bearing swap.  

	Hope this helps.
				TP.

Timothy Pepitone
'78 924
'82 Scirocco GL

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 8 Jan 1995 12:33:59 -0500
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Bob Spindel.....911 seats

Bob:

I successfully updated my '73T to '79 sport seats last year.  Really was a
simple changeover, and an opportunity to get rid of rusty 20 year old
fasteners.

Bought a set of adapters from Automotion- not particularly cheap, but well
made and very strong!  I think they were about $190, but they have somany
discount sales, you can easily save some bucks if you time it.

Refinished all existing rails, and replaced all fasteners with non-factory
grade 12 (I want the seats to stay put if I ever get clobbered).  If you're
careful, you can remove the seatbelt latches from the old living room sytle
seats, and position them properly on the new seats - this will work, but may
want to go ahead and update to newer belts and use the correct latches.

The whole thing works just fine, and it's such a pleasure to drive with seats
that firmly lock my wide posterior in place.  They may not be proper for a
concours car, but I already have one of those that never gets driven anymore.
 I get to enjoy this Porsche!

Good luck!

Pat Garvey

'72 914-4 Parade concours double winner (no fun anymore)
'73 911 T Daily driver in warm weather

Date: Sun, 08 Jan 95 11:45:06 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: Plug Wire Problem


     
You can buy new plug-ends and connect them up to your wires after removing the 
original plug-end (what you call the receptacle).  This is a common failure 
because the heat of the engine makes the plug-ends (and rubber boots) brittle 
and then sometimes they crack the next time you pull on them to change a spark 
plug.

Derek Au

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
     
I have an '82 911SC with a loose #2 left side (facing engine from rear) plug 
wire. The wire is loose at the plug...either the plug is stripped or the 
receptacle on the end of the wire has failed.  Anyone else ever experience 
this or know what is at fault here?

Date: Sun, 8 Jan 95 11:04:59 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Re: Renovating Leather Interiors....


On Thu, 5 Jan 1995, Mark Reynolds wrote:

>
> I am currently thinking of buying one of these 'renovation' kits where you send
> a sample of your leather and they send you back all sorts of dyes and stuff to
> apply to it.
>

Well, I am renovating the interior of my 83SC, and have determined that you can
do all the stripping and prep work yourself, but it is better to leave it to
the experts to do the final repairs/tinting. 

The leather in my car have been tinted after the driver seat bolsters have been
repaired quite a few years back. He tinted the all the leather inside the car,
including turning the back shelf into a tan color instead of the standard
black. When I got the car, the tint was all dry and flaking off. I took the 
back shelf to a good local leather specialist. She told me that they used a 
inapproriate laqueur based tint on the leather. She told me to strip all the
inside with laquer thinner. I took all the panels out of the car (doors, 1/4
panels, seats, rear seats...) and stripped them all. Quite a trip from the
fumes. After that, I took all the parts down to her, and she is presently 
finishing the detailing and starting the retinting. Should look like new, and
total cost ~450 CND ( $350 US).

No leather was bad enough to warrant replacement, it just looked ragged and rought
until I stripped it...it was quite nice to see baby-bottom soft leather appear 
from under all that rough sandpaper texture leather..

Mike
83 911SC

Date: Sun, 8 Jan 1995 15:40:50 -0600 (CST)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Loose plug wire

The ends (receptacles) are replaceable.  Also the rubber pieces are 
replaceable (Have their own part numbers). 

The connectors screw on.

Using a spare plug check to see if the connector grips the plug  end to your 
satisfaction.  If it does check to see if the small electrical "adaptor" 
is still attached to the plug on the affected cylinder.  If not, find it!

If the rubber end on the spark plug connector is damaged replace it.

If the plastic portion of the connector is damaged I would replace the 
connector after a resistance check is made to see if it is out of 
tolerance as well as damaged.  I have used connectors with chipped ends 
as long as they held the rubber insulaters.  Remember to check the 
resistance of the connector

David Duffield
'911 knowledge



------------------------------

Date: Sun, 8 Jan 95 13:47:43 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE: 914 starter

>From: michael@helix.nih.gov (Michael A. Freed)
>Message-Id: <9501081622.AA13398@helix.nih.gov>
>To: gary@superior.ucsf.edu
>Subject: 914 starter

>Gary, When I substituted a battery that I know was well-charged, and then
>tried to start the car, the battery voltage went down to about 7.5 volts.
>I could hear the starter cranking but then it died. I even checked that
>the engine was not hydrolocked by taking out the spark plug-starter worked a
>little better and then died. The resistance from the positive starter terminal
>to ground is about 35 ohms. Does your manual specify that this is correct?
>Thanks, Michael


The starter is a brush-style DC motor.  Turn the motor slowly while checking
the resistance, looking for an open or shorted winding.

35 ohms is a good resistance for a winding.  I'm guessing that you have
one shorted winding, which is making the motor heat up and die.

The motor can be rebuild (rewound), which is cheaper than replacing.  It's
not that different from a "bug" starter, so you should be able to find
a shop pretty easily.  (George gets $55.00 for a used starter.)

What I would do is go to a "you-pull-it" junk yard and snag one from
a VW type-IV (411 square-back, or newer bus).

Hope this helps,
gary@superior.ucsf.edu

Date: Sun, 8 Jan 95 17:59 EST
From: "Kevin C. Gross" <0004056890@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: '89 944 heater

Gary,

I would start by checking the operation of your heater valve.  It is
a valve run by a vacuum diaphragm, and its job is to open and close
the flow of coolant through the heater core.  On your car, it is
probably at the back of the engine, spliced into the hose which
runs between the heat pipe next to the block, and the heater core
nipple on the firewall.

On the sixteen valve cars, the valve is next to the oil filter,
spliced into the hose running between the front end of the heat
pipe and the water pump.  These valves are a common failure item.

With the engine running and at temp, have a friend move the temp
control knob from lock to lock (so to speak).  You should see the
lever arm of the heater valve move from open to shut.  If it does
not move, it may be a bad valve or it may be that it is not getting
the right vacuum "signal."

If you are getting blasted with hot air all the time, I would
suspect the valve before suspecting the mixer flap.  However, that
might be something to check next.  I would also make sure that
the cabin temp sensor (behind the grill in the dash) is hooked up
and working right.

Kevin


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 8 Jan 1995 23:01:18 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 928 won't start

On Fri, 6 Jan 1995, John Milton wrote:

> Subject: 928 won't start
> 

May well be the spark but unlikely, you can easy check the spark by 
getting a spare plug, unplugging a lead and attaching it to the spare 
plug, lay the plug on top of the engine, and turn the engine over a few 
times.

Could well be water in the tank, was it stored nearly full or nearly 
empty. 

If the tank was left part full, each time the car warms up, air is 
expelled via the breather, when it cools at night damp air is drawn into 
the tank where the water vapor condenses on the cold metal, running down 
to the bottom of the tank. Over several months it is possible to get 
several pints in the tank in this way.

Water being 1.25 times as heavy as gas always stays at the bottom, and 
does not get into the fuel lines until you start the car. After a few 
secs it gets drawn into the injectors and glug glug clonk.

The solution is clamber under the car with an old plastic bowl, loosen a 
fuel line from the pump (standard discaimer about smoking, eyes etc) and 
drain out a quart or so. decant it into a glass jar and then look to see 
if any water is present.


If you find any water, keep draing until you get no more water. You can 
pour most of the gas back into the tank.

Peter

| From   : Peter Diffey         |

Date: Sun, 8 Jan 1995 23:20:50 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: 914 starter

> 
> >Gary, When I substituted a battery that I know was well-charged, and then
> >tried to start the car, the battery voltage went down to about 7.5 volts.
> >I could hear the starter cranking but then it died. I even checked that
> >the engine was not hydrolocked by taking out the spark plug-starter worked a
> >little better and then died. The resistance from the positive starter terminal
> >to ground is about 35 ohms. Does your manual specify that this is correct?
> >Thanks, Michael
> 
> 
> The starter is a brush-style DC motor.  Turn the motor slowly while checking
> the resistance, looking for an open or shorted winding.
> 
> 35 ohms is a good resistance for a winding.  I'm guessing that you have
> one shorted winding, which is making the motor heat up and die.
> 
Are you sure about this 35 ohms, this would imply that the starter will 
only draw arout .3 amp - hey we don't need batteries any more

the 35 ohms is probably the resistance of the starter solenoid, although 
that seems low.

35 ohms across the starter itself is likely to mean that one or both 
brushes is worn so much that it no longer contacts the stator

Peter

recall around 3 weeks back I asked if any one out there had experienced 
944 farting after you leave the car, well as a result there has been some 
consersation on the subject.

Well when I raised the question I didn't have a problem, it was really 
just "as a mater of interest", well I seam to have stirred up the dreaded 
demons because it has now developed the full monty (UK expression - 
probably equates to something like the full cassius clays)

Taking the daughter to a riding lesson this afternoon, along a narrow 
winding road, criusing at 55 suddenly no power - tacho instantly reads 
zero volts, luckily I managed to swing into a pub car park, from where I 
called the commander, who agreed to bring our trusted ford to tow me 
home, she arrived, but not in the expected ford but in mans renault, 
strange I thought. She had broken down on the way - clutch cable snapped 
at a busy junction. So the man in the renault gives us a lift back to the 
ford ( it has had a history of breaking cables I had a spare in the troot)

I then repaired the ford and we went back to the 944 - complete with tow 
rope, of course you've guessed, it started first go, and showed no sign 
of the problem on the way home
 
Now the big question - will it get me to work tomorrow and what is wrong 
with it.

Techy bits now - it must have capacitive discharge ignition, where the 
devil is it, the haynes is useless.

Where does the CD set take it's timing pulse from?

Thanks for help in advance.

Peter
