Date: Sun, 8 Jan 1995 20:46:36 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Blinker Problem-the last chapter

Hi,

I'd like to thank all those who responded to my problem with my turn signal
switch. I still haven't solved my problem, but I  noticed something new while
working on the car today. When I turned off the ignition with the turn signal
stalk in EITHER the left or right position, the RIGHT side turn signals
(parking lights) light up  at an intensity 2-3 times brighter than when
blinking. Also, at the begining of the day I noticed that the rear left
signal would also light up, but later on only the right side would light up. 

I have checked just about everything that was suggested. All the ground
returns from the light housings are connected and the master cylinder switch
is working properly. I don't have a rear fog light but the wires that would
connect one are fine and isolated.  All the bulbs are fine. The only thing I
couldn't check was the turn signal switch in the steering column because I
don't have a big enough wrench to get the wheel off.

Can somebody tell me why the left parking lights don't come on, please. I
suspect it's the turn signal switch but if it is not, then it's off to the
mechanic for expensive diagnosis.

Thanks a lot,
Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

Porschephiles #1057                         Mon Jan 9 09:50:51 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 09 Jan 95 00:23:20 -0800
From: Cornelius_Verburg@mindlink.bc.ca (Cornelius Verburg)
Subject: 944, 928 cruise control

P-files:

I've been following the cruise control thread and am interested in knowing
a little more about how the cc system works. My '84 944 experiences the
same symptoms described by Jeff Holt in his original posting and I would
like to fix it. Then all of my car's gadgets will work :) (Except for the
right foglight, of course, which I still have to get around to - does
anyone have a spare?). Once the cruise is fixed, I may even use it once in
awhile - who knows, but for now it's just annoying that it doesn't work.

I bought my car about at a place about four hours away and while driving it
home tried out all the features including the cc. It seemed to have trouble
engaging, but when engaged, seemed to work fine. Shortly after arriving
home, I replaced clutch slave cylinder, water pump, rad, belts, and rebuilt
clutch master after which work the cruise more or less quit completely. I
say more or less because 1. It still accelerates (with usual delay, but
lets go very quickly) when I try to set the cc and 2. Once, during a
highway trip, the cruise worked for awhile (I tried to set it and got
nothing so forgot about it. A little while later, while going up a long
hill, the cruise all of sudden took over - could be that the cruise took
over when I my speed dropped to whatever the cc was actually set to (ala
Jim Harriger's 928 experience, which I will test tomorrow)).

The switches all appear to be working (including clutch and brake, which I
tested during my one opportunity in the mountains). Maybe there's a vacuum
leak which became worse while I was working on the repairs.

A few questions for someone in the know:

1. How does the cc work? I'm very familiar with servo systems, but I'd like
to know what the cruise system's comesinto's and goesoutta's are. How does
the cc system modulate the throttle? In my car, the actuator looks like a
rotary solenoid, but someone mentioned the vacuum system being involved. Is
the cc system documented in the service manuals or is it treated like a
black box? How about troubleshooting it? Is there a general reference on
cruise control? Did Porsche design its own cc system or buy it from someone
else?

2. What else does the car use vacuum for besides cc? (This probably tells
you I know nothing about engines and transmissions - you're pretty much
right, but I'm learning thanks to y'all). What are the symptoms of a vacuum
leak? What vacuum system tests are there? How does one find a vacuum leak?

Con

Included postings:
- ------------------------------

> or (most commonly) starts to engage (accellerator pedal moves), but
> as soon as I release the lever it disengages.

> may be a relay since I've had to replace the horn relay and the

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 95 00:29:10 -0800
From: Cornelius_Verburg@mindlink.bc.ca (Cornelius Verburg)
Subject: Rain and an '84 944

p-files:


On Jan 2, Joseph Malin asked about water in his 944. I asked pretty much
the same question when I first joined the list a few months ago and I kept
the responses in a file. I'll be trying to e-mail the entire file directly
to him.

I received quite a few suggestions and followed up on a few (original
posting attached):

Removed battery to look for rust:
Found absolutely no rust but what *may* have been a water entry point
around the stud that holds the battery clamp. Sealed it using two part
plumber's epoxy (may not have been the best choice, but I had it here so I
used it - plumbers apparently swear by it).

Removed sunroof and checked drain holes by pouring water through:
None were plugged since water came out bottom. I didn't measure the amount
of water that came out vs. the amount I put in, so I suppose some may have
gone astray, but I doubt it.

Then during the Christmas break it rained and rained and rained and my car
just sat there in the rain. (Nice to stay home for a few days, but I'd sure
like to have a garage for my car, foggy windows are a real drag.) I checked
periodically and found a slow accumulation of water on the floor at the
front of the doors. The carpet along the wall in front of the doors was
damp as well. I didn't drive, so the water was not coming in as a result of
driving. I suspect the following two possibilities: leaky door seals (the
passenger side, which leaked the worst had a small fold in its rubber
seal) or a leaky windshield. In my original posting, I noted that the water
accumulated behind the passenger seat. This could still have been a leak at
the front of the car since at the time the front of the car was raised on
jackstands for awhile and the water could have run to the back under the
plastic door sill cover. There's no water behind the seats this time
around, but I did find some there again a few months ago.

Since removing the windshield to re-seal it seems risky (is it?, I'd have
it done) and a new one expensive (how much?), my next step will be to try
and recondition the door seals a little more aggresively than with the
silicon spray I've used in the past. I'm thinking of using D&C's High
Vacuum Grease, which I've heard is supposed to have the right stuff in it
for rubber. Any other suggestions? How much are door seals, anyway?

One of the responses to my original posting spoke of door drains. Where are
they? I looked and only found a small hole at the bottom of the door and
don't see how it could leak into the interior.

Con

Joseph's posting:
- ------------------------------
>
> Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 14:02:03 -0500 (EST)
> From: jjm98@acs.org (Joseph Malin)
> Subject: Rain and an '84 944
>
> I recently purchased a 1984 944.  The car has been working really well
>  except for one problem.  Whenever I drive the car in the rain the floor
>  becomes wet.  The passenger side is is far worse then the driver side
> and the front is worse then the back.  I have assumed since the floor
> becomes wet only when the car is driven, that the water is being splashed
> up from underneath.  Upon investigating the underbody, I saw only one
> obvious opening... but it looked suspiciously like a drainage hole.
> The hole is behind the front wheel and a bit towards the middle of the
> car.  Has anyone out there had a similar problem?  I am inclined to try
> blocking the hole, but it looks like it was placed there on purpose...
>
>  Any ideas would be appreciated.
>
> Joe Malin
> (jjm98@acs.org)


My original posting:

> Mon Nov 14 17:08:14 1994

> It's rain time in Vancouver again, and again I've found water behind and
> beneath the passenger seat in my '84 944. Last winter, the car sat in the
> rain for a few weeks before I got it into a garage and the floor became
> totally soaked. I thought I'd fixed the problem by cleaning the seal
> around
> the passenger door, but shortly after cleaning, the rains stopped and I
> couldn't tell for sure. Now that the rains are back, it looks as if the
> problem is still there. I takes quite a bit of rain to make the carpet
> wet,
> so the leak must be quite small.
>
> Has anyone experienced this problem before (or have any bright ideas) ?
> If
> so, I'd appreciate hearing from you.
>

> and
> drains appear to be ok (I haven't tested the drain yet, it just looks
> ok).

> between the door and fram, but I'm not sure whether they got there before

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 95 8:57:29 EST
From: paul tacke <Paul.Tacke@lambada.oit.unc.edu>
Subject: '87 924S Hard Cold Start



Philers!

Over the past week or so with temperature dipping it the single digits, I've
noticed my '87 924S has been difficult to start.

When starting for the first time in the morning, it wont start unless I
slightly depress the gas pedal.  Once it does start it refuses to idle above
500rpm and usually stalls, unless I keep my foot on the pedal, In which case
it seems to be running rich (lots of exhaust smoke and sputtering as I
rev it).

This seems alot like an aux air regultor failure on CIS equipped cars, is
this my problem with the motronic system?

Thanks in Advance!

Paul Tacke
paul.tacke@lambada.oit.unc.edu
'87 924S

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 95 09:28:57 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Daytona IMSA Practice

Found this on rec.autos.sport.info this morning.

The Porsche WSC car looks competitive, if only for its history of endurance.

- ------------------------------------------------------------------
BUSY IMSA TEST OPENS '95 SPORTS CAR SEASON AT DAYTONA

A BUNCH of cars -- and a number of quick ones -- made the annual
International Motor Sports Association's open test session preparing for
the Feb. 4-5 Rolex 24 At Daytona an exceedingly interesting proposition
on Jan. 7-8 at Daytona International Speedway.

The Exxon World Sports Car track record unofficially took a beating
Sunday as four cars bettered the mark set by Spaniard Fermin Velez in
qualifying for the '94 Rolex 24.

As nearly 50 IMSA cars tested for the season opener, Scandia
Motorsports' two Ferrari 333 SPs set the pace. Velez drove the #3
Ferrari to the fastest lap of the session, 1:43.731, an average speed of
123.550 mph. Italian Formula One driver Michele Alboreto drove the team
car, #33, to a lap of 1:44.510, 122.629.

Also breaking Velez's lap record of 1:45.934, 120.981, was defending WSC
champion Wayne Taylor of Altamonte Springs in the #30 Ferrari, 1:44.767,
122.329; and James Weaver in the #16 Riley & Scott Mk. 3, 1:45.480, 121.502.

The test concludes Monday. A section of the Oldfield Grandstand will be
open, with access through the Visitors' Center.

                              NOTES

* No less than 14 World Sports Cars were on hand for the test. An
additional three entered that did not appear. Fast laps follow, with
(additional drivers) followed by a listing of cars/fast laps with
undocumented driver of record:
                               WSC
NO  DRIVER(S)                      ENG/CHAS       TIME      SPEED

 3  Fermin Velez (Evans, Baldi)    Ferrari 333SP  1:43.731  123.550
33  Michele Alboreto (Gentilozzi)  Ferrari 333SP  1:44.510  122.629
30  Wayne Taylor (Salazar, Theys)  Ferrari 333SP  1:44.767  122.329
16  James Weaver (Dysn/Sharp/Paul) Ford R&S Mk 3  1:45.480  121.502
35  Mario Andretti (Wollek/Gdyr)   Porsche WSC95  1:45.985  120.923
50  Sigala/Barbazza                Ferrari 333SP  1:47.630  119.075
63  Downing/Dickens/McAdam         MazdaKudzu DG3 1:50.454  116.030
 7  Brown/Bell/Wagner/Julian       Chevy Spice    1:51.737  114.698
 6  Sutherland/Gray                Olds Spice     1:52.698  113.720
 8  Mandeville/Camferdam           MazdaHawk MDR3 1:54.870  111.570
43  Payne/Williams                 Olds Denali    1:57.448  109.121
xx  TBA                            Ferrari 333SP  NT        NS
 7A Brown/Bell/Wagner/Julian       Buick Tiga     NT        NS
94  Kopf/Cunningham                FordChevronB71 NT        NS

                              GTS-1
90  Tommy Riggins (Delano/Petery)  Olds Cutlass   1:49.593  116.942
 5  Brassfield/Hoerr/Dismore       Olds Cutlass   1:53.597  112.820
72  Adam/Peters/Vargo              Porsche 911 T  1:55.004  111.440

                              GTS-2
55  Trejos/Quiros/Aase             Porsche 911RSR 1:59.450  107.292
22  Epps/Newman                    Porsche 911    2:00.532  106.329
 0  Quester/Halsmer/Donohue        BMW M-3        2:01.143  105.792

                              NOTES

* Scandia Motorsports, Pirelli and Ferrari collaborated on a press
conference on Saturday at which team owner Andy Evans announced a
three-year deal whereby Scandia would serve as "exclusive development
team" for Pirelli in IMSA. "With the technical expertise of Ferrari and
Pirelli, we believe Scandia Motorsports now has the potential to win a
championship in 1995," Evans said. He announced the season-long lineup
for one Ferrari 333 SP would be Mauro Baldi and a driver TBA. Michele
Alboreto and Stefan Johansson would partner Baldi at Daytona. The second
car will see Evans and Fermin Velez do the season, with defending Rolex
24 winner Paul Gentilozzi and Robbie Groff at Daytona.

* Tony Southgate, the designer of the 333 SP, spoke at the press
conference of it being "20-odd years since Ferrari had seriously
attempted to win a 24-hour race." At the time of the conference,
he spoke of two completely new cars and one other, Scandia's first
chassis, as being in the garage. Before the test was completed, two more
Ferrari's had joined them -- one '94-spec car that was driven on Sunday
by Massimo Sigala and Fabrizio Barbazza; and the other a '95-spec car
that was frantically being assembled in the paddock on Sunday evening.
"The #3 car has a 24- hour engine," said Southgate, "while the #33 and
the #30 have sprint engines running at low revs, because the engine
shop's trying to get the other engines done. This is not a completely
new car. On the '95 version the most obvious changes are in the bodywork
- -- a new nose for more downforce and less drag; and side panels with
a different oil cooling arrangement, because that was inadequate as
it was. The basic chassis is the same. The biggest difference is the
endurance engine and transmission package." In response to another
question, Southgate simply replied that Ferrari "officially is not going
to Le Mans..."

* Paul Gentilozzi said the Ferrari was obviously much different than the
sedans he was used to driving in both IMSA and the SCCA Trans-Am Series,
but that the car was "surprisingly comfortable and an excellent car to
drive. The engine is very smooth and it revs up quicker than anything
I've driven. I think we can drive it easily and still complete 750 laps,
which I think it will take to win." NOTES

* Michele Alboreto said he was "much more dark in the hair," the last
time he had been to Daytona for a race. "I was here in 1981, with the
Lancia Martini," said Alboreto. "Daytona is one of the most important
races in the world. It would be important to my career to win it."

* Andy Wallace reported that the new Auto Toy Store Chevrolet Spice was
frantically being completed in South Florida, therefore it was not at
the Daytona test. Wallace reported the team hoped to test the car for
the first time at Moroso Motorsports Park in West Palm Beach on Tuesday.
His Daytona teammate and another former Rolex 24 winner, Jan Lammers,
was also on foot at the test.

* Four-time Rolex 24 winner Bob Wollek was effusive in his praise of the
new Porsche World Sports Car, which he briefly tested at Charlotte Motor
Speedway before Christmas. "How can you expect better than to drive a
Porsche and get paid for it," said Wollek, who shared the car with Mario
Andretti and Scott Goodyear. "It's difficult to say how good this car
will be... It's brand-new and hasn't been tested a lot. We'll be able
to tell a lot more by Monday, because there's so little mileage on the
car, now. I've never seen a bad TWR car, or a bad Porsche. (With TWR and
Porsche) working together, I can't see it being a flop. There's too much
experience and know-how; and the ability to react if something's wrong
for it not to be a winner."

* Four-time IMSA GT champion Geoff Brabham arrived on Sunday and was
due to test the Porsche for the first time on Monday. He will share the
second car with Hans Stuck and 1985 Rolex 24 winner Thierry Boutsen.
"It was a bit of a surprise when Porsche called me," said Brabham, "but
it was an opportunity worth taking a chance with. It's nice to join an
effort where nothing's good enough but to win. I have driven a Porsche
before -- I drove a couple races in 1986-87 -- at Mount Fuji in Japan in
a 962."

* Chevron's new World Sports Car, the Ford-powered B71-94, arrived at
the Speedway late on Sunday. Engine builder Ted Wenz was splitting time
between the Chevron and Dyson Racing's Riley & Scott Mk. 3. According to
James Weaver, Dyson's car was "run-in" at Roebling Road Raceway, a club
and testing circuit outside of Savannah, Ga. "We wanted to take care of
all the new-car problems," said Weaver of the car's first runs. Designer
Bob Riley, Bill Riley and Mark Scott were all on hand at Daytona to see
a promising first outing at the "World Center of Racing" for drivers
Dyson, Weaver, Scott Sharp and John Paul Jr.

* Paul Jr. was pleased to report that he would be on hand for the
Rolex 24 -- a race he won in 1982. Team owner Kevin Doran said his
NASCAR SuperTruck program, for which Paul will drive the full season,
is slightly behind schedule, therefore Doran thought it more important
that Paul become committed to drive at Daytona. "I might put a Winston
Cup driver in the truck for Phoenix (Craftsman SuperTruck opener, on
the same weekend as the Rolex 24)," said Doran, who also added he was
seeking sponsorship for the Truck program.


- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ mhv.net
E-Mail: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 9:28:33 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Jacking the 911 up...


>I have just gone through the exercise of putting my 911 up on jack stands. What
>is the new wisdom for this. I have a floor jack, but don't currently own a jack
>pad (the gizmo that goes into the jack point in the rocker panel). I had to use
>a combination of the car jack, floor jack and adjustable 3 ton jack stands.
>So, who uses the jack pads, or is there another way? How about a 2x6 and the f
>jack in the approriate spots (wherever they are). According to the car manual, 
>there are only 4 spots appropriate for a floor jack, and I have too keep them
>clear for the stands. Where can I jack with the floor jack.

I have the jack pads.  they are ok as long as you make sure you push them
into the jack hole all the way.  otherwise you'll deform the jack hole
and poss the rocker too.  another problem is that since the pad doesn't
rotate it will not be flat on the floor jack as you jack up the car.
i've found that if you put your floor jack parallel to the car instead
of perpendicular it works better.  you'll want a 4" square bit of old
2x4 that's been soaked in some old oil to go between the pad and your
floor jack otherwise you'll probably run into the pad slipping off the
jack (ouch).  I'm planning on welding a couple of bumps onto the
bottom of my pads so they grip the wood block even better.  You could
also use the factory jack wound all the way down and stuck in the jack
port then put the floor jack under it.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 08:19:48 -0600
From: martinw@eapi.com

From martinw Mon Jan  9 09:13:39 1995
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
To: P911Pilot@aol.com, porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: Plug Wire Problem
X-Mailer: SCO Portfolio 2.0
Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 9:13:34 -0500 (EST)
Message-ID:  <9501090913.aa01128@eptax.eapi.com>


  >I have an '82 911SC with a loose #2 left side (facing engine from rear) plug
  >wire. The wire is loose at the plug...either the plug is stripped or the
  >receptacle on the end of the wire has failed.  Anyone else ever experience
  >this or know what is at fault here?

I have an 82 sc also.  the ignition cable plug on the end of the cigar
tube gizmo is designed to plug onto the end of the spark plug with the
little screw on doo-hicky on the top of the spark plug.  if that little
screw on bit unscrews a bit it will behave as though it's loose.

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 95 08:30:40 CST
From: dhartger@nas_jsc1.jsc.nasa.gov (Dan Hartgerink)
Subject: RE: why did I ask that stupid question 


Peter wrote ..........  

(stuff deleted)

>Well when I raised the question I didn't have a problem, it was really
>just "as a mater of interest", well I seam to have stirred up the dreaded
>demons because it has now developed the full monty (UK expression -
>probably equates to something like the full cassius clays)

>Taking the daughter to a riding lesson this afternoon, along a narrow
>winding road, criusing at 55 suddenly no power - tacho instantly reads
>zero volts,

(epic auto repair experiance deleted)

>I then repaired the ford and we went back to the 944 - complete with tow
>rope, of course you've guessed, it started first go, and showed no sign
>of the problem on the way home

>Now the big question - will it get me to work tomorrow and what is wrong
>with it.

(more stuff deleted)


Peter,

I had a similar series of experiances with my 944 about 2 years ago.
The car would run fine, but would suddenly stop dead with no warning
I was always able to restart the car, but sometimes it took about 
half an hour of waiting before it would start.  One time when it
stayed broken long enoug for me to trouble shoot the problem, I was
able to determine that the fuel pump was not running.  This eventually
led me to suspect the DME relay located in my fuse/relay box (I have
an '87 944).  

In short I eventually pulled the relay from its socket and then 
removed the plastic cover on the relay itself.  This revealed a small
printed circuit board with several solder connections on it.  On close 
(very close) examination I discoverd a failed solder joint on the 
largest solder pad on the PC board.  Apparently this solder joint
was making a good connection under certain circumstances (temperature 
etc.) but then opening for periods of time, thus shutting off the 
fuel pump and killing the engine.  

I took a soldering iron and re-soldered the joint (its best to 
remove the old solder first) put the cover back on the relay and 
stuck the relay back into the car and havent had a problem since.    

Good luck

Dan Hartgerink 



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 08:32:38 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Cruise Control Weirdness


I did not respond to this thread earlier because it seemed like a different
problem, but maybe not.

The cruise control in my '87 911 used to bleed off speed by about 0.5 mph/mile.
It seemed like a vacuum leak type of thing, but the CC is not a vacuum type of
system.  Unable to trace the problem to any obvious source, I eventually
replaced the CC brain.  Works great now.

I've heard about this same thing from a few other Carrera owners.  The CC
system may be the same in the 928.  In fact, the CC box has a 928.xxx. prefix
for the porsche part number stamped on it.

The CC brain is VDO manufactured electronics package.  A new one lists for
$600.  I called around bone yards and found a salvage from Parts Heaven for
$125.  I wanted to repair the one I have, (I suspect a bad transistor or
something) but I cannot get an electrical schematic.  I also cannot find
anyone who will repair VDO electronics.

If anyone knows how to debug these things, let me know.  As mentioned, I think
the problem is a simple failed transistor or thermister.  I've heard enough of
this same problem that if we can publish a "solder a replacement X-component
on the board" fix.  We may save a number of people lots of $$$.

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 95 08:30:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.ncr.com>
Subject: RE: More Welding: Metal Fabricators Handbook



Subject: More Welding: Metal Fabricators Handbook
 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------  
 --

     Continuing the thread on welding... Usually when there is a desire to
     weld, there is also an accompanying desire to fabricate patch panels,
     brackets etc. for rust repair.  Welding takes you half the way there.
     There are two excellent books on metal fabrication called "Sheet Metal
     Fabricator's Handbook" and "Metal Fabricator's Handbook" by the same
     author.  There are other sources for this book but I know that it is
     sold by Eastwood through their catalog.  The sheet metal book is the
     one to get.  I have both and they are good reading for the apprentice
     welder.

     Derek Au

==  One of those books is written by the same guys that did the
== 'Welder's Handbook'  Richard Finch and Tom Monroe.
==  The other book is written by a fellow named Ron Fournier.
==  These are good books, and they do give a little more depth
== in fabrication.  I have seen 'em at bookstar . . . ~$15
==
==  I have them. . . they wont fix your car.  Sorta vague for what you and I
== would want to see in them (rustoration).   Some fabrication
== technique is already in the 'Welders Handbook'.
== Good food for thought.
==  -kyle

------------------------------

Date: 9 Jan 1995 09:52:38 U
From: "Piescik, Walter" <wpiescik@mailcenter.tsmi.iitri.com>
Subject: Welding Class

Kyle,

Good description of the sizzle, frying eggs (or bacon) is the correct sound.

>From my original text:  Welding puts holes in your body. 

>From your response:
==  To Walter; blowing holes in panels is poor technique and lack of
== practice.  Wooh! Easy now. . . that was meant as constructive criticism.
==  Ok, not flame.   Have you tried the copper spoon behind the panel
== to aid in those cases when overheating is difficult to control?  it 
works.

I might have been more precise, Welding puts holes in your *person*.

I am intrigued by the gold deposited shield. I use a number 10 shield, and I
am going to a number 12.  I will try to find a gold deposited type an may
look to you for help in finding one, thank you for the offer. I readily admit
that it would be noce to see the work before striking the ark.

Put my floors in this weekend! I'm guessing about 360 spot (button hole)
welds

Kind Regards
Walter

the tail and an oil cooler radiator in the RF fender.  What's
this 3rd one at the front go to ?  (This was the stupid question.)

down but the two times I've seen it get it's hottest it got
that way _from_ idling.  Is this normal ?

course).  The stereo is now inoperative until I can enter the security 
code (which I do not have).  I contacted the dealer and they have not

there had similar experiences and any ideas on how to get this code?

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1058                         Mon Jan 9 16:53:06 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 10:17:02 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911: What is that 3rd radiator

> Q. When prepping the my '86 911 for storage I discovered
> a long radiator under the front of the car with a blower [next to
> the battery] that sucks air from behind/under the bumper and 
> blows it down through this radiator.  I have a an A/C radiator in
> the tail and an oil cooler radiator in the RF fender.  What's
> this 3rd one at the front go to ?  (This was the stupid question.)

More A/C condensor. It's part of the "get it right" package that Porsche
added to "fix" the A/C in '86 (one of the reasons it's my year of
choice for "best late 911"...)

> Q. I've alway heard about idling the car to get the temps
> down but the two times I've seen it get it's hottest it got
> that way _from_ idling.  Is this normal ?

Given that you have no airflow at idle, I think so. You get better
cool-down results driving at low speeds in *NON* stop-and-go traffic.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 1995 08:27:55 -0800 (PST)
From: YASEKR@YMV5.YMP.GOV
Subject: Oil leaks in 911

Hey P-filers,

This is hardly a new subject but my experience of the last few 
days might provide fodder for thought for someone in like
circumstances.

The initial oil leak problem was largely solved when I replaced
my '73 2.4L engine with an '83 3.0L 1 1/2 years ago. The past few 
months, however, have been somewhat frustrating due to a leak 
that I could not pinpoint. When I was at my local shop for clutch
clevis repair (nonscheduled <g>), the mechanic rounded up the usual 
suspects but all had ironclad alibis. Last week, having made some
free time, I finally tracked down the little drip. It was the oil
tank: specifically, the assembly that the oil filter screws in to.
The O-ring had shrunk and gotten brittle, and after only 22 years,
Sheesh. Well after receiving ribbing about being a space shuttle
commander, I replaced said part and the Challenger is flying again.
So, if you are looking for an oil leak, check everything, because
finding them is like an Easter egg hunt: you never know where
you're gonna find them. And that's all I have to say about that.

Regards,

Rob Yasek
'73 911T
'91 Bixby Noodlehead

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 10:21:23 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: G-50 in place of 915?

> I was wondering whether anyone knows if it is possible
> for me to replace the stock 915 transmission with the newer G-50 transmission
> (since I was told that these were more reliable).  

Not without a HUGE amount of fabrication. It's a different length, has 
different mounting points, and uses a hydraulic clutch, for starters.
Fix your 915 instead.

> If not, how hard is it to
> rebuild the 915 transmission?  

It's not that hard, but you *MUST* have the special tools. All the
tools cost about as much as a rebuild, so you can either buy the tools and
have them for next time, or pay someone to do the work. YOu won't save
money on this ....

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 1995 08:35:27 -0700
From: bart@research.att.com (Bart N. Locanthi)
Subject: re: 944 sudden stall

here's another possible reason for a 944 to suddenly quit with
no warning, again involving the fuel pump.

there's a connector atop the transaxle through which power to
the fuel pump flows.  the one on mine decided to have an identity
crisis ("to connect, or not to connect...?") in, ahhh, rock springs,
wyoming, on easter sunday four years ago.

stopped cold with no warning, wouldn't start up unless it sat for
a few minutes, ran for a few miles, stopped again.  did this until
the duty cycle for "off" was such that 1 mile was a difficult
journey.  then towed to the nearest porsche dealer, in ... salt
lake!!

 -bart

Dan,
	I am not sure of the brand, but they come in a yellow and black box
and are the plastic teeth kind.  They will do the least amount of
damage if they let go.  One set fits my wife's Mitsu Galant (185SR15)
FWD, one set fits my Datsun pickup (they originally were for my 
'69 FBird, not even sure of the tire size) and I am not sure of the last
set and what car they used to go to.
	I like them, they are easy to put on and, best of all, they are light
weight.

Tom

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 13:38:34 -0500 (EST)
From: Ujjal Bansel <ujj@server.chem.ufl.edu>
Subject: Re: Rain and an '84 944



On Mon, 9 Jan 1995, Cornelius Verburg wrote:

> p-files:
> 
> 
> On Jan 2, Joseph Malin asked about water in his 944. I asked pretty much
> the same question when I first joined the list a few months ago and I kept
> the responses in a file. I'll be trying to e-mail the entire file directly
> to him.
> 
> I received quite a few suggestions and followed up on a few (original
> posting attached):
> 
> Removed battery to look for rust:
> Found absolutely no rust but what *may* have been a water entry point
> around the stud that holds the battery clamp. Sealed it using two part
> plumber's epoxy (may not have been the best choice, but I had it here so I
> used it - plumbers apparently swear by it).
> 

Hello,
It is possible for water to get into the passenger side of a 944 if there 
is a hole underneath the battery. I have had this problem when I ran some 
wires from the battery to an amplifier in the back. Actually, it was my 
brother's idea (he is a grad student in physics). We drilled a hole in 
the battery compartment to run the wires down to somewhere behind the 
glovebox. We tried to patch around the wire and hole with a sealant but 
that didn't work. Water still got in and ran down the wire flooding the 
passenger side of the car. I would imagine that if there was any rust in 
the battery compartment or any kind of corrosion around the battery clamp 
studs, water will find a way to get inside the car. 

I tried to fix the problem applying bondo in the battery compartment and 
around the wire. It seems to have done the job, but once in a while during
a heavy rain storm, I see some water on the floor. It probably needs another 
coat. I hope this helps.

Ujjal Bansel
ujj@chem.ufl.edu

'85 944

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 95 13:53:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: G-50 in place of 915?


I agree with Stan.  I'd also say that the 915 is perfectly adequate for your 
car,
and you should not have reliability or longevity problems with it.

Bruce A. answers this question probably once a week, and I have long since
stopped reading his answers!  I think the jist of it, though, is that the 
conversion
is a boatload of work.  I think that Patrick offers a G50 conversion set-up, 
not
sure of its particulars but they advertise.

Nice things about the 915 are that different gearings are readily available, 
which
is not the case today for the G50's.  You will also find that Porsche 
mechanics
have rebuilt a lot of them, are familiar with the process, and have the 
spares
on hand.  All not true of the G50's, which are "too new," if that makes any
sense!

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 12:55:11 -0800 (PST)
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Car color confusion

>Date: Thu, 5 Jan 1995 12:38:50 -0500
>From: NeilK356@aol.com
>Subject: Car color confusion

>I bought a '73 911S targa in August  and since I bought it I  wanted to know
>what the original name paint color was. So I requested a certificate of
>Authenticity from Porsche in November and got it yesterday in the mail. I
>always assumed that the paint was a light yellow or beige color. When I
>looked at the certificate it listed the color and code as Rose Red 4610. This
>obviously doesn't match my car. The code also doesn't correspond to the
>Kunstharzlack plate in my car which has 132-9-1 written on it. The car has
>been repainted, but the door jambs and trunk are the same color as the rest
>of the body.

>So my question is- What does Rose red look like and what does 132-9-1 mean. 

Peter Albrecht responded accurately with:

>>Date: 06 Jan 95 12:56:26 EST
 
>>The book does list a paint code (paint code and color code are different).
>>The paint code 132 on the plate in your car indicates ivory. That at least
>>matches what your car has on it/in it now. I don't know what the -9-1 mean.
 
>>Color name    color code    paint code   paint manufacturer
>>Ivory          4646          132         Lesonal (Sikkens)
 
It was a yet another rain filled weekend in Northern California,
so it was a good opportunity to look thru the factory shop manuals.

  132 = Ivory 
    9 = Paint applied at Porsche factory
    1 = Paint manufacturer = Lesonal (2 = Glasurit)

>Lastly, it says "Fog Lamp,White, Over Bumper".  I took the non-original fog
>lights off my car. What did the old one look like? Where they like the chrome
>ones but painted white?

Here's a possibilty for these lights.

Some early 911's had round driving (fog?) lights that mounted to the small
grills to the left and right of the front hood edge.  So they were above 
the bumper and inbound the headlamps.  

"White" could refer to the lens, with "Yellow" being another choice.  

The unique grills may still be in place. 

IMHO, these lights looked "tacked on" and a previous owner may have
replaced them for aesthetic reasons. 

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 95 16:45 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Ultimate Car COLOUR

	Some options are a Cherry/Plum type metallic burgundy,
	dark red or an actual pearl off-white. I have been told 
	that Mercedes paint is of better quality/durability than Porsche.

Speaking of paint quality, does anyone use Imron anymore?  Or is there another
aircraft-quality paint that's a little easier to work with?

Tracy Nelson (tnelson@telesciences.com)
'87 944S

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 95 16:51:00 PST

I am the orginal owner of an 88 944S with 120k miles. Bodywork has been done 
in Mt Kisco at Simone Bros with excellent results. Formula Motorsports 
replaced the clutch a few years back but has never done any bodywork.  When 
I had work done at Formula, Mark only accepted cash for work and decided not 
to inform be of this until 3pm the day I was picking up the car. If you 
decide to use him, I'd check on his payment methods first.  Also, having the 
clutch replaced two other times (once before Formula and once after) I was 
not as pleased with Formulas work. I have heard other good things about 
Marks shop but unfortunately my experience wasn't.

casued a potential law suit so if you want to know more of my personal

Hi All,

        Seeing as how people are on the topic of 914 heater etc...

        With the onset of the rain and winter here, I have been noticing
the horible inefectiveness of my 914s' defroster/defoger. I have only
owned this car for a little over 7 months. But have already dropped the
engine a number of times to do extensive replacement of old/broken parts.
So my question is: Do the 914s simply have a really inefective system? Or
is there possibly something wrong? The heater by itself works great. But
the window keeps fogging up. It's really bad in the rain...

==  I've had my '73 914 since late '74.  When it was younger, it had amazing
== amounts of heat, even when sitting.  Granted things had to be fully warm.
==  Since then, the steel exchangers rusted out at 50k and were replaced 
with
== SSI.  The heat is still there, but the seals in the doors and top were 
poor and
== so less heat.  If you are getting lot of steam off the warm air during 
rain, you
== may be missing those little air deflectors under the body at the rear 
firewall.
==  There is also the possibility that the rain drains in the engine 
compartment
== are not ducting right, causing water to pass over the exchangers.
==    Another possible is that your silencers (inside the rockers) are 
soaked.
==  -kyle

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 17:32:56 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Jacking up Porsche

  >What is the best way to raise the front end and then support?  Where is the
  >best place to place jack stands?  I want to work on front brakes.  
  >Next, how should the rear be raised?  And than supported with jack stands to
  >work on rear brakes?  I have one hydro floor jack, two jack stands and lots
  >of wood.

Well I've never jacked up the car end-at-a-time, only side-at-a-time.  If
you use the jacking port the front wheel comes off the floor then, a 
short time later, the rear wheel.  I use jack stands on the rear with
a block of oiled wood in the triangular web under and slightly to the
read of where the torsion bar pokes out.  I've heard of putting the
stands on the bar itself but it isn't designed to bend that way and
I don't like it.  I've also used a block of wood under the rocker/jack
port (only on the left side, oil and a/c on the right) to jack the car.

as far as jack stands under the front of the car, I know I found a good
place on the suspension, but I can't visualize it right now.  When I've
wanted just one end up in the air my technique has been to jack up one
side with the jack at the jacking port and put a stand under the end
I want up.  Then I go to the other side and jack at the jacking port.
The weight transfer will settle the end you don't want up as the
second side comes off the ground.  then put a stand under this side too.
to get an end really high, like dropping an engine, you'll need to do
it in 2 or 3 stages.

- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

> great "dragster". Since this will be my fist real sports car, I
> wanted something to play with during my stoplight to stoplight hops.

> (Z28's,Trans Ams, Vettes?) a run for their money. Oh well, I guess
> I'll just hope for a spiritual revelation..

Then Mike Piera wrote:

>In SCCA pro-solo autocross competition you can observe 911s against Vettes
>and other fast cars. Pro-solo uses a drag-race start with timed starting
>lights, and a straightaway.  With a decent driver, almost any 911 will BLOW
>AWAY an american V-8 off the line, and for some distance, even if the 911
>has less power. The 911 can use full throttle at launch, while a strong
>V-8 will have to start at about 1500 RPM and feather the throttle for
>some time, otherwise spinning the tires and going even slower. The
>Mitsu AWD turbo would not have this problem, but has turbo lag and
>the weight of a cadillac to contend with. The water cooled Porsches are
>not great dragsters for the same reasons as above.

>So, a 911 is actually quite a good dragster. Ask Scott Jessen if any car
>has pulled him on the start of a pro-solo (other than a modified car).
>And once you get ahead, it's very hard to catch up, and the other guy
>will probably back off in a stoplight race anyway.

What Mike has said is completely true.  Before upgrading the motor to a 3.2,
(and despite what has been said about the juvenile-ness of street racing).
 I on occasion would surprise some 5.0 Mustang drivers for a few stoplights.
 The 2.4E was a quick setup and I had no problem dusting the Mustangs.  At
the Pro Solos, you are hard pressed to find a harder launching car than the
911s.  With the 3.2 in the early 911 it's a Camero/Vette/GT3000 owner's
nightmare -- a 911 that can turn a sub-13 second quarter miles??]  Yow]

As far as maintenance and value considerations, Some of the 'philer's
experience is contrary to mine and my 5 previous 911s.  The most expensive
non-wear (brakes/tires/clutch, etc.) related maintenance item was a $300
alternator in our Carrera.  I've had no problems depending on them for
day-to-day use and have come out far better cost wise that ANY of the 20
someodd other vehicles I've owned....  Of course YMMV...

 -Scott Jessen

Date: Mon,  9 Jan 95 17:58:17 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944, 928 cruise control

Answers below:

- ----------
> From: Cornelius Verburg  <Cornelius_Verburg@mindlink.bc.ca>
> Subject: 944, 928 cruise control
> Date: Monday, January 9, 1995 12:23AM
>
> I've been following the cruise control thread and am interested in knowing
> a little more about how the cc system works.
[...]
> A few questions for someone in the know:
>
> 1. How does the cc work? I'm very familiar with servo systems, but I'd like
> to know what the cruise system's comesinto's and goesoutta's are. How does
> the cc system modulate the throttle? In my car, the actuator looks like a
> rotary solenoid, but someone mentioned the vacuum system being involved. Is
> the cc system documented in the service manuals or is it treated like a
> black box? How about troubleshooting it? Is there a general reference on
> cruise control? Did Porsche design its own cc system or buy it from someone
> else?
The actual cruise control actuator varies on each model.   944's are 
electric motors; others on pfiles report that 928's have vacuum servos. 
 Dunno about 911's.  In any event, a weak vacuum servo wouldn't matter 
much, because a cruise control is a closed-loop system, not just a 
throttle.  That is, as the car's load changes (hills, etc.) the speed 
should remain constant, because the cc logic monitors vehicle speed and 
actuates the servo accordingly.  So long as there was enough vacuum to 
operate the actuator to the level needed, you'd have a good cruise 
control system.

Defective electronics would cause nearly every symptom I've read about 
in this thread recently.

Electric systems (944's) are different than vacuum systems.  The 
electric actuating motor doesn't need vacuum, so it either does what 
it's told or it doesn't - no weak in-between states.  It can jam in a 
particular position or refuse to operate entirely, but it won't go part 
way and wimp out.

Both systems above actuate the throttle via direct mechanical linkage.  
Electronic throttle (so called "fly by wire") cars use an entirely 
different system with no external acutator.

If your car doesn't _hold_ speed or set speed almost perfectly, then 
the control electronics are likely the fault.  Complete failure, or 
erratic operation can be either the control or the actuator or related wiring.

The cruise control unit in my 951 is made by VDO.

> 2. What else does the car use vacuum for besides cc?
>  What are the symptoms of a vacuum
> leak? What vacuum system tests are there? How does one find a vacuum leak?
Brake boost, HVAC flaps, emissions controls are primary uses.  There 
may be more.
Symptoms are variable depending on which subsystem is affected.  There 
might be no observable symptom, or the car could stall and refuse to restart.

		JBS

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1059                         Tue Jan 10 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Mon,  9 Jan 95 17:58:22 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: European delivery

I've done this twice, but not for 8 years so there may've been changes. 
 That said, my dealer informed me that they make less profit on Euro 
delivery but they also do less work and don't carry the finance charges 
or the risk of you not accepting the car from them.  They're more of a 
broker in this kind of deal.

So the risks and financial outlays are lower for the dealer, thus the 
lower profit.  Others on the e-list have already chimed in with other reasons.

		JBS

Date: 09 Jan 95 18:22:19 EST
From: "Byron D. Short" <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 S2 Questions

Ok, I picked up my new (used) '90 944 S2 this weekend, and now am setting out to
prepare it for SCCA Solo competition.  I have several questions that only
brilliant people like the Porschephilers could know:  <G>
 
1.  The car is an M030, Sports Chassis.  I've been told this is extremely rare,
but I also have found a few more in the hands of my competitors.  How rare is an
M030 S2?  Is there any way to document how many were built with this package?

2.  Since it's the M030, it has 9" rears and 7.5" fronts.  Unfortunately, the
workshop manual doesn't list the 7.5" rim at all, and never says which cars came
with the 9" rims.  In SCCA people can and do get thrown out for not having a car
which matches the workshop manual or other factory documentation.  Where can I
get something more complete on the contents of the M030 package?  Does Porsche
offer any way to get component breakdowns of packages such as this? 

3.  Exhaust.  In SCCA Solo Stock we can remove and replace the exhaust from the
catalytic converter back.  I've done this on my turbo to help eliminate some
turbo lag and lose some weight (no muffler--just a 3" straight pipe), but on the
S2 I'm afraid it would be so loud as to be obnoxious to drive AND very likely
decrease available torque.  Since we are a low speed kind of event where torque
is everything, I doubt that I should consider an exhaust change.  However,
changing the air filter to a K&N should yield both hp & torque, so it's on the
list.  Opinions?

4.  Ride height.  As an M030, the front spring perches have about 1.5" of
lowering capability.  My first instinct is to use every bit of it and to lower
the rear to match.  It appears from the geometry that this will not effect front
caster and camber, but that the rear will get more negative camber.  Should I go
as low as it'll go in the front as I've planned?  Are there any performance
detriments to this (other than the difficulty in getting the car on and off the
trailer <g>)?  What kind of alignment should I aim for?  I'm assuming max front
caster and only around 1 degree negative camber all around.  The tires will be
(of course) BFG R1 230's, probably 245's all the way around, but I may
experiment with 225's in the front.

5.  What else would you put on your "to do" list?  Other than the cam belts are
there any major checks to make before I start pullin' some g's?

Thank you, thank you, thank you.

Byron Short

90 944 S2 M030 -- autocrosser & trailer dweller.
87 944 Turbo -- just barely pretty enough to be a daily driver.

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 95 15:33:17 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: Owners of Chains in San Francisco Area


Hi all,

I'd be careful about remarks on owning chains in the San Francisco area.

Why, just last week I saw a Mustang 5.0 with a bumper sticker that declared:
 "Sticks and Stones may break my bones, but whips and chains excite me!"
The fellow (I think it was a guy) had many earrings in BOTH ears, didn't 
look like a pirate and his leather was heavy with many studs. Shaved head 
too.

Seriously, if you have ANY Porsche with big meat rubber and wheels to match, 
buy a second set that allow for a normal size chain or legal traction 
device to fit under the fender WITHOUT contact at full suspension bottom.
This may mean 7" wheels and 215 tires on the back of a 944 to do this. My
914/6 would only take 5" x 15" wheels with 175/70 snow tires with chains.

When you use chains, make sure the damn things are TIGHT and SECURE. Observe
the 25 MPH speed limit when using them. When possible, borrow someone 
else's 4-wheel drive for these trips. Or rent one. Saves on the paint, also.

Jim Pasha

Date: 09 Jan 95 15:57:41 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>

From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE

While I'm not in the habit of going against Her Listmeister...

>> Q. When prepping the my '86 911 for storage I discovered
>> a long radiator under the front of the car with a blower [next to
>> the battery] that sucks air from behind/under the bumper and
>> blows it down through this radiator.  I have a an A/C radiator in
>> the tail and an oil cooler radiator in the RF fender.  What's
>> this 3rd one at the front go to ?  (This was the stupid question.)

>More A/C condensor. It's part of the "get it right" package that Porsche
>added to "fix" the A/C in '86 (one of the reasons it's my year of
>choice for "best late 911"...)

Our '84 had this and I'm pretty sure my '79 did too.  The earliest example
of this front condenser that I've personally seen is on Haas Fogel's '72
911E with "true" factory air (my '72 had the dealer installed unit that used
a cute little condenser/fan unit tucked in the lft. rear quarter.)

>> Q. I've alway heard about idling the car to get the temps
>> down but the two times I've seen it get it's hottest it got
>> that way _from_ idling.  Is this normal ?

>Given that you have no airflow at idle, I think so. You get better
>cool-down results driving at low speeds in *NON* stop-and-go traffic.

Yep.  I think some folks confuse this "standing idle" with the smart
practice that Turbo owners should use.  I have seen the temp in our 911 drop
at an idle, but it's only after successive back to back AX runs and the temp
was going from WAY TOO G__ DAMN HOT to just WAY TOO HOT...

 -Scott Jessen



------------------------------

Date: 09 Jan 95 16:04:38 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: No more BFG Autox tires


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: No more BFG Autox tires
Date: 1995-01-09 17:56
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 BARNEY BETTILYON wrote:

>When I called Team T/A today to place my semi annual order, I was informed
>that they were NOT going to produce the autocross compound (226-xxx) tires
>anymore. They have a few sizes left in stock, but that's it. Are the
>Yokohama 008RsII that much better?

>Anyone know what is going on????

The BFG R1 in the road race compound (230) is a great tire.  I am also
disappointed they chose to do away with the 226 (autocross only) compound,
but BOTH are faster than the Yoko RSII.  I've run all three, and IMHO the
average AX driver will consistently put in faster runs on the BFGs.  This, I
believe is because the BFG is a far more forgiving tire at the limit than
the RSII is -- you make a little mistake, you don't hose an otherwise good
run -- you have to drive a damn near perfect run to equal an average run on
the BFGs (just buy any of the Yoko sponsored national Solo II competitor a
beer sometime and ask 'em).  The hot rumor running around the BFG
competitors these days is a THIRD compound will be the eventual replacement
of both the 226 and the 230 BFG R1.  This compound will wear and handle heat
(read: high speeds) like the 230 does, but start working at a lower
temperature and be "close" to the cold performance of the (sob) now defunct
226.  As a final word: as a company BFG (Michelin) has impressed me far more
than Yokohama ever did (or tried to do) by having such an active group (Team
T/A) aimed at the grass roots competitors -- answering phone questions,
e-mail questions, attending events and providing deeper contingency $$s....

 -Scott Jessen



------------------------------

Date:         Mon, 09 Jan 95 17:55:34 CST
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      RE: why did I ask that stupid question

On Mon, 9 Jan 95 08:30:40 CST Dan said:
>
>
>Peter,
>
>I had a similar series of experiances with my 944 about 2 years ago.
>The car would run fine, but would suddenly stop dead with no warning
>I was always able to restart the car, but sometimes it took about
>half an hour of waiting before it would start.  One time when it
>stayed broken long enoug for me to trouble shoot the problem, I was
>able to determine that the fuel pump was not running.  This eventually
>led me to suspect the DME relay located in my fuse/relay box (I have
>an '87 944).
>
>In short I eventually pulled the relay from its socket and then
>removed the plastic cover on the relay itself.  This revealed a small
>printed circuit board with several solder connections on it.  On close
>(very close) examination I discoverd a failed solder joint on the
>largest solder pad on the PC board.  Apparently this solder joint
>was making a good connection under certain circumstances (temperature
>etc.) but then opening for periods of time, thus shutting off the
>fuel pump and killing the engine.
>
>I took a soldering iron and re-soldered the joint (its best to
>remove the old solder first) put the cover back on the relay and
>stuck the relay back into the car and havent had a problem since.
>
>Good luck
>
>Dan Hartgerink
>
>

Same thing happened to me on my '87 944S. I took the easy way
out and replaced the relay @ $44.  You can check your fuel pump
by removing the relay and bridging terminals 30 and 87b with
a short piece of wire with male spade connectors on both ends.
This will make your fuel pump run as long as your battery is
connected. You should here fuel going through the fuel rail.

Darren
'87 944S
darren@ua1vm.ua.edu

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 95 16:24:00 PST
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: snowchains - what to buy


Dan,

The best chains I've used (I've trashed many!) are made by Konig.  The offer 
low profile versions to help with the little clearance problem.

They aren't cheap, but they are very well designed, perform well, and last. 
 I'd order a second set of rubber tensioners (the ususal campbells won't cut 
it) at the same time and store them in a zip lock.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 95 19:50:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: Ultimate Car COLOUR


>Speaking of paint quality, does anyone use Imron anymore?  Or is there 
another
>aircraft-quality paint that's a little easier to work with?

My understanding has been that Imron is available in only a handful of
colours, limiting its usefulness.  I have heard other paints described as
being like Imron in terms of durability.

K.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 09 Jan 95 17:13:00 PST
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Re: Ultimate Car COLOUR


I still use Imron for things that I don't have powder-coated.  It's great 
for engine blocks, small pieces that I need done but don't have enough for 
the minimum charge at the powder-coater.  There's a flattening agent 
available that you can mix in so you can get the original semi-flat finish 
for blacks.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

73 911T Targa Oxidized Blue

moons ago.  They came loose a couple of times - wouldn't
want that to happen to my P-car!  Ouch!!!   :-)

But they were incredible.....

front
>panel, I think it has holes. The floor board is solid, car has been

>It has the Carrera-tensioner, Motor was rebuilt 60K miles ago by a 
>professional. When I asked him about Divilar studs and pop-off valve, 
he

please
>enlight me. He also said that the synchro was worked on 8 years ago.

>$4200. Reason for selling too small for family.

Older 911's do not have cis injecion so won't have the pop off valve, 
also should be a 2.2 or 2.4 eng no need for the studs either.

What you will have is lots of rust everywhere. Be real careful with this 
car. 10 years in the rust belt is enough to do it in.

As with buying any Porsche ALWAYS HAVE IT CKED OUT BY AN INDEPENDENT 
PORSCHE MECHANIC. If you are not a member of PCA find someone who is as 
someone usually knows about most of the Porsches in a give area.

Try  to get the receipts for all the work he said has been done on the 
car. Also ck out the mechanic with the pca group.

							mike

Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 23:41:18 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Bead Blasting

> Im rebuilding the engine in my 912.  Is it ok
> to bead blast the case and the cover?

No. You can bead blast pistons, con rods, heads -- things that
don't have oil passages that can get plugged up and not cleaned
out. You gotta clean the case the hard way. I use about 4 hours of
hard scrubbing in new Varsol, follow with about a case of spray
carb cleaner with more scrubbing. Final rinse in carb cleaner, spray
dry with "dried" compressed air.

Then again, I'm *REAL* picky about this sort of thing.

> Also I would like to Replace the stock cam
> with a step up cam anyone have any info
> where I can get one?  

You need Duanne Spencer's book "The 356 Performance Handbook". There *ARE*
still performance cams being made (none up to the late lamented Stoddard
Performance Cab), and this book points out the makers and pros and cons
for most of them popular grinds. Some advise: don't go for too much more
lift, and stay under 280 degrees of duration for a street engine. A stock
912/SC cam is *VERY* good though and you'd need to spend some time convincing
me that you *REALLY* needed to replace it for performance reasons unless you
were building a vintage racer (then the rules might get you...)

> One more Question
> is ther anny difference between the aluminum
> Jugs or the cast iron ones? Thanks for anny help.

Yes. Different clearance, different thermal expansion and heat shedding
rates, and mainly different pistons. You *REALLY* want to either get a
set of the "real" 912/SC alloy piston/cylinders, or get your old jugs
rebored and just replace the pistons. ***BE VERY CAREFUL*** if you have
the cylinders rebored -- I've recently run into shops not putting the
cylinder under enough compression when boring, so that once you torque the
head down, well, Mr. Piston doesn't fit so well any more...

Stan

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1060                         Tue Jan 10 14:57:43 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 09:18:54 +0000
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: Blaupunkt Security Code


Mike,

	I had a similar problem when I bought my 911. The first time that
the battery was disconnected (by the dealer who I bought the car from),
the radio wanted its code.

	The bad news is that, as far as I know, you have to get the correct
code (the dealer *eventually* got it for me from the previous owner) *or*
the radio has to go back to Blaupunkt. I have heard stories about putting
radios in freezers to make them lose their memories, but I have also heard
that it's not true (make sure you seal it watertight if you try this) ...
then again, seeing how easy it was for a service engineer to override the
password on my laptop makes me suspicious of any such scheme.

	One tip - if you put more than 16 (?) incorrect codes in, the radio
will lock up and will not accept any more attempts to enter it, and the
documentation says that it *has* to go back to Blaupunkt. My dealer told
me that if you leave it switched off but with power connected (i.e., with
ignition key in acc position) for 1 hour, it will accept another code
attempt.

	Hope this helps.

Philip Katz                                        P.M.Katz@bt-web.bt.co.uk 

1989 911 Carrera 3.2 Sport Coupe (Taubenblau/Baltic Blue Metallic)
Zero cats (but we're thinking of getting 2 ...)

------------------------------

Date: 10 Jan 1995 09:24:29 U
From: "Piescik, Walter" <wpiescik@mailcenter.tsmi.iitri.com>
Subject: Performance cam for 356

For my 356 SC I selected Dema Elgin's Hot Street cam (I do not recall the
number, but I will find it for you if you wish) With big carbs, stock exhaust
and a lightened flywheel, it takes some revs to start up a moderately steep
hill, but the engine is a runner, with lots of torque from as low as
2500-3000 rpms. I am running 9.5:1 1750 big bores on pump gas without a hint
of problems. Dema recommends as high as 10:1 compression, but I did not have
the guts.

Before anyone flames me for for building a potential grenade, remember that a
cam with more overlap can allow "relief" at lower rpms, eliminating the
liklihood of pinging in the mid range where 356s are succeptable. (This
"relief" as I have named it is due to the fact that the piston has already
begun its travel up the cpmpression stroke when the intake valve closes, and
some gas apparently escapes during this phase, lowering the effective
compression ratio) As the rpms go up, the "relief" effect diminishes (due to
the increased inertia of the incoming gasses), but the greater velocity of
the fuel/air mix at the intake valve creates better mixing in the chamber,
better and more complete combustion, and perhaps other witchcraft which
prevents pinging. 

This kind of compression ratio could not be expected to last using a more
conservative cam.

Anyone tempted to extend this logic to a late 911 is discouraged from doing
so, in that the witchcraft performed on the intake headers may negate the
effect of relief. 911 SCs are more succeptable to pinging at high rpms when
the tuned headers are doing their thing.

I have never measured the performance of "scooter" (as we call the 356 SC),
but I know that he gives our gracefully aging (then) 911 SC a run for its
money up to 35 mph or so.

Bear in mind that a 912 is heavier, and this kind of engine might not work as
well for you. I have no knowledge of the gear ratios involved, but I would
look into it if I were you, in order to assure that I was creating a balanced
machine.

Disclaimer: If I have managed to sound like I know what I am talking about,
do not be fooled.

Good luck, and stand back when you first start it up,

Walter Piescik


------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 10:27:42 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: '72 911 S questions

Eric Brown (ericb@microsoft.com) asked,

- -------------------------------------------
I was talking with a local Porsche mechanic, Squire Tomasie,  who is 
very highly
regarded. I told him that I was looking for an early 911 that would be a good
daily driver and autocrosser and I mentioned the '72 S. He brought up 
two points
that I was hoping you could comment on.

First, he said that the S had its power and torque come on very late, 
like above
5500 RPM, and that an E would make a better autocrosser because of a wider
torque curve.
- -------------------------------------------

This is not true of the "2.4" S. I have plotted out the torque curves of the
T, E, and S
and only the T has an advantage at lower RPMs, but at VERY low RPMs where you
should not be running anyway. The S has much better top end and a higher
redline,
so you can go faster in each gear, without losing time up and downshifting.
This 
should more than make up for a few foot pounds less of mid-range torque. 
The S is strong enough at 3500 RPM, with a kick at about 4500 rpm right to
the
redline of 7300. I have driven SCs that felt weaker in midrange power than my
S.

- -------------------------------------------
He also said that the oil tank in the '72 was a bit problem prone and 
that it was
difficult to plumb an external oil cooler. Have you had any problems with
your
oil system plumbing? Have you added an oil cooler? Would an oil cooler only
really be needed for extended high speed track driving?
- -------------------------------------------

The 2.4 S already has a front loop cooler. A non-stock cooler would be
illegal anyway,
and the biggest problem with my car is that it NEVER  warms up in cool
weather! 
The stock cooler is fine even for track use with a stock 2.4S engine.
If you are not interested in keeping stock, I have heard that the '72 S oil
console
is the best to use for external oil coolers, and has been used in some
non-'72
race cars. The '72 has a seperate filter assembly and oil tank. So I don't
know
where the mechanic got his info from.


- -------------------------------------------
BTW, I am going to be looking at a '74 S tomorrow. Any comments about that
car in general? I know that it has a larger engine (2.7) that is 
slightly de-tuned
compared to the '72 S, so its torque curve would probably be broader.
- -------------------------------------------

The '74 S is a real nice car. It has a much stronger torque curve than the
2.4 S. 
It even has as much torque as the 3.0 SC engine, but weighs less. It
is also quite light, barely more than a '73. But I would miss the top end
rush
of a "real" S engine. The '74 S can be easily converted to a '74 US carrera, a
nd that
would be a great car : 7 and 8 x 15 wheels would be perfect for the 225/50/15
tires.
Also you can use a bigger rear sway bar with the carrera in SCCA stock class.
Only rear flares, a duck tail (optional actually), rear sway bar, and front
spoiler 
would need to be added to make a Carrera, although you may need power windows
and a few other standard features to do it right (and legally).
Most '74S's did not come with the front loop cooler, although it could be
added. The '75 and up S is not nearly as good a performance car..


Mike Piera '72 911 S

Date: 10 Jan 95 11:15:54 EST
From: "Byron D. Short" <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: 924/924S To buy or not buy?

JoshB999 asks about the merits of a 924S vs. a 924.

Keep in mind that I'm a devout autocrosser.  IMHO, if not for the
performance characteristics of Porsches, they'd really just be neat
looking but impractical cars.  Performance is what Porsche is all about. 
Such is my belief, and this weighs into my delicately worded opinion,
which follows:

ARE YOU NUTS?!  Oops, not as delicate as I had planned!  Sorry.  Start
over.

The 924S is a FABULOUS Porsche among the water pumpers.  It is, as you
say, a 944 in the lighter body of a 924.  IOW, it's typically quicker than
a 944, and since it's also a little narrower it's the C Stock weapon of
choice over the 944.  Best of all, many (I've heard "all" but I can't
confirm) of these cars came with the M030 suspension, which would account
for it's responsiveness.  First check to see if the car is an M030.  Pull
back the carpet from the rear over the spare tire and look at the build
plate.  It should list "030" somewhere on the list (my 944 S2 has it
first).  If it's there, it's still a good idea to make sure the special
spring perches are in place.  These cars came with an adjustable front
spring perch, which worked via a "screw" built into the bottom of the
factory Koni shocks.  Turn the front wheels to full lock and look from
the back up to the shock.  The lower section of the shock should be
threaded, allowing the perch itself to be raised or lowered.  If
everything is in order, and you can swing it, and especially if it's
priced about the same as the regular 924 you've looked at, it's a serious
candidate for purchase.  I've seen real nice 924S's in this area bringing
$7-$9K.  Regular 924's in the same shape, about half that.  Since the 924S
you looked at has some problems I certainly wouldn't want to pay too much,
but getting in now and correcting it's problems (that power steering could
be costly!) allows you to pay as you go, and when you're all done, you
have one of the best of the series.

Byron Short

'90 944 S2 M030--autocrosser and trailer dweller
'87 944 Turbo--barely pretty enough to be a daily driver
 


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 95 11:31:04 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Bead Blasting

> > Im rebuilding the engine in my 912.  Is it ok
> > to bead blast the case and the cover?
> No. You can bead blast pistons, con rods, heads -- things that
> don't have oil passages that can get plugged up and not cleaned
> out. You gotta clean the case the hard way. I use about 4 hours of
> hard scrubbing in new Varsol, follow with about a case of spray
> carb cleaner with more scrubbing. Final rinse in carb cleaner, spray
> dry with "dried" compressed air.

The manual also recommends reaming out all the oil passages with
gun bore cleaning brushes. Seems like the right idea....

John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 08:52:24 -0800
From: gblanche@qntm.com
Subject: 911's...Something ELSE to worry about?

In my search for a 911, I have read books, asked a lot of questions and 
talked to many people.  One of those people was a co-worker who owns an 
'82 Targa.  He advised that for some reason, the Porsche drivers seem to 
be "singled out" for abuse by other drivers.  Whether it's simply being 
"forced out" when trying to merge onto a highway, or having a pedestrian 
scratch the side with a key.  There seems to be a desire to retaliate 
against those who would own a Porsche.

Is it as bad as I've been led to believe?  Will I need to drive twice as 
defensively when I strap into the Porsche?  And will I need to worry 
every time I park, that my car is going to be molested?

If owning a Porsche requires this kind of paranoia, I'm not sure how 
much I'd enjoy owning one...

Greg Blanchette
gblanche@qntm.com
Wanted: '87-'89 911 Coupe...

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 11:48:04 -0600
From: Richard Hocking <hocking@cig.mot.com>
Subject: Re: 911's...Something ELSE to worry about?

> defensively when I strap into the Porsche?  And will I need to worry 
> every time I park, that my car is going to be molested?

> If owning a Porsche requires this kind of paranoia, I'm not sure how 
> much I'd enjoy owning one...

If you are worried about owning a Porsche I would recommend getting some
other car.  If every time you park, you start to worry.  You are not going 
to enjoy owning the car.  For myself, I will not be pleased if my car gets
keyed or stolen.  However, this is what I have insurance for and part of
my buying decision was: if I have to worry too much about the car because
it is so expensive then I probably shouldn't buy the car.

I really hate seeing people park across two spaces etc... trying to keep their
car from harm.  If they are that paranoid I don't think they should buy the car.
Although, having said that I do always try to park at the end of rows and avoid
parking under trees (which drop sap).  

I know people who own expensive cars and who never worry.  Often their car
is worht more than mine, but they say "don't you worry".  The answer is
"no".  If they aren't going to worry about their $25,000 Nissan why should
I worry about my $25,000 Porsche.

Richard Hocking
'87 911 Targa  [ RICK GB 1 ]

Date: 10 Jan 95 13:26:17 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: No more BFG autoX tires.

 
Hi, Scott.
 
Do you know what the tread wear rating of the 226 and 230 BFGs is? I have to
get new tires for next season, was planning on Yoko 008 RS, but would
consider others. The thing is, the tread wear rating has to be 75 or more or
else I get bumped up a class. The RS qualifies, the RS II would move me a
class. How about the BFGs?
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 10 Jan 95 13:26:24 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Bead blasting

 
Wolfgang Attwenger asks about bead blasing the engine case and "cover"? of
his 912.
 
Don't do it. Damn beads get in everything, they're very difficult to get
out, and if any of them stay in there and get into the oil stream your shiny
new engine will be "Edelschrott" in a very short time. Makes a dandy coffee
table though.
 
"Cover"? You mean the third piece of the case, or the engine sheet metal?
It's OK to bead blast the sheet metal once it's been far removed from the
engine.
 
I know that people who sand blast car bodywork tell you to take the engine
and transmission out or you will have problems. Sand gets in through
transmission breather, various air and oil holes for engine. I'm told that
walnut beads do not have a problem, they are softer than glass or sand so
that if they do get into the engine they don't cause as much damage, but I
would still not risk it.
 
You are going to have to clean your engine the hard way -- by hand. If it is
out of the car, you can get a big start on it by spraying engine degreaser
on it, letting it sit for a few minutes, then using the high pressure
spray at a local coin-operated self-serve car wash to get the big black
pieces off. Do the rest by hand/fingers with solvent.
 
Cams -- where are you located? I know somebody in the San Francisco area who
does excellent work, but if you put in a cam you may also need springs
etc. And besides to get the most from a hotter cam, you also need to
address the rest of the intake system, pistons, compression ratio, also
change carburetor jets.
 
Pistons and cylinders -- I'm very happy with the forged aluminum pistons in
bored-out iron barrels. Shasta Design and other people make them using TRW
forged blanks. I have 60,000 miles on mine with no problems, despite
"experts" who tell you that this will only work for about 15,000 miles
or whatever before destroying an engine. The Japanese NPR pistons and
cylinders are cheap, and were a cheap solution for people who
wanted to keep their old, nearly worthless Porsches running. Now all of
these once nearly worthless cars are worth more (356s, etc) and it's again
sensible to put $600 or $1000 worth of pistons in a car worth $5000 and
up (356 again; good 912 close behind). Although NPRs are no longer being made,
they are relatively easy to find, but the people who have them for sale seem to
think that because they are no longer made they are worth lots more. For not
too much more money you can get the forged aluminum pistons and you'll be
much happier.
 
Pete
 
Pete
 
 
 


------------------------------

> against those who would own a Porsche.

Well, someone keyed me this weekend.  Don't know why, either.  
As far as I can tell, I didn't cut anyone off, or anything like that.
It was in a parking garage, and someone must have done it on
"general princples".   Did a thorough job, too.   Right door,
right rear above the wheel, and left front behind the wheel.  

I'm fairly philosophical about these problems.  If someone assumes I'm
a jerk because I drive a certain sort of car, they most likely have
other reasons to assume I'm a jerk in addition to the car, so I might
as well just drive what I like.  In other words, fuck 'em.  But the
risk of vandalism remains, and you may have to expect such treatment,
particularly if you live out in the real world (and, believe me, it 
doesn't get much realer than Baltimore).

Btw, if anyone has repaired such damage to their paint, i'd appreciate
any tips you have.

Bill

85 911 Champagne, scratched
86 cat, psychotic

P.S. If you _really_ want to develop the feeling that the world is
out to get you, spend some time commuting by bicycle.

Subject: Motronic Sensor Troubleshooting Help

Pfellow Philers:

	My '84 Carerra has been steadily losing its engine
tune.  There is an intermittent miss that comes and goes
depending on throttle position and what appears to be

rough idle; lousy gas mileage, etc.

_Excellence_ (thanks, Jim!).  There are some differences
between the motronic sensor implementation between the air-
and water-pumpers, which may be part of my confusion.

	I would have suspected the oxygen sensor, but Jim's
article states that it is turned off by the DME when the
engine is cold; my problems are not temperature dependent.

	I plan to go through the electrical connections for 
all the sensors and to clean and "seal" them with 
electronic grease.

	Does anyone have a troubleshooting matrix for motronic
related ills they could post?  I realize it may not necessarily
be motronic-related, but it seems to me that's the obvious
place to start.

Dave ('84 Carerra Targa, platinum metallic)

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 12:45:56 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: 951 cutting out at 1700 rpm

Dear p-net gurus,

All of a sudden my 951 has developed problems revving above about 1700
rpms.  It idles fine, but as soon as I bring the engine speed up it
acts like I hit the rev limiter, i.e., the engine seems to cut out
momentarily until its speed drops back down.  By blipping the throttle
repeatedly, I can occasionally break through this 1700 barrier.  Once
I get the rpms up in this way, I can hold the engine at any speed
above 1700 as normal.  Since I knew that my spark plug wires were
marginal, I went ahead and replaced them, as well as wiggling FI
connectors, reseating DME and ignition relays, etc., all to no avail.
Any thoughts?

Thanks,
Milo
