Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 16:05:39 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: re 914 ski rack


Dear Kyle,

The Mohn ski rack fits the 914 well in the factory position or on its own.
However, when installed, you cannot remove the top! It mounts under the
rollbar and in the front windshield frame receivers. However, I do not think
they make the 914 rack anymore so instead we use the Piper rack parts for
this is easily available and it is very popular. Glad to see you are taking
your 914 skiing. We all need to drive our 914s more and more!

George Hussey

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1061                         Wed Jan 11 00:28:34 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 16:08:57 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: re testing 914 starter


Dear Michael,

What most overlook when testing the 914 starter circuit is the rear
transmission ground strap. It is critical in grounding the starter. If it is
worn, dirty, corroded or misconnected, the starter will turn over slowly and
in an extreme case where the battery is fresh, seek the accelerator cable as
a ground and melt it in the tube! Always check this ground lead first when
diagnosing starter problems. It is connected between the 10 o'clock position
on the rear transmission cover (under a nut) and the right rear trunk floor
stud.

Alternator belt adjustment is easy:  simply remove the two left front engine
cylinder cover oval access plugs, loosen the allen bolt under the front plug
and tension the altenator from under the side plug. Tighten the allen bolt
and reinstall the plugs and you are done!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 16:08:51 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: re rust, chassis stiffening, POR1


Dear Al,

Before installing the chassis kit, we always coat both sides of the metal
with Metal Ready Primer (aids in welding) and then POR-15. When we install
the kit, we always make sure we have a solid bead of weld completely around
the perimeter to seal the two metal plates (as well as filling all of the
spot weld holes). We then add more POR-15 after wire brushing, then seam
sealer, chip guard and polyurethene paint. If you look at a 914 body closely,
the factory has sandwiched many of the sheetmetal parts together and they
have not necessarily rusted to any greater extent.

We always try whenever possible to spray rust paint into the inner box
section (longitudinal/inner rocker area). This gives us one upsmanship on
factory rust protection as today's rust prevention products are far superior
to what was available then.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 16:08:54 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: re POR-15


Dear Jonathan,

We have tried Miracle paint and everything else. POR-15 is best. That is why
we sell it. We want the best for our 914s and it is not affected by UV;
that's nuts! We have been restoring Porsches since 1977 and experimented with
everything, sometimes learning the hard way. POR-15 is the best!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 16:08:56 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: re re 914 heat


Dear Pat,

The 914 heat exchangers, when in good shape along with the appropriate
plumbing, provide great heat, and the stainless systems heat exchangers,
fabulous heat. These exchangers along with the auxillary heater blower motor
with both hoses connected to both j-pipes will burn your feet!

For heat in racing cars with headers, we use the aftermarket VW bug electric
heaters. These stow nicely behind the speaker grilles and into the
paper/aluminum heater tubes, directly connect to the battery and mount an
on/off switch in the dash where the defroster switch would be. These heaters
allow the ventilation system to work normally while providing the
hottest/cleanest heat.

George Hussey

Barton P. Chambers wrote:

> >BTW,does anyone remember/use tire studs? I thought those little unobtrusive
> > ice-beaters were great!  As I recall, in Chicago, they were used and
> > outlawed in the late 60s or so (probably tire or salt lobbies).
>Nah, they chew up pavement like nobodies business.  Folks who have to pay for
> new paving (You & Me) outlawed 'em (for the most part).

Actually, studded snow tires are commonly used in snowy parts of the
US.  When I was in upstate NY, they were legal from October through
April, or so.  They worked *really* well on icy roads.  They are a
good compromise (of safety vs. road wear) for areas that are icy more
often than not in the witer months; where the road surface is hard
packed snow rather than asphalt.

California drivers are scary in the snow!  Where I grew up, nobody
needed or used chains except for the snow plows and fire engines...

On another weather note, I have noticed this week that my 931, with
its 3-4 inches of road clearance, is not the best amphibious vehicle
for fording flooded streets!  I really should fix my truck.

 -mike   '80 931 Fire Engine Red

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 17:09:51 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: '72 911S & dumb autocross rules

Dave Darling, darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov, (or the caffeine inside him)
stated :

>>(I said) "A non-stock cooler would be illegal anyway"

>        Say WHAT?  Which lame-o organization penalizes people for
>trying to make their engine last?  Local (PCA Zone 7) rules allow
>and recommend *any* changes which improve engine cooling or help
>maintain oil pressure.  Up to and specifically including removing
>the "rain tray" from the 914 engine lid, which even saves 1 lb.
>or so of weight.
>        If you're talking SCCA, I guess it's just another reason
>to not go and play with them.  Feh.
>        Oops, I'm being an asshole again...  It's either the cof-
>fee or the morning...  Sorry 'bout that, but the feelings are still
>there...
>        So, which  organization are you talking about?

You think that's bad, b-b-b-baby you ain't seen nothing yet!

In SCCA Solo-II we cannot even run the Carrera hydraulic cam chain
tensioners! They are illegal even in street prepared unless the engine
had them standard, i.e. 3.2. I have written to the SCCA Solo Events Board
since the mid-80's trying to get these legalized. I told them that any
Porsche dealer will install them on a customers engine that has old,
worn tensioners. I even sent a copy of the factory technical bulletin
kindly provided to me by Bruce Anderson. But they said it is not a
recall or factory directive, and the original parts are still available,
so we can not use them.

The SCCA rules are super strict, and nothing can be legally changed from
stock unless the rule book specifically says so. This keeps most older
911s out of the stock classes : who wants to take chances of destroying
a $7,000 engine? (I guess I'm about the only one dumb enough...).

If you don't like the rules (does anyone like them?) then you should
write the SCCA. I will give you a copy of the factory bulletin if you
want to show it to them again. I think the currect SEB is trying to
be friendlier than the old "Lotus lovers, Porsche haters" group.
At least the SCCA has a rules committee that takes member input
seriously and has a process of getting clarifications and changes.
I called the PCA rules guy and got no help at all.

The best way to change this rule is to allow any modification which helps
protect the engine but provides no performance advantage (tensioners,
oil baffles, etc). But I don't think they would ever allow non-stock
coolers of any kind, since they could be argued as a performance
enhancement.

Mike Piera, '72 911S Targa, "too stock to live, too fast to die"

reprinted with permission

Lime Rock Park To Host Largest Sports Car Race in North America

Lime Rock Park in conjunction with the Dodge Dealers Advertising
Association has announced the running of the largest sports car race in
North America. The Dodge Dealers Grand Prix at Lime Rock on Memorial
Day weekend, May 26-29 1995, will feature seven of the world's fastest
sports car racing series for a purse of over $500,000.

For the first time in US road racing history SCCA Pro Racing and the
International Motor Sports Association will featuretheir pro racing
efforts in a co-sanctioned event that will showcase over two hundred of
the world's fastest sports cars competing in a total of eight hours of
racing.

Headlining the weekend will be the SCCA's TransAm Tour and the IMSA
Exxon World Sports Car series. The weekend will include six television
programs both live and tape delayed on ESPN and Prime Networks.

The tentative weekend schedule includes: SCCA TransAm Tour, IMSA Exxon
World Sports Cars, SCCA Barber Dodge Pro Series, IMSA Exxon Supreme GT,
SCCA World Challenge, IMSA Bridgestone Super Car,and Neon Celebrity
Challenge.

Off-track activites will include the 1995 MoPar Expo, New England's
largest all-Chrysler aut show and swap meet, with over 200
Chrysler-powered vehicles on display.

For ticket information call 1800RACELRP

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 17:10:47 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: VDO Cruise Control Guru (long-ish)

No, not me . . .

This evening I spoke with George Murphy, a contributor to The Star magazine 
(MBCA) who has a sideline remanufacturing a variety of VDO products, and he 
*believes* that the cruise control amplifiers used by M-B, Porsche, BMW and 
a number of other auto manufacturers are the same.  You will want to talk to 
him -- preferably with the VDO part number off of your unit in hand -- 
before sending it in.  His address(es) and phone number are:

     George Murphy
     Performance Analysis Co.
     1345 Oak Ridge Turnpike
     Suite 258
     Oak Ridge, TN  37830

     615/482-7260   ** 5 - 9 p.m. eastern **

     e-mail:  murphyga@ornl.gov

He has been warned of the potential influx of questions/requests.

On the phone he said that a system that will accellerate but not hold 
definitely has a failed amplifier.  His prices for remanufactured units vary 
by type but are probably between $99 and $150 with core.

I have done business with Mr. Murphy in the past and have found him to be 
friendly, knowledgeable and reasonable when it comes to price.

Best regards,

     -- Bill
        wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 95 15:24:50 PST
From: Patrick Buddenbaum <Patrick_Buddenbaum@ccm.fm.intel.com>
Subject: Re: Tire chain market in Frisco


Text item: Re: Tire chain market in Frisco




  > BTW, does anyone remember/use tire studs? I thought those little
  unobtrusive
  > ice-beaters were great!  As I recall, in Chicago, they were used and
  > outlawed in the late 60s or so (probably tire or salt lobbies).

  >>> Nah, they chew up pavement like nobodies business.  Folks who have to
  pay for
  >>> new paving (You & Me) outlawed 'em (for the most part).

  Up here in Portland, tire studs are still legal and really do chew up the
  roads.  It's great to drive down the highway in those three inch deep
  tire ruts - you don't have to steer :-).  It takes a massive effort just
  to get your car out of the ruts to change lanes!    When the rain we get
  turns to ice (aka black-ice) in the mornings and evenings, the studs make
  a big difference.  Almost everyone in my sales office has them on the
  cars.  Salt is strictly banned, and the rock pebbles they throw down do
  little in our icy environment.

  Pat Buddenbaum
  pbuddenb@inside.intel.com
  '84 911 Carerra

Don't take out the axles unless you have "stub" axles to put in the 
hubs. The axles hold the bearings together. You can take the CV apart 
from the stub axles and use your own or find a couple at swap meet or 
wrecking yard.

Do you have a tow insurance at least they will pay one  way.
					mike

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 17:24:25 -0800
From: tfrazer@sonic.net (Thomas Frazer)
Subject: Re: 911's...Something ELSE to worry about?

Subject:

> From:          Bill Byrne <byrne@cspjhu.ece.jhu.edu>
> Well, someone keyed me this weekend.  Don't know why, either....
> It was in a parking garage, and someone must have done it on
> "general princples".   Did a thorough job, too.   Right door,
>I was in SFO airport a month ago.  Parked near a gorgeous black 993
>cab.  Came back after picking my friend up, there was a long key
>scratch on the front quarter panel and door.  No reason, just becuz
>it was a pretty car.  Some people are that way.

Yes, the crux at the heart of being a Porsche fan. I sold my '87 Carrera
Cabrio three years after I had bought it new after enduring thrown rocks,
numerous "fingers", being cut off in traffic, slashed tires...and I ordered
diamond blue to be low key!
Perhaps now that the car has a few years on it, it wouldn't cause such a
stir.  I always felt very uncomfortable in that car, especially contrasted
with the '77 S coupe that I had before it.  Porsches attract attention,
newer ones can make some green with envy.  It's one of those things that
you have to weigh. As great a machine that that 911 was, I couldn't live
with the image and all that it carried with it.  And it being so new (read
$$$$$$$) made me treat it, at first, like jewelry, rather than a  car to
use.  It felt like it was owning me, rather than the other way around.

After suffering acute Zuffenhausen withdrawl, I bought a lovely '64 356SC
coupe that generates lots of nice comments and appreciating glances.  The
antithisis of my Cab experience.  And a fine car in its own right.

Porsches are one of lifes great rewards...enjoy!

Tom Frazer
'64 356 SC European model
'91 Audi 200 Quattro wagonfromhell
'71 Steyr Puch Haflinger
'68 Glasfugel Libelle sailplane

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 18:34:22 -0600 (CST)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Car color confusion

Hi John,

The driving lights (maybe "rally" lights) were round and above the bumper 
on either side of the hood.  The brackets went through the grills and 
attached to the tops of the battery boxes.  I have the diagrams in my 
shop manual.  There were also two types of chrome grills.  The later 
grills had more slots and on the '73 911 were painted black or black chromed.

These were really ugly lights but not as ugly as the ones bolted to the 
hoods!

David Duffield

have always elicited friendly responses from the general public.  You need to 
know however, that you haven't experienced the ultimate in anticarmattical 
hatred and abuse until you've owned and driven a red Ferrari.  Phew!!  Had a 
79 308 GTS that people HATED.  The 930 was Bambi by comparison. All this 
negative behavior is  just one of the minor disadvantages of driving the 
wheels you want to drive.

every raised digit is a testimony to your good taste and success.  Blessed are 
the meek and unfulfilled for they are condemned to drive Asian iron.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 95 23:15:43 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>

From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: Race force transmission

Let's see if I can make this coherent.  There are three independent
mechanical linkages.  The INPUT .. engine to clutch .. is controlled
by the engine speed.  The OUTPUT .. wheels back to output gears is
controlled by the wheel speed.  The IN BETWEEN .. the transmission
input can be locked to the INPUT (clutch out) or the OUTPUT (in gear)
or both (running down the road).

The role of synchronizers is to make the IN BETWEEN match the OUTPUT
when the clutch is IN.  The synchronizers are funny clutches that will
run in gearbox lubricant and match the speed of the IN BETWEEN and
the OUTPUT.  This has to have rather funny behavior.  It's role is
to match the speeds as you slide into gear .. and then get out of
the way since the acutual engagement is via a 'gear-within-a-gear'
(which some of us call dogs).  This mechanism wants to get into
place firmly before the power is applied strongly.

In road usage, the synchronizers first delay the shift .. back
pressure on the gear lever) until the speeds of the IN BETWEEN
and the OUTPUT are close.  Then they release and let you slide into
gear with little speed mismatch.  This give smooth shifts and is
eased by pause in up-shift and double-clutch on the way down.

If you race, you are more impatient.  You want to get into gear and
get accelerating (or decelerating) withoug waiting for the synch
to take place.  This severely wears the synchronizers and puts
more stress on the 'dogs'.  Still, if you are willing to put up
with wear, it is faster.

Some transmissions have no synchronizers at all.  They want to
be put FIRMLY into gear to get the maximum engagement.  They will
only grind if you are a wimp at shifting.  Most cycle transmissions
are like this as are some racing transmissions.

Rick Dill
My cat moved to Brooklyn and my allergies are better.  My Porsche
is sleeping for the winter.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 95 23:34 EST

as part of the Turbo S.  Anyone ever done this?  Can I do this without also
upgrading to the Turbo S spindles and 928S4 brakes, or will the adjustable
Konis and springs just bolt on to my existing setup?

23.5mm), but adding the rest of the options?

week, is it worth it to upgrade beyond the swaybar options from the M030
(27mm fromt, 18mm back) and go to, say 30mm front and 20mm in the back?

Porschephiles #1062                         Wed Jan 11 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 22:58:04 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: 951 cutting out at 1700 rpm

>air flow meter signal.  I would also check the idle switch on the
>throttle.  If you cannot easily check fuel pressure, try replacing

Thanks, Kevin.  I am now about 95% sure that the problem is the
throttle switch (i.e., confident enough to go out and buy a new switch
tomorrow and achieve complete certainty).  Terminals 4 and 6 show
about .5 ohm throughout the full travel of the throttle (i.e., the
switch isn't opening those terminals in-between idle and full throttle
like it is supposed to).  I was led to checking this after I stumbled
upon the test procedure for checking "throttle valve cut-off" in the
factory manual (turbo supplement).  It says: "Pull off plug on
throttle switch and bridge terminals 4 and 6 with auxillary wire.
Start engine and increase speed to approx. 1600 rpm.  The motor should
begin to surge."  My switch is evidently keeping these terminals
bridged all of the time, and the motor does indeed surge when I hold
the throttle open at least far enough to hit 1600-1700.

 -Milo

P.S.: Even though the plug wires weren't the problem, the new
ones have ended the fireworks display under my hood! :-)


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 00:58:00 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: CA Smog and 912 w/Webers

> Can anyone tell me what the deal is with Weber IDF40's on a 912 and CA smog.

It's real simple: the "real" carbs are still readily available. Parts are
readily available. There is no compelling reason to allow substitute carbs,
and no one has bothered to get an exemption. 

The Weber exemption for 911s with Solex and Zenith and MFI has largely
to do with lack of availability of new whole replacement units. Since
the Weber is a suspercession item *PER PORSCHE*, it's legal. If you could
still buy Zeniths, there would be a lot of unhappy early 911 owners...

> It is a less expensive way to cure the worn Solex syndrome.

I'll take exception to this. A *GREAT* rebuild is about $250 per carb, and
gives you perfect restoration of all functions. The best price I've seen 
on a conversion is direct from PMO, and is about $460. So the delta is 
in the noise particularly when you consider that a properly set up Solex 
PII-40 gives a lot more top-end power than a Weber, but the smaller
main bore on the Weber makes more torque in the midrange, which "feels"
faster/better/etc than the Solex. Once you crest 4500 RPM, though, it's
a different story...

Stan

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1063                         Wed Jan 11 12:27:17 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 04:13:07 -0500
From: PKitchak@aol.com
Subject: Re: Jacking up Porsche

Use a 2x6 cross wise in front of the gas tank for the jack..Put the
jackstands on the front ends of the McPhearsons.  That should work. 
You can jack the rear with about a 18" section of 2x4 or 2x6 under the motor
running front to back. I have a batch of historic 911s from R to ST to RSR
and SCRS with cases I don't want to damage and it has always worked well.
Obviously rear jackstands go on the ends of the torsion bar tubes in the rear
wheel wells.

17mm. I think this is the case on all SCs -  it was on my 79 SC.

the oil just to find that you can't fill it! 
I also had to unclip the throttle cable hinge thing which got in the way of
the filler plug. Took just under 3 Liters.

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 10:19:21 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 951 cutting out at 1700 rpm

On Tue, 10 Jan 1995, Milo R. Dorr wrote:

> Dear p-net gurus,
> 
> All of a sudden my 951 has developed problems revving above about 1700
> rpms.  It idles fine, but as soon as I bring the engine speed up it
> acts like I hit the rev limiter, i.e., the engine seems to cut out
> momentarily until its speed drops back down.  By blipping the throttle
> repeatedly, I can occasionally break through this 1700 barrier.  Once
> I get the rpms up in this way, I can hold the engine at any speed
> above 1700 as normal.  Since I knew that my spark plug wires were
> marginal, I went ahead and replaced them, as well as wiggling FI
> connectors, reseating DME and ignition relays, etc., all to no avail.
> Any thoughts?
> 

You recall from the threads that I have been having a cut out frob on my 
85/944, further examination has convinced me that it is the throttle 
position detector.
The position sensor is bolted on to the underside of the throttle 
butterfly mechanism.

The detector is, I beleive a simple linear potentiometer, they obviously 
tend to wear at something like the normal throttle position, last night 
when mine started playing up, I found that with the car stationary, mine cut 
out at 1900 revs whenever i brought the revs back down thru the range.

A few years ago I had a ford with bosch efi and I had a similar problem, 
once diagnosed, and it took a while, the mechanic simply disconnected the 
sensor ( by unplugging the cable ) and the engine ran fine.

I haven't tried that this time on my car because the problem is too 
intermittent - this morning I did 90 miles with no problem, I suspect 
that my sensor is failing in a slightly more progressive manner than 
yours, but eventually it will be cutting regularly.

You should be able to prove out the sensor in position, with the engine
switched off, by getting an ohm meter and connecting it between two of the
3 contacts on the sensor and then slowly turning the throttle pulley, I 
cannot tell you which of the three contacts to connect the meter to.

All my engineering experience make me think that this is a more likely 
explanation than a DME failure, things that happen at mid range in 
electronic controlled systems are usually external events, electronic 
systems tend to fail at one or other end of the operating range, for 
example either in start up or rev limit mode. Of course Sods Law may apply...

Peter

ps - please let me know how you get on

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 07:12:34 -0500 (EST)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: Re: 911 SC Questions

On Tue, 10 Jan 1995, David A. Rowe wrote:
<details deleted>
> Question I have is, given the fact that there has been body work done, and
> that the paint is not original _and_ not a true 1978 color, would I be
> making a poor investment?

This is 1995. Car and investment constitute an oxymoron. If you think
buying an 18 year old production car with over 100,000 miles is an
investment, do more research. If you want a good car to enjoy, spend
time and money while you own it, and MAYBE not take a bath when you 
sell it, find a good 911. If you are really looking for an investment,
consider buying an undervalued stock or get involved in futures.

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 07:59:00 PST

I don't watch the show much at all, but I have seent the Skip Barber magnet.

FYI: 
     I installed the Weltmeister throttle cam.  What a change.  Sure does 
teaches finesse, especially when taking off from a stop and upshifting. 
 Takes a little getting used to since a little pedal travel equals a healthy 
amount of revs.  Downshifts, however, are fantastic.  Maybe something 
between this round cam and the stock cam might be better.

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 13:33:54 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 911's...Something ELSE to worry about?

On Wed, 11 Jan 1995, Barton P. Chambers wrote:
> ummmm...I don't know about it taking a red Ferarri (although I would, given a 
> decent chance, but I digress...)  Someone who shall ever remain nameless (Unka 
> Bart) got 13 tickets in a 12 month period in good ol' Lawton, OK in a *bright*
> yellow corvette, and made (no joke) #1 on the local cops "Hit Parade."
> Got ticked *twice* sitting at *red* lights!  
>  
The is the apocraphal story about the UK police on the M$ motorway 
playing snooker -

Snooker is a game like pool played with 15 red balls and 6 coloured 
balls, the object is to pot a red, then a coloured ball, replace the 
coloured ball and repeat until all the reds have been potted - each of 
the coloured ball carries different point values

The police patrol crews were playing the game of having to nick a red car 
followed by the highest values colour etc etc

In this game yellow vettes would have been virtually imune from tickets, 
there only being 1 yellow ball, and it only scored 2 points - better 
still if you drove an orange car you would never get booked...

Peter

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 09:35:58 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Maryland Motorsports Park

I went to the fourth and final meeting of the Maryland Motorsports Park
organization.  The group of developers is attempting to gain approval
fromthe Hartford County COuncil to get the proposal approved.

The park will feature a 1.5 mile IMSA style course + 1 1.05 mile
SCCA/Club course which can be combined to a 2.55 mile F1 course.

The poromoters ar emphasising "Not Just Racing" events, such as
concour, dog shows, a bandstand (for concerts) and bicycle racing.

They are interested in club support (hence my attendance as PCA
Delaware President) and they realize track events/drivers ed will be a
prime supported of their facility.


The plan for the facility is in Havre De Grace, a town just south of
the susquehanna river, just off I-95, 20 miles north of baltimore.  The
track directly adjoins US 40, so there is no need for transporters to
negotiate curvy backroads.

It's about 20 minutes from Baltimore, 80 minutes from DC, and 80
minutes from Philadelphia.

They are trying to garner support in the form of petitions and letters.

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 09:41:21 -0500
From: michael@helix.nih.gov (Michael A. Freed)
Subject: testing 914 starter

Thanks George for the advice. What I did:
 -check ground strap by jumpering between negative battery cable and engine
block - still cranked weakly.
 -check for hydro (gasoline) lock by removing spark plugs. There was quite a
bit of gasoline on the plugs, but even without them, engine cranked weakly.
 -check for bad battery by substituting good battery from my wife's car -
still cranked weakly.
 -measure starter motor resistance (too high, some Porschephiles think) and
voltage during cranking (too low), which suggested shorted winding.
 -ordered a rebuilt starter from you.
Michael

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 09:59:08 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Upgrading to M030 suspension

> Hello p-filers,
> 
> I'm looking into upgrading my '87 944 Turbo to the M030 suspension offered
> as part of the Turbo S.  Anyone ever done this?  Can I do this without also
> upgrading to the Turbo S spindles and 928S4 brakes, or will the adjustable
> Konis and springs just bolt on to my existing setup?

Yes, the struts are interchangeable, though not cheap.
I did the full conversion -w- 26MM torsion bars in back.  It worked pretty well.  I had the 26.8mm front swaybar (since then a 30MM ghas become available) and had a weltmeiseter 22mm rear bar, whcih was overkill, even in the full loose position.

> 
> What's the effect of NOT upgrading the torsion bars to 25.5mm (mine are
> 23.5mm), but adding the rest of the options?

The same as if you just put stiff springs in the front.  The struts are
not particularly exciting, except that they are ride height
adjustable.

The biggest benefit of the packaqge is the front brakes.  Beyond that
it just abounts to stiffer bushings.  Don't forget theat the control
arms are actuially different, since both bushings (rear saddle and
front to engine X-member) are stiffer.

If you REALLY do the full conversion you have to change out the reqar
trailing arms, since their moulded in bushings are also stiffer.


> 
> If the car is being used at track, autoX and on the street a few days a
> week, is it worth it to upgrade beyond the swaybar options from the M030
> (27mm fromt, 18mm back) and go to, say 30mm front and 20mm in the back? 
> This has been suggested by a few folks I've talked to, but I don't know what
> to believe. Thanks.
> 

If you're not doing the brakes, you can do just as well  by buying some short springs, the 30MM anti-sway, an adjustable rear bar, and 26 or 27mm torsion bars, as well as Koni struts.  The adjustable spring perches are nice, but not realy necessary.

Don't forget to account for new wheels (8+9x16 is the hot setup)

Steve

>hatred and abuse until you've owned and driven a red Ferrari.  Phew!!  Had a

>negative behavior is  just one of the minor disadvantages of driving the
>wheels you want to drive.
 
>How to deal with this abuse?  I say f**k 'em.  Every scar, every scratch,

>Ted Smith

    I couldn't agree more ! One of the top reasons people buy Ferrari is also
 one of the top reasons they sell it--the attention, and it flips both ways;
 most people are friendly, and someone at every gas station will just want to
 know how much (80 thousand dollars) and how fast (a hundred ninety three... 
 these aren't close to truth but if you say $22k/135mph they're terribly 
 disappointed). But a lot of people look at you as if YOU were the lawyer who 
 foreclosed on their house....or want to size you up as if, gee, YOU don't
 LOOK rich...or feel they have to race you...or go way out of their way to 
 ignore you-- The last class are usually men in their 40s who damn well  
 thought -they- had the glamour car of the neighborhood.  Really gets 'em.

    My other car is a '70 Mustang convertible, bright yellow. Gets all the
 attention but never a discouraging word, only complete enthusiasm. Cops ??
 I drove everyday for 8 months just down the street from a cop station without
 any cop noticing I didn't have registration or inspection sticker---they were
 too busy looking over the car !
    I don't drive cars for the attention--I'm proudest of my 4RE when I get
 out of it in front of the corner auto parts store, me covered in grease head
 to toe working on some other car. Really makes 'em wonder.

     Anybody who drives an exotic for the glamour usually ends up terribly
  disappointed and fearing every bump in the road.  Anybody who drives a car
  for the thrill of the car--and for Ferrari, its good handling and a 
  phenomenal sound at the expense of a very crude Italian car--always wears a
  smile.

         - Lee A, 308 GT4 Dino sn 15346  Bright red
                  '70 Mustang cvt 351c/4v bright yellow
                  '49 chevy pickup (rust and green colored)

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 10:49:21 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: What's best trans oil 4A 924/44?

Hello Porschephiliacs,
	I was sifting through the records on my '77 924 recently and 
discovered the manual trans oil hasn't been changed since 1986! My owners 
manual says to use 30 weight hypoid oil. Is there any particular brand or 
type of lubricant that is better?  I hate to try anything too radical, 
the trans shifts fine except for a slightly weak syncro in 3rd (no 
grinding or anything).  I've heard you shouldn't use synthetics like 
Redline on a really dirty trans (like mine probably is by now) because it 
will loosen sludge and churn it through your gears.  So should I go with 
Redline or use regular old lubricant? Any recommendations would be 
appreciated!
THANX!

Jay Karolyi

'77 lima bean green 924
'88 signal red U.S. legal 959 (do Matchbox cars count? :^)

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 10:24:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: 911 SC Questions


>This is 1995. Car and investment constitute an oxymoron. If you think
>buying an 18 year old production car with over 100,000 miles is an
>investment, do more research.

Well, maybe David meant investment in his own happiness, in
which case an SC is a terrific choice.  With respect to the colour, this
is just my opinion:  it matters less that it is not an original colour
for that year than that it is consistent with the colours Porsche used
for that model and surrounding years.  A metallic nile green would
look really out of place, for example.  Unless you want to concours
the car (heaven help you and yours), who the hell know all the colours
Porsche used at any given time?  (OK, Brett Johnson and John
Patarek, wise guys.)

The price depends a lot on the condition of the car's mechanicals,
assuming you've OK'd the coachwork.  100K is well into the mileage
at which you *might* need major work, depending on all sorts of
things.  Then again, maybe not.

Depending, depending, depending, $12.5 is toward the high side of
the car's worth.  If the mechanicals are good to go for, say, another 40K
miles, probably a fair price.

Kevin Gross

but I wouldn't say that 12.5 was towards the high side of the range though
paerhaps for this particular model given body work, high miles etc.

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 09:20:40 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: 951 cutting out at 1700 rpm

Peter,

Thanks for the reply.  I had vaguely remembered a thread on this, but
had not yet gotten desperate enough to go back through the archives to
remind myself where I had seen it (my memory ain't what it used to
be!).  Instead I did a little more poking around last night, and I am
now fairly certain that the throttle switch is indeed the culprit (see
my response to Kevin Gross, who also rang in with a number of
suggestions, the throttle switch included).

I'm not certain how things are on your car, but on mine the throttle
switch detects two things: (1) the angle of the throttle butterfly
(using a potentiometer) and (2) whether the car is at idle, full
throttle, or in-between (using a pair of switches that close at the
endpoints of the throttle travel).  The angle pot in my switch tests
OK, it is the other switch that appears to now be permanently closed
regardless of throttle position.  It sounds like it might be the
reverse for you.  Even though my car has been grounded for a day or
two, I am glad that the failure was hard (the bug stayed put until I
could find it), not intermittant like yours.  Another piece of luck is
that on the 951, they put the switch on the side of the throttle body,
rather than underneath, so I am hoping the replacement will be more
straightforward.

 -Milo


------------------------------

Date: 11 Jan 95 12:34:37 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911s... something else to worry about?

 
This anti-911 attitude is not unique to the U.S. I remember when I bought my
first Porsche in Germany, neighbors who had been friendly suddenly turned
into classic German stonefaces. ("Damn American! Who does he think he is,
coming over here and buying a better can than we have?") I kept a Golf GLS
as a beater. One day at work, one of the executive assholes at Bosch, who
never talked to me before, came to my desk and asked if I owned a Porsche.
"No." But I could have sworn I saw you driving a red 911 with oval export
plates this weekend. "Wasn't me. I have a red Golf with Ludwigsburg plates."
It sure looked like you, aviator sunglasses and all...  He walked away,
confused but still certain of his overall superiority.
 
When I left that job, I made a point of parking the 911 right outside his
office window to load up my stuff.
 
Pete

Subject: 356 rear bars for sale

Cleaning out my garage, I have the following rear suspension stuff from a
1960 356.
 
Torsion bars -- pair of 24 mm diameter rear torsion bars (early "long" bars)
Trailing arms -- excellent condition, holes not beat out.
Trailing arm retainers -- with long tube to match long trailing arms
 
The arms and retainers were bead blasted, primed with Variprime, painted with
Centari gloss black, and put away. I don't have any cars would be correct with
this earlier setup (my 61 and 65s use the "shorter" bars, which don't stick
out of the retainers as far).
 
Anyway, if anybody wants these, make me an offer.

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 10:04:15 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: 911 SC Questions


- --Boundary-6090931-0-0

David: Bought and sold a 78 911SC last year and looked at 25+ SC's.  The one 
you're describing seems high relative to my recent experience.  Selling prices 
can be significantly lower than prices listed in the paper, etc. 
 
I bought a real nice 78, 50K miles, all options for 13,500, needed schocks and 
tires.   I passed on several solid original cars, 78-80 with 100-140K miles 
for  10-11K.  Keep looking or buy it for 10, 500 if you really like it.  My 
personal preference is for original colors, very nice interiors and service 
records.  history has proven that a car in stock condition  will always be 
worth more than one that's been modified.  They are out there and the market 
is flat, flat ,flat.  If you have dee nero you will get dee car.  Cash is king 
right now in the used car market and that is especially true of the exotics. 
Having dee money puts you in a very good position.  Owners of cars I looked at 
were very frustrated with tire kickers who needed financing, wanted to trade 
their Volvo or were offering 6-8K. 
Good Luck,take your time, find the right one. 
Ted Smith 
67 912 Targa softback 
356 C cpe 
356 B cab

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 12:19:59 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 Engine Removal

        Well, in the hour of daylight (yes, sun!) I had yesterday,
I managed to get about 15 minutes' progress made on the 914 Engine
Drop.
        I'm starting to get worried.  I *think* I'm ready to un-
bolt and lower away, but I want to make sure.  No skinned knuckles
as of yet, which makes me nervous--when will the Blood Sacrifice
occur?
        So help me:  What have I overlooked?

FI brain disconnected from battery tray
Battery out of car
Throttle, air cleaner box, oil filler, dipstick out of car
Manifold Pressure sensor & Decel Valve out of car
Two fuel lines disconnected
Charcoal Cannister vacc lines disconnected
Oil Temp sender wire disconnected
Speedo Drive cable disconnected & pulled out of Engine Bar
Clutch Cable disconnected & pulled out of Engine Mount Bar
Clutch Cable pulley & housing off car
Tranny Ground Strap disconnected
Starter Wires disconnected
Rear Shift Rod & plastic linkage conver removed
Muffler removed (what the heck...)

        Any help is appreciated!

- --DD, praying for a sunny weekend  (shyeah, right!)

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 13:33:24 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: SCCA autocross rules

Dave Darling replied to my statement that Carrera tensioners are illegal :

>        Good Lord!  Not even *chain tensioners*!?!?!?  That's
>bloody ridiculous!  It may be "stock class", but it sounds to
>me like you can still do quite a lot of stuff to your car to
>make it faster--just nothing to help it last, eh?  PCA Zone 7
>rules prohibit R-compound tires in Stock class, for one thing,
>while it seems that they're legal in SCCA Stock.
  
Yes, SCCA allows some things that PCA doesn't : particularly
ANY size "street" tires that fits. PCA penalizes for reduced
diameter tires. Even Hoosier street legal race tires "autocrosser"
are now legal in stock class. They are bias ply race tires, but
with tread and DOT approved (street legal).

>      And, while I'm at it, "Street Prepared"!  What a laugh!
>I don't think 80% of those cars could *possibly* be legally
>registered for street use!

This is now a big discussion topic, why is it called "street Prepared"
when the cars won't pass emmisions (no catalytic converter, etc)
or other road laws. Most people think the class is OK as is, maybe
the name just needs to be changed.

>        Even if SCCA listens to member input, that still lets
>me out.  I'm not a member, and with these rules, unlikely to
>become one.  So I'm making all of these judgments without the
>benefit of any experience to back them up.  (Hypocritical, me?
>Naaaaaah!)

I think the SCCA solo board would be happy to listen to you : they
should hear from people who don't want to join due to idiotic rules.
Actually, you should write to the SCCA president or Board of
directors! They want people to join, and should be told of these
problems and why you are not joining.

I will be glad to provide addresses and fax numbers to anyone
who is kind enough to write to the SCCA to improve the rules.

>        As I said, one more reason not to bother playing with
>the SCCA crowd.  (Another being the Ride Height rule.  Have
>they finally dropped that one yet, or is it still in place, together 
>with moving the 2.0L 914 up to A-class?  Double punish-ment!)

The ride height modification rule HAS BEEN DROPPED! So any
car with STOCK height adjustable suspension may now lower to
their hearts content.

As for classes, the 914 2.0 stays in CS, but the 1.7 and 1.8 move
from DS into CS with their bigger engined brother. The 944T S
and 968 move from BS to AS. These are the only Porsche class
changes this year. In a nutshell, SS is 930 and 928, AS is all 911s
 and 914/6, BS is 944S, S2, 944 T (non-S), CS is 944, 924S, and 914-4.
SCCA does not have 20 stock classes like PCA, so a '65 911
runs against a 993!

Regards, Mike Piera  '72 911S targa, A-Stock soon.

Porschephiles #1064                         Wed Jan 11 19:05:38 CST 1995
Date: 11 Jan 1995 10:33:56 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@synoptics.com>
Subject: Targa top reconstruction

                      Subject:                              Time:  10:10 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Targa top reconstruction              Date:  1/11/95

> David:  Los Gatos Upholstery in Los Gatos did a good job on mine.  He did 
> inside and outside top as well as the rear window on the softback.  Forget
how 
> much  it cost but he's done other PCA members tops and interiors with good 
> results.  Owners name is MIke.  Good  Luck. 
 
Ted Smith 
- -------------------------
Ted/David,

I was pretty disappointed in the work Mike (of Los Gatos Upholstery) did on
my
88 targa top.  He came well recommended so I hoped he could fix the hack job
on the repair arranged by the former owner (the top had been knifed).

The materials were very good and the top had no twists or loose fitting.  Off
the car it looked great!  But when installed it did not fit properly, leaving
a
large, uneven gap at the trailing edge (it didn't fit snugly with the targa
bar)
and the leading edge was too high, creating a lot of drag and wind noise. 
(This
car had never had been in any collision; the top from another 88 targa fit
fine.)
Furthermore, the driver's window wouldn't fit neatly into the rubber slot in
the
top if it was raised before the door was closed.

The car was left with him for the work.  This wasn't a mail order job.  And
when I complained he kept it for another day and, as far as I could tell, he
corrected nothing in that time.  After my second complaint he said that was
the best he could do.  I paid $275 for the job, plus another $240 for the
targa
bar seal (yikes...$200 for the part alone!).  Syd's Upholstery (Middlefield
Rd in
Mtn View, another highly recommended shop) promised they could fix it right,
for another $200.  I lived with it until it was sold.  I will never go back
to
Los Gatos Upholstery.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
95 993 coupe, guards red
85 535i, everyday grey

P.S.  I read last year's thread about adjustments to the top.  It didn't help
my
situation.

Date: 11 Jan 1995 13:15:13 -0500
From: "Mohr Bob" <mohr_bob@po.gis.prc.com>
Subject: FW: The Porsche Motorcycle

And there we are!
_______________________________________________________________________________
From: ROBERT HELLMAN on Wed, Jan 11, 1995 1:02 PM
Subject: The Porsche Motorcycle
To: Mohr Bob
Cc: BMW NA (Frank Stevens); Jorgensen, Ed; Motorcyclist Magazine


Dear Bob & fellow Porsche fans:

	As a Porsche 356 owner and BMW motorcycle rider, I too was fascinated  by
the rumor of a Porsche motorcyle, though I expressed my doubts to you from the
first. Given the soft motorcycle market and Porsche's present financial
constraints, it simply seemed unlikely.
 	
	The sole detail that prompted further inquiry was the inclusion of the
name of Porsche board member Hans Riedel in some versions of the tale; for I
knew Herr Riedel well from his days at BMW Motorrad, and I knew of his
continuing affection for two-wheeled German iron.
	
	Still, it was with a sceptical predisposition that I approached Hans
Sautter, a close mutual friend of Mr. Riedel and of mine, who also happens to
be
top press man for BMW motorcycle world wide. Mr. Sautter not only assured me
that the Porsche motorcycle rumor was false, but pinpointed its origin in the
German motorcycle magazine Motorrad Reisen und Sport.

	Thus, regrettably perhaps, there is no truth whatever to the Porsche bike
story.  

						Robert Hellman
						Editor
						On the Level
						BMW Riders Association

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 13:34:29 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; POR-15 vs. Miracle Paint vs. Corroless

>From: Dr914@aol.com
>Subject: re POR-15

>Dear Jonathan,

>We have tried Miracle paint and everything else. POR-15 is best. That is why
>we sell it. We want the best for our 914s and it is not affected by UV;
>that's nuts! We have been restoring Porsches since 1977 and experimented with
>everything, sometimes learning the hard way. POR-15 is the best!

>George Hussey

     I've talked to Bill Hirsch (who sells "Miracle Paint"), Eastwood (who
 sells Corroless), and "Skinned Knuckles" magazine (who sells magazines).
 They've been running rust tests on competitive products, I've sent off
 for their articles on the results.

     From what I can gather;
    * Corroless is a 38 year old British product, developed for off-shore
      oil platforms. Only sold in the US thru Eastwood, it is a "fortified
      enamel."
    * Miracle-paint and POR-15 are "water hardened polyurethanes." I got a
      vague "no" when I asked Bill Hirsch if their Miracle Paint and POR-15
      were the same product (they are available in the same colors, for about
      the same price, and about the same claims). Both claim incredible film
      strength, adhesion, immunity to solvents/acids/salt/brake fluid;
      Miracle paint claims it will reliably seal gas tank leaks up to the size
      of a dime....(back the whole with cloth, fill the tank, remove the
      backing. Hey, its just flammable..)
    * Bill Hirsch advises brushing miracle paint on, not over scale but that
      its not necessary to remove the rust. They claim their adhesion is so
      good they include rubber gloves (or you can't get it off your skin;
      however the truth may be that the stuff is that toxic (Eastwood was
      quick to point out that POR-15 contains iso-cyanides). Bill Hirsch also
      sells a thinner for Miracle paint. I got a vague answer on whether
      Miracle Paint could be sprayed (if adhesion is what they say, will it
      come off my gun?).
          As far as UV sensitivity, JC Whitney sells a "Miracle paint" (for
      about the same price/same claims) but warns that it needs to be
      topcoated. Bill Hirsch denies theirs is so sensitive, and claims they've
      had excellent results using it over their warehouse floor (in clear).
    * Neither Eastwood or Bill Hirsch publish any type of comparison with
      the other guys. I'm skeptical that the "big guys" (PPG, DuPont) don't
      have anything with similar claims (and I worry they are simply
      responsible) but "Skinned Knuckles" magazine claims that Corroless
      and POR-15 are their top-2 choices for Rust converters/primers. They
      haven't tested Miracle paint but have heard good about it.

       I haven't tried either, but I have had the experience once of trying
      to remove primer on some Taiwanese sheetmetal---the nasty paint stripper
      I use wouldn't faze it--not a bubble, no softening, not even a change
      in gloss--and since I've wondered what the hell they used.
      
       Any chemists out there who know what this stuff is ???

                   -Lee A.



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 11:37:29 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: re: re: CA smog/912/Webers


Stan,
Thanks for your $.02. I have a couple of points I think are relavant.
 I think that a Weber conversion is less expensive than you say. I got a set of brand new
 Weber IDF40's (Italian ones) with K&N aircleaners for $300. They were not jetted correctly
 though. So I got some replacement emulsion tubes and fuel jets from PMO for about $40 (I
 think???) I put them onto the 12 and they work great!  Much better than the Solexes. So
 we're upto $340 and some time. But the time is free and also a part of owning an older 
Porsche. I know, the Solexes have larger venturies but they also had the worn throttle 
shaft problem so common to  Solex pII40s. As for replacing the Solexes; I found some new
 one for about $600 per carb. That's $1200 for  both! Onto get the old ones rebuilt, well,
 I think they can be done but you really need some one who can machine the throttle bodies 
correctly i.e. drill it straight or your back to buying new. I asked the local guru about 
this process of drilling and he claims it's a 50/50 chance of getting it drilled correctly.
Back to the original smog question though; I have results from smog tests with both sets of 
carbs and the webers produce less emissions. I just can't understand why CARB is so reluctant 
to add these carbs to the "accepable" list. I know that original replacements are around but
 how do they guage when the supply runs out. This is just my additional $.02.
Sean
scifi%

Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 14:21:04 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: RE:Jacking up Porsche


For the back of my 911:

I always just put a block of wood on my jack and slid it under the
engine to the rear of the sump screen. With both wheels off the ground
I put jack stands under the point at which the body seams turn inward
for the fire wall (which is supposed to be the strongest part of a 911).
Most of my p-car friends do it the same way and non have ever had any
damage. I *have* seen damage from the jack plates, both to the jack 
"socket" and to the rocker panel. The first time I lifted the car under
the engine, I kind of cringed, but virtually everybody at the track 
seems to do it that way, and I've seen many pictures of 911 racing cars
lifted that way. When you think of the normal stresses on the engine
and mounts, lifting the body isn't excessive. Any other opinions? 
Flames?

Reid



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 14:43:03 -0600 (CST)
From: thomas pollock <tpollock@d.umn.edu>
Subject: Re: 914 scale models / kits

There were some plastic 914 kits in the early 70's but have not seen 
anything in many years.  Solido (French) had a 914 diecast 1/43 scale of 
the same vintage, I have a yellow and black one in my collection.  I 
believe that they may have reissued that model several years ago and may 
be available from sources like EWA.  I can look in the last Danhausen 
catalog (1992) to see if they show any others.  Schuco may have had a 
diecast and there may be some white-metal or resin kits as well.

Tom Pollock
Center for Professional Development
University of Minnesota
tpollock@ub.d.umn.edu

1987 White 951 (on ice for the winter)

hall@macs.mxim.com (Hal Lillywhite) writes:

>In article <3ek0p5$ael@mloeff01.elec.mid.gmeds.com> wijung@koppa2.delcoelect.com (Waqar Jung) writes:
>>I am looking for 2 way hand held radio with 3-5 miles range

>>Any suggestion/s will be very much appreciated.

>The best technical solution would be 2 meter FM with a ham license.
>A no-code tech license can be had without learning morse code.  If
>you don't want to go to the trouble to learn enough to pass the test
>for this a CB would probably work for you.  Hand held CB's can be
>purchased for under $100.  Be aware that either works best if you
>have no major hills between the two radios.

About handheld CBs... be sure to get a small whip antanne  ( 2 - 4 feet)
and something in the 4-5 watt range as far as the transciever power goes.
The rubber ducky antannes that come with most handhelds aren't good for
much.

One of the first things I got for my survival `box' was a handheld CB.


------------------------------

Date: 11 Jan 1995 14:34:07 -0800
From: Soren LaForce <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re-911 brake pads

                       Subject:                               Time:2:31 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          re:911 brake pads                      Date:1/11/95

Elliot writes:

> What is the list wisdom regarding brake pads (front and rear) for
>a 1983 911 SC used primarily for the street and only occasionally (very
>occasionally) driven in autox or driver-ed. ? 

I have been *really* happy with the Freodo AF pads in my '80 'SC.

My car is a street/auto-x car.  These pads require no warm-up
but work effectively auto-xing

Automotion (blech) has them.  I don't know who else.  Imparts doesn't.



- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov


------------------------------

Date: 11 Jan 1995 14:51:17 -0800
From: Soren LaForce <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- leaky 911

                       Subject:                               Time:2:49 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          re: leaky 911                          Date:1/11/95

John writes:

>During this past week with the deluge of rain here in Northern California
>I've had some water getting into the interior of my car and I can't tell
>where it's coming from.
>
>It's only on the passenger side floor and it is very wet (about 1/4" - 1/2"
>of standing water).  The door sill is not wet nor is the carpeted area 
>under the dash.     


It's probably the windshield.

My girlfriend had this problem with her '81 'sc.

She used a permatex windshield silicone sealant and the problem seems to 
be gone.  This was after having the seal replaced *and* sealed.

I believe the sealant goes between the glass and seal and between the paint 
and seal on the outside.


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 13:37:32 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: RE: Calif. smog/912/Webers


Sean:  How do they determine when the supply or Solex's runs out?  Easy!  When 
thtey are no longer available from Porsche.  I put new Solex's on my 912 to 
stay smog legal.  I got it to pass  at the referee because I had the stock 
equipment but it didn't meet specs.  How could this be especially since I had 
had the car pass the previous time on a worn engine and now the engine and 
carbs were new.  Answer:  BAR keeps on raising the requirements.  the car when 
new would not pass smog in Calif. now because the standards been raised?  Just 
talked to an exotic car dealer who told me not to buy a 70-80's vintage 
Maserati because the new smog laws in effect Jan. 1 would not allow any 
70-80's vintage cars to pass.  You get a temporary pass for two years and then 
there is no limit on the amount you need to spend to make your car meet the 
requirement.  They are making a concerted effort to get smokers off the road 
but catching relatively clean vintage cars in the process. Another  example of 
your tax bucks at work in a bureauracy run amuck.  If you can find a smog 
station that will pass you with thte Webers, go for it.  And pray that they 
are still around next time..... 
 
Good Luck 
Ted Smith

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 18:00:33 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: re: CA smog/912/Webers

>  I think that a Weber conversion is less expensive than you say. 

Think again. Include in your price the need for new intake manifolds or
the adapt-o-plates. The *REAL* price for a true conversion is $480. 
Call PMO and ask *THEM*. Of course, you could pay Harry's mark-up
or get really raped by Automotion....

> As for replacing the Solexes; I found some new
>  one for about $600 per carb. That's $1200 for  both! 

Sure. So how old is the car and how  often have you had to replace
the carbs? So what's that in $/year?? And if you'd like a real shock,
go price a carb for a late large-block Ford, like one of the CV carbs
from the mid-80s or so... The price is *COMPLETELY REASONABLE* when
you consider the market size, and what OTHER carbs sell for. 

> Onto get the old ones rebuilt, well,
>  I think they can be done but you really need some one who can machine 
> the throttle bodies 
> correctly i.e. drill it straight or your back to buying new. I asked the 
> local guru about 
> this process of drilling and he claims it's a 50/50 chance of getting 
> it drilled correctly.

I'm glad I don't have to depend on him for my other machine work. This is
*NOT* rocket science and there are at least three places anyone with a
356 derived engine should automaticly know about that can do this:
Stoddard, NLA, and Eurometrix.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 15:31:02 -0800
From: donr@deltanet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: Re: 911's...Something ELSE to worry about?


>>  There seems to be a desire to retaliate 
>>against those who would own a Porsche.
>>
>>Is it as bad as I've been led to believe? 

Not in my experience in Southern CA, can't speak for elsewhere. Take too 
much effort to go after all the Porsches here (g)

There is no question, however, that color has a direct bearing. I used to 
have a silver 944T which didn't seem to attract much attention. A friend had 
the same car in Guards Red. We compared notes from time to time. He was 
followed regularly by the CHP, which I wasn't, and got more tickets than I 
did. Driving similarly, in style and mileage, I was clearly at less risk, at 
least from the CHP. Too bad, because I really liked the red. My 911 is blue, 
and seems to cause the same relative indifference. 

A few years ago, at traffic school (for those who haven't had the pleasure, 
it is a CA way of not having tickets go on your record), the instructor had 
statistics relating tickets and colors. Red, compared to anything else was a 
disaster, outdid the next color by over 2X. Based on that, I would never own 
a red car of any kind in CA, unless it is a 356 Speedster which only seems 
to attract a positive reaction (g).

Don

86 911 Carrera
56 Speedster
Don Rutherford
'86 Carrera
'56 Speedster

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 16:42:03 PST
From: Michael R Schmidt <Michael_R_Schmidt@ccm.ch.intel.com>
Subject: Re[2]: Blaupunkt Security Code


Text item: 


In case I run into the problem in the future---How does one enter the
security code?  Where would I normally find the code.  I'd like to look to
get my hands on it now rather than waiting and going through the process
that you evidently went through.

Thanks in advance for any help you may offer.



- --
Jeff Ironfield
jaironf@pacbell.com


For newer cars, (mine is a 1991 944S2), Porsche maintains a database which 
contains the code for each stereo based on the serial number (found on the back 
of the unit).  

Both dealers in town were able to access the code number on-line based on this 
serial number (some confusion here, as the first dealer wasn't sure whether to 
use the serial number or another number off the back of the stereo).  Best bet 
is to get all of the numbers off the back of the unit.

On my model (the "Stuttgart (sp?)"), the code is entered as follows (let's use 
the code number "8027" for this example):

[1]  Turn the power on to the stereo and turn it on
[2]  Wait until the word "code" is displayed
[3]  Enter the code by 
     - pressing the #1 key 8 times, 
     - pressing the #3 key 2 times, and 
     - pressing the #4 key 7 times.  
     Each digit on the display is incremented each time the corresponding key 
     is pressed.  
[4]  When your code number is displayed, hit the "rocker switch" (on my stereo 
     it is on the bottom right hand corner and is the tuner during normal use),
     and your stereo should immediately begin to work

Now that my stereo works again, I remembered how mediocre the sound is.  Next 
step is to improve the sound quality, while leaving the factory stereo in place.
Any thoughts?

Mike Schmidt

1991 944S2
1986 Bronco

- --Boundary-6104256-0-0

IMHO Swepco is not a good solution for everyday driving especially in colder 
climes.  My mechanic wouldn't put it in my 911 because he said it's heavier 
than the Shell(?) multigrade he likes and that the car would shift more 
stiffly when cold.  I live in N.CAl. Can't imagine how much stiffer the shift 
would be in the GWN.  He likes it for racing though.

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 20:09:50 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: No more BFG autoX tires.

Pete,
The new BFG road racing tires have a treadwear index of 50 and are real
sticky. I can't speak for autoX but they are great on a road course. Lap
times have been plummeting lately and I feel that it is the tire technology,
at least to a considerable extent.
The 50 rating is a bit deceptive as they are really very good at lasting a
long time. I got 12 track days out of my last pair and they still had plenty
of life, albeit no tread. They are now, for all intents and purposes,  slicks
and as such are illegal in Club Racing. For just track events they have at
least another weekend to goat the instructor level. 

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
8:01 pm

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 20:12:53 -0600
From: dkelly@tomcat1.tbe.com (David Kelly)
Subject: Re: Two way hand held radio

> >The best technical solution would be 2 meter FM with a ham license.
> >A no-code tech license can be had without learning morse code.  If
> 
>  What is the procedure for getting a no-code license?

A not-bad start is to buy a study guide, available at Radio Shack, or your
local bookstore. You might have a local amateur radio store, check there,
as they will also know the schedule of local exams. Also likely to know of
free classes by the local amateur radio club.

The American Radio Relay League is on the net, I forget the address, but
its arrl.com, or arrl.org, or ftp.arrl.org, or some such.

73,
- --
David Kelly, N4HHE,   n4hhe@amsat.org,    dkelly@nebula.tbe.com 
- ------------------------------------------------------------------

them up end to end, they'd still point in the wrong direction?

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 21:26:12 -0500
From: EuroPerf@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Engine Removal

Dave,
These are some obvious things you didn't do yet or forgot to mention.

Disconnet: plug from alternator and inj. harness plug at relay plate
                accelerator cable
                CV joints
                heater hoses
                heater control cables
Remove:   heater control boxes with elbows attached (it's easier)
                starter motor-It's easier to get the trans past the left
axle!

I find it easier to remove the drive train if the muffler is left on because
it gives you something to grab onto and balance the assembly while lowering
it to the ground!

Good luck and holler if you need more help.

Bob Kakascik
EuroPerf Racing

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 19:55:01 PST
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: Re: Cleaning K & Ns?????

Use Simple Green diluted 1 to 1 with warm (not hot) water.

Simple Green is a great non toxic, biologically safe cleanser.  It's sold in
1 gallon jugs (similar to bleach or ammonia) for about $8/gal in concentrate.

I've also used it with near boiling water to clean off engine parts, it
really does a fine job of cutting grease.

- --

AL4-55  Intel, 5200 NE Elam Young Parkway, Hillsboro, OR 97124-6497

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 23:57:30 -0500
From: Beverly514@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1058 Mon J...

Henry,
>There is a 71 911 T for sale, and I am thinking about buying it.
[stuff delted]

If you go look at the car make sure you look for rust everywhere.

>He had it for 21 years, it has 130K miles, the car is daily driven, it
>was a California car until 10 years ago, it currently lives in Chicago.
>It has rust around headlights, the most severe part is at the right >front
panel, I think it has holes.

Eventhough the car once lived in California, it depends where in California.
This is probably a mute point anyway. Since the car has lived in Chicago for
10 years, it sounds like the climate has caused some damage . If the rust is
that noticable on the right panel, make sure you look at the metal supporting
the front suspension. 

My '70 911E only spent the first year of it life in Europe, the remaining
years have been in sunny (now flooded) Southern California. The suspension
pan devolped severe rust and had to be replaced. Make sure you check this
out. Another area you need to check is the bottom of the doors. If the drain
holes have become plugged (they do over time) water will do its dasterly deed
just sitting there. Many body shops will cover this over with Bondo.
Depending on the climate, it may take three to four years for the rust to
become visable again. If you are serious, take a small magnet with you. If
there is enough Bondo, the magnet will not stick.

[more stuff deleted]
> He claimed he had all records. Ths asking price is 
>$4200. Reason for selling too small for family.

Personally, I would be cautious - have a professional check the car out.
Maybe you have come across one of those deals you can't afford to pass up. If
the guy is on the up and up, he won't mind if you have the car checked out. 

Good Luck!!

Bev Frohm

'70 911E Targa  (Street Concours & Touring)
'74 914 2.0        (Daily Driver & AutoCross)
'84  female cat Freckles
'89  male (six toes) cat Elmer
'48 Husband unit Lars

Date: Wed, 11 Jan 1995 22:16:15 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: 951 cutting out at 1700 -- problem solved


A new throttle switch cured the problem.  There were two errors in my
previous posts, however.  First, the switch only senses idle/off-idle,
not full throttle.  This became obvious after cutting open the old
switch and seeing only one (broken) microswitch that is operated when
the throttle is closed.  Second, even though the switch is mounted on
the side of the throttle body, rather than underneath it as on some
other 944s, you still need to remove the throttle body to get a clear
shot at one of the screws fastening the switch.  Fortunately, this
is pretty straightforward anyway.

 -Milo

Peter Diffey: I got a message from an MCI gateway indicating that
a message I had tried to send you (also cc'ed to the whole list)
got bounced.  Any idea why?

Date: 12 Jan 95 01:44:17 EST
From: Byron Short <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: Sports Car Communist Assholes

Hi phellow P-philers!

I read with interest the criticisms of SCCA's rules policy for Solo. 
There's a major misconception among PCA members about SCCA Stock, which
is that SCCA Stock allowances should parallel PCA Stock.  Well, they
don't! 

SCCA Stock is, pretty much, stock!  As in, "as delivered".  PCA Stock
allows a neat and thoughtful combination of upgrades in motor,
suspension, and other parts that enthusiasts like to change.  This is not
to say that one is better than the other, just that they are different. 
SCCA has no quarrel with this level of preparation, in fact we have a
category that's conceptually similar!  In SCCA it's called "Street
Prepared".  It allows, if I may paraphrase, bolt on engine componentry
(intake, fuel injection or carburation, headers, etc even if not
originally equipped) and enough suspension tweaks to keep you smilin' til
your bank accout hit's empty!  It's likely that a fully equipped SCCA
Street Prepared car exceeds PCA rules somewhat here and there, and that a
fully equipped PCA Stock car exceeds SCCA SP rules here and there, but
conceptually the classes are very similar.  And it's very likely that the
majority of Porschephiler's well prepared PCA Stock Porsches will compete
very nicely and very competitively in local SCCA Street Prepared
competition!  At a national level of course, as in PCA, you're better off
with a car optimized to the particular rule set.

Don't damn SCCA for allowing two distinctly different versions of
streetable Porsches to compete!  SCCA Stock provides a place for those of
us who really haven't done anything to our Porsche a place to play and be
very competitive!  I know.  I won a the SCCA D Stock National
Championship in 1993 driving a Porsche 914 1.7.  The car was "as
delivered" except: muffler, air filter, shocks, front sway bar, a truly
wild alignment, and tires.  My new 944 S2 will be a national caliber B
Stocker with only air filter, alignment and tires!  Would these cars
equipped this way be competitive in the Porsche Parade?  Not terribly. 

In SCCA you have a choice of streetable preperation levels.  Why should
that be considered a "Communist Act"?  :-)

Lastly, the reference to the SCCA's SEB (Solo Events Board) as "Porsche
haters, Lotus lovers" amused me greatly.  You see, I'm a member of this
eight person board, and in this capacity I read every week how we are out
to get MR2's, Corvettes, RX7's, Honda's, BMW's, Mustang's, and yes even
Loti and Porsches!  If we were out to get everyone who thought we were
out to get 'em you could only be safe driving Studebakers and Hudsons!  

For the record, in the last 22 years SCCA Solo National Championships have
been claimed by Stock category marques as follows: Porsche 42; Lotus 9;
Studebaker & Hudson 0.  It's not time to trade in that 911 on a
Hawk or a Hornet just yet! :-) 

Byron "but you can call me Communist Asshole" Short :-)

'87 944 Turbo--B Stock (or is that class 11?) if I can find a stock KLR
		chip--otherwise Mod in either rulebook!
'90 944 S2 M030--My real B Stock car!
Previous Porsches: '73 914 1.7 converted from 914 2.0, '68 912.
Yep, a real "Porsche hater"... :-)

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 03:17:12 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re:  CA 912 Smog Test.

Dear Sean:

         The CA boys are right- Webers aren't Legal in CA. HOWEVER they can
easily be adjusted to pass the CA smog test, so ifin you get a tester to test
'em and you pass, you pass! The easiest way is to take the car to the station
with the LEAST amount of Porsche knowledge- like a Hyuandi repair shop with a
smog license. If you want to have a higher probability of passing, use the
trumpet-type 912 Air Filters, drill out the base plate to match the 4 studs
of the Weber and fit the 912 Air filters to your Webers. The smog lines hook
up like they're made to, since they are, and with this arrangement, the
Webers look a lot like Solexes- enough so the Average Smog Mechanic can't
tell the difference and will give you the test.
      Weber went through the BAR's hoops to get several models legal in CA
for the HonDatToys, but decided that it wasn't worth it for Porsches as, with
the sliding 20-year rule, they would be exempt by 1989. Unfortunately, the
Smog Boys CHANGED THE RULES (LAW), and now everything after 1966  is NOT
exempt and has to have the Original Equipment and go through the bi-annual
test!  (Please note that everything  BEFORE 1966 IS exempt, which means that
ALL 356's do NOT need a smog test- EVER!  I sure like the ring of that!)
     It is still possible to rebuild the Solexes for about the same cost as a
set of Webers, including replacing the throttle shafts and putting bronze
bushings in as well as machining all surfaces and untrasonic cleaning of the
throttle body, as we do this all the time, but New Webers with ball bearings
in the throttle shafts and ease of main jet/air correction jet/ emusion tube
changing OUGHT to be legal- especially if they PASS THE DAMN TEST! (IMHO.)
You may thank you Loco State/Federal Gumnt for this asinine law.

  And KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 08:26:37 CST
From: wpcostel@porsche.aud.alcatel.com (William Costello)
Subject: RE: Jacking up a Porsche

I use a small floor jack and a jack plate from Automation for lifting my 911.
The jack plate is very sturdy, coated to prevent rust, and has never caused
any damage to my car. I use hockey pucs (hard rubber) between the floor jack
and the jack plate. This protects the metal coating on the jack plate and
provides a flexable "joint" between the floor jack and jack plate. The
rubber has a good grip and adjusts with the difference in angles between
the floor jack and jack plate while lifting the car.

To lift the rear of the car, I jackup one side (both wheels off the floor) and
place a jack stand, with a saddle type head, under the end of the torsion bar
tube located in the rear wheel well. I bought some heavy clear plastic tubing
and split it to go over the saddle head of the jack stand, This prevents metal
to metal contact with the car, saving the paint/coating on the torsion tubes.
I then lower the jack (front wheel returns part way to the ground) and repeat
the procedure on the other side of the car.

To lift the front of the car, I follow the same procedure. but use jack stands
with flat heads and hockey pucs to hold the front up at the corner of the
floor pan (as shown in the owners manual).

The only concern that I have ever had is that the doors are harder to close
while the rear of the car is off of the floor. I suspect that this is due to
body flex. After returning the car to the ground, the doors work fine. Has
anyone else noticed this ? Also, the procedure that I described makes the
flex from side to side since one side is up and the other down for a short
period of time. I have never had any problems with the handling after this
so I suspect the car can take this OK. All comments are welcome!

W.P. Costello

86 911 Carrera in Meteor Gray Metalic
87 Buick Skylark (152K miles and still going)
94 Pontiac Grand-Am (provided by Mary Kay Cosmetics)
Z, OJ, Stormy, and Porsche (our loyal/lazy cats)

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 08:45:15 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Re: 911's...Something ELSE to worry about?


I have a GuardsRed '87 Targa and live in the southeast suburbs of Houston.
With "few exceptions", I've had nothing but admiring glances.  Now for the
few exceptions....

One October day I was returning to work from a west-side meeting on the I-610
loop.  My boss was in the passenger's seat, a co-worker was pretending to sit
in the back, and we were enjoying the top off cruise.  Just before the
junction of the I-45 spoke, there is a catwalk across the highway from a mall
parking lot to a movie cinema.  As we approached, a guy lined up over my lane
and dropped a bottle.  (What happened to the good old days of spitting?)  I
never saw it, but my boss suddenly commanded "@#$%, Look out, Turn quick".
The bottle glanced off the right front fender about 6" in front of the
windshield taking a quarter sized chunk of paint with it.  If the timing had
been a fraction of a second closer, the bottle could have gone thru the
windshield or open top.  Potentially fatal situation.

I can handle "Pennies from Heaven" and "Raining Cats and Dogs", but some
bastard dropping a bottle...."The Gods Must Be Crazy".

Wayne Michelsen
W_Michelsen@lfhs2.hso.link.com
'87 911 Targa [GuardsRed/Black]

Date: Tue, 10 Jan 95 14:06:51 PST
From: jaironf@PacBell.COM (Jeff Ironfield)
Subject: Re: 911's...Something ELSE to worry about?

>Is it as bad as I've been led to believe?  Will I need to drive twice as 
>defensively when I strap into the Porsche?  And will I need to worry 
>every time I park, that my car is going to be molested?

I have owned two different Porsches now for almost 5 years (a relative 
newcomer) and my experience has been not discernably different than other 
vehicles I have owned.  I always try to park in out of the way places, end 
of rows, wide spaces, etc.  While I like to drive fast when suitable I also 
try not to attract any unwanted attention.  No double space parking, no 
engaging those individuals with a chip on their shoulder, etc.  

You've got to be careful where you park any nice car esp. a Porsche since 
they don't have any defensive rubber on the car sides to prevent dings, 
chips, and dents.  I has been my experience that if you park a car in a 
parking lot like most people it will get dinged and chipped, fact of life.  

My advice is buy it, take care of it, park it away for other cars, and have 
fun. 

Jeff Ironfield
87 944 (gone now)
87 911 Targa ( here for a long time)

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 16:23:18 +0100
From: J.C.Kuenen@et.tudelft.nl (Jeroen Kuenen)
Subject: Re: testing 914 starter

Michael A. Freed wrote:
>Thanks George for the advice. What I did:
>-check ground strap by jumpering between negative battery cable and engine
>block - still cranked weakly.
>-check for hydro (gasoline) lock by removing spark plugs. There was quite a
>bit of gasoline on the plugs, but even without them, engine cranked weakly.
>-check for bad battery by substituting good battery from my wife's car -
>still cranked weakly.
>-measure starter motor resistance (too high, some Porschephiles think) and
>voltage during cranking (too low), which suggested shorted winding.
>-ordered a rebuilt starter from you.
>Michael
>

Sounds to me that the starter motor rotates too heavy which can be caused by 
worn bearings of the starter motor.
