Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 09:33:50 CST
From: dhartger@nas_jsc1.jsc.nasa.gov (Dan Hartgerink)
Subject: RE: Jacking up a Porsche


W.P. Costello writes about his 911:

(stuff deleted)


>To lift the rear of the car, I jackup one side (both wheels off the floor) and
>place a jack stand, with a saddle type head, under the end of the torsion bar
>tube located in the rear wheel well. I bought some heavy clear plastic tubing
>and split it to go over the saddle head of the jack stand, 

good idea! Ill be stopping by the hardware store on the way home from work.


>This prevents metal
>to metal contact with the car, saving the paint/coating on the torsion tubes.
>I then lower the jack (front wheel returns part way to the ground) and repeat
>the procedure on the other side of the car.

When I put my '87 944 up on stands, I place the rear jack stands under the 
torsion tubes as well (this thread was about 911's) but I dont place
them at the ends that stick out of the tube (Im assuming there are some 
similarities between the two cars tubes), but somwhat closer to the middle 
where the tube is much thicker.  I was really worried about doing this the 
first couple of times, but so-far nothing has bent or deformed etc. 

Any comments on this placement for a 944?   


>The only concern that I have ever had is that the doors are harder to close
>while the rear of the car is off of the floor. I suspect that this is due to
>body flex. After returning the car to the ground, the doors work fine. Has
>anyone else noticed this ?  

(stuff deleted)

My 944's doors are somewhat out of alignment when the whole car is up on 
stands, not enough so you can see it, but when you open and close them, you 
can tell that the latches do not line up like they do when the car is 
suspended from the wheels. Also, it is nearly impossible to latch the 
hatchback once it has been opened.  As with W.P.'s 911, all these symptoms 
go away once the car is back on its wheels.  

As for the front of the car, I place jack stands under the "beams" molded
into the unit body floor of the car.  I make sure to align the top of 
the stand with the section of the "beam" that is composed of two 
overlapping thicknesses of sheet metal.  I really hate doing this  because
it creates damage to the underbody coating and does a tiny amout of damage
to the metal itself.  I dont use wood or any sort of pad because Im really
paranoind about having the car squish me like a bug while Im working on it,
but I think Ill try the tubing idea here also.  

Comments, advice ?    


Dan Hartgerink



'87 944

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 10:16:38 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911's...Something ELSE to worry about?

> I have a GuardsRed '87 Targa and live in the southeast suburbs of Houston.

In general, Houston has been a good place for my cars. The 911 was Grand
Prix White, and as a result nearly completely invisible to the cops. Too
many people tooling around in triple black turbos and guards red cabs
to pay attention to a white 911, I guess.

Parking is seldom something I worry about. You park the car, you come back,
if there are dents/dings/etc, then that's just entropy. If I can't deal
with that, then I shouldn't be driving then car. As it turns out, I have
cars that fall into that category; they DO NOT get driven anyplace
that I have to leave them -- outdoor cafes are fine, but even the post office
is a no-no. None of my 914s or 356s, or the 911SC have fallen into that
category though. And I can't imagine owning a newer Porsche and feeling
that way - even a new 993 or Boxter.

> With "few exceptions", I've had nothing but admiring glances.  Now for the
> few exceptions....

And then there's the "I guess this is admiring" category. Just before
Christmas, I was at the Galleria, doing some last minute shopping. In
the 356, of course. So when I was done, I headed back to the car just in
time to see a trio of obviously high-school girls sort of wandering in
circles around my car. I heard one say "But it's SOOOOoooo *OLD*". Another
said "Maybe but it's really cute" to which the third responded "Yeah, sort
of like Dillon's car, with a hat on." They scattered when I got closer,
figuring that I had to be at least as old as the car...

Sigh. That's what too much TV will do for you I guess...

> I can handle "Pennies from Heaven" and "Raining Cats and Dogs", but some
> bastard dropping a bottle...."The Gods Must Be Crazy".

Ouch. Not as bad as the woman killed on US 59 when someone tossed a
cinder block through her windshield, but still you were DAMN lucky.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 10:09:16 CST
From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: Answer to vibration & idle probs.

Greetings Philers!

I think I figured out why my idle is high (and climbing); why the car 
takes two tries to start when cold, and what what the vibration problem 
is.

It seems the previous owner may have upped the idle to 1100rpm in my 951S 
to cover up a bad passenger side motor mount!  

I remember from previous 944 experiences that a bad passenger motor mount 
will cause the car and steering wheel to vibrate at idle.  This tends to 
smooth out over 1000rmp.  Since mine idles at 1100, I really never noticed 
it; UNTIL, I turned on the AC when the car was cold and it began idling at 
850.  Lots of vibration then.  I thought to myself, "I've had this problem 
before."  

So, if I could get a little bit of net wisdom to check my logic:

1) Bad passenger motor mount causes car and steering wheel to vibrate at 
idle.

2) Less than honest seller ups the idle to 1100rmp to hide problem.  Says 
that car has a small vacuum leak.

3) High idle and hard start are due to car's systems (brain?) having 
problems dealing the the higher than normal idle setting.

4) Fixing the motor mount and readjusting the idle should fix the 
vibrations, idle creep and hard starting.

George, everybody, does this should plausible or did I miss something?

Thank you all for your help!!!

Bert
'88 951S



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 12:04:34 -0500
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: '72S versus '74S

Mike and Eric,

The two cars are really very different:

'72S: old body style, MFI, 190 hp, 2.4-max displacement on mag case without
problems, built in oil cooler radiator (the loop-cooler came in '73) Classic
"S" ride but with reasonable low end torque.

'74S: newer body style, a little heavier, 175 HP with CIS.  2.7 liter, most
with case problems.  Last of the non-smog cars (good from that standpoint).
 aux-oil -cooler not standard but avialable.  Nice driver, less cam.  Not as
quick or fast as the '72S.  Published Top end on '72 is 143 mph and '74 is
137, I beleive.

Mike is right, with flares added and a few options the '74S can become a
Carrera; the engines were the same unless you find a euro-Carrera which had
the 911.83 "RS" 210 hp motor (great car!).  Most Carrera's had ext. loop oil
coolers, power windows, etc.

I put 100k on a '74S and now have a '72S.  

 -Allen Henderson-

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 11:11:45 CST
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: 911's...Something ELSE to worry about?

> As we approached, a guy lined up over my lane and dropped a bottle.

This is not a Porsche thing...  It's happened at least three times
in the past year or so here.  Always to folks in "OldsmoBuicks".
One man killed on I-94 near Eau Claire, WI when teenagers dropped a
chunk of concrete from an overpass.  A woman and her husband killed
when someone dropped a *street light* from an overpass on I-494.
Most recently - teens dropped a chunk of concrete from a pedestrian
overpass on a county highway in one of the eastern suburbs.  Driver
was struck in the head, but survived.

mike
mjt@adc.com

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 11:24:17 -0600
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Cat. Conv. on '75 914?

Hello Porschephilers,

This has been bugging me for a while now.
My '75 914 1.8L didn't have a catalytic converter on it when I bought it.  It just has a straight pipe
connecting the primary and secondary mufflers.  I don't know if the previous owner removed it,
or if it came from the factory without one.  I believe the 914 was originally a California car.  At
least I bought it in California back in '86 when I lived there and the owners manual has service
stamps from California Porsche dealers.  The car always passed the emission tests and the
guys doing the testing never bothered to check the exhaust system for a converter.  Of course
the "You pass or you don't pay" places that I went to have a lot of motivation to pass the car. 
Here in Minnesota, testing starts with the '76 model year so I just squeeked by!

Did all '75 and '76 914's have catalytic converters?  Just the 2.0L models?  Were 914's sold in
California equipped differently than the others?

Thanks for any info,
Pete


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 12:09:15 EST
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re: Marellli distributor

Bill says:
>>A friend of mine has a '69 2.0  911T with a bad Marelli distributor--<<

Yo Bill, IMHO, *ALL* Marelli Distributors are bad.  Replace it with a Bosch
006. There is a slightly different advance curve, but your friend will
never notice it. New, these are around $600.00. Rebuilt, $300.00 or used,
$150.00. BTW, the '69-'71 Marelli has a centrifugal advance, not vacuum.
(Or, at least mine does).

>>On another note, on my 72 911T,...I bought two tensioner clamp-on
blocks...Supposely they will prevent the nasty tensioner failure many of us
older 911 owners fear...<<

These "blocks" will *NOT* prevent tensioner failure. They just prevent
total collapse of the piston. The tensioner can fail and you may never know
it's happened. I use the mechanical (solid) ones on my race car, but I pull
the covers and check the tension twice each season.

Barney Bettilyon
cmxk95a@prodigy.com
'70 914-6 racer
'89 Carrera Cab


------------------------------

Date: 12 Jan 95 12:40:56 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Transmission oil -- Swepco prices

 
Don Rutherford reports that Twinks is selling Swepco (I presume the 201
variety) for $45.50 or $46.95 a gallon.
 
DON'T BUY FROM TWINKS!!! I have never found any product in a Twinks catalog
that wasn't available cheaper elsewhere. (Almost anyelsewhere). You pay for
the slick catalog and their inept staff. I don't mind paying high prices if
you get something in return, such as Stoddard's expertise, and quick and
accurate delivery of high-quality parts, but Twinks has no redeeming social
value.
 
This price is about $5.50 to $7.00 higher than the same product, seen yesterday
at the local VW hot rod shop (Kymco, Costa Mesa, CA). And swap meet prices are
typcially $30 a gallon (Troutman usually brings a few gallons of 201 to the
Pomona swap meets; his non-swap meet price is probably higher).
 
(Later)
I just called Kymco, confirmed that their price is $39.99, and that they
will ship, with Visa or Mastercard. Their number is 714-642-1835. Since
Kymco and Twinks' Long Beach shop are only about 20 miles apart, I can't
imagine shipping being that much different for people who are, say, west of
the Mississippi and don't use the Twinks Indianapolis operation.
 
The other source, Troutman, can be reached at 1-800-356-9307 or
1-619-699-9277 (Temecula, CA). I just called there and confirmed, the price
is indeed $30. Go for it.
 
Pete

Greetings Philers!

I think I figured out why my idle is high (and climbing); why the car takes two tries to start when cold, and what what the vibration problem is.

It seems the previous owner may have upped the idle to 1100rpm in my 951S to cover up a bad passenger side motor mount!  

I remember from previous 944 experiences that a bad passenger motor mount will cause the car and steering wheel to vibrate at idle.  This tends to smooth out over 1000rmp.  Since mine idles at 1100, I really never noticed it; UNTIL, I turned on the AC when the car was cold and it began idling at 850.  Lots of vibration then.  I thought to myself, "I've had this problem before."  

So, if I could get a little bit of net wisdom to check my logic:

1) Bad passenger motor mount causes car and steering wheel to vibrate at idle.

2) Less than honest seller ups the idle to 1100rmp to hide problem.  Says that car has a small vacuum leak.

3) High idle and hard start are due to car's systems (brain?) having problems dealing the the higher than normal idle setting.

4) Fixing the motor mount and readjusting the idle should fix the vibrations, idle creep and hard starting.

If I am tooling along a country lane and I see an unattended  horse on the 
verge, I assume that it will bolt at any moment.

especially if he is in a "high risk" category.

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 13:17 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re:924/924S To buy or not to buy

JoshB999@aol.com wrote in to say:
	In  a response to my previous message on whether or not to buy a 924S or a
	924  Byron D. Short wrote.
	
	>ARE YOU NUTS?!  Oops, not as delicate as I had planned!  Sorry. Start over.
	The 924S is a FABULOUS Porsche among the water pumpers.  It is, as you
	say, a 944 in the lighter body of a 924.  IOW, it's typically quicker than
	a 944, and since it's also a little narrower it's the C Stock weapon of
	choice over the 944.  Best of all, many (I've heard "all" but I can't
	confirm) of these cars came with the M030 suspension, which would account
	for it's responsiveness <end quote>

Hmmm, this sounds a little odd, since I have been told that almost all of the 
944s equipped with the M030 suspension were Playboy Cup racers (i.e., it is a
pretty uncommon option), and that the suspension was a little stiff for 
everyday use.  Still, I suppose they're out there somewhere.
	
	Well I haven't been accused of being real sane since I am buying a Porsche
	but I did decide to get the 924S.  I should be picking it up this weekend,
	and I got for 3k which from what I understand is pretty good on the price.
	As Byron said the main reason to get one of these cars is the fact that they
	tend to be lighter and quicker than a comparable 944.  The main question I
	have is ,  Why would anyone disconnect the power steering and is there any
	reason I can't just remove the damn thing? As far as I am concerned the only
	vehicle that *needs* power steering is a tank or a semi-truck.

Apparently this is a pretty common failure mode for the 944.  I know I passed
on an '86 951 because when I put it up on the rack there was a lot of PS fluid
dripping from somewhere.  I would imagine that the previous owner had a leak
and just disconnected the pump to stop it.  Given the price of steering racks,
you may want to just leave it disconnected.

Good luck with the car -- I'm sure you'll love it!

Tracy Nelson (tnelson@telesciences.com)
'87 944S

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 10:43:54 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Swepco

> 
> 
> I want (have) to change my trans oil for my 83 911SC. I have phoned 
> around to some dealers, and the consensus is that Swepco is the best
> (quote : "The ONLY oil to use" ) for the tranny. However, up here in 
> Canada, its $18.00/litre (roughly $45 US/US gal).
> 
> First of all, is this the oil of choice, and is this price reasonable?
> 

Swepco gets MY vote, also in an '83 SC.  I first tried Valvoline, then
Redline MTL (good in my BMW experience), finally coughed up the $$ for
Swepco.  BIG improvement in the lame 2nd gear synchro with the initial
fill-up, and a small improvement with each change since (6 each @ 15k
miles...).  The price sucks, I'm sure there's a truck stop somewhere
that would fill a milk jug with it for $10, but so far I've paid the
boutique prices... so far it's cheaper than the OTHER solution to the
2nd gear synchro problem.

Just don't tell yr. wife how much it costs!

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC
'72 2002tii



------------------------------

Date: 12 Jan 95 13:48:11 EST
From: "Byron D. Short" <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: Sparts Car Communist Assholes

>> Previous Porsches: '73 914 1.7 converted from 914 2.0 . . .

>Okay, I'm curious.  Usually we hear about conversions from the 1.7 to
>something more powerful.  Why would one convert to a 1.7?  Is there a
>story to be heard here?

Not much of one. . .  My 73 was originally a 2.0 and Steve Compton helped
me get it legal and competitive.  Unfortunately I was in his class, he
drove a 74 914 2.0, so through the course of our Pro Solo seasons we took
just enough points away from each other to truly annoy.  In the winter we
began to look over the specs on the 1.7, which at that time was down one
class in DS.  The popular wisdom was that the car couldn't compete, but we
felt it would dominate any tight track and we could let the Hondas and
Nissans split wins on the open courses.  It worked well for both of us. 
Steve went on to the CS National Championship while I won the DS title and
the Sexy-Mexi (my wife Yvonne) took runner up in DSLadies.  Along the way
not everything went well, as you SCCA regulars will remember. . .but
that's a long, boring and painful story I'd rather not re-live.

Byron Short

87 944 Turbo  Damned ugly daily driver
90 944S2 M030  More serious than ever for '95

synthetic.  does this sound reasonable ?

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 13:19:22 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; more POR-15 vs. Miracle Paint 

>From: Dr914@aol.com
>Subject: re POR-15

>Dear Jonathan,
>We have tried Miracle paint and everything else. POR-15 is best. That is why
>we sell it. We want the best for our 914s and it is not affected by UV;
>that's nuts! We have been restoring Porsches since 1977 and experimented with
>everything, sometimes learning the hard way. POR-15 is the best!

>George Hussey

     Uh, sorry George, but I talked to POR-15 (800-45-POR15) who says that
 POR-15 -IS- UV sensitive and must be topcoated !  This is the same
 recommendation JC Whitney makes for their "Miracle Paint" but was denied
 via example by Bill Hirsch for -their- "Miracle Paint" (eg, they used it as
 topcoat over a cement floor). Makes you wonder why they bother selling
 3 colors (clear, silver, black--again, just like "Miracle Paint") when you
 have to topcoat anyways, or how much you buy (for brake fluid or battery
 acid immunity) when your weakest link in the chain is the topcoat...

     I asked POR-15 if their stuff is the same as "Miracle Paint" but got
 the same vague, delayed "I don't know" answer that Bill Hirsch gave me.
 Bill Hirsch claims they tried POR-15 but it didn't work well in a battery
 box; yet POR-15 claims to be immune to battery acids....Hmmm, maybe JC
 Whitney has a tech help line (ooohhhh...).
         
     Bottom line, apparently POR-15 and Corroless and Miracle Paint all
 make great rust primers, probably better than Dp-90 or Dupont's epoxy
 primers. POR-15 and Bill Hirsch make great marketers too; and make me really
 wish I could get a straight answer (or just a convincing response !). 
 I'm tempted to order a can from either, look at the source of manufacture
 and ingredients to compare--but then again.....

                   -Lee A.

In  a response to my previous message on whether or not to buy a 924S or a

>ARE YOU NUTS?!  Oops, not as delicate as I had planned!  Sorry. Start over.
The 924S is a FABULOUS Porsche among the water pumpers.  It is, as you
say, a 944 in the lighter body of a 924.  IOW, it's typically quicker than
a 944, and since it's also a little narrower it's the C Stock weapon of
choice over the 944.  Best of all, many (I've heard "all" but I can't
confirm) of these cars came with the M030 suspension, which would account
for it's responsiveness <end quote>

Well I haven't been accused of being real sane since I am buying a Porsche
but I did decide to get the 924S.  I should be picking it up this weekend,
and I got for 3k which from what I understand is pretty good on the price.
 As Byron said the main reason to get one of these cars is the fact that they
tend to be lighter and quicker than a comparable 944.  The main question I
have is ,  Why would anyone disconnect the power steering and is there any
reason I can't just remove the damn thing?  As far as I am concerned the only
vehicle that *needs* power steering is a tank or a semi-truck.

Byron-->  I will check to see if it has the M030 suspension when I pick it
up, can you tell me what more about it or recommend a good book on Porsche
suspensions.  I haven't found much in any of the Dallas bookstores.

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 15:01:56 +0000
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Something ELSE...."high risk" category

In message <199501121920.LAA10292@radiomail.net>  writes:
> >If I see a person on a bridge, I try to avoid passing directly under him
> >especially if he is in a "high risk" category.

Hi Chris,

>    I'm not sure I understand.  Exactly what characteristics visible from a
>    moving car would place a person in this high risk demographic?

Hmmmmm...We haven't been out on our own for very long, have we?  (he said with
a big grin on his silly gesicht...)  In many parts of the world, including many
parts of the the good ol' US and A, the ability to accurately answer your 
question is (all too frequently) all the separates the quick from the dead.

But, since we all gotta start somewhere (the old soldier reluctantly said, with 
a pained expression on his ugly mug), if you see *any* person standing on a 
highway over-pass, you might reasonably consider that person to be a potential 
malefactor on that ground alone.  (Unless you're in West Virginia, in which 
case you can relax, it's just one of the local citizens out for the excitment 
of seein' all them cars movin' on a *flat* surface.)

If that person is also apparently a *young* person, (we all know how prone to 
mischief the young can be), you would be advised to increment the threat
rating at least one click.  Of course, the earlier exception still applies, 
and, naturally, I could be mistaken.  Sure! Lots of youngsters go watch 
traffic when there's nothing on MTV...

If said YP has a hat on backwards, and is apparently keenly observing the 
on-comming traffic below, increment the threat factor another click or two.

If said YP is further observed to be holding anything in aloft, say a large
rock or chunk of concrete...[the remainder of this is left as an exercise for 
the stoont...]




Bart Chambers

'77 Feline Varmint Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweis

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 12:05:51 -0800
From: rsaldana@qualcomm.com (Rolando Saldana)
Subject: Re: Fwd:Answer to vibration & idle probs.

Porschephiles,

My 944 has been suffering from a vibration when in reverse gear. Back when
the car was inspected prior to my purchasing it, the mechanic pointed out
that the vibration indicated motor mounts needed replacement. Turbo upgrade
mounts were procured and taken to a local P-mechanic for installation.
Well, the vibration in reverse persists.  There is no noticeable vibration
at idle (which BTW is not set to 1100 rpm), so I do not plan to readjust
the idle just yet.

At this point I am assuming that the mechanic did his job and the mounts
were installed correctly. What other sources are known to cause this
vibration? 

Thank you all for being a constant source of great information .


Rolando A. Saldana
Engineering
QUALCOMM, Inc.
619-658-4170



------------------------------

Date: 12 Jan 95 15:03:00 EST
From: "Byron D. Short" <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: 924/924S To buy or not to buy?

Congratulations Josh!

>Why would anyone disconnect the power steering and is there any
>reason I can't just remove the damn thing?  As far as I am concerned the
>only vehicle that *needs* power steering is a tank or a semi-truck.

The racks tend to leak, so one choice is to drain the system and remove
the pump.  If you want to fix the rack there was a thread about this in
just the last couple weeks.  Removing the power steering (and possibly
installing it on any tanks you may have parked in the back yard <g>) is a
good idea for street use; not legal for SCCA stock, I'm sure another
'philer can advise you regarding PCA stock?  

>Byron-->  I will check to see if it has the M030 suspension when I pick
>it up, can you tell me what more about it or recommend a good book on
>Porsche suspensions.  I haven't found much in any of the Dallas
>bookstores.

The BEST book is the full Porsche workshop manual series, about $350. The
best book priced within reason, however, is the PORSCHE 944/924S
Technical Specifications book, also direct from Porsche, about $12 I
think.  It's tiny size (about 3.5" X 4.5") conceals a wealth of
knowledge, including such oddities as M030 spring rates versus standard,
sway bars, shocks, etc.  Worth almost as much as the full shop manual
series, but don't tell that to Porsche!

Byron Short

87 944 Turbo  --  Damn, just gets uglier every time I look at it.
90 944S2 M030 --  Ahh, that's better.

chunk of concrete from an overpass.  A woman and her husband killed

overpass on a county highway in one of the eastern suburbs.  Driver
was struck in the head, but survived.

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 14:26:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.ncr.com>
Subject: RE: Cat. Conv. on '75 914?



From: pete.klager

Hello Porschephilers,

This has been bugging me for a while now.
My '75 914 1.8L didn't have a catalytic converter on it when I bought it. 
 It
just has a straight pipe
connecting the primary and secondary mufflers.  I don't know if the previous
owner removed it,
or if it came from the factory without one.  I believe the 914 was 
originally
a California car.  At
least I bought it in California back in '86 when I lived there and the 
owners
manual has service
stamps from California Porsche dealers.  The car always passed the emission
tests and the
guys doing the testing never bothered to check the exhaust system for a
converter.  Of course
the "You pass or you don't pay" places that I went to have a lot of
motivation to pass the car.
Here in Minnesota, testing starts with the '76 model year so I just squeeked
by!

Did all '75 and '76 914's have catalytic converters?  Just the 2.0L models?
Were 914's sold in
California equipped differently than the others?

Thanks for any info,
Pete

==  The '76 I bought has all the hooks and evidence there
==  was a cat system on it.  The quick giveaway is the two
== indicators on either side of the inst cluster, one for overtemp
== and one for 'change me time'.  There should be a small black
== box in the trunk's driver side tail inside.  That box is a temp sensor
== for the cat and is wired to the dash indicator.  Apparently, the cats
== on these were constantly monitored by a probe in the cat.
==          On the passenger side
== footwell there is a foam block with a compartment provided for the
== speedo cable tick counter, in effect cars with this feature have two
== speedo cables.  The counter is inline.  There are reset buttons on
== the counter body to extinquish the dash indicator after the magic
== count has arrived.  Pity the poor soul whereupon that day arrives!!
==  I think a lot of people replace the cat/muffler mess with a MONZA
== since they make a bolt-on swap.  I almost wish I had those leftovers
== from the carnage. . .
==
==  In the engine bay, there should be an air pump mounted atop the
==  blower housing.  There should be steel tube plumbing for each cylinder
== to provide dilutionary air, and possibly a branch circuit to provide
== reaction air to the cat (some models varied, if memory serves).
==  The exhaust plumbing for these turkeys is different than the 73 and
== 74 models;  more U-bends and less flowthru for the heat exchanger.
==  It's a double whammy (imho) because not only do you get a poorer
== performing exhaust, but you also get a poorer performing heater. . .
==  The obvious intention behind this newer plumbing was to make
== way for the cat *and* muffler.
==
== BTW,
==   I wonder how difficult it would be to 'roll my own' cat and muffler
== system for the 73 and 74 year model header system?  In stainless?
==   Hmmm, I see Whitney has dual in and out cats.. .
==
==  A while back, I had to investigate some problems with a melting cat
== and I found out that at full throttle, a cat only restricts 2 to %5.
==  The article went on to describe a simple way to test cat exhaust
== systems for plugged cats by substituting an air fitting for the
== oxygen sensor and measuring the gas pressure while operating.
== Anything over 5-10? psi indicates a plug.
==
==  That's all I have been able to glean from my manuals and specimen . . .
==
==  -kyle          Saga's floopan has arrived. . .

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 15:37:57 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 factory service manuals

> I am interested in acquiring, at a reasonable cost of course, a set of factor
> service manuals for my '87' 944. As I understand it, I need the 924, 1976 - 8
> (4 volumes: WKD.481.521) & 944, 1983 - 89 (6 volumes: WKD.481.821).
> 
> 	Tim Pinckney
> 	Rochester, N.Y.
> 	(716) 427-5638, tsp:henr801a:xerox

Hi, Tim,

I just acquired a set of the 944 factory service manuals on microfiche for
@26 from Stoddard.

The PCNA part number is PNA 000 127.  The part number for the 944 Turbo
service manyal is PNA 000 126 (cost is $12 for that item.)

The manuals seem to be complete, if a bit difficult to use, but I understand
that Xerox used to do some work in micrography, so you might be able to 
use this information more than others...

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
(800)ALL-P944/(914)658-9593

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 12:43:00 -0800
From: bill@bpetersen.com (Bill Petersen)
Subject: More -P- envy 

From the January issue of Pandemonium, Orange Coast Region edetorial:

<snip>

This month I have a Bitch I'd like to get off my chest. You may remember
that on the last Tour a La Grape your ole tour leader got the first ticket
in 23 years of leading that event. To to it off I got the citation for
going too slow. 50 mph in a 55 mph zone. Since it is a long way to go to
appear in court I pleaded Not Guilty by a declaration, explaining the whole
fiasco that the officer said I was holding up traffic when the fifteen cars
following me were part of my group proceeding to make a left turn. I posted
the $179.00 fine with the declaration fully expecting justice to prevail.
To my surprise I received a notice that I had been found guilty and was
fined another $100.00 on top of the $179.00

It is no wonder the average person has no respect for the judicial system.
The officer could have caused a serious accident the way he drove on the
left side of the hiway and broke into our column. Our group spent over
$10,000, with the motel, meals and the wine purchases, let alone the
gasoline spent in the area on that weekend. Needless to say it will be a
cold day in hell before this person leads another tour to or spends a dime
in San Luis Obispo county. G.V.McC.

<snip>

The author is retired and 70ish. His red 928 must have looked at the
officer the wrong way.

...Bill

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 15:48:45 US/Eastern

> that the vibration indicated motor mounts needed replacement. Turbo upgrade
> mounts were procured and taken to a local P-mechanic for installation.
> Well, the vibration in reverse persists.  There is no noticeable vibration
> at idle (which BTW is not set to 1100 rpm), so I do not plan to readjust

> were installed correctly. What other sources are known to cause this
> vibration?

> 
> 
> Rolando A. Saldana
> Engineering
> QUALCOMM, Inc.
> 619-658-4170
>

Hi, Rolando,

We will need a bit more information about your car:

1) 5 Speed or Automatic?

2) If 5 speed, any vibration in any other gear?

3) If 5 speed, clutch pedal in or out?

4) Describe the vibration:  Felt in seat of pants, steering wheel, Shift
Knob, other?

5) Any other oddities about the car? 

6) What year is the car? What transmission options (LSD)?

7) Any other observations about the vibration (e.g. only when cold, never
when cold, just after putting it into reverse, when stopping from reversing,
etc.)

Sorry to be such a pain about the symptoms, but the only other alternative
is for you to bring it by and show me ...   :-)

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 16:25:15 -0500

I  have 69 T and I removed the the Maretti distributor and replaced with
Bosch.  The car was running fine with the Maretti but when we rebuilt to 2.2

to the Carrera chain tensioners but used the same as you without problems.

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 15:30:59 -0600
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  RE: Cat. Conv. on '75 914?

Kyle Ehler writes:
==  The '76 I bought has all the hooks and evidence there
==  was a cat system on it.  The quick giveaway is the two
== indicators on either side of the inst cluster, one for overtemp
== and one for 'change me time'.  There should be a small black
== box in the trunk's driver side tail inside.

I don't have the black box in the trunk.  I do have the cat. "change me"
indicator on the dash, but instead of an Overtemp lamp, I have an EGR
"service me" indicator.  And my 1.8L does have an EGR system installed.

==          On the passenger side
== footwell there is a foam block with a compartment provided for the
== speedo cable tick counter, in effect cars with this feature have two
== speedo cables.  The counter is inline.  There are reset buttons on
== the counter body to extinquish the dash indicator after the magic
== count has arrived.  Pity the poor soul whereupon that day arrives!!

Yep, I've got the tick counter.  My indicator lights have never gone off.
I've had the car from 120,000 miles through 168,000 miles.

==  I think a lot of people replace the cat/muffler mess with a MONZA
== since they make a bolt-on swap.  I almost wish I had those leftovers
== from the carnage. . .

That what I did (Monza setup).  I still have the original primary/straight pipe/secondary
muffler system in my garage.  Pretty rusty though...

==  In the engine bay, there should be an air pump mounted atop the
==  blower housing.

My 1.8L doesn't have an air pump.  I think only the 2.0L's did.

Maybe what happened is that the cat "change me" light went off on the
previous owner (or the cat plugged up) and they changed it by putting in
the straight pipe and then disconnected all the "change me" electrics.

Pete

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 16:22:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Jacking up a Porsche


>Any comments on this placement for a 944?

You can use the torsion bar carrier, either inside or outside the member
you mention.  Or the control arm pick-ups, or the frame rails.  There is
also, of course, the side-centre pads and the official dimples at the four
corners.  If you're jacking the car onto jackstands, generally best to
use the side-centre pad for the floor jack and the dimples for the
jack stands.  If you do use the suspension points, be a little careful.

On the 911 side of things, I recall a comment made by John Paterak a
few years back.  Apparently the 930's were heavy enough that he had
seen a number of them tear their square jack pad receiver channel
when it was used with a pad.  However, it is the best way, IMHO, to get
the job done on 911's.

Kevin Gross

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 16:36:36 CST
From: wpcostel@porsche.aud.alcatel.com (William Costello)
Subject: Swepco

The question about SWEPCO 201 Multi-Purpose Gear Lube being worth the money
was answered by Bruce Anderson in the Technical Notes column of the December
1991 issue of Excellence. The summery is that it SWEPCO 201 is very good for
915 transmissions. One gallon is required for filling an empty 915 transmission.

Who SWEPCO is:

          Southwestern Petroleum Corporation
          PO Box 789
          Fort Worth, TX
          76101

          1-800-359-LUBE

SWEPCO 201 can be purchsed at the SWEPO facility in Fort Worth or ordered over
the telephone and shipped to you. The last price I got from them was $134 for
a case of 6 1-gallon jugs. Thats about $24 per gallon with tax for local
pickup. A case is the minimum amount sold. This will give you an idea of
the markup of products sold by big Porsche mail order operations.

Zims will pump SWEPCO 201 into a clean jug for $32 a gallon from a drum if you
stop by. If you order SWEPCO 201 by mail, they charge more since it comes in
the 1-gallon jug packaged by SWEPCO. Zims prices are always less that the
dealer and most other mail order operations. The people at Zims are always
as nice as can be and will help answer any questions, even some of the
stupid ones that I have asked while learning to maintain my car.

W.P. Costello

86 911 Carrera in Meteor Gray Metallic
87 Buick Skylark (152K and still going)
94 Pontiac Grand-Am (provided by Mary Kay Cosmetics)
Z, OJ, Stormy, and Porsche (out loyal/lazy cats)

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 14:37:28 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 factory service manuals

| From:  <tsp.henr801a@xerox.com>
|
| I am interested in acquiring, at a reasonable cost of course, a set 
of factory
| service manuals for my '87' 944. As I understand it, I need the 924, 
1976 - 82
| (4 volumes: WKD.481.521) & 944, 1983 - 89 (6 volumes: WKD.481.821).

I have an '84 and bought only the 944 '83-'89 set. The only thing not covered
is the interior and dash, as that is the only thing the pre-85.5 944 has in
common with the (non-S) 924. The Haynes manual mostly makes up
for that, and is much less $$. Since your car is an '87, I don't 
believe there is
any reason at all to have the 924 manual set (unless you have spare money).

I got the manual set from the local P-dealer for $165, which is 
considerably less
than list. Not sure if they were just tired of it sitting on a shelf or what...

    Eric

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 15:21:23 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Ignition choice for a Weber'd 3.0 SC

Hi Al:

I have a 914-4, not a six, but this may be of interest to you.  The 4 has a
conventional ignition (points and a coil).  I recently replaced the points
with a Pertronix ignitor (popular with the VW crowd, fits entirely within
the distributor where the points were, it's a magnetic-type pickup).  It
works very nicely, and supposedly they've sold 1,000,000 so far. I feel
it's much better than the Allison unit, for example.

The trouble is, all their units have been for 4-cylinder cars _until right
now_.  Within a month or so a 6-cylinder version is coming out. These units
will work with the MSD 6-series (at least the 4's did).

I just bought an MSD 6AL and will be installing it on a BMW straight-six
(now w/points, later w/Pertronix).  If you like, I'll keep you informed.


 ________________________________________
|  Andrew E. Kalman     aek@netcom.com   |
|       standard disclaimers apply       |
 ________________________________________

Date: 12 Jan 95 21:19:29 EST
From: "Byron D. Short" <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re:  SCCA "Stock" rules

Al Johanson wrote,

>What about those little clamps that you can install on the older >hydraulic
tensioners which prevent total collapse of the piston *WHEN* >it fails?  I had
these on one of my engines and it saved me thousands of >dollars.  They only
weigh a few ounces and are *PURELY* a safety >device.... are those illegal too?

Yep.  The book says if it isn't explicity listed it isn't allowed.  I'm going to
ask Mike Piera to submit any Porsche directives on the subject and see if we
could get a FasTrack entry on this.  Chances are not particularly good, but it's
worth getting another letter since the SEB has rolled over three and shortly
four members in the last year or so.  I can't remember if I gave my long
explanation through the whole list or just to another p-philer directly, but
I'll paraphrase the reasoning for you here.

The PCA is handling one marque and in this capacity has no difficulty dealing
with special circumstances like tensioners.  The SCCA is working with over 900
seperate models in the current Stock category listing.  Whereas PCA can and does
deal in specifics, SCCA is forced to deal in generalities.  What we pass as a
rule should apply equally to Hondas, Subarus, and the aforementioned Studebakers
and Hudsons.  

Every rule proposal to the SEB must be considered as a precedent which will be
applied to all those other 900 cars.  This breeds a paranoia that if we approve
chain tensioners on 911s the '38 Hupmobile could use this same logic to gain an
extra 2 horsepower by altering the geometry of the reverse idler muffler-cam
drive assembly to dissipate heat in the flugal joint.  Or something.  

In the final analysis SCCA tends to throw their hands up and run away.  A noble
act, I'll admit. ;-) BTW, I'm as capable as the rest at fleeing the scene of an
impending thought-process, so I'm not pointing fingers here.  
Let's take a run at it one more time, whaddya say?  I encourage Mike Piera to
get us some info on what the factory "allows", versus what they "encourage" and
what they "require" on tensioners.  Required factory directives and recalls are
legal in stock; can we show them one?  Or at least a strong factory
recommendation?  If it's an absolute imperative to have to keep from grenading
the motor, shouldn't there be a factory directive requiring them from Porsche?
Also, try to cover any possible legal methods (or lack thereof) of attaining the
same benefit.     Include your own suggested wording which covers the bases
without leaving loopholes which could allow unexpected performance-enhancing
interpretations is also a big plus.  Again, I suspect that it won't fly, but I'd
like to hear the discussions since I wasn't on the SEB the last time Mike wrote
in about it.  

By placing this here I'm trying to railroad, um er, recruit, yeah, that's it,
recruit Mike Piera for this.  Any objections Mike?  Your previous ride height
letters were noticed and discussed; you may have a better chance of getting the
collective ear of the SEB than most.  

Byron "Damn, I never shoulda 'fessed up to bein' on the SEB" Short

87 944 Turbo--dark out now, it looks better
90 944S2 M030--always looks good

Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 20:51:18 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: 944 throttle switches

>so it a switch rather than a pot - interesting
>
>the turbo setup may be different to the non-turbo, so what is the switch 
>supposed to do? I know that ( assuming my prob is the switch ) it causes 
>the car to loose both spark and fuel pump - feture rich these german cars 
>eh!!

Pete,

As far as I can tell, there are at least two different kinds of 944
(Motronic) throttle switches.  The two types look similar, but can be
distinguished by the number of conductors in their DME harness
connections.

The first type consists of two microswitches only and has a
3-conductor connector.  One conductor is grounded, the second
conductor is bridged to the ground conductor by switch 1 when the
throttle is closed, and the third conductor is bridged to the ground
conductor by switch 2 when the throttle is fully open.  The opening
and closing of the two switches is effected by a rotating arm driven
by the throttle shaft.  There is no potentiometer in this type of
switch.

The other type of switch is the one I have, which incorporates a
single microswitch and a potentiometer.  The DME harness connection to
this switch has 6 conductors (3 for the pot, 2 for the switch, and one
unused).  The pot rotates with the throttle shaft, and when the
throttle is closed, a little arm attached to the pot closes the
microswitch.  I'm not sure why the closed throttle information could
not be derived from the butterfly angle information provided by the
pot.  However, the circuit diagram I have indicates that the output of
the pot goes to the Knock Regulation Unit, whereas the output of the
microswitch goes to the DME (i.e., the DME doesn't see the pot output
directly), just like the first type of switch.  I am tempted to infer
from this that only the turbos have this second kind of switch, but I
am not sure about this.

If the "no-throttle" microswitches in either type are closed while
the engine speed is 1600 RPM or greater, the DME will shut off both
injection and ignition.  As far as I can tell, the main purpose for
this behavior is to save fuel while coasting: i.e. throttle and
microswitch are closed while engine speed remains above idle (unless
you're freewheeling with the clutch in).  Perhaps your switch is
shorting intermittently, making the DME think that the car is coasting
when it isn't.

Incidently, a new switch cost me $75.

Milo
'86 951

Thought for the day: "If you're not living on the edge, you're taking
up too much space".

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 08:50:52 -0500
From: Mike.Worland@DANA.COM
Subject: Ignition for Webers



Hi Al:

I have a 914-4, not a six, but this may be of interest to you.  The 4 has a
conventional ignition (points and a coil).  I recently replaced the points
with a Pertronix ignitor (popular with the VW crowd, fits entirely within
the distributor where the points were, it's a magnetic-type pickup).  It
works very nicely, and supposedly they've sold 1,000,000 so far. I feel
it's much better than the Allison unit, for example.

The trouble is, all their units have been for 4-cylinder cars _until right
now_.  Within a month or so a 6-cylinder version is coming out. These units
will work with the MSD 6-series (at least the 4's did).

I just bought an MSD 6AL and will be installing it on a BMW straight-six
(now w/points, later w/Pertronix).  If you like, I'll keep you informed.


 ________________________________________
|  Andrew E. Kalman     aek@netcom.com   |
|       standard disclaimers apply       |
 ________________________________________


Al,
 I have found another product that works well for 4 and 6 cylinder
applications. Crane Electronics manufactures an *optically * tiggered
replacement for points. This system is very simple to install in the base of
the distributor and is very reliable. I use it with MSD 6AL and it works
very nicely.  I think you would find it more reliable than a magnetically
triggered ignition system. If you are interested I can get  you the info on
the manufacturer etc...

____________________________________________
| Mike Worland    mike.worland@dana.com                |
| '71 911

        |
| standard disclaimers apply                                             |

Wayne - sounds like you were dead unlucky here, usually this sort of 
behavior is associated with small groups of cowardly young men who only 
ever do it when no one else is about.

Given two lanes to choose from I always try to avoid passing directly 
under lone youths ie take the other lane, I reason that if I take the 
other lane, at least they are presented with a more difficult shot.

This all a bit like walking under ladders - if you regularly walk under 
ladders the guy painting the upstairs window frame will drip paint from 
time to time.

There is no doubt in my mind that there is a direct link between our 
actions and the consideration we give to those actions and the results.

Given the original thread concerning p-drivers and vandalism, it is 
fairly clear to me that if you choose to park in some places you stand 
more risk of theft and vandalism. Failure to acknowledge this link is 
failure to understand (or recognise the problem)

Wayne I have sympathy with you regarding the bottle, my response was 
after all intended as a generalisation.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 08:57:22 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Muffler and heat exchanger paint


I received my Pano yesterday and was very amused at an expert (Paterek)
telling someone that VHT paint was the correct paint for a 911/356/914
factory heat exchanger.

This is where the fantasy bullsh*t starts for concours/restoration. The 
Patereks do a fine job for their customers, I like their work.

In this case, however, the factory specified a paint that had a high zinc
content. It is called `cold galvanizing' in the paint trade and can be found 
in the correct gray at many local hardware stores. NOT VHT. While VHT is 
a fine finish, it is not correct.

In applying the paint to heat exchangers or mufflers, remove all scale, oil
and other drippings. Ensure that the surface is as clean as you can get it.
Paint all outer areas. Allow to dry, it takes a couple of hours. Re-install,
the heat will turn the dark gray light. 

When I last showed my '73 911S, I had just redone the exhaust system this
way. I had a lot of questions about the `original' finish. All couldn't
believe that the paint was that easy to find.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 9:00:59 PST
From: "David O. Blanchard" <blanch@capella.cup.hp.com>
Subject: PCRs vs Solo II Rules

> To Bryon Short; Why do you believe that a basically stock 944S2 is
> uncompetitive in the Parade, my '90 S2 , a truly stock driver (Konis,rear
> bar,and road race BFGs) took second at the Lake Placid event against another
> S2 fully set up but still within Solo II rules, why not come compete.

The problem with going to Parade in a real stock car is that
there is always some person there who has a read the rules and
has prepared their car to the rules and knows how to drive the
damn thing.  This is especially true where the cars are common
(911 SCs, 944s, 911 Carrerras, etc.).  If you go less than
fully prepared, you will probably settle for a less than first
place trophy. 

The other problem is the stupid PCRs.  They allow highly non-
stock cars, but the average competitor is in a mostly-stock
car.  Only those with extreme dedication really want to drive
a fully prepped car 3000 miles.  Result: Locals (who don't
have far to drive) win large amounts of heavy hardware.  Then
there are the wierd tire rules to contend with.  You can't
just run tires that fit,  they must be of such and such a
circumference.  For most of us who go to compete, this often
means buying a set of tires we would not have otherwise bought.

After all that whining, I'll see you in Portland (with my
over prepared car on wierd sized tires)!

DavidOB --- blanch@cup.hp.com    81 924 Turbo (931, Toy car) 
Golden Gate Region PCA           
SF Region SCCA                   88 Toyota turbo All Trac

Hi, Bart.
 
Many many years ago, when it was still funny (1972? 1974?) National Lampoon
published a parody of "Boys Life" magazine, called "Boys Vice." In the young
scientist section, they had a deal about "Let's learn about physics" or
some such. "This month, we will examine the motion of falling bodies." They
then presented a nomogram with three axes -- speed of moving car, height of
bridge, and how many seconds before the car is under you, should you drop
the brick? Put ruler across first two axes, read off drop time from third.
 
My suggestion for fitting sentence for anybody convicted of this sort of
attempted or successfully completed murder: they get tied to the rear bumper
of a 911 and taken for a scrape around the Nuerburgring. Or 5 laps of Road
America. Hey, they're smooth roads, where's the problem, Ms. ACLU?

Date: 13 Jan 95 12:01:09 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: More P-envy

 
Bill Petersen's story about feeding the bears on the Rally:
 
Like Martin Walker says, it's not a fine, it's a tax. And it's going to get
worse, with things like Orange County suddenly finding it lost all the money
we gave them and now they want to find a way to get more out of us.
 
If Porsches get more tickets than other cars, red Porsches especially, it's
OK, it's politically correct, it's just that hidden Porsche tax that they
didn't tell you about at the dealer.
 
And when your insurance company finds out that you were an unsafe driver,
for examply by doing 50 in a 55 zone where everybody knows you should be
doing 70 to be safe, they can raise your premiums. That's politically
correct too because that takes that "disposable income" as the economists so
glibly call it, and gets it back into the economy where it will do some good.
Mainly for the insurance companies' ecnonomy, I suppose.
 
Nothing is going to change because, as Martin says, "I can't do it alone."
If drivers were as militant (in the non-lethal term) and organized as the
NRA, we wouldn't have this problem. But we're sheep, and they can fleece us
anytime they need more money. My militant solutions? Jam the courts by
appealing everything, including parking tickets. Appeal decisions. Sue
municipalities for entrapment. Get a lobby together with some tame lawyers
who will just harass the hell out of the system. (OK, I realize, we pay for
the system). Blockade roads in protest. Form moving chicanes going exactly
at the speed limit. Get the legislature to pass a bill making your driving
record inaccessible to third parties, such as insurance companies. If they
want to know how bad a driver you are, they should go by their own records
(of accident claims) or a database kept by the insurance companies for their
own collective use. Start referendums which will take police out of traffic
patrol and have them actually working to prevent crime. (This whole Clinton
"put another 100,000 cops on the street" only means we're going to have that
many more cops writing tickets. Yes, I know, the funding says they're
supposed to do real police work, not traffic, but do you believe it? Or are
they releasing other cops to do traffic?) Start a referendum that blocks
ticket revenue from going to the municipality or county; have it go to pay
for road work, traffic improvements, and such. Stop federal funding for
police overtime to do speed enforcement on interstate freeways (ever notice
how there are more cops out there on weekends? That's not their regular
shift; they're getting overtime at your federal taxdollars expense.) Stop
the federal blackmail of witholding tax revenue to states unless they can
prove compliance with the federal 55/65 mph speed limit.
 
No, I don't believe the National Motorists Association is ever going to
achieve anything, so no flames, don't tell me to join them because "it's a
start." It's a dead end road unless they get creative/militant/throw a
monkey wrench in the system.
 
BTW, Bill Petersen, was the cop who gave you a ticket local, county, or CHP?
Yes, raising bloody hell with the chamber of commerce/hotels/local mayor
can't possibly hurt. Have the other members of your club also send letters,
saying they are boycotting this town/county to the best of their ability.
 
Pete

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 09:15:33 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Ignition for Webers (long)

Mike writes:

>Al,
> I have found another product that works well for 4 and 6 cylinder
>applications. Crane Electronics manufactures an *optically * tiggered
>replacement for points. This system is very simple to install in the base of
>the distributor and is very reliable. I use it with MSD 6AL and it works
>very nicely.  I think you would find it more reliable than a magnetically
>triggered ignition system. If you are interested I can get  you the info on
>the manufacturer etc...

The Allison unit I mentioned previously is now sold as a Crane Cams unit. 
I've had real problems with this unit, _due to its confusing the Bosch
L-Jetronic injection computer at high rpm_.  Strangely, it did not confuse
the tach.  It makes a very nice spark, though, so on an MFI car it would
probably work nicely.  I feel the pickup is considerably flimsier than the
Pertronix unit, and of course you have to find a place to mount the
heat-sinked iginition amplifier.  I've never had a failure with either
type.  The Allison/Crane units (they're on the XR700's third major
revision) are around $100, the Pertronix is around $50. 

Chris:

Your mechanic probably tried to install the Allison _with the distributor
in the car_. Don't do this, it's too much hassle.  The Pertronix is
considerably easier to install because:

 1) the mounting pieces are made primarily of metal (nicely/precisely made,
by the way)
 2) it has way fewer parts
 3) it has no parts outside the distributor
 4) there's no need to orient the pickup so that the spark occurs "in sync"
with the rotor aligning with the cap -- this is because the "pickup's"
geometry matches the points exactly, not like the Allison/Crane, which has
to be carefully aligned inside the distributor, which can take some time.
 5) it's half the price

I encountered one problem with the Pertronix - its mounting plate had a
moon-shaped cutout to allow the vacuum advance/retard to function, but it
was too small.  30 seconds with a grinder doubled the size of this cutout,
and all was well.

The Allison/Crane has the fact that it's more "universal" going for it - it
can be had in 4-, 6- and 8-cylinder varieties, and it fits in a wide
variety of makes and models of distributors.

 ________________________________________
|  Andrew E. Kalman     aek@netcom.com   |
|       standard disclaimers apply       |
 ________________________________________


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 11:22:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: SCCA Solo II stock


Eric,

>Does stock mean "as delivered by the factory" or are you
>allowed to install factory options that were available for that
>year and model?

>For example, if I got a 944S2 without M030, could I install the
>M030 bits and still be stock?

I'm a bit out of touch with SCCA reg's of late.  However, it has
been my understanding that you may add any available, factory
option so long as you add the whole option.  In the case at hand,
if you were to add some M030 bits, you would have to add all
of them, even those which might seem frivolous or advantageous.
So, struts, control arms, spindles, brakes, bushings, bars, etc.
depending on exactly which M.Y. car you are dealing with.  And
lotsa luck documenting it to anyone who cares -- pack your
fiche reader, I guess.

Hope this helps.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 11:31:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re:  SCCA "Stock" rules


Glenn Ingram asked about this a couple of years ago.  I could not find
any official factory recommendations regarding a tensioner update,
only that it's OK to do in their eyes.  Which does not surprise me: if the
factory were to recommend it (versus OK'ing it), they would be exposing
themselves to warranty/service action legal madness.

With respect to the SCCA's exposure to a bazzilion little model-specific
tech nits, keep in mind that they are also keen to keep costs down.  If
they were to allow much more latitude in non-performance mod's, it would
arguably create a situation where people felt they needed to make all
those changes to play in the game, raising the real or perceived cost of
entry.  Yes, zinged valves are more expensive than a Carrera tensioner
kit, but that put the SCCA back on the spot of calibrating exactly how
likely it is for a street race car to lose its chain tension, which is 
basically
impossible.  (I personally have no opinion on this SCCA issue!)

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 10:20:34 -0800 (PST)
From: Tom Feller <tomf@mxim.com>
Subject: Gear Oils

In the 15 years or so I was VW/Audi/Porsche mechanic the gear oil issue 
has come up many times. I used to have several factory serive notices 
about gear oil. The key is is most gear oils you buy are TOO 
slippery. Porsche calls for a GL-3 gear oil not GL-5 or Gl-6.  GL-3 can be 
almost impossible to find without special ordering the oil.
This is a case where a upgrade to GL-4,5 or 6 is a problem. The sycro 
rings are desgined to have a given fiction between the inside of the ring 
and hub on the gear. If gear oil is to too slippery the fiction is 
reduced and the shifting can be poor. In addition over time the inside 
of the ring becomes polished and the car will never shift right.
The first shop I worked at was a old and very 
respected air cooled porsche shop and they did and still do only use 
Sweepco. But later I work for another very well respected shop we used a 
special VW/Porsche gear oil made by Kendal. Both gear oils work quite well 
and often fixed the poor shifting caused by used the wrong gear oil. Many 
shops do not want to stock several different grades of gear oil so the 
supplier tells them that this or that multi-grade GL-5/GL-6 will do the 
job for all cars and so people end up with the wrong oil in their 
transmissions. I when I had my own shop it took me months to get the 
right gear lube from my Valvoline supplier but finally after months of 
telling him that I needed a GL-3 only gear lube he "found" the right number 
and ordered me some the correct product in. It too worked quite well with 
never shifting problem on my rebuilds.


 - Tom Feller

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1070                         Fri Jan 13 17:41:11 CST 1995
Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 11:37:34 -0700
From: "Drew A. Spencer" <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Letter from Monty Smith re:Parade Club Race


I've been asked to forward the following letter to the list
from Monte Smith, past president of the Intermountain Region PCA.
Any questions or comments should be directed to him.

Begin Included message
- -----------------------

The following was received from Monte Smith:

Some clarification is needed after the interesting slant in the report
of 1/12: The decision that there would be no Parade Club Race was reached
after three frustrating months of work.  We received very little help from
the Portland Parade Committee (they wouldn't even discuss the issue at their
last meeting) and were snubbed by the track.

As a last ditch effort we contacted the groups who have the track on the 

weekend following Parade and, when we found they might be willing to let
us use those dates, we approached the track people.  They ruled, however,
that they would not allow those groups to give us their dates.  What is 

important is that we never attempted to go around PIR management and that 

they found out about it because we approached them. 


At present, some PCA National Board Members are attempting to convince the
Portland group to let us use PIR for two of the five Parade days; it is
very doubtful that this will happen.  Frustration. Fini.

- -------------------
END Included message

Drew

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 13:56:14 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: PCRs vs Solo II Rules

>> To Bryon Short; Why do you believe that a basically stock 944S2 is
>> uncompetitive in the Parade, my '90 S2 , a truly stock driver (Konis,rear
>> bar,and road race BFGs) took second at the Lake Placid event against another
>> S2 fully set up but still within Solo II rules, why not come compete.
>
>The problem with going to Parade in a real stock car is that
>there is always some person there who has a read the rules and
>has prepared their car to the rules and knows how to drive the
>damn thing.  This is especially true where the cars are common
>(911 SCs, 944s, 911 Carrerras, etc.).  If you go less than
>fully prepared, you will probably settle for a less than first
>place trophy. 

This is less true in some of the less popular classes. I took a 1st
in the Boston Parade autocross, with an absolutely box stock 87 944S,
except for A008-RTU tires (several years out of date DOT approved
road racing tires). I have relatively little autocross experience,
although I do have some SCCA racing experience and a bunch of PCA
drivers education race track experience.  The Parade was the only
time (so far) I have autocrossed the car. My time would have been
well out of the money in the "regular" 944 class, but the 944S
field was light. There were a number of other classes where
non-heroic times won the class, or at least placed well.

Interestingly, my most recent autocross previous to that was the
Portland Parade, where I took 2nd in an essentially stock 914-2.0
(lowered by the "sag" method, but stock springs, sway bars, wheels,
etc., on A008 (not R) tires). I had expected the 914-2 class to be
packed, both with cars prepared to the limit and with experienced
autocrossers, but it didn't turn out that way.

So, I suggest that unless you are in the "I'm not going to run unless
I know I'm going to win" mode, bring whatever you have to the parade
(or other PCA autocross), have a shot at it, and see what happens.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 11:02:02 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: SCCA Rules for Showroom Stock


Byron,

As a former 25 year member and Solo II competitor, I will make a 
recommendation that John Kelly and I submitted and explained in the Wheel
ten years ago.

Limit Showroom Stock to five year model participation. 

Makes life simple. Policeing is much easier. Reduces model congestion.
Makes classes easier. It would be even better to limit shocks and tires
and swaybars to those delivered

Crap can Street Prepared or require all cars to be emission legal per
49 states. Suspension is free per existing rules. Any drivetrain mods 
must have either CARB exemption or Fed compliance and be properly 
installed and adjusted and be approved for use by the board.

I quit my membership because SCCA has not been a `Sports Car' club. The 
normal rank-and-file Solo II paricipation has more junk sedans and coupes 
than legitimate sports or GT cars. It has not lived up to its charter in
promoting true sports cars. 
For the average Porsche owner, In we are still being penalized on the 
track as well as in SOLO events, despite how you personally feel. 

I can look back and say that I've won my division, (4 times, different 
classes) so I probably should be happy. But I see many potential 
participants going off mad, on the surface there is no logical explanation 
for the classifications. Some board members have been receptive in the 
past,  few changes have benefitted LEGAL Porsches participating. A few 
A/S 914/4 2.0s are less legal than you believe, it's not just the ride 
height either (Look in the exhaust ports).

Byron, I'm not not directing this as personal thing at you. I am 
generalizing the comments of many PCA members in the San Francisco Bay
Area. There are 175 active PCA autocrossers in Northern California, a
large number of these people would particpate if the Solo Board would
consider that they would add to the quality of the events.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 12:35:01 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Por-15,Miracle paint; PPG's response


      Ok....I called PPG tech support line (216-572-6111) and they did 
    not have any reference to "Miracle Paint" or "POR-15."  What they
    did say was;
      - Their best paint for durability is "Durathane," which is their 
        polyurethane most competitive with DuPont's Imron. There is
        also a flattener available for this in case its going in 
        an engine bay, etc; use either DX595 or 685. PPG wouldn't 
        go as far as claiming it is immune to battery acids, etc as
        Miracle Paint and POR-15 claim, but (as with Imron) find its usage
        largely on trucks, airplanes, etc. 
    
     - Their best primer is the "DP" line of zinc-oxide epoxy primers, but
       these will not stop oxidation (as Corroless/POR-15/Miracle Paint
       claim). Though PPG recommends DP as a corrosion resistant primer
       over good metal, it does not recommend it over rust ("would be a
       bandaid"). In my own rust experiment (a wrought iron chair in the
       backyard I sandblasted and painted with DP-90) I think the stuff is
       pretty fantastic and doesn't require topcoating. But it doesn't keep
       a consistent gloss (if you want to use to without a topcoat) and is
       usually a little flatter than I'd want. 

       By far, what I felt from PPG was that I was getting responsible 
     answers, and not a sales pitch. But unfortunately I didn't get 
     any validation or invalidation from PPG about the other "miracle"
     products. The fact that PPG didn't even have a pat response -may-
     indicate that the restoration market POR-15/Miracle Paint cater to are
     so small that PPG doesn't even have a sales defense to offer for their
     product (much less make a product that looks/smells like it) and that 
     they are content supporting OEM and body-shops alone. 
       POR-15 is -not- a new product (its 17 years old). Being an engineer
     and living technology, the only things I use or have that old are 
     usually my cars... Of course, I have to be skeptical of tremendous
     claims; I don't believe in 80 mpg carburetors and that sort of thing.
     But even after doing bodywork for 10 years, in the last 5 I've learned
     how little I knew then, and have found "better living thru chemicals"
     and tools time and again. Theres a lot to be said in using something
     you are comfortable with, but it doesn't mean you wouldn't be ecstatic
     with something else...
      So to me, there is nothing to controvert what POR-15 and Miracle
     Paint claim so far...
                   -Lee A.

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 13:23:13 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Need advice on 1979 911

> I am writing because I am 
> concerned about the maintenance costs I may face, as I plan on using this as 
> an everyday car.  I drive about 1,000 miles per month, half of which are San 
> Francisco city traffic.  I will keep it in my garage.  

I put 150km on an '81 Euro SC before selling it this fall. The Euro model
is essentially identical except for the engine and CIS, the doors, the
bumpers, and the marker lights.  A few things:

1) be sure it has the real Euro engine (930/10). 
2) be sure that the seller has originals of the DOT and EPA paperwork,
   in addition to the title. If he doesn't, too bad; find another car.
3) have it fully checked out and smogged at the seller's expense. If
   it doesn't pass, or there is missing equipment, see (2).

> I want to get an 
> alarm for it, and a stereo with a CD player.

Can't help you with this, but it's just like a US spec 911. I used a 
Viper alarm because it was cheap, and never listened to the radio anyway
so it didn't matter that I had a Sony XR-7180.

> Should I be concerned?  

About the gas smell, yes. Get that checked out ASAP. About owning a Euro
911, not really. *IF* all the paperwork is in order.

> Can anyone estimate 
> the average maintenance costs?  

Your milage will vary. I estimate *MINIMUM* annual maint for a 911 as follows.
You may get lower or higher, depending. I assume professional service at
an independent shop, no do it yourself.

1 major service, $650
4 oil changes, $125 each
3/4 set tires $550 (you'll buy a two sets of rears per set of fronts; you'll
buy a full set every two years, the 3/4 set of tires let's that average out)

total cost: $1325, about $100 a month. 

Other things: if you need shocks/brakes/etc, that's extra. You eventually 
will. As things break, they'll need to be fixed. It's expensive. How expensive
varies with what the part is (some have good sources in the aftermarket,
some are only from Porsche) and whether you can do it yourself or not.

Good luck.

Stan

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 14:37:24 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: End of color confusion

Hi,

I'd like to thank Peter Albrecht and John Wright for their help concerning
the correct color (Ivory) of my car as well as the others who answered my fog
light question.  I decided to call Porsche in Reno this week to find out the
truth. Unfortunately, I had asked to speak to someone concerning the
confusion and they transferred me to Owner Relations. I explained my problem
to a Porsche rep and asked if there could be a mistake. He then said "Well,
it is possible that the car was completely stripped and repainted." I
explained further that the paint was definitely original and that their was
no chance that Rose Red  was the original color.  When I again politely
suggested that there was a mistake, he implied that such mistake couldn't be
made, especially if his computer indicated that my car was Rose red. He did
say however that he would leave a note for Howard Adams to look into it.  But
it made me mad that he thought that I was an idiot. His attitude that Porsche
could never make a mistake really needs to be changed. 

Well I called Howard on my own today and told him the situation. He was very
helpful and asked for the paint color and code -Rose Red  4610 - and looked
up the info. Seems as if somebody goofed up he said. There is a rose red but
it is 4510, Ivory according to him is 4610. So as Pete mentioned earlier,
Certificates of Authenticity aren't the last word in Authenticity. People can
make mistakes sometimes when looking up the info. 

As for the fog lights, white means clear lenses as opposed to yellow
Euro-style lights.

Thanks again,
Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 11:42:14 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: SCCA Prep


Kevin,

The rule states "as delivered". It was strictly enforced that if the option
wasn't ordered on your car, it wasn't supposed to be there. Differing 
options like sport suspension were in the gray area because, as an example,
a normal 83 944 had no rear sway bar but the mounting brackets were there.
Most people added them with no one the wiser.

Later 944s get sticky. Almost all 944s were equipped with rear bars after 
85 1/2. 924S had front bar standard, rear bar with sport suspension and M030.
In the chart I published with my article and in the little spec books, you 
will see a basic range and years applicable for all factory sizes. It should 
be no problem to legally tune the rear with the combinations available for 
the 944S2, 944 Turbo and 968. It may be difficult in the stock class to
prove your point without the spec book, so buy one.

The killer Street Prepared combo would be a 3.0 944S4 engine in a 83 944
with the S4/Turbo M030 setup. It's legal.

Jim Pasha

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 12:12:30 -0800 (PST)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: RE: SCCA Solo II stock

>From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
>Subject: RE: SCCA Solo II stock


>Eric,

>>Does stock mean "as delivered by the factory" or are you
>>allowed to install factory options that were available for that
>>year and model?

>>For example, if I got a 944S2 without M030, could I install the
>>M030 bits and still be stock?

>I'm a bit out of touch with SCCA reg's of late.  However, it has
>been my understanding that you may add any available, factory
>option so long as you add the whole option.  In the case at hand,
>if you were to add some M030 bits, you would have to add all
>of them, even those which might seem frivolous or advantageous.
>So, struts, control arms, spindles, brakes, bushings, bars, etc.
>depending on exactly which M.Y. car you are dealing with.  And
>lotsa luck documenting it to anyone who cares -- pack your
>fiche reader, I guess.

>Hope this helps.

>Kevin Gross


Kevin is pretty much on base with this, but it goes deeper than that. If
you decide to "update"/"backdate" a car with another models suspension or
engine etc. You have to do the whole car, and I mean the WHOLE car. If your
car doesn't have A/C, and all M030 cars did, you would (by the strict
letter of the rules) be required to install A/C. Same goes for any and all
options that would go with such cars. I myself don't know how many of M030
models were built and what options were available with them, but basically,
if you plan to run a car in stock, it has to be as-the-factory-intended-it-
to-be. In stock you can change tires, shocks, front sway bars, brake pads,
and cat back exhaust. There's little things as well, but those are the main
points. That's why I prefer "street prepared" class over stock. 

Just a note on updating your 944, stock classes tend to be the most
competetive as far as nitpicking the rules and protests go. If you don't
intend to be competetive in SCCA, then it might not be as big a deal. If
you start winning a lot (or even a little) people will want to scrutinize
your car. It happens... The chances are, is that you'll be given a warning,
or you may be disqualified. That's generally why people move into SP when
they want to start tweaking and playing with their car.

Good luck with your 944...

Josh

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CS -> CSP
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Everything expresed here is the opinion of the idiot that wrote it, 
namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 12:56:19 PST
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Allison/Crane installation


>   I have the Allison/Crane installed in my 914-4.  I had a "professional"
>   put it in.  He said it was a nightmare to install (Actually, when I think
>   about it, just about everything turns into a nightmare with this guy so
>   that could be an entirely bogus statement). 

Speaking of installing Allison/Crane optical systems.

I've installed two versions of the Allison/Crane system.

The early one had a slotted aluminum foot that attached to the
detector unit via one long bolt.  

There was little adjustment range in the foot so you had to be careful 
of the mounting hole placement.

The latest one I used (OK, I'll admit it, purchased from J.C.Whitney)
had a two piece bracket to give sufficient adjustment range.

In both cases I fabricated my own one piece bracket after I had determined
a good position for the pickup.

I would NOT try to install one of these systems with the distributor in the
car.

As I remember it, in the early days Allison used to advertise that
it was as easy to install as regular points and gave a low estimated time.
This claim was the subject of a California lawsuit and Allison stopped claiming
this.

If you have a vacuum advance on the distributor, make sure the sensor
leads have a flexible mounting.  The wires can flex and open as the point
plate moves.

It is important to have the distributor rotor pointing to a spark plug
terminal in the cap when the "points" open, otherwise it will arc to 
the cap and destroy it.

I tested this position by taking an old cap and cutting out an inspection
slot under a convenient spark plug wire terminal so I could see exactly
where the rotor was pointing when the points open.  

I hooked up the Allison to a +12V power supply, a car battery would
work fine, and attached it to the sending unit + distributor.


                  +12 V
                ____|________________                         
                 |                  |
                 |                  <
                 |                  >  1K resistor
                 |                  <
  distributor    |                  >
     +       ____|_____             |
  pickup---->| Allison |-------------  <-- coil drive lead
             |_________|            Voltmeter
                 |                   |
                 V                   V

By rotating the distributor drive shaft by hand (in the direction
of normal distributor rotation), the voltmeter will read +12V when
the spark would normally occur and the rotor will be pointing to where the
spark will jump.  This should point to the exposed inspection terminal.


John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com
