Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 16:56:03 -0500
From: "Peter H. Jones" <phjones@smtpwpo.dayt.tasc.com>
Subject:  Porschephiles #1069 Fri Jan 13 12:10:18 CST 1995 -Reply

I can understand why folks might be dubious of the NMA (National
Motorists Association) as a force for good for drivers and highway
users. They ARE a lobbying group, the only one for the motoring public
certainly, but they also provide benefits and services to their
membership, especially in the way of vital information. Our Ohio
representative has accomplished much by working through the system in
Ohio - All of Ohio's highways that are legally capable of being 65 mph
ARE 65 mph, and thanks to NMA proactive work through state
legislature. In fact, Ohio recently opened up thousands of miles of
non-interstate roads to 65 mph, due to the same proaction. Locally, in
Dayton-Beavercreek, our rep has directly increased speed limits to their
rightful 85th percentile place. Such changes nationally will be a mindset
change that will take place over years, but it has happened rapidly here.

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 95 13:59:46 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: Muffler and heat exchanger paint


     I saw the section in Pano too.  I don't think that just any cold 
     galvanizing paint will work though.  I bought a can of cold 
     galvanizing spray paint made by 'Aervoe' from a hardware store and I 
     doubt it would stand up to the heat from a heater box.
     
     I'm about to try the 'Stainless Steel Coating' from Eastwood.  Had any 
     experience with this stuff?
     
     Derek Au

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
     
I received my Pano yesterday and was very amused at an expert (Paterek) 
telling someone that VHT paint was the correct paint for a 911/356/914 
factory heat exchanger.
     
This is where the fantasy bullsh*t starts for concours/restoration. The 
Patereks do a fine job for their customers, I like their work.
     
In this case, however, the factory specified a paint that had a high zinc 
content. It is called `cold galvanizing' in the paint trade and can be found 
in the correct gray at many local hardware stores. NOT VHT. While VHT is 
a fine finish, it is not correct.
     
In applying the paint to heat exchangers or mufflers, remove all scale, oil 
and other drippings. Ensure that the surface is as clean as you can get it. 
Paint all outer areas. Allow to dry, it takes a couple of hours. Re-install, 
the heat will turn the dark gray light. 
     
When I last showed my '73 911S, I had just redone the exhaust system this 
way. I had a lot of questions about the `original' finish. All couldn't 
believe that the paint was that easy to find.
     
Jim Pasha

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 20:04:11 -0500

Subject: Jack stands/spring plates...

>I have a problem with putting the stands on the ends of the >torsion bars,
comments ?

When I first read this it did seem a little strange, but I think
it is OK.  The first thing that comes to mind is bending loads
going into the torsion bars, but I think that actually most of
the load is tranferred directly from the spring plate to the
body of the car via the spring plate bushing (what its job is
anyway).  There may be slight bending loads on the spring plate
itself, but we are not really talking about alot of load here -
900lbs maybe?

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 20:07:44 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Isocyanates (prev 'no subject')

Pfilers,

The various isocyanates found in modern clearcoat-hardener paints can kill
you.  That said, here is what happens and how to combat it.

The isocyanates react with air and moisture to form urethanes.  A similar
component is found in the urethane adhesives found in windshield sealants,
here it is not sprayed and does not get a chance to enter your lungs in any
mist.

Per *ANY* paint manufacturer and OSHA, the *ONLY* respirator permitted is a
'supplied-air' type (and there is a NIOSH number to match).  These are very
expensive.  They are required in commercial operations unless vapor/mist
concentrations can be maintained at sufficiently low levels through good
ventilation.  According to SAF Safety,  Sherwin-Williams and OSHA, an
activated carbon filter solvent prefilter respirator designed and sold for
paint solvents will filter out isocyanates, the problem is knowing when the
filters are no longer effective.  The solvents in automotive paints have an
odor and flavor (they can be smelled and tasted) so the painter can realize a
filter is no longer effective and replace same.  Isocyanates cannot be
smelled or tasted, since this warning is not available, the filter
respirators are not permitted.

According to the technical assistance as Sherwin-Williams and Dupont,
isocyanate toxicity is not necessarily gradual.  Some air-borne pollutants
(such as carbon monoxide) affect the body gradually. A painter might use
isocyanates for 20 years without effect then one day be coughing up blood.
 Another painter may have a reaction the very first time exposed.  According
to the same sources, the 'reaction' may range from finding some blood on a
pillow in the morning to simply 'acute respiratory arrest'.

Many painters choose to disregard the warnings, I know of several that can no
longer visit a paint shop because of a demonstrated sensitivity to the
chemical.  Use this information as you wish, but this is not a toy or a game.
 

On a positive note: the paint manufacturers are all trying to develop and
market an isocyanate-free paint that is safer for users.  Dupont tried one
and already took it off the market.  Sherwin-Williams may have something as
early as this summer.

Peter Leckband  

------------------------------

the hood right up.  I couldn't really tell what wasn't working right,
and the Haynes' Manual didn't have enough detail.  There is a square hole
that the latch goes into, but the latch didn't catch on anything.

   The other day, three things happened: (1) I joined P-phile for the 
express purpose of posing this question to you all, (2) I got to take a
first-hand look at my buddy's '74 911, and (3) the damn hood popped open
at ~45 mph, bending the hinges, rear corners of the hood, and pressing
two dimples into the cowling beneath the windshield.  (Looks like about a 
grand of damage.)  Apparently the primary hood latch has also failed.

  But enough grumbling, my question is this: what should the secondary 
latch grab on to?  The '74 had a piece of metal with a triangular cross
section, but mine did not seemed to have an analogous spot for one.  My
mechanic claims there should be a bar across the sqare hole, but I feel
that there should be a triangular piece (similar to the '74's) tacked on 
somewhere (next to the square hole)?  Can someone take a peek at their's 
and advise?

   Any ideas on the primary latch?  I think that the car cover in the 
luggage compartment was pressing up from the inside, but I know the 
hood was latched down. (I tried to lift it up with my fingers after closing
it.)  My rubber "smile" has the usual buckling due to the usual rust;
could this be interfering with proper closure?


  Thanks in advance.  Sorry this got so long.  (Brevity is the soul of wit?)

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 23:29:51 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Wheels, baby

>Yahoo!  I never knew driving such a beautiful car could be so much fun?
>Why did I wait so long to buy my dream car?
>
>. . .The first improvement I'd like to make in my recently acquired '96 911
> is to acquire some new wheels.  I was told that the wheels on the car were
>the originals, but I've never seen another 911 with this style - they look
>like 928 wheels, and they're not very flattering to a 911.  And I'm
>interested in getting a little wider rubber so I can have a little more
>fun, but then again the car is a daily driver.  Can somebody give me some
>tips on how wide or skinny and how big or little I should go?  Also, does
>anybody have any favorite sources here in LA (Manhattan Beach), and what
>should I look to spend?

Tom,

On the '78 through '89 911's you can do the following:

Front: 8x16 Fuchs (944 Turbo (951) part number with 225/45ZR16 tires.
Rear: 9x16 Fuchs (from 911 Turbo) with 245/45ZR16 tires.

Fuchs are by far and away the best wheels you can put on your '86 911.
8x16 944 Turbo offset Fuchs will cost you around $600 for a pair in
excellent condition. The 9x16 fuchs will cost you about $1200 for the
pair.

The only drawback to this setup is that there are not many tires made in
the 225/45ZR16 size. Dunlop SP 8000s, Pirelli P-Zero, P-700, and Yoko AVS
Intermediate come to mind.

Depending on the particular car, you may want to roll the front fender
lips. My car did not require this until I tried using and 8x15 wheels
with 225/50ZR15 tires for autocross.

The 9x16 setup on the rear is not a problem.

Call Galen Bieker at Werks II (818-845-2530) about this setup. He is in
Burbank and may be able to turn you on to some wheels. Tell him I sent
you.

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Sat, 14 Jan 1995 07:51:49 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Swepco/Red Line Trans Oil

About the current thread on Swepco oil;
There seems to be a misconception that Swepco is a synthetic oil. It is my
understanding that it is not synthetic. It is a product that is used, to a
great degree, in the trucking industry and the rigors that exist in that
heavy stress environment where it has proven itself.
I have used it in my 944's for years and it seemed to make them universally
smoother shifters. I also tried Red Line Synthetic once and all hell broke
loose. It sounded like I had no sychros at all. Too slippery it seems. The
folks at Red Line were very nice and sent me some different product that
worked OK but I subsequently changed back to Swepco.
The 944 synchros are a different design that the 915 trans in the 911 series
so I can't speak for the air coolers.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:39 am

Date: Sat, 14 Jan 1995 09:42:29 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 question

> What is the lift/duration of the PREFERRED cam in a 914-2.0?  Assuming
> stock bore/stroke, euro pistons, and stock injection.

Depends on application. For *STREET* use, the only performance cam worth
installing is the FAT Performance "fuel injection performance cam". I
think that their part number is FJ-440. 

For full-out racing either road racing or autox while using mostly stock
EFI, contact me. That's a different application. 8{)

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 14 Jan 1995 10:05:05 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Euro 911 Paperwork

> Stan replied to Brett Morrison regarding the potential purchase of a 911 Euro
> car and the importance of the 'correct papers' from EPA and DOT.  I've looked
> at 5 or 6 Euro cars in the last 6 years and have received only blank stares
> when I've asked to see copies of the waivers.  Can any of you tell me exactly
> what is necessary?  What should the documents look like or be headed with?  I
> would consider buying a Euro car but I haven't been fully satisfied that a
> Customs agent wouldn't come and take my toy away.  Also, any problems with
> emmissions testing / things to be prepared for?

There are typically three important pieces of paper on a grey market car:

1) DOT. This is a certification from the DOT that the car meets all relevant
   DOT spec for glass, seat belts, door intrusion, 5 mph bumpers, etc.

2) EPA. This certifies that the car meets relevant emissions and has
   all the right parts like a cat, leaded fuel restrictor nozzle, etc.

3) Certificate of Physical Inspection. When the car is titled the first time,
   or often when it is imported if the conversion was done in Europe, the
   state DOT/DMV/Dxx has to certify that the paperwork and the car match
   up.

I also had several other pieces of paper:

a) German service log, title, and registration
b) German bill of sale
c) certification from the shop in Wiessbaden that did the work
   that they had done the work to current US regs
d) translation of the German paperwork
e) certification that the translator was approved to do such technical
   translations
f) shipping paperwork

I could see not having (3) as viable -- the title *should* cover that. Once
you have a clear US title, it can be argued that you never would have
gotten it if that had not existed at some point (sort of like not needing
a marriage license after you're married...).

But (1) and (2) are *CRITICAL*. If you ever get challenged -- like if your 
conversion was done by a fly-by-night place that "converted" you by
just saying "OK, this car is converted" instead of doing the work --
you can be served and required to either make the car compliant, export
it back to Europe, or have it crushed and melted. Unless, of course,
you can prove that the EPA and DOT actually signed off on *THIS CAR*.

As to what they look like, well, they're on regular DOT and EPA letterhead,
and they use that horrible IBM line printer font that other "offical" US
government mass-produced paperwork (like nastygrams from the IRS, etc.)
uses. They have official seals over the signatures, and the titles/office
etc of the signatories, so it can be verified. They're numbered, too.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 14 Jan 95 08:43:14 -0800
From: donr@deltanet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: 911 submarine

I wouldn't be so stupid, right? All those stupid people who get their cars 
caught in (LA) floods.....well... a friend was driving his 84 Carrera home 
last week. Heavy rains, but he like me and presumably most others, finds 
that except for the ventilation, 911's do just fine in that kind of weather.

Got pretty wet and some of the cars started to act up and finally the road  
started to get blocked with stalled cars and three lanes became 2 and things 
slowed down.... then the 2 lanes became 1 and things really slowed 
down....finally everything stopped. Absolutely nowhere to go.

The water started to rise. The 911 floated around for a while as the water 
continued to rise but then it started to settle and the water level started 
to rise from the floor. As John said, when it was apparent that the level 
was rising up his legs, it was time to abandon ship which he did through 
"the hatch".

Water rose to about the level of the top of the seat cushion. He rescued it 
the next day by which time the water had subsided, but his insurance co 
wrote it off. John is now looking for his 5th Porsche.

Could have been me.

Don
86 911 Carrera (daily driver)
56 356 Speedster
Don Rutherford
'86 Carrera
'56 Speedster

Neil NW Walker wrote:
>Seriously are there ANY REAL benefits for synthetic vs. Dino Oil? I have
heard, 
>but cannot remember where, that no REAL advantage exists, at least for street 

I dunno about other characteristics, but when it is cold out, there is a
*big* REAL advantage to synthetics... whether engine oil or trans oil. (Not
that I would be driving the Porsche when its -30 outside, though). The
synthetic flows; the dino fffllllooooowwwsssss.... ;)

In the 924S, I use this weird gear oil from Shell (German Shell) that the
factory imported for teams running the Canadian 944 Turbo Cup series a few
years back. It was *more* expensive than anything else I've seen, but my
mechanic swore by it, so I bought it.

It did seem to improve things, but that's just an impression.

the
>paint...that in itself is a bad thing but the amount of dust is

before

the
>car in my garage with the heat on to cure the paint, is this a good 
idea?

>

>rosvall@nbnet.nb.ca

Talk with your painter and see if he will stand behind you if you 
"color" sand the affected area. You should actually color sand the 
entire car. But this has to be done before the paint cures.

You use 1500 grit wet dry sand paper to color sand. This will take out 
all the imperfections.

------------------------------

Date: 14 Jan 95 12:37:00 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: GL-3 vs. GL-5

 
GL-5 is a tougher standard than GL-3. GL-5 is intended for higly stressed
hypoid drives and is similar to MIL-L 2105 B; GL-3 is for transmissions with
low to medium loads.
 
The GL rating is an API classification, just like the SH or CD ratings of
motor oil. SH = spark ignition, grade H, CD = compression ignition [diesel],
grade C; an SH/CD oil is better than, say, an SF/CC oil.
 
I use Swepco in my 356s, it works fine.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

From: owner-porschephiles@tta.com

	(Linux Smail3.1.28.1 #1)  
	id m0rTDGS-0000aPC; Sat, 14 Jan 95 13:31 EST
Message-Id: <m0rTDGS-0000aPC@inasec.ca>
Date: Sat, 14 Jan 95 13:31 EST
X-Sender: cseko@198.53.239.2
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: porschephiles@tta.com
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: Re: Porsche envy and break in

DAYEFTDIX@aol.com wrote:
>into, stereo swiped, ignition switch broken, persons tried to steal, now not
>so happy. Any ideas on type of security devices needed to keep my baby at
>home. Thanks

How annoying.

Well, I have had every car I've owned broken into/attempted at least once,
so I'll offer the following things I've found that work:

1. Don't park the car. <cough>
Okay, so it isn't practical. Try not to park in underground parking lots,
like those in apartments or malls. This is where most cars get broken into,
besides home (at least in Canada - I worked on studying auto theft/damage
patterns a few years ago at work.)

2. Get a flashing LED.
Get a few of them. The flashing light will discourage minor thieving. You
can also get "Porsche Alarm" stickers from the dealer (the ones for 928's
are nice), and put them on various windows. Of course, you can always get a
car alarm, but thieves just look for the flashing red LED's, anyways. (Any
thief not discouraged by an alarm is going to get the car, anyways).

3. Get a dog, and train it properly.
Not many thieves will touch a car with a dog in it, whether it is barking or
not. Mine barked. *Very* loudly (German Shepherd/Collie). It took a bit of
training to get her to bark only when someone was within 15 feet of the car.
(I left the sunroof open and the windows a quarter way down, and always
parked in the shade in the summertime, of course).

At home, my living room window overlooks the driveway (and my neighbours),
and it took even *more* training to get her to bark only when someone walked
up my driveway (the P-car is parked at the back of the driveway - I have no
garage), but not bark when the neighbours came home.

4. (for home) Motion sensor lights.
I don't know about where you are, but here, those kits that take two
spotlights and hook them up to a motion sensor are awfully cheap. Halogen
spotlights don't use much electricity, as well. In my old house, the garage
backed out into an alley, and putting in sensor lights around and inside the
garage chilled things appreciably (the garage door miraculously openned
itself the odd night, though <grin> - but the cars weren't touched.)

I took a greater interest in these things when my insurance company raised
my deductible to $1000 because I was loosing too many radios (I lost three
in one summer in my BMW 2002). I haven't lost one since, although someone
tried the P-car once - while it was parked in a friend's underground
apartment lot.

Hope this helps...

Craig.

Date: 14 Jan 95 16:39:59 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: First 912E?

Jay Karolyi writes about a 912E with VIN # 912 000 001. According to my
info, that's not a valid VIN number. The 912E number range is 912 600 0001
through 912 600 2099. (Juergen Barth's Porsche book, known to have
mistakes). Engine numbers from the same source say 406 0001 through
406 2115.
 
Is it worth anything? Who knows? A little bit more, maybe. Check those
numbers again, is the 6 missing? And is the engine number also very low? (It
doesn't need to be the first engine in the series in the first body of the
series; they weren't that religious about staying in sequence.) If
so, it may be that first 912E. But I'm surprised that the very first car
would be in civilian use. The first few of any production run are reserved
for in-house use, testing, press fleets, etc. and I think Porsche has a
policy of putting at least one of everything away in their non-public
storage vault/museum.
 
Pete

Date: 14 Jan 95 18:42:50 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: End of color confusion

 
Neil Kumpers writes
>I decided to call Porsche in Reno this week to find out the truth...
>I called Howard [Adams] on my own... and [he] looked up the info. Seems as
>if somebody goofed up, he said. There is a Rose Red but it is 4510, ivory
>according to him is 4610. So as Pete mentioned earlier, Certificates of
>Authenticity aren't the last word in authenticity. People can make mistakes
>sometimes when looking up the info.
 
I just got the Jan/Feb 356 Registry today. On p. 26, under AUTHENTICATION
ALERT, Ron Roland says "But the latest I have heard is that some individuals
have 'created' an exact copy of the Porsche letterhead, down to the metric
paper size, to make their own version of the Certificate and
A-Letter-From-The-Factory; aren't laser printers wonderful? You may not be
able to get original documents from the factory but you can from the
underworld. While I don't wish to rekindle the Kardex Kontroversy, a simple
Xerox copy, at nominal cost, would remove all doubt."
 
My sentiments exactly. However, you could also forge a Kardex copy
relatively easily. To be precise, a Kardex copy, or the Certificate of
Authenticity (they might as well print this on the same stock as used for
"attaboy awards" for all the good it does) is probably only of value to
the person who originally requested it from the factory.
 
Pete

Date: 14 Jan 95 20:39:25 EST
From: Byron Short <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: '75 911 w/SC cams.  PCA/SCCA class rules

Dirk Bergstrom writes...
>PCA will take me no matter--I may end up competing against "improved"
>cars, but I'll still get track time.  But what about SCCA?  From what 
>I've read here and on the autox.team.net list, I'm not sure if they'll
>let me play in their reindeer games.  Will they throw me out, or just
>put me up against a bunch of fire-breathing trailer-riding supercars?

SCCA Solo events take ANY kind of car at any preparation level as long as
it can pass a simple safety inspection.  As you suspected, the cams move
you to F-Prepared, a class which *could* have some pretty wild machinery. 
In all likelihood, however, you'll find little if any, other folks in your
class, and you're more likely to find someone like you, that is basically
a street driver with a cam or other internal engine mod.  In SCCA regions
are allowed to create their own classes in addition to the standard
classes, and many regions have adopted a "Super Street Prepared" class or
something similar, which is for any street legal car built beyond the
rules of Street Prepared.  Whether you wind up in FP or in some regional
class for street cars with internal engine mods, you should be able to
run any wheels/tires you want (including slicks in FP).  And of course,
your primary goals of having a blast and gaining seat time will be met no
matter!

Byron Short

87 944 Turbo -- waxed it today.  Now it's ugly AND shiny.
90 944 S2 M030 -- tomorrow we adjust the spring perches d
                                                         o
                                                          w
                                                           n.



------------------------------

Date: 14 Jan 95 20:39:34 EST
From: Byron Short <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: SCCA Rules for Showroom Stock

Jim Pasha writes (amid numerous other inaccuracies)...

>...few changes have benefitted LEGAL Porsches participating.  A few A/S
914/4 2.0s are less legal than you believe, it's not just the ride height
either  (look in the exhaust ports).

Well, Jim, I could sit on my hands and bite my tongue for a while, but...

I HAVE looked in the exhaust ports of the most competitive 914 2.0 in the
country (in the last two years)--in fact I've seen the motor apart and
been there to help verify that the head CC'd to spec before assembly. 
This car was in impound after winning the CS National Championship in
1993 for 4 days having everything torn down and inspected from shifter to
brake bias (it took the protesting competitors days to find the gauges,
but they insisted on testing the actual pounds in the line) to front
spindle dimensions to full carpet pad existence, to ignition timing to
pedal bushings.  Some gas was even siphoned from the car with the
intention of being mailed to a lab for testing, but the protestor backed
down when he found it was going to cost several hundred dollars.  It's
easy to slander, but I suggest you re-join SCCA, come on out to Topeka or
any Pro Solo or Tour event, plunk down the bucks on these cars you think
are illegal and prepare to find out for yourself.  Prior to that your
sweeping generalities and innuendos are less than appreciated.  I'm sure
there are some illegal cars out there somewhere, but they are usually the
un-competitive ones!

I know and respect John Kelly.  I've been on the same side sometimes and
at times opposite sides of issues with him and always found him to be
well informed and a worthy adversary.  Jim, you'll forgive me if I choose
to credit those statements to you rather than John?  And you'll
understand if I don't form my opinions of the other 175 San Francisco
area PCA autocrossers based on your proclaimed representation of a "large
number of" them?

And Jim, please, don't give advice on SCCA Solo prep legalities (Kevin re:
M030 conversion) until you've read a *current* SCCA Solo II Rule book. 
The first two paragraphs of your response to Kevin are totally
inaccurate.  The third paragraph is correct.

Byron Short

87 944 Turbo
90 944S2 M030

Porschephiles #1073                         Mon Jan 16 02:00:04 CST 1995
Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 09:17:10 -0500
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Re: Euro 911 Paperwork

In response to the dialogue on certification paperwork, there was a document
published in 1984 titled "Handbook of Vehicle Importation, A guide for
importing a vehicle into the United States".  It includes copies of certificat
ion documents and letters from DOT/EPA relative to the importation process.
 It was published by the "Automobile Importers Compliance Association", 1607
New Hampshire Ave., N.W. Washington, D.C. 20009, telephone (202) 293-1017.

My guess is that since the "Grey Market" dried-up and died, this Association
may no longer be in business.  In line with other warnings, you may remember
the articles in Autoweek and Automotive News  several years ago on faulty
certifications (particularly with some well-know "boutique" sellers in
Southern California) and withdrawal of certifications and title/licenses of
cars performed by those shops cited.  Another concern (which may or may not
be important), is that the wholesale value of many of those cars is way below
those of US spec vehicles.  Many dealers won't touch them at all and the
rough "rule of thumb" by those wholesale buyers who would was 60 percent of
low book.

Perry

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 10:09:46 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: 75 911 w/SC cams- PCA/SCCA rules

Dirk Bergstrom's '75 911 has SC cams, 11 blade fan, Dilavar studs,
'73 exhuast and tensioner blocks.

> What do these modifications mean for my class placement in PCA and
>SCCA?  I'm going to autocross the car as-is, and perhaps with sticky
>rubber (I have a spare set of 7" wheels).  At this point in my
>career (early), I don't really care what class I end up in--I won't be

In SCCA the cams will send you directly from Stock to Prepared (the
same class as the 914/6 race car that won FTD at the last 2 Porsche
parades!)

The 7" wheels, exhaust, and fan would be legal in Street Prepared, but
any one of these will take you out of Stock.

Recommendation : as a beginner, just don't mention the cams and
run in Street Prepared. You will be driving an underdog in SP anyway,
so nobody should care.

Mike Piera, '72 911S, '94 SCCA NE Divisional ASP champion (last time in
ASP with this car, thank god)


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 10:14:04 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Subject: PCRs vs Solo II Rules

David O. Blanchard <blanch@capella.cup.hp.com> wrote :

>> To Bryon Short; Why do you believe that a basically stock 944S2 is
>> uncompetitive in the Parade, my '90 S2 , a truly stock driver (Konis,rear
>> bar,and road race BFGs) took second at the Lake Placid event against
another
>> S2 fully set up but still within Solo II rules, why not come compete.

>The problem with going to Parade in a real stock car is that
>there is always some person there who has a read the rules and
>has prepared their car to the rules and knows how to drive the
>damn thing.  This is especially true where the cars are common
>(911 SCs, 944s, 911 Carrerras, etc.).  If you go less than
>fully prepared, you will probably settle for a less than first
>place trophy. 

>The other problem is the stupid PCRs.  They allow highly non-
>stock cars, but the average competitor is in a mostly-stock
>car.  Only those with extreme dedication really want to drive
>a fully prepped car 3000 miles.  Result: Locals (who don't
>have far to drive) win large amounts of heavy hardware.  Then
>there are the wierd tire rules to contend with.  You can't
>just run tires that fit,  they must be of such and such a
>circumference.  For most of us who go to compete, this often
>means buying a set of tires we would not have otherwise bought.

I agree with David that the PCR's are NG. They allow an unbelievable
amount of modifications in the stock "P" class. This would theoretically
pose a great disadvantage to someone driving a really stock car.
These rules basically allow ANY suspension (sways, torsion bars, 
bushings, 1" wider wheels, etc). It is an absolute FARCE that they have the
circumference rules, which have made me run 225/50/15 tires instead of
the 205's I normally run. This was an AVDANTAGE when I used the 7"
wheels in Lake Placid, but probably hurt me on 6" wheels in Boston.

But from my experience at the Boston and Lake Placid parades, any of
the P classes could have been won by a good driver in a car without
modifications in excess of the SCCA stock rules. Proof is that I won
in Boston when my car was in stock configuration, by 1.5 seconds over
any other stock class. And in Lake Placid, Franklin Wong in his 924S,
bumped himself up a class (just for fun) and still beat all other watercooled
cars (at least he won his class easily). I think Byron in his stock S2 would
beat all watercooled cars at the parades I have been to by a good margin.

So don't be discouraged if your car is stock- get some good tires, drive
your best, and you can win.

Mike Piera  '72 911S Targa

Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 10:18:49 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Euro cars/paperwork

>There are typically three important pieces of paper on a grey market car:

>1) DOT. This is a certification from the DOT that the car meets all relevant
>   DOT spec for glass, seat belts, door intrusion, 5 mph bumpers, etc.

>2) EPA. This certifies that the car meets relevant emissions and has
>   all the right parts like a cat, leaded fuel restrictor nozzle, etc.

>3) Certificate of Physical Inspection. When the car is titled the first
time,
>   or often when it is imported if the conversion was done in Europe, the
>   state DOT/DMV/Dxx has to certify that the paperwork and the car match
>   up.

Uhhhhhh, what if one didn't have any of this stuff, hypothetically speaking,
of course?  My car, a '76 911, was brought over from Germany in 1985.  The
only "conversion" done was to replace the H4s with sealed beams (I put the
H4s back on), and replace the orange taillight lenses with US red ones.  The
whole rest of the car is Euro spec.  No 5mph bumpers, no smog pumps, no
thermal reactors, etc.

I actually have little fear of retribution.  Maybe ignorance is bliss?

Mike Dayton

Date: 15 Jan 95 11:32:33 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Dust in paint

 
Hi, Peter and Julie.
 
Most likely you can rub that right out. I painted a quickie repair to my
daily driver here in cool (60ish; eatcher heart out) and very soggy
California about a week ago. I tried to get cute and blend the paint into
the surrounding old enamel with a final application of very thin Centari
enamel reducer, and got huge runs in the paint. I sanded them right out
yesterday and repainted. This morning, it's cured already, I'll be wet
sanding and polishing and calling this job done. So if your garage is 60ish
degrees and you've waited a week, even the thickest paint should have cured
by now. Especially if your painter used hardener, which I didn't. (Note:
message from another p'philer says you have to do this "before it cures." I
don't know if Centari takes weeks or months to achieve a final cure, but by
cured I mean hardened enough to allow sanding; what you and I would call
"Yep, it's dried.") And yes, use 2000, not 1500. It's gentler and easier to
polish out the sand scratches, and you're less likely to break through the
paint. There are now some even finer grits on the market, imported from
Japan, that might be still better but I haven't tried them. My paint shop
has a display box on the counter with six grits of this stuff, multicolored,
it looks like pastel note paper. Paint shop guy says this stuff is
wonderful.
 
Anyway, the dust. Depending on how big these rocks are, you can probably get
the paint perfectly smooth with the use of a sheet of 2000 grit paper, wet
sanding, using a foam rubber pad available from auto paint suppliers (NOT the
heavy rubber sanding blocks used for woodworking!) 2000 grit is so fine that
it leaves almost a glossy surface. 3M and Meguiar's both make 2000 grit, the
Meguiar's lasts lots longer but you have to buy 20 sheets at a time. Then
you have to polish this out. To give you some idea of how fast the paper is
used up, I wet sanded an entire 356 using 3 sheets of paper. Use lots of
water. If you don't have an electric buffer, you'll have
to do it by hand. For electric buffers, I like Meguiar's Heavy Cut Cleaner,
followed by Meguiar's Swirl Remover and if you like their Glaze. If you don't
want/like/can't find Meguiar's, 3M and DuPont make products every bit as good.
Ask your paint supplier. If you have to do this by hand, there are other
good products out there (Imperial Hand Glaze from 3M?) I have a tube of some
German stuff here, from Glasurit, that cuts quickly but gently; I really
like this for hand polishing small areas or areas that can't be done by
machine (dashboard of one 356 was done in Glasurit and hand polished in the
way I described; 2000 grit and Glasso polish). The Glasso Polishing Compound
is their no. 562-1602 and it is great stuff. I use it by putting a small
amount on a wad of cotton (like cotton balls but bigger). Be careful not to
sand through the paint, of course, but 2000 is so fine that you should not
be able to do that unless you make an effort. Be careful around sharp corners
though, the paint is thinner and the sandpaper cuts much faster there.
 
The Glasso polishing compound and the Meguiar's professional line of
products mentioned have an advantage in not containing silicone. If you do
need to repaint anything, such as if you break through to primer or
(shudder) bare metal, you don't need to worry about silicone ruining the
next layer of paint.
 
There might be one problem with polishing individual areas: you'll like it
so much better than the rest of the surface that you wind up sanding out the
entire paint job. If you go that far, do get an electric buffer (I have a
Hitachi variable speed job, about $150, see Florida International Tool Co.
for best prices) and plan on spending 2-3 days on it. The advantage to this
is that you will get an absolutely smooth, dust-free, run-free,
lemon-peel-free paint job. You probably wouldn't want to pay a painter to do
this on "company time."
 
Pete

and then compute the compression ratio based on the new bore, stock stroke and
new deck height values?  

I'm going to try using this method and let you all know what I come up with. 
If anyone else has a method they've used, I'd like to know what it is.

Subject: 951vibration during braking

Friends,

My '87 951 (75,000 miles) recently developed a front vibration when applying
the brakes lightly to moderately. When braking hard, this vibration
disappears. I am not quite sure whether it is a sensation transmitted via the
brake pedal, or felt via the body.

I initially thought of warped brake rotors, but then, wouldn't that continue
under harder braking ?

Thanks,

Bart (AllPorsche@aol.com)

Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 17:02:41 -0500
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: Towing a 914, going to extremes.

Dear P-filers,

Thanks to everybody who offered advice regarding towing a 914 with a Jeep
Grand Cherokee Ltd and U-Haul dolly. Responses were unanimously agreeing that
this combination wasn't going to be a problem. So, last Friday night my
friend and I took off to Lincoln, Nebraska from New Orleans, Louisiana. Going
by the map, it appeared that Route 65 was the way to go. Estimated distance
was about 1100 miles and we (optimistically) calculated driving time @ 18
hours. What I didn't appreciate on the map, however, was that 65 is not even
a divided highway, and leads straight through the Ozark mountains. To make a
long story short, it took us closer to 21 hours before arriving...and that
was with no snow on the roads.
For the return trip we drove from Kansas City to St.Louis and down 55 to New
Orleans. About 100 miles longer but definitely easier, especially with my '73
914 2.0 on tow. The Jeep had no problem pulling at 75 mph, although gas
mileage dropped from 18 mpg to 13 mpg. The dolly is indeed an extremely
stable way of towing a car, and as far as I can judge, no mechanical damage
has occurred.
We slept for 7 hours and managed to be back home at 7 PM on Sunday.
One thing I just found out: whenever a vehicle has wheels on the road,
whether driving or being towed, a VALID REGISTRATION is required in some
states. So I guess I lucked out...

Bart

'87 911 Carrera Cabriolet
'87 951
'74 914 1.8
'73 914 2.0
'93 Jeep GC Ltd (with 2300 miles more...)

There was a Euro version with one-barrel Solexes, but the EP version 
was artifically created to accommodate moving an established technology
(PII-40s on 356) into a new car.

A minor writeup that this is now legal, complete with the Porsche
part numbers needed to make it work, is in one of the early UpFixin's...

Stan

Date: Sun, 15 Jan 95 18:03:18 US/Eastern

> Friends,
> 
> My '87 951 (75,000 miles) recently developed a front vibration when applying
> the brakes lightly to moderately. When braking hard, this vibration
> disappears. I am not quite sure whether it is a sensation transmitted via the

> brake pedal, or felt via the body.
> 
> I initially thought of warped brake rotors, but then, wouldn't that continue
> under harder braking ?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Bart (AllPorsche@aol.com)

Hi, Bart,

Nope, you have warped rotors.  Have them checked for runout and replaced.

Don't waste your time with turning them... They will just warp again.
Put new rotors and new pads on (most people are capable of this) and drive
on in peaceful, vibrationless bliss.

Good luck,

- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

Date: Sun, 15 Jan 95 20:44:15 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Gearbox oils

First a caveat.  I deal with this on a theory basis.

The demands upon a gear oil are very interesting.  It isn't very
surprising that different oils give different optimizations.  Modern
hypoid differentials have a lot of sliding which must be lubricated.
Some of the oils which preserve these gears are highly corrosive,
but build up slippery resultant surface coatings.  This is no problem
if the differential is separate from the gearbox (!-).

The gears and bearings simply want good slippery lubrication with
enough film strength to keep metal parts from rubbing.  This is
another compromise element, not necessarily matched to the one above.

The synchronizers need to have viscosity and friction properties that
allow them to engage (non-lubricant behavior) and then free again
before going into gear.  They don't want high wear, so lubricant
properties are really needed.

This all is approached with a variety of mechanisms, materials, and
lubricants.  A single number on a gearbox oil will probably be
insufficient to describe the needed properties.  Those gearboxes that
combine differential and gearbox with the same oil will need different
materials than those which separate them.

Rick Dill

Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 22:50:37 -0500
From: YoramGuy@aol.com
Subject: '86 vs '87 Carrera Preference

Stan,
On a couple of occasions you voiced your preference for the '86 Carrera among
later model 911's.  I understand some of that preference to center around the
915 vs G-50 transmissions, and I believe we agreed to disagree on that one...
Are there any other particulars which you prefer in the '86 over the '87
(which is my 'target')?
I'd appreciate any details, and any opinions from the rest of the forum.

Thanks,
Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI
...Still Looking for an '87 Carrera Coupe...

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 22:08:22 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: '86 vs '87 Carrera Preference

> Are there any other particulars which you prefer in the '86 over the '87
> (which is my 'target')?
> I'd appreciate any details, and any opinions from the rest of the forum.

Nope. It's the 915 vs. G50 thing that drives me. '86 is the earliest year
Carrera to get if you're getting a Carrera, at least as I see it. From
my perspective, you get a Carrera or newer if you're looking for a "civilized"
Porsche, something that you can drive daily without giving up too many of
the creature comforts you'd have in say a Maxima or similar. So, the '86
has the "fixed" A/C which has bigger vents and integration with the
heater, they typically have luxo features like most are in full leather, and
most have sunroofs and all have electric windows and typically door
locks. In '87 they kept all that but added the G-50. From the perspective
of meeting the target I describe, you can't go wrong with a later car,
right on up to the last of the C2s just before the 993 (which I put in 
a completely different category, BTW).

I however am driving a 30+ year old car, and immediately prior had a 
Euro 911 that was as bare bones as I could find. I'm looking for performance,
and don't want things getting in my way. Like not being able to find
7:31 ring and pinion for the G50. Like the extra weight from all the
luxo stuff. Like that extra 2" of headroom I need so badly that the
blasted sunroof eats. So I want the latest car that I can find that doesn't
bring too much extra baggage with it.

So my ideal compromise car would be a '86 factory turbo look cab. Something
I can tweek slightly and be *VERY* happy with, but comfortable enough
that my wife won't roll her eyes and sigh. However, the compromise winds
seem to be blowing into a different pattern of late: a tow vehicle and
dedicated competition car, with a 356 or 3 for daily driver and fun...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 02:49:35 -0500

Subject: Re: CA 912 Smog Test.

Dear Thom:

         The Old  California Smog Law had a 20-year sliding exemption scale,
but the NEW CA smog law does NOT!   So, as it is now, 1965 and earlier cars
ARE exempt, but everything later must be tested every 2 years. And it's even
worse- starting in 1996 (but soon to be postponed until 1997, after the '96
elections) is the Dreaded IM240 test- a 6 minute DYNO test that will take at
least a half-hour to perform and lead to long lines and ping-ponging back to
your mechanic and back to the smog test and back to your mechanic 'cause the
testers can't do any adjustments and the adjusters can't do the testing! And
the cost limit will be $450, but suppose you need  two jobs costing $400
each- you gotta do BOTH and suppose you need a $1500 valve job to pass the
test, you gotta do it. And suppose you need THREE $300 jobs, you gotta do 2
 but not the third, but you get only a ONE-time exemption  so the next time
you're out of luck.
     The Maestro predicts that once this IM240 disasater hits Joe Sixpack,
there's gonna be another American Revolution. (Too bad it'll have to wait
till the year 2000 elections to make itself felt, but  it will.
    It the meantime, ALL 356's are EXEMPT FOR ALL THE CA SMOG TESTS- FOREVER!
(Well, that's what the Smog Boys claim in their "Smog Reporter" sent to all
Licensed Shops, of which the Maestro is one.)

    All the more reason to:
KEEP THE 356 FAITH!!!
The Maestro


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1074                         Mon Jan 16 16:10:23 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 00:40:32 -0800
From: uo14@freenet.victoria.bc.ca (Eric R. Cherneff)
Subject: re: paint and sandpaper



Peter A. recently mentioned a Japanese sandpaper that is newly available
for polishing paint. I brought some of that paper back from Japan, and it
is truly amazing. The grit scale is from 400 to 1200, based on a system
that is 1/4 the system we use (i.e. 1200=4800 our system). The back of
this sheet is rougher than the abrasive! It seems to be made of a plastic
sheet, which is very durable. I have used it for polishing rocker shafts
and arms on 356 motors to a mirror-like finish. I haven't tried it on
paint yet, but I suspect the results would be great if you had the
patience. If anyone is interested, the stuff is called "Rub-lap" and it is
made by Kovax (Komatsubara Abrasive Co.). I don't know where you can get
it here, though.

Eric
'60 356B
'75 914 2.0

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 09:50:22 -0500
From: LeeW639371@aol.com
Subject: 993 ride height

To: The guy who asked me about Euro ride height for the
      993 (Sorry, I lost your name).
From: Lee Walczak / Wash., D.C
Re: 993 suspension adjustments

Here's the deal: The 993 front suspension is adjustable, I'm
told, in the usual way. You can raise or lower the collar around
the shock tower. The rear is different. You can fine-tune the
ride height via three shims that Porsche makes: 3 mm, 5 mm,
and 8 mm. If your friend really wants Euro ride height (about
1-in. lower than U.S.), tell him to get Porsche lowering springs
matched to his suspension (normal or sport). I'm running H&R
springs that take the car down 1-1 1/2/-in. and have no problems.
The car rides about as low as my old 944T did, which means I
have to be careful at driveway dips. Hope this helps...
.

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 10:42:55 PST
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: Balupunkt

>I replaced a Blaupunkt in my Audi with a Pioneer, and it did wonders for the sound quality.
>Bob Joyce

Back in 1987 I put a Balupunkt Lexington with some honeycomb 3.5" into my 1982 Mercury Capri and it sounded 
great.  More importantly, I appreciated the clean design of the unit - simple layout of the controls, clean sound, and 
problem-free operation.  It's been a long time since I've shopped for car audio, but my opinion back then was that the 
Japanese head units had too many features on too few controls - and too many tiny buttons.  They certainly did not look 
as solid as the Blaupunkts at the time.

However, I will say this - a friend of mine has a Sony CD head unit with detachable face.  A real nice unit available at a 
decent price from Crutchfield's or some similar place.

Matt Carpenter - mwc@lubrizol.com
'84 928S

From: owner-porschephiles@tta.com

	id m0rTuMx-0000b2C; Mon, 16 Jan 95 11:33 EST
Message-Id: <m0rTuMx-0000b2C@inasec.ca>
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: Re: towing - Cnd. Info.
To: Porschephiles@tta.com
Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 11:33:27 -0500 (EST)
In-Reply-To: <33556.tc17@cornell.edu> from "thak chaloemtiarana" at Jan 16, 95 09:19:12 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 2322      

thak chaloemtiarana said...
> I plan to attend several driver's ed next year and am figuring the least
> ...
> dolly?  Are there any restrictions about towing a car into Canada?

Well, the rules in Canada are pretty much the same as in the states - the 
trailer has to be plated and insured, no radar detectors, and Southern 
Ontario has photo radar now - hmmm. ok, so they're a bit different.

I'm pretty sure you need trailer brakes as well.

The main problem people seem to have bringing cars into Canada for 
events is confused student customs officers. Their guidelines seem to 
change every year <sigh>. A good idea would be to call ahead to the 
border, or to convoy with some others. At our region's weekends, it seems 
the first couple of 'marecans crossing the border gets a raised eyebrow, 
but if a half-dozen Porsches on trailers show up at once, well...

We used to give out information on getting thru customs, but we were 
wrong more often than right. In general, though, make sure you have some 
kind of official paper saying you own the car, and impress on the customs 
person that the car is *not* staying in Canada - it is going back home 
the same way (and hopefully the same condition :) it came in. Their 
primary concerns are making sure the vehicle is in the hands of its 
rightful owner, and that duty is paid if the car is staying in Canada.

btw, Rennsport region's calendar of driver's education events (blatant 
advert here) will be posted at the Web site below later this week. It was 
supposed to be last week, but our executive meeting got cancelled due to 
continuous freezing rain.... <sigh>

New feature this year, though - at our Mont-Tremblant events (at least the
first one), we'll be running an autocross (a *fun* autocross) on the
skidpad at the same time. It should stretch our organizational abilities 
to the limit, but we're looking for new challenges, now that we've 
mastered the four-lane, no-waiting, chinese-fire-drill, morning tech 
inspection... :)

 --- << snip >> ---
Craig Seko (613)951-6960 in Ottawa, the 2nd coldest capital in the world. 
| LiveWire BBS (613) 746-2001 | Personal and Porsche club info are at:  |
| telnet live.inasec.ca       |  http://www.inasec.ca/people/Craig_Seko |
These are my opinions and I alone am responsible for them. Live free or die.

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 10:42:19 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Minor Mods and AutoX Legality


I've been following the thread on PCA/SCCA rules and regulations.  Interesting.

My '87 911 has had the ever popular cracking/failure of the rear sway bar
mounts.  To remedy this, I have welded up the mounts with an additional
piece of metal across the open side, effectively turning the C-shaped bracket
into a box channel.  This is intended to reinforce the piece and redistribute
the bending stresses to prevent future failure.

So, does this modification of a "suspension related" nature eliminate me from
legally competing in the PCA-P15 and SCCA-AS stock categories?

Date: 16 Jan 95 12:43:05 EST
From: Dennis Winter <71334.2372@compuserve.com>
Subject: '86 vs '87 Carrera Preference

>>I'd appreciate any details, and any opinions from the rest of the forum.

>>Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI
>>...Still Looking for an '87 Carrera Coupe...

Guy,

I have opinions on 87 Carrera's. I had one, my wife had one, I have a friend who
still has one. I had only one gripe about the car, which caused me to sell it.
I put 52,000 mile on mine. Replaced the head temperature sender 3 times. My
wifes car has a lot less milage on it, we replaced the head temperature sender
only once. My friends car has even less milage on it, he has replaced the head
temperature sender twice so far.

My wifes car we also sold, but it had other problems that I attribute to it and
not to 87's in general.

I don't know if the head temperature sender is a problem with other than 87's,
but believe the above is enough evidence that it is a problem with 87's.

The head temperature sender problem was so annoying for me for two reasons.

 1-When it goes out, the car is dead. It does give you plenty of warning, but
when it goes, the car won't start. Well... it will start after it cools off, but
it will quit again as soon as it warms up. Not long enough to drive anywhere.
The warning signs are the engine starts cutting out. Like one or two cylinders
don't fire. This happened to me so much in the 911 that my heart still skips
when my 914 does it, but its never gone dead on me.

 2-The dealer (3 of them) will adamantly deny that the head temperature sender
can be the problem, insisting that it has to be something else. The local dealer
kept the car for three days, said there was nothing wrong with it, and refused
to replace the head temperature sender. This was the forth failure I personally
experienced, so I had become very familiar with the symptoms.

	D.	16-Jan-95 at 09:36:50 PT

When I was atuoxing my 73 2.0 I flat towed it all over northern calif.

have to cut holes in the front trunk floor pan. I also had to hook into 
the light system to have brake and turn lights work on the 914.

WILL STEER.  Also you can never back up.

twoing do not need it.

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 11:50:33 -0700
From: Corey_Jackson@HP-Loveland-om10.om.hp.com
Subject: 944 steering failure

Item Subject: Text_1
     This weekend I diagnosed and fixed the reason for the sloshy steering 
     on my 85.5 944.  Of the four bolts holding the steering rack to the 
     chassis member, two had sheared off.  They were the two on the 
     driver's side (of course).  The rack was just sliding in the mount on 
     the passenger side.  360 degrees of steering play makes for a tiring 
     ride!  
     
     These bolts are M10 8.8 bolts.  I suspect the top bolt failed first, 
     then the rack came out of its proper location and the second bolt 
     failed after about two weeks.  Has anyone had similar problems?  I 
     replaced the failed bolts with similar 8.8 bolts.  Is there a 10.8 or 
     other useful strength I should use?  There didn't appear to be any 
     other damage.
     
     ---------------------------------------------------------------------
     Corey Jackson                      Colorado Memory Systems Division
     (303)635-7303                      Hewlett-Packard Co.   Loveland, CO  
          

------------------------------

Date: 16 Jan 95 10:59:48 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: Euro 911 Paperwork


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: Euro 911 Paperwork
Date: 1995-01-16 12:50
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Peter Leckband asked:
>Stan replied to Brett Morrison regarding the potential purchase of a 911
Euro
>car and the importance of the 'correct papers' from EPA and DOT.  I've
looked
>at 5 or 6 Euro cars in the last 6 years and have received only blank stares
>when I've asked to see copies of the waivers.  Can any of you tell me
exactly
>
<snip>

This hasn't come up for a while, but one of the considerations (no matter
how remote it might seem to you NOW) is that if you ever do compete in
Autocross in PCA or SCCA the fact alone that your car is a EURO will throw
you into higher classes.  Both rule sets are based on "available and
delivered through U.S. dealerships" (or similar wording) vehicles in the
more stock classes.  I've seen a couple of folks get screwed on this
technicality after they casually attend an autocross and then get hooked --
then they find their Euro car is totally non-competitive in the "MOD"
classes in which it gets placed.

 -Scott Jessen



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 11:12:49 pst
From: Jon_Kies-CC_at_ASTFIN@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Re: towing 914

    Dear Thak,
    
    Below is a description of an expensive ($600) flat tow-bar rig  that 
    requires no cutting to install.  Flat towing is easy, as long as you...
    
        1)  Unhook the battery
        2)  Turn the ignition key past the steering wheel lock.
        3)  Don't back up (more than a foot or two)
    
    If you are flat towing correctly, the wheels (and hence the steering 
    wheel) turn in the same direction as the tow vehicle.  It is kind of 
    wierd to look in the rear view mirror and see the pilotless 914 
    steering wheel turning as you turn.
    
    The very nice tow bar...
    
    The tow bar is 5 separate pieces.  4 of the pieces attach to the car, 
    the 5th piece is the tow bar.  Two of the four pieces attach to outside 
    the vehicle body behind the front bumber.  They have tabs that extend 
    out the fog light opening for attachment to the towbar.  The other two 
    pieces attach inside the vehicle body.  These inside pieces extend from 
    the mounting bolts of the towbar tabs to the rails running through the 
    spare tire compartment. They transfer the pulling load from the 
    perpendicular front body sheet metal to the longitudal front rails.
    
    Installation is about 2-3 hours.  Topper Chasse currently manufactures 
    all the pieces and does an excellent job.  Very heavy duty with top 
    grade hardware.  He can be reached at his office at 818 845 2530.  
    Expect to pay about $600 incl tax.  Pretty steep, but when you consider 
    the advantages of flat towing (reduced weight to pull, no 
    loading/unloading), it starts to become worth it.
    
    
    Thanks,
    Jon
    




------------------------------

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 11:13:22 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: Cold Galvanizing 


To Derek and a few others that have written. 

The can of paint I have is called, "Cold Galvanizing" I will get the 
manufacturer and address if I can. The Eastwood product has similar 
properties, though I'm not sure of the ingredients.

I purchased my spray can from Orchard Supply Hardware, a chain in California
that has carried the product for 20 years.

I find that a coating lasts for about two years, I have very little scale
and exterior rust. Oil droppings, unfortunately, do stain it, much the same
as the original factory paint. 

FYI, 1974 and later 911s have stainless composition mufflers. They were
not coated with any paint.

1973 and earlier 911s, all 914s, 1976-77 924, 912, 912E and some 928s had 
gray finish paint on the exhaust systems. The remainder had stainless or a 
black finish (944) on the exhaust systems.

Sorry for any confusion. You are correct about varying qualities of paints,
I will get the manufacturer of the one I use.

Jim Pasha

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 14:33:21 -0500
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: 993 ride height

Pete(s),

I checked some factory 993 lit. I have.  The std. 993 is listed at a height
of 1300mm.  The "sport" version is listed as being 10mm lower in the front
and 20mm lower in the rear.  
Don't know exactly how that would work out on the height.  The "lower" is
effected with shorter springs with different spring rates on the sport
version, according to the lit.

The (new) Euro. RS/ RS Clubsport is listed with a height of 1265mm.

I could find no reference for the std 993 Euro versus std 993 US being
different from each other.

 -Allen Henderson-

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 11:59:48 PST
From: tobias@sybase.com (Tobias Olney)
Subject: Re: Tour a al Grape problems (long)


Mike Dayton wrote:
- -----------------
>Maybe we should start by *all* writing the chamber of commerce of 
>that town. I'm certainly fed up.  It's our country.  It's our tax dollars.  
>Where do I sign up?

Post the Chamber of Commerce's address.  I'll write 'em a letter!
- ----------------

Before we go sending boycotting hate mail to the Chamber of Commerce,
perhaps we should take a minute to evaluate the situation more
thoroughly.

What we know so far:

1. Porschephile allegedly unjust ticket.

A member of Porschephiles got a ticket to the tune of, what was it,
$179? for going 50 in a 55. He sent in the ticket with a check and
a letter of protest, only to get slapped with an additional $100
fine.

2. Testimony that ticketed Porschephile tends to be a jerk.

Another member of Porshcephiles claims that abovementioned ticket
victim is something of a jerk, and gives examples of inappropriate
behavior at some concours Parade event or other.


What we don't know for sure yet, and ought to find out before we
start boycotting a whole community:

1. What violations were REALLY being committed? 

My only official moving violation in 11 years of driving was for
doing 65 in a 55. What the ticket didn't say was that I was actually
doing 80 in a trashy Datsun with one brake light out, which the cop
was nice enough to omit from the report (I was a pennyless student
in a hurry). Perhaps our persecuted Porschephile was going 
50 in a 55 BACKWARDS, or with plastic wrap on his tires (see
Testimony above)? Did he moon the cop as he was approaching the
vehicle?

2. What exactly did the ticket victim's letter of protest say?

Did it say "Here's your f***ing money, you ***holes. Why don't
you stick it up your..." etc. ?

3. What exactly did the response with additional $100 fine say?

We should give the county a chance to tell their side of the
story.


Don't get me wrong, I'm all for organizing against unjust tickets
doled out to people just because they drive Porsches. I drive
one myself (when it's running - no tickets yet), and if we can
determine that the county really did mistreat our ticketed Porsche-
phile, then I'll vollunteer to be the first to write them a letter.

What I want to avoid here is a big reactionary movement to boycott
an entire county that is centered around an event that just might
be a cop dropping indecent exposure and reckless driving charges
against the kind of ***hole that give the rest of us Porsche drivers
a bad reputation, and instead being nice with an easier 50 in a 55
offense.

Let's try to treat the county as justly as we expect to be treated.
They should get exactly what they deserve.

 -Tobias Olney
'81 $931$ - wanna buy it?
looking for a 914 2.0 in great shape for autocross/daily driving

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 12:27:56 EST
From: sanctus2@annex.com
Subject: 928S alignment


I have been trying to get my '86 928S aligned correctly for 6 months
now.  I have paid for 3 seperate alignments at 2 different Porsche
dealers.

The latest alignment so far is the best (at least the car isn't pulling
to the right any more) but it's not perfect.  Is it impossible to align
a 928S so that the it drives perfectly straight?

The dealer gave me a computer printout of the results of the latest
alignment:

Before:

         Left Front                                  Right Front
  Min.   Nominal    Max  Actual             Actual   Min.  Nominal   Max
 - 0.67   - 0.50   - 0.33  - 0.6   Camber     - 0.7 - 0.67  - 0.50  -0.33
  3.49     3.50     4.00 ......   Caster    ......   3.49    3.50   4.00
  0.08     0.13     0.17   1.09     Toe      -1.22   0.08    0.13   0.17

          Left Rear                                  Right Rear
 - 0.83   - 0.67   - 0.50  - 1.2   Camber     - 1.2 - 0.83  - 0.67  -0.50
  0.08     0.17     0.25   0.01     Toe       0.09   0.08    0.17   0.25

************************************************************************

After:

         Left Front                                  Right Front
  Min.   Nominal    Max  Actual             Actual   Min.  Nominal   Max
 - 0.67   - 0.50   - 0.33  - 0.8   Camber    - 0.9 - 0.67  - 0.50   -0.33
  3.49     3.50     4.00    3.4   Caster      3.6   3.49    3.50    4.00
  0.08     0.13     0.17   0.14     Toe      0.15   0.08    0.13    0.17


         Left Rear                                   Right Rear
 - 0.83   - 0.67   - 0.50  - 1.4   Camber    - 1.3 - 0.83  - 0.67   -0.50
  0.08     0.17     0.25   0.18     Toe      0.15   0.08    0.17    0.25

Judging by these figures, (and I'm not sure what ALL of them mean) is
this an acceptable alignment?  Also the mechanic told me because my car
rides a bit lower than normal for a 928, it's harder to keep it aligned.
Is this true?

Jack Schwartz
sanctus2@annex.com

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 13:07:22 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: !#&$%*#@# Mechanics...Stripped 911 Tranny Plug..Help


Well, I managed to get a gallon of Swepco (for a case of beer,
no less!). Put the car up on jackstands, and went underneath
with my new 17mm hex wrench. The filler plug cam out with a
"snap" sound, and unscrewed fine, but it was obviously tightened
too much. The drain plug was a different matter...it has obviously
been abused, and the 17mm socket was more like 19mm at the top of
the socket, and 17 at the bottom. The sides of the plug were
rounded inside. I inserted the hex wrench, and carefully applied
torque. No go, and the insides of the plug started to round out
even more. I became apparent that the torque on this plug was more
than the 18ft-lbs that is required.

I have now managed to "round" out the insides of the plug, and am
stuck. So, any ideas? I can:

1) Try the hammer and chisel approach, and try to get enough material to
   drive the plug to unscrew it.

2) Drill out and use an easy-out. Does anyone know how big this plug is?
   It seems to be really soft, so it could be aluminum.

3) Pipe wrench on the theads that are sticking out of the tranny case.

I have ordered a new plug from the dealer, and have put out a contract on
the mechanic who last changed the tranny oil. I know I have at least 70ftlbs
before the socket stripped out.

Any suggestions?


Mike 83 911SC with a crippled drain plug :-(

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 13:44:05 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: 74 Carrera

I am going to be looking at a 74 911 Carrera on Wednesday. This particular
car has too many miles (280K) for me to be really serious about purchasing it,
but I thought it would be a good starting point for this year and model. At
least to see one extreme of the spectrum.

I know that the 2.7 engines had stud pulling problems, so Timeserting with
Dilivar or RaceTec studs are a must. This is the year before the thermal
reactors and the rest of the smog junk, so it seems a good compromise
for my purposes (daily driving, drivers ed, and autocross). Many folks
have replaced the engines of early cars with 3.0 or 3.2 liter motors,
but I don't want to get into that sort of modification just yet. And I don't
intend to build a mondo racer 'cause I just don't (yet?) have the driving
skill. I do want a car that will be fun to drive and good for developing
my meager skills with. I do like the earlier cars being that they are
leaner and lighter. I especially like the looks of the Carrera body
accents (flares, air dam, spoiler). If I could afford it (and/or the
market for these cars weren't so hopelessly inflated), I'd get a
'73 Carrera RS. I do know that the '74, while looking similar and
having a similar name, is not the same car: no lightening and
less HP. Other cars I am considering are a '72 or '73 S.

For those who may be wondering, I am now looking for a 911
rather than a late model 944S2. I have recently driven several
911's. There is something about the growl from behind and the
vibration in the seat of your pants that is hard to explain. Besides,
they hold their value *much* better than a 944. If I could afford
both, I would have a 944 for commuting and a 911 for the weekend,
but...

So, other than rust, are there any other things that one should look
out for or be aware/wary of in the '74 Carrera?

TIA,

    Eric, '84 944

Porschephiles #1075                         Tue Jan 17 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 17:48:40 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 924S Options and Suspension

Answers below,

> From:  <JoshB999@aol.com>
> Subject: 924S Options and Suspension
> Date: Saturday, January 14, 1995 7:05PM
>
> Well,  its done.  I took the plunge and picked up an 87 924S today.  If you
Congratulations!  I think you'll be very happy.

> 1: High beams wont go off.  The switch doesn't seem to want to budge and I am
> just curious if there is any way to fix this without taking the steering
> column apart.
The lever clips onto the high/low switch within the column.  Could be 
it just popped off, or maybe the plastic locking tab broke.  Either 
way, to examine the area you must remove the upper & lower plastic 
column covers.  Takes a phillips screwdriver only.  The wheel can stay on.

> 2:  Windshield wiper return/intermitent setting doesn't work.  Same question
> as above.
Could be a problem in the switch itself, connector, or relay.  Easiest 
thing is find another 924S/944 and swap wiper relays for a moment.

> 3: Tires, the car currently has Eagle ST 205/55R15s on it, the tread is
I've got 2 year old Goodrich Comp T/A's.  They have good dry grip and 
wonderful wet behavior.  Nice street tire overall.


		JBS

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 15:47:23 -0800

>  Randy B. Kirby                         Sensormatic Electronics Corporation 

Re the '90 C2, Bruce Anderson did a summary which is posted on Compuserve as 
follows;

 <There were a couple of problems with these early C2/4 models that can be 
an expensive nascence there were a lot of failures with the original dual 
mass fly wheel and there was a problem with the cylinder heads leaking. Both 
of these problems were fixed in 1991/92 and Porsche has been pretty good 
about helping fix the earlier cars.>

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 20:00:48 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re:Vibration/Blanchard grinding

Bart,
Vibration during braking:
First check the front wheel bearing for play. If none exists then you have
warped rotors. Either replace them or, if they are within specs, have them
Blanchard ground.
Don't bother having them turned. Blanchard grinding is the only acceptable
way to salvage rotors. New ones are probably the best answer, especially if
they are original to your car.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:37 pm

Date: 16 Jan 95 21:13:13 EST
From: "Byron D. Short" <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: Rules Schmoolz -- Just pick one!

There's a lot of threads here about the various rulesets we have to choose from.
Tell you what I think:  We're really lucky to have three, count 'em, three
available rulesets which fit the average Porsche owner's idea of "stock".  To be
100% as competitive as you can be, of course, you have to pick a venue!  If
you're willing to settle for 80% you can build for two rulesets at the same
time.  If you've already built the car it would be merely a coincidence if it
happened to exactly match the hot setup for any ruleset.

The current progression, from most stock, to most wild is:
	SCCA Stock  -->  PCA Stock  --> SCCA Street Prepared.
It's not a natural progression, however as some SCCA Stock items could be
illegal in PCA Stock, and some PCA items could be illegal in SP.  (SCCA Stock
does, of course, progress naturally to SP.)  

To try to make sense of any ruleset, assume it came together through the
"dartboard" method.  In this method, the votes of the governing body are taken
by throwing darts while blindfolded at a spinning dartboard lined alternately
with the words "NO" and "YES".  Once you assume this, you are left with no
politics, no "fairness" issues, just a set of rules.  Some rules we like.  Some
we hate.  Some help my car.  Some don't.  But they still are the rules.   

I would try to determine which set (of the three available) seemed to most
closely match what I want to do to my car, then I would build to that ruleset.
If my goal was just a monthly speed fix, I'd build accordingly.  If my goal was
a national championship, well, that's different--more costly and not necessarily
more fun either.

Since joining the SCCA's SEB I've found that I know less and less.
Particularly, I can't really know anymore what constitutes "fairness".  Every
time I think I've hit on one tiny little morsel of the stuff, some driver comes
along who's better than we thought, or who figures out a new interpretation, and
suddenly "fairness" isn't so concrete.  "Gray areas" sometimes expand to the
point that black and white seem like distant points on opposite horizons.
Still, I think, we progress towards a better ruleset, often times, despite
ourselves.  From what I know of the PCA ruleset (which admittedly isn't much) it
seems to me they have done a very nice job of meeting their member's needs.  I'm
jealous that they get to work within one marque which seems easier to me; but
then that feeling would probably evaporate if I sat on their board.

Hey, explore your options!  I suppose the perfect ruleset is one which allows
exactly what you've done to your car and no more, and classes you against 30
other competitors just like you! (Or 30 half-blind guys in Yugos, depending on
your point of view ;^) !)  Barring that, just build it so you can have fun!  

Byron Short

Now if you wouldn't all mind, kindly forget that I'm one of those damned,
sh*t-for-brains, could say as dumb as a babboon, but the babboons would be
insulted, rules guys so we can talk Porsches!

87 944 Turbo 
90 944S2  


------------------------------

Date: 16 Jan 95 21:21:07 EST
From: "Byron D. Short" <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: SCCA SEB and chain tensioners

>Loti.

The biggest problem is making one stock legal and proving it.  I'm not
sure how they'd do in legal trim; probably no real threat of seeing one
this way, especially after all the hoops old Porsches have been made to
jump through.  Steve (Compton) and I have often said that you could pass
100 street-driven 914's in front of us and unless they've been
conscienscously built to SCCA rules, we could throw out 99.  Heck just
pull the distributor cap and look for the rev-limiting rotor--that'll
eliminate 90 or more!  The cars just don't exist in SCCA legal trim until
they've been put that way--and that ain't cheap!  I bet the problem with a
Lotus is even more humongou$.

>Chain tensioners.

Someone said earlier that Porsche would never have issued a recall, as
that would have put them at risk of lots of law suits.  I totally
disagree.  914's had the recall for the sub-standard fuel lines (which are
therefore legal in SCCA), and that problem could be far more catastrophic
to the driver, and therefore litigation-wise.  Getting PCNA to say that
they "accept" the tensioners probably won't sway the SEB since Porsche
will gladly "accept" 2" wider wheels, stiffer springs, and more.  Let's
face it, Porsche will "accept" anything that makes the cars go faster;
that doesn't mean it's a recall item, or even a recommendation.  So first
choice is a recall or other similar "factory directive".  Second is a
factory "recommendation" for non-competition use.  Barring these two,
we're better to go without Porsche documentation and appeal to common
sense (yeah, I know, using the words "SEB" and "common sense" in the same
sentence is a misdemeanor in some states).  ;^)

Regarding our chances:  with a factory recall or mandatory directive, near
90%!  With a factory recommendation probably 30-40%.  With neither,
probably less than 10%.  That's either great news or horrible news
depending on what the factory says. . .but then I had previously said it
would be a cold day in Hades before we could get ride-height adjusted
914's to stay in CS.  Like I said previously, I'd really like to see the
discussion rather than just accepting it "because that's how it's always
been done."

>S2.  How did you ever find one with the M030???

Pure blind dumb luck!  I put out the word on Compuserve and the second
response was a "vapor car" supposedly coming in off of a lease prior to
actual lease end.  Since my background is in the car business I know that
this is a very tricky deal, to break a lease early, so I didn't have a lot
of desire to jump through all those hoops.  That is, until the dealer
offered to read me the original window sticker, which as paid options ONLY
listed the Limited Slip and the Sport Chassis.  Very calmly I had him go
out and check the build codes behind the rear carpet.  "030".  Suffice it
to say I became *much* more interested!!  With some patience (not my best
quality) the hoops were finally cleared and I struck the deal over the
phone.

I'm the second owner.  All service records are there.  Oil changes every
2500 miles, even while on vacation in Florida.  The car has only minor
paint chipping in the lower rockers behind the wheels.  Everything else is
perfect.  56K miles.  This weekend we screwed down the perches and
adjusted the rear spring strut, dropping the car around 1.5" all around. 
Laying under the car it's clear that we found a truly exceptional vehicle.
The only difficulties were breaking bolts loose--obviously the first owner
never tinkered with ANYTHING.  All the part #'s are correct, the paint
dots on the springs are right, it's like he knew he was just breaking it
in for me!

We'll race it for the first time this weekend, then once more before we
drag it out to Jacksonville for the season opener.  All the car needs now
is a bunch of white checkers on the nose!!  :-)

Byron Short

87 944 Turbo  --  looks good from 100 yards plus.
90 944S2 M030 --  the real deal.
 


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 18:38:01 -0800 (PST)
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: 6v optical point replacement

>Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 08:26:35 -0600 (CST)
>From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
>Subject: Optical ignition triggers

>I'm helping another 356 owner fix some problems he's been having.
>Since I have been singularly unsuccessful at talking this guy out
>of his preconceived notions as to what's really wrong, and have been
>asked to find or attempt to prove that this can't be done, I'll
>ask what should be a silly question:
>
>does anyone know of a 6 volt breakerless ignition system for or that
>can be adapted to 356s? 

At least there WAS a 6v Allison system that fit on the 356.

In the Automotion catalog (copyright 1992) page 119,

   "356 6-volt    XR-700     $159.95"

It is NOT listed in the latest Automotion catalog.

In the Allison 1989 Master Catalog,

    Allison lists this part number: 

       700-6231 is for use in the 4 cylinder - Porsche 356 6 Volt system.

The 1989 phone number for Allison is 818-303-3621

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com
