Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 18:58:31 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: 914 rebuild

Folks,

I remember a conversation I had on the phone one evening with a guy from FAT
Performance.  I memory serves, he told me that with the NPR 96mm kits that I 
should not install the metal gaskets on the shoulders of the heads.   I take
this to mean that the bigger sleeves are somehow self-sealing.  

I've tried the installation with and without.  With the gaskets there is a 
noticeable 'gap' at the top of the cylinder, but without them the cylinders
fit snugly with the combustion chambers.  I also noticed that without the 
gaskets the test install left small marks from the snug fit on the tops of
the cylinders.  Am I correct in leaving the gaskets off?

By the way, rough calculation of deck height vs combustion chamber volume 
shows that I'm somewhere between 8.2 and 8.8:1 for a compression ratio which
is fine as far as I'm concerned.

Thanks,
- --

 - Open Networks Engineering    fax:313 996 9908             abaris@msen.com -
 -                                                                           -   
 - [ '70 914 1.9 (96mm NPR, canary yellow 916 conversion) ]                  -

Date: Mon, 16 Jan 95 21:20:39 PST
From: waitz@siarc.com (Anthony A. Waitz)
Subject: Re: Porsche 924S

> Curious and curiouser.....  If yours was a special edition I am going to have
> to find out the history of mine.  I forgot to mention many of the other

Josh,

As far as I know the special edition 924S' were built in 88.  There were about
500 of them made and they had:
  mechanically
	heavier front sway bars
	adjustable front spring perches
	Koni adjustable shocks
	rear aluminum control arms
	15x7 wheels in rear
	no rear wiper
	manual windows
  aesthetically
	black exterior
	grey with maroon pin stripe interior
	maroon carpet
	
I will get the option code for this car and post it tomorrow.

Tony Waitz

------------------------------

Date: 16 Jan 95 21:54:48 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porschephiles #1074 Mon Jan 16 16:10:22

Hi, Peter.
 
>Is there a straight conversion between GL numbers and SAE numbers
 
No. SAE (Society of Automotive Engineers) number measures viscosity grade,
the GL number for gear lube or Sx or Cx designation (x is letter of alphabet)
for motor oil is an API (American Petroleum Institute) test standard. For
motor oils, these generally supercede each other; an oil that meets SH-CD
exceeds the demands to meet the older SF-CC standard.
 
Just to confuse everyone still more, there is another rating roughly
equivalent to the GL grades, and that is in the mil-spec (military
specifications) system. GL 5 is also MIL-L 2105B, GL 4 is MIL-L 2105.
 
GL3 - light to medium duty transmission and final drive service
GL4 - normal duty hypoid final drive lube, heavy duty transmission service,
roughly equivalent to MIL-L 2105.
GL5 - heavy duty hypoid final drive lube, roughly equivalent to MIL-L 2105 B
 
Now here's an interesting bit of trivia. For early 911s, Porsche specifically
did NOT approve GL 5 or MIL-L 2105B gear lube, calling for GL 4 or MIL-L 2105
only. That changed with the 1972 model, and the introduction of the Type 915
transmission replacing the Type 911. The Type 915 specifically called for
single-viscosity SAE 90 GL 5 (or MIL-L 2105B), but also permitted SAE 90 GL 4
(MIL-L 2105). I just ran across this today, while translating tech specs for
a new 911 book from German to English. It also says that "This [change to GL5]
is only possible because the Porsche blocking synchromesh can easily be adapted
to work at lower friction levels."
 
Pete

Date: 17 Jan 95 02:28:21 EST
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: 86'951 Running Hot

My 951 seems to be running warmer than it should. In the cold weather it 
runs to the last line on the temperature guage. The fan also runs after
the car is turned off. I just had my water pump replaced @ 99,000.
This was the second pump in less than 15,000! I have filed a claim with
PCNA (still under warranty).At the same time the water pump was replaced,
The sender for cooling # 928.606.201.01,thermofan switch #951.606.481.00,
and the fuel/temp guage were replaced. (Recomended by mechanic)

When the car is idling the temp gauge reaches the last line, but never
over in the red area. When I move again the temp falls to about the
half way mark. I don't think this is normal? The fan is coming on in
freezing weather! What is going to happen in the summer?

I thought it was standard that the thermostats (2) in the water pump are
replaced along with the pump? These parts 944.106.129.05, 951.106.311.00
are not on the parts list on my bill.

Also, the temperature switch 930.606.118.00 is still original. Could 
this be the problem? The coolant system was filled with Peak phosphate
free 50/50 mixture. The mechanic told me he bled the system twice, and
insured me that the system was bled properly.

Could I have a blocked radiator causing inefficient cooling?

I am taking the car back to have this problem resolved. The mechanic
agrees that there is some sort of problem. The shop is about 2 1/2 hours
away, thought I would post this before I see him next week.


The shop is Performance Plus in Northern N.J.  Owner: Tony Henderson

I would really appreciate some insight on this problem along with a
explaination on the function of these various sensors and switches
in the cooling system.

TIA

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 13:31:35 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: 944 still cutting out at medium revs


Thanks all for the helpful comments about why my 944 is cutting out 
whilst travelling at 50-70 mph.

I have checked all of the suggestions
1	pump - seems to be working fine

2	dodgy connects in pump wiring - all clean and good

3	throttle switch - seems to have no effect, there are in fact two 
switches in the same body one operates only with the throttle closed, the 
other operates only at 80+% open, so neither would seem to be involved.

4	damp dist cap - this would tend to produce erratic behaviour 
rather than dramatic cut outs

As far as I can tell, my fuel pump does not run until the engine is 
turning - is this normal on a 944/85

My latest theory is that I have a dodgy engine speed/position sensor 
there are two separate sensors, one controls timing + drives the rev 
counter, I am unsure what the other does ( probably metering). Presumably 
one of the sensors (via the dme) causes the fuel pump to be switched on.

The question is does this logic make sense, or am I missing something.

Pete

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 09:01:56 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Bought belt tool!

Dear Porsche friends:

Well, I finally broke down and bought the infamous and expensive belt adjusting
tool for my 944. I figured it was a good investment, no more trying to 
coordinate trips to mechanic with my SO, no more paying for the adjustments,
knowing that it has been done correctly, etc.

I should have it today. I have read the directions on the fiche and from what
I gather these are the steps:

Cam belt:
1. Cold engine. Remove what you need to get the job done...
2. Release belt tension by backing up crank 10 Degrees. About 1.5 teeth on the
   camshaft gear.
3. Measure, and if necessary loosen adjuster nut and adjust.
   To tighten belt turn adjuster CCW (is this right?)
4. Advance crank a couple of turns. Repeat #2 and #3 until in spec
   Specs is 2.7 +/- 0.3 (in Porsche's Magical P9201 units :)

For the balance shaft:
Can the measurement be taking directly on the belt as it lays there or does 
the same procedure (backing the crank CCW) must be performed before a
correct reading is obtained? 

Specs are like on cam belt 2.7 +/- 0.3. 

Note: the belt has 2K miles on it, the specs for a new belt are different!

Also, I believe the adjuster turns CW for a tighter belt. Is this correct?

One final ?, the idler for the balance belt should be 0.5mm from the lower
balance drive gear. Should the balance belt touch the top part of the idler
when adjusted properly?

Thanks!!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689

'85 Guards Red 944 (The Beast)

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 09:11:56 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 86'951 Running Hot

Hi, Michael,

There are a couple of things that could be causing your 
problem. Therefore, a couple of tests can help narrow down the 
source.

1) Try bridging the connector for the thermoswitch (on the 
radiator) to make the fans run *ALL* the time... If you are 
still having the problem with the high temperature, then the 
thermoswitch and the relay and fans are not the problem.

If that is the case, then you have three possible culprits:

a) The thermostat
b) The radiator
c) The waterpump

I would guess that the thermostat is the most likely culprit, you can
check it by removing and placing it in a pan of water on your (wife's)
stove, noting the temperature at which it opens.

The radiator might be clogged (the water passages) or have restricted airflow
(through pebbles etc. in the air passages)...

The waterpump may not be providing the right flow of water, but least likely 
of the three.

Good luck,


- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 09:27:32 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Bought belt tool!

> Dear Porsche friends:
> 
> Well, I finally broke down and bought the infamous and expensive belt adjusti
ng
> tool for my 944. I figured it was a good investment, no more trying to 
> Also, I believe the adjuster turns CW for a tighter belt. Is this correct?

Lou, the underlying principle is set the adjuster so that if it loosens a
bit, that it has a tendency to make the belt tighter and not looser...

> 
> One final ?, the idler for the balance belt should be 0.5mm from the lower
> balance drive gear. Should the balance belt touch the top part of the idler
> when adjusted properly?

The idler should not touch the balance belt, but just miss it. Not a
critical adjustment...

> 
> Thanks!!
> 
You're welcome...

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 10:11:34 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re:  PCRs vs Solo II Rules

David O. Blanchard replied :

>> I agree with David that the PCR's are NG. They allow an unbelievable
>> amount of modifications in the stock "P" class....
 
>> But from my experience at the Boston and Lake Placid parades, any of
>> the P classes could have been won by a good driver in a car without
>> modifications in excess of the SCCA stock rules. Proof is ... I won
>> The Boston Parade by 1.5 seconds over any other stock class, and
>> Franklin Wong won in Lake placid easily, both in SCCA stock cars.
>> I think Byron would beat all water cooled cars in a stock S2.

>Yes, Byron probably could.   He is a National SCCA class winner.  I'm
>glad he has an S2 and not something I own.

>You forget to mention that Franklin Wong is one of the best drivers in
>PCA (and SCCA) and owns THE car to own in the P6 class.  Not only that,
>he has prepared it to the nth degree.  We run out here in SFRegion SCCA.
>In SCCA, I don't have to run against 944s/924Ss but I'm very familiar
>with Franklin and his car.  He took first at San Diego Parade.  I took a 
>third.  The guy that took second was in a junky race car with plastic
>body pieces.  I didn't mind losing to Franklin, but was annoyed about
>having to run against a race car in what should be a stock class.
 
>> So don't be discouraged if your car is stock- get some good tires, drive
>> your best, and you can win.
 
>Sorry, that's not the way the world works.  Better cars that are better
>prepared and better driven, win.  Notice that there are three parts to 
>that equation: cars, prep and driving.  Oh, my car is prepared well,
>driven well, but is not as good an autocross car as a 944/924S.  So,
>when one with all three comes around (Like Franklin), my chances go down
>hill.  

You missed my point : I know Franklin is a great driver, but his car
is not "prepared", it is stock. His beating you simply proves my point-
he did not do any of the things I mentioned that are legal in PCA : 

> These rules basically allow ANY suspension (sways, torsion bars, 
> bushings, 1" wider wheels, etc)...

His car is not prepared to the Nth degree, it is just balanced well.
He DOES have the correct car to begin with- more important than preparation.
My point is that a well driven SCCA Stock car will beat a PCA prepared 
car with an inferior driver. Of course, the PCA prepared car has an advantage
and will beat you- all other things equal. But winning autocross is mostly in
the mind and experience, car setup is not NEARLY as important. 

For more proof that a good SCCA stock car could have won any stock 
class in Boston, take my time and multiply it by the SCCA solo-II PAX factors
to get times for some of the other classes. An interesting point if you do
this : 
the 962 driven by Derek Bell (?) in an "exhibition" run, without walking the
course,
would have been competitive in SCCA Modified classes for formula cars! And
the
brakes were dragging on the 962 because it was a display car and kids fooled
around
with the brake adjustment.

This year I set my car up to PCA rules : bigger torsion bars, adjustable
spring plates,
plastic bushings, 7" wheels with 225/50/15 tires, duck tail, etc. But I did
not go
substantially faster on the autocross course. I made these modifications to
try to
win the Porsche Parade in Lake placid, but my modifications backfired when my
rear spring plate bolts came loose and I went relatively slightly slower than
when
I was stock in Boston. In SCCA events (without the spring plate
problems) I was not much faster than before.

On racetracks these mods made a much bigger improvement - the car was
more controllable and precise.

Anyway :

***  gospel divider ********

Anyone who is serious about being a top autocross driver should
keep their car STOCK and concentrate on DRIVING. Trying to 
go faster with modifications every event will take focus away from
the driving and you will newer improve what really counts- yourself.

***  gospel divider ********


Rev. Mike Piera, '72 911S (rev limited to 7300)


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 09:25:06 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: poor mileage on a 73'S

There are many possibilities here. First, it is possible the rebuilt
unit was not the correct one for this car. If it is the correct unit it
may have never ben properly set up. If it is the proper unit and it was
properly set up, someone may have messed with it later, or it may have
failed (does he know if the entire unit was rebuilt?).

When MFI pumps go bad one symptom is they run way too rich. The smell of
gasoline in the oil would indicate the poor mileage problem is due to
the MFI. This is not good because the unburned fuel gets into the oil
and changes the lubrication properties which is bad news for bearings
and other moving parts.

The MFI may not be the cause of low mileage at all. It seems to me your
friend should get his MFI checked at a shop with early 911 experience
and an exhaust analyzer. 

It is possible poor compression, valves way out of adjustment or even
ignition system trouble could cause low gas mileage. The MFI may very
well be working perfectly. I think 15 mpg on the highway is too low and
means something needs attention.

It should cost less to get the MFI right  (Assuming you can find
someone competant to deal with the MFI unit) than to add CIS or
Webers.  The only reason to trash a MFI set up is if you just can not
find someone to set the car up properly (or someone has given you a new
Weber set up for free). Don't give up on MFI. When it works right,
there is nothing like it.


- ----- Begin Included Message -----
Hi everyone:
  My neighbor's 73' 911S was wrecked a couple years ago, damaging the 
engine bay.  The MFI pump was replaced with a rebuild unit along with heads, 
etc.  He complaint to me this morning that he only gets about 15 mpg on the 
highway, VS. 20 for my 69'S.  At first, I thought it's because of the 
larger displacement of his engine, but he said he remembers getting about 
20 mpg before the MFI job.  Can anyone help by pointing out possible 
problems/solutions?  Also, other than convertion to webers, are there any 
other MFI replacements?  Can a CIS system from a similar 
power/displacement car be used?  Thanks in advance!

						Chien Wang

69 911S



- ----- End Included Message -----

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 10:57:08 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 86'951 Running Hot

> When the car is idling the temp gauge reaches the last line, but never
> over in the red area. When I move again the temp falls to about the
> half way mark. I don't think this is normal? The fan is coming on in
> freezing weather! What is going to happen in the summer?
That's too high!  The gauge's movement and fan operation independently 
confirm that the water's too hot.  The gauge should be very close to 
the middle, assuming it's working OK (sounds like it is).

> Also, the temperature switch 930.606.118.00 is still original. Could
> this be the problem? The coolant system was filled with Peak phosphate
> free 50/50 mixture. The mechanic told me he bled the system twice, and
> insured me that the system was bled properly.
Peak antifreeze has phosphates, which you should avoid in aluminum 
engines.  Prestone makes a phosphate-free antifreeze in grey bottles now.

I've heard of several instances of failing radiator fan thermostat 
switches (me included).  They're cheap and medium-difficult to replace.

> Could I have a blocked radiator causing inefficient cooling?
Possible, but I would doubt it.  This sort of thing is really rare.  
But if you (or a previous owner??)  used hole-plugging crud from the 
parts store, or the thing's in really bad condition then this is more possible.

Your problem could be:
1) System still needs bleeding.  Doing it twice doesn't guarantee 
anything but a higher bill.  Doing it *right* once is more important.  
Does your mechanic *really* know how to bleed a 944?
2) Fan switch defective for stage 1 operation (light cooling)
3) Defective waterpump
4) Blowing / blown head gasket
5) Blocked water flow

Your fans have 2 speeds: stage 1 is silent and fills most cooling 
needs.  Stage 2 is like a turbine and should virtually never be 
engaged.  This is true only for 85/2 and newer 944's.

The fans respond to the water temperature near their thermostat, on the 
radiator itself.  The temp. gauge responds to the head/block water temp 
via a sensor.  Notice that there's a [normally rigid] thermal coupling 
between the two, but if for instance, your radiator hose blew out, the 
radiator fans would *not* run but the engine would overheat.

So, If both fans & gauge say the water's hot, then it almost invariably 
*is* too hot.  Air in the system can do this, but usually not to the 
degree you specified.

Hope this helps,

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 08:06:43 EST
From: sanctus2@annex.com
Subject: 1986 951 Running Hot


71324.3010@compuserve.com wrote:

>71 My 951 seems to be running warmer than it should. In the cold weather it
>71 runs to the last line on the temperature guage. The fan also runs after
>71 the car is turned off.

>71 When the car is idling the temp gauge reaches the last line, but never
>71 over in the red area. When I move again the temp falls to about the
>71 half way mark. I don't think this is normal? The fan is coming on in
>71 freezing weather! What is going to happen in the summer?

71> Could I have a blocked radiator causing inefficient cooling?

I had a similar problem this past fall with my 928S.  It turned out
that my car was sucking up leaves like a vacuum cleaner!  I found my
radiator had about 30 leaves plastered to it!  Every day I removed the
leaves and the overheating problem went away.  I'm not saying that this
is the problem with your car but it's worth taking a look at.

Jack Schwartz
'86 928S Guards Red

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 10:15:20 -0600
From: Richard Hocking <hocking@cig.mot.com>
Subject: Re:Vibration/Blanchard grinding

- -- Begin original message --

> From: Jerry944T@aol.com
> Subject: Re:Vibration/Blanchard grinding
>
> Vibration during braking:
> First check the front wheel bearing for play. If none exists then you have
> warped rotors. Either replace them or, if they are within specs, have them
> Blanchard ground.
> Jerry

- -- End original message --

Question(s):  (Maybe dumb, but I am just starting to do my own work).

How do I check the front wheel bearings for play ?
What are the indicators that bearings are good/bad ?
Is the check for the front bearings and the rear bearings different ?
Is there a difference between how you perform the check on a 911 and a 944 ?

Thanks,
Richard Hocking
'87 911 Targa   [ RICK GB 1 ]

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 09:16:11 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: Re: Flight Level

Kit,
I have installed the pertronix system into a '69 912 with little to
no problems. I didn't have the vacuum advance type distributor thought (061).
In an 031 mechanical advance dist. it was a direct bolt in type install. With
an 050 mechanical I had to cut the flange off the rotor to fit the Ignitor
module onto the breaker plate. Maybe you should consider replacing the distributor to an 050. The Maestro sells them with his special mod. I have also installed
the perlux device into a VW bug 009 distributor with no problems. Good luck.
Sean

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 08:43:19 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thom Fitzpatrick" <thom@tim.com>
Subject: Re: 914 rebuild

>I remember a conversation I had on the phone one evening with a guy from FAT
>Performance.  I memory serves, he told me that with the NPR 96mm kits that I 
>should not install the metal gaskets on the shoulders of the heads.   I take
>this to mean that the bigger sleeves are somehow self-sealing.  
>
>I've tried the installation with and without.  With the gaskets there is a 
>noticeable 'gap' at the top of the cylinder, but without them the cylinders
>fit snugly with the combustion chambers.  I also noticed that without the 
>gaskets the test install left small marks from the snug fit on the tops of
>the cylinders.  Am I correct in leaving the gaskets off?

I whenever I put new cyliners on, I schmear some valve grinding compound 
in the head where the cyliner will seat, and then grind the cylinder in
the head for a bit.  Its s'posed to help them seat better.  

This is a St Muir VW trick.

Thom

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 09:39:38 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: Re: CA Smog

Just thought I'd add a little note to the pile about CA smog testing.
I had an '84 Fiero (I know!! but it was a good car!). Anyway I brought the 
car to the local shop to get a smog check. The car was running very well.
The mechanic gave me the bad news, it failed the test and in his words
"I can't believe this car made it here!". He claimed it needed piston rings.
Not a chance. So I paid him his smog fee plus the time to do a compression
check. I was refered to the CARB smog ref station. I went to the smog ref
and was told that the car need a new TBI (throttle body injector) and it would 
pass "no problem". He gave me the waiver ( due to the price of the replacement
unit.) and I was on my way. Now I have two "braintrust" opinions of why the car won't smog. Some time passes and I decide to sell the car. So back to the local
shop, just to get a failure so I can go to the smog ref again. He soaks me for 
another $80 and says "This thing still runs!". Like he knows what is going on!
It fails and I'm off to see the ref again. This time I've grown a beard and look a little different. I go to the same ref station and get the same ref as before and he tells me this time that the car needs a new prom chip and the car will
pass. I get another waiver.
    Basically, I'm just triing to say that these ref don't know S**T!!(sorry for the caps but it pisses me off) CA and myself like clean air but let's get some
useful people doing the checking and make the laws reasonable for people who
want to comply. So what if you don't have original equipment, as long as it 
passes. Everyone wins. Clean air and nice old cars. Just 2 more cents
Sean

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 13:37:04 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Wheel size conversion

Help !

'82 911 SC

Before I go to drivers Ed I want to mark the maximum downshift points on
my speedometer and the optimum upshift points on my tach.  I have bought
some lovely 1/16" red and blue tape and some 1/8" white vinyl numbers for
this.

Problem:  I just checked my owners manual, the speed to rpm chart is based
on 215/60 VR 15 tyres.  I have the 16" wheel option and am running
225/50 VR 16.  How do I convert between the two (these are original and
the speedo is calibrated properly ) ?

My plan is to convert the max downshift rpm to speed to mark on the speedo
since I don't there there'll be much wheel slip/skid when I'm downshifting,
and put the optimum upshift points on the tach since there will probably
be (possibly be?) some on hard accelerating.  The speedo will just be
marked with red lines, the tach will get blue lines and little numbers
since they're all clustered together.

Comments ?

>

>

>
>6 Volt XR700 Ignition Power Module & Optical Pick Up.......700-6021
>

>

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 13:54:38 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Wheel size conversion

> Before I go to drivers Ed I want to mark the maximum downshift points on
> my speedometer and the optimum upshift points on my tach.  I have bought
> some lovely 1/16" red and blue tape and some 1/8" white vinyl numbers for
> this.
> Problem:  I just checked my owners manual, the speed to rpm chart is based
> on 215/60 VR 15 tyres.  I have the 16" wheel option and am running
> 225/50 VR 16.  How do I convert between the two (these are original and
> the speedo is calibrated properly ) ?

If your speedo was not recalibrated to match the tires, there would be
no impact whatever from wheel/tire changes on the speed/rpm indicated.
The effect would be on actual speed vs. indicated speed. 

If your speedo is recalibrated, the difference is 1.19% - the 16 inch wheels
turn an extra 1.19% as often as the 15" wheels. So your speedo would be reading
higher by 1.19%.

> Comments ?

Watch the track - shift by ear & seat of pants. There's too much going
on out there to be looking at the tach/speedo all the time.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 12:42:59 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: RE> 914 + Solex

>> Did Porsche ever sell a 914 (European or otherwise) with Solexes? Or, is the
>> basis for SCCA EP 914's artificially created by the rules?
>
>There was a Euro version with one-barrel Solexes, but the EP version
>was artifically created to accommodate moving an established technology
>(PII-40s on 356) into a new car.

        The specific model in question was the Euro version of the 1.8L
1974 - 75 (? dunno if it lasted that long).  According to ol' Mr. Haynes,
the ROW 1.8L 914 had one of several carbeurators on it.  They use a Solex
(I think) as an example.  One barrel.
        US versions, of course, had the L-jetronic FI.

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 14:51:44 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: POR-15 and panel repair


Dear Bart,

When replacing the rear trunk floor with one of our replacement parts, it is
necessary to lift the reinforcement cap on the center brace (after cutting
its spotwelds) and then cut from left to right with a die grinder (This is
necessary because the original floor extends from the taillights to the
engine bay).

After all welding is completed, we coat all with metal ready cleaner and then
POR-15. Since both top and bottom surfaces are accessible, there is no need
to precoat. Additionally, the new trunk floor replacement is galvanized to
help protect it. Follow the instructions on the POR-15 can and spray on. You
can brush on the stuff, but this will require more sanding to get a smooth
top coat.

Next, we caulk all seams with seam sealer, prime and paint with polyurethene.
Always use proper breathing equipment and spray in an area with good
ventilation.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 14:47:41 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 A/C


Dear Craig,

The AC kit we have is mounted in the so-called factory position so the
condenser mounts above a square hole cut into the bottom of the front trunk
floor. The condenser used is $150.00. It is important to decide whether you
choose to install a DPD or VPC system. Both were dealer installed, but are
different enough to not be compatible. The DPD system offers more front trunk
room; the VPC unit better cooling.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 14:51:54 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Engine Removal & more


Dear Craig,

The factory has available a 914 cradle that fits a floor jack to assist in
engine removal. However, all one has to do is situate the floorjack under the
engine mounting bar. This will balance the power plant for removal.

You can certainly jack the front end with a floorjack and small piece of
plywood for cradling. Situate the floorjack directly under the center of the
cross member and jack there. Since the steering rack cover is attached to the
crossmember, caution has to be excercised when jacking, hence the plywood.

Additionally, four jacking donuts are available at the four corners of the
floor pan. These assist in jacking one corner.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 14:52:01 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 heat


Dear Craig and Stan,

If you look in Hot VWs magazine, you will see the advertisement for the
electric heaters. We don't receive the magazine and I do not remember the
name of the company. However, we have ordered and installed these units and
the both work great and fit perfectly. Write us if you cannot find the
listing and I will do more research.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 12:14:43 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Isocyanates

This is a follow-up to Peter Leckband's excellent posting
about the dangers of using paints with isocyanates 
without proper protection.

I've used SCUBA apparatus, which I think ought to be OK.  
It's probably not the best solution if you're painting all 
day, everyday, because you have to walk around with a 
tank on your back (unless you have a very long hose), and 
because you have to be careful not to let the drool that 
accumulates on the mouthpiece drip onto your beatiful 
paint job, but it does offer protection against breathing the 
isocyanate vapors.  If you do go this route, you can use a 
small cylinder, like a 30 cu ft one.  You'll use less than a 
quarter of a tank this size to do a whole car.

I also am told (or read) that one can absorb
the isocyanates through the skin, so it's a good idea to
wear something that covers arms, legs, head, etc.  (Maybe 
a  SCUBA mask for the face?  That might be carrying it a 
bit far.)

Also, if you don't want to fool with the isocyanates, but
still want to do a basecoat/clearcoat, PPG makes a 
clearcoat called NCT (New Clearcoat Technology) that is 
pretty good. It dries very fast (out of dust in a few minutes 
at most) and is nearly as hard as the catalyzed clearcoats 
with isocynates.  It's not quite as durable, at least 
according to PPG, but it's damn hard for me to tell.
I've got a red 240Z that I painted two years ago and it 
looks as good as when I did it, except for normal dings, 
etc. 

Bob Spindel

'72 911E, now actually restored, and which I might get to 
try out this weekend if the Seattle rains ever stop.

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 12:27:12 PST

Subject: Old Beaters, New Smog

Re: new smog laws

I agree, what becomes of an idea after it has been thru the political
process and then a state bureaucracy can be sad indeed.  I'm sure the AM
airwaves will fairly crackle with righteous anger when these new
laws hit.

But all you have to do is follow some yahoo down a long hill in his '55
pickup, or some Newly Arrived Family in their '72 Galaxie as they chuff 
down the freeway on 5 of 8 cylinders, and you know (or your nose
knows) the motivation for these laws!  Don't even get me started on the
CA school buses (smoky diesels exhausting straight-out at face level).

Too many cars (even clean ones) on the road.  Nothing that a 
dollar-a-gallon fuel tax wouldn't fix... but we all
know what the political process did with THAT idea...

 -Ed




------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 13:01:21 -0800
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: Wheel size conversion

> > Before I go to drivers Ed I want to mark the maximum downshift points on
> > my speedometer and the optimum upshift points on my tach.  I have bought
> > some lovely 1/16" red and blue tape and some 1/8" white vinyl numbers for
> > this.
> > Problem:  I just checked my owners manual, the speed to rpm chart is based
> > on 215/60 VR 15 tyres.  I have the 16" wheel option and am running
> > 225/50 VR 16.  How do I convert between the two (these are original and
> > the speedo is calibrated properly ) ?
>
> If your speedo was not recalibrated to match the tires, there would be
> no impact whatever from wheel/tire changes on the speed/rpm indicated.
> The effect would be on actual speed vs. indicated speed.
>
> If your speedo is recalibrated, the difference is 1.19% - the 16 inch wheels
> turn an extra 1.19% as often as the 15" wheels. So your speedo would be
reading
> higher by 1.19%.

1.19% at 122mph is a difference of 1.45mph.  This makes obsolutely no
difference on an SC speedo since the numbers are in 30mph increments
and white ticks are in 10mph increments.  By the way, you will have
only one upshift point on the tach.  On my stock SC I use just over
5500rpm.  All the race cars I have seen have the (up)shift point marked
on the tach.  It can be under, at, or over the factory redline indicator.
If you also want a downshift mark figure out where on the tach it is
safe to downshift from any gear.  You are only glancing at one gauge then.
My race car doesn't even have a speedometer.

> > Comments ?
>
> Watch the track - shift by ear & seat of pants. There's too much going
> on out there to be looking at the tach/speedo all the time.

If you haven't been using a marked up speedo on the street it is only
going to add confusion on the track.  Get comfortable with this on the
street before using it on the track.  The tach is easy to look at because
it is in the center.  I always glance at it when I hear the engine speed
up so I shift at the correct time.  The speedo is off to the side and the
only time I ever have time to look at it is on the straight.

It appears what you are trying to do is determine how to keep your engine
in its power range.  This is good.  If your drivers ed is on a racetrack
then ask people what gear each corner is in.  It is easy to equate a
corner to a gear.  Downshifting normally only occurs when you are also
braking.  Just remember to downshift when you are almost finished with
braking.  This allows the engine rpms to be as low as they will get.
Don't downshift when you start braking because the rpms haven't dropped
yet.

Have fun out there!

Keith Watson
'81 Porsche 911 SC Targa
'85 VW Golf - Conference Production H race car

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 16:16:52 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Wheel size conversion

> The 16" wheels are original.  And the speedo is calibrated very closely
> judging by the speeding ticket I got christmas eve :'(.  I just want
> to make sure I'm clear here - if the max downshift rpm from 5 to 4 (eg)
> says  5,000 rpm and the chart (based on 15" wheels) says 5,000 in 5th
>  = 122 mph then I multiply 122 by 1.19 to give 145 as the max down shift
>  speed from 5 to 4 with 16" wheels!  19% seems an awfully large difference!

Indeed it is! What I wrote was that the difference is 1.19 percent, not 19%!
The actual result is 122 * 1.0119 = 123.45mph - really a negligible correction.
There's no way I could tell the difference.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 13:20:10 -0800 (PST)
From: Tom Feller <tomf@mxim.com>
Subject: 914 P&C 

I will give you my $0.02 on this head gasket issue on the big air cooled 
VW engine.

All the bus/914 engine use head gaskets in the cylinder head.  The 1600 
bug/bus engines do not use head gaskets. If the case has been surfaced 
where the cylinders meet the case and the heads have been flycut insure a 
flat sealing surface, then a tight seal should be not problem.  If you 
don't want to spend the money the have the head surfaced the trick of 
using croase lapping compound to seal up the head works okay.

Now when you put in big bore piston and cylinders the thickness of the 
clyinder walls is smaller and/or the cylinder are bigger in diameter. Some 
engine builders prefer not to use the head gaskets because; One, they are 
too small or Two, the cylinder does not completely crush the gasket. The 
reasoning here is that the 1600 engine work fine without gasket so should 
the bus/914 motor. I has been my experience that this works just fine if 
the heads have been flycut and the case sealing surface is in good condition.


 - Tom Feller

Date: 17 Jan 95 16:48

   I don't even know that much about my 914, much less a 944.  His concerns
   are as follows:

   1) Is that price reasonable for the vintage & milage?  What should one
   expect in a 944 for $9000?

   2) Do these cars cost a fortune to maintain?(perhaps compared to a 914)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 17:43 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Fair 944 price?

CHRIS_FENDER@westcon.com stuck his head in to say:
   A co-worker has his eye on a '88 944 with 75K miles.  The owner is asking
   $9000.  My co-worker has never owned a P-car & he hasn't driven the car 
   but he says the car is in beautiful condition.

   I don't even know that much about my 914, much less a 944.  His concerns
   are as follows:

   1) Is that price reasonable for the vintage & milage?  What should one
   expect in a 944 for $9000?

I'll check my blue book tonight, but that sounds reasonable.  I paid more for
an '87 944S, but it had less than half the mileage of the one your friend is
considering.

   2) Do these cars cost a fortune to maintain?(perhaps compared to a 914)

Hmmmm, given the amount of 914 repair info on the list lately, I'd guess not! ;)
Seriously, there are a few known (notorious?) points of failure in 944s (water
pumps, oil coolers, motor mounts) but overall they are pretty reliable.  Just
tell your friend to make sure the seller has all the maintenance receipts.  The
most important item is to make sure when the timing and balance shaft belts
were changed.  These *must* be done every 40K miles.  If the owner doesn't have
the receipts, plan on having this done right away, so you can start your
"count-down timer" from a known point.  You should have your friend plan on
taking the car to a good Porsche mechanic and having a pre-purchase inspection
made.

Tracy Nelson (tnelson@telesciences.com)


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 15:12:18 -0800 (PST)
From: Tom Feller <tomf@mxim.com>
Subject: 15" vs 16" wheels 

I think that even 1.19 % difference is too much. Remember that the 15" 
wheels have 215/60 that gives a side wall height of about 129 mm. While 
the 16" wheel have 225/50 and a sidewall height of about 112.5 mm. With 
the 16" wheels 25.4 mm taller than the 15" and the 16" tires have a 16.5 
mm shorter sidewall the total differences in height between the 15" 
wheels and tires and the 16" wheel and tire is less than 10 mm.

Would this really change the speedo reading by 1.19% ?

 - Tom Feller

------------------------------

Date: 17 Jan 95 15:14:26 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Marking your tach & speedo for the track


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Marking your tach & speedo for the track
Date: 1995-01-17 17:01
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


>My plan is to convert the max downshift rpm to speed to mark on the speedo
>since I don't there there'll be much wheel slip/skid when I'm downshifting,
>and put the optimum upshift points on the tach since there will probably
>be (possibly be?) some on hard accelerating.  The speedo will just be
>marked with red lines, the tach will get blue lines and little numbers
>since they're all clustered together.
>
>Comments ?

Martin,
I'll be honest, my first reaction was "what the ___?" and then I remembered
the first time I went to a time trial/drivers ed. and how many little things
I worried about and how many big things I didn't know enough TO worry about
 -- then your idea made me smile.

Some words of advice:
If you have a rev limiter in the car and it works, keep your concentration
on the track, your line (braking turn-in points, etc.) and less on keeping
the engine at peak horsepower and torque or over-reving.  I would pop the
tach out and rotate it so the redline is at the top -- it won't be long
before your peripheral vision will pick up the needle as it hits high rpms.
 You are there to learn to drive your car at speed -- no matter what anyone
tells you DO NOT DRIVE FASTER THAN YOU ARE COMFORTABLE.  Most good
instructors will coach you on proper line, turn in, braking, markers to look
for on course, etc. and they will do all this at reduced speed.  Take your
time and absorb all you can and try not to get caught up in the
competitiveness, you will improve, you will get faster, and you can do it
without wrecking your car if you grow by slowly pushing your limits.  Have
fun and GOOD LUCK]

 -Scott Jessen



------------------------------

Date: 17 Jan 95 18:31:29 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: More trans oil stuff

Comment to myself re trans oil stuff. Earlier I posted that Porsche
recommended only API GL 4 trans oil for the old Type 911 trans, and
specifically said not to use GL 5. When the 915 trans came out on the '72
models, they recommended GL5, and said GL 4 was also OK.
 
But all of these recommendations were for single-viscosity SAE 90 oils, not
multigrade like SAE 75W-90 or such.
 
Continuing with my book translation, I came across some changes. They
stopped saying GL 4 was ok for the 1974 models. Beginningin 1987, they
recommend multi-viscosity trans oil, SAE 75W-90, MIL-L 2105B, API GL 5, and
that's where it stands today for the 95s.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 15:46:49 -0800 (PST)
From: Tom Feller <tomf@mxim.com>
Subject: Gear Oils Again

I have really enjoyed the response my recent post on gear oil. Some very 
good questions were raised so have I have gone out and checked out a 
few things.

1. I was wrong about the API service spec. GL-4 or Mil-L 2105 is the current 
requirement for up 1972.  The later 915 transmissions call for 
GL-5 or Mil-L 2105B NON HYPOID gear lube. A hypoid is when the pinion gear 
does not drive the ring gear at the center but rather some piont higher or 
lower than center. This type of drive places an extreme load on the ring 
gear and requires special additive to the gear lube. 

Both my factory manuals and my Porsche Spec books list non hypoid GL-5.

It is interesting to note that both my 924 and 944 books list
GL-4 or Mil-L 2105. In addition all VW, Audi and BMW manual transmissions 
call for GL-4/Mil-L 2105.
 
2. I visted with couple of my friends who own Porsche shops. One uses 
Valoline GL-3/GL-4 gear oil in all VW, Audi and Porsche manual 
transmission. The can states it is for use in Ford Tactors. The other 
uses Valoline GL-5 non-hypiod gear lube in the Porsches and GL-3/GL-4 in 
the VW/Audi's.  He said that the GL-5 non hypiod is for some kind of 
industial use.

Here is the info off the Kendal gear lube it have used before:

Kendal VW/Porsche-Audi Manual Transmission Gear Lube Part # 673-7740
	SAE 80w-90, API Service GL-4, Mil-L 2105
"Fromulated for manual transmissions and transaxless requiring special 
compoundings to satisfy the synchronizer coating requirements."

I have more to add to this but will wait to see the response first.

 - Tom Feller

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 95 18:13:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 86'951 Running Hot


I agree with George B's suggestions.  A couple of other things to
think about.  First is whether the radiator fans come on when the car
runs hot.  If not, maybe a good sign that the thermostat is not working.
If it's not working, the coolant in the engine will stay hot (per the
gauge in your dash), but the radiator will stay cool and so not
trigger the fan switch.

You might even be able to tell this by feel with your hand.  Try touching
hoses on both sides of the thermostat.  (When my oil cooler's thermo-
stat failed, I could see high temps in my oil temp gauge, while a hand
on the oil radiator found it cool.)

Also make sure that when the waterpump was replaced, Tony
installed a new thermostat the right way.  The new ones have are
offset differently in the waterpump housing with a rubber ring and
steel washer.  The thermostat has to be oriented properly in the
housing -- it has a bleed hole in its face.

When you are moving on the highway, the radiator fan is *not* a
factor in cooling the engine.  In fact, its blades impede cooling by
blocking a certain amount of fresh air flow.  I would say that if you
still see the needle at midpoint while cruising on the highway,
your problem is not the radiator fan or fan switch.

If you have been good about changing coolant once a year, and
I suppose sticking with the phosphate-free stuff, I don't think radiator
plugging should be an issue.  I could be wrong, though; this is just
from limited personal experience.

Unlikely that it's the waterpump.  BTW, the EuroSelect remanufactured
waterpumps are crap, in my opinion.  Most offended by the fact that
they pretty them up by spray painting them silver, yech.  However,
Porsche is currently paying $100 for cores and will buy them without
regard to exchange, sweet deal.

Hope this helps.

Kevin Gross

>Some words of advice:

>tells you DO NOT DRIVE FASTER THAN YOU ARE COMFORTABLE.  Most good

Very wise words, as well.

Most "accidents" at driver education events involving student drivers (at
least, at Rennsport's events), when investigated, come down to this - a
student being pushed by an instructor to do things that the student is
uncomfortable doing.

If you're a student at a PCA driver's education event, and you're not
comfortable with your instructor, SAY SO! If necessary, ask for a different
instructor! It is *your* car, and *your* life. No doubt your instructor is a
great driver, but that doesn't mean he or she is a great teacher, or has a
fifth sense of when you're not comfortable.

I know there's a certain amount of ego (well, a lot, actually :) in these
kinds of situations, but, to be blunt, bent sheet-metal sucks.

my $0.02CND (0.015 US)
Craig.

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 00:01:04 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Blanchard Grinding/Rotors

To those that inquired about Blanchard grinding, including a p-philer by the
name of Jonathan Blanchard (whose grandfather probably invented the process)
I offer the following explanation which I hope is reasonably accurate;
Blanchard grinding is the process where a piece such as a rotor or a flywheel
is placed on a table that rotates. While the rotor is spinning a stone is
held against the rotor. The stone is also turning but on an axis that is
different than the rotor and in the opposite direction. The result is a
smooth finish that looks like cross hatching. The finish that is imparted is
a function of the coarseness of the stone.
The advantage is that you are not cutting the rotor as you do in turning,
where the rotor ends up with undesirable micro grooves. Turning the rotor is
actually grooving it and grinding is a whole different deal where abrasion is
taking place.
 Any metallurgists please comment as I don't know the exact consequences of
either method.
Once one side of the rotor is done it is perfectly flat so when it is flipped
over to do the other side it will be parallel to the first side. 
If you look at a new rotor or flywheel you will notice the distinctive cross
hatch pattern that signifies that the Blanchard grinding method was used.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
9:04 pm



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 21:19:43 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Letter from Monty Smith re:Parade Club Race

Hi Drew -

Yes, the National office has for years resisted any wheel to wheel 
driving in P-club.  It was not until the last two years that any for of 
it has appeared associated and supported by the National office.  For 
years we have had to go else where to do anything like this.  Before the 
best we could do was time trialing, but timing was always limited to 
individual cars while practice sessions had abour 25 cars spaced out 
around the track with limited passing.  Passing was limited because cars 
were grouped by times and by the areas of the track (i.e. no passing in 
the corners or no passing between turns X and y, etc.).

Parade has always been rather limited because of the nature of it.  Many
people bring their pride and joy on vacation and the idea is to have fun. 
In the past, when racr tracks have been used for the driving event, we
have totaled a few cars and that puts a damper on the activities.  I can
remember a 911 hitting the final end of the guard rail at PIR in 1980 and
doing endovers down the main straight.  We also lost at least two cars
coming out of turn 14? (final right hander heading up hill to start/finish
at Raod America in 1984) at the Chicago Parade.  It was not pretty and
very disheartening for the Parade entrants.  There was also a bad (if not
totaled) car accident at Riverside during the "autocross" at the Costa Mesa 
Parade in 1985.  Since then no more racetracks.  And I can understand.

But I though this was going to be only for "licensed" personnel and not 
all Parade entrants.  I thought it was going to a seperate event and not 
even associated with Parade.  Guess not!

The thing I don't understand is why if we are not using racetracks 
anymore, do the drivers of modified cars need to wear driving suits etc. 
to compete.  I can see it for racetracks but not for an autocross.  In 
SCCA or other PCA autocrosses we can wear shorts and no shirt if we like.  
Doesn't make sense.

Well maybe we'll see you in Reno if our SCCA schedule permits.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 22:30:46 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Checking 944 thermostats


All of the respondents to Mike Kehr's post made the reasonable and
appropriate suggestion of checking the thermostat for proper opening.
These are quite easy to test, *assuming* you can get the silly thing
out of the pump while the pump is still bolted to the engine!  The
challenge, of course, results from the minimal clearance in front of
the pump.  I own two pairs of (reversible) snap ring pliers.  The
first pair is big and hefty, with the proper sized tips to engage the
big mutha snap ring that holds the thermostat in the pump mouth.  This
pair is way too big to get anywhere near the target.  My other pair is
small enough to get at the ring (even had to bend that pair up a bit
though), but the tips are too small to squeeze and hold the ring
firmly enough to coax it out of its groove.  I spent a couple of hours
one afternoon trying to pull my thermostat for testing, only to give
up in complete frustration.  What appears to be needed are small,
compact pliers that can accommodate the larger tips.  I have not been
able to find such a thing, even in the pro tool catalogs like Snap-On
and Mac.  Has anyone found a slick tool/trick to make pulling the
thermostat from an installed pump easier/possible?

 -Milo
'86 951

Porschephiles #1079                         Wed Jan 18 12:11:16 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 04:31:51 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: 931 tranny plug & intercooler

Greetings Porschephiles!

With all the talk recently about transmission fluid, I decided to change
mine: 
I discovered a nice tool to remove these  plugs on the 1980 924 Turbo's with
the 016-Z style Porsche box.  The problem is that the clearance between the
transmission carrier and the filler plug is so tight that a conventional tool
will not fit.  I found a tool at my local Euro parts store which is intended
to be used with a standard 3/8" socket wrench.  The trick is to use a 17mm
(open end or ring) wrench arround the bit that protrudes from the
transmission when the tool is inserted.  This allows enough room for the
insertion of the removal tool.  The tool cost $5 and is made by Empi (part #
00-5773-0).
By the way, the plug on my particular car was INCREDIBLY tight (100 ft/lbs
plus probably) so I had to fashion an extension for the 17mm wrench to
increase the leverage.  The fluid was filthy - black/brown with quite a few
metal shavings on the magnetic drain plug - a change was definitely in order!
 I am hoping that a change to synthetic will solve the problem of the car
sometimes refusing to go into 1st gear.

My 931 is up on axle stands at the moment while I research ways to install a
Renault Fuego intercooler - the intercooler I finally decided on.  It is a
nice looking aluminium unit - and includes a fan installed on the back.  This
will be advantegeous at lower speeds when the air flow through the
intercooler is low.  I am planning to use a pressure switch to activate the
fan at 3 Psi or so (have not decided for sure yet).  I have made a model of
the intercooler dimensions to make sure it will fit (before I buy) ... in the
area where the oil cooler, water bottle & headlight bracket now resides.  The
oil cooler will be shifted to the drivers side (lengthening the pipes) and
the metal bracket on the back of the passenger side headlight will need to be
cut off (some way to stop the light shake as a result of this still to be
engineered).  Slight 'clearancing' of some sheet metal will be required -
nothing too dramatic though.  Once the intercooler in installed, my local
turbo shop will fabricate the pipes needed to go from the turbo to the
intercooler and from the intercooler to the throttle body.  The wrecking yard
that has the intercooler wants $200 for it ... seems a bit much as this
months European Car mag (where I saw the Fuegi IC) showed a whole engine
complete with all the bits for $300! (about to be installed in a Lotus
Europa).

Any ideas/comments/help appreciated - 
regards - 
MIKE
1977 924 (still driving daily)
1980 931 (about to be quite a bit 'cooler')

------------------------------

Date: 18 Jan 95 12:01:00 +0000
From: swellen@intgp1.att.com
Subject: 15" and 16" wheels

- ------------------------------------------------------------
Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 15:12:18 -0800 (PST)
From: Tom Feller <tomf@mxim.com>
Subject: 15" vs 16" wheels 

I think that even 1.19 % difference is too much. Remember that the 15" 
wheels have 215/60 that gives a side wall height of about 129 mm. While 
the 16" wheel have 225/50 and a sidewall height of about 112.5 mm. With 
the 16" wheels 25.4 mm taller than the 15" and the 16" tires have a 16.5 
mm shorter sidewall the total differences in height between the 15" 
wheels and tires and the 16" wheel and tire is less than 10 mm.

Would this really change the speedo reading by 1.19% ?

 - Tom Feller

- ------------------------------
I think you need to divide the extra inch on the wheel by two, don't
forget you have a tyre wall above and below.
So add 12.7 mm to 112.5 and get 125.2

Either way either 205/55 or 225/50 is correct for 16" wheels.
The tread depth has more effect on gearing so unless our
friend who started this chat, and who's name I've lost (sorry),
wants to re-calibrate as the tyres wear out I'd say leave
as the original values.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 08:43:32 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Driver's Ed. (was- Re: Wheel size conversion)

>> > Before I go to drivers Ed I want to mark the maximum downshift points on
>> > my speedometer and the optimum upshift points on my tach.  I have bought
>> > some lovely 1/16" red and blue tape and some 1/8" white vinyl numbers for
>> > this.
>>
>> Watch the track - shift by ear & seat of pants. There's too much going
>> on out there to be looking at the tach/speedo all the time.
>
>If you haven't been using a marked up speedo on the street it is only
>going to add confusion on the track.  Get comfortable with this on the
>street before using it on the track.  The tach is easy to look at because
>it is in the center.  I always glance at it when I hear the engine speed
>up so I shift at the correct time.  The speedo is off to the side and the
>only time I ever have time to look at it is on the straight.
>
>It appears what you are trying to do is determine how to keep your engine
>in its power range.  This is good.  If your drivers ed is on a racetrack
>then ask people what gear each corner is in.  It is easy to equate a
>corner to a gear.  Downshifting normally only occurs when you are also
>braking.  Just remember to downshift when you are almost finished with
>braking.  This allows the engine rpms to be as low as they will get.
>Don't downshift when you start braking because the rpms haven't dropped
>yet.

I don't remember the original poster's level of experience, but I got
the impression that he is about to attend his first driver's school.
If that is the case, my recommendation is to skip all of the "optimum
shift point" effort, and save it for later. In my experience as an
instructor, most students are massively overloaded with new information
at their first school. I believe that the hardest part they have to
learn is the line for the track, and how to drive it smoothly and
consistently at a set of gradually increasing speeds. Optimizing
shift points simply drains off some mental energy which could be
better used elsewhere. Besides, gear choices coming out of corners,
etc. will all change drastically as the student's speeds increase
through the corners. I tell new students to put the car in 3rd and
leave it there. Upshift to 4th on the longest straight, if you
can't stand backing off at 80 or 90 MPH, or if you are in a 914,
where 3rd gear doesn't go very fast. The idea is to get issues of
gear selection out of your mind while you are learning the hard
stuff, which is cornering.

For intermediate students who can drive the line smoothly and
consistently at a respectable pace, duplicate the gear choices
for each corner used by the fastest driver you can find with the
same car as yours (including gear ratios and wheel diameter),
as suggested by another responder, and then "grow into" those gear
choices as your cornering speeds continue to increase. 
I support the idea of not becoming too
instrument dependent, with specialized marks all over the place.
You should be looking at the track, not flying IFR. Perhaps look
at the tach to upshift at the redline, but most everything else
can be done by feel. As someone suggested, if you do your downshift
late in the braking period, there won't be a problem with revs
(assuming you really needed to downshift for that corner).

By the way, I employ the same philosophy on braking. For the
beginner, brake early and often. Be done with braking in time
to get the corner right. When you have cornering mastered at some
reasonable level, then start to refine braking technique. Unless
you already toe/heel naturally, don't try to learn it the first
day, on top of everything else. At the end of your first day you will
probably have some perspective on why heel/toe is desirable. You
then have all of your street driving time to practice it before
your next event (when your foot slipping off the brake won't be
as big a disaster, hopefully).

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 9:01:52 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Marking your tach & speedo for the track

Hi Scott,

  >Martin,
  >I'll be honest, my first reaction was "what the ___?" and then I remembered
  >the first time I went to a time trial/drivers ed. and how many little things
  >I worried about and how many big things I didn't know enough TO worry about
  > -- then your idea made me smile.

okay, okay

  >the engine at peak horsepower and torque or over-reving.  I would pop the
  >tach out and rotate it so the redline is at the top -- it won't be long

When I bought the car I rotated the tach to that peak torque is at the top
and rotated the speedo so that speed in 3rd at peak torque is at the top.
I also rotated the temp/oil press so that at a good temp and oil press
(at high rpm) they are straight up and down respectivly.  My goal was that
under high power (ie on straight or just stabilized out of a turn, which
is really the only time I'll have time to look), one glance should show all
needles ponting in the same direction - if not somethings wrong.

would you suggest changing this setup ?

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 09:35:13 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 944 Thermostat removal, oil leaks, high temps- Long

P-philers, Milo writes:
===============
compact pliers that can accommodate the larger tips.  I have not been
able to find such a thing, even in the pro tool catalogs like Snap-On
and Mac.  Has anyone found a slick tool/trick to make pulling the
thermostat from an installed pump easier/possible?
==============

Here's what I did just a few weeks ago on my 944. I also have a set of C ring
pliers, but as Milo points out, they are worthless while the WP is in the car.

Here's what I did: got a nail punch that was small enough to fit in the C-ring
hole. I also got a small (~2.5"), flat blade screw driver. I then hooked up the
C-ring hole with the nail punch and compressed it enough (towards the center...)until I was able to fit the SD between the C-ring and the WP body. You then 
kind of work the SD around the circumference and get it out.

The trick is to have tools short enough to get leverage as you do this. I 
usually get the front wheels on ramps any time I get to work on the bottom
of the engine to get enough clearence. About 8". 

Boy, did I do that a lot in the past few weeks. Had a pesty 
oil leak on the oil cooler, that dripped right on the balance shafts, PS pump
and masked itself as a lower bal shaft seal leaking due to the way the oil
flowed on the PS supporting bracket.

Had to take the head apart twice :) First time for bent valves
Second time went a lot faster. Found out the oil cooler does not come
out with the exhaust headers in place :(. 

Should have changed the oil cooler seals the first time, but then
again the internal seals were not leaking. Got an upgraded gasket from Zims.
It is one piece of metal with the 3 oil cooler seals embedded into it. Much
better design than 3 individual ones.

I too experienced EXTREME water temps after putting the engine back together.
This follows the recent thread on 944 with high temps. The gauge was pegged
for the longest time (really scary). There was no water flow until the
thermostat opened. Oil got really thin, pressure was like 0.5 bar. It took
a long time for the sucker to open up. Head was hot, thermostat was not 
open and as a result nothing was going though the radiator. Therefore, the
fans would not go on since fan switch was cold!

Once thermostat opened, gauge showed cooling, fans went on. I made sure that
the system was bled by openning the screw a few times and making sure that I
was getting antifreeze and not steam. 

I guess, I would do it again (hopefully not for a long time), I would carefully
fill up the engine block with antifreeze so the system will bleed much faster.

These were my experiences. I hope they help someone out there. Feel free to
ask questions if you need more info...

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa 
'85 Guards Red 944 	(With no more OIL LEAKS!)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo
'88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 10:00:57 EST
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Blanchard Grinding/Rotors

The problem with any grinding of rotors, is the heat treatment history. If
the rotor is being ground or turned cause its warped, it will continue to
warp the next time it gets hot, regardless of how pretty it was after the
grinding/turning. When it comes to brakes, it ain't worth the risk. Of
course I never went as fast as when my rotors were warped and coudn't use
my brakes much...


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 10:04:41 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)

Tom writes:
> I think that even 1.19 % difference is too much. Remember that the 15" 
> wheels have 215/60 that gives a side wall height of about 129 mm. While 
> the 16" wheel have 225/50 and a sidewall height of about 112.5 mm. With 
> the 16" wheels 25.4 mm taller than the 15" and the 16" tires have a 16.5 
> mm shorter sidewall the total differences in height between the 15" 
> wheels and tires and the 16" wheel and tire is less than 10 mm.
> Would this really change the speedo reading by 1.19% ?

Yes, because the sidewall height gets added to the diameter twice...
once below the wheel and once above it.

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 09:53:12 PST
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: sparkplugs, antifreeze, and brake fluid!

I getting ready to start my winter maintenance on my '84 928.  I'll start with changing the spark plugs (61000 mi now), and I'll flush the cooling and brake 
systems.  A few questions:

Plugs:  I was reading the archive about plugs - I didn't really see a general consensous on what the best plugs was.  Scott Jensen prefers the NGK Palladium. 
 Kevin Gross's opinion is that among quality plugs, they're just a commodity.  Bosch Copper may be considered better than platinum because of the larger 
electrode (lass potential to foul, misfire).  Any other thoughts?  If I go NGK, where can I find them (Cincinnati/Columbus/Cleveland Ohio)?

Antifreeze:  I thought I would look for the phosphate-free Prestone, distilled water, and use a bottle of Prestone's super flush.  Will the flush help?  Are there 
any adverse side effects?  Any comments?  A post on rec.autos.tech suggested a "low silicate" formulation for an aluminum engine, but this is new to me, 
anyone heard of this?

Brake Fluid:  After reading FAQ's and archives I think I should stay with DOT-3.  Is DOT-5 better?  Why? Better feel?  Lasts longer?  With DOT-5, I've 
never flushed a brake system before and would be afraid that I didn't completely remove all moisture.  Since DOT-5 doesn't absorb water, it may collect and 
rust brake system components.  Also, I've read that DOT-5 has a lower boiling point than DOT-3?  Is there any particular brand of brake fluid that works 
really well (DOT-3 or DOT-5)?

My car is a summertime daily driver.  My primary goal is to maintain the car in top condition as cheaply as possible, without sacrificing performance.  I.E.  I 
don't want to use DOT-5 if DOT-3 is "pretty close" and I'd have to flush DOT-5 every year...   or, plugs that won't last...

While I'm posting, let me say that I think this list is great.  Thanks to Stan for its continued operation!

 -Matt Carpenter
 mwc@lubrizol.com
'84 928S

Date: 18 Jan 95 11:20:15 EST
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: 86 951 Running hot

I am fowarding this to the list, for whomever is interested. This is a reply 
about the hot running 86'951. 

From: Ralph Forey


Mike,


        The cooling system on these things is a continual source of worry and 
frustration for me too (85/1 944).  When I had my oil cooler gasket/seals 
replaced, the mechanic didn't realize that he had forgotten to put coolant 
back  in until after I had driven and noticed the symptoms of this problem (as
you probably realize, these cars don't air cool very well at all).  Then, he 
never fully got the air bubble out of the head, and I spent ~ 1 hour bleeding 
and filling the system until I was comfortable that I had gotten most of the 
air out.  Now, it still runs slightly hotter than it used to (just over the 
"center" line when cruising on the highway), but I am attributing it to the 
oil that was put in (Kendall 20W50 instead of the Valvoline 10W40 that I'm 
used to putting in).  I have also replaced the coolant temperature fan switch 
several times (once after the water pump died) and still find that it is 
temperamental; most of the time it turns on when the temp hits the last yellow
line, sometimes it waits longer, sometimes less.  It also seems to change when
there is a  change made somewhere in the system; for example water pump 
replaced or radiator flush and fill.  The other thing that makes this even 
worse is realizing that the switch in the radiator and the temperature gauge 
are measuring different things; 
one coolant temperature in the radiator, the other coolant temperature in the 
head.  Then, throw in a faulty thermostat and other anomalies (one fan not 
working) and then we're in for some real fun.


It is amazing with all this confusing information we are presented that we 
don't hear about head gaskets blowing more often.   

Also, sometimes I'd just like to take it back to the mechanic and tell him 
"make it run like it used to (or better) using the these new parts that you've
put on" but in light of the above behaviors this is probably unrealistic.

Ralph FOREY_RALPH_E_III@LILLY.COM

PS.  If you think that this may be important to anyone else, forward it to the
list.  Everything I send there never gets there ...

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 11:01:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Checking 944 thermostats


Hi Milo,

I haven't really had your problem with the t-stat snap ring.  For me, it 
was,
one time, an issue of its orientation within the housing which made it
difficult to remove while the pump was in the car.

Snap On does make a ton of snap ring pliers, and they sell a boxed set
of all the ones you could ever want.  There are probably only a few
you really need.  Personally, I own a mid-sized one for snap rings and
one with the angular points you need to remove 944-series CV snap
rings (acute angle ends rather than holes, if that makes any sense).

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 09:28:03 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Splitfires


Hi all,

I have done some testing of the Splitfire plugs. They do help in
low and midrange. I suspect that this is due to more electrode area 
being available than in a standard electrode configuration. 

Frankly, I can't see the added expense of Splitfires over the more 
conventional types. The quality control sucks, especially on the 
sealing gaskets supplied. The things fall off. Scott Jessen and 
others have pointed this out. I used Bosch sealing gaskets (the 
aluminum thing that looks like a washer but isn't) and had no 
problem with sealing. The `performance' instructions Splitfire 
offers are bunk. 

The 944S2 (I got it right this time) and 968 can use the Bosch DTC
plugs. These have three contacts rather than the usual one aimed at 
the electrode. These are a good plug as they do not shroud the tip and
require no indexing to achieve optimal flame propagation. You 
motorcycle types might rmember the the so-called rim-fire plugs in 
Yamaha 2-cycle engines. These work in a similar fashion.

Otherwise, index the plugs for each cylinder and you will have a better
result than using Splitfires. And save $3-$4 per plug.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 12:08:39 EST
From: tynor@atlanta.twr.com (Steve Tynor)
Subject: re: upshifts (was Driver's Ed. (was- Re: Wheel size conversion))

Frank wrote:

| You should be looking at the track, not flying IFR. Perhaps look
| at the tach to upshift at the redline, but most everything else
| can be done by feel. As someone suggested, if you do your downshift

I agree with everything said here (i.e. don't worry so much about
instruments - the "line" and "smoothness" are the top priorities for the
first couple of schools).

However, this comment about upshifting at redline caught my attention.
I recall a session I had with Joe Cogbill who advised me that the
optimum upshift point is at about 4000-4500 RPM on the 951 and that,
unless you weren't going to upshift at all (e.g. in a short shoot where
you're about to downshift anyway), "you're just converting gas to noise"
by delaying an upshift past that point.

Steve

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 13:09:44 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: overheating 944 continued

This is a continuation of my previous message...

Ralph Forey writes:
===================
one coolant temperature in the radiator, the other coolant temperature in the 
head.  Then, throw in a faulty thermostat and other anomalies (one fan not 
working) and then we're in for some real fun.
===================

Ralph, on my 85.1 only the driver's side radiator is controlled by the
radiator switch. Both fans turn on only when I turn the A/C on. On my car,
the fan goes on halfway between the last line on the gauge and the hot field.
It stays on until about it reaches half way past the first line after the cold
region. I have the original switch, I don't recall its temp range, but I think
its upper limit was like 92C. Can some one confirm this?

You may want to remember that using the A/C forces both fans on. Might save you
some hot day when the switch dies. Also, in case of overheating, I would crank
up the heater, and run the heater fan at max. You will have toasty toes, but
the heater core will act as an extra radiator to extract heat from the 
engine and help to cool things down. 

That leads me to my next tip. Make sure that when you bleed the system you have the temp control on the heater at max. You want to circulate the water all
over the system.

Also, I had an intermittent right fan. As it turns out, it looks like one
of the blades was partially broken. As a result it was really imbalanced, making
lots of vibration while it ran. I took it appart an chopped off a portion of theother 2 blades. This balanced the fan. Looking around, I noticed that the 
fan connector had a cover. I removed the cover to find an unsoldered joint.
Most likely due to its vibration. After re-soldering and rebalancing the
fan runs like a champ and is a lot quieter. I don't think that the missing
blade surface will affect cooling that much.

Hope this helps someone out there!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa 
'85 Guards Red 944 (with no oil leaks and a balanced and functioniong fan!
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo
'88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 10:10:54 -0800
From: Carson Chen <cachen@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: 95' 911 2wd vs 4wd (Timo Karttaavi)


Contents:


  Re: 95' 911 2wd vs 4wd (Timo Karttaavi)

_____________
Date: Wed, 4 Jan 95 11:55:54 EET
From: Timo Karttaavi <Timo.Karttaavi@tel.vtt.fi>
Subject: Re: 95' 911 2wd vs 4wd
