magazine "Car". It features a comparison of the current 911s (C2,
C2 Tiptronic and C4). I think the author's choice was the C4 by
a very small margin.

Timo
- ------------------------------

Timo,

This may be late in responding to your email but here's some
perspective from my C4 buying experience.


I was looking for an 1988-1993 Carrera 4 a while ago (this was before
the 993 C4 was available)  and got very helpful advise from really
nice folks on this mailing list. I've appended a summary of the best
excerpts hoping to return the favor and benefit others. By the way, I
hope you original authors don't mind my leaving your names on. See
Below. 

Also...
As a recent 1990 C4 Targa owner, here is a short synapses of my own
buying criterion and experiences. Please keep in mind these are
*personal* opinions and not meant to cause a C2 vs C4, 911 vs 944,
etc. etc. flame war. I respect and appreciate all that the marque
stands for.  

So, here goes...

REASON FOR BUYING: 
  1. Have been driving BMWs (530i, 535i) for 12 years and wanted
     something on the wild side (used to build and drag motorcycles).
  2. Always wanted something very quick and yet predictable.
  3. Drove many 911s (friends) in the past but personnally didn't like
     the oversteer characteristics (exactly like a motorcycle when you
     hit an oil slick, water, etc. while in a turn. Controlable but
     with surprises and excitment). So, never bothered to buy.
  4. I don't drive cars to their limits of adhesion but do like
     spirited jaunts on mountain roads.
  5. Like to go through the gears a and feel the raw acceleration.
  6. Enter C4. Curious.

RESEARCH:
  1. Obtained all the articles from Car&Driver, R&T, Excellence
     magazines. All the write-ups were very favorable.
  2. Obtained excellent owner input, see below, and examined all the
     records of the C4 owners I visited to make sure they had the
     factor upgrades or showed no problems.

DECISION TIME:
  1. Bought a white 1990 Carrera 4, Targa in immaculate condition.
     When I took it into the dealer for the first time the mechanic
     said "congratulations on your new car." I told him it was used.
     He took a long second look.

     COMMENT to Porsche North America (if you are listening):
         You've produced a product that has expanded your market to a
         new set of buyers. Thanks. 

EXPERIENCE:
  1. Have had nothing but fun over the last several months. The C4 is
     totally predictable and when I switch back and forth from driving
     the C4 and BMW 535i I'm not surprised by different handling
     charteristics, meaning they are both neutral. Of course, the C4
     is much more potent in raw power and doesn't lean in the turns.
  2. The acceleration is like driving a drag bike. Point it, punch it
     and hang on. 1st and 2nd gear are always a blurr. In the
     beginning months I used to hit the over rev cutout all the time
     because I was just hanging on for dear life. Now I only reach the
     rev cutout/limiter once in a while. Thank goodness for this
     engine saving feature. 

ROAD WARRIOR EXPERIENCE:
  1. I'm pretty saftey concious so don't engage in races etc.
     However, folks in other cars seem to alway want to provoke. So.
     On different occasions had a Saab, BMW 540i & Volvo (the fast
     one), tailgating me through the mountain roads and with ease I
     wisked away. They tried hard but... 

  2. Though the magazine articles talk about burning the clutch to get
     good 0-60mph times, I never felt it was a good way to abuse the
     car. However, during these rainy days, I decided to drop the
     clutch one day and experienced a loud roar from the tires and then
     sling-shotted down to the next stoplight. What a delightful
     experience, exceptional wet condition control compared to my
     535i. ...and by the way, the Corvette in my rearview mirror was
     still spinning his rear wheels.

Happy Driving!
Carson

>From liang@hpindbu.cup.hp.com Fri Sep 16 09:53:49 1994
From: Alf Liang <liang@hpindbu.cup.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Carrera 4
To: cachen@cisco.com (Carson Chen)
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 94 13:15:58 PDT
In-Reply-To: <199406291804.LAA20092@stout.cisco.com>; from "Carson Chen" at Jun 29, 94 11:04 am
Mailer: Elm [revision: 66.25]

Hi Carson,

Mine is a '90 C4.  So far it has been trouble-free and GREAT FUN to drive.  I 
am not an aggresive driver and don't push the car all that hard.  I have come to
really appreciate how responsive it is and how much easier it is to drive. 
Though I have read about some feeling the C4 was less "tossable" than a C2.

There has been just one factory recall for me.  It has to do with a resistor in
the heater circuit not having adequate wattage rating.  Using heater during 
prolonged autobahn driving could lead to fire.  Replacing it was not a big deal.

There was one other (much more serious) problem that was discussed in the 
porschephile group.   It has to do with oil leak affecting 1989, 1990 & 1991 
C2/4.  There was no recall notice but dealers will perform necessary work if
there is indeed a problem with your car.  This info was from another netter,
Quincy Dong (QLD1@pge.com), perhaps he can give you more insight (I don't 
want to use his exact article without his consent).  

Hope this is of some help, and you will be a happy C4 owner. 

Alf
______________
Subject: re:Carerra 4
X-Incognito-Sn: 236
X-Incognito-Format: VERSION=1.52a ENCRYPTED=NO

Carson,

I have a 1990 Carrera 4 and I love it!  Especially after having taken the 
Autocross class at Candlestick.

There are some concerns you should know about:
	-  The radio for the 89 & 90 is connected to the alarm system.
	   If you take the radio out and it is not properly grounded, the car
	   alarm will "go off" without the usual siren going off, therefore
	   your battery will drain down without you knowing the cause.

	-  There was a recall of the cruise control that the factory fixed.

	-  I think there was another recall on the fuel system--I don't 
	   remember exactly what, but the factory fixed that.

	-  There is something about the 89-91 having some cylinder heads
	   leaking oil.  I haven't been able to get the factory to change the 
	   heads yet, but I'm working on it.  The engine has to have some 
	   oil leakage before the factory do anything about it.  The factory
	   won't fix it unless there is a problem.
	   It's for engine numbers 62 M 06836, M64.01 for manual transmission
	   and 62 M 52757,M64.02 for Tiptronic transmissions.

	   This involves new set of pistons and cylinders and machining the
	   heads to work with the new "head gaskets".

I can't remember what other recalls there was, since the car is fairly 
new--the owners probably had all the recalls done automatically since it 
didn't involve additional $.

The C4 is heavier than a C2 and therefore to a "race driver" the C2 is a 
faster car to race in.  It's like the old "ABS" syndrome, the race drivers can 
brake better w/o ABS than race a car that has ABS.

With the C4, you'll have an extremely hard time throwing the tail out.  It's 
kind of like the best of FWD and RWD all rolled up together.

I can't compare to a regular C2 since the C4 is my first Porsche.  From all 
the articles I read, the C2 was a better car to drive fast!  But after the 
auto-x school, I think the C4 was a better car "all around".  It's kind of the 
lazy-man's way to drive and not have to work hard and still have the fun of 
driving a sport car.

Let me know if you have anymore questions.

Quincy Dong
QLD1@pge.com
(415) 973-6919

Carson,

The auto-x school was put on by the Loma Prierta (sic) region of the Porsche 
Club, or inother words the Zone-7 auto-x.  There is one going on this August 
because they has such huge turnout for the one in April.  I highly reconmend 
it because of the amount of track time for your car.  You really learn the 
limits of your car in a controlled enviroment.

Hank Watts coordinate the school.  He's the guy who wrote SOLO DRIVING and you 
get a copy of his book before the school to read.  They offer this class every 
year and you will learn about the dates from various "Porsche" magazines.  I 
learned about the school through the Porschephilies.

>From hegarty@iis.ee.ethz.ch Fri Sep 16 09:55:51 1994
To: Carson Chen <cachen@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: Carrera 4 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 29 Jun 1994 11:03:20 PDT."
             <199406291803.LAA20029@stout.cisco.com> 
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 1994 09:53:57 +0200
From: Christopher Hegarty <hegarty@iis.ee.ethz.ch>

Hi Carson,

I just called my Porsche dealer/mechanic and asked him what he
thought, and I've included his comments in the text below.

My dealer told me that the first two model years (89 and 90 I believe)
had problems with the clutch - nothing serious, just requiring early
replacement of the clutch plate.  Porsche subsequently beefed up the
material in the clutch and since then everything is ok.  If you buy a
car from one of the first two model years and it still has the
original clutch, then it may require replacement soon.  However, once
you do replace it, you get the new clutch and everything is ok.

BTW, the clutch on the C4 does tend to go faster than that of the C2
for one very simple reason: if you drop the clutch on a C2, you can
spin the rear wheels.  On the C4, you can't spin all four wheels (too
little torque), so the clutch burns instead.  I did this a couple of
times at the beginning, much to my embarassment.  But once you get the
behaviour worked out and know how to treat it, it's no problem.

There were also a couple of recalls on the first model years (to do
with the Motronic and/or cruise control, according to the dealer).
Mine hasn't been recalled (yet).

Apart from that, I haven't heard anything negative.  My car is '92,
and I've never had anything go wrong with it, but then I've had the
dealer service it in accordance with the Porsche requirements.  This
is expensive in itself, unfortunately.

One other thing: the standard C4 suspension setup from Porsche has
pretty nasty understeer.  If you don't plan to drive on the track it's
probably fine.  I didn't enjoy it because I've had a couple of 911's
and I missed the old behaviour.  My dealer had the suspension setup
changed so that the car handled almost neutrally, just a touch of
oversteer.  You might want to think about this, but this can be done
at anytime.

You probably already know this, but with Porsches it always makes
sense to buy the latest model year you can afford.  Reason: the
factory has a policy of making running improvements, so each model
year there are changes.

Also, there's a book about the C4 which is worth reading.  If you're
interested I can get the details from home and send it to you.  It
explains in some detail how the 4WD system works etc.

Great decision to get a C4!  It's the only 911 I've ever had where I
actually felt comfortable beating it around a bit on a wet road.  And
the 4WD is great when it snows.  It's the only true "all weather"
sports car I've ever owned.

Good luck in your search.  Please let me know if you have any other
questions.

Cheers

Chris
_________
>From marc@farallon.com Fri Sep 16 09:56:45 1994
Date: 5 Jul 1994 14:16:34 -0700
From: "Marc Epard" <marc@farallon.com>
Subject: RE: Carrera 4
To: "Carson Chen" <cachen@cisco.com>

Hi Carson,

Sorry I didn't get back to you sooner, but I've been out of town.  I'm not an
expert on which years are better or worse, but I'm happy to share my
experience.  I have a 1991 Carrera 4 Targa, which I enjoy thoroughly.  It is my
daily driver in all seasons.  The targa is great in the warm months and the
all-wheel-drive makes the winter no problem at all (it snows here, sometimes a
lot).  I also do Porsche club drivers ed events at a nearby track, which I
highly recommend.

I've only had one recall and it was for a resistor on a blower in the engine
compartment which could overheat and cause a fire.  The dealer replaced it in a
few minutes.  I did have some clutch-related problems and I was worried that
Porsche would blame the track driving.  Porsche replaced the clutch and a few
other components at their expense and with out my even asking.  I think the C4
clutch and flywheel has had several refinements which makes me believe that it
had problems at first.  Mine works fine now, but with one strange thing:  when
it is cold (<0C), it smells funny if it is slipped even slightly.

I also had a problem with the fuel-level sending unit that ended up being
frustrating to get fixed.  Now and then it would just quit.  Porsche replaced
it, but the new one didn't always indicate correctly, so they replaced it, too.
 Then fuel started leaking around the seal where it enters the gas tank.  It
took several tries to get that fixed.  When my mechanic called Porsche, they
said they have had this happen now and then and that they had a specific
procedure to get it sealed.  (Install a new seal, torque it down, drive it for
15 minutes, torque it down again).  It worked that time.

Oh, I also had most of the snaps in the front trunk carpet pull out of the
fabric.  The dealer fixed them at no charge.

Other than that, I've had routine maintenance plus a some extra expenses from
doing track events.  The regular service is a little pricy -- your mechanic can
tell you what the typical charge is for a particular service (15K, 30K, etc.). 
I flush the brake fluid for each track event and have used more brake pads and
tires than normal due to the track driving, but this is definately worth it.  I
learned to do the brake work myself and that cut down the cost consderably.  I
also don't use Porsche pads because they are too expensive and there are better
ones around (I'm using Repco Metalmasters right now, but I think I'll try Cool
Carbon next time).

There is one other thing I should tell you.  If I were buying again, I might
not get a C4;  I'd consider a 2-wheel drive coupe instead, but only because I
like the track events.  The C4 doesn't handle as well as a C2 (on dry pavement)
and the targa is heavier and has more flex in the body.  On the other hand, I'd
really miss being able to take the top off and would feel like I needed a
different vehicle in the winter.  Hmmmm.  Maybe I just need another Porsche....
;-)

Hope this helps.  Have fun!

 -Marc
_______________________________________________________________________________


Hi Carson,
>
>Ah yes, I'd be very interested in knowing the title of the C4 book you
>mention, especially how the AWD works.
>
The book is called "Carrera 4: Porsche Allrad von 1900 - 1990 /
Porsche 4 wheel drive from 1900 - 1990."  Publisher is Suedwest
Verlag, Munich.  It's in both German and English (alternating pages in
each language).  You can certainly order it from Toad Hall Motorbooks.
It's got quite a bit of information about how the C4 differentials are
controlled etc.  The Porsche owner's manual tells you practically
nothing.
>
>It's interesting, I've owned several BMW 5 series for the last 12 year
>and now I want something more radical. Sounds like the C4 fills the
>ticket well. I spend every other week in Tahoe and during the winter,
>every weekend. So, from your description, the AWD should handle well
>during the winter.
>
It does.  I live in Switzerland and used the C4 to go skiing quite a
bit last year.  You still need winter tyres, and it's important not to
forget that although the C4 will get you moving much better than any
other 911 on an icy road, it won't stop you any faster :-).  I did
have to be careful not to get lulled into a false sense of security.

Please let me know how it goes with the search for your car.  The new
model of the C4 based on the 993 is coming out in a month or so, that
might result in some good later models becoming available as people
buy the new one.

Cheers

Chris
_________

> From: Carson Chen <cachen>
> 
> More info Carl.  By the way, in your experience with a Targa similar
> to Marc's? Meaning, there's alot of flex in the body.

IMO

Putting things into percpective, the Targa has minimal body flex
compared to the majority of open topped cars on the market today.
I doubt you would even notice it much but it depends on what you are
used to.  Sure, angle the car up a steep driveway and you will hear the
creek as the targa rollbar fights to counter the torsional flex, but then
even my coupe does that.  Ask Ehab about his Targa compared to his
Supra, he was very concerned about this before he bought his.

Carl

Porschephiles #1080                         Wed Jan 18 16:15:39 CST 1995
Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 11:22:58 -0800
From: richardson@newton.apple.com (Peter Richardson)
Subject: Some 928 buying questions from a newbie

Hi all,
I'm a new porschephile.  After reading some of the recent archives and
lurking for a few days I have some questions I hope you can help me
answer...
I live in San Jose, CA, and intend to purchase a used 928S or S4 soon.

Here are my questions.

1) Where are all the used S4's?
I saw a few in Hemmings, but they're on the east coast.  Haven't seen very
many out here.  Someone told me that was because Porsche sold thousands of
928's each year in the US in the mid-80s, but sales dropped off because
prices went up so much and they sold only 200 928's in 1992. (Ouch!)   Or
am I just not looking in the right places?

2) If there are that few S4's, are the differences between the S and S4
worth the time it takes to find one?
(I don't want to start a "my xxx is better than your yyy because=8A" war
here.  Maybe it would help if I say I'm mostly interested in reliability
and handling).

3) I noticed that not many of the vocal porschephiles seem to own late
model 928's.  Is there something you know that I should know?

4) Why are there so many automatic 928's?
Someone told me that 80% of the US 928's were automatic, and almost all of
the ads I've seen are for automatics.   Is there a reason for that?  Did
buyers stay away from the 5-speed because they're unreliable?  IMHO, a
stick is so much more fun to drive.

5) Is it worth the extra money to find a 928 with very low mileage (< 30K)?
One dealer told me that 200K miles was easy for a Porsche kept in good
condition (so I should buy his 928 with 70K).  My '87 non-Porsche is giving
out after 80K.

6) I have my heart set on a shiny black 928.  If all I can find is a
non-black car, (and I'm not too concerned about lowering the resale value
by having it repainted...) what kind of paint job should I get that's
worthy of a Porsche?  I don't want a $99 Earl Scheib special, but I don't
want a $10,000 300 coat Imron laced with gold dust only-to-be-looked-at
showpiece either.

Some Bay Area specific questions:
7) Anybody had good/bad dealings with California Motorsports in Mountain
View?  They had a nice selection of used 911's, some 944's and one 928S.
The guy seemed to know what he was talking about, but it probably isn't too
hard to fool me (at this point).

8) Can anyone recommend a good pre-purchase inspection place in the Bay
Area, and (if different) a good mechanic I can establish a long-term
relationship with?
This is probably the most important question for me.  I wouldn't know a
timing belt from a bicycle chain (yet).

Thanks for any help or advice you can offer.

- -- Pete Richardson   (richardson@newton.apple.com)
'87 non-Porsche  (but not for long!)

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 14:05:40 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: re: upshifts (was Driver's Ed. (was- Re: Wheel size conversion))

>Frank wrote:
>
>| You should be looking at the track, not flying IFR. Perhaps look
>| at the tach to upshift at the redline, but most everything else
>| can be done by feel. As someone suggested, if you do your downshift
>
>I agree with everything said here (i.e. don't worry so much about
>instruments - the "line" and "smoothness" are the top priorities for the
>first couple of schools).
>
>However, this comment about upshifting at redline caught my attention.
>I recall a session I had with Joe Cogbill who advised me that the
>optimum upshift point is at about 4000-4500 RPM on the 951 and that,
>unless you weren't going to upshift at all (e.g. in a short shoot where
>you're about to downshift anyway), "you're just converting gas to noise"
>by delaying an upshift past that point.

I haven't done it for a 951, but a plot of rear axle torque versus
speed (i.e.engine torque curve, translated through each gear ratio, etc.)
for my 944S shows that the red line is the right spot for all shifts.
Another way to do the same analysis is to look at rear axle HP as a
function of car speed, which requires a bit less arithmetic (please
don't start the torque/HP discussion again unless you think about
it for a while first- rear axle HP versus car speed really does work).
It might be interesting for someone to do it for other common, stock
Porsches.

By the way, in keeping with my beginner's strategy of "put it in 3rd
and leave it there", all of this shouldn't be an issue for the
beginner. 

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 14:20:50 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: 914 Sheet Metal

Dave wrote:
> I've got two (out of three) very stubborn screws on that one
> piece of metal.  I've tried Liquid Wrench and some thumping,
> but to no avail.  Every time I try to get 'em out, I wind up
> chewing up the head a little bit more.  One screw is just
> holding sheet-metal to sheet-metal (with one of those welded-
> on nut things), but the other one goes into the case.
>         HELP!  Any suggestions?

Yes, I would suggest grinding the head off and drilling the shaft out.
Usually after grinding the head off of such stuck screws, I can get the
screw shaft to unscrew, but drilling it out isn't too hard, just requires
extreme care.

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 11:29:16 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: Some 928 buying questions from a newbie

Pete writes:

>Hi all,
>I'm a new porschephile.  After reading some of the recent archives and
>lurking for a few days I have some questions I hope you can help me
>answer...
>I live in San Jose, CA, and intend to purchase a used 928S or S4 soon.

All rights!!  More 928 people!  You know, I haven't seen good used S4's for a 
while either.  I think it may have to do with the low resale value and high
insurance cost of the car.  Porsche dumped many 928s on this country in the
late `70's and early `80's and consequently, there are a lot to be had for the
price of a loaded Hundai.  Very depressing.  
Anyway, my '79 has 118K and is still very strong (but it could be stronger!).  
If you're looking for a good 928, I'd get an '87 S4.  This has the 4-cam engine
and the big Brembo brakes on the front.  I think it also has the DME fuel
injection and the engine displacement is 5.0 liters.

>4) Why are there so many automatic 928's?
because these cars were GT (Luxo Barge) cars, not true sports cars.

>5) Is it worth the extra money to find a 928 with very low mileage (< 30K)?
IMHO, no

>2) If there are that few S4's, are the differences between the S and S4?
See above.

You can save yourself a TON of dollars if you join PCA (Are you a member?)
and search through the adds in the back for spare parts to keep your beast
rolling.  If you don't have much mechanical aptitude or desire, you'd better
have a lot of cash for the repairs.  Here's a sample:

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 11:13:12 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Checking 944 thermostats

| From: Milo R. Dorr  <milodorr@netcom.com>
|
| <stuff removed for brevity>
| and Mac.  Has anyone found a slick tool/trick to make pulling the
| thermostat from an installed pump easier/possible?

What worked well for me was a pair of angled needle nose pliers.
Got them at the local auto supply. The angle of the bend is about 75
or 80 degrees and the tips are small enough to go into the snap
ring's holes.

BTW, my 944 runs hotter after the head rebuild, by about one mark
on the gauge. I was told that a 50-50 mixture of antifreeze and water
will cause hotter running than a more dilute mixture. It had almost
pure water in it before the head repair (because I was topping it off
so often).

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

Engine Rebuilders Supply (I think that is the name) advertises the tool for
$389 in Pano and Excellence.

I was told that you don't need the tensioning tool for the cam belt of
'87 and newer 944's cause they have a self-tensioner. Can anyone
comment if this is correct?

You are supposed to use the tensioning tool on the balance shafts belt,
but that is not nearly as critical a failure point if you wanted to try to
tighten it "by feel".

With reference to several recent posts regarding the fans in a 944:

turn on the A/C.  Both fans should come on.  If not, you've got
a problem.

Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 11:22:58 -0800
From: richardson@newton.apple.com (Peter Richardson)
Subject: Some 928 buying questions from a newbie


Hi Peter, I just bought an older 928 (shinny black!) and I think I can answer
most of the questions you have below:

- ----------------------------Original message----------------------------
I live in San Jose, CA, and intend to purchase a used 928S or S4 soon.

Here are my questions.

1) Where are all the used S4's?

>Don't know why you can't find any, I thought Cal. was the Porsche capital!  I
found mine in the Washington Post


2) If there are that few S4's, are the differences between the S and S4
worth the time it takes to find one?

>There are a lot of differences between the original 928, S, and S4.  The bigge
st being between the S and S4.  The first 928 had 230 HP, the S had 300 HP and
the S4 340 HP.  There is little difference in style between the 928 and 928S
(2 spoilers and a line down the side of the car on the S).  The S4 has a re-des
igned front section and rear section with a big ol' spoiler on the rear window.
  Personally, I think they all look beautiful in their own way, but they have
decidedly gotten prettier as they get newer.


3) I noticed that not many of the vocal porschephiles seem to own late
model 928's.  Is there something you know that I should know?

I kinda have a theory that people who own the newer ones aren't as "in to" the
cars as people who own the older ones that tend to need TLC.  Basically, the ne
wer ones are probably too new to have developed problems that would require one
 to join the list and ask for help.  Also, there's not much to do to a S4, as
far as making it faster, better handling.  So, I guess that may be another reas
on why you don't see many questions from 928 S4 owners.


4) Why are there so many automatic 928's?

>If I understand correctly,the 928 was designed as a "touring" car, meaning tha
t it was supposed to be as comfortable as sporty, hence the proliferance of aut
omatic transmitions.


the ads I've seen are for automatics.   Is there a reason for that?  Did
buyers stay away from the 5-speed because they're unreliable?  IMHO, a
stick is so much more fun to drive.

>There are troubles with the synchros in earlier manual transmitions.  Mine is
starting to exhibit wear, but this just means that I have to be more aware of
my shifting and double clutch when down shifting into 2nd gear.  I'm sure that
the automatics have some probles too, though.


5) Is it worth the extra money to find a 928 with very low mileage (< 30K)?
One dealer told me that 200K miles was easy for a Porsche kept in good
condition (so I should buy his 928 with 70K).  My '87 non-Porsche is giving
out after 80K.

>There are several things that seem to go out at certain times in a 928's life.
  Most of them around 80K miles.  I bought mine with 90K miles, with the water
pump replaced, new timing belt and no problem with the gears.  It's got 102K mi
les now with no major problems.  What I can tell you is to ask about these few
things that ALL 928's have problems with:  Water pump, timing belt, steering ra
ck(leaking?), oil leaks, and 2nd gear synchros(or all of them for that matter).


6) I have my heart set on a shiny black 928.  If all I can find is a
non-black car, (and I'm not too concerned about lowering the resale value
by having it repainted...) what kind of paint job should I get that's
worthy of a Porsche?  I don't want a $99 Earl Scheib special, but I don't
want a $10,000 300 coat Imron laced with gold dust only-to-be-looked-at
showpiece either.

> I had a place recomended to me and they are suposedly the best in the area,
they said that it would be about $5,000 to do it right.  They said that the 928
 is a particullarly difficult car to paint.  I informed him that the price they
 want to paint it is about 2/3 of what the car cost me!  He said that that is
what he would charge, but he wouldn't suggest doing it, in my case.  He said to
 have fun with it, put the money into performance parts.

All in all, I love my 1980 Euro 928.  If I had to do it again, I would probably
 bought an S.  Definately get a pre-purchase inspection.  Make sure they check
the things I listed above.  Good luck, and tell us what you decide on!
                                                      Adios, Sean

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 14:44:37 EST

Frank wrote, in reply to me:

| >However, this comment about upshifting at redline caught my attention.
| >I recall a session I had with Joe Cogbill who advised me that the
| >optimum upshift point is at about 4000-4500 RPM on the 951 and that,
| >unless you weren't going to upshift at all (e.g. in a short shoot where
| >you're about to downshift anyway), "you're just converting gas to noise"
| >by delaying an upshift past that point.
| 
| I haven't done it for a 951, but a plot of rear axle torque versus
| speed (i.e.engine torque curve, translated through each gear ratio, etc.)
| for my 944S shows that the red line is the right spot for all shifts.
| Another way to do the same analysis is to look at rear axle HP as a
| function of car speed, which requires a bit less arithmetic (please
| don't start the torque/HP discussion again unless you think about
| it for a while first- rear axle HP versus car speed really does work).
| It might be interesting for someone to do it for other common, stock
| Porsches.

According to the plot in my owner's manual, for the '87, 944, 944S, and
951, peak torque is at between 3000-5000 (looks pretty flat) for the
944, 4250-6000 (again pretty flat) for the 944S, at 3500 for the 951
(pretty peaky). This is a plot of torque vs. engine speed though: not
vs. vehicle speed as Frank suggests.  

| By the way, in keeping with my beginner's strategy of "put it in 3rd
| and leave it there", all of this shouldn't be an issue for the
| beginner. 

Agreed!

Steve

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 15:37:36 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: re: upshifts (was Driver's Ed. (was- Re: Wheel size conversion))

> According to the plot in my owner's manual, for the '87, 944, 944S, and
> 951, peak torque is at between 3000-5000 (looks pretty flat) for the
> 944, 4250-6000 (again pretty flat) for the 944S, at 3500 for the 951
> (pretty peaky). This is a plot of torque vs. engine speed though: not
> vs. vehicle speed as Frank suggests.  

Peak torque is not important as far as calculating the optimum shift
points is concerned. You should shift when the torque at the drive wheels
is equal in the two gears, unless that occurs above redline, in which case
you shift at redline. The shift point is therefore well past the engine's
torque peak for most engines and most gearings. The reason for this is
that if you shift when the drive-wheel torque is higher in the gear you are
in, you miss the added acceleration you would have gotten if you didn't shift,
and if you shift when the drive-wheel torque for the gear you are shifting to 
is higher, you miss the added acceleration you would have gotten if you 
shifted sooner.  The previous comment about maximizing drive-wheel HP is 
equivalent - since at any given road speed the drive-wheel rpm is constant, 
the drive-wheel HP is directly proportional to the drive-wheel torque at that 
speed.

- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 14:54:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.ncr.com>
Subject: re: paint and sandpaper


  <snip>

Peter A. recently mentioned a Japanese sandpaper that is newly available
for polishing paint. I brought some of that paper back from Japan, and it
is truly amazing. The grit scale is from 400 to 1200, based on a system
that is 1/4 the system we use (i.e. 1200=4800 our system). The back of
this sheet is rougher than the abrasive! It seems to be made of a plastic
sheet, which is very durable. I have used it for polishing rocker shafts
and arms on 356 motors to a mirror-like finish. I haven't tried it on
paint yet, but I suspect the results would be great if you had the
patience. If anyone is interested, the stuff is called "Rub-lap" and it is
made by Kovax (Komatsubara Abrasive Co.). I don't know where you can get
it here, though.

Eric
'60 356B
'75 914 2.0

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 15:15:22 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re: 15 vs. 16" wheels (my slice of Pi)

Subject: Re: 15" and 16" wheels

>I think that even 1.19 % difference is too much. Remember that the 15" 
>wheels have 215/60 that gives a side wall height of about 129 mm. While 
>the 16" wheel have 225/50 and a sidewall height of about 112.5 mm. With 
>the 16" wheels 25.4 mm taller than the 15" and the 16" tires have a 16.5 
>mm shorter sidewall the total differences in height between the 15" 
>wheels and tires and the 16" wheel and tire is less than 10 mm.
>
>Would this really change the speedo reading by 1.19% ?

>Works out to about 1.2% for me. Pie (or was it pye) x diameter or 2 X pie x
>radius is the formula most of us have forgotten, and pie is 3.1416.

>Don

     For 225/50; (sidewall height x 2 + wheel height)* 22/7
                 = (225 + 406.4)* 22/7= 2008 mm/rotation

     for 215/60; (258 + 381)= 1983 mm/rotation

             the 215/60 is slower by 0.988%...or the 225/50 is faster by
   1.01%...or a whole lot less than the width of a line on your speedo or any
   possible accuracy it could have... so who cares ??? Do you think the IRS 
   will nix your mileage deduction since it overread by 1%?  The only 
   question is if you like the ride and handling of the lower profile tires
   and want to pay for them.

        Lee A, living better thru math,
                 then realizing that the numbers didn't help at all...

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 13:45:47 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: Threads


Stan,

There is an international standard, though I'm not sure of the name of
it. It's from the SAE and specifies the thread and type for spark
plugs with 16mm and 18mm bodies. I don't think that's a real problem.

I think the real problem lies with what the manufacturers DON"T do 
to their plugs: 
Bosch and a few other Euro sparkplug manufacturers put a special
lubricant to prevent thread siezing in aluminum and iron heads. Many
other manufacturers do not. Splitfire does not. One more reason to 
use Bosch or Beru other than the manual telling you to. I have 
examined a number of plugs and do not see this lubricant present.
This is why you should not use anti-sieze compound with Bosch or 
Beru plugs. The damn things will back out on you and the torque 
required to tighten will not be correct. It took me a while to 
figure out why a friend's 944 kept having loose spark plugs.

For you 914/4 owners, NEVER reuse a sparkplug gasket (the aluminum
washer thinge). They are designed to be used once, you will wind up 
over-torquing the plug in the tightening process. The gasket is 
designed to accept this torque in the process of being crushed. 
Without the gasket being compressed during tightening, the threads 
and area around the sparkplug boss are distorted. The metal will 
fatigue and fail or strip the threads. Clark Anderson has pointed 
this out to many 914/4 owners.


Jim Pasha

- ----- Begin Included Message -----

From stan@tta.com Wed Jan 18 12:14:03 1995
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Splitfires
To:pasha@hal.com

Jim,

There's another issue: German vs. US cut threads. My understanding is
that if you use US cut threads on a German head, it causes additional
metal to be displaced from the thread area. Then you go back to German
threads, and pop! the plug can blow out... Might be worth investigating
further, etc.

Stan


- ----- End Included Message -----

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 16:27:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: sparkplugs, antifreeze, and brake fluid!


Matt,

You don't want to use the silicone DOT 5 fluid.  Stick to the glycol-based 
DOT
3 and DOT 4 types, such as Castrol GT LMA.  For a discussion of why, see
Bruce Anderson's book.

(Isn't this in the FAQ?)

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 12:46:19 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: 15" and 16" wheels

> >Would this really change the speedo reading by 1.19% ?
> Works out to about 1.2% for me. Pie (or was it pye) x diameter or 2 X pie x 
> radius is the formula most of us have forgotten, and pie is 3.1416.
> Don

If you used Pi in your calculation, you didn't look at the equation very
hard:

                   (2*Pi*R1
error percentage = (------- - 1) * 100
                   (2*Pi*R2

where R1 and R2 are 1/2 the wheel diameter plus the sidewall height.
The 2*pi factor cancels out of the division, so you only have to divide
the radii, subtract 1, multiply by 100, and that's the error percentage.
As has been mentioned, an error of 1.19% is irrelevant to driving your
car. You would be better off looking at the track than worrying about
a 1 mph difference in your shift points.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 17:06:19 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 stalling


Dear Bart,

It is typical for a 914 2.0 to start, run and die three times before it idles
normally (when cold of course). If you have a problem beyond that, the
auxillary air valve is not opening, your intake system has leaks, the fuel
pressure is too low or the head temperature sensor is not providing enough
resistance!)

We assume, of course, your 914 has decent compression, the valves are
adjusted and the ignition system is in great tune!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 17:11:46 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: re: upshifts (was Driver's Ed. (was- Re: Wheel size conversion))

>Frank wrote, in reply to me:
>
>| >However, this comment about upshifting at redline caught my attention.
>| >I recall a session I had with Joe Cogbill who advised me that the
>| >optimum upshift point is at about 4000-4500 RPM on the 951 and that,
>| >unless you weren't going to upshift at all (e.g. in a short shoot where
>| >you're about to downshift anyway), "you're just converting gas to noise"
>| >by delaying an upshift past that point.
>| 
>| I haven't done it for a 951, but a plot of rear axle torque versus
>| speed (i.e.engine torque curve, translated through each gear ratio, etc.)
>| for my 944S shows that the red line is the right spot for all shifts.
>| Another way to do the same analysis is to look at rear axle HP as a
>| function of car speed, which requires a bit less arithmetic (please
>| don't start the torque/HP discussion again unless you think about
>| it for a while first- rear axle HP versus car speed really does work).
>| It might be interesting for someone to do it for other common, stock
>| Porsches.
>
>According to the plot in my owner's manual, for the '87, 944, 944S, and
>951, peak torque is at between 3000-5000 (looks pretty flat) for the
>944, 4250-6000 (again pretty flat) for the 944S, at 3500 for the 951
>(pretty peaky). This is a plot of torque vs. engine speed though: not
>vs. vehicle speed as Frank suggests.  

The real issue of course is that when you shift to a higher gear, 
to an RPM where the engine almost certianly develops more torque,
you have to multiply that torque by a smaller number (i.e. the gear
ratio in the higher gear) to get rear axle torque. For most typical
torque curves and gear spacings, you get more rear wheel torque by
starting with less engine torque (at a high RPM), but multiplying
by a higher gear ratio in the lower gear. This is not always the
case, hence the need to generate a curve of rear axle torque (or HP).
In any case, it is hard to get an accurate answer just looking at the
engine torque curve. You can get a good clue from the HP curve.
If it hasn't rolled over quite a bit at the redline, you will
do better shifting at the redline.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 17:02:40 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: CA smog test blues

The recent discussion of emmisions testing reminded me of the time when I 
took my `76 Toyota Corolla to be tested in San Diego.  The "technician" came 
back with the news that the car had failed.  I read the slip carefully and 
saw that this "expert"* had run the test as a catalysed exhaust system.  
When I pointed out the factory sticker on the driver's door jam, he openned 
the hood and pointed to what he claimed was my catalytic converter.  My 
reply was that the part in question was actually my master brake cylinder.  
He ran the test again and the car passed.

It was also mentioned that CARB needs to hire refs who know what they are 
doing.  If they knew what they were doing, they would go into business for 
themselves rather than working for the state.

Just an opinion,

     -- Bill
        wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu

* ex = has-been; spurt = drip under pressure

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 17:07:43 CST
From: dhartger@nas_jsc1.jsc.nasa.gov (Dan Hartgerink)
Subject: RE: timing belt tool


Eric writes:

....stuff deleted......

>I was told that you don't need the tensioning tool for the cam belt of
>'87 and newer 944's cause they have a self-tensioner. Can anyone
>comment if this is correct?

>You are supposed to use the tensioning tool on the balance shafts belt,
>but that is not nearly as critical a failure point if you wanted to try to
>tighten it "by feel".

>  Eric


I have an '87 944 that has a self tensioner device on it.  Ive been 
running on belts (Im on my third set) installed by me, and tensioned 
with the self tensioner now for just over 60K miles.  Of course, the 
self tensioner only takes care of the timing belt, so I do the balance
belt by feel, assuming that the tension here is somewhat less critical
than the tension on the timing belt itself.  I am assuming that if the
balance belt slipped it wouldnt destroy the engine, however I imagine 
that if the balance belt broke that it would take the timing belt with it.

This may qualify as living dangerously,   .... but hey.    

Dan Hartgerink

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 16:50:05 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; buying a 928 (newbie advice)


  1. Availability of black/repaint; !!DON'T !! buy a car thats the wrong
     color expecting to repaint it. Since engine bay, etc is painted on 
     a Porsche repainting it right means stripping every last screw off
     it first. Only worth it if you happened to have the whole car apart.
     928s are difficult to paint well because of gasketing between the
     front and rear valances, also the trim around the driver's door doesn't
     come off (as easily as a 911, and those aren't easy cars to paint
     right either).

   2. Every car is an automatic; something like 70% of 928s were sold that
     way, I suppose its a really good automatic. The 928 shifter is not
     quick or easy, and will not survive rough handling. The clutches do 
     seem to last, even with pretty rough smokeums...  

   3. early vs. late vs S4; the early non 'S cars will take a failure of the
      timing belt and not hurt the engine. The Euro "S" models will hit,
      as will the 32-valve cars. 

   4. Reliability; the cars are great, the engines will last forever. 
      Little stuff will always fail, since its a Porsche. The radiators
      and gas tanks go bad. Its not a Honda, but it can be a reliable car.
      Avoid full leather (on the dash) as this -always- stretches and twists
      the dash, etc.  

   5. Satisfaction in driving; 928s are awesome, lots of power and phenomenal
      handling. They are heavy and don't have a sports-car feel like a 911,
      but they are very stable at any speed and will take corners faster than
      you dreamed possible. The Air conditioners really cool, the cars are
      reasonably quiet, but have a marvelous V8 sound.

         As with any Porsche purchase, just get the very best one you can
      afford and then expect to continually maintain it.

                    Lee A, ex '79 928 (9 years/60k miles)

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 18:54:24 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: antifreeze in bugs? bugs in antifreeze?

    Just heard an amusing story last night from a friend of mine who I
haven't seen in years...  He dropped out of school for a while because
he wasn't sure what he was doing here (and also he was in some academic
s---) and apparently just did the real world thing for a while.  one of
his jobs was a stint at a Jiffy-Lube and he was telling me about the
incompetence of some of the people who worked there...  When I told him
I had a 914, he immediately related the story of when a coworker was
told to give an oil change/checkup to an old bug - apparently he was
found testing the percentage of ethylene glycol in the oil-bath air
cleaner.  Just another reason to do your own maintenance...

Nate "and he probably told the guy all that smoke meant he needed a new
head gasket" Nagel

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 20:10:57 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Blanchard Grinding/Rotors

Doug,
I'm not sure if you are right. I once warped a set of brand new rotors and
yes I did go fast that weekend but the ride home was miserable!
Anyway we did Blanchard grind them and they lasted the rest of the season.
 Certainly the history of the rotor is important but It is my experience that
the warpage can be alleviated by grinding. Turning the rotors is almost
certainly counter productive.
So now I know how to bed in carbon/kevlar brakes and hopefully we won't have
to deal with that problem again

Regards,
Jerry

89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:45 pm

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 18:30:19 -0800

Hi Pete:

I'm speaking second-hand, but perhaps this will help.  

I have a friend who wanted a 928 and eventually bought (Summer '94) a
5-speed '89 S4 with only 13,000 miles on it.  It wasn't cheap, but he got a
lot of car for the money.  It's silver w/dark grey (?) interior, in
spectacular shape (widow selling car). He found it advertised in the DuPont
registry by a place in Missouri, I believe. This place was very
professional, on-the-level, and he bought it "sight-unseen" but thoroughly
researched.  They were used to this sort of sale. He flew out and drove it
back - one long "Italian tuneup."

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 20:04:57 -0800
From: donr@deltanet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: Re: 15" and 16" wheels


>If you used Pi in your calculation, you didn't look at the equation very
>hard:
>
>                   (2*Pi*R1
>error percentage = (------- - 1) * 100
>                   (2*Pi*R2
>
>where R1 and R2 are 1/2 the wheel diameter plus the sidewall height.
>The 2*pi factor cancels out of the division, so you only have to divide
>the radii, subtract 1, multiply by 100, and that's the error percentage.

>John R. Lupien
>lupienj@wal.hp.c
>
It was Pi, knew I couldn't remeber the correct spelling. As to <you didn't 
look at the equation very hard: etc etc>, you are quite right, I didn't look 
at it at all, as the whole mathematical exercise was done in less time than 
you took to write it all down.

Don

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 1995 23:20:06 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Option Numbers for 1988 924S

Yep, Steve, it is the limited edition - M030 suspension, wind-up windows,
manual left-side mirror, manual seats, no sunroof, no rear wiper, black with
grey cloth (maroon pinstripes and maroon carpets), one-of-500...aka a great
street racer with better performance, better aesthetics, and twice the
interior room of the 944.  After driving the dealer's 944 demo for an
afternoon and demurring because of limited space for my 6'4" frame, I paused
to sign up for a contest he was sponsoring.  A month later (on Christmas Eve)
he called and said, "Come get your new 924S".  He offered to give me equal
credit on another model Porsche or an Audi if the 924S was too cramped but
suggested I try it first.  He was right.  It is perfectly adequate for us
tall guys (although nothing else Porsche has built since the the '60s is!)
and is a great daily-driver.   I'm looking forward to the day Porsche
attempts more watered-down attempts at club racers so I can squeeze my
ungainly frame into a new 911-derivative (or perhaps, better yet, a Boxster)
without skinning the top of my head!
Regards, Bob
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper (lots of head-room, leg-room, elbow-room, living-room....)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 01:16:26 -0500 (EST)
From: Elliot Randal Stivers <estiver@emory.edu>
Subject: 928

*In responce to Pete's question about 928s*

Hi! I have been reading the porschephiles group for some time now, but 
this is my first post.  What really caught my intrest was this thread on 
928s.  I too am interested in getting a 928 sometime soon.  Unfortunately 
I don't think that I have the money to get a really new one, I am 
shooting for an '87 S4 but they are hard to find.

After doing a fair amount of research, It is MHO that the earliest 
year to get the 928 is in '85.  In '85 the 928 got a 5.0 liter 
engine along with 54 extra horses and 39 lbs of torque.  The engine 
was a dual-overhead-cam with Bosch fuel injection.  There were 
several other small conviences added with only approx. 90 lbs 
additional weight.

'86 added anti-lock brakes 

'87 was the big year with the introduction of the S4. The engine was 
tweaked a little more to give an extra 28 hp, bringing the grand 
total up to 316 w/317 torque.  In addition there were several 
"major" styling changes which, IMHO, really ready the 928 for the 
90s and make an already good looking car even more so.  

'88 and '89 show no significant improvements over the '87 S4 but 
seem to cost much more in proportion to what you get. 

The '85s and '86s seem to be (relitivly) plentiful and cheap here in 
Atlanta, but I would reccomend holding out for an '87 if you have 
the time.

Happy Hunting

Elliot        



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 07:43:02 +0100
From: Magnus Ottenstrom <magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: Spark plugs


As there's a discussion regarding spark plugs I have to give some
information regarding the difficulty to buy a spark plug.

Performance Products catalogue recommends Bosch W5D Super or NGK BG7ES
for a 1980-83 911SC. Aha. NGK BG7ES can be bought at a low cost car parts 
store for 1$ compared to 3.75$ for the Bosch plugs when you buy them
from the Porsche dealer. 

As the recommendation is for American cars I called NGK Sweden up and asked
them what they recommended for my car. The ONLY plug NGK recommends is
B8EV (gold - palladium) with the nice price 17,50$ - each. 

I have just ordered Bosch W3CC from Porsche for 3.75$.

The moral of the story is that if you have a European 911 your engine
might need other plugs than the American 911's.

Magnus Ottenstrom
Sweden 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 07:44:54 +0100
From: Magnus Ottenstrom <magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: Spark plugs - correction


Whoops! Should be BP7ES and not BG7ES.

Fresno, Ventura, LA, Orange, Riveside, Sacto, Yolo, Placer, El Dorado, San

tested on the dyno. (Oh, and it will be a crime to operate a "gross polluter"
too!).
    The Scenarios given in the Nov 1994 edition of this fine piece of
literature  assuming the car fails the smog test are:

1. Fails. Cost less than $450 to fix? Pay it. It passes Test. All OK.
2. Fails. 1 repair needed, costs OVER $450. Must Pay it! No wavier.
3. Fails: 2 Repairs needed 1 costs $300, the other $600. At least the $600
repair MUST be done before eligible for a wavier!
4. Fails: 3 Repairs needed, costing $300, $350 and $700. Must do the $300 and
$350 before eligible for wavier.
5. Fails: 2 repairs needed $300 and $400. Must do BOTH!

P.S. only ONE wavier is ever granted per vehicle!

God BLESS our Representatives that allowed this monstrosity to be passed into
law! (And the Bureaucrats too!)

and is in a FAQ, could someone please send it?

time I had them on the track, and the coefficient of
friction is not high enough for my non-assisted brakes for
autocrossing.

Carbon Kevlar (?),  and the ones sold by Automotion,
Tweeks, etc. Any others worth trying, how about Ferodos?
I have heard various stories about problems with the available
Carbon based pads. Also some have different compounds
available. Which have worked well?

I will be glad to collect all opinions on these pads and come
up with the general consensus.

require new rotors and bedding in, etc.

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 17:07:08 SST
From: Lawrence Leong <lawrence@hpsgsi3.sgp.hp.com>
Subject: RE: Threads (was: Splitfire)

<snip>

>For you 914/4 owners, NEVER reuse a sparkplug gasket (the aluminum
>washer thinge).  They are designed to be used once, you will wind up
>over-torquing the plug in the tightening process.  The gasket is
>designed to accept this torque in the process of being crushed.  Without
>the gasket being compressed during tightening, the threads and area
>around the sparkplug boss are distorted.  The metal will fatigue and
>fail or strip the threads.  Clark Anderson has pointed this out to many
>914/4 owners.
>
>
>Jim Pasha

Jim, I've never used Bosch plugs before, so pardon my ignorance.  Are the 
Al washers supplied with the plug?  If so, where does one get spare 
washers, or are these easily available?

Thanks
Lawrence

Date: 19 Jan 95 09:52:00 +0000
From: swellen@intgp1.att.com
Subject: Tyres

Thanks to Lee of Washington for the information on
tyres from the Auto Motor und Sport magazine.
As for the performance of the Yokos I have the
following observations.
I replaced P600s in 215/60 ZR15 size with A-008Ps
and found them a large improvement especially in
terms of grip. The only disadvantage was a very
high wear rate, about 8000 miles for the rears
for instance and I'm not a hard driver. The Yokos
were a much newer tyre design than the P600s.
My current 944 has 205/55 and 225/50 ZR16 combination
with Dunlop D40 Mk2s. These were the bees knees in
England 3 years ago, now Dunlop make the SP8000s
and only still sell the D40 Mk2s for customers who
want cheap(ish) tyres.
  All this points to what the tyre companys have
being saying. They claim tyre design used to be
some science and a lot of art, these days it's
mainly science with some art. It does seem tyre's
are improving at an unprecedented rate and the 
A-008Ps are mearly suffering from being an "old"
design.
  I don't think this matters to most of us, I
drive around on obsolete Dunlops and I think the
resulting handling is brilliant. However I must
admit that my next set of tyres will be the best I
can get regardless of cost. So finally as I am 
looking forward to buying a new set of tyres fairly
soon has anyone had experience of Continentals
AquaContact?

from inside sources. What does seem to be confirmed
by these same sources is the nose, boot, has be

aimed at are 25-30k pounds sterling for a flat four
engine and the flat six with 200bhp will be a lot
more. Oh and the 1996 launch date may well turn into
1997 if past performances are to go by.

1,000 pounds with a no penalty withdrawal if I don't
like the car or the price. When I hummed they brought
the deposit down to 250 pounds. Goodness knows what
I could have achieved if I'd haggled!

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 10:59:32 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: sparkplugs, antifreeze, and brake fluid!

On Thu, 19 Jan 1995, Kevin Hughes wrote:

> Subject: RE: sparkplugs, antifreeze, and brake fluid!
> Kevin Gross wrote
> 
> //You don't want to use the silicone DOT 5 fluid.  Stick to the glycol-based 
> //DOT 3 and DOT 4 types,

Kevin & Kevin

Read some time ago about the merits of silicon fluid - this is a summary 
of what I remember.

The traditional glycol based fluids have an affinity for water, typically 
they have a lower boiling point than silicon based, and a far lower 
boiling point when contaminated with water.

From this it is clear that you are far less likely to get brake failure 
caused by vapourisation with silicon.

There may be some issues about silicon fluid attacking the rubber in the 
cylinders, but I cannot remember any details ( I don't think this is a 
problem).

The big problem with silicon fluid is the fire risk.

Silicon fluid is far more likely to catch fire than gasoline. 
If you drip gas onto a hot exhaust, it will vaporise, but will only catch
fire if there is a naked light or spark around. 
If you drop silicon on the exhaust, it ignites without any inducement.

A high proportion of engine fires on modern cars are brake fluid induced, 
a typical scenario is a frontal collision where the fluid res gets 
smashed or dislodged ( you know the stupid wobbly ptastic box on top of 
the servo) the contents then fall straight on to the hot exhaust..

Luckily 944's have the servo on the cold side of the bay.

Pete


+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 11:12:35 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: 944 still cutting out at medium revs


I have finnaly found my problem - thanks again for the various contributions.

The break thru came when the car cut out in heavy rain - not only did 
the engine stop, but my rear wiper switched off.

Dropped the fuse box, waggled the wiring -- voila

God knows how much it would have cost me at my local P-service shop.

Germans may be great at engines and bodies, but they know zip about 
needle-point (knitting) the uk spec 944 fuse panel wiring is a disgusting 
mess!!

Pete

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 09:06:01 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 944 gas gauge woes

Here's one for the 944 experts...

My 85.1 944 fuel gauge is acting up. If I fill up, the gauge never registers
all the way to full. It stops about an 1/4" from the full mark.

On the way down, it will register up to a point, about a little past the
1/4 line and then buries itself into the left. All the way!

I have cleaned the battery cables (ground) and the 3 wires comming out of the
+ terminal. I first thought it was a voltage or missing ground problem. But
all other instruments work ok.

I've taken the tank sender apart and made sure the little spring contacts were 
making good contact with the sensing wires. Also checked the reserve light
contact. An ohm-meter shows about 75 ohms at the lowest sender level (empty
tank) and about 4 ohms at the highest (full tank). 

This makes sense since low resistance (full tank) means more current = more
deflection on the gas gauge.

It appears to me that the whole operating range should be shifted right.
It looks like the sender is not adjustable. 

Does any one know if there is any kind of adjustment in the back of the
fuel gauge. Something like a trim pot? I figured that if there is one, I could
fill up, drive home, take the inst cluster apart and adjust the trimmer pot
to show a full tank...

Comments?

and THANKS!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (Beauty, nah, THE REAL BEAST!)
'85 Guards Red 944 (The Beast)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo
'88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 17:06 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: re: 15 vs. 16" wheels (my slice of Pi)

Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com pointed out:
	
	     For 225/50; (sidewall height x 2 + wheel height)* 22/7
	                 = (225 + 406.4)* 22/7= 2008 mm/rotation
	
	     for 215/60; (258 + 381)= 1983 mm/rotation

Heavy sigh.  I really wanted 225/50 series tires, but I "figured" the size
difference would throw off my speedo enough to be noticable.  The price one
pays for being an English major, I suppose...

Then again, maybe it's just more incentive to go for those 16" wheels...

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)
'87 944S

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 9:05:09 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Engine stand advise

  >The engine's just about out of the SC now, and I'm attempting to
  >determine just how I'm going to work on it once it's separated
  >from the trans.  I'm considering purchasing an engine yoke/vise
  >setup, but I don't believe I have a heavy enough bench to bolt
  >it to that would withstand having an engine cantievered off one

I just set my engine directly on my work bench.  A cheap, build-it-yourself
one I got from Furrows for the purpose, however I did assemble it with
3" decking screws not the silly little nails that came with it.

The bench creaked a little but no problem, solid.  The engine is pretty
light, probably 250lbs or so with the cis on it.  I used little blocks
of 2x4 and little pieces of 1/2" trim as wedges to block the thing
solidly into various positions.

RE: Some 928 buying questions from a newbie

Peter asked:

bill and Bart did a fine job of representing our points, here are some more.


>Here are my questions.
>1) Where are all the used S4's?

      A. People are still happy with them
      B. Loan isn't paid off yet
      C. Comparing purchase price to value, want to drive it till it dies.

      Have seen several at the local dealership in Houston, the Dupont 
      Registry (SP) has lots of brokers listed.  (not a recommendation)


>2) If there are that few S4's, are the differences between the S and S4
>worth the time it takes to find one?

      S had both 16v and 32v motors, euro just 16v.  S4 started one world 
      one motor era.
      I sent Peter my FAQ that is still in construction.  work work work you 
      know..

>3) I noticed that not many of the vocal porschephiles seem to own late
>model 928's.  Is there something you know that I should know?

      Highest count on WW was 18 I think,  some took themselves off after 
      the #ed auto list add routine.   (humor mode pls)  The air-heads in 
      the group don't like talking about any car that has almost as much 
      weight in accessories than their whole car. (done)  Members we have 
      had have represented all changes in the line from original to GTS.

>4) Why are there so many automatic 928's?

      Well discussed already.   Market was US,  SL,6xx BMW's,XJS owners.
      What happened was first time P buyers were the majority.

>5) Is it worth the extra money to find a 928 with very low mileage (< 30K)?
>One dealer told me that 200K miles was easy for a Porsche kept in good
>condition (so I should buy his 928 with 70K).  My '87 non-Porsche is giving
>out after 80K.

      Garage queens- hard on rubber and relays, both is great supply on the 
      car.  NO.

>6) I have my heart set on a shiny black 928.  If all I can find is a

      Have the dealer check around, they are always at auctions and network 
      the other dealers.

>Some Bay Area specific questions:

      Now the same wary eye needs to be out in Cal as we have here in 
      Houston with flooded cars.  Check for signs.


Regards, Steve

haven't seen in years...  He dropped out of school for a while because
he wasn't sure what he was doing here (and also he was in some academic
s---) and apparently just did the real world thing for a while.  one of
his jobs was a stint at a Jiffy-Lube and he was telling me about the

I had a 914, he immediately related the story of when a coworker was
told to give an oil change/checkup to an old bug - apparently he was
found testing the percentage of ethylene glycol in the oil-bath air
cleaner.  Just another reason to do your own maintenance...

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 11:25:43 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: oil disposal

>proper disposal ? I live in Algonqin IL (32 mi. NW of Chicago) and I'm having
>a tough time finding a place that will.  Not even the incompetent grease monkeys 
>at Jiffy-Lube will take my used oil.  Any suggestions are welcome.  My garage is 
===================
Craig:
	If I remember correctly, any place that sells oil must take used
oil back for recycling. I think it is an EPA mandate. I also remember that
Exxon oil containers have a toll free number to call for the nearest gas
station (exxon) that will take oil back. Check with Sears, Kmart or any
big stores with an auto-parts/service section.

Does your town recycle? Here in the East Coast have many alternatives to oil
disposal. I guess we don't have enough chain saws! :)

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 11:37 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Factory alarms

From: DAYEFTDIX@aol.com
	Does anyone know if porsches, specifically 944 turbos, came with factory
	alarms. I have additional key hole on my left rear quartwer panel, and
	someone said this was a factory installed alarm. I am so concerned about this
	because my car was broken into, and I was considering purchasing an alarm,
	but not if it has the factory alarm. I can't check and see know because my
	car is in the shop. Thanks for any info.

Yep, that's the factory alarm.  You should have a long skinny key that fits
into it.  They honk the horn if anyone opens the doors (and maybe hood) while
the alarm is active.  They also cut off an ignition component (fuel pump relay?)
so noone can drive away with the horn honking.

I'd still spring for a different alarm, though.  I would think it would be
pretty easy to pry open the keyhole and somehow disable the alarm from there.
Also, my insurance company won't give me an alarm discount because the alarm
doesn't passively arm itself.  Plus, with aftermarket alarms you can get cool
toys like interfaces to the sunroof, windows and rear hatch.  I'm hoping to
install a new stereo system in my 944S this summer, and you can bet I'm going to
install a new alarm then, too.

Tracy Nelson
'87 944S


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 08:42:25 -0800 (PST)
From: Wayne Joerding - Economics <joerd@wsunix.wsu.edu>
Subject: Over-reving on a 1980 911SC

I've developed a problem with over-reving on my 1980 911SC AFTER the 
engine has completely warmed up. i.e. this is not a cold engine problem. 
Specifically, after driving on the highway for 20 minutes the engine 
idles at over 2000 RPM.  When cold, the engine idles at a more reasonable 
1200 RPM.

When I purchased the car I found that the previous ouwner had 
disconnected the hose that connect to a vacumen type device on the right 
side of the engine.  I can't remember the name of this device but it 
serves to maintain revs after foot is removed from the accelerator.  
Consequently, it was very difficult to shift without clunking the engine.

I reconnected the hose and obtained much smoother shifting.  A month or 
so later the problem with over-reving emerged.  I don't think the two are 
definitely related, especially after re-disconnecting the hose and 
finding that the problem didn't go away.

So, any ideas?

My local mechanic thinks the most likely problem is that the vacume 
device I referred to earlier is worn out.  What does the net think?

How difficult would it be to replace this device if necessary?

The car is in storage this winter, but come spring I'll be very 
interested in fixing the problem.

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 08:50:17 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: Re: 986

At 10:14 AM 1/19/95 EST, BlaineDeLancey wrote:

be the reason for the redesigned front end?  Out of curiosity, how many
>are putting up the deposit, and what is the projected price these days? 
>What I'd give to see Porsche get back into something other than the
>gold-chain world!  I hate having to work so hard hoping that one day I can
>upgrade to a newer 911.  
>

Blaine,

        Just happens we (San Diego region) had a Tech at the dealer 
(Pioneer) last night.  Pioneer said the Boxters will be allocated to dealers 
based upon past sales figures for the dealers.  this is a change from past 
policy when cars were allocated based upon the number of deposits received.  
I guess under the old system, some dealers took large numbers of deposits to 
increase their alotment size, resulting in many frustrated would-be 
customers. Pioneer anticipates getting about 200 Boxters in the first year.  
They have quit taking deposits, and did not specify how many deposits they 
have, but did say "it was getting rediculous".

        The price is still pegged at "under $40k", although if the first 
years production is fully subscribed, we all know what that will do in the 
marketplace.

- --      Bob


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 10:58:59 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Over-reving on a 1980 911SC

> When I purchased the car I found that the previous ouwner had 
> disconnected the hose that connect to a vacumen type device on the right 
> side of the engine.  I can't remember the name of this device but it 
> serves to maintain revs after foot is removed from the accelerator.  
> Consequently, it was very difficult to shift without clunking the engine.

Likely the control pressure regulator, and that is also the most likely 
cause of your problem -- but for a different reason. It's also known as
the 'warmup regulator'....

> My local mechanic thinks the most likely problem is that the vacume 
> device I referred to earlier is worn out.  What does the net think?

I think you need to replace your mechanic with someone that actually 
understands CIS.

> How difficult would it be to replace this device if necessary?

"Normal hand tools, simple bolt-on procedure." It's just that getting
the control pressures re-adjusted is a bit tricky unless you have the
special tools and experience.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 19 Jan 95 12:25:20 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Paint and sandpaper

 
Kyle Ehler mentions a "nib file." This is basically a short piece of mill
bastard file, maybe with a gentler grind on the curved teeth, mounted in a
small piece of wood. I think they take off too much paint for the usual dust
inclusions (it's basicaly a "paint shaver") but I use them on the occasional
run to bring it down faster, then finish with sandpaper and polish as
before.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 12:25:36 -0500
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject:  P/C Set #911 103 928 01

Tom,

Yes, the bad news is you have the wrong pistons and they won't work with your
motor very well, if at all.  

Your supplier has sent you the special 2.7 RS pistons that work with MFI.
 Usually, these cost more than the standard pistons and are desired by folks
converting to carberators or upgrading their 2.4's to 2.7's.

These RS pistons fit the 911.83 engine made from '73 to '76.  You will have
to return them or sell them to someone.  What did you pay for them?

 -Allen Henderson-

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 13:03:24 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Oil Disposal

This appears to be an increasing trend.  My local community accepted 
waste oil for proper disposal until last summer.  Now I cannot use this 
service, so guess what I'm motivated to do by my government?  Anybody 
else noticed this?

Here's my oil disposal timeline (in a vertical format):

1) oil gets dumped on the ground and in sewers
2) environment gets damaged by oil
3) oil is classified hazardous by EPA (USA)
4) disposal is regulated; new businesses pop up to charge for its disposal
5) free disposal methods disappear, nobody's willing to take your oil any more
6) oil gets dumped on the ground and in sewers   <<<<<---  you are here

		JBS

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 13:49:45 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: I just bought 912E VIN#1 !!! shocks?

Hello Porschephiliacs,  Yesterday I picked up 912E #9126000001 for $6200! I 
checked the number in the trunk and it matched the window #.  The engine is 
#P*000003, so I figured they must have kept the first two for testing.  
As I drove away from the notary's office, the previous owner stopped 
me and told me to take good care of his baby (better than he did 
anyway).  I then asked him if he knew if the car was special in any way.  
He said no, so I showed him the VIN on the title he just signed over and 
pointed to the "1"  He looked with surprise as I gave him a big grin :^) 
and drove off.  Am I mean or what?  Anyway I looked through the records 
and got the idea that NOTHING has ever been replaced in this car's 66,000 
miles!  Especially bad are the shocks, can I use 911 shocks and who makes 
the best ones for a firm ride?  I adjusted the slipping clutch and gave 
it thicker 20W50 oil.  Now it only smokes at startup and deceleration, 
and the clutch slips at 4000RPM instead of 3000.  I hope it lasts a 
little while or I'll have to sell my beloved '77 924 to pay for parts :^( .
This car is very fun to drive and I have to thank all those on P-philes 
who gave me enogh info to give me the nerve to buy it!
Jay Karolyi
'77 Lima Bean green 924 
'76 Alpine white with mysterious brown spots 912E (clutch slips and it 
smokes like uncle Charlie but its ALL MINE!!!!!!!!!  :^)

What! Who! OK, so I sit at the back and listen a lot ...sometimes I fall
asleep... ;-)

I don't mail to the list much as there are *many* people on this list that can
answer questions better than I ever will. But as a later model 928 owner I can
say I have not had any problems with the car in the 2+ years I have owned it.

My GTS is a 5 speed and has seen the track at Vegas twice and run in 20+
autocrosses. I think the reason not many S4's onwards are seen is that 
there really isn't that many in the US. I know from talking to the regional rep
of PCNA (FWIW) that less than 100 GTS's were imported through fiscal 1993 and 
1994.

Still can't bring myself around to installing a roll bar... cutting into that
nice shiny new metal! aaargh! Guess I'll have to get a track car one of these
days....   now, back to sleeeeepp......

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 17:07:08 SST
From: Lawrence Leong <lawrence@hpsgsi3.sgp.hp.com>
Subject: RE: Threads (was: Splitfire)

<snip>

>For you 914/4 owners, NEVER reuse a sparkplug gasket (the aluminum
>washer thinge).  They are designed to be used once, you will wind up
>over-torquing the plug in the tightening process.  The gasket is
>designed to accept this torque in the process of being crushed.  Without
>the gasket being compressed during tightening, the threads and area
>around the sparkplug boss are distorted.  The metal will fatigue and
>fail or strip the threads.  Clark Anderson has pointed this out to many
>914/4 owners.
>
>
>Jim Pasha

Jim, I've never used Bosch plugs before, so pardon my ignorance.  Are the 
Al washers supplied with the plug?  If so, where does one get spare 
washers, or are these easily available?

Thanks
Lawrence

Date: 19 Jan 95 09:52:00 +0000
From: swellen@intgp1.att.com
Subject: Tyres

Thanks to Lee of Washington for the information on
tyres from the Auto Motor und Sport magazine.
As for the performance of the Yokos I have the
following observations.
I replaced P600s in 215/60 ZR15 size with A-008Ps
and found them a large improvement especially in
terms of grip. The only disadvantage was a very
high wear rate, about 8000 miles for the rears
for instance and I'm not a hard driver. The Yokos
were a much newer tyre design than the P600s.
My current 944 has 205/55 and 225/50 ZR16 combination
with Dunlop D40 Mk2s. These were the bees knees in
England 3 years ago, now Dunlop make the SP8000s
and only still sell the D40 Mk2s for customers who
want cheap(ish) tyres.
  All this points to what the tyre companys have
being saying. They claim tyre design used to be
some science and a lot of art, these days it's
mainly science with some art. It does seem tyre's
are improving at an unprecedented rate and the 
A-008Ps are mearly suffering from being an "old"
design.
  I don't think this matters to most of us, I
drive around on obsolete Dunlops and I think the
resulting handling is brilliant. However I must
admit that my next set of tyres will be the best I
can get regardless of cost. So finally as I am 
looking forward to buying a new set of tyres fairly
soon has anyone had experience of Continentals
AquaContact?

Subject: 986

It might be worth rembering that the show car Boxster

there is a rumour the wheelbase has been stretched
to make it a 2+2 but this hasn't had much comment
from inside sources. What does seem to be confirmed
by these same sources is the nose, boot, has be
enlarged in order to meet crash regulations. Prices
aimed at are 25-30k pounds sterling for a flat four
engine and the flat six with 200bhp will be a lot
more. Oh and the 1996 launch date may well turn into
1997 if past performances are to go by.
  I spoke to a dealer about deposits and they said
1,000 pounds with a no penalty withdrawal if I don't
like the car or the price. When I hummed they brought
the deposit down to 250 pounds. Goodness knows what
I could have achieved if I'd haggled!
  Despite the warning that the real car will not be
as drop dead gorgeous as the show car I may well put
my name on the list and learn how to rob banks to
get the funds needed.
