Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 10:59:32 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: sparkplugs, antifreeze, and brake fluid!

On Thu, 19 Jan 1995, Kevin Hughes wrote:

> Subject: RE: sparkplugs, antifreeze, and brake fluid!
> Kevin Gross wrote
> 
> //You don't want to use the silicone DOT 5 fluid.  Stick to the glycol-based 
> //DOT 3 and DOT 4 types,

Kevin & Kevin

Read some time ago about the merits of silicon fluid - this is a summary 
of what I remember.

The traditional glycol based fluids have an affinity for water, typically 
they have a lower boiling point than silicon based, and a far lower 
boiling point when contaminated with water.

From this it is clear that you are far less likely to get brake failure 
caused by vapourisation with silicon.

There may be some issues about silicon fluid attacking the rubber in the 
cylinders, but I cannot remember any details ( I don't think this is a 
problem).

The big problem with silicon fluid is the fire risk.

Silicon fluid is far more likely to catch fire than gasoline. 
If you drip gas onto a hot exhaust, it will vaporise, but will only catch
fire if there is a naked light or spark around. 
If you drop silicon on the exhaust, it ignites without any inducement.

A high proportion of engine fires on modern cars are brake fluid induced, 
a typical scenario is a frontal collision where the fluid res gets 
smashed or dislodged ( you know the stupid wobbly ptastic box on top of 
the servo) the contents then fall straight on to the hot exhaust..

Luckily 944's have the servo on the cold side of the bay.

Pete


+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 11:12:35 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: 944 still cutting out at medium revs


I have finnaly found my problem - thanks again for the various contributions.

The break thru came when the car cut out in heavy rain - not only did 
the engine stop, but my rear wiper switched off.

Dropped the fuse box, waggled the wiring -- voila

God knows how much it would have cost me at my local P-service shop.

Germans may be great at engines and bodies, but they know zip about 
needle-point (knitting) the uk spec 944 fuse panel wiring is a disgusting 
mess!!

Pete

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 09:06:01 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 944 gas gauge woes

Here's one for the 944 experts...

My 85.1 944 fuel gauge is acting up. If I fill up, the gauge never registers
all the way to full. It stops about an 1/4" from the full mark.

On the way down, it will register up to a point, about a little past the
1/4 line and then buries itself into the left. All the way!

I have cleaned the battery cables (ground) and the 3 wires comming out of the
+ terminal. I first thought it was a voltage or missing ground problem. But
all other instruments work ok.

I've taken the tank sender apart and made sure the little spring contacts were 
making good contact with the sensing wires. Also checked the reserve light
contact. An ohm-meter shows about 75 ohms at the lowest sender level (empty
tank) and about 4 ohms at the highest (full tank). 

This makes sense since low resistance (full tank) means more current = more
deflection on the gas gauge.

It appears to me that the whole operating range should be shifted right.
It looks like the sender is not adjustable. 

Does any one know if there is any kind of adjustment in the back of the
fuel gauge. Something like a trim pot? I figured that if there is one, I could
fill up, drive home, take the inst cluster apart and adjust the trimmer pot
to show a full tank...

Comments?

and THANKS!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (Beauty, nah, THE REAL BEAST!)
'85 Guards Red 944 (The Beast)
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo
'88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Wed, 18 Jan 95 17:06 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: re: 15 vs. 16" wheels (my slice of Pi)

Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com pointed out:
	
	     For 225/50; (sidewall height x 2 + wheel height)* 22/7
	                 = (225 + 406.4)* 22/7= 2008 mm/rotation
	
	     for 215/60; (258 + 381)= 1983 mm/rotation

Heavy sigh.  I really wanted 225/50 series tires, but I "figured" the size
difference would throw off my speedo enough to be noticable.  The price one
pays for being an English major, I suppose...

Then again, maybe it's just more incentive to go for those 16" wheels...

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)
'87 944S

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 9:05:09 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Engine stand advise

  >The engine's just about out of the SC now, and I'm attempting to
  >determine just how I'm going to work on it once it's separated
  >from the trans.  I'm considering purchasing an engine yoke/vise
  >setup, but I don't believe I have a heavy enough bench to bolt
  >it to that would withstand having an engine cantievered off one

I just set my engine directly on my work bench.  A cheap, build-it-yourself
one I got from Furrows for the purpose, however I did assemble it with
3" decking screws not the silly little nails that came with it.

The bench creaked a little but no problem, solid.  The engine is pretty
light, probably 250lbs or so with the cis on it.  I used little blocks
of 2x4 and little pieces of 1/2" trim as wedges to block the thing
solidly into various positions.

RE: Some 928 buying questions from a newbie

Peter asked:

bill and Bart did a fine job of representing our points, here are some more.


>Here are my questions.
>1) Where are all the used S4's?

      A. People are still happy with them
      B. Loan isn't paid off yet
      C. Comparing purchase price to value, want to drive it till it dies.

      Have seen several at the local dealership in Houston, the Dupont 
      Registry (SP) has lots of brokers listed.  (not a recommendation)


>2) If there are that few S4's, are the differences between the S and S4
>worth the time it takes to find one?

      S had both 16v and 32v motors, euro just 16v.  S4 started one world 
      one motor era.
      I sent Peter my FAQ that is still in construction.  work work work you 
      know..

>3) I noticed that not many of the vocal porschephiles seem to own late
>model 928's.  Is there something you know that I should know?

      Highest count on WW was 18 I think,  some took themselves off after 
      the #ed auto list add routine.   (humor mode pls)  The air-heads in 
      the group don't like talking about any car that has almost as much 
      weight in accessories than their whole car. (done)  Members we have 
      had have represented all changes in the line from original to GTS.

>4) Why are there so many automatic 928's?

      Well discussed already.   Market was US,  SL,6xx BMW's,XJS owners.
      What happened was first time P buyers were the majority.

>5) Is it worth the extra money to find a 928 with very low mileage (< 30K)?
>One dealer told me that 200K miles was easy for a Porsche kept in good
>condition (so I should buy his 928 with 70K).  My '87 non-Porsche is giving
>out after 80K.

      Garage queens- hard on rubber and relays, both is great supply on the 
      car.  NO.

>6) I have my heart set on a shiny black 928.  If all I can find is a

      Have the dealer check around, they are always at auctions and network 
      the other dealers.

>Some Bay Area specific questions:

      Now the same wary eye needs to be out in Cal as we have here in 
      Houston with flooded cars.  Check for signs.

haven't seen in years...  He dropped out of school for a while because
he wasn't sure what he was doing here (and also he was in some academic
s---) and apparently just did the real world thing for a while.  one of
his jobs was a stint at a Jiffy-Lube and he was telling me about the

I had a 914, he immediately related the story of when a coworker was
told to give an oil change/checkup to an old bug - apparently he was
found testing the percentage of ethylene glycol in the oil-bath air
cleaner.  Just another reason to do your own maintenance...

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 11:25:43 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: oil disposal

>proper disposal ? I live in Algonqin IL (32 mi. NW of Chicago) and I'm having
>a tough time finding a place that will.  Not even the incompetent grease monkeys 
>at Jiffy-Lube will take my used oil.  Any suggestions are welcome.  My garage is 
===================
Craig:
	If I remember correctly, any place that sells oil must take used
oil back for recycling. I think it is an EPA mandate. I also remember that
Exxon oil containers have a toll free number to call for the nearest gas
station (exxon) that will take oil back. Check with Sears, Kmart or any
big stores with an auto-parts/service section.

Does your town recycle? Here in the East Coast have many alternatives to oil
disposal. I guess we don't have enough chain saws! :)

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories
len@library.att.com	201-386-3689

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 11:37 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Factory alarms

From: DAYEFTDIX@aol.com
	Does anyone know if porsches, specifically 944 turbos, came with factory
	alarms. I have additional key hole on my left rear quartwer panel, and
	someone said this was a factory installed alarm. I am so concerned about this
	because my car was broken into, and I was considering purchasing an alarm,
	but not if it has the factory alarm. I can't check and see know because my
	car is in the shop. Thanks for any info.

Yep, that's the factory alarm.  You should have a long skinny key that fits
into it.  They honk the horn if anyone opens the doors (and maybe hood) while
the alarm is active.  They also cut off an ignition component (fuel pump relay?)
so noone can drive away with the horn honking.

I'd still spring for a different alarm, though.  I would think it would be
pretty easy to pry open the keyhole and somehow disable the alarm from there.
Also, my insurance company won't give me an alarm discount because the alarm
doesn't passively arm itself.  Plus, with aftermarket alarms you can get cool
toys like interfaces to the sunroof, windows and rear hatch.  I'm hoping to
install a new stereo system in my 944S this summer, and you can bet I'm going to
install a new alarm then, too.

Tracy Nelson
'87 944S


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 08:42:25 -0800 (PST)
From: Wayne Joerding - Economics <joerd@wsunix.wsu.edu>
Subject: Over-reving on a 1980 911SC

I've developed a problem with over-reving on my 1980 911SC AFTER the 
engine has completely warmed up. i.e. this is not a cold engine problem. 
Specifically, after driving on the highway for 20 minutes the engine 
idles at over 2000 RPM.  When cold, the engine idles at a more reasonable 
1200 RPM.

When I purchased the car I found that the previous ouwner had 
disconnected the hose that connect to a vacumen type device on the right 
side of the engine.  I can't remember the name of this device but it 
serves to maintain revs after foot is removed from the accelerator.  
Consequently, it was very difficult to shift without clunking the engine.

I reconnected the hose and obtained much smoother shifting.  A month or 
so later the problem with over-reving emerged.  I don't think the two are 
definitely related, especially after re-disconnecting the hose and 
finding that the problem didn't go away.

So, any ideas?

My local mechanic thinks the most likely problem is that the vacume 
device I referred to earlier is worn out.  What does the net think?

How difficult would it be to replace this device if necessary?

The car is in storage this winter, but come spring I'll be very 
interested in fixing the problem.

------------------------------

> oil back for recycling. I think it is an EPA mandate. I also remember that
> Exxon oil containers have a toll free number to call for the nearest gas
> station (exxon) that will take oil back. Check with Sears, Kmart or any
> big stores with an auto-parts/service section.
> 
> Does your town recycle? Here in the East Coast have many alternatives to oil
> disposal. I guess we don't have enough chain saws! :)

Also I know for a fact that Discount Auto Parts takes used oil for free. They
don't take oil filters though. The Jiffy lube where I live, Gainesville, 
FL, accepts oil filters. Anything is better than dumping it on the ground.

Ujjal Bansel
'85 944


> 
> Lou Nicotra
> AT&T Bell Laboratories
> len@library.att.com	201-386-3689
> '84 Guards Red Carrera Targa (Beauty, nah, THE REAL BEAST!)
> '85 Guards Red 944 (The Beast)
> '87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo
> '88 Silver BMW 325is
> 

Wow, a lot of nice toys you got there.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 08:50:17 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: Re: 986

At 10:14 AM 1/19/95 EST, BlaineDeLancey wrote:

be the reason for the redesigned front end?  Out of curiosity, how many
>are putting up the deposit, and what is the projected price these days? 
>What I'd give to see Porsche get back into something other than the
>gold-chain world!  I hate having to work so hard hoping that one day I can
>upgrade to a newer 911.  
>
>Blaine

Blaine,

        Just happens we (San Diego region) had a Tech at the dealer 
(Pioneer) last night.  Pioneer said the Boxters will be allocated to dealers 
based upon past sales figures for the dealers.  this is a change from past 
policy when cars were allocated based upon the number of deposits received.  
I guess under the old system, some dealers took large numbers of deposits to 
increase their alotment size, resulting in many frustrated would-be 
customers. Pioneer anticipates getting about 200 Boxters in the first year.  
They have quit taking deposits, and did not specify how many deposits they 
have, but did say "it was getting rediculous".

        The price is still pegged at "under $40k", although if the first 
years production is fully subscribed, we all know what that will do in the 
marketplace.

- --      Bob


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 10:58:59 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Over-reving on a 1980 911SC

> When I purchased the car I found that the previous ouwner had 
> disconnected the hose that connect to a vacumen type device on the right 
> side of the engine.  I can't remember the name of this device but it 
> serves to maintain revs after foot is removed from the accelerator.  
> Consequently, it was very difficult to shift without clunking the engine.

Likely the control pressure regulator, and that is also the most likely 
cause of your problem -- but for a different reason. It's also known as
the 'warmup regulator'....

> My local mechanic thinks the most likely problem is that the vacume 
> device I referred to earlier is worn out.  What does the net think?

I think you need to replace your mechanic with someone that actually 
understands CIS.

> How difficult would it be to replace this device if necessary?

"Normal hand tools, simple bolt-on procedure." It's just that getting
the control pressures re-adjusted is a bit tricky unless you have the
special tools and experience.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 19 Jan 95 12:25:20 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Paint and sandpaper

 
Kyle Ehler mentions a "nib file." This is basically a short piece of mill
bastard file, maybe with a gentler grind on the curved teeth, mounted in a
small piece of wood. I think they take off too much paint for the usual dust
inclusions (it's basicaly a "paint shaver") but I use them on the occasional
run to bring it down faster, then finish with sandpaper and polish as
before.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 12:25:36 -0500
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject:  P/C Set #911 103 928 01

Tom,

Yes, the bad news is you have the wrong pistons and they won't work with your
motor very well, if at all.  

Your supplier has sent you the special 2.7 RS pistons that work with MFI.
 Usually, these cost more than the standard pistons and are desired by folks
converting to carberators or upgrading their 2.4's to 2.7's.

These RS pistons fit the 911.83 engine made from '73 to '76.  You will have
to return them or sell them to someone.  What did you pay for them?

 -Allen Henderson-

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 09:47:49 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: 912/Anza Exhaust?

Does anyone have any experience with using an Anza exhaust system on a 912.
I have installed one on my buddies MGB, it looked good and seemed to work well,
but, it rusted out in a very short time. I am interested in buying one
for my 912, but I don't want to replace it every year! I now have a Bursch
exhaust and it is very good, but a bit loud. Is the Anza less noisy? Any input
would be appreciated.
Thanks in advance.
Sean
69 912
Zero and Maddog, 8 legs of Terror!

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 13:03:24 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Oil Disposal

This appears to be an increasing trend.  My local community accepted 
waste oil for proper disposal until last summer.  Now I cannot use this 
service, so guess what I'm motivated to do by my government?  Anybody 
else noticed this?

Here's my oil disposal timeline (in a vertical format):

1) oil gets dumped on the ground and in sewers
2) environment gets damaged by oil
3) oil is classified hazardous by EPA (USA)
4) disposal is regulated; new businesses pop up to charge for its disposal
5) free disposal methods disappear, nobody's willing to take your oil any more
6) oil gets dumped on the ground and in sewers   <<<<<---  you are here

		JBS

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 13:49:45 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: I just bought 912E VIN#1 !!! shocks?

Hello Porschephiliacs,  Yesterday I picked up 912E #9126000001 for $6200! I 
checked the number in the trunk and it matched the window #.  The engine is 
#P*000003, so I figured they must have kept the first two for testing.  
As I drove away from the notary's office, the previous owner stopped 
me and told me to take good care of his baby (better than he did 
anyway).  I then asked him if he knew if the car was special in any way.  
He said no, so I showed him the VIN on the title he just signed over and 
pointed to the "1"  He looked with surprise as I gave him a big grin :^) 
and drove off.  Am I mean or what?  Anyway I looked through the records 
and got the idea that NOTHING has ever been replaced in this car's 66,000 
miles!  Especially bad are the shocks, can I use 911 shocks and who makes 
the best ones for a firm ride?  I adjusted the slipping clutch and gave 
it thicker 20W50 oil.  Now it only smokes at startup and deceleration, 
and the clutch slips at 4000RPM instead of 3000.  I hope it lasts a 
little while or I'll have to sell my beloved '77 924 to pay for parts :^( .
This car is very fun to drive and I have to thank all those on P-philes 
who gave me enogh info to give me the nerve to buy it!
Jay Karolyi
'77 Lima Bean green 924 
'76 Alpine white with mysterious brown spots 912E (clutch slips and it 
smokes like uncle Charlie but its ALL MINE!!!!!!!!!  :^)

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 14:05:03 -0500 (EST)

Subject: 911 steering rack spacers ?

another thing I'll be doing before I'm off to drivers ed is to get a
decent alignment.  The car has been lowered somewhat, and has a little
bit of bump steer.  I understand there are some spacers that can help with
this problem.  Before I go rushing off to buy spacers I may not need, or
pay for an alignment that I'll have to do over again if I put spacers in,
can anybody tell me

1)  do these spacers really help, when are they really needed (ie when
    car has been lowered X mm)
2)  where can I look to determine whether or not I already have
    them installed

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 10:08:16 -0700 (MST)
From: ark@slc.unisys.com (Adam King)
Subject: Re: Some 928 buying Q's

|
|RE: Some 928 buying questions from a newbie
|
|>3) I noticed that not many of the vocal porschephiles seem to own late
|>model 928's.  Is there something you know that I should know?
|
| <Steve said>
|      Highest count on WW was 18 I think,  some took themselves off after 
|      the #ed auto list add routine.   (humor mode pls)  The air-heads in 
|      the group don't like talking about any car that has almost as much 
|      weight in accessories than their whole car. (done)  Members we have 
|      had have represented all changes in the line from original to GTS.
|
What! Who! OK, so I sit at the back and listen a lot ...sometimes I fall
asleep... ;-)

I don't mail to the list much as there are *many* people on this list that can
answer questions better than I ever will. But as a later model 928 owner I can
say I have not had any problems with the car in the 2+ years I have owned it.

My GTS is a 5 speed and has seen the track at Vegas twice and run in 20+
autocrosses. I think the reason not many S4's onwards are seen is that 
there really isn't that many in the US. I know from talking to the regional rep
of PCNA (FWIW) that less than 100 GTS's were imported through fiscal 1993 and 
1994.

Still can't bring myself around to installing a roll bar... cutting into that
nice shiny new metal! aaargh! Guess I'll have to get a track car one of these
days....   now, back to sleeeeepp......

Adam. ark@slc.unisys.com

Porschephiles #1083                         Thu Jan 19 20:12:30 CST 1995
Porschephiles #1083                         Thu Jan 19 20:12:30 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 14:12:31 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Re: Wheel size conversion 

This formula may help:

MPH = (RPM * overall tire diameter) / rear axle ratio * 336 * transmission
gear ratio

Peter L

Date: 19 Jan 95 11:05
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: 73 RS oil pump update?

Hi P-philers:

I am (still) rebuilding an original 73 911 RS engine.  My current decision is on 
the oil pump: should I rebuild the original pump or upgrade to a newer Carrera 
version?  I believe the original has a magnesium body (like the engine case) and 
the Carrera version is aluminum and may have a higher flow rate and output 
pressure.  I also believe the Carrera version will fit unmodified.

Any comments would be appreciated.

Jeff Jensen
jcjensen@raychem.com

I need some advice, I have been actively looking at buying an '85-'87 911 Carrera Coupe, 
so far I've not found anything interesting...

Well, I just returned to my office after test driving an '89 911 Coupe. This car was
advertised in the paper for $20.9K, yes $20,900. So of course I flew to this place to take a
look and to test drive it. The car has 90k miles, it is extremely clean in/out and it is a 
one-owner car.  I could not verify/review any of the maintenance & service records.  Needless 
to say, I will have the car inspected by the Porsche mechanic who works on my '88 944.

But for now my concern is of course the mileage on the car, 90,000 miles. What do you 911 
owners think about this, should I stay away from this car? I don't know much about this 
particular model year. Is there anything peculiar about this MY Carrera? I've been reading 
some recent posts about '87 Carreras having problems with temperature senders. Are there 
any common problems related to the '89 Carreras? Any comments about maintenance costs?

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 12:51:34 -0800
From: bfas@halcyon.com (Jeff Bailey)
Subject: Quaife Installation

Next week I'm planning on having a quaife limited slip put into my '72 911 
and I have been getting conflicting info on what needs to be done.  The 
transmission is the early 915 type.  

On one hand I've heard that all you need is the early 915 course spline 
quaife and a spacer and then the quaife should go right in.

On the other hand I've heard that you need the 901 quaife, which fits in the 
915 transmission, and then cut your stub axles by 4mm.

Can anyone confirm what needs to be done here?  I've concerned that I'll get 
poor handling or damage some parts if this is not done correctly.

Thanks,
Jeff Bailey
bfas@halcyon.com


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 15:55:01 EST
From: BlaineDeLancey <Blaine.Delancey@lambada.oit.unc.edu>
Subject: Re: Over-reving on a 1980 911SC

> 
> > When I purchased the car I found that the previous ouwner had 
> > disconnected the hose that connect to a vacumen type device on the right 
> > side of the engine.  I can't remember the name of this device but it 
> > serves to maintain revs after foot is removed from the accelerator.  
> > Consequently, it was very difficult to shift without clunking the engine.
> 
> Likely the control pressure regulator, and that is also the most likely 
> cause of your problem -- but for a different reason. It's also known as
> the 'warmup regulator'....

Stan, if it's on the right-hand side, wouldn't it be the auxiliary air
regulator?  The 'warmup regulator' which modulates the fuel input, is on
the left-hand (driver's) side, just below the heater blower motor and
assembly.  The auxiliary air regulator is just behind the oil filter,
above the valve cover I think.  Of course, it contributes to the warmup
behavior as well, as it modulates the air flow.  I always hear of the fuel
regulator (warmup regulator) beging replaced, how come this aux. air unit
rarely gets mentioned?  Do they not go bad as easily?  I was thinking
maybe it was disconnected as a 'cheap fix' by the previous owner, though
I'm not sure which hose was disconnected.  Perhaps if it's the 'output'
hose, and that regulator IS working, the car was adjusted with regulator
out of the loop, so that now it's back in, the settings are off.

Blaine

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 14:14:30 -0700
From: esherte@sandia.gov (Eugene S. Hertel)

I need to modify/upgrade the shift mechanism in my '72 911T.  The local Porsche

Subject: 911 short shift mods

I need to modify/upgrade the shift mechanism in my '72 911T.  The local Porsche
shop recommends a later model shift tower.  What is the conventional wisdom on
that versus the aftermarket "short shift" kits.  I do not race or autocross.  
Respond directly if this is not an item of general interest.

Gene Hertel
esherte@sandia.gov

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: I just bought 912E VIN#1 !!! shocks?
Author:  Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu> at internet
Date:    1/19/95 11:05 AM


Hello Porschephiliacs,  Yesterday I picked up 912E #9126000001 for $6200! I 
checked the number in the trunk and it matched the window #.  The engine is 
#P*000003, so I figured they must have kept the first two for testing.  
As I drove away from the notary's office, the previous owner stopped 
me and told me to take good care of his baby (better than he did 
anyway).  I then asked him if he knew if the car was special in any way.  
He said no, so I showed him the VIN on the title he just signed over and 
pointed to the "1"  He looked with surprise as I gave him a big grin :^) 
and drove off.  Am I mean or what?  Anyway I looked through the records 
and got the idea that NOTHING has ever been replaced in this car's 66,000 
miles!  Especially bad are the shocks, can I use 911 shocks and who makes 
the best ones for a firm ride?  I adjusted the slipping clutch and gave 
it thicker 20W50 oil.  Now it only smokes at startup and deceleration, 
and the clutch slips at 4000RPM instead of 3000.  I hope it lasts a 
little while or I'll have to sell my beloved '77 924 to pay for parts :^( . 
This car is very fun to drive and I have to thank all those on P-philes 
who gave me enogh info to give me the nerve to buy it! 
Jay Karolyi
'77 Lima Bean green 924 
'76 Alpine white with mysterious brown spots 912E (clutch slips and it 
smokes like uncle Charlie but its ALL MINE!!!!!!!!!  :^)

Subject: SF Bay Area Pre-Purchase Inspections


Several people have asked for a recommend shop that does pre-purchase 
inspections in the San Francisco Bay Area. 
 
D&M Motors in Palo Alto has done an excellent job of servicing my cars for 
several years now and I know they do pre-purchase inspections. 
 
While I have not had them do a pre-purchase inspection for me, I just happened 
to be hanging around the shop on two different occasions when they reported 
out  to the sellers and prospective buyers (a 930 and a 928).  In both cases, 
both seller and buyer seemed very satisfied with the information provided. 
 
D&M can be reached at (415) 329-9016.   
 
I suggest that you ask to have Dieter Mees (the owner) do the inspection.

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 15:48:45 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Engine Removal & more

>The factory has available a 914 cradle that fits a floor jack to assist in
>engine removal. However, all one has to do is situate the floorjack under the
>engine mounting bar. This will balance the power plant for removal.

        If you're removing both engine and transmission together,
simply putting the jack under the engine bar would *not* balance
the two.  When I got my engine out yesterday, I put it up on
blocks, using the mounting bar to support the engine.  I very
definitely needed the floor jack on the transmission side to
everything in the air.
        I'm not sure about only removing the engine.  It may be
that it balances with the tranny and headers (etc.) off the en-
engine, but the bar is rather far forward.  I kinda doubt it.
        Then again, I've only done two, and George has probably
done 200+...
        Another option, instead of trying to balance on one jack,
is to use two.  That was how Josh and I did it the first time.
Coordinating two jacks is very definitely a two-person operation.

- --DD

Jay!!

Whatever you do, DON'T sell it to a collector!!  Keep it.  Fix it.  Insure the

they can make money on it and then sell it to someone who'll keep it in their
garage, protecting it but never letting it see the pavement again.

Don't sell to ANY collector!!  They're ALL speculators and most will sell it
to the highest bidder in a New York minute.

Drive it!!  Send pictures to your friends!!!  Keep it forever!!!  It is now 
part of your family.

Congrats!!

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 15:56:22 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Bay Area 928's

        Picked up a copy of the _Diablo Dealer_ at the grocery
store yesterday.  It's one of the local (SF Bay Area) freebie
car ad papers.  Saw two or three 928s in there.  One was adver-
tised as a 928 S 32-valver with 5-sp.  No price listed, natch!
        So there are *some* out there for sale with the manual
trannies.
        One of the reasons that the automatics were so popular
was the 5-speeds on the early cars.  From reading reviews in
the car mags of the time, it seems that people were *very* un-
impressed by the shifting of the early 928.  They were all re-
commending that people buy the automatics instead.  Evidently
Porsche fixed the problem after a couple of years, because I
saw a later review which said the manual was now even better
than the slushbox.

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 14:09:58 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: Washers


Lawrence,

I had a problem getting conneced to your host. Here's the reply:

I generally do not re-use sparkplugs. Some autoparts stores or speed
shops carry them, none of the chains do as far as I know. All plugs
come with washers unless they are the tapered seat type like Ford and 
GM use.

Just use the range recommended in your owner's manual or the direct
crossover in the Bosch spec sheet if you have a 1975 or earlier 
Porsche. (They had a different numbering scheme back then).

Jim Pasha

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 14:04:18 -0700 (PDT)

Subject: handbrake-induced oversteer

Faithful readers:

	I have a question about the use of my parking brake.  It is fun to 
use it to induce oversteer (especially in snow/ice or rain).  I only do 
this in places with safe amounts of room for error.  My father said that 
this causes very serious damage to the car (a front wheel drive Jetta GLI 
16V) and that the car never runs right after these manuevers (I didn't 
tell him I did this on his car.....)  
Is his assertation true?  Does use of the parking brake cause damage to 
the car/tires or whatever?

Also, are parking brakes always attached to the rear wheels?

	Thanks,
	justin

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 17:34:30 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: handbrake-induced oversteer

> Faithful readers:

> this in places with safe amounts of room for error.  My father said that 
> this causes very serious damage to the car (a front wheel drive Jetta GLI 
> 16V) and that the car never runs right after these manuevers (I didn't

Hi, Justin,

Never caused a problem with any car that I ever did it with...And I have
driven quite a few.

Rabbits and Jettas and Audis all respond well to this kind of treatment, but
you will accelerate the wear on the rear brake shoes (or discs), but that is
minor compared to the fun you have... :-)

The only car that I have encountered that works the parking brake on the
front wheels is the SAAB (read: weird Swedish car, made by trolls who have
never seen a german car...)

BTW, I used to go to that school (Gonzaga)... When I was there, I was called
a COG-rat...that thing still there???

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 17:33:56 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: short shifters, cats, and killer paint



The '73 and later shift tower is a big improvement over the 
earlier model. Joe Reid, our NNJR tech guru says that the
short shift kits for a 915 transmission are a waste of time
for two reasons - it's only going to shift as fast as the 
already weak synchros will allow, and the extra mechanical
effort required is a pain makes it tough to downshift into 
lower gears when the synchros inevitably get weak. 

It *does* reduce the physical distance between shifts, which 
I always thought to be out of character in a sports car.


  Reid 

(confirmed air-head as opposed to those other "water-on-the-brain types)

ps (pardon the spam): 

    with all the talk about cats and paint. It reminded me of a book 
    called "Why Cats Paint" (really!) strange and interesting. If your 
    cat uses urethane, make sure it wears a fresh-air respirator, not
    the kitty litter type.

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 14:51:32 -0800
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: brake pads/warping rotors

On Jan 19,  8:53, Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517 wrote:
> Subject: brake pads/warping rotors
> All this talk about warping rotors has got me thinking.
>
> As I have previously mentioned I'm prepping the car now for at least
> on drivers ed this spring (at Mid-Ohio).
>
> Should I consider putting on cool carbons or some other "race" brake
> pads for the event ?  If I don't, will I stand a good chance of warping
> rotors ?  A set of pads is certainly cheaper than the rotors !

My stock '81 SC has over 1,000 track miles on the same rotors.
(I have used MetalMaster pads.)  You almost certainly will boil the
brake fluid though.  When the brakes cool off you will have a very
soft pedal.  On the warmup lap always test the brakes before you
reach the first corner.  Getting the brakes warm again will firm the
pedal back up and the brakes will work fine.  Be careful on the way
home because you won't have a chance to get the brakes warmed up
before you need them in a panic stop.  Bleeding the brake fluid after
the event will get everything back to normal.

This has been my consistent experience.  It hasn't been a problem on
the race track just on the way home.  A way to reduce the severity
of the problem is to brake a couple of car lengths sooner and just a
little easier.  Some people use a brake duct called "Cool Brake"
which attaches to the front brakes.  These get more air to the front
brakes and keep them cooler.

Even if you do absolutely nothing to your car, a stock SC will do
quite nicely at drivers ed.

Keith Watson
'81 911 SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 17:10:07 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Over-reving on a 1980 911SC

> Stan, if it's on the right-hand side, wouldn't it be the auxiliary air
> regulator?  

Sheesh, right, left, what's the difference? Well, when you've only had about
3 hours of sleep in the preceeding day and a half, the answer is "not much".
You are right, errr, "correct"...

> how come this aux. air unit
> rarely gets mentioned?  Do they not go bad as easily?  

Because they get overlooked? I've had them go bad with some frequency.
Ever look inside one? There's a rotating disk with hole in it. The
disk shuts off air flow from side to side, or permits airflow through
some portion of the little hole depending on where it is in the rotation
cycle. The size and shape of the hole vary wildly with the application, 
depending on the operational needs of the engine. The function is to let
unmetered air into the intake system, which raises the idle. As the engine
warms up, the hole rotates away from the passage and no air flows -- i.e.
only metered air is let into the engine. 

Failure of this gizmo causes the car not to run very well when cold. If
it sticks open, the car runs great when cold but runs lean when warm due
to the extra air bypassing the metering system.

And if you put the wrong unit on your car because you can no longer get
the right unit due to parts supercession, the car just doesn't run as
well. I know this to be a problem with Euro models... Had to do surgery
on a perfectly good aux air unit to change the hole size.

Stan
The size of the little hol

Gene,
I have installed one of the short shifters from automotion. The shift throw
is smaller, but the stick is a little shorter as well. all in all it works good.
Basically they just raise the fulcrum of the shifter with an additional plate.
Basic physics. Just another $.02.

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 18:16:00 PST
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Re: antifreeze in bugs? bugs in antifreeze?



 ----------
>From: porschephiles-request
>To: porschephiles
>Subject: Re: antifreeze in bugs? bugs in antifreeze?
>Date: Thursday, January 19, 1995 10:31AM
>
>    about disposing of drain oil - it work well as a lube for chainsaws
>- I also pour it onto my driveway (gravel) to keep it from washing
>downhill in the rain (I live on a cliff) - The Worldwide near me has a
>big drum for the excess - I don't know if you have to pay or not,
>though, my dad usually handles that (since I fix his truck...)
>    Don't know what to do with brake fluid, meself...
>
>Nate
>
WHAT!!!!  You pour it on your driveway?  Do you know what happens to that 
shit?

Where do you live that you are allowed to dump waste oil like that?  In 
California, you'd get busted for illegal dumping of hazardous waste. 
 Recycle it.

Even using oil as chainsaw lube is becoming environmentally incorrect.  I 
saw some info about the amount of saw oil dispersed in  forests by loggers 
and us home-type woodcutters. Just by the splatter.  It's enough that new 
lubricants have been developed that are environmentally/loggerly friendly.

Evaporate the brake fluid if you can't find anyone to take it.

(Stepping off soapbox)

It would be a bummer if your P-car ended up over the cliff, however.

Bob Brewer

------------------------------

Date: 19 Jan 95 21:20:25 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsche 993 brake fluid

 
Kevin Hughes writes
>It would be interesting to know what Porsche recommend for 993s
 
I'm not an owner, but the specs call for DOT 4 - 200 brake fluid. This is a
new type which has higher wet boiling point than the usual DOT 4 and is less
hygroscopic. Because of this, Porsche increased the recommended brake fluid
change interval from 2 up to 3 years.
 
Pete

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: I just bought 912E VIN#1 !!! shocks?
Author:  Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu> at internet
Date:    1/19/95 11:05 AM


Hello Porschephiliacs,  Yesterday I picked up 912E #9126000001 for $6200! I 
checked the number in the trunk and it matched the window #.  The engine is 
#P*000003, so I figured they must have kept the first two for testing.  
As I drove away from the notary's office, the previous owner stopped 
me and told me to take good care of his baby (better than he did 
anyway).  I then asked him if he knew if the car was special in any way.  
He said no, so I showed him the VIN on the title he just signed over and 
pointed to the "1"  He looked with surprise as I gave him a big grin :^) 
and drove off.  Am I mean or what?  Anyway I looked through the records 
and got the idea that NOTHING has ever been replaced in this car's 66,000 
miles!  Especially bad are the shocks, can I use 911 shocks and who makes 
the best ones for a firm ride?  I adjusted the slipping clutch and gave 
it thicker 20W50 oil.  Now it only smokes at startup and deceleration, 
and the clutch slips at 4000RPM instead of 3000.  I hope it lasts a 
little while or I'll have to sell my beloved '77 924 to pay for parts :^( . 
This car is very fun to drive and I have to thank all those on P-philes 
who gave me enogh info to give me the nerve to buy it! 
Jay Karolyi
'77 Lima Bean green 924 
'76 Alpine white with mysterious brown spots 912E (clutch slips and it 
smokes like uncle Charlie but its ALL MINE!!!!!!!!!  :^)

Subject: SF Bay Area Pre-Purchase Inspections


Several people have asked for a recommend shop that does pre-purchase 
inspections in the San Francisco Bay Area. 
 
D&M Motors in Palo Alto has done an excellent job of servicing my cars for 
several years now and I know they do pre-purchase inspections. 
 
While I have not had them do a pre-purchase inspection for me, I just happened 
to be hanging around the shop on two different occasions when they reported 
out  to the sellers and prospective buyers (a 930 and a 928).  In both cases, 
both seller and buyer seemed very satisfied with the information provided. 
 
D&M can be reached at (415) 329-9016.   
 
I suggest that you ask to have Dieter Mees (the owner) do the inspection. 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@us.oracle.com)

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 15:48:45 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Engine Removal & more

>The factory has available a 914 cradle that fits a floor jack to assist in
>engine removal. However, all one has to do is situate the floorjack under the
>engine mounting bar. This will balance the power plant for removal.

        If you're removing both engine and transmission together,
simply putting the jack under the engine bar would *not* balance
the two.  When I got my engine out yesterday, I put it up on
blocks, using the mounting bar to support the engine.  I very
definitely needed the floor jack on the transmission side to
everything in the air.
        I'm not sure about only removing the engine.  It may be
that it balances with the tranny and headers (etc.) off the en-
engine, but the bar is rather far forward.  I kinda doubt it.
        Then again, I've only done two, and George has probably
done 200+...
        Another option, instead of trying to balance on one jack,
is to use two.  That was how Josh and I did it the first time.
Coordinating two jacks is very definitely a two-person operation.

- --DD

Jay!!

Whatever you do, DON'T sell it to a collector!!  Keep it.  Fix it.  Insure the
hell out of it and drive it.  Most collectors will keep them locked away until
they can make money on it and then sell it to someone who'll keep it in their
garage, protecting it but never letting it see the pavement again.

Don't sell to ANY collector!!  They're ALL speculators and most will sell it
to the highest bidder in a New York minute.

Drive it!!  Send pictures to your friends!!!  Keep it forever!!!  It is now 
part of your family.

Congrats!!

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 15:56:22 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Bay Area 928's

        Picked up a copy of the _Diablo Dealer_ at the grocery
store yesterday.  It's one of the local (SF Bay Area) freebie
car ad papers.  Saw two or three 928s in there.  One was adver-
tised as a 928 S 32-valver with 5-sp.  No price listed, natch!
        So there are *some* out there for sale with the manual
trannies.
        One of the reasons that the automatics were so popular
was the 5-speeds on the early cars.  From reading reviews in
the car mags of the time, it seems that people were *very* un-
impressed by the shifting of the early 928.  They were all re-
commending that people buy the automatics instead.  Evidently
Porsche fixed the problem after a couple of years, because I
saw a later review which said the manual was now even better
than the slushbox.

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 14:09:58 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: Washers


Lawrence,

I had a problem getting conneced to your host. Here's the reply:

I generally do not re-use sparkplugs. Some autoparts stores or speed
shops carry them, none of the chains do as far as I know. All plugs
come with washers unless they are the tapered seat type like Ford and 
GM use.

Just use the range recommended in your owner's manual or the direct
crossover in the Bosch spec sheet if you have a 1975 or earlier 
Porsche. (They had a different numbering scheme back then).

Jim Pasha

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 14:04:18 -0700 (PDT)

Subject: handbrake-induced oversteer

Faithful readers:

	I have a question about the use of my parking brake.  It is fun to 
use it to induce oversteer (especially in snow/ice or rain).  I only do 
this in places with safe amounts of room for error.  My father said that 
this causes very serious damage to the car (a front wheel drive Jetta GLI 
16V) and that the car never runs right after these manuevers (I didn't 
tell him I did this on his car.....)  
Is his assertation true?  Does use of the parking brake cause damage to 
the car/tires or whatever?

Also, are parking brakes always attached to the rear wheels?

	Thanks,
	justin

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 17:34:30 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)

> Faithful readers:

> this in places with safe amounts of room for error.  My father said that 
> this causes very serious damage to the car (a front wheel drive Jetta GLI 
> 16V) and that the car never runs right after these manuevers (I didn't

Hi, Justin,

Never caused a problem with any car that I ever did it with...And I have
driven quite a few.

Rabbits and Jettas and Audis all respond well to this kind of treatment, but
you will accelerate the wear on the rear brake shoes (or discs), but that is
minor compared to the fun you have... :-)

The only car that I have encountered that works the parking brake on the
front wheels is the SAAB (read: weird Swedish car, made by trolls who have
never seen a german car...)

BTW, I used to go to that school (Gonzaga)... When I was there, I was called
a COG-rat...that thing still there???

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 17:33:56 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: short shifters, cats, and killer paint



The '73 and later shift tower is a big improvement over the 
earlier model. Joe Reid, our NNJR tech guru says that the
short shift kits for a 915 transmission are a waste of time
for two reasons - it's only going to shift as fast as the 
already weak synchros will allow, and the extra mechanical
effort required is a pain makes it tough to downshift into 
lower gears when the synchros inevitably get weak. 

It *does* reduce the physical distance between shifts, which 
I always thought to be out of character in a sports car.


  Reid 

(confirmed air-head as opposed to those other "water-on-the-brain types)

ps (pardon the spam): 

    with all the talk about cats and paint. It reminded me of a book 
    called "Why Cats Paint" (really!) strange and interesting. If your 
    cat uses urethane, make sure it wears a fresh-air respirator, not
    the kitty litter type.

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 14:51:32 -0800
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: brake pads/warping rotors

On Jan 19,  8:53, Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517 wrote:
> Subject: brake pads/warping rotors
> All this talk about warping rotors has got me thinking.
>
> As I have previously mentioned I'm prepping the car now for at least
> on drivers ed this spring (at Mid-Ohio).
>
> Should I consider putting on cool carbons or some other "race" brake
> pads for the event ?  If I don't, will I stand a good chance of warping
> rotors ?  A set of pads is certainly cheaper than the rotors !

My stock '81 SC has over 1,000 track miles on the same rotors.
(I have used MetalMaster pads.)  You almost certainly will boil the
brake fluid though.  When the brakes cool off you will have a very
soft pedal.  On the warmup lap always test the brakes before you
reach the first corner.  Getting the brakes warm again will firm the
pedal back up and the brakes will work fine.  Be careful on the way
home because you won't have a chance to get the brakes warmed up
before you need them in a panic stop.  Bleeding the brake fluid after
the event will get everything back to normal.

This has been my consistent experience.  It hasn't been a problem on
the race track just on the way home.  A way to reduce the severity
of the problem is to brake a couple of car lengths sooner and just a
little easier.  Some people use a brake duct called "Cool Brake"
which attaches to the front brakes.  These get more air to the front
brakes and keep them cooler.

Even if you do absolutely nothing to your car, a stock SC will do
quite nicely at drivers ed.

Keith Watson
'81 911 SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 17:10:07 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Over-reving on a 1980 911SC

> Stan, if it's on the right-hand side, wouldn't it be the auxiliary air
> regulator?  

Sheesh, right, left, what's the difference? Well, when you've only had about
3 hours of sleep in the preceeding day and a half, the answer is "not much".
You are right, errr, "correct"...

> how come this aux. air unit
> rarely gets mentioned?  Do they not go bad as easily?  

Because they get overlooked? I've had them go bad with some frequency.
Ever look inside one? There's a rotating disk with hole in it. The
disk shuts off air flow from side to side, or permits airflow through
some portion of the little hole depending on where it is in the rotation
cycle. The size and shape of the hole vary wildly with the application, 
depending on the operational needs of the engine. The function is to let
unmetered air into the intake system, which raises the idle. As the engine
warms up, the hole rotates away from the passage and no air flows -- i.e.
only metered air is let into the engine. 

Failure of this gizmo causes the car not to run very well when cold. If
it sticks open, the car runs great when cold but runs lean when warm due
to the extra air bypassing the metering system.

And if you put the wrong unit on your car because you can no longer get
the right unit due to parts supercession, the car just doesn't run as
well. I know this to be a problem with Euro models... Had to do surgery
on a perfectly good aux air unit to change the hole size.

Stan
The size of the little hol

Gene,
I have installed one of the short shifters from automotion. The shift throw

Basically they just raise the fulcrum of the shifter with an additional plate.
Basic physics. Just another $.02.

WHAT!!!!  You pour it on your driveway?  Do you know what happens to that

Where do you live that you are allowed to dump waste oil like that?  In 
California, you'd get busted for illegal dumping of hazardous waste. 
 Recycle it.

Even using oil as chainsaw lube is becoming environmentally incorrect.  I 
saw some info about the amount of saw oil dispersed in  forests by loggers 
and us home-type woodcutters. Just by the splatter.  It's enough that new 
lubricants have been developed that are environmentally/loggerly friendly.

Evaporate the brake fluid if you can't find anyone to take it.

(Stepping off soapbox)

It would be a bummer if your P-car ended up over the cliff, however.

Bob Brewer

------------------------------

Date: 19 Jan 95 21:20:25 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsche 993 brake fluid

 
Kevin Hughes writes
>It would be interesting to know what Porsche recommend for 993s
 
I'm not an owner, but the specs call for DOT 4 - 200 brake fluid. This is a
new type which has higher wet boiling point than the usual DOT 4 and is less
hygroscopic. Because of this, Porsche increased the recommended brake fluid
change interval from 2 up to 3 years.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 18:50:30 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: oil disposal

When the local auto shops stopped accepting used oil due to the
disposal costs, California required places that SELL new oil to accept
up to 5 gallons of the black stuff, no purchase required.  You might
check on this where you are.

Dumping oil on a gravel driveway is not a nice thing to do; it all
washes into some body of water eventually!

As for the other fluids (brake, coolant), my county and nearby city
governments have "disposal days" (they take motor oil and batteries
too) on a regular basis.  Ask them; if they say "No" then remind them
of the alternative...

 -mike    '80 931

	You should never, never ever use gasoline to clean parts.  
Although many good cleaners are flamible gasoline is also explosive.  
When it evaporates it creeps along the floor and can be ignited by say 
your hot water heater or furnace or even a spark.

gasoline.  I have just aquiered a '68 912 and the gas tank is half full 
of old varnish smelling gas.

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 17:59:53 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: Re:D&M Palo Alto/Dieter

I had an experience at D&M I'd like to share. I was going to sell my 912, Thank
goodness I didn't. It's a keeper. Anyway, This guy comes to my house to look at
the car, He likes it and gives me a deposit. He tells me he wants to have his
mechanic check it out. I tell him there is no problem at all. I know the car
and it's not concour but it's damn good. So I bring the car to Palo Alto from
SF in perfect running order. I meet up with the guy and he introduces me to 
Dieter. I don't know this guy so I want to see what he's gonna do to the car.
I mean I still own it. He goes balistic that I'm watching him and says that
he wont do the inspection with me watching. I get all steamed but I let him do 
what he wants. About an hour later I hear him triing to start the car. It wont
start. So I go into the garage and have a look. His associate that helped him 
with the compression check jamed the accelorator to the floor, which inturn 
left the throttle wide open. I'm glad it didn't start! (The linkage needs Adj.)
So I point out to him that the throttle is stuck wide open and it's flooded.
I unstick the throttle and he pulls the plugs and "cleans" them. Ok not a big
problem so far. He puts the plugs back in and noe the car starts, but it's 
running on three cylinders. What the *&%#$* did he do! I`m getting pissed and
the perspective buyer is losing interest. He pulls the plugs again and one of 
the electrodes is bent, he straightens it and puts it back in. Same thing, but
this time he takes the buyer for a ride. Sounds real bad and I'm getting madder.
He comes back, pulls the plug again and I notice there's no compression ring
on it. The ring is gone into the black hole of the shrouds. He has no replace-
ment plugs on hand but I do in my tool box I keep in the trunk.(just in case)
New plug everything is fine except the buyer. He wants no part of this but
since he's paying he'll wait for the report. Dieter`s report: The car is
very good, No rust..Best one he's seen in a while. Needs heater cables,
claims new trans mounts(driied out), Needs tires soon, compression is good,
etc,etc... Small stuff. 
Moral: Dieter could have done better. He blew the sale by making mistakes.
I'm glad today that it turned out like this. I'm gonna keep the car for a long 
time. It's the only one that works all the time including the new one(not a 
Porsche, too bad.) He drove the buyer away from the sale because now the
buyer thinks he's gonna visit dieter alot. Good for dieter, bad for the buyer.
Now dieter doesn't have either, a customer with a 912 or a good recommendation.
Enough drivel already.......2 more cents.
Sean

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 22:58:33 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: What carbon-fiber pad for...

Mike,
I have used Cool Carbon and Performance Friction pads extensively. Of course
this is on a track situation but I think you will find the same results in
AutoX. Performance Friction are a bit grabby when hot but otherwise
excellent. Cool Carbon are a bit easier to modulate but require more leg
pressure. Both last a long time. I also found that Performance friction
tended to warp rotors. They claim to have changed their formulas at this
point.
Bottom line is that you probably can't go too wrong no matter whose product
you use.
Hope you can tolerate the squealing on the street.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
5:14 pm

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 23:05:33 -0500 (EST)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1080 Wed Jan 18 16:15:35 CST 1995

On Wed, 18 Jan 1995 porschephiles-request@tta.com wrote:

> I have a question for the 911 experts out there.  I am just finishing up 
> and overhaul an a 77 2.7L.  My parts suppiler sent me the wrong P&C set, 
> 911.103.928.01, one catalog list these as "1973-76 Carrera, 2.7, Euro". I 
> don't have Spec book on that list this engine. The pistons have a dome 
> rather than the bubble on standard 2.7 pistons. The CR is less as the 
> same for both pistons sets.
> 
> Did it have MFI or carbs? 
> Has anyone ever run these on a CIS car?
> 
When I was Parts Manager at AutoThority, in the early '80's, these were 
the only P's & C's we would use for 2.7's. The pistons were forged, where 
all others were cast, the cylinders were Nikasil, and the compression 
ratio was identical to the "swirl top" pistons at 8.5:1. We never had any 
problems, and I used to buy two or three sets a month. It didn't hurt 
that if someone decided to build up the engine later with hotter cams, 
there was never a clearance problem, either. I would use these.

Larry Bershtein

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 23:33:41 -0500
From: PKitchak@aol.com
Subject: Re: Some 928 buying questions...

I have a "bunch" of Porsches, and a 81 928 that I drive daily during the
summer here in MN. Yes...it is more than a month long, actually April 1 to
November 15.  Has 100,000 mi + and runs well.  I think any of the used ones
are the best buy in GT cars and upkeep although not cheep is not outrageous.
 Be careful about richardson's list of expenses, much of it is "consumables"
which you would buy in any car.  And, if he is buying brake rotors, you know
he is hard on the car. At any rate, if you only have $10,000 to $15,000 to
spend on a car, you can't do better.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 23:33:50 -0500
From: PKitchak@aol.com
Subject: Re: Marking your tach & speed...

Using the redline is still the best overall advice for upshifting.
 Absolutely do not worry about downshifting.  You should not be using it to
brake the car.  Keep both hands on the steering wheel, brake hard in a straigh
t line and when the car is well slowed down, shift it down.  The good drivers
will go straight from 5th to 2d when they are real busy at the end of a fast
straight followed by a slow turn (Elkhart Lake 5 and 12, Heartland 1,
Brainard 3, Second Creek ???..no fast straights etc.) Wear out the brakes,
not the gearbox, and save the risk of an over-rev when the rev-limiter won't
help on the downshift.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 23:34:43 -0500
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1081 Thu J...

In regards to the hole in the left side of a 944, yes it is a factory alarm
activated by turning the alarm key after locking the car, however do not lose
that key as they are impossible to replace.  I had one on my '84 and it was
great except in the cold wet weather it would freeze,  there is an updated
lock assy with a stronger key available that was fitted to the later 87-88
models, before the alarm was intergrated into the door handle in '89.

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 00:29:09 -0500
From: Drive951@aol.com
Subject: Re: Factory Alarms (944)

>Does anyone know if porsches, specifically 944 turbos, came with factory
>alarms. I have additional key hole on my left rear quartwer panel, and
>someone said this was a factory installed alarm. I am so concerned about
this
>because my car was broken into, and I was considering purchasing an alarm,
>but not if it has the factory alarm. I can't check and see know because my
>car is in the shop. Thanks for any info.

The second key hole is for a factory alarm.  There is a second key, sturdy
with a smaller grip than the
 ignition key, that operates the alarm.

The alarm is armed when the key hole is in the horizontal position.  If
anyone opens either door when armed, the alarm will sound and cut the
iginition.  Thats all it does, though the ignition cutting is important.

Charlie Boyer
'86 951

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 21:50:46 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: 911 steering rack spacers ?

You wrote: 

>
>another thing I'll be doing before I'm off to drivers ed is to get a
>decent alignment.  The car has been lowered somewhat, and has a little
>bit of bump steer.  I understand there are some spacers that can help 
with
>this problem.  Before I go rushing off to buy spacers I may not need, 
or
>pay for an alignment that I'll have to do over again if I put spacers 
in,
>can anybody tell me
>
>1)  do these spacers really help, when are they really needed (ie when
>    car has been lowered X mm)
>2)  where can I look to determine whether or not I already have
>    them installed
>-----------------------------------------------------------------------
- ---------
>Martin C. Walker                                         
martinw@eapi.com
>Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 
629-2517
>Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 
721-7010
>580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 
629-2449
>
>
>

The spacers go on the bottom of the steering rack between the mouning 
points. you need to get under the car and take off the metal protection 
plate covering the steering rack. You may be able to shine a flashlight 
in the tie rod end area and see if you have what looks like washers 
under the rack. If the car is lowered at all you should have the 
spacers. They are avail from all aftermarket suppliers.

Put them in before your alignment as the toe will have to changed to 
accomodate the spacers.

			mike

- -- 
- --
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

	According so some of the posts here, coming up to a turn I should

down-shifting to slow down.  After braking, put the car in the necessary 
gear for the turn and step on the accelerator through the turn.  If this 
is the case, where does heel-toe braking come in?  According to the previous,

time.  Am I missing an important point here or is it just a matter of 
driving style?

Date: 20 Jan 95 00:58:06 EST
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: re: Some 928 buying Q's

A couple more notes on 928 development chronology:

'86 after serial number 999 have 304 mm. dia, 32 mm thickness, (i.e. HUGE)
four-piston front brakes; the "final" brake system for the car.  Somebody said
these are Brembo brakes; I don't know, they say "Porsche" all over them.

'87 and on have a simpler, stronger and less chatter-prone single disk clutch,
simpler and easier to work on intake system, and an electric cooling fan (easier
to work on front of engine).  Also, in '87 rear wheels widened by 1 inch to 8";
rear tires went from 225/50-16 to 245/45.

'89 and on have final drive ratio of 2.7 rather than 2.2 of the predecessors.  I
would much prefer the higher (numerical) ratio on my '86, but the ring and
pinion set is about $1,300.  As it is first gear is almost like second on some
other cars, and I turn about 1800 RPM @ 60 in 5th, which IMO is extreme loafing.
I'd rather turn 2200 RPM and have 22% more torque.  The common explanation is
the gas-guzzler laws, since Euro cars kept a 2.7 or so ratio all along. 

Highly recommended reading: Bruce Anderson's series in "Excellence" on buying a
used Porsche ("Porsche Price Trends").  Also, Porsche Technical Specifications,
86-89 928, for $10-$15 at many Porsche parts suppliers.  And: Euroselect parts
catalog, which from Stoddard comes with a prices list for both Euroselect and
Porsche parts.  An evening spent scanning those parts prices is a sobering
education in the reality of 928 ownership.

BTW, my local Porsche dealer just replaced my (multi-disk) clutch at 80,000 mi.
for $1,000, p&l, using Euroselect parts.

Good Hunting!

Alan Watkins ('86 928S 5 sp., black/black)
76030.40@compuserve.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 00:56:09 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: RE: I just bought 912E VIN#1 !!! shocks?


>Hello Porschephiliacs,  Yesterday I picked up 912E #9126000001 for $6200! I 
>checked the number in the trunk and it matched the window #.  The engine is 
>#P*000003, so I figured they must have kept the first two for testing.  

That's it.

>can I use 911 parts for this car...

Yes most parts are the same for 911 and 912 automobiles. The torsion bars
are a little thinner for the 912 (26mm - 27mm rear) due to lower engine
weight.

>and got the idea that NOTHING has ever been replaced in this car's 66,000 
>miles!  Especially bad are the shocks,

Actually that's not all bad. This way your sure that EVERYTHING is original,
and probably no incompetent mechanic has had his/her hands in it. The 912
is a joy to work on though, so my advice is either find the BEST mechanic
in your area to work on the car (no matter the cost) or do the work 
yourself. I nearly lost my P car to incompetent work (once resulting to a 
fire due to a loose FUEL line and another near engine loss (on the H-way) to 
a loose OIL line). Since then I'll pull the engine out myself before letting 
anyone else close!

>I hope it lasts a 
>little while or I'll have to sell my beloved '77 924 to pay for parts :^( .

Take care of her and she'll stay with you forever! Hum well we're talking
about cars here not women! But my experience tells me this is true for
both ;-)

Maintenance on my 912 has been reasonable. If you shop around you'll find
good parts for reasonable prices. My favorite parts place is an outfit in
San Luis Obispo, CA called 'German Parts and Restoration' their number is
805-549-8525.

>Jay Karolyi
>'77 Lima Bean green 924 
>'76 Alpine white with mysterious brown spots 912E (clutch slips and it 
>smokes like uncle Charlie but its ALL MINE!!!!!!!!!  :^)

Moisture will go through paint after many years. Although spots could have 
been caused by leaves sticking to the car during fall. 

First few items to buy:
        1) Fire extinguisher (halon)
        2) shocks & all wheel alignement
        3) engine rebuilt along with new clutch (demand to supervise
           work being done and keep all parts).

Good luck

Can't agree more ... (Ferdinand did'nt hang around in museums)

I spent nearly two years of enjoyable moments restoring my 912. I have
to admit that I did'nt have the money when I started taking the entire
car apart, but I had a garage and I had time. (and curiousity)

Halfway through the project it did'nt look like a car anymore. There were
parts all around the house (yes even the bedroom) (but if you're creative
then can be very decorative if your wife/girlfriend lets you!)

I gained a lot as well. I got a chance to bring it to bare metal and then
put it back together. I will forever appreciate the craftsmen that
worked on my car 25 years before I did.

The 'Project White 912' is now a weekend/nice day (almost everyday in New
Mexico) that looks brand new from 5 feet. (Yes there are many things
that I would like to re-do on the car that I would do differently etc...
but I'd do it again any day)

Warning: Every project section takes 4 times as long as you think.
Warning: You will redo every project section at least two times.
Warning: Don't have a deadline.

Just do it.

Porschephiles #1085                         Fri Jan 20 11:30:57 CST 1995
Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 14:01:39 +0100
From: Magnus Ottenstrom <magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: Do You believe in Trolls...


George Beuselinck wrote
 
>>The only car that I have encountered that works the parking brake on the
>front wheels is the SAAB (read: weird Swedish car, made by trolls who have
>>never seen a german car...)
>>
=======================
Kit wrote:

>Just you wait till you drive around for a while in a 900. You'll want to
>replace that 'weird' with wonderful and 'trolls' with 'great cousins of 
>German engineers' 

>The only metal I've enjoyed other than German is Swedish. Really!
>Besides they use 900#'s just like Porsche!
=======================

George


Being a Swede and employed by Saab (aircraft division) I just have to comment
on this.

I personally agree that it's not that good design to have the parking brake
on the front wheels. This was the design for Saab 900 up to model year 1988 (?).
Saab 9000 and newer 900's have the parking brake on the rear wheels.

Trolls? Yes of course. They just went out of their caves and produced on the
worlds safest cars out of barque. And as they had never seen a car before
(and absolutely not a german one) they, as the first manufacturer in the
world, installed a turbo on a series produced car. 

The very same trolls designed the first serial produced car (Saab 92)
with a aerodynamic body in 1947 (was first shown in Geneve in 1953).
The designer, Sixten Sason, later designed a camera which by modern
standards looks odd. It is however still produced after 46 years
and is still regarded as the best camera in the world - Hasselblad.

The aerodynamic design was introduced in other cars much much later. 

I can agree with you, George, the old 900 is a bit odd when it comes to
e.g. position of the pedals and the parking brake. Despite that, I am 
very proud to see that this small country (8 million) can produce
cars, aircrafts, trains, cameras, nuclear plants, satellites,
space equipment, intelligent missiles etc that are technically
very advanced and appreciated around the world.

Sorry for continuing this non Porsche discussion on the net but I just had to
defend the Swedish designers... 

Have a nice weekend!

Magnus Ottenstrom '82 911 SC

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 08:25:10 -0500
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Re: Factory Tours

Pat:

You can often get a "short" factory tour with a "walkin" request to the
Customer Delivery Department Lounge  that is right next to the Porsche Museum
in Works II in Zuffenhausen (follow the signs off the Autobahn).

There are restrictions at certain times of the year for vacations and model
changeovers.  The local Porsche dealer says the factory will be "closed to
the public" (not sure about the museum) during September 1995 for changeover
and initial production of the 1996 Boxster.

Better way if you're a member of PCA, is to write "Fr. Ilse Nadele, Worldwide
Porsche Clubs Coordinator, Dr. Ing. h.c. F. Porsche A.G., D-7140 Ludwigsburg,
Germany" and indicate you would be interested in a factory tour.  Since she
coordinates all of the Club visits, you may be able to link up with one of
the visiting groups and enjoy a much more in-depth visit of the facility.
 Ilse is a charming person, and you also might get lunch in the factory
dining hall ("Casino"), or better yet the executive dining/VIP area.

Perry

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 08:07:57 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: torque wrenching


There's been some discussion of lug nut and spark plug torque
settings lately.  I don't want to recharge this topic (it seemed
to get old), but I'm feeling somewhat naive ... so here goes.

I've never used a torque wrench for these two applications (Ouch!
I say as I duck for cover).  Anyway, I've always used the
"..grunt..There..That seems about right" method.  Also, the
spark plugs in my 911 are hard enough to get at with socket extension
and medium ratchet (especially the two forward ones) I can't
imagine how I might get a torque wrench in there.

The question is: Am I flirting with danger/damage?  Have I just been
lucky so far?  Or, do I already have damage and just not know it?  I'm
pretty meticulous about everything else.

As an owner of an automatic '91 928, I can tell you why we bought the 
automatic. We had a stick shift BMW 733 earlier (probably the only one 
in the country!) and it was not fun to drive. I associated the problems 
we had with the weight and decided that since the 928 was 3500 lb it 
would be better with an automatic. Voila! Looking back, I do not regret 
it, the 928 auto is very good. And I have some other cars with sticks 
(Caterham 7 and, at that time, C2, now 993).

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 10:00:29 EST
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Heel toe braking and shifting

>Dear Drivers,
>
>        All this talk of shifting points and heel toe braking has brought 
>up a question in my mind.   I haven't done any competetive driving YET, 
>but trying to learn as much as I can.
>        My question is as follows:
>
>        According so some of the posts here, coming up to a turn I should 
>keep the car in the gear it is in.  Brake only should be used, no 
>down-shifting to slow down.  After braking, put the car in the necessary 
>gear for the turn and step on the accelerator through the turn.  If this 
>is the case, where does heel-toe braking come in?  According to the previous, 
>there is no reason to have your foot on the brake and accelerator at the same 
>time.  Am I missing an important point here or is it just a matter of 
>driving style?
>
>
>
>-Brian Klinetob
>
>'83 944

After you're nearly finished braking, you reach over with your foot, while
still braking, and blip the throttle to match revs as you re-engage the
clutch. The throttle should then come on as the brake comes off. The idea
is to stay on the edge of the friction circle as you transistion from
straight line to lateral g loading. Performing the brake to throttle
transition as you enter the turn is called trail braking. if you can do
that smoothly, you're a better driver than nearly everyone on the planet.
You can practice this at slow speeds on the road. Have fun




------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 10:40:12 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: Heel toe braking and shifting

>	All this talk of shifting points and heel toe braking has brought 
>up a question in my mind.   I haven't done any competetive driving YET, 
>but trying to learn as much as I can.
>	My question is as follows:
>
>	According so some of the posts here, coming up to a turn I should 
>keep the car in the gear it is in.  Brake only should be used, no 
>down-shifting to slow down.  After braking, put the car in the necessary 
>gear for the turn and step on the accelerator through the turn.  If this 
>is the case, where does heel-toe braking come in?  According to the previous, 
>there is no reason to have your foot on the brake and accelerator at the same 
>time.  Am I missing an important point here or is it just a matter of 
>driving style?

I think there has been a misinterpretation of previous comments. For
"performance" driving, you want to perform the downshift while braking,
so that power can be applied as soon as the car is turned. Turn in 
should immediately follow the braking, so there is no time inbetween to
shift (don't worry about trail-braking, where braking and cornering
overlap, at this level of your education). The earlier discussions
related to where during the braking interval should the downshift
occurr. If you are braking at the end of a long straight, into a 2nd
gear corner, and you perform the required shift to 2nd as soon as you
start braking from a high speed, the car will still be going too fast
for 2nd gear when you let the clutch out, and you will learn a lot
about stress failures of engine parts. Instead, do the shift to 2nd
near the end of the braking interval (but still while braking), when
the car has slowed considerably, and the car's speed is suitable for 
2nd gear. The earlier discussion also related to "instrumenting"
some of this with marks on the speedometer or tach, and the
judgement (at least my judgement) was that you should just wait
until relatively near the end of the braking to shift, without
consulting any instruments.  

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 07:51:36 -0700
From: stephenk@lmc.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Re: antifreeze in bugs? bugs in antifreeze?

>Evaporate the brake fluid if you can't find anyone to take it.

How does evaporating brake fluid prove to be less environmentally obtrusive
than pouring it out?  Merely, evaporating something doesn't stop it from
existing or significantly change its chemical structure (that is, make brake
fluid less toxic), does it?

Stph

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 9:53:05 -0600 (CST)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: WSC:  Mario Andretti and Porsche at LeMans

Found this in rec.autos.sports.info:

>
>
>The January 16th issue of AUTOWEEK reports that the Porsche/TWR
>backed Le Mans car is a factory LMWSC car powered by a 3.0L turbo
>limited to 530hp.  This is the same car that will be running at Sebring
>and Daytona, but not at the other IMSA WSC venues, because of its
>turbo.  It also can't win the pole at Sebring or Daytona, because they
>are reserved for WSC cars. No mention of whether the engine is purpose
>built or an existing design.  The chassis, however, is all-new. 
>
>Results from the IMSA Daytona test Days:
>
>Ferrari 333SP   Evans, Velez, Baldi                 1:43:731
>Ferrari 333SP   Evans, Albereto, Gentilozzi, Groff  1:44:510
>Ferrari 333SP   Taylor, Moretti, Salazar, Theys     1:44:767
