Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 10:00:36 -0600
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Re: 911 steering rack spacers ?

>
>another thing I'll be doing before I'm off to drivers ed is to get a
>decent alignment.  The car has been lowered somewhat, and has a little
>bit of bump steer.

Could someone please explain what 'bump steer' is and what it feels like?
The steering on my 914 feels very tight and solid except when I have the
steering wheel turn all the way to one side or the other - like when maneuvering
in tight spaces in a parking lot.  As I roll along slowly with the wheel cranked over,
everything feels smooth, but every now and then (once per wheel revolution?)
the front end of the car suddenly jumps.  There is a very sharp jolt and then the
steering is smooth again.  It feels almost as though the front tires ran over a
broom stick, except the car wiggles from side to side, not up and down.
When this happens, I don't hear any unusual scraping noises or anything that
would indicate that my wheels are touching any part of the front suspension.
This isn't bump steer is it?  BTW, I'm using stock 165R15's with Riviera wheels.

Thanks,
Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 11:40:20 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: handbrake-induced oversteer

Handbrake turns don't really hurt the car too much.  Your father sounds 
like mine - wrong, and not inclined to consider engineering as part of 
the answer!

I used to do this alot in Vee Dubs, for kicks and for driver training 
(terrorists and all, you know).  The parts that get stressed are the 
brake cable, which may snap (and really screw you at a bad instant) and 
the tires, which skid for a moment and may flat-spot.  On rain the tire 
damage is lower, and in snow there's little if any damage and it's easy 
to do, especially in a FWD car.

Your car (or your father's) will run just perfectly fine after this 
adventure.  Note that on certain Jetta's the rear parking brake is the 
disk, not a drum as with virtually every car on the [USA] planet.

The parking brake is normally on the rear, but as others mentioned 
yesterday some Saabs have them on the front.

		JBS

- ----------

Date: Fri, Jan 20, 1995 11:58 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: first turbos

Geee, I really hate to rain on everyone's parade here, but unless I've
been takin' toooooo much of that ol' medication again (gotta watch me like
a hawk, or I'll do it every time...); *and* unless Porsche was masquerading
under the General Bullmoose label back in 1961, and Manufacturing those
Turbocharged Buicks and Oldsmobiles, General Motors was the first to
manufacture turbocharged autos.  In 1963 they *added* the Corvair Spyder
to the turbocharged series (and, I believe that's the year they dropped the
Buick and Olds - speaking of which, the Aluminum V8 motor for that lives on in 
the Rover, but without the turbo)

I mentioned this a a response to Magnus but forgot to enlighten the group as
well when I did.

Cheers,

Bart Chambers

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 11:56:06 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Downshifting, heel and toeing

Brian writes:
<All this talk of shifting points and heel toe braking has brought 
up a question in my mind.   I haven't done any competitive driving YET, but
trying to learn as much as I can.>

A little theory about race driving:
On a race track you should be doing one of two things at all times. Maximum
acceleration or maximum braking. For simplicity sake that is the rule even
though it is not always possible or practical.
So, coming down a straight you have your foot on the gas right up until the
point where the brakes have to come on. Since there is a corner coming up at
the end of each straight you must be prepared to accelerate through that
corner with maximum acceleration. Therefore you will have to be in a
different gear than that which you used down the straight.
So the question is if you are braking hard when do you get to change the gear
so that acceleration will take place when the brakes are released?
 The answer is while you are under maximum braking and that is where the heel
and toeing takes place.
So right foot hard on the brakes, the same foot blipping the throttle to
facilitate downshifting and the left foot on the clutch so that the gear can
be changed.
Don't forget to change the gear with your right hand while your left steers.
All this is happening very rapidly and precisely of course.
PLEASE, PLEASE practice this on the street before you set a tire on a track.
Have mercy on your instructor. It could be me!

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:42 am

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 11:29:57 -0600 (CST)
From: thomas pollock <tpollock@d.umn.edu>
Subject: Re: 928 vs Lotus Esprit

That vintage Lotus Esprit make very good planters - they are very 
unreliable.  Have a good friend here in Duluth that bought one new in 
1980.  Even in our cool Summers he could not drive the car in traffic for 
more than a couple of blocks without overheating.  A recall added an 
additional electric fan that provide no relief.  The build quality was 
awful - particularly the electrical system - all kinds of little bits 
failed or fell off.  It was black and gold and sure was pretty.  He 
struggled with the car until 1986 and then traded it in on a 951.

Tom Pollock
tpollock@ub.d.umn.edu
87' 951

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 09:10:48 -0600
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  Oiling Dirt Roads/Air filters - Was: Re: antifreeze in

Nate Nagel writes:
>PennDOT actually oil and chips the (dirt) road I live on on a biannual basis.

Wow!  They really use OIL??  'Round here (Minnesota) they spread a powder
(Calcium sum-thin-err-other) on the roads which mixes with the dust and absorbs
water to keep the dirt on the road.  The final result looks a heck of a lot like they
oiled the roads though.  And every year I have to scrape all this sticky
sand/gravel/dirt out of my fender wells.  It can build up a couple inches deep
in the corners.

I also cringe every time I drive my 914 over an "unoiled" section of dirt road where
the dust really gets kicked up.  The front of the car stirs the dust up and the engine
and blower sucks it in.  My engine is tan (dirt) colored.  Unfortunately, its the only
practical way I can get my Porsche from the garage to the blacktop as I live a mile
and a half down a dirt road from the nearest highway.

Does anyone know of an air filter for a 914 that provides maximum filtration while not
impeding the airflow too much?

Pete Klager

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 10:25:14 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE: Disposing of used oil


Don't pour it on the ground or let it evaporate!  There are other people
that actually want to live on this planet!

Pour all of your noxious stuff (oil, brake fluid, etc.) into sealed
containers.  Old plastic milk jugs are perfect for this.  Put the
old gasoline into your neighbors Toyota.

Call your trash company, and tell them that you have some HOUSEHOLD
hazardous material that you need to dispose of.  They'll tell you
where to take it.  If they think that it's commercial, they will
refer you to someone else.

In California, I get to drop it off at the county run recycleing plant
for free, and two months later it's back in quart bottles with "Grand-
Auto brand 10W-40" written on the side.

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

you can.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 11:13:59 -0800
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: Marking your tach & speed...

On Jan 20,  8:57, Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517 wrote:
> Subject: Re: Marking your tach & speed...
>   > Absolutely do not worry about downshifting.  You should not be using it
to
>   >brake the car.  Keep both hands on the steering wheel, brake hard in a
straigh
>
> No, but I want to be comming into the power when I floor accelerating out,
> which means I must know which gear to be in given the forward speed of
> the car.

When I do performance driving I determine gear selection based
on the tach, not on the speed of the car.  I know that the power
on my SC really kicks in around 3500rpm.  I also know that my
car doesn't accelerate any faster (power stops increasing) above
5500rpm.  So when I'm driving on the track I keep the tach in
the range of 3500 to 5500.  And since the tach is the biggest
gauge and it's right in the middle it is easy to look at.  So if
I accelerate out of a turn and the tach is below 3500 I know that
I was one gear too high for that turn.  Next time I should use
a lower gear.

If you will be driving on an established race track you should
equate a given turn with a given gear.  The easiest way to find
out what gear to use in each turn is to ask someone who has already
driven on that track (which will include people in this group).
And it oftern turns out that different types of cars (Porsches, VWs,
Acuras, etc.) will use the same gear for a given turn.  Here is an
example of what of what I mean.  Before the first time I drove on the
Seattle track I asked about braking points and gears.  This is a lap:
turn 1 treat as part of the front straight, turn 2 is 3rd gear, down
the hill is 4th gear, turn 3A and B at the bottom of the hill is 2nd
gear, the back straight is 4th gear, turns 5A, 5B, and 6 are 3rd gear,
at the top of the hill at the apex of turn 7 shift to 4th, turn 8 is
3rd gear, etc.

If you don't have someone to ask then you will have to experiment.
Don't try making the first lap or two perfect.  Try leaving the car
in a higher gear than you think might be needed and see if the engine
bogs down (drops out of the power band).  You should be familiar
enough with your car that engine sound will tell you if if is low
in the RPM band or high.  For the first laps on laps on a new track
you will just be trying to figure out where to turn and shouldn't
be trying to go fast.  On a track you get more than one chance at
each turn so use the repetitions to make small changes throughout the
day.  You will find that it is easy to figure out which gear to use
and very difficult to figure out where to steer.

Keith Watson

------------------------------

Thanks, Vol.  Oh well, I may as well 'fess up and tell the truth (if,

other kindly disposed Porschephilse, that have been eaten by my dog - no
wait, I don't *have* a dog - no wait, I've got a new Powerbook 540c with
36 MB of RAM and a 19.2 KBps internal modem, ummmm, same-same...

Actually, I've just gotten a *second* brand new PB. (god, this is too
long and boring to go into the details, but:) it keeps crashing.  Make
that, *CRASHING*!

Tuesday, I got it back (the *new* new one) from the vendor who kept it
for 8 days (thus leaving me to beg, borrow and steal time from others to
get my mail) and promised to determine why it kept crashing when it was
hooked up to our ethernet network.  While he had it, he lifted the (3rd
party ) extended RAM (which I told him was the *probable* source of the
problems) and the internal, two-piece modem (which, as I explained to
him, was also apparently involved) and drove a completely new Powerbook
under them.  And, I found out *much* later, they didn't check performance
under ethernet because they don't *have* ethernet.  Picky, picky,
picky...Strangely enough, they couldn't duplicate my problems.  Oh
well...

When I got the thing back, at noon tuesday (having been away from the
office and *totally* incommunicado, mail-wise, since Thursday thanks to
the fair Dora spraining her ankle while I was at work Thursday), I only
had 325 messages in my in-box.  So I went through as quickly as I could,
hitting the reply button for your messages, and deleting others as
quickly (and some *too* quickly) as I saw that they were not for me
directly (ooops, and some that *were*), well, you get the picture... (can
you spell *CRASH*?   Say, Bart; have you ever had this problem before?
Oh!  Well, you've got it again.)

Well, good thing I had to foresight to delete the originals as soon as I
hit the ol' "Reply" btn; 'cause otherwise, I'd have to actually reply,
instead of feeding you this puny b-ache about how the dog (er, Macintosh)
ate my homework.  Good thing, too, that the crash(es) totally wiped out
all the pending replies...

I'm awaiting a new 32 MB RAM simm, and a new modem (and another crash,
but I'm confident that I won't have to wait as long for that as for the
hardware...)

I don't know about you, but I kinda like the "escape" story better...


Cheers,

Bart Chambers

Date: 20 Jan 95 16:03:11 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Blaupunkt radio names;

Have you ever wondered what those letters and numbers after the "town name"
of a Blaupunkt radio mean? I came across a sample decoding of one name
today.
 
Example: Blaupunkt Koeln SQR 22
 
S = search
Q = quartz tuning
R = reverse (autoreverse, they mean)
2 = 20 Watt output
2 = sales begin 1982
 
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 13:06:59 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Engine Stand Advice

Someone asked whether one could use a garden variety 
engine stand on a 911.  Yup.  No sweat.

You do need to make four little adapter gizmos that 
"compensate" for the ridge machined into the 911 
case where the transmission bolts on, but that takes 
about ten minutes.  There isn't enough flat space 
there for the arms of the engine stand to rest on, 
so you have to make flat space with the adapters.  
As usual, it's one of those things that's easy to 
do, but hard to describe.  The "adapter" is 
essentially a piece of aluminum, about 1'2" thick 
and 1" in diameter, with a hole drilled through the 
middle through which the mounting bolt goes.  One 
face of the "adapter" is cut down (you can use a 
file) to accomodate the ridge.  looks like this:


		xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
		x		xx xxxxxxxxxxxxxx
		x		x	x	x
		x		x  Hole	x	x	1/2"
		x		x	x	x
		xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

				1"


Sorry,that's the best I can do.  I'm happy to 
send one to you to look at, actually faxing or 
mailing a drawing would be easier.  

Bob Spindel

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 13:45:52 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re: first production turbos

>From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
>Subject: first turbos

>Geee, I really hate to rain on everyone's parade here, but unless I've
>been takin' toooooo much of that ol' medication again (gotta watch me like
>a hawk, or I'll do it every time...); *and* unless Porsche was masquerading
>under the General Bullmoose label back in 1961, and Manufacturing those
>Turbocharged Buicks and Oldsmobiles, General Motors was the first to
>manufacture turbocharged autos.  In 1963 they *added* the Corvair Spyder
>to the turbocharged series (and, I believe that's the year they dropped the
>Buick and Olds - speaking of which, the Aluminum V8 motor for that lives on 
>in the Rover, but without the turbo)

>I mentioned this a a response to Magnus but forgot to enlighten the group as
>well when I did.

>Cheers,

>Bart Chambers
>Frau, Dora
>'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
>'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
>'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

     Bart is right (didn't you own that Spyder, Bart ?) but the material I 
 have says that the Olds turbocharged Jetfire (215 ci/215hp from a
 turbocharged, alcohol and water injected aluminum V8) and the Corvair turbo
 were both introduced in '62, and might share the trophy for being first. I 
 used to get a wrinkle when I read the self-congratulatory ads by Porsche
 claiming the first production turbo, when the Corvair shipped more turbos
 their first year than Porsche probably shipped their first 5 or 10...

     About 8k of the Olds were built, the turbo model was abandoned in '64 in
 favor of more naturally-aspirted cubic inches.  I only know about this since
 another Pfiler noted me previously, and I've never seen one of the Olds (yes,
 this -was- your fathers Oldsmobile !).

       Lee A, yes we still have a radically customized '66 Corvair Monza
              in the outback...

      PS. Does anybody know when the Corvair turbo was killed ? Did it
         last til '69 ?

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 13:30:09 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Rack Spacers

On the subject of Rack Spacers, Martin wrote:

> 1)  do these spacers really help, when are they really needed (ie when
>     car has been lowered X mm)
> 2)  where can I look to determine whether or not I already have
>     them installed

Rack spacers *definitely* change the handling, and minimizing your bump
steer is one of the more satisfying (IMO) things you can do in the
handling department.  Disclaimer: even at stock height my 'SC has bump
steer.  I presume Porsche put it there for a reason; I suspect it may be
a passive safety feature (?? reduces steering input when road dips ??
something like that anyway).  So adjust at your own peril, and take it
easy until you're familiar with what's going on.  Read Puhn's book for a
the theory.

Anyway what you want is for the tie rods to be parallel to the control
arms (A-arms) at your static ride height.  This eliminates (in theory)
steering input caused by suspension movement.  Crawl under you car and take
a look, you'll see the various parts, and this will make sense.  The
factory (I'm told) gets things parallel by moving the steering knuckle
(outboard end of tie rod) up and down on the strut, so that is probably
The Right Way to do it.  Since it involves strut removal and a hydraulic
press (at least), most of us don't bother with this method (though you
can buy struts set up how you like).

The Shade Tree method is to move the *inboard* end of the tie rod, by
moving the the steering rack up and down.  Of course the steering wheel
linkage doesn't necessarily like this, and there isn't a large amount of
room (adjustment range) available, and the rack mounting may be weaker
afterward... what's that?  the *Automashin* catalog doesn't mention these
features?  guess they needed the space to sell "Porsche Nut" paperweights!
Notwithstanding those drawbacks, you *can* adjust bump steer this way,
and since even I have lasted 100k miles since doing mine, I guess
Porsche put a big enough F of S in the steering gear to survive this
sort of modification.

The rack height is adjusted by putting spacers between the rack and the
aluminum subframe that it's bolted to.  The spacers are little donuts
that go over the two 17mm subframe bolts.  To really zero out the bump
steer you need a *range* of adjustment, though the one-size-fits-all kit
sold by Automashin is a good place to start.  I added fender washers to
the stack as well until I got the right geometry, and then had a
machinist make up aluminum bushings of the correct length.  You also
MUST install bolts that are longer by the length of your spacer, to have
any hope of keeping the mounting strength equal.  Use the same kind of
bolt you took out, too... on my car I believe they were 8.8 type.  After
you raise the rack you have to go up in the trunk and loosen the
u-joints in the steering shaft and spin the wheel a few times to allow
the various connections to "adjust" to the new rack location.  Make sure
the steering is free at all points while the car's still up in the air,
you don't want to find out about an interference while you're on your
test drive.  On my car the limit of rack adjustment is set not by rack
travel but by where the steering shaft starts clunking against something
in its tunnel.

So give it a try; like I said you will notice a big change in the way
the car handles and responds to bumps.  For testing find a repeatable
bump in a curve to drive over at a (large) repeatable speed; I found a 
spot on the freeway I drive daily with a gentle undulation, just enough
to move the car up and down on the suspension.  When I started (after
lowering my car) this "whoop" would provoke about a two foot wiggle in
the car's path (at 75 mph); after a few weeks of messing around...
nothing (from the front wheels, anyway).   Feels great! 

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org


 

i.e. it reduces steering input when the car
goes over a "whoop" (pulls negative Gs) or some such.  Anyway, adjust at
your peril

> The spacers go on the bottom of the steering rack between the mouning 
> points. you need to get under the car and take off the metal protection 
> plate covering the steering rack. You may be able to shine a flashlight 
> in the tie rod end area and see if you have what looks like washers 
> under the rack. If the car is lowered at all you should have the 
> spacers. They are avail from all aftermarket suppliers.
> 
> Put them in before your alignment as the toe will have to changed to 
> accomodate the spacers.
> 
> 			mike

> Date: 20 Jan 95 00:58:06 EST
> From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
> Subject: re: Some 928 buying Q's
> 
> A couple more notes on 928 development chronology:
> 
> '86 after serial number 999 have 304 mm. dia, 32 mm thickness, (i.e. HUGE)
> four-piston front brakes; the "final" brake system for the car.  Somebody said
> these are Brembo brakes; I don't know, they say "Porsche" all over them.
> 
> '87 and on have a simpler, stronger and less chatter-prone single disk clutch,
> simpler and easier to work on intake system, and an electric cooling fan (easier
> to work on front of engine).  Also, in '87 rear wheels widened by 1 inch to 8";
> rear tires went from 225/50-16 to 245/45.
> 
> '89 and on have final drive ratio of 2.7 rather than 2.2 of the predecessors.  I
> would much prefer the higher (numerical) ratio on my '86, but the ring and
> pinion set is about $1,300.  As it is first gear is almost like second on some
> other cars, and I turn about 1800 RPM @ 60 in 5th, which IMO is extreme loafing.
> I'd rather turn 2200 RPM and have 22% more torque.  The common explanation is
> the gas-guzzler laws, since Euro cars kept a 2.7 or so ratio all along. 
> 
> Highly recommended reading: Bruce Anderson's series in "Excellence" on buying a
> used Porsche ("Porsche Price Trends").  Also, Porsche Technical Specifications,
> 86-89 928, for $10-$15 at many Porsche parts suppliers.  And: Euroselect parts
> catalog, which from Stoddard comes with a prices list for both Euroselect and
> Porsche parts.  An evening spent scanning those parts prices is a sobering
> education in the reality of 928 ownership.
> 
> BTW, my local Porsche dealer just replaced my (multi-disk) clutch at 80,000 mi.
> for $1,000, p&l, using Euroselect parts.
> 
> Good Hunting!
> 
> Alan Watkins ('86 928S 5 sp., black/black)
> 76030.40@compuserve.com
> 
>

> Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 00:56:09 -0700

> Subject: RE: I just bought 912E VIN#1 !!! shocks?

> >Hello Porschephiliacs,  Yesterday I picked up 912E #9126000001 for $6200! I

> >can I use 911 parts for this car...
> 
> Yes most parts are the same for 911 and 912 automobiles. The torsion bars
> are a little thinner for the 912 (26mm - 27mm rear) due to lower engine
> weight.
> 
> >and got the idea that NOTHING has ever been replaced in this car's 66,000 
> >miles!  Especially bad are the shocks,
> 
> Actually that's not all bad. This way your sure that EVERYTHING is original,
> and probably no incompetent mechanic has had his/her hands in it. The 912
> is a joy to work on though, so my advice is either find the BEST mechanic
> in your area to work on the car (no matter the cost) or do the work 
> yourself. I nearly lost my P car to incompetent work (once resulting to a 
> fire due to a loose FUEL line and another near engine loss (on the H-way) to 
> a loose OIL line). Since then I'll pull the engine out myself before letting 
> anyone else close!
> 
> >I hope it lasts a 
> >little while or I'll have to sell my beloved '77 924 to pay for parts :^( .
> 
> Take care of her and she'll stay with you forever! Hum well we're talking
> about cars here not women! But my experience tells me this is true for
> both ;-)
> 
> Maintenance on my 912 has been reasonable. If you shop around you'll find
> good parts for reasonable prices. My favorite parts place is an outfit in
> San Luis Obispo, CA called 'German Parts and Restoration' their number is
> 805-549-8525.
> 
> >Jay Karolyi
> >'77 Lima Bean green 924 
> >'76 Alpine white with mysterious brown spots 912E (clutch slips and it 
> >smokes like uncle Charlie but its ALL MINE!!!!!!!!!  :^)
> 
> Moisture will go through paint after many years. Although spots could have 
> been caused by leaves sticking to the car during fall. 
>

>         1) Fire extinguisher (halon)

>            work being done and keep all parts).

> Good luck

Porschephiles #1087                         Fri Jan 20 18:44:50 CST 1995
Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 13:44:58 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: Driving School

WHartje writes: (what a weird name!)

>>The question is  what are the opinions of you racers out there on the various
>driving schools. I live close to and am familiar with Bondurant's impressive
>facility in Arizona but I also have heard that Jim Russell's is a better
>school for open wheel racing, and you can get your SCCA licence more easily
>with one of their combined courses.
 
I took the Jim Russell school Techniques of Racing  course last year and had
an absolute blast!!  They use Van Dieman FF vintage '75 for their cars (I drove
number 4) and are set-up quite nicely.  I could go on and on about the
experience, but suffice it to say that once you go to a formula car, sedans
and sports cars are just second best.  The course lasted for 3 days and I took
it with the mechanics who work on the cars.  Of course, some of the cars had
the obligatory Demon Tweak, but most were very even.  The course was at Laguna
Seca, a most interesting ride.

Anyway, I'd highly recommend the Techniques course to anybody interested in cars
or in going fast.

And the instructers were great.

later,
bill

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 14:09:22 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: fluids disposal

Stephen Keller wrote:
> How does evaporating brake fluid prove to be less environmentally obtrusive
> than pouring it out?  Merely, evaporating something doesn't stop it from
> existing or significantly change its chemical structure (that is, make brake
> fluid less toxic), does it?

and Martin C. Walker wrote:
> when you evaporate it it doesn't just disappear you know.  it just ends
> up in the soil the next time it rains.
 
Pouring the stuff on the ground creates a plume of contaminated soil
(plus likely runoff) that may well reach a freshwater body in or on
the ground.  If you leave the same stuff to evaporate, (1) some of it
will be chemically degraded before it precipitates out at all; and (2)
the eventual surface concentration on the ground will be so miniscule
that biodegradation will take place far sooner than pollution by
leaching.

Remember, to, that ethylene glycol antifreeze is both toxic and
sweet-tasting.  Keep it away from young'uns and animals alike.

RECYCLE your spent stuff and avoid the issue!  If you can't, evaporate
it.  I guarantee that you can find something better with which to oil
the street.  (What the road crew uses is 90-bazillion weight oil that
does not leach anywhere... and they bind it in a gravel "composite".)

 -mike

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 18:17:29 -0400
From: cbt@eduplus.ca
Subject: Tires

>     Date: 19 Jan 95 09:52:00 +0000
From: swellen@intgp1.att.com
Subject: Tyres

>    Thanks to Lee of Washington for the information on tyres from the Auto
>Motor und Sport magazine. As for the performance of the Yokos I have the
>following observations.
>    I replaced P600s in 215/60 ZR15 size with A-008Ps and found them a large
>improvement especially in terms of grip. The only disadvantage was a very high
>wear rate, about 8000 miles for the rears for instance and I'm not a hard
>driver. The Yokos were a much newer tyre design than the P600s. My current 944
>has 205/55 and 225/50 ZR16 combination with Dunlop D40 Mk2s. These were the
>bees knees in England 3 years ago, now Dunlop make the SP8000s and only still
>sell the D40 Mk2s for customers who want cheap(ish) tyres.
>    All this points to what the tyre companys have being saying. They claim
>tyre design used to be some science and a lot of art, these days it's mainly
>science with some art. It does seem tyre's are improving at an unprecedented
>rate and the A-008Ps are mearly suffering from being an "old" design.
>    I don't think this matters to most of us, I drive around on obsolete
>Dunlops and I think the resulting handling is brilliant. However I must admit
>that my next set of tyres will be the best I can get regardless of cost. So
>finally as I am looking forward to buying a new set of tyres fairly soon has
>anyone had experience of Continentals AquaContact?
- ------------------
I was driving a '86 944 w/ the same exact tire for 3 years. I was very
happy with the D40 M2's. Have tires improved enough to warrant switching to
others.(assuming they don't cost more than say 20% more.)

How on earth can you determine the best for your application when you can't
try them ?

I have just sold the '86 and relaced it with a '88 944 Turbo S. It came
with Pireli P-Zero's but the rear two are worn out completely. I know you
should stay with  the same type all around but I don't think I can afford
P-Zero's. I've also heard that they are overpriced for their performance.
Any thoughts on what I should do ?

Stephen Davies

'88 944 Turbo S

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 14:21:40 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: 928 Purchase Thread

Gary writes:

>1] why are they so inexpensive to buy [Boston Globe ads for 84-86s in the
>$8k-$15k range?
>2] why do so few Porsche technicians (Bruce Anderson and Mark @ 928 Intl
>notwithstanding] recommend them? I've talked to over a dozen myself and they
>just roll their eyes and mumble, "Too complex, unreliable, fall apart, scary
>electricals..." Is this a case of unfamiliarity breeding contempt?

Those are real good questions with hard answers; it depends on the owner.  I
like mine (I used to love it but the cost of parts is pissing me off) but the
facts are the cars (all model years; maybe not the post '87 stuff, though) have
problems that are expensive to fix.  For example:

#1. Since '78 and up to '86, Porsche has changed the clutch set-up (different
pressure plates, friction surfaces, amounts of pressure plates and friction
surfaces, throw-out bearings) 5 times!!  They KNOW it had a problem and they
tried to fix it FIVE times by redesigning it!!

#2. Since '78 and up to '86 they had 3 different types of fuel injection
systems.  '78 and '79 had CIS, '80 to '82 had AFC, '83 had DME (?).  It has 
changed completely every few years making parts hard to come by.

#3. Spark plug wires cost $185 !!!!!!!!!!  And the plug wires for the S4 cars
with twin distributers are about $240

If you can't work on it yourself, you'd better have plenty of cash.  Maybe the 
owners would rather have a new, reliable, warranteed Hyundai.

later,
bill


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 14:25:50 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: brake fluid fires

Peter Diffey wrote:
> A high proportion of engine fires on modern cars are brake fluid induced,

Are you for real?  Where do you get that?

I have seen a lot of car fires; not one that appeared to be primarily
fed by brake fluid.  Yes, it's flammable, but it just doesn't leak out
fast enough to fuel much of anything.  And it has nowhere *near* the
volatility of gasoline, ie it won't flash back to the source.

Glycol brake fluid IS a strong reducing agent.  You should keep it
well away from oxidizers like pool chlorine and nitric acid (8-0
...and car paint.

 -mike

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 23:36:33 +0000
From: Jean-Christophe Pret <jcp@miris4>
Subject: Re: WSC: Mario Andretti and Porsche at LeMans


According to the January 18th issue of AUTOhebdo (a french motor racing
magazine), the so called Porsche WSC 95 is powered by a 962 twin turbo 3.0l
engine (type 935/85) limited to 540 hp (by an air restrictor probably) to
comply
with the IMSA/Le Mans regulations. The article also mentions a 956 gearbox.

The chassis is derived from the TWR-designed Jaguar XJR 14, which took part
in the 1991/92 IMSA series and in the 1991 world endurance championship. The
similarity between the two cars is obvious on the picture that accompanies the
article.

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 16:24:02 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; 928 resale value


>RE: 928 Purchase Thread

>Perhaps someone can reduce my ignorance: If 928's are okay cars to own,
> 1] why are they so inexpensive to buy [Boston Globe ads for 84-86s in the
>  $8k-$15k range?
> 2] why do so few Porsche technicians (Bruce Anderson and Mark @ 928 Intl
>  notwithstanding] recommend them? I've talked to over a dozen myself and  
>  they just roll their eyes and mumble, "Too complex, unreliable, fall
>  apart, scary electricals..." Is this a case of unfamiliarity breeding
>  contempt?

>Gary Pighetti

    You've got me ! Why would any Porsche technician slam a 928 but not a
 a 944 ? What supposedly is different about their makeup ?

   The reason the crater in price is probably the same reason Cadillac
 Allantes crater--fantastic cars, but there are lots of other fantastic
 cars in the same "luxury sports" league (Mercedes, BMWs, Vettes, etc) so
 that class of cars is maybe less distinguished than the 911 in terms of
 looks, ride, and owner loyalty.

    Geez, you can get 290 hp, 32-valve sound, excellent brakes and true
 comfort for $15k in a 928. You can find 16 valve cars all day long in
 Houston for under $10k. Either will take you past 200k miles if you look 
 after them, cruise comfortably at 100mph, and pull thru corners like its
 bored with you. Its the one Porsche where you can be a truly average driver
 and still get around quickly (Wrong gear ? Wrong line ? Change your mind
 on those brakes ? No prob !). Its the only car I've ever driven in where
 speed only showed up on the speedometer, but not in the feel on the road.

    When the 928 came out, it was toted as -the- supercar. I'm sure there
  are lots of other great cars too, but I don't know how anybody could
  keep from being impressed by a 928.

            Lee A. gave mine up after 9 years for something crude...

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 14:46:57 -0800
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: Marking your tach & speed...

On Jan 20, 16:19, Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517 wrote:
> Subject: Re: Marking your tach & speed...

> Well I agree, but my point was 3,500 in what gear.  If I want to accelerate
> strongly from 30mph it means 2nd, but if it's 60pm its probably 3rd.

This may be one of those questions which we can't answer exactly for
you.

>   >I accelerate out of a turn and the tach is below 3500 I know that
>   >I was one gear too high for that turn.  Next time I should use
>   >a lower gear.
>
> I thought the goal was to change your gear during the braking so you
> could immediately apply power throughout the turn.

Yes, I just didn't say that clearly but I also didn't contradict that.
I simple way of thinking about it is - brake in a straight line, do the
downshift at the end of the braking zone, if you have judged things
right the turn starts immediately when the brakes are released.  From
the start of the turn until you near the apex your left foot is on the
gas pedal keeping the car at a constant speed, then close to the apex
of the turn your foot starts going to the floor.  By "accelerate out of
a turn" I was refering to the region from the apex of the turn until
the turn is finished or where ever you start pushing the gas pedal down.

>   >If you will be driving on an established race track you should
>   >equate a given turn with a given gear.  The easiest way to find
>   >out what gear to use in each turn is to ask someone who has already
>
> Will absolutely do that !  Anybody here done Mid-Ohio ?

Someone please help him out!  (Now that I've said you would :-)

Keith Watson

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 18:04:18 -0500 (EST)
From: Ujjal Bansel <ujj@server.chem.ufl.edu>
Subject: Oil Cooler leak on 944



Hello,

I took my '85 944 (early model) to my mechanic to have the timing belts 
retensioned (1000mi after timing belt change). He noticed that there was 
an oil leak from the oil cooler. I knew about the leak for a while now, 
but lately the leak has turned into a gush. I know that there are oil 
cooler seal kits available. How hard would it be to fix the oil cooler 
seals. I have the HAYNES manual which has the procedure for the removal and 
installation of the oil cooler. Has anyone ever done such a job? What 
kind of tricks should I be aware of. I am pretty sure that removal of 
some of the exhaust is necessary. How should I avoid breaking some of the 
nuts and bolts of the exhaust system. I appreciate any help.

Ujjal Bansel

'85 944 (164274 mi and still running)

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 15:11:22 -0800
From: Carlos Sham <sham@cpuserver.acsc.com>
Subject: Re: re; 928 resale value 


I am a current owner of a '84 928S Euro. This car is just amazing.
As many people would expect this car's electric system may go
wild anytime, something falling apart, this and that loosen up.
But I'm experiencing none of such thing. All electric systems work
fine. Never failed to start. Feeling as solid as it looks. (except
the sunroof inner lining is loosen and makes some rattling noise.)
Just recently on a trip from LA to Bay Area, the car hitted 150mph.
I even use the car on everyday basis. With the traffic in LA, the
car still never over-heat (thanks to water cool!) Only difference in
traffic is shifting in and out of gear gets harder. (Maybe I just 
feel limp being trap in the traffic :P) Anybody can explain that.

Here, I would like to ask a few questions:

1) My car is a Euro, with 5 speed. I don't see many 5 speed on the
   street, and Euro is just as rare. I wonder how many other Euro
   928 is on the street. Can some of Euro's owner raise their voice,
   or Someone have any figure?

2) The Euro's are much stronger, with 221kW (300hp) power. Why they
   didn't give the same spec to the US version?

3) Can someone put a newer picture of 928 in the picture archive!?
   That one is fading!!

Happy Driving.

Carlos
sham@acsc.com

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 18:16:19 -0500 (EST)
From: Async User <tpep@epix.net>
Subject: Re: torque wrenching



On Fri, 20 Jan 1995, Wayne Michelsen wrote:

> 
> There's been some discussion of lug nut and spark plug torque
> settings lately.  I don't want to recharge this topic (it seemed
> to get old), but I'm feeling somewhat naive ... so here goes.
> 
> I've never used a torque wrench for these two applications (Ouch!
> I say as I duck for cover).  Anyway, I've always used the
> "..grunt..There..That seems about right" method.  Also, the
> spark plugs in my 911 are hard enough to get at with socket extension
> and medium ratchet (especially the two forward ones) I can't
> imagine how I might get a torque wrench in there.
> 
> The question is: Am I flirting with danger/damage?  Have I just been
> lucky so far?  Or, do I already have damage and just not know it?  I'm
> pretty meticulous about everything else.
> 
	If you don't use a torque wrench on your wheel lugs you run a 
very good risk of warping your rotors.  And on the spark plugs you run 
the risk of stripping the threads, real easy on aluminum heads.  At best 
it will weaken the threads.
			TP

Mike,
	I'm sure my recycle man has passed my name along to the local
AA counselor.  I was into some home winemaking a while back and
started collecting used wine bottles to use for my home brew.
Friends and relatives would save their bottles for me and in a short
period of time I had 10 to 12 cases of empties.  Well, over time, I
lost interest (and the wine wasn't that good) so I decided to rid
myself of the bottles.  Every week I would fill the glass recycle 
container with about 8 to 10 bottles.  It took months to get rid of
all those.  I wonder what the neighbors thought?

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 15:21:29 -0800
From: Carlos Sham <sham@cpuserver.acsc.com>
Subject: Recommended Mechanics (LA)


This is possibly an FAQ. But any recommended mechanics in the
LA basin area. Or any good or bad experience with any of them?

I do simple work by myself, but three months back I had to change
the timing-belts, water-pumps, tensioner...etc so I looked around.
Most independent guarge just gave me verbal estimate. No write-ups.
I ran around a few days and finally decided to bring it back to 
the dealer. Yes, the dealer. Two reasons, (1) they have better
charging scheme, and service. (2) they warranty their work for
two years. I paid an arm and a leg for the work. But I'm satisfied.
The dealer I went to is on Santa Monica Boulevard in Santa Monica
called Steve something. 

Eager to hear more from all of you.

Carlos
sham@acsc.com

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 12:26:52 -0500
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: Brake pads..

>I need to try some high-friction (carbon based?) pads on my
>'72 911S. They will be primarily for autocross, but maybe
>a track event or two.

Mike,
I can second Jerry's recommendation of carbon-kevlar based pads.
I've been using Cool Carbon (blue compound) pads in my 951 for both track and 
autocross.  Different cars so you probably need a different compound due to 
weight diff.  I think green is for racecars (read higher coeff of friction) 
and red is for lighter cars?  Check this out with a dealer.

Pros: they stop *now*, I've had no problems with fade, boiling fluid, warped 
rotors etc despite repeated hard braking from ~130 to 60; they warm up quickly
for autox use, they're easy on rotors and they're long-lasting.  
Cons: they squeak like the devil for street use and the (carbon?) dust builds 
up quickly making it difficult to keep wheels clean; they're damned expensive 
($250/set).  
Due to the cons, I put back the regular pads at the beginning of the winter 
saving them for the track season. I can definitely feel the difference in 
stopping power.  You can brake much later with the CC pads.

The break-in procedure is to find a deserted road and brake firmly to a 
complete stop from successively higher speeds without locking up until they're
'bedded' in.  New rotors are not needed.  

Steve J.
'87 951
Looking for *rust-free* (is there such a thing?) '73/'74 914 2.0 for track

------------------------------

Date: 12 Jan 1995 14:44:00 -0800
From: Soren LaForce <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- scca/pca "stock class"

                       Subject:                               Time:1:49 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          re: scca/pca "stock class"             Date:1/12/95

Byron writes:

>Hi phellow P-philers!
>
>I read with interest the criticisms of SCCA's rules policy for Solo. 
>There's a major misconception among PCA members about SCCA Stock, which
>is that SCCA Stock allowances should parallel PCA Stock.  Well, they
>don't! 

Maybe so, but it's nothing compared to *your* misunderstanding of "pca
stock" class.

I think you missed the point.  The complaint is that non-performance 
mods move you to street prepared when they deliver no performance 
above a stock car.

>SCCA Stock is, pretty much, stock!  As in, "as delivered".  PCA Stock
>allows a neat and thoughtful combination of upgrades in motor,
>suspension, and other parts that enthusiasts like to change.  This is not

First, PCA doesn't allow or disallow anything, ZONES set their own rules.
There may be national rules at Parade (don't know, never been) but for 
the garden variety auto-x that people drive their cars in more than once
a year, it's zone by zone.

For example:

Second, zone 7 stock it just that: Stock.  Pretty much the only changes 
allowed are non-performance changes that will protect engine/car 
life.

You are thinking of either the improved or production classes (again
zone 7).

>
>Don't damn SCCA for allowing two distinctly different versions of
>streetable Porsches to compete!  SCCA Stock provides a place for those of
>us who really haven't done anything to our Porsche a place to play and be
>very competitive!  I know.  I won a the SCCA D Stock National
>Championship in 1993 driving a Porsche 914 1.7.  The car was "as
>delivered" except: muffler, air filter, shocks, front sway bar, a truly
>wild alignment, and tires.  My new 944 S2 will be a national caliber B
>Stocker with only air filter, alignment and tires!  Would these cars
>equipped this way be competitive in the Porsche Parade?  Not terribly. 

Again, scca was being damned for not allowing non-performance mods.

The only mod you list that might be acceptable under zone 7 stock is the
shock replacement (depends on the shock).  Disallowed items:  muffler (if
not functionally equivalent to stock), airfilter, sway bars, allignment, 
tires (with treadwear less than 120).

You have done *much more* to improve the performance of your car than 
any zone 7 stock car.

This is not really the issue.

Zone 7 mods in stock class that scca would not (if I understand
correctly) allow are:  oil system (e.g. deep sump, oil coolers, accu-sump)
enhancments, and chain tensioners upgrades.  

Admittedly, allowing the engine to run cooler is an advantage *because it 
means you will finish more events*, but is that really bad?  Or really an
"advantage?"  No.

The chain tensioner mod has no performance advantage what-so-ever, and 
shoud be done to *all* pre '84 cars (excpet the two years where you can't).

Yet these would move the car out of stock...

>
>In SCCA you have a choice of streetable preperation levels.  Why should
that be considered a "Communist Act"?  :-)

Got to agree with you on this one!

Thunder Hill is *private property*.  ;-)

>Lastly, the reference to the SCCA's SEB (Solo Events Board) as "Porsche
>haters, Lotus lovers" amused me greatly.  You see, I'm a member of this
>eight person board, and in this capacity I read every week how we are out
>to get MR2's, Corvettes, RX7's, Honda's, BMW's, Mustang's, and yes even
>Loti and Porsches!  If we were out to get everyone who thought we were
>out to get 'em you could only be safe driving Studebakers and Hudsons!  

You've got my sympathy on this one.  That the kind of board where you know
that if *anyone* is happy, you've screwed up.

>For the record, in the last 22 years SCCA Solo National Championships have
>been claimed by Stock category marques as follows: Porsche 42; Lotus 9;
>Studebaker & Hudson 0.  It's not time to trade in that 911 on a
>Hawk or a Hornet just yet! :-) 

The above is basically irrelevent to the issue at hand:  Why are
non-performance
mods not allowed?  To all cars?  So Porsches still win.  They just win at more

risk to the engine than necessary.  

911 engine rebuilds are in the neighborhood of $10,000.  Chain tensioner 
replacement is about $600 for original or $800 for pressure fed ($200 and 
$400 for the parts).  No one in their right mind would put original tensioners

in a pre-'84 car.  Yet unless they do, they have to drive in street prepared 
where they are *not* competitive w/o more money.

While I understand the dificulties of arranging the classes so that all
marques
can compete, this one escapes me.  I challange you:  What's the reason if not
stupidity or "dislike?"   My vote is on stupidity.  Not you personally Byron,
but 
the normal performance of any committee/bureaucracy that has become 
sedentary and mired in its waste.


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 16:47:30 PST
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: More on D&M Motors


Sean: 
 
Regarding your message appended below . . .  
 
Clearly your experience was unfortunate.  For what it's worth, I've had my 
cars serviced by D&M for years and the service has always been excellent. 
 
This is not to say that the service has always been perfect . . . they have 
made a few minor mistakes over the years but they've always been quick to own 
up to the errors and make them right no questions asked.   
 
In addition, my experience has been that the time they spend on various jobs 
and the associated prices are reasonable. 
 
I've also referred a fair number fellow German car owners to D&M (Porsche and 
VW) and never had anything but positive feedback. 
 
I certainly have no intention of defending what was clearly a situation that 
should have been handled better, but I would hate to see a local, independent 
shop that generally does very high quality work damned for a single 
unfortunate incident. 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@us.oracle.com) 
1962 356B Super90 Cabriolet

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 17:59:53 PST 
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman) 
Subject: Re:D&M Palo Alto/Dieter 
 
I had an experience at D&M I'd like to share. I was going to sell my 912, Thank 
goodness I didn't. It's a keeper. Anyway, This guy comes to my house to look at 
the car, He likes it and gives me a deposit. He tells me he wants to have his 
mechanic check it out. I tell him there is no problem at all. I know the car 
and it's not concour but it's damn good. So I bring the car to Palo Alto from 
SF in perfect running order. I meet up with the guy and he introduces me to  
Dieter. I don't know this guy so I want to see what he's gonna do to the car. 
I mean I still own it. He goes balistic that I'm watching him and says that 
he wont do the inspection with me watching. I get all steamed but I let him do  
what he wants. About an hour later I hear him triing to start the car. It wont 
start. So I go into the garage and have a look. His associate that helped him  
with the compression check jamed the accelorator to the floor, which inturn  
left the throttle wide open. I'm glad it didn't start! (The linkage needs Adj.) 
So I point out to him that the throttle is stuck wide open and it's flooded. 
I unstick the throttle and he pulls the plugs and "cleans" them. Ok not a big 
problem so far. He puts the plugs back in and noe the car starts, but it's  
running on three cylinders. What the *&%#$* did he do! I`m getting pissed and 
the perspective buyer is losing interest. He pulls the plugs again and one of  
the electrodes is bent, he straightens it and puts it back in. Same thing, but 
this time he takes the buyer for a ride. Sounds real bad and I'm getting 
madder. 
He comes back, pulls the plug again and I notice there's no compression ring 
on it. The ring is gone into the black hole of the shrouds. He has no replace- 
ment plugs on hand but I do in my tool box I keep in the trunk.(just in case) 
New plug everything is fine except the buyer. He wants no part of this but 
since he's paying he'll wait for the report. Dieter`s report: The car is 
very good, No rust..Best one he's seen in a while. Needs heater cables, 
claims new trans mounts(driied out), Needs tires soon, compression is good, 
etc,etc... Small stuff.  
Moral: Dieter could have done better. He blew the sale by making mistakes. 
I'm glad today that it turned out like this. I'm gonna keep the car for a long  
time. It's the only one that works all the time including the new one(not a  
Porsche, too bad.) He drove the buyer away from the sale because now the 
buyer thinks he's gonna visit dieter alot. Good for dieter, bad for the buyer. 
Now dieter doesn't have either, a customer with a 912 or a good recommendation. 
Enough drivel already.......2 more cents. 
Sean

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 16:57:21 -0800
From: "John Milton" <porsche@hpcvusm.cv.hp.com>
Subject: 928 update

About a week ago I put out a request for ideas on diagnosing my
non-starting 928.  I got a couple of good responses and checked
a few things out last weekend:

    Fuel pump
         Is it running?
    	    I listened back by the right rear wheel while my wife
            tried to start it.  It sounded to me like the pump was
            running.

    	 Check the fuse.
    	    The fuse was OK.

    	 Check the relay.
    	    I could hear/feel the relay click when I tried to start
            the car.  (I also heard/felt the ignition relay click.)

    Spark
    	I pulled a plug wire, put in a spare plug, grounded it to the
        head and had my wife try to start the car.  Yeah I was getting
        a spark (at least on the right side of the motor).

    Battery
    	(I checked this because my mechanic said that sometimes
        if the battery got a little low the car wouldn't start,
        even if it would crank over.)

        Well, a couple of the cells were low on water so I topped
    	them off and recharged the battery.

At this point the car still wouldn't start and I was out of ideas.
(I was also beginning to worry about my checkbook since I felt I had
checked out all of the cheap easy things.)  It was time to bring in
the professionals; I had the car trucked to my mechanic for him to
look at.  He went through his diagnosis and discovered that I had very
low compression.  He squirted some oil in to the cylinders, pulled
the fuel pump fuse cranked it a few times, replaced the fuse, cranked
some more and it finally started.  As he explained to me, the engine had
flooded, washing the oil from the cylinders in the process which caused
the lack of compression and hence the no-start problem.  After he got
the car running again he noticed that the cold-idle was lower (< 1000
rpm) than he would expect (~1200 rpm) but claims that the only way
to adjust this is to replace the DME computer ($$$) so its probably
not worth replacing just to up the cold-idle.  He does think that
the cold-idle may be related to the no-start problem though.

Here is the sequence of events that led to the problem:

    1) back 928 out of garage and park it (the car ran for about
       30 seconds, the outside temperature was ~35F)

    2) spend 3 hrs cleaning the garage

    3) start 928 (its running like sh*t)

    4) turn off ignition

    5) try to start 928, no luck
       I tried a few more times with no luck (my special incantations
       didn't help either).

       I know I pressed the gas pedal a few times which would
       contribute to the flooding but I don't know if flooding
       caused it to run so poorly to begin with or if that was
       a different problem and I just made things worse.

    6) push 928 into garage

My mechanic hypothesizes that since the car didn't warm up during
the short time it was running that perhaps the DME computer got
'confused' when I tried to restart it later, flooding the engine.
He suggested that if I had simply driven the car around the block
before parking it that I may have avoided the problem entirely.
I have a EE/CS background and know computers well enough to know
that they can do strange things, but this hypothesis sounds like
a bit of a reach.  Anybody out there have any better ideas?  (Now
there's a loaded question.)

John Milton
porsche@cv.hp.com
`86 928S WeissGold

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 17:18:44 -0800
From: "John Milton" <porsche@hpcvusm.cv.hp.com>
Subject: Porsche maintenance

Howdy,

My '86 928 needs some simple maintenance so I'm here looking for advice.
(The car just turned over 60K miles and I've had it for about 6 months.)

    0) Manuals
       Where do I find some usable/affordable shop manuals (or is that
       an oxymoron)?

    1) Battery Box
       In the process of checking the battery (see my previous post) I
       found that it has leaked sometime in the past and had started
       to attack the battery box so I cleaned the battery box with a
       brush, water, and baking soda.  What are my options for further
       cleaning (if necessary) and repainting the battery box?  (I'll
       need a paint that I can brush on in order to fully cover the
       battery box.)

    2) Brake pads.
       My brakes make too much noise and the rear pads are getting to
       the point that they need to be replaced.  I'm looking for some
       good pads for everyday use.  I used Repco Metalmasters on my
       previous Scirocco so I was considering using them on the 928
       (barring any better recommendations from this group).

    3) Brake fluid.
       It sounds like the general consensus of this group is Castrol
       LMA GT.

    4) Oil
       Any compelling reason to switch to something (non-synthetic)
       other than Castrol 10W-40?

Thanks in advance.

John 'porsche is a 2 syllable word' Milton
porsche@cv.hp.com

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 95 21:48:00 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Turbos

Bart is essentially right in his analysis of Corvair.  The swing
axle was like the Porsche of the same period.  The 1965 design was
the same suspension used by Lotus in F1 when the Corvair was
introduced.  The 180 hp 2.4 liter 6 was really nice.  Nader lied
and did immoral demos on TV (no air in the tires).  GM wimped.

On the other hand, didn't Studebaker introduce turbo models before
then went under?  I think that was before Corvair.  Anyone got a
good history book out there?

Saab, revolutionary as it was at introduction, was a copy of the
DKW that was one of the few cars to survive reliably thru WW II.
They did not pioneer the three-cylinder two-stroke driving the
front wheels, but copied what was running when the war ended.

Rick

------------------------------

Date: 20 Jan 95 22:03:31 EST
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: Some 928 buying questions...

Pkitchak@aol.com writes:

"Be careful about richardson's list of expenses... if he is buying brake rotors,
you know he is hard on the car." 

I beg to differ; the 86-1/2 and later cars, at least, are well known for going
through brake rotors quickly.  Mine were well under the minimum thickness spec
at 50K, and now at 80K the replacements are showing visible wear.  And I know
the previous owner (first 50K) didn't use it hard.  To paraphrase somebody
else's 928 quip, "fill er up, check the oil, and change the rotors..."

Fortunately the rotors aren't too expensive and are an easy DIY job.

BTW, I don't think it was Richardson with the list of parts; it was Richardson
who asked the initial question.  And the only list of parts or repairs I can
find in this thread was from Bill Van Bibber and didn't mention rotors, it
mentioned pads.

One of the greatest disservices we 928 owners can do to a prospective owner is
mislead him about how expensive the cars are to maintain.  Or at least to
*properly* maintain.  I found Bill Van Bibber's list quite unrepresentative of
my 30,000 mi. experience with my '86.  He didn't even mention timing belts,
water pumps, or clutches!

He also qualified it with "if you don't have much mechanical aptitude or desire,
you'd better have a lot of cash for the repairs."  I couldn't agree more.  In
fact, I would recommend a strong dose of both aptitude AND desire.  The cars are
very complex, very tightly packaged, and they have a LOT of 4-digit-priced
parts.  Caveat Emptor.

Alan Watkins ('86 928S)


------------------------------

Date: 20 Jan 95 22:03:38 EST
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: re: 928 Purchase Thread

GARY A. PIGHETTI asks a couple really good questions: 

>>>why are they so inexpensive to buy
I think in large part it's the ridiculous parts and labor bills you can rack up
just solving some apparently simple problem.  It's really easy, for example (and
I am not making this up) to go in with a slight driveability problem and drive
out leaving $1,000 behind because the mechanic had to take the whole induction
system apart to replace some hoses, junctions and a sensor or two.

>>>why do so few Porsche technicians recommend them?...they
just roll their eyes and mumble, "Too complex, unreliable, fall apart, scary
electricals..."

That's because they ARE really complex and they HAVE scary electricals.  Mine
hasn't been unreliable or fallen apart, but on the other hand, what other car
needs THREE washer fluid pumps, 24 relays and 45 fuses?

Then of course there's the "image" problem, but I'll let the air-cooled guys
talk about that...

Alan Watkins ('96 928S)


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 14:56:26 -0800
From: richardson@newton.apple.com (Peter Richardson)
Subject: 928 search update:  Thanks for _all_ the help

Wow!  My questions generated an awful lot of responses.  Thanks to everyone
who spoke up.  The 928 FAQ (in progress) was very useful, and contained
lots of info I hadn't seen before.  At the end of this message I've
summarized the answers to my questions, but first... two 928 buying
stories...


I asked you all for a recommendation for a pre-purchase inspection place,
and had a number of people recommend Tony Heyer at Heyer Performance in
Mountain View.  (one friend of mine heard I was looking for a repair shop
and recommended "Joe's Foreign Car Repair", and when I asked if they
specialized in Porsches, she said "It says 'foreign' in the name!")  I
chose Heyer  :-).
I got a good recommendation for CarreraTech in Campbell too, but Heyer was
closer to the car.

I was looking at a Red '86 928S (70K miles, "must see. All books and
records. overserviced, etc.") that had had some body changes to make it
more like an S4 (and a wierd ground effects package that I was hoping could
be removed).  I had the dealer drive it to Heyer and went there a few hours
later to see how the inspection was coming.

Tony was great.  He asked if I had noticed that all the S4 bodywork was
fiberglass (I hadn't... I told you I'm a newbie) and would shatter at low
impact speeds, requiring expensive replacements (as opposed to the factory
bumpers which are metal and rubber).  While that in itself was enough for
me  (If I wanted a plastic car, I'd drive a Corvette!), he also gave me his
opinions on some other anomolies he'd noticed... the quality of the paint
job/bodywork, a receipt for a new clutch and a receipt for valve job which
both seemed a little early given the mileage of the car, etc...

He had a stock '81 928 in the shop at the same time and he took the time to
show me the differences (between the '81 and the '86 models, and between
the condition of 'my' car and the one he had there.)  Then he answered some
"from a mechanics point of view" questions I had, and charged me an
extremely reasonable fee (since he really didn't get very far inside the
engine before I showed up).  It was a very positive, educational
experience.

In any case, I decided not to buy that particular car, so I'm still in
search of a (preferably black) 928, 5spd in good shape.


Dave Darling mentioned a black '86 928 5spd in the "Diablo Dealer".  Thanks
Dave.  I noticed that one and called about it on a Saturday (a day or two
after their "Grand Opening").  The first three phone calls were answered by
someone who told me nobody was around who could answer my simple questions
(How much?  How many miles?).  Keep in mind that this car was supposed to
be at a car dealer!  Not a great way to run a business, IMHO.  Anyway, the
fourth call revealed that it had 80K miles, and they were asking =8919,600.
Also, it was a "must see, overserviced, etc."  (I'm beginning to doubt
claims from used car dealers.;-))

The next day I drove about 40 minutes to see it and... it wasn't there!
Arrgh! The salesman told me that the owner (his cousin) had taken it for a
trip up to Marin county, and wouldn't be back soon.  He also "revealed"
that his cousin (22 yrs old) didn't really want to sell it, but that his
father thought it was too dangerous, which makes me wonder if he's driving
like a maniac.  We were chatting for a while and he said "The car's in
great shape.  He loves it, it's his baby." So I asked to see the books and
records, and found out he doesn't have any...   When I added up all the
evidence, this car seemed a little risky even though I haven't seen it in
person (and I was pissed about it not being there), so I'm still looking.


The next stop for me is the "Porsche Market Letter" which should be in my
mailbox today.  I also found a web site
(http://www.sjmercury.com/searchcl.html) that lets me search the San Jose
Mercury News classifieds for 928's.


- ------
Here is the condensed version of the answers to my questions... I'm
collating this from a large number of messages, but any misquotes are
entirely my fault.

>1) Where are all the used S4's?
There just aren't a lot around, because Porsche doesn't sell as many.

>2) If there are that few S4's, are the differences between the S and S4
>worth >the time it takes to find one?
Some said yes.  Some said no.  It depends on what you want and what you can
afford.  With an S4 you get more HP, new body, new (improved) single-disc
clutch, but higher prices.

>3) I noticed that not many of the vocal porschephiles seem to own late
>model >928's.  Is there something you know that I should know?
Again, there just aren't as many out there.  One person suggested that
owners of very late model Porsches aren't as "into" the Porsche scene
(perhaps because they don't have to spend so much time fixing them) as
owners of older models, and so they just aren't as vocal.  (this was not a
"late-model owner" flame.  They phrased it much better than I did...)

>4) Why are there so many automatic 928's?
Because it's supposed to be a luxury car, not a little speedster.

>5) Is it worth the extra money to find a 928 with very low mileage (< 30K)?
In general, no.  They last a long time.  Don't rush out and buy a car with
200K miles on it, but don't worry too much about 10 or 20K here or there.

>6) ... what kind of paint job should I get that's worthy of a Porsche?
(also, "Should I repaint the car?")
The general consensus was it's very difficult to paint a 928 well, so
expect to pay a lot (=89$4000) for a good job, but it can be done, and it
will lower the resale value.


Again, thanks for all the advice.  Further updates as events warrant... :-)

- -- Pete

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 20:02:01 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: Some 928 buying questions...

Alan writes:

>One of the greatest disservices we 928 owners can do to a prospective owner is
>mislead him about how expensive the cars are to maintain.  Or at least to
>*properly* maintain.  I found Bill Van Bibber's list quite unrepresentative of
>my 30,000 mi. experience with my '86.  He didn't even mention timing belts,
>water pumps, or clutches!

I should have said that this is the work that I've already done to it, not that
has been done to it.

Actually, the water pump had already been replaced on my car and I figured while
I was in there I'd replace the timing belt ($30.00) and fix the oil leaks (the
complete gasket kit cost $260.00) .  But look at the little $18.00 dollar part;
the pilot shaft bearing.  That required taking out the twin clutch pack and
twin pressure plate system (HEAVY) to replace it.  I figure that job woulda cost
about $1000.  And the ignition key; cheap parts but UNBELIEVABLE disassembly
of the vehicle.  Easily another $1000.  The clutches seemed to be in great
shape so maybe that, too, had been replaced.
Funny, the rotors seem fine.  Opps!!  I've jinxed (sp?) myself!!!

The moral is "If you WANT to play in the Big Leagues, you got to pay"

I WANT to play!!

later,
bill


------------------------------

Date: 21 Jan 95 00:09:33 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: First turbo cars

 
Porsche wasn't first. Neither was Saab. Try Corvair and Oldsmobile in the
early 1960s. The 1962 Olds F-85 Jetfire had a claimed 215 hp from the
turbocharged aluminum V8, and needed water/alcohol injection to live. It
lasted only through 1964. The turbocharged Corvair Monza Spyder came out in
mid-62 with 150 hp. Later this engine was optional on the Corsa, through the
1966 model year. These things didn't have wastegates so they relied on
compressor sizing to choke the flow. They also tended to do their best
imitation of hand grenades. Porsche's breaktrough was the wastegate,
developed for the Can Am 917.
 
The 911 Turbo came as a 1975 model, late in 1974. Through the end of 1977,
Porsche built 2888 Turbos. Through the end of 1993, total production reached
26658. Not all that limited, really. (Limited by our ability to buy them, I
guess).
 
Magnus Ottenstrom writes
>We were, however, first to have an ejection seat in a fighter aircraft
 
First ejection seat was the Dornier Do-335, not the Saab J21, but both had
it for the same reason -- to clear the rear propeller. A few Dorniers reached
Luftwaffe units before the Saab reached the Swedish Flygvapnet, but for the
Dornier, peace broke out before it could reach combat.
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 00:56:25 -0500
From: Hultgrenho@aol.com
Subject: 9201 tool

Sorry this is a little late, your 9201 tool question was earlier in the week.
 If I'm lucky, I review the digest once a week for 944 stuff -- usually don't
say much -- many more on the list with far more experience than I.
Previous responder (Dan) is correct, 1987 944S has the built-in timing belt
tensioner that sets belt tension -- tool is unnecessary.
Balance belt tension can be set by just allowing 180 degree rotation of the
belt at operating tension  (this is close to prescribed tension -- I have
checked this with the tool).
HTH
Lon Hultgren
Ocean Blue 944S, still with little white speckles up front!

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 01:56:18 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Subject: 911 short shift mods

Gene Hertel asked :

>I need to modify/upgrade the shift mechanism in my '72 911T.  The local
Porsche
>shop recommends a later model shift tower.  What is the conventional wisdom
on
>that versus the aftermarket "short shift" kits.  I do not race or autocross.

Then Reid Zeigler said :

>The '73 and later shift tower is a big improvement over the 
>earlier model. Joe Reid, our NNJR tech guru says that the
>short shift kits for a 915 transmission are a waste of time
>for two reasons - it's only going to shift as fast as the 
>already weak synchros will allow, and the extra mechanical
>effort required is a pain makes it tough to downshift into 
>lower gears when the synchros inevitably get weak. 

>It *does* reduce the physical distance between shifts, which 
>I always thought to be out of character in a sports car.

I think the factory short shifter helps a lot on a 915. But the
later shift tower would be nice too. I used the factory short shifter
on an '86 and the difference was HUGE, much easier shifting, and less
grinding into second gear. I don't know why but it did the trick. I wish
I could put one on my '72 but not SCCA Stock legal in a '72 (what is?).

Mike Piera '72 911S Targa  AnalogMike@aol.com

Porschephiles #1089                         Sat Jan 21 23:30:59 CST 1995
Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 13:54:17 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: brake fluid fires

On Fri, 20 Jan 1995, Mike Weihman wrote:

> Are you for real?  Where do you get that?
> 
> I have seen a lot of car fires; not one that appeared to be primarily
> fed by brake fluid.  Yes, it's flammable, but it just doesn't leak out
> fast enough to fuel much of anything.  And it has nowhere *near* the
> volatility of gasoline, ie it won't flash back to the source.
> 
Yes I am serious, this information is based on uk  investigation of a 
number of fires.

As stated this information was based on a report - the report could be wrong.


There is evidence in many of the fires that brake fluid either from the 
res, or a fractured pipe was sprayed on to the hot exhaust, only a wall 
fire results, but this fire in turn causes combustion of plastics, and 
eventually fuel lines - then  the small fire gets serious.

You are quite right, the silicon fluid itself is not the major fire 
feeder, but is often to ignitor.

As an aside, some years ago I had a Bultaco MX bike. I had a tank slapper 
that fractured the GRP tank, a gallon on fuel dowsed the engine and 
exhaust, I was still astride the bike and enveloped in a cloud of hot vapour

I have never understood why it didn't burn... Phew

Pete

| From   : Peter Diffey         |

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 09:33:22 -0500
From: PKitchak@aol.com
Subject: Re: Marking your tach & speed...

You write:

From: martinw@eapi.com

No, but I want to be comming into the power when I floor accelerating out,
which means I must know which gear to be in given the forward speed of the
car."

Here are my thoughts: 

You get that from driving the track or the course. For example:  I know that
Elkhart turn 1 is 3d gear, turn 5 is 2d, turn 6 is 3d gear and the "kink" is
bite you lip and go for it fourth.  Soo..If I have time to downshift and
everyting goes well, I do the heel and toe thing, particularly if I am going
down just one gear.   But, just as often, more often actually, I am very
busy. Going into 5 and I go straight to 2d, turn the car and get full on the
gas. 

We have also found that in very high performance engines, the wear on the rod
bearings (the weakest link) seems to be high reving downshifting.  So, we
avoid using the engine as a brake.. Brake pads a much cheaper than engines
and the brakes are much more controllable, provided you have a bias dial.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 09:37:46 -0500
From: PKitchak@aol.com
Subject: Re: handbrake-induced oversteer

Just a note on this subject that may be interesting to some:
The factory sets up the (911 at least)  rally cars to plan on using the
handbrake.  I have a 70 Monte Carlo 911S (#0002) (3 made) and an 84 954
(Rothman's SCRS) (20 made - 12 race cars) and both came set up for emergency
brake steering. What they do is disconnect the button on the handle so that
the brake will not lock when you pull on it.  The button is actually
"reversed" so you have to push on the button at the top of the "pull" to set
the brake.  We used to use this technique rallying the 911s while we were on
dirt, and we used it less frequently on very tight turns while ice racing to
induce the rear out before we got back on the power.  Obviously it doesn't
work very well to try to be on the power and on the emergency brake at the
same time. So long as the emergency brake is on the rears it will probably
work well, but I am doubtful (but don't have any actual experience) that it
would do much but induce a lot of understeer if it were connected to the
front wheels.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 10:21:08 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Heel toe braking and shifting

Reagrding comments about braking/downshifting :

For a novice like myself, I've learned that this amazingly-
difficult-to-do-smoothly-when-a-million-other-things-
are-going-on braking/downshifting is not totally necessary.
Someone told me (and I believed him) that the amount of time
saved by performing perfect heel-toe braking/donwshifting
is not a big deal when compared to just getting yourself in the right gear
going into the corner.  FWIW, I brake as hard as I can in a straight line,
then ease up, down shift, and turn in to the
corner.  Not real pretty, but it works, and especially for first-
timers on a track, I'd recommend it - you'll have enough things
on your mind.  One guy at one of our driver's ed events last
summer almost put his car into a wall by doing what I thought
was alot of unnecessary shifting (he tried to shift from 2nd
to 3rd right in the middle of the last turn coming out on to the
front straight - it didn't work).

BTW, I say we keep up these "driving" related threads - that's
what pcars are all about anyway.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

------------------------------

Date: 21 Jan 95 10:49:06 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Tires

 
Stephen Davies writes
>How on earth can you determine the best for your application when you can't
>try them?
 
You can't. Tires are like religion. You just pick one that sounds good and
hope it does what it claims. If you really, truly BELIEVE that you have the
best tires for your car, you will remain steadfast in that belief,
dismissing all false prophets, and will actually FEEL how much better your
tires perform. (English translation: it's all in the mind of the consumer
anyway). Tire ads help to reaffirm this faith even long after the sale.
 
Me, I worship at the Unified Church of Bridgestone and Yokohama (reformed).
 
Car magazines can't test them objectively either, no more than John Cleese
and Co. can do a Consumer's Guide to Religion (consensus: Church of
Englandism is best because divorce is easier than in Roman Catholicism, as
easy as under Communism in fact; you need less crockery than in Judaism, and
have less invested in running shoes and trips to Mecca than in Mohammedanism).
In the U.S. at least, most car magazines choose tires at least in part based
on ad buying by same tire makers. (Sorry if that bursts anybody's bubble).
 
Pete
 
 


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 11:15:25 -0500
From: PKitchak@aol.com
Subject: Re: Results of downshifting t...

A final thought.  Although the driving schools spend a lot of time on this
and there has been a lot of discussion...And, in fact I do it. All of we P
people have syncros instead of the old trannys without them or the square cut
gears in the race transmissions. My real opinion is that we all like to
pretend that it is necessary, but it really ain't EXCEPT to make sure that
you don't get the rear of the car sideways by not having the motor (hence the
rear wheels) running fast when you let out the clutch. If you brake harder at
the rear than the front the car IS GOING TO GO SIDEWAYS. 

Any of you real racers disagree?

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 12:06:16 -0500
From: Tedd914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Engine stand advice

Drew 

     It shouldn't be a problem to convert a good substantial 'merican iron
eng stand to serve your purpose. A reputable(?) welding shop should be to go
a couple of routes. 
      1 - cut off the existing attachments at the top of the stand you buy
and weld on, say a 3/8" plate w/ holes to match the yolk, in the cut off
head's place.  (You can do all of this BTW, if you're reasonably sure of your
welding abilities.) Depending on the stand itself, you may want to add a
'gusset on the engine side of the upright.
     2 - If you can't find a decent 'merican' stand, your welding shop  (or
you) can throw a stand together relatively easy using something like 2"x3"x
1/4" wall rect. tubing. This can be a little better and a little more $.  If
you build it 'yourself', you can go heavier tube, wider-longer for more
stability, to your height (taller pr lower) etc. Again, a good shop can help
in several ways.
    I built 3 or 4 for a shop I was involved with in CO a few years ago and
they're still in use to my knowledge. 

Good luck
Tedd914  (6)
'70 914-6 Adriatic blue
'70 911T   (?)   white
'84 944 Platinum (wif's car)
