Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 14:19:51 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: First Turbos (Superchargers)

It appears from this discussion that history is a function of the
participants' birthdates.  I won't venture a guess as to when the *FIRST*
turbo/superchargers went into series production, but the
Auburn-Cord-Duesenberg folks were producing them in Auburn, Indiana, long
before General Motors (or Porsche, Saab, et al) had their brilliant idea.
 Incidentally, the A-C-D Museum is highly recommended for any lover of fine
automobiles.  It is in the original factory and showroom  building, and the
cars are arrayed as if for sale.  The Art Deco architecture is also
outstanding.  In addition to the A-C-Ds, there is an eclectic collection of
other cars and motorcycles (including a 356B and several of Gordon Buehrig's
fine designs).  In my opinion, it's one of the finest automotive museums in
the world, displaying some of the finest automobiles in the world.  Well
worth a detour.
Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper    

------------------------------

Date: 21 Jan 95 16:03:55 EST
From: Byron Short <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: SCCA vs PCA revisited

Soren LaForce writes...

>Maybe so, but it's nothing compared to *your* misunderstanding of "pca
>stock" class.

No arguement there--my exposure is only to local (Alpine Mountain Region
and Rocky Mountain Region) PCA events.  Heck, I only recently became
aware that the local zones/regions run their programs with their own
rulesets!  I'm also beginning to think our local PCA regions are among
the most permissive anywhere!

Soren covers the general problem as follows:
>I think you missed the point.  The complaint is that non-performance 
>mods move you to street prepared when they deliver no performance 
>above a stock car.

Once it was argued that aftermarket spoilers add no performance advantage
since at solo speeds the effect is well below meaningful.  So the
addition of aftermarket spoilers was legal (all of this took place in
SCCA Street Prepared, BTW.)  A Corvette driver read the rule and decided
(correctly I might add) that he was every bit as valid an aftermarket
spoiler builder as any company out there.  Only his spoiler would be so
huge (and incredibly ugly) that it would provide significant downforce. 
The result: a four-foot high spoiler with side fences!  By September at
the National Championships, every car in the class sported 3-4 feet of
spoiler, and all the competitors, including those who had built these
monstronsities, were pleading for a more restrictive ruling.  What
started out as "non-performance mods" had become a "must" for national
contention, and the lobby for more restrictive spoiler rules was
satisfied.

Soren covers the specific problem (chain tensioners) this way:
>I challange you:  What's the reason if not stupidity or "dislike?"   My
>vote is on stupidity.  Not you personally Byron, but the normal
>performance of any committee/bureaucracy that has become 
>sedentary and mired in its waste.
 
Currently SCCA allows factory directives or recalls in the stock class. 
This means that if the factory felt that something was bad enough as to
warrant a "fix" then that "fix" is legal.  FI, the 914 fuel lines.  The
chain tensioners are something that I'd love to see legal for stock; if
PCNA issued a factory directive requiring better tensioners then we'd
have something.  Barring that, SCCA is in no position to override PCNA's
opinion about what their cars need to live.  You may choose to say that
makes SCCA "stupid", but in fact, our position is, and will remain, that
we'll follow the factory's lead.  

If you would like a stock 911 to have better tensioners doesn't it make
more sense to ask PCNA for them?  They engineered the car, not SCCA.  The
definition of SCCA's stock is based on PCNA's definition as shown by
deliveries when new and factory recalls/directives after delivery.  
Geez, PCNA has a stake in how the cars perform for millions upon millions
of collective miles.  If PCNA is satisfied their cars meet their
reliability requirements who is SCCA to "correct" them?  

Other examples of track-specific problems:  AWD Eagle Talons eat clutches
like popcorn.  Early Ford turbos tend to coke the bearings and destroy
the turbo.  BMW 3-cars have a poor rollover record.  Camaro LSD's burn
out in less than a season.  Neon's snap front spindles.  Miata's overheat
in race traffic.  SCCA is not in the business of intervening when a
street car has design limitations on the track/autocross course/on your
way to work.  While it might be argued (tongue in cheek) that even SCCA
could design a car better than Chrysler, surely you don't think the SEB
makes better engineers than Porsche!?!  :-)

>Second, zone 7 stock it just that: Stock.  Pretty much the only changes
>allowed are non-performance changes that will protect engine/car 
>life.

Neat!  I wasn't aware of this!  Maybe this has something to do with why I
receive some flame-mail that says "SCCA is too restrictive in stock" and
some that says "SCCA is too permissive in stock".  

Where is Zone 7?  How different are all the zones?  *Is* there any
National ruleset?  Where can I get National/Regional/Zone PCA rules?

Thanks, Soren, and everyone, for the info and counterpoint!

Byron

87 944 Turbo
90 944 S2

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 16:47:31 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: 914 wheel bearings

Excerpts from mail: 21-Jan-95 914 wheel bearings by TommyWmson@aol.com 
> OK, here's a stupid one.
> I think my front wheel bearings may need replaceing.  Seems to have waaay to
> much play when pushing on the tops of the wheels (back and forth). It makes
> a little knocking noise.  So, do I need to replace just the outer bearing, or
> the
> inner bearing too??? Or is it something else????
> What special tools will I need for the job? Bearing pullers? Bearing press?
> 
> Tommy - tommywmson@aol.com
> Jackson, Mississippi 
> 
> '73 914 2.0

    If it IS the bearings (check and make sure it's not a bad ball joint
or strut) they're easy to replace.  Once you get the rotor off, if one
of the bearings is bad, it will be perfectly obvious.  There's a special
tool to remove/install the bearing races (they're pressed into the cast
iron rotors) but I've found if you can keep the races from cocking in
their mounting areas you can just use a hammer and screwdriver if you're
careful.  (keep hitting one side, then the other.. and when it's seated,
give a few taps every 45 degrees around the race to make sure it's
seated well.)  In fact, the bearings on my 914 are easier to do this to
than the ones on my dad's Chevy.
    Here's my little question for you p-philes... I just took apart the
front end on my 914 and found that I'm going to have to play a little
mix 'n' match with my bearings (I had a complete good set, they just
were not all on the same rotors...) so I took everything apart and
cleaned out all the old grease while I was at it.  What kind of grease
should I use to repack them?  My dad had some ~20 yr. old Quaker State
bearing grease that he bought when his truck was new - but I feel kinda
iffy about using this since my p-car's bearings are so much smaller. 
What do you guys use?

later,

Nate

------------------------------

Date: Sat, Jan 21, 1995 5:18 PM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Turbos

Hi Rick,

> Bart is essentially right in his analysis of Corvair.  The swing
> axle was like the Porsche of the same period.  The 1965 design was
> the same suspension used by Lotus in F1 when the Corvair was
> introduced.  The 180 hp 2.4 liter 6 was really nice.  Nader lied
> and did immoral demos on TV (no air in the tires).  GM wimped.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 15:39:13 -0800
From: milodorr@netcom.com (Milo R. Dorr)
Subject: Re: 944 altitude switch

On 1/20/95, Kirk writes (with refreshing brevity :-)):

>Does my '88 944 have one?

Yes (at least if it's a U.S. car).

>Where is it?  

Near the DME in the passenger footwell (a cylindrically shaped metal
thing with a couple of wires coming out of it).

>How test?

A properly functioning switch is open at less than about 3300 feet,
and closed at higher altitudes.  To make sure the DME is doing the
right thing with the info provided by the switch, you need an exhaust
gas analyzer.  With the engine idling, disconnect the oxygen sensor
and measure the CO at the pre-cat test pipe.  Disconnect the altitude
sensor and bridge the cable conductors (simulating > 3300 feet of
altitude).  The CO reading should lean out a bit.

>Why DME need this input?

Unlike the LH-Jetronic "hot wire" system, the flapper-box air flow
meters on our Motronic-equipped cars measure air volume, not air mass.
At higher altitudes, a specific volume of air contains less oxygen for
combustion than the same volume at sea level.  To keep the mixture
from becoming too rich, the DME needs to be told to shorten the
injection pulses a bit at high altitude.

 -Milo
'86 951

Subject: Re: Paxton "Altitude Compensator" for Porsche ?

Kit Christopher Jungmannn wrote:
>>From: Stan Hanks
>>You *COULD* try to find a Paxton "altitude compensator" -- a smallish
>>belt drive centrifugal supercharger that only gives about 0.5 bar boost...
>Can anyone provide me with some additional information on this device ?
>Where is the Paxton factory located (if they are still in business), etc...

Sounds like a pretty radical solution to me.

German Auto of Knoxville (615)-691-1911 puts them in 911's. <- not a
recommendation, just for your information. I don't know anything about them.

Two people have put Paxtons in their cars in our PCA region that I know of.
I don't know where they got it done, or how much boost they were using. One
was a 944. I saw the car in May with the motor, and I saw the car in July
with a different (non-supercharged) motor <grin>. The other car was an early
C4. That car's motor lasted three seasons, I think. In both cases, the
failure mode, as expected, was traceable to the pressurized intake.

Given the type of mods the factory does to 951 motor's, for example,
"bolt-on" power from super/turbo-charging is not what I'd recommend to
anyone... if the car is going to see lower altitudes, I'd be very careful...


Craig.

Date: Sat, 21 Jan 1995 19:09:28 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 wheel bearings

>     Here's my little question for you p-philes... I just took apart the
> front end on my 914 and found that I'm going to have to play a little
> mix 'n' match with my bearings (I had a complete good set, they just
> were not all on the same rotors...) 

Don't mix and match races and bearings on used bearings. You won't like
the results. New bearings are *CHEAP* compared to getting to do it again
in a thousand miles or so...

> What do you guys use?

Street cars use Valvoline heavy duty grease; race cars use Amsoil synthetic.

Stan

I've been using RedLine (the oil people) synthetic CV joint / wheel bearing
grease for some several years and I have yet to replace a bearing that I
packed with it.  It comes in a grease-gun tube, and, imagine that, it's
red!

Porschephiles #1091                         Mon Jan 23 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 05:34:31 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Heel & Toe soapbox

Hi Mike,
I agree with most of your post and yes you shouldn't be trying the somewhat
"busy" heel and toe technique on a high speed, oh shit I've got to turn now
situation, unless you are comfortable with the technique.
The reason for doing it during street driving is so that the technique
becomes second nature and you won't trip over yourself when it really counts.
Also there is a lot less wear and tear on your equipment if you do the H & T
on a regular basis on the street. I've gotten to the point where I can
synchronize the engine speed precisely enough that I really don't need the
clutch. Off course the car has to be out of gear when doing the "blip" for
the subsequent shift. I certainly do not recommend this as a regular practice
but to illustrate the point.
Seriously after 3 or 4 events and no H & T you are going to find yourself,
one day, with a less than tolerant instructor. He may even have a sensitive
stomach and the lack of smoothness associated by the braking, release the brak
e, then downshift, then accelerate method will be more than he/she feels he
should be subjected to.
Instructing is tough and in many cases hazardous, not to mention thankless in
many cases so a student that practices off track is really appreciated
I feel that the track event doesn't end with the last run group. You should
take your skills to the street. On the other hand there is no reason you
can't practice proper techniques and smoothness on the street before the
event.
I am sure you  are a fine driver, we just want to get you to be a little
better.
Please take my criticism and realize that the intent is at all times friendly
and aimed at increasing the joy of your Porsche experience.
Off the soapbox.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
5:27 am

From: owner-porschephiles@tta.com

	(Linux Smail3.1.28.1 #1)  
	id m0rW2mx-0000a0C; Sun, 22 Jan 95 08:57 EST
Message-Id: <m0rW2mx-0000a0C@inasec.ca>
Date: Sun, 22 Jan 95 08:57 EST
X-Sender: cseko@198.53.239.2
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: porschephiles@tta.com
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: Re: Heel & Toe soapbox

Jerry wrote:
>Hi Mike,
>I agree with most of your post and yes you shouldn't be trying the somewhat

and, fwiw, I agree with most of yours :)

>stomach and the lack of smoothness associated by the braking, release the brak
>e, then downshift, then accelerate method will be more than he/she feels he

Hmm. Whatever happened to double-clutch downshifting? Students can
approximate double-clutching quite quickly; there is a natural progression
from double-clutching to heel'n'toe; it is safer for the student (and the
instructor :) because the car should be already going slow enough for the
corner after the braking phase; and, most importantly, it is just as smooth
as heel'n'toe... done properly, of course :)

I'm not saying double-clutching is a better or faster technique than
heel'n'toe, but one can be pretty damn fast with either. I remember one
"Instruct the instructors how to instruct" meeting in my region where the
better part of an hour was spent debating the merits of each... people much
wiser and more experienced than myself got pretty worked up over the issue.
In the end, though, everyone agreed that getting the student to drive
smoothly was more important than a particular technique...

Just a thought,
Craig.

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 17:24:35 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Re: Engine Fires

>There is evidence in many of the fires that brake fluid either from the 
>res, or a fractured pipe was sprayed on to the hot exhaust.

 As a professional firefighter, I've seen perhaps 200 - 300 car fires. I've
never made the brake fluid/engine fire connection-it's possible I suppose,
but it's hard to believe that brake fluid is a MAJOR cause of engine
compartment fires.  

Based on personal experience, non-impact type engine fires are a result of
fuel leaks ignited by (very) hot engine parts, or by an electrical arc (as in
spark). A surprisingly common comment from the car owner is "Damn, I just got
the car back from the shop." I've always suspected that aging fuel lines
disturbed by the mechanic were the culprit, although many times the car is
relatively new. Go figure...

>I had a Bultaco MX bike. I had a tank slapper that fractured the GRP tank  a
>gallon on fuel dowsed the engine and exhaust, I was still astride the bike
and >enveloped in a cloud of hot vapour. I have never understood why it
didn't burn.

The reason motorcycle didn't burst into flame is simply that the engine
wasn't hot enough to ignite the fuel. The two primary factors in any fire are
the "flash point" and the "ignition temperature" of the fuel. Although
gasoline produces flammable vapors at 45F degrees below zero (gasoline's
"flash point"), the ignition source -the heated object, spark, flame,
etc.-must be at least 750F degrees or so (gasoline's "ignition temperature")
in order to ignite the vapors. In this case,  the engine was below the
"ignition temperature" of the fuel. 

What often happens under the hood of an automobile is that common
combustibles like paper, plastic, or leaves which have an ignition
temperature of around 450F degrees  come in contact with various engine parts
well above this temperature. The combustibles ignite creating a flame. While
the engine itself may be below the ignition temperature of the gasoline, the
open flame is now well above the 750F  necessary to ignite gasoline. The open
flame melts the fuel lines, and you presto, you have an engine fire.
 
Porsche 914s were notorious for engine compartment fires. The 914's battery
had a small, raised dike around the cell caps. Rain water would collect in
this dike which was higher than the cell caps. The dike would fill up and
rain water would enter each cell through the cap's vent hole and overfill the
cells, spilling battery acid on a fuel line directly below. Fuel leak plus
ignition source equals fire. And of course these fires are extremely
difficult to extinguish due to the magnesium engine cases used by Porsche
(and Volkswagen). Halon works well, but contrary to popular belief, few fire
department's carry halon extinguishers.

Michael K.

'87 911 Cab.

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 18:54:57 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: A-C-D Museum

>Where is the original factory located ?
Kit, the museum (and former factory) is in Auburn, Indiana, in the northeast
quadrant of the state an hour or so south of the Michigan state line.
 There's an annual A-C-D meeting there that is well worth attending, but
going during the rest of the year is easier.  For info, write A-C-D Museum,
1600 South Wayne Street, P.O. Box 271, Auburn, IN 46706.
Bob Joyce

Subject: New 993 C-4

I've been a lurker on the list for 6 months or so, just hanging out and
learning a lot. I just took delivery of my first Porsche, an Polar Silver
(Midnight Blue interior) 993 C-4 coupe 2 days ago, and would like to be
entered in the "who's who."
I have some experience driving high performance sports cars, having driven a
Nissan 1990 Turbo Z for 2 years, among others, but the combination of
handling, performance (even holding to the 4500 rpm break-in limitation),
and exquisite workmanship in my new P-car are truly awesome.  I haven't
really challenged the handling limits but would have to say even slow
corners under significant power produce no noticeable understeer for me.
The car is really neutral on the dry pavement I've been on so far.

difficult to get into 2nd on the upshift (and occasionally on downshift),
with a very firm hand necessary to select 2nd. Is this normal in so new a
car? I had an aftermarket alarm put in the car, and the technician mentioned
in passing that he had mounted a small motion sensor UNDER the shift boot
area, rearward of the shifter. Could this be obstructing the shifter for the
shift to 2nd? If this seems likely, I'll get it back to him, and have the
darned thing relocated or removed!
Thanks in advance, and it's great to finally be a Porsche owner.
Preston

1995 993 Carrera 4 Coupe, Polar Silver


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 95 14:30:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: torque wrenching


Hi Wayne,

I guess it really boils down to a question of whether you can tighten things
properly without a torque wrench.  If lug nuts and spark plugs are about all
that you do, using a torque wrench is a good insurance policy.  The
downside to not using is either harming the threads, or putting something
together to loosely and having it back out.  (Seen a bunch of instance of
the latter at the track last year.)

You won't see a professional mechanic use a torque wrench too often,
esp. when it comes to generic nuts and bolts.  Two reasons: s/he has done
it often enough that the wrist is calibrated and s/he can feel the stretch. 
 The
other is of course that using a torque wrench takes extra time.

Me, I'm an amateur and use one a lot more often than my professional
friends.

Hope this helps.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 95 14:39:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Carrera exhaust system by B & B.


>Has anyone installed an exhaust system made by B & B Fabrications Inc. for
>a late model (1984-1989) Carrera?  If so, I would like to hear your 
comments
>either directly or via the list

There's good news and bad news.  The good news is that they are nice parts
that flow well.  In combination with a chip, the shop has dyno'd some worth-
while performance gains.  The other good news is that Bill Boat is willing 
to
work with you to produce special versions of the exhaust.  We've gone 
through
a number of iterations on the race car, and most recently had a set of
straight pipes made up.  (He also custom made a new one-piece final pipe
and tip for my own 944S when the unavailable factory part rotted away.)

The bad news in a couple of flavours.  Delivery times suck and have pretty
consistently been missed.  The 911 muffler straps break all the time, and we
carry spares.

On balance, if I were looking for an aftermarket exhaust, I'd go with B&B.

Kevin

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 95 15:00:44 EST
From: 22-Jan-1995 1457 <olson_r@cho000.dnet.ge.com>
Subject: Re: Checking 944 thermostats

On Tues, Jan 17, Milo (milodorr@netcom.com) wrote:
  > I spent a couple of hours one afternoon trying to pull my (944)
  > thermostat for testing, only to give up in complete frustration.
  > ... Has anyone found a slick tool/trick to make pulling the
  > thermostat from an installed pump easier/possible?

 A few weeks ago I worked for a couple of hours trying to remove
 the thermostat from my '84 944, struggling for a couple hours
 with various types of wrong tools.  For me, short pliers with
 small pins, whether angled or not, kept popping off.  Finally,
 I decided that what was needed was a hefty snap-ring pliers
 with big pins at an angle, and long enough levers to give adequate
 leverage for the rather stiff snap-ring holding the thermostat.

 So, I picked up Snap-on tool PR5645A ($20), which is a 9" snap-ring
 pliers with .09" pins at 45deg.  Working from the underside,
 the ring comes right out.
Ron  (olson_r@cho.ge.com)

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 23:47:52 -0500
From: EuroPerf@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 cases

Tim,
From my 20+ years experience, I have found no significant difference among
the crankcases for the 4 cyl. engines.

I have used all of these cases for building engines stock and up to 250 hp
racing engines. 

The problems arise when you try to use the VW Typ2 case as there are numerous
differences!

Good luck,

Bob Kakascik
EuroPerf Racing

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 23:47:59 -0500
From: EuroPerf@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Pushrod Tube Seals

Dave,

I've found that even using the Viton o-rings you can still get leaks from the
tubes after a period of time. It depends primarily how much heat your engine
develops (whether stock or modified).

In our race engines we must replace the seals at least once during the season
but these are extreme conditions.

Be sure you clean the surfaces thoroughly in the head and case and when you
install the tube with new seal, lube it with oil and be careful the o-ring
doesn't "roll" out ot the groove in the tube.
It WILL LEAK!

Good Luck,

Bob Kakascik
EuroPerf Racing
Stable EnergieS

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 23:47:54 -0500
From: EuroPerf@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 rebuild

Jerry,
Yes it is correct NOT to use the cyl. head gaskets when using the 96mm P&C
kit. The wall thickness of the cylinder is quite thin and I have seen it cut
into the gasket and break off inside the combustion chamber.

Because the cyl. wall is thinner, it can more easily seat into the combustion
chamber surface when it is torqued. Also because it is thinner, if you raise
the comp. ratio higher than 9:1 the cyl. wall begins to distort from the
extra heat buildup.

You need to check very carefully (with a feeler gauge) the clearance between
the top of the cyl shoulder and the top fin (machined boss) of the cyl head.
I like to see .020" min. This is to allow for expansion and compression of
the alum. in the comb chamb.

This clearance will vary depending on whether or not the heads have been
flycut and of course how much.

Have fun!

Bob Kakascik
EuroPerf Racing
Stable EnergieS


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 23:47:53 -0500
From: EuroPerf@aol.com
Subject: Re: What carbon-fiber pad for...

Mike,
I have tried all of the major brands of Hi Perf brake pads on the market
under street, track, autocross and Club Racing conditions both on customers
and our own race cars and have found the PORTERFIELD brand carbon-kevlar pads
to be the best.

They use the highest quality resins available in their composition as well as
a ceramic insulator between the friction material and the metal backing. They
are very nice to the rotors and squeal very little (if at all) compared to
the other brands on the market.

To date PORTERFIELD has only one compound and has not found it necessary to
alter their composition.

Good Luck,

Bob Kakascik
EuroPerf Racing
Stable EnergieS

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 23:56:02 -0500
From: EuroPerf@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 steering rack spacers ?

Martin,
Yes the steering rack spacers do help with bump steer.

You can tell if you already have them by looking at the steering rack
mounting bolts. The spacers are placed between the rack and the mounting
flanges on the cross mount. They will be approx. 15-19mm thick.

Yes you will need to re-adj the toe setting after inst. rack spacers.

The more you lower the car the greater the angle from the steering knuckle to
the rack becomes. The optimal setup is to have the tierods parallel to the
ground.

Good Luck,

Bob Kakascik
EuroPerf Racing
Stable EnergieS

Date: 23 Jan 95 00:54:05 EST
From: Dave Hinton <76025.1324@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 Sunroof

Topic:  Sunroof Alignment

I have a problem with my sunroof alignment on my 911.  The back
edges of the sunroof are not flush with the roof.  It would
appear that the curve of the sunroof is slightly more than the
roof, therefore when the center of the sunroof is adjusted flush
to the roof, the back edges are not flush to the roof level.  As
my car is not on the road now, I thought it might be a good time
to remove the sunroof and reshape it.  My plan was to put some
tension on the center to lesson the degree of curve and leave it
for a couple of months.  Has anyone out there had a similiar
problem?  Do you think the paint would be affected by this
treatment?  Your comments are appreciated.

Dave Hinton    77  911S

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 11:54:13 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Torsion bars,bushing lube?

>I would like to get some recommendations for size/type of suspension
>upgrades
>for an '84 930. I've been looking at the Weltmeister stuff including:
>Swaybars, 22mm front,22mm rear
>Torsion bars (solid) 22mm front, 27mm rear 
>Adjustable spring plate, (good idea?)
>Poly-Graphite bushings, all applicable.

Use 29 mm rear torsion bars.  The stock bars are 26mm I believe, so going up
1mm isn't enough.

Use the Weltmeister STREET bushings.  The are harder than stock by several
times, but still have a little "give" so the won't rattle your teeth. Forget
the adjustable spring plates; yours are already adjustable from the factory.
 Early models weren't.  Swaybar sizes are fine.  Be sure to use the back up
plates for the front bars where they go thru the inner fenders. Use
Automotions bushing lube.  It appears to work the best to eliminate squeaks.
The above combination will give you a ride that is firm, but not harsh and
gives you the control you need on the track or autocross.  Helps eliminate
squat out of corners, and keep the turbo power on the track.

Jon Lowe
Former owner of '78 930 with above mods



------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 11:54:08 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: brake pads/warping rotors

>As I have previously mentioned I'm prepping the car now for at least
>on drivers ed this spring (at Mid-Ohio).

>Should I consider putting on cool carbons or some other "race" brake
>pads for the event ?  If I don't, will I stand a good chance of warping
>rotors ?  A set of pads is certainly cheaper than the rotors !

Use Cool Carbon brake pads.  Even more important at Mid-Ohio is to use the
Cool Brake kit advertised in PANO.  Look for the one that says it uses the
original Holbert molds.  Or Bill Braucksick at Performance Alignment can get
them for you in Cinci. (You DID have hime align and lower your 911 didn't
you!!!???; he does almost all of the track cars in Cinci and
Dayton-advertises in Bent Pylon)  The Cool Brake kit will greatly increase
rotor and pad life and also virtually eliminate fading on an SC or other more
or less stock 911.  Also FLUSH your brake fluid no longer than 2 or 3 days
prior to the event, using a good high temp DOT 3 fluid like Ford Heavy Duty
in the blue can.  Forget Castrol GT; it simply does not have a high enough
dry boiling point.

About your later post on shift points at Mid-Ohio; they will change as you
learn the track.  And you will spend MOST of your first school just learning
the track at Mid-Ohio.  I tell students to just put the car in third for the
whole track until they get turn in points, track out points and apexes down.
You will be REAL busy until driving the track becomes natural, too busy to
worry much about shift points. Your instructor will help you pick shift
points as you learn the track and as you pick up speed. That is what he or
she is there for.  DON'T worry about lap times and revs out of corners your
first event.  Worry about smoothness, staying on the line. learning the
track.  If you are smooth, fast times will come.  If you aren't smooth, you
will be slow, guaranteed.  Mid-Ohio, more than any other track I have driven,
rewards smooth.  Most of its turns are connected in some way, so that if you
do one wrong, you've just screwed up two or three others.

Have fun!

Jon Lowe
PCA/BMWCCA Instructor at Mid Ohio '80 thru '94...over 100 events there

Two weeks ago I purchased an '84 944 with 53k (!) and all records.  Great 
interior, minor chips on the outside, strong engine. I  
didn't know a person could have so much fun in a car!  Now I have a few 
questions:

I have had the belts replaced and the motor mounts upgraded to the turbo 
mounts.  The car really shook at idle when I bought it, but now it's 
completely smooth.  The previous owner had the water pump upgraded about 
20k ago, and the dealer gave the car a passing grade.  It seems to be 
running great.  Are there any other major things that should be checked?  

On this model, is the coolant fan supposed to 
come on regularly in traffic?  The temperature gauge is always about in 
the middle when on the highway, but it goes past the 3/4 mark in traffic 
and the fan comes on.  The fan always goes off when the gauge has gone 
back to 1/2. I will be changing the coolant soon- I think it's been over 
a year.  By the way, I have some new Prestone in a yellow bottle that the 
Kragen people say is phosphate free.  The label say's it's OK for 
aluminum engines.  Is this right, or should I be looking for the grey 
bottles that have been mentioned here?

of the minor mechanical and cosmetic  details:
 - Anyone know how the rear hatch release switch fits together?  My switch 
triggers the hatch release when it's barely touched, then has to be 
wobbled before it shuts off the power.  I've disconnected it for fear 
that it will pop the back while I'm driving.  Maybe it's missing a part?  
Anywhere I can order a new switch to solder in there?
 - The cruise control stalk was taken apart when I got the car.  I have 
all the pieces....  Anywhere I can get a diagram of how they fit 
together?  I don't feel comfortable doing this by trial and error.

This is getting long...I'll save the rest for later!  Thanks to everyone 
on the List-I would never have had the guts to buy a Porsche (especially 
an 11 year old Porsche) without all this great information.

Subject: Adjusting Valves on a 924

        I made an attempt to do the valves clearances the other day on the 924.
This is the first time I have tried this on an overhead cam motor.  One
big question I had was when do you check the clearance?  The manual states
when the cylinder is at tdz. However this is really only possible
to know on #1 for sure.  It seems to me that you should be able to check the
clearance whenever a cam is pointing straight up.  Is this the case?  BTW
I ended up turning the engine, for lack of an adequate wrench, by putting
the car in gear and pushing the vehicle - can anything be hurt by doing 
this? How about in reverse?
 
        So if I have done the checking right, I found a number of exhaust
valves were over tight.  Around .2mm as opposed to .4mm.  I also found a 
number of scars on the lobes of the tight cams.  This has me worried a bit
as the head was rebuilt about 5000km ago by the PO.  I have not noticed
any real difference in performance, except maybe that the idle is more 
even - perhaps.  I would imagine that tight cams could be bad, opening on
adjustment?
 
 
Thanks,
Kristian

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 07:27:57 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Adjusting Valves on a 924

> 
>         I made an attempt to do the valves clearances the other day on the 92
4.
> This is the first time I have tried this on an overhead cam motor.  One
> big question I had was when do you check the clearance?  The manual states
> when the cylinder is at tdz. However this is really only possible
> to know on #1 for sure.  It seems to me that you should be able to check the
> clearance whenever a cam is pointing straight up.  Is this the case?  BTW

Yep, you did it right.  You can check the adjustment when the cam lobe is
pointing away from the cam follower.  The manuals just pick #1 TDC as a
convenient starting point...

> I ended up turning the engine, for lack of an adequate wrench, by putting
> the car in gear and pushing the vehicle - can anything be hurt by doing 
> this? How about in reverse?

Should not hurt anything to do so, in reverse is a bit more difficult due to
the gear ratios involved...
 
However, it might be easier to take the 
spark plugs out and turn the motor by hand...

>  
>         So if I have done the checking right, I found a number of exhaust
> valves were over tight.  Around .2mm as opposed to .4mm.  I also found a 
> number of scars on the lobes of the tight cams.  This has me worried a bit
> as the head was rebuilt about 5000km ago by the PO.  I have not noticed
> any real difference in performance, except maybe that the idle is more 
> even - perhaps.  I would imagine that tight cams could be bad, opening on
> adjustment?

Too little play results in burned valves.  I would go ahead and make the
adjustment.  (Keep in mind that too much play causes a clatter, which may be
why the mechanic kept them tight...)

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 08:37:53 -0500 (EST)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: First Production Supercharger; First Production Turbocharger

Mercedes Benz introduced the first production supercharged car in 1921.

Supercharging was picked up by many others, including Auburn, Cord,
Duesenberg, Alfa Romeo, Bugatti, Bentley, MG, and others.

After a little research, it still looks like Oldsmobile holds the record
for the first production turbocharged car with their Jetfire in 1962.

FORZA!                  Smith, Walker And Associates, Melbourne, Florida
GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 15:07:26 -0500
From: Jim01j21m@aol.com
Subject:  928 Cruise Control Problems

Hi all, I may be very late with this as I am a bit behind on my mail.
 Several P-car owners have been discussing various problems with their cruise
controls, primarily on 928's.  I have the factory manuals for the 928 and
spent some time looking up just how the system works.  Prior to 88 this was a
vacume controlled and operated system.  So YES vacume leaks can and do have
various effects on the system depending on where and how bad they are.  The
basic troubleshooting steps are as follows:
   1.  Ck the fuse No. 7, this fuse is also for the stop lights.
   2.  Connect a manual vacuum pump to the sys. and ck for leaks.
   3.  Ck. for twisted or pinched vacuum lines.
   4.  Ck. electrical connection on the vacuum servo.
   5.  Ck. function of swi. on clutch pedal.
   6.  If no defect is found rmv. the control and ck. on the multiple pin
plug of the vacuum servo.

My belief is that most problems will be in the vacuum system, remember just
how bad German rubber is, and start replacing all the various vacuum hoses.  

Hope this helps.
Jim Mayzurk
89 928GT

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 09:34:57 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Pushrod Tube Seals


Dear Dave,

The viton seals (rated at 400 degrees) are specially made and not available
at the dealer (we have ours made in fact). As 914 engines get older and run
hotter, it is very important to use a higher temperature seal to avoid
continual replacement.

As an additional note:  always check the valve adjusting lugs for wear and
readjust the valves during pushrod tube seal replacement.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 09:35:06 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 frame restoration


Dear Chris,

Your fuel-injected 2.0 on the open road should return 30 MPG. Any less and
there is a problem.

The most probable cause for the poor 2.0 fuel consumption (and we assume the
brakes are not sticking!) is a defective manifold pressure sensor. After
years, the diaphram breaks and the device can no longer sense engine vacuum
(or lack of it) to adjust duration of injection. What results is the system
thinking you are running at constant full throttle and hence a rich mixture
and poor gas mileage!

The easy way to test the pressure sensor is by evacuation (it looks like a
hand grenade or small pineapple, has a vacuum hose and electrical plug
mounted to it. It is located behind the battery support.) Simply draw 16
inches of vacuum with a hand-held vacuum pump (or suck on the sensor and see
if it holds your tongue). If you cannot draw a vacuum or the vacuum drawn
leaks off, the device is bad. Replacement will instantly rester fuel economy
and bring back hot idle.

Finally, a new pressure sensor may not initially allow the engine to run well
because of other vacuum leaks disguised by the old defective, rich running
unit. Repair of these leaks will ensure good performance. Always change the
oil after installing a new sensor. The old one has caused a rich mixture,
washing of the piston rings and in an extreme case, flooding of the crank
case with gasoline.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 09:35:15 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: No Subject


Dear Tim,

All 914 cases were basically the same, but differed as follows:  
  '70-'73 1.7 cases were the same except some of the early ones had no oil
baffle plate
  '73-'74 2.0 cases were for the most part a 1.7 case with extra clearance
for the 2.0 piston skirt
  '75-'76 2.0 and 1.8 cases had the extra oil pressure relief valve
eliminated from the side
  '74-'76 1.8 carburated engine cases were tapped for mechanical fuel pump
mounting
  '75-'76 2.0 cases warping in the cam bore and running with excessive
friction. This causes these engines, even when freshly rebuilt, to run so hot
that they cannot be relied upon. Hence, whenever we suspect that one of these
engines has run hot in the past, we replace the case as standard rebuild
procedure, with the '73-'74 2.0 variety or use a 1.7 case and relieve it for
piston skirt clearance.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 09:35:26 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE> 914 + Solex


Dear Dave,

The carburated 914s were made in 1974, 75 and 76 for Europe only. The engine
number began with AIV (as opposed to WO EC GA etc.). They were rated at 85
HP, used a mechanical fuel pump attached to the engine block and two 40 POSIT
Solex carburetors connected with a crossbar linkage and a centrally mounted
flat air cleaner.

George Hussey

Date: 23 Jan 95 06:55:32 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: 911SC questions


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  911SC questions
Date: 1995-01-23 08:48
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I'm thinking about getting a high mileage SC for a driver, time trialer and
future club racer.  I have some questions for those "in the know".

I've heard that '78s (and '79s too?) have bigger valves than the later ('80
+) SCs?  If so, is this any advantage performance wise?

Did all SCs have electronic speedo's?

If I find one that needs to be made back to smog legal -- has anyone tried
putting the 3.2L Carrera exhaust on (with the 3 way cat)?  (I happen to have
one of these)

I've heard the 3.0L motors are incredibly durable (I had no probs w/ my '79)
and good for 250K+ miles if given moderate care, but when the motors are in
the 150K+ mile range, are the valve trains getting weak?  Is freshening up
the top end a good idea for hard use?

Any particular advantages or disadvantages for any of the model years?

Lastly, how competitively are SCs classed for PCA club racing (I don't have
a rule book...).  As in, are all SCs, Carreras, C2s in the same stock class?
(or some such bad luck..).

Thanks for any and all help...

 -Scott Jessen
'72 911 dedicated AXer (that DOESN'T get driven on the street (anymore))....
sjje@chevron.com

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 08:56:12 CST
From: dhartger@nas_jsc1.jsc.nasa.gov (Dan Hartgerink)
Subject: RE: 928 update 


John Milton wrote:


....(trouble shooting info deleted)....

>Here is the sequence of events that led to the problem:

>    1) back 928 out of garage and park it (the car ran for about
>       30 seconds, the outside temperature was ~35F)

>    2) spend 3 hrs cleaning the garage

>    3) start 928 (its running like sh*t)

>    4) turn off ignition

>    5) try to start 928, no luck
>      I tried a few more times with no luck (my special incantations
>       didn't help either).

>       I know I pressed the gas pedal a few times which would
>       contribute to the flooding but I don't know if flooding
>       caused it to run so poorly to begin with or if that was
>       a different problem and I just made things worse.

>    6) push 928 into garage

>My mechanic hypothesizes that since the car didn't warm up during
>the short time it was running that perhaps the DME computer got
>'confused' when I tried to restart it later, flooding the engine.
>He suggested that if I had simply driven the car around the block
>before parking it that I may have avoided the problem entirely.
>I have a EE/CS background and know computers well enough to know
>that they can do strange things, but this hypothesis sounds like
>a bit of a reach.  Anybody out there have any better ideas?  (Now
>there's a loaded question.)

>John Milton
>porsche@cv.hp.com
>`86 928S WeissGold


I did basically the same thing a few years ago when I was a new
944 owner.  I had the car parked in a friends driveway during
a ski trip.  During the middle of my vacation I went out to the
car and started it (temperature approx 25 Deg F) to "make sure
everything was OK" It started fine, and I let it idle for about
a minute and then shut it off.  About 4 days later when I was 
trying leave Colorodo for Houston  :(   the car wouldnt start at
all, it just kept cranking till the battery died.  

After half an hour or so of frenzied troubleshooting I pulled the 
spark plugs and found (much to my relief) that they were totally 
fouled with goop and soaked with gasoline.  I dried the plugs off 
and blew air into the plug openings and let the car sit for a while
to allow any gasoline in the cylinders to evaporate.  I put the
plugs back in and the car started up with difficulty and sputtered
along for a while until it warmed up, but ran fine after that.

I had always assumed that this problem was some combination of 
improper treatment (not letting the engine fully warm up) and a 
confused engine computer pumping way too much gas into the engine. 
I had never heard of the oil depletion theory till I read Johns 
message, but there could be somthing to it since I remember having
some trouble starting the car even after drying out the cylinders.


Dan 


'87 944

Date: 23 Jan 95 10:46

Subject: 914 pressure sensor/poor fuel milage

>The easy way to test the pressure sensor is by evacuation (it looks like a
>hand grenade or small pineapple, has a vacuum hose and electrical plug
>mounted to it. It is located behind the battery support.) Simply draw 16
>inches of vacuum with a hand-held vacuum pump (or suck on the sensor and see
>if it holds your tongue). If you cannot draw a vacuum or the vacuum drawn
>leaks off, the device is bad. Replacement will instantly rester fuel economy
>and bring back hot idle.

>George Hussey

   What do you mean "hot" idle?  The motor currently idles consistently @
   900rpm.  The only time the idle varies from 900rpm is after I have driven
   aggressively for an extended period of time.  Then the idle goes up to
   about 1100rpm but eventually settles down to 900rpm again. If my pressure
   sensor is bad would I necessarily be experiencing an erratic idle or any
   other "performance" anomalies?

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 11:40 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: 944 struts - a job for p-philes?

	Dear P-philes;
	Once the front M-strut assemblies are out, can an accomplished
	back-yard mechanic rent a spring compresser, take it apart,
	put in a new 'shock' and put it back together w/o any big
	problems?

Don't see why not.  Did this on my dad's '80 Rabbit with no problems, and the
hardest part was getting the old insert out (the cap was a little the worse
for several season's exposure to salt-impregnated slush).  Just remove the
spring, clamp the bottom in a vice, get a BFW and crank on it.  Actually, since
you've probably taken care of your car, a "regular" wrench is most likely
adequate.

Be sure to *carefully* mark the alignment adjusting bolts (punch a mark on
the bolt and a corresponsing mark on the strut mounting flange), unless you
were planning to get the car realigned anway...

Good luck!

- -- Tracy Nelson
'87 944S


------------------------------

Date: 23 Jan 95 11:56:05 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 914 wheel bearings

 
Tommy (Wmson) asked about replacing wheel bearings.
 
If the bearing is loose, try adjusting it first before giving up and
replacing it. This is a lot easier. Jack wheel up, take off wheel, pry off
hub cab (the REAL hub cap, little domed thingie in center of hub). Inside
you will find a largish nut, probably held by a cotter pin and tab washer or
in many (Most? All?) Porsche applications by a teardrop-shaped special clamp
with an Allen head screw in the side. To remove play in wheel bearing,
GENTLY tighten this nut or clamp (if clamp, an Allen wrench in the loosened
socket head screw serves as a handy handle). You want it just snug enough so
that you can move the large flat thrust washer under the nut or clamp with a
large screwdriver, with some drag. You don't want it loose, you don't want
it clamped down tight. Actually, it's really not much more than finger tight.
Once this drag has been set, tighten the clamping
screw or install a cotter pin and tab washer, put some grease around the
area, and pound the hub cap back on. Install wheel and see if that doesn't
reduce the play.
 
If you really truly need new wheel bearings, they're cheap enough. Don't
forget to buy the grease seal too. You could pound them out by going around
the rings with a hammer and screwdriver, but this is very likely to nick the
bores in the hub, and give you problems later on (rapid wheel bearing wear; new
bearings are no longer held perfectly circular due to defects gouged
into hub). It's a lot safer to find a piece of brass rod to use as
a drift, instead of the hardened blade of a screwdriver. Brass is far less
likely to mar the bearing bores. When reinstalling new bearings, first wipe
out all the old grease, press bearings back in (here you may have to
improvise to make a puller using threaded rod and something like large
sockets or perhaps the old outer ring to use partway, before it too gets
pressed in; best way is still a proper bearing press). Once assembled, the
big nut is tightened up fairly firmly to set the bearings, then backed off
all the way, then the "finger tight" method used for adjusting.
 
Whatever grease you use, try to get all of the old stuff out. Some greases
are incompatible with others (it is said that factories often use
sulfur-based grease which is incompatible with moly-based grease etc.) I
figure as far as brand, grease is grease. Front wheel bearings seem to last
a long time no matter what you put in there, as long as it's a proper wheel
bearing grease and there's enough of it.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 23 Jan 95 11:55:30 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: First Turbos

 
Bob Joyce mentions the superchargers used on Auburn/Cord/Duesenbergs. These
are a completely different animal from turbocharging. The first production
automotive _turbos_ were definitely GM units.
 
Superchargers are mechanically driven by the engine, by means of gears or
shafts or belts. Turbochargers are driven by exhaust gases. This is often
erroneously described as "free energy" from the otherwise wasted exhaust
gas. This is not entirely true, but mechanically driven superchargers use up
a lot of the engine's output directly.
 
Turbocharging was invented by a Swiss engineer, Alfred Buechi, in 1905. He
used axial blowers, and applied the idea to large industrial engines.
 
The idea of supercharging is a little bit older, if you include crankcase
compression and the like. Gottlieb Daimler had some patents for crankcase
compression type supercharging in 1885 and 1889, but may not have built
actual engines using the idea.
 
The first actual superchargers were vane-type blowers, similar in concept to
the still available Paxton blower. This idea goes back to 1588, an Italian
inventor, Agostino della Tresia. The Wittig blower, with blades free to fly
out and rub against the housing, appeared in Germany
around 1900. A Swiss engineer named Zoller developed a similar vane blower
with restrained blades for a Fiat rotary two-stroke aircraft engine around
1912. The idea of the Roots blower goes back to a German inventor,
Pappenheim, around 1636. This idea was developed by a couple of brothers from
Indiana, Philander (great name!) and Francis Roots, in 1848. Their air pumps
were sold around the world for ventilation in mines and moving industrial
air and gases and such. The first recorded use of a Roots blower on an
internal combustion engine is a two-stroke V4 aircraft engine built by N.E.C.
in Engand, 1911.
 
While Buechi used axial flow turbines, the idea of centrifugal compressors
was already known. The world's first working gas turbine engine was built in
France in 1903 and used a 3-stage centrifugal compressor. This prinicple was
adapted by an American engineer, Sanford Moss, working for General Electric,
and eventually resulted in the turbocharger in much the form that we know it
today. Moss and associates were testing turbocharged aircraft at altitude by
1919.
 
The first recorded use of mechanical supercharging on a car is a Chadwick,
1907, for their racing program, and was first used in the Giants' Despair
hillclimb in Pennsylvania, 1908. This was a vane-type blower. By 1912 several
companies in Europe had begun to experiment with various types of
supercharging, most notably Hispano-Suiza. Both sides in World War I
experimented with superchargers to allow aircraft to reach higher altitudes.
The only ones to be released for service were German AEG G IV bombers powered
by Daimler-Benz engines with three-stage blowers, released for service in
August 1918.
 
The first ever use of a Roots blower on a car was by Mercedes-Benz, October
1919, on a modified Mercedes sleeve-valve (Knight patent) engine. In the
1920s, Roots blowers became fairly common on high performance and racing
cars including the aforementioned products of Auburn-Cord-Duesenberg.
 
The best history of supercharging and turbocharging I've ever found is in
Automobile Quarterly, vol 9 no.2, by Karl Ludvigsen. The above information
comes from that article.
 
Pete
 
 


------------------------------

Date: 23 Jan 95 11:56:01 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Paxton supercharger

 
Kit Jungmann asked about info on Paxton blowers.
 
Paxton is at
 
Paxton Products, Inc.
929 Olympic Blvd.
Santa Monica, CA  90404
1-213-394-2751. This Area Code may have changed to 310 by now.
 
I have to agree with others on the forum that putting one of these on is a
pretty radical step. Unless you have a lot of patience and engineering skill
to redesign aftermarket stuff to work properly, it's likely that you won't
be happy with the results. No reflection on Paxton or anybody, just personal
experience with the general level of aftermarket kludge solutions.
 
Bottom line is, move to a lower altitude, suffer with lack of power, or go
get a factory turbo- or supercharged car.
 
Pete

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 12:44:55 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: 914/2.0 and SCCA autox

Howdy, 

I wrote to Stephen I Jagernauth (sjagernauth@attmail.com) who mentioned
he was looking for a 914/2.0 when he answered my Brake pad question :

>>That's funny, I am picking up a '73 2.0 tomorrow, a good basis for a 
>>track car. From Atlanta originally, spent 5 summers in Connecticut.
>>I don't know what I'm going to do with it but I couldn't pass it by.

Stephen replied :

>My boss was on vacation in Atlanta last Thanksgiving and mentioned the
supply
>of 914s he noticed.  I'd consider making a trip if necessary.  What did you 
>pay for yours?  The going rate here in NJ (I live in PA, work in NJ) is
around
>$4k for a fairly clean specimen but they all have rust unless someone
already
>spent big bucks to fix it.   Fred Hess on the list has a '73 with only 30K
>but he wants $8k for it.  

I got a good deal on it- drove it home yesterday. It is pretty clean, needs
several small things though, which is why it was cheap. I don't think it
ever had rust repaired- it is much cleaner than the '73 that I had in '80 !
It even has a nice Momo steering wheel, Bursch muffler, Yoko 008R tires
on the Fuchs forged wheels (best), so its almost ready for autocross!
Needs some work and a good tune-up (sat for a while in a garage).
Has only 103,000 miles I think. It's a late '73 model (June). 
Camshaft was replaced a few years ago, so engine should be OK.

I could be convinced to part with it so I can afford to get my 911
back up to speed. I could sell it as it is for WELL under $4000.

>BTW, how would I get SCCA autox info for this area?  Are 914s competitive in

>stock classes?  I just started doing NNJR-PCA autox last year and was
placing
>2nd every time I ran but my 944Turbo is not properly set up yet and is not a

>good car for the short, tight tracks we're limited to.  I don't want to make

>major mods cage etc for track so considering less expensive car hence 914.  
>Would also consider a early 911T/E, say '70-73?  More money but probably 
>better 'investment'.

There's lots of autocrossing in the Harrisburg area, I go there a few
times a year for SCCA Pro Solo and Divisionals. Put out a note on the
Pfiles list and someone from that area will get in touch with you.

The 914/2.0 is about the best car in C-Stock, and can run at a lowered
ride height this year again. The only mod you need for a 914 is a bigger
front sway bar and good alignment and shocks, so they are a great
autocross car. A good driver in a 914/2.0 can usually beat most 911s
(except mine, I hope!) I think a clean 914/2.0 is a very good
investment-  the prices are now going up much faster than for 911s,
which took a killing in the late 80's. The 914 prices never dropped
because there was no speculating. Of course the 914 will feel very slow
compared to a 944 Turbo, but the handling will make up for it.

The 914 is also lots of fun on the track, but I spun-out in my '73 1.7
several times at Lime Rock (I was just a kid then...). The 914 really
rewards proper lines and driving style, since there is no way to make up
for a bad corner! And I thought my 914 brakes were at least as good as
my 911S brakes. Of course I wasn't going as fast!

The 911 is several times more expensive : rebuilding the fuel injection
on my '72 S is about the same as an engine rebuild on a 914! But if you
really want a 911, a '72-'73 911 can't be beat for fun! Any model T, E or
S is OK if it's not rusty, depends on how much you can spend.

Regards,

Mike Piera '72 911S, '73 914/2.0  AnalogMike@aol.com

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 12:29:59 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: 914 F.I (was: Re: 914 frame restoration)

>...useful comments on pressure sensor leakage and testing deleted...
>
>Finally, a new pressure sensor may not initially allow the engine to run well
>because of other vacuum leaks disguised by the old defective, rich running
>unit. Repair of these leaks will ensure good performance. Always change the
>oil after installing a new sensor. The old one has caused a rich mixture,
>washing of the piston rings and in an extreme case, flooding of the crank
>case with gasoline.

It is important to understand that vacuum leaks per se will not cause a
914 (or any other Bosch D-Jetronic car) to run too rich or lean. A simple
vacuum leak will just cause the car to idle too fast. The throttle is
nothing but a big "vacuum leak", controlled by your foot. There are some
electronic sensors on the throttle. but those are for 2nd order effects.

A vacuum leak in the pressure sensor will cause the engine to run rich, 
as George says. However, the reason is that the air flow through the
hose to the sensor, caused by the vacuum leak, causes the sensor to
see less vacuum than actually exists in the manifold, and this reduced
vacuum causes extra gas to be injected when it is not actually needed.

Note that this differs considerably from almost any other fuel metering
system, in that with all (?) others, excess air caused by a leak causes
lean operation.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 09:54:46 -0800
From: peterg@airdata.com (Peter Gregory)
Subject: Muffler and heat exchanger paint

Can I even paint the 'J' pipes on my 912 with this cold galvanizing paint?

- ----- Begin Included Message -----

In this case, however, the factory specified a paint that had a high zinc
content. It is called `cold galvanizing' in the paint trade and can be found 
in the correct gray at many local hardware stores. NOT VHT. While VHT is 
a fine finish, it is not correct.

- ----- End Included Message -----

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 13:54:29 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Bought a 944-now the questions begin!

> On this model, is the coolant fan supposed to
> come on regularly in traffic?  The temperature gauge is always about in
> the middle when on the highway, but it goes past the 3/4 mark in traffic
> and the fan comes on.  The fan always goes off when the gauge has gone
> back to 1/2.
This sounds about right based on my experience.

> I will be changing the coolant soon- I think it's been over
> a year.  By the way, I have some new Prestone in a yellow bottle that the
> Kragen people say is phosphate free.  The label say's it's OK for
> aluminum engines.  Is this right, or should I be looking for the grey
> bottles that have been mentioned here?
Unless Prestone's recently changed packaging, the yellow containers DO 
have phosphates in them; grey does not.  Prestone claims the regular 
(w/ phosphates) fluid is OK for aluminum engines, and I've successfully 
used it for 12 years in various all aluminum and aluminum/iron 
head/block combinations with no visible problems within the water tracks.

But that's not science, and if you've got a warranty on your new car 
then stick to the specified fluids.  You wouldn't want them to make you 
pay $$$ for a water pump because you saved $5 on Prestone!

> Now that the big things are done, I want to start concentrating on some
> of the minor mechanical and cosmetic  details:
> - Anyone know how the rear hatch release switch fits together?  My switch
> triggers the hatch release when it's barely touched, then has to be
> wobbled before it shuts off the power.  I've disconnected it for fear
> that it will pop the back while I'm driving.  Maybe it's missing a part?
> Anywhere I can order a new switch to solder in there?
Order one from your local dealer, or aftermarket suppliers that have 
OEM pieces.  Maybe got one from a wreck.  The old one should just pop 
out - a 60 second job.


		JBS

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 13:15:11 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: 912E #1 update:gonna keep it!

Jay,

For most old 911s/12s one can do anything their heart desires. There
are enough examples around that modifying a car to suite your own taste
is simply a personal decision. VIN #0001 and motor #0003 does
distinguish your 912E. If you feel VIN #0001 is special you should not
do anything to compromise originality. In fact, you would actually have
a responsibility to do everything carefully and correctly (which also
means the initial cost will likely be higher).

Removal of the radio plate to install a radio might seem to be no
problem, but what about the installation of brakets to mount the new
radio and what about the speakers? You could replace the original door
pannels to reinstall if the car was ever to be restored to it's
original condition (radio/speakers removed) but then those pannels
would age differently than the rest of the interior. A compromise would
be to locate and install a radio consistent with those shipped with
912Es.

You must contact PCNA and at least get the Cardex for your car. They
will give you a certificate of authenticity. It is likely the #1 VIN
will get you a little more attention than normal. PCNA should
know what wheels were shipped on your 912E. I would also encourage you
to have the car appraised by an expert in Porsche body work. If the car
is unhacked upon and does not have hidden rust, then the #1 VIN becomes
more important.

Your car maybe smoking due to valve guides. Your cylinders and pistons
could very likely be reuesd. There are alternates to new cylinders and
pistons, especially for cars that will not be raced or driven
competitively. Again, an expert would be useful when the engine is
dismantled. But the longer you drive it when it's wrong, the more
likely you will have to spend even more $$$ when you do go for the
overhaul.

On the other hand, if you feel your 912E is really just the same as all
the others out there, then you should make whatever changes you wish.
 Just disreagrd the VIN and have fun!. You own it and you can make
 whatever changes suit your fancy. Ignore the VIN (its only a id number
 after all) and do it your way.

What to do with an old 911/12 is a bit of a dilema. You may think your
modification/upgrade is really clever and attractive... and the next
person may think you have seriously devalued the car. The longer one
plans to keep a car, the more radically one can change it with
disregard to any economic consequences. If you keep it original you may
not enjoy it as much, but you have preserved the value of the car in
the open market.

My advice would be to spend your money getting the car in tip top
mechanical shape. I would use only Porsche parts ($$$) and deviate from
the original enginnering only in cases wehere upgrades are widely
excepted by the Porsche community (For instance tensioner upgrades, or
replacement of the hydroneumatic front suspension on 2.0 and 2.4 liter
911Es, or SS heat exchanges). Spending money for a radio when the car
is smoking does not make sense to me. The PO of my car installed a
$1700 stereo on a car with extraordinary play in the valve guides, a
clutch worn almost to the rivets, a broken odometer, a failed MFI unit,
eight year old tires with good tread but hard as rocks and a rusted
through heat exchanger... go figure.

Enjoy your new Porsche!

**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021  1971 911E coupe

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

**********************************************************************

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 19:34:07 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 914 wheel bearings



Just a word of caution on wheel bearings

914 bearings if loose are probably well worn, before tightening you 
should really check whether they are fit for purpose.

This involves removing the hub and inspecting the rollers and races, if 
you see any signs of reddish metal or bits of chrome missing you need to 
replace them. 

If you just tighten up worn bearings you can expect possibly high wear or 
far worse, a seizure - this will probably shear the stub axle and perhaps 
cause an accident.

Personal preference I prefer bearings slightly loose rather than risk too 
tight - you get slight brake knock-off but less risk of seizure.

If there is any evidence of bearing destruction, always replace the 
grease as it will contain bits of old chrome that will nack your new 
bearings.



+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

the car (it is stock and is driven mostly in town). TIA.

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 14:48:30 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Daytona 24 hr race - info needed.

> I'm planning on driving from DC down to the Daytona 24-hour race next month. 
> haven't been to the race - or Florida - before & have a few questions:
> - when is the best time to arrive? I have plenty of time & can arrive several
> days early so if there are practice sessions etc worth seeing...

Best time to arrive is Thursday, unless you can arrive on Wednesday...
Catch some Zs, because 24 hours is a long time to watch the race...
Get settled in and have some barbecue down by the beach...
  
> - where is the track? I've checked an admittedly bad map of Daytona but can't
> see anything looking like a road racing circuit on it.
>
You can't miss it, about 3 miles inland on the main drag. (forget the
number) but all roads lead to it, especially the exit from I-95.  
 
> - do I need a ticket to get in? If so, how much & where do I buy them? Also, 

Yes, a couple of years ago, pit passes were $50 for the whole deal. You can
buy them at the ticket booth at the main entrance.

> is there pit access before or during the race?

Pit access before, not during the race or during practice and qualifying.

> 
> - where to stay near the track? I'm looking for an inexpensive & safe place 
> to park my car while I'm there.
> 
All the places near the track are trashy, unless you are willing to spend
$$$ on the beach for a Marriott etc. Remember that just because it is a
national chain does not mean that it will meet your standards.

> - is there a PCA or PCNA presence at the event - a guest enclosure or 
> hospitality area?

I don't know of any official PCA presence, but I'll be willing to bet that
Alwin Springer and his group are there to support.  Don't plan on getting
any freebies just because you are a PCA member or a Porsche owner...

I did happen to hear that a couple of PCA members will be driving a 993
Turbo at Daytona (Art Pilla among them) and a few PCA members are bound to
attend, but mostly you'll just run into friends that you have made
elsewhere...

> 
> Any other information or help would be much appreciated!

Bring raingear, just in case.  Be prepared for any type of weather.

When you want to leave the track Saturday evening (to get some sleep) plan
on spending about 2 hours trying to exit the track.  The traffic patterns
inside the track are terrible.

Bring a radio, so that you can hear what's happening around the course.

Bring lots of money for the terrible track food. :-)

Take notes and post them when you get to a terminal... :-)

Take your camera and lots of film.

If you get a chance to stand on the high bank in front of the grandstand, do
it.  The angle is impressive...

> 
> Thanks,
> 
> John
> 
> 95 911
> 
Enjoy!!!

if you have already received the original.  Thanks

Archie T. Smith
East Carolina University
Department of Sociology, Brewster A-412
Greenville, NC 27858 (919) 328-6147
Bitnet: SOASMITH@ECUVM1 Internet: SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU

- ----------------------------Original message----------------------------
Help.  I am trying to correct a problem with my right turn signal indicator.

I purchased a 1972 914 1.7 in September of last year.  I have been going
through it doing minor work from years of neglect.  Here is my problem-

When you engage the right turn signal, the park lights blink as normal but
the right turn signal indicator in the tack dial does not blink nor light
up.  Also when the hand brake is applied, the parking brake and oil temp
light in the gasoline guage dial blinks.  This blinking stops when the engine
is running.  The flasher relay is clicking both when the right turn signals
are blinking and when the parking brake/oil temp lights blink.

I have done the following:
  Replaced the flasher relay with original equip. type
  Checked the indicator bulb and bulb holder contact with ground
  Checked and cleaned the parking light contacts both front and rear
  Replaced the turn signal switch on the steering column.  (The old switch
     had a broken cancel mechanism)
  Put voltmeter on the right indicator when the right turn signals are blinking
  no voltage present when the park lights blink nor when not blinking.

I think the previous owner altered some connections behind the Tack dial to
stop the seat belt buzzer from operating when the seat belts are not connected.

I noted there are some leads with diodes.  Checked those and got voltage in
one direction and not the other as appropriate.  My schematic is a Haynes
manual and it is not very clear as to the connections.

Has anyone had this problem?
Could anyone tell me the proper connections for the signal lights?
Could I run the right indicator light connection to the terminal from the
  emergency flasher which connects the signal flasher relay to the turn
  signals?
There is a gray wire in the wiring harness that just terminates without a
connection.  I don't know if that is correct or what?  Help.

Archie T. Smith
East Carolina University
Department of Sociology, Brewster A-412
Greenville, NC 27858 (919) 328-6147
Bitnet: SOASMITH@ECUVM1 Internet: SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 14:16:51 CST
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)

A while back, I called the Speedway at 904-253-7223 and they sent me
some info.  The Speedway is by the Airport, NE of the intersection of
I-4 and I-95.

> - do I need a ticket to get in? If so, how much & where do I buy them? Also, 
> is there pit access before or during the race?

Schedule for the 33rd Rolex 24 is as follows:
  Thursday Feb 2
      12:30 -  4:00  practice and front row qualifying
       6:00 -  8:00  night practice
  Friday Feb 3
      10:00 - 11:45  practice
       1:00 -  5:00  qualifying
  Saturday Feb 4
      12:00 - 12:30  practice
       3:00 -        RACE

Here is the info I have about ticket prices.  The 4-day and pavilion passes
must be purchased by 5pm Friday:

Thursday:
  admission      - $6
  paddock        - $6
  night practice - $3

Friday:
  admission - $6
  paddock   - $6

Saturday and Sunday:
  grandstand only (unreserved)    - $25
  infield/grandstand (unreserved) - $40
  paddock                         - $25

infield car parking  - $5
infield RV parking   - $30
reserved RV packages - $195 to $420

4-day pass - $60
  includes: unreserved grandstand/infield admission plus
  paddock/garage admission and car parking (must be purchased by
  5pm friday)

"Pavilion Club" pass - $135
  includes: reserved infield grandstand, special viewing and hospitality
  areas, paddock/garage access, reserved parking, food and beverage
  services in the pavilion


> - where to stay near the track? I'm looking for an inexpensive & safe place
> to park my car while I'm there.
> - is there a PCA or PCNA presence at the event - a guest enclosure or 
> hospitality area?

There are about 80 hotels within 10 miles of the track.  I am planning
on making it a golf/race weekend, so I'll be there by Thursday night.
Anyone else going?  And does PCA or PCNA attend?

Date: 23 Jan 1995 12:40:06 U
From: "Joyce Thomas" <Joyce_Thomas@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: 356 Questions

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               356 Questions

>I have a 1961 356 B with the Super engine (a romping, stomping 75 horses).
It >has Zenith 32NDIX carbs on it (these are stock). I had the air filters
off
>yesterday and noticed that when I press the throttle, the accelerator pump
>doesn't squirt a mist of fuel, but big drops of fuel seem to just drop into
>the venturi. I assumed that this is not supposed to happen. Any suggestions
>as to what the problem might be. I disassembled the carbs and soaked them in
>carb cleaner and then used compressed air to blow out the tiny orifices. I
must
>have missed one (or more). Any suggestions would be appreciated. I am also
>soliciting suggestions about what type of spark plugs would be best to use
in
>the car (it is stock and is driven mostly in town). TIA.
>Tom Oxner

Tom,
When the injection nozzle drops (as opposed to squirts) gas into the venturi,
it is an indication that your accelerator pump is not working correctly. 
When there is volume the injector squirts, when there isn't enough
volume you get the drops.

When you disassembled the carbs you didn't mention changing the plunger or
diaphram.  My guess is this is your problem.  You need to rebuild the
accelerator pump.

Spark Plugs to use:  Bosch W225T7 
(if you can find them - Maestro do you have any?)

- --Joyce_Thomas@cpqm.saic.com
1965 356C Cabriolet
1986 944

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 12:44:15 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Engine Stand Adapters


I'm sure I posted this last week, but I am equally sure I
haven't seen it in the digests I've received.  So if this
is a duplicate posting, sorry...


Someone asked whether one could use a garden variety 
engine stand on a 911.  Yup.  No sweat.

You do need to make four little adapter gizmos that 
"compensate" for the ridge machined into the 911 
case where the transmission bolts on, but that takes 
about ten minutes.  There isn't enough flat space 
there for the arms of the engine stand to rest on, 
so you have to make flat space with the adapters.  
As usual, it's one of those things that's easy to 
do, but hard to describe.  The "adapter" is 
essentially a piece of aluminum, about 1'2" thick 
and 1" in diameter, with a hole drilled through the 
middle through which the mounting bolt goes.  One 
face of the "adapter" is cut down (you can use a 
file) to accomodate the ridge

I'm happy to send one to you to look at, actually 
faxing or mailing a drawing would be easier.  

Bob Spindel

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 15:44:55 -0500 (EST)

> Porsche.  What about boring the engine when I rebuild it? I bet its too 
> worn to just re-ring it.  This might sound silly, but I don't want to 

    Well, hey, you know you can just get new cylinders with your
pistons/rings... should be under $500.  Or you could always go for a
big-bore kit and keep the original-size parts if you ever want to sell
the car.

    Good luck!  ...lucky bastard. ;)

Nate

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 20:49:42 +0000 (GMT)
From: Timothy Pepitone <tpep@epix.net>
Subject: Re: cabrio conversion of '72 911T Targa



On Mon, 23 Jan 1995, William Dunham wrote:

> 
> I recently purchased a '72 911T Targa that was converted to a cabriolet.
> The rear window was removed, the roll bar cut off and the cab top put on.
> An appraiser that specializes in custom/exotic cars claimes that this is
> OK from the structural standpoint.  Is this correct?  How much does the roll
> bar contribute significantly to the chassis stiffness?
> Comments appreciated.
> 
	William,  From what I understand of this conversion the roll bar 
(targa band?) will unbolt from the body, no need to cut it off.  If the 
conversion was done properly the needed renforment panels should have 
been welded in.  I don't remember where but you can obtain a manual that 
covers such a conversion.  If you can get it perhaps you could check to 
see if the renforments were installed.

	Hope this helps.      TP
