Porschephiles #1094                         Mon Jan 23 22:04:05 CST 1995
Date:          Mon, 23 Jan 1995 12:56:25 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Autox and understeer

Ladies and Gentlemen, I am pleased to announce the successful
completion of  PCA Golden Gate Region's first 1995 autocross.

On January 22nd ten cars and fourteen drivers gathered together at
the Grower's Ice company in Salinas, CA for a Fun Autocross. 
Weather by and large permitted, and each driver had ten runs of
three laps each (one practice, two timed).  Top time of day (~35.3
sec) was taken by George Neidel (though it may have been his son Rob,
they were close...  Forgive me Rob, if I erred).

Most notable was the gentleman in the '89 C4 who placed fifth
overall.  He arrived with no helmet, no experience, and relatively
little clue.  He claimed to have never driven his 911s near their
limits (previous car was an '85), never been to a school, etc.  Beat
my best time by three seconds, and was two seconds better than some
fairly experienced drivers.  Congratulations to Ken.

My memory of the event is primarily of understeer (in a 911).  The
course was short, with two hairpins, which I did my best to
straighten by zealous cone rearrangement.  As we were packing up, one
of the other drivers said that low front tire pressure may have
caused some of my understeer.

I've been running with the factory recommended air pressure
(29F/32R)--is this too low?  Hank Watts (in his execeedingly cogent
work "Secrets of Solo Racing"), says 35-42 psi is the optimum range.
 However he's talking about race tires, and I'm running Bridgestone
RE71s (205/60VR15 on 6" wheels).  Should I put some more air in
there next time, or are the higher pressures only for sticky rubber?

Breathlessly awaiting the net.wisdom

Dirk
'75 911S, Brick Shithouse Red, bigtime understeer.

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 22 Jan 1995 22:26:52 -0500
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: '73 914 2.0 fuel injection

P-philes,

As a 914 newby with a lemon (no, not the color) original '73 914 2.0, I
attempted this weekend to tackle rough idle for about 60 sec. followed by
stalling. Starting the engine is never a problem. Armed with Haynes and the
914 Handbook (factory manuals are on back order forever) I gave myself a
crash course in D-jetronic.
Step 1. Get familiar with the major components and their location
Step 2. Check all the vacuum lines. Aha ! some clever mechanic interupted the
vacuum line from the airfilter to the auxiliary air regulator. Clever job too
as he just cut the line and rejoined with a wood stick. From this point on,
it was fair to assume that the auxiliary regulator was shot.
Step 3. The idle adjusting screw was in ALL the way. Probably to correct for
2.
Step 4. On initial engagement of the ignition key, the fuel pump can be
heard.
Step 5. With the ignition key on, moving the air intake valve results in
happy clicking of the injectors. So the throttle valve sensor is likely OK.
Step 6. Since I can start but not accelerate, and since idle stals after 1-2
min, I looked at the head temperature sensor. It is supposed to offer high
resistance when cold. I disconnected the sensor (infinite resistance) and now
the engine kept running. Very rich and at about 1500 rpm. Going full throttle
and back is not a problem, so the deceleration valve may be OK. Points look
OK. Upon restarting the engine logically floods.

Summary, my main problems right now are a defective auxiliary air regulator
(do they routinely break or should I just check whether there is 12V on its
line ? Resistance is close to 0 Ohm and the manual states 30 Ohm although my
mini multimeter only reads in 1K increments) and a defective head temperature
sensor.

Am I logical so far or did I miss something major. This is my first weekend
with D-Jetronic...

I looked at catalogs from Stoddard, AJ, Automotion, Performance Products,
Tweeks and Automobile Atlanta. The following points:
1. There is a VERY wide variety in who offers what.
2. Prices are all over the book. Ex. '73 2.0 Auxiliary air regulator:
     Tweeks: NA
     Performance Products: Rebuilt $41.50
     Automobile Atlanta : New $295, Used $125
     AJ Racing : $272.67
     Stoddard: $90.16
                                                              Head
temperature sensor
     Tweeks : $19.50
     Performance Products: $19.95
     Automotion: $17.95
     Automobile Atlanta: $28.00

Has anyone any better ideas ? Do I NEED the auxiliary air regulator for
anything else but starting ?

All help and comments welcome..

Bart (AllPorsche@aol.com)

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 15:10:59 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Heel-n-Toe vs. Double-Clutch

        Someone talked about heel-and-toe technique vs. double-
clutching.  Can't you do both?
        Right before you finish braking, clutch in, take car out
of gear, clutch out, blip throttle (heel & toe!), clutch in, may-
be blip throttle again, put car in gear, clutch out, finish
braking, turn in, stomp on it.  (Well, in a 914 you stomp on it;
not enough torque to break me loose in most spots.)
        Double-clutching is evidently nicer to your tranny and
maybe your clutch than just clutch-and-grind, but it takes longer.
But, as John Byrne pointed out to me, how much time are you gain-
ing, vs. how much damage are you doing to your car?  Now I shift
slower.

- --DD

Dave Darling                    914 dismantler
                                darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 15:14:58 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 wheel bearings

>Tommy (Wmson) asked about replacing wheel bearings.
>
>If the bearing is loose, try adjusting it first before giving up and
>replacing it.
        [snip!]
>You want it just snug enough so
>that you can move the large flat thrust washer under the nut or clamp with a
>large screwdriver, with some drag. You don't want it loose, you don't want
>it clamped down tight. Actually, it's really not much more than finger tight.

        What he said.  I've done this once on my car, once on a competi-
tor's car (pulled off grid for loose bearings, so I helped him out).  No
cotter pins, though, it has the Allen screw on the big clamp nut.  One
word:  better too loose than too tight, but "some drag" means a lot more
drag to some folks than to me.  My first set was too loose (just barely
acceptable) so I got the second set to where I could move the washers with
some difficulty.  Not "just barely", but not "some drag".
        This may just be a problem with me, 'cause my first valve adjust
(on a Honda) I set the valves *WAY* too loose--"some drag" again.

- --DD

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 17:07:25 -0500
From: wise@db.erau.edu (John Wise)
Subject: Ref: 24 Hours @ Daytona

John,

I work directly across the street from the track.  Although I have never
attended the race, I usually attend the time-trials during lunch.  

>>- when is the best time to arrive? I have plenty of time & can arrive 
>>several days early so if there are practice sessions etc worth seeing...

As I said, I normally go over for the practice & time trials on Thursday &
Friday.  There is a stock car museum at the track and a Corvette museum
about a mile away on the other side of I-95.  It has only been open for 6
months or so.  It is supposed to have a few old Porsche racers, but I have
not been in it to verify that fact.  And of course, there is the beach,
which is usually too cold for we FL wimps anyway.  But it is interesting to
note that where the racing used to be held before the built the speedway.  

>>- where is the track? I've checked an admittedly bad map of Daytona but 
>>can't see anything looking like a road racing circuit on it.

The race is held a the Daytona International Speedway.  It has an infield
track that is added to the high-speed oval for the 24 hours.  The Speedway
is on International Speedway Blvd (Rt 92) about 1 mile east of I-95.  

>>- do I need a ticket to get in? If so, how much & where do I buy them? 
>>Also, is there pit access before or during the race?

The tickets for the time trials are $4-$5 per day.  You can buy a ticket
for the race at the gate for a grandstand seat- I have been told - for
about $10-20.  The Infield tickets go for about $50-60 (if my memory serves
me).  

>>- where to stay near the track? 

At that time of the year you can stay down on the beach for a very
reasonable rate.  I stayed at the Sunny Shore Motel 6 years ago when I
moved down here - it is a modest but clean place right on the ocean.  Its
number is 904 252 4569.  It has several efficiencies.  

If you want to call the travel agent my University uses, call 800 252 0516
and ask for Susan.  She is a very honest and effective person (who knows
the area) and would get you a good deal.   


>>I'm looking for an inexpensive & safe place to park my car while I'm there.

I park my 77 911 in the Martin-Marietta lot right across fro the track
every day.  The 24 hour race is not an overwhelming event like the stockcar
races, so you should not have a problem finding a safe place to park.  

>>- is there a PCA or PCNA presence at the event - a guest enclosure 
>>or hospitality area?

I have not seen one in the past, but there may be one during the race.  

John

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 15:04:35 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 928 clutches


In repect to the thread about 928 clutches, they are called upon to 
launch a large, heavy object into motion from a standing start. This 
means the friction material will wear faster because it will heat from 
the work being performed.

Yes, the clutch has been revised a few times. Considering all factors, 
you should be able to get in excess of 80,000 miles (129,000Km) with 
your clutch. This will go down if you drive in bumper-to-bumper traffic 
or exclusively around town.

One nice thing about the 928, the clutch was designed so the drivetrain 
does not have to be removed as in the 924/944/968 line. Parts are 
comparable to most imports of this class. 

The 928 is a fine touring car. It has it's idyosyncracies, but it is no 
less reliable than a Jaguar or Mercedes of the same category. Just don't
refer to it as a German Corvette.

Jim Pasha

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 17:32:50 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Re: Looking for a 911 part


> ...blower motor in the luggage compartment for moving air over A/C coils
> to aid in cooling ... The motor I have is good, but it needs a new housing.
> Porsche only sells the whole assembly. ...

Our timing is just a little off.  Not long ago, my motor part failed.  I ended
up getting a new motor, but I did locate several assemblies in bone-yards. 
Parts Heaven had one for around $125.  Anyway, you may want to get a complete
assembly from salvage like that.  I understand that a motor failure is not at
all uncommon.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 15:50:20 pst
From: Jon_Kies-CC_at_ASTFIN@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Re: Autox and understeer

    Greetings Dirk,
    
    Hope you had fun at the autocross.  The RE71s have a very soft sidewall 
    (in comparison to BFG's or Yoko's) and need at *least* 40lbs to keep the 
    sidewalls from rolling over.  In fact, due to the construction of street 
    tires, street tires need more air pressure than race tires.  As an 
    example, my BFG 230's (205/50-15) run high speed time trials at 23lbs 
    hot with no rollover!
    
    For street construction tires,  mark the side and shoulder of your tire 
    with shoe polish in two or three places.  After a run, look at the shoe 
    polish to see where it has rubbed off.  If it has rubbed off below the 
    tread line on the tire shoulder, then you need to increase the 
    pressure. If there is still visible polish on the tread, then your 
    either not driving the car hard enough or you have too much air 
    pressure.  After you have your rollover correct, you can adjust your 
    tire pressure in small increments to affect handling.
    
    Please note this does not work with race tires.  They have very stiff 
    sidewalls that do not require air pressure to keep them upright.  Race 
    tires need a tire pyrometer to optimize pressure settings.
    
    IMHO, this is the way to begin adjusting tire pressures.  You may want 
    to join ($0.00) Team T/A at 1-800-RACE-BFG for the monthly newsletter.  
    They have alot interesting bits about tire construction and helpful 
    hints.
    
    Have fun,
    Jon
    


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 16:05:10 -0800 (PST)
From: Ted Rodgers <rodgers@indigo01.akctr.noaa.gov>
Subject: PCA licenses/Portland race

Barney, 

Is it a requirement to have a PCA license to enter a PCA race, assuming 
you are a PCA member, or can I run on my vintage license?

I know that SCCA and most vintage organizations honor each others 
licenses.  For example in the NW, SCCA honors ICSCC and SOVREN (vintage) 
licenses, as long as you are a SCCA member.  Vintage clubs who are 
members of the Vintage Motorsports Council all honor each others licenses 
for one race a year.

I live in Seattle and would love to enter the Portland race, but if I 
have to get an additional license for the one PCA race which is close to 
home probably won't.

------------------------------

Date: 23 Jan 95 19:19:49 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Do you believe in trolls

 
Martin Walker asks about the aerodynamic cars built in Germany.
 
They weren't Zeppelins. Maybach had a model called a Zeppelin but it was a
huge luxury tank of a car, like a Cadillac or Lincoln of the time (or
Mercedes?) The 1921 Rumpler Tropfenwagen is regarded as one of the first
attempts at streamlining, Cd only 0.28. Later examples of the streamlining
craze are the experimental cars built by Paul Jaray, the production
Hanomag, and of course the Beetle which led to the Porsche 114 which led
to the 356 which was really just a first attempt at a 911 and there you
are...
 
Speaking of an earlier thread about turbocharging and all, Ferry Porsche
used to tool around during the war in a Beetle with a supercharged VW engine
designed, I think, for stationary use at high altitudes.
 
Pete

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 20:03:40 -0500
From: Mrmojo911@aol.com
Subject: Targa Tops

Several items on the list lately about targa top interchangeability. Be
advised that the front latch design was changed in '86 so pre-86 tops will
not fit post-86 cars (and vice-versa, of course) without substantial modificat
ions (Stoddard can do it, but it ain't cheap). 

If anybody out there has a good 86+ top for sale, please e-mail me.

Charles Broome
'88 Targal

Date: 23 Jan 95 20:41:49 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 questions

 
Is the accelerator pump OK? There is a seal around the accelerator pump
plunger. (No diaphragm like most accelerator pumps). Also, did you check
and clean the two check valves at the bottom of the float bowl?
Clean the squirter jet that you can see poking into the carburetor barrel?
If the plunger seal is defective, new plungers are available for $20ish
(Twinks catalog wants nearly $30 which means it must be available elsewhere
for less).
 
(Later) I see Joyce Thomas said the same thing. Check your accelerator pump.
Use a factory manual.
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: 23 Jan 95 21:20:17 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Do you believe in trolls

 
The Rumpler Tropfenwagen was described by Jan Norbye as "a kiosk put into a
boat's hull, riding on a wagon." The thing was built in 1921.
 
>If that doesn't start a flame war, maybe you're all asleep and I'll rejoin
>T*d's list.
 
Come on, now, Bob, you own a 356 and a recent 911. Admit it, now -- doesn't
the 356 feel like the "trainer" version of the 911?
356 is to 911 what AT-6 is to P-51?
 
And if you look at very early 901/911s, they're pure 356 inside. There were
356 plans that never made it into production, but which led directly
to the 911. The 356 T7 would have had a 2-liter six-cylinder with two
camshafts, stronger 4- or 5-speed transmission. A cheaper version would have
kept the 616 engine of the 356 SC, possibly in an under-floor installation.
Later there was talk of building the 356 with the six-cylinder engine
alongside the new 901/911. Or building a 1.6 or 1.8 liter engine with parts
shared with the 901.
 
There was a memo in which it was suggested that the 356 revert to a pure
2-seater, with the space under what used to be the rear seats used for a
fuel tank, a resulting bigger front trunk, and a hatchback.
 
None of these things ever came to be.
 
All of this from Conradt's 356 book, p. 160-161.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 23 Jan 95 21:20:25 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Legislation alert

The Windblown Witness, San Diego Region PCA's newsletter, reports that
SB2050, in the California state senate, "could make it very expensive to
drive your older (pre-1990) Porsche. If you own such an older car, the state
is going to set limits on the total number of miles you can drive that car.
If you drive more, you'll be fined for the excess miles. The older the car,
the worse the penalty. The bill targets cars made between 1966 and 1979 as
the group most responsible for the high smog levels even though many of
these cars have been retrofitted with catalytic converters. If you do not
want San Diego County to act as a test case for this bill, write your
representative on the San Diego Board of Supervisors NOW! Ask them to vote
NO implementing SB2050 in San Diego as a pilot county."
 
Never mind San Diego; this is getting ridiculous. If you live in California,
write your senatecritter NOW, find out where it stands on this, and tell him
where you stand, and depending on his attitude perhaps tell him where he'll
stand next election, if you have anything to say about it.
 
This is, I think, just a thinly disguised tax. People gotta drive. If you
drive, the state wants some excuse to take more of your money. I don't think
the hidden agenda has anything to do with actually restricting miles driven.
 
This could also make a thriving market for spare speedometer/odometers.
Unless the state figures out a way to put seals on them. Swapping speedos is
no problem with most of our Porsches, but that's not the point.
 
Anyway, this has to be stopped NOW. I'll try to find the text of SB2050, but
don't know if it's online. If anybody else can help, please post it.
 
Pete

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 21:51:03 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: 912E #1 update:gonna keep it!

Jay, don't put a radio in that car!  The cover plate itself is relatively
rare, and should be retained.  Also, putting in a radio means finding a
correct, contemporary (and working) model to install, drilling a hole in the
body for an antenna, and cutting holes in the interior for speakers.  Do the
restoration correctly, regardless of how it affects the convenience of
driving the car.  I hope the expense doesn't discourage you soemwhere down
the road.
Bob Joyce
1965 356SC (an original, one-owner car)
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 21:50:54 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: First Turbos

Peter Albrecht says "Bob Joyce mentions the superchargers used on
Auburn/Cord/Duesenbergs. These are a completely different animal from
turbocharging. The first production automotive _turbos_ were definitely GM
units...."

Peter, as I said privately to someone else who responded in a similar
fashion, the writer side of me relishes debate on the semantics of words, but
the engineer side is less enthusiastic.  There is a reason Karl Ludvigsen
titled his article "The Origins of Supercharging", rather than "The Origins
of Supercharging and Turbocharging", even though he discusses turbocharging
extensively.  Any device that pressurizes the intake side of an engine is
properly a "supercharger", whether it is driven by exhaust gases or by other
means.  Engineers refer to the latter as "superchargers" and to the former as
"turbo-superchargers".  You'll notice that Ludvigsen uses the terms
"turbosupercharger" and "turbocharging" frequently in his article
(particularly on pages 189-197), but always correctly in the broad context of
supercharging.  He makes it clear that turbines driven by exhaust gases are
just another means to an end.  I suspect (though I certainly can not confirm)
the term "turbocharger" was dreamed up in some marketing maven's office,
rather than in an engineering department.  So, no, Pete, they are not
completely different animals: one is simply a subset of the other.

I agree completely with you on Ludvigsen's article.  Like everything else he
has done, this one is first-rate.

Also, I want to thank you for your contribution to English-language Porsche
literature.  The translation of Conradt's "356 Porsche" is outstanding, and
certainly makes the book widely available to an appreciative audience.

Best regards,

Bob Joyce

1965 356SC (yes, a one-owner car)
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 22:01:28 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: 356 Questions

Tom Oxner says, "...noticed that when I press the throttle, the accelerator
pump doesn't squirt a mist of fuel, but big drops of fuel seem to just drop
into the venturi. I assumed that this is not supposed to happen."
Actually, it is, Tom.  The accelerator pumps do not dispense a "mist" but
instead put out a distinct "stream" if the pedal is depressed sharply.  If
you depress it with less enthusiasm, you'll get "drops".  Probably nothing
unusual here.  Get a calibrated vial (a plugged diabetic syringe minus its
plunger works well for this) and catch the output from each pump.  I don't
know what the volume should be for Zeniths, but the outputs should be equal.
 If not, you probably need a rebuild.
Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 20:14:02 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Legislation Alert--SB2050

Ok here it is sorry for the band width for the non calif P-philers but 
watch out others states usually follow Calif. I have not yet read this 
so can't tell you what is there.

					Mike


 BILL NUMBER: SB 2050	CHAPTERED  09/30/94
	BILL TEXT

INTRODUCED BY  Senator Presley
   (Principal coauthors:  Assembly Members Goldsmith and
Richter)

	LEGISLATIVE COUNSEL'S DIGEST
   SB 2050, Presley.  Air pollution:  vehicles.
   (1) Existing law authorizes each air pollution control
district and air quality management district to modify its
emission reduction strategy if the State Air Resources Board
makes a specified finding.
   This bill would require the districts and the state board,
for that purpose, to take into account specified district and
state programs.
   The bill would require the San Diego County and Ventura
County Air Pollution Control Districts, in their triennial plan
review, to determine the target pollution miles per vehicle, as
defined, and to reduce that figure by 5% annually.
   The bill would require a decal disclosing the smog index, as
defined, for each vehicle, as determined by the state board, to
be affixed to a new motor vehicle, except as specified, prior to
the sale or registration of the vehicle.  The bill would
require certain information to be affixed to a used motor
vehicle offered for sale by a dealer.
   (2) Existing law requires the state board to adopt emission
standards for used motor vehicles.
   This bill would authorize the Bureau of Automotive Repair to
develop and make available to the public a list of maintenance
practices designed to improve a motor vehicle's operating
efficiency, and would provide for reduction of the vehicle's
smog index if a test shows that emissions are reduced.
   The bill would require the Department of Consumer Affairs to
develop a program to certify emissions retrofit devices, as
defined.
   These provisions would become inoperative upon a specified
finding by the Environmental Protection Agency.
   (3) Existing law defines "low-emission motor vehicle" for
certain purposes in state law.
   This bill would include in that definition a vehicle that has
been modified by the use of an emissions retrofit device.
   (4) Existing law requires the test at smog check stations to
include specified items and establishes criteria for smog check
stations to issue a certificate of compliance or a certificate
of noncompliance.
   This bill would establish additional criteria for the
issuance of those certificates based on the target pollution
miles of a motor vehicle, and for the issuance of odometer
certificates of noncompliance.  The bill would require the
Bureau of Automotive Repair to develop a program to biennially
inspect motor vehicle odometers at smog check stations, and to
notify the smog check stations of the target pollution miles, as
specified.  The bill would, in the San Diego County and Ventura
County Air Pollution Control Districts, require the test at
smog check stations to include determinations relating to the
odometer and target pollution miles, and would require a smog
check after one year if the prescribed mileage is exceeded.  The
bill would require the bureau to provide for a test of the
extent to which vehicles exceed expected test levels of ozone
precursors.
   (5) The bill would require the state board to establish a
repair subsidy program and an emissions credit exchange program,
as specified.
   (6) Existing law authorizes a district to levy a specified
fee on motor vehicle registrations.
   This bill would authorize the San Diego County and Ventura
County Air Pollution Control Districts to increase that fee by
$1 to implement the pilot program established by the bill.  The
bill, except for that fee increase authority, would not become
operative until the districts have sufficient funds to implement
the pilot program, as specified.
   (7) The bill would impose a state-mandated local program by
imposing new duties on the districts, and by changing the
definition of a crime relating to pollution control equipment of
vehicles.
  (8) The California Constitution requires the state to
reimburse local agencies and school districts for certain costs
mandated by the state.  Statutory provisions establish
procedures for making that reimbursement.
   This bill would provide that no reimbursement is required by
this act for specified reasons.
   (9) The bill, except as specified, would not become operative
until a specified system for the electronic filing of
certificates of compliance or noncompliance is determined by the
Department of Consumer Affairs to be operational, as specified,
and, except as specified, would become inoperative 5 years from
its operative date and would be repealed on the January 1
following that inoperative date


- -- 
- --
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Porschephiles #1095                         Tue Jan 24 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 23:53:37 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Are Early 930s Grenades?

I'm so confused.  Are 1976 and 1977 3.0 930 cars set up like NASCAR
qualifyers?

I just got my new PML and I see a couple of '76 930s asking prices in the mid
teens.  As I am search for my 911SC coupe, I noticed these Turbo prices and
wonder why not? I love the look and don't plan to autocross (I've read about
the difficult handling with the turbos throttle lag).  The only two I've
driven were modified (bigger turbo and Lots-O-Lag) but provided huge grins
and many giggles when boosted.

The front cover article mentions small brakes and turbo failures.  Are the
brakes the same as an SC? Could they be upgraded to the 78-newer brakes or
something better yet?

Several years ago I spoke with an engineer from Garrett regarding turbo
failures, I was told the most common failures was a result of poor habits
(failure to idle the car after a run to cool down the turbochargers bearings
 - of particular concern when not water-jacketed), or poor maintenance
(infrequent oil changes or restricted air filters).

Everyone I've talked to warns me to stay away, but no one seems to have any
substantive experience, only rumor and innuendo.

Were the 3.0 engines themselves a problem with this setup?

I've read that the SC was actually the faster car.

What other problems do they have?

Do any of you have experience with an actual purchase and ownership of such a
car in recent years?  

A 930 Jones on a 911 budget,
Peter Leckband
the Search goes on

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 23:34:13 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Digest-PLEASE

Fred Hess suggests:

> >Could I please recieve the digest version. This list is HUGE.
>        
>    May I sugest that we help out our fellow lost porschephiles
> by sending them a copy of the FAQ when administrative requests
> are sent to the list. Should we be sending the FAQ or a copy
> of the Welcome To Porschephiles that I (and probably all) received
> when added to the list?

I greatly appreciate all the suggestions and help that gets offered,
so I guess I ought to tell you how things work.

WHEN THINGS GO RIGHT

A prospective new member/transfer to-from digest/etc message is
sent to "porschephile-request@tta.com". There it gets dumped in a file
with a lot of other list admin related mail. Once a day or so, I run
a couple of pre-processing scripts on the file, stripping out the 
failed mail messages for processing by something else and leaving me with
the 12-20 *real* messages out of the 500-1200 I started with. 

I read each of them, and either reply personally, or forward it to an
automatic agent. If the person asks for a status change, like getting
digest, or dropping or whatever, they get a terse one line response
saying what has been done, a log is updated, and the thing happens.
If they're asking to join the list, they get a welcome message, a copy
of the FAQ, and a survey questionaire.

Also in this category are people who send me direct personal notes
having either developed a realationship with me over time, or having
gotten my name from someone else. These I just handle, often with a 
personal note back.

WHEN THINGS GO WRONG

Some bone-head posts to the list as a whole instead of having bothered to
READ any of the stuff mailed them when they joined as noted above. These
vermin are then solicited by Bart Chambers to READ THE FUCKING RULES
even though he's a lot more polite about it than I am. He cc's the
admin address on his note to them, and the right thing happens. 

I'm particulaly keen to drop people that misdirect their requests since
if they can't read, I have no use for them. I'm much less keen to add
people that send "please sign me up" notes to the whole world, because
the *ONLY* published address for this list is that of the admin address.
If I get a big rush of those at once, I always ask where they got the
address, then send Julio the $25 assassin after the originator of this
confusion...

So, your concerns and offers of assistence are appreciated, but things are
as they say pretty well covered...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 23:39:37 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: cabrio conversion of '72 911T Targa

> The rear window was removed, the roll bar cut off and the cab top put on.
> An appraiser that specializes in custom/exotic cars claimes that this is
> OK from the structural standpoint.  Is this correct?  How much does the roll
> bar contribute significantly to the chassis stiffness?
> Comments appreciated.

I looked at this a great deal when I found myself in possession of a
911 targa and three late electric cab tops (complete) at the same
time once...

Near as I could tell, the cab got one or two more pieces of stiffening
than the targa from '83-85, then from '86 on it was the same tub.
So given that you're not talking about an exceptionally stiff car
to begin with, I'm inclined to believe that it's not that greatly
compromised. It's not the roll bar that makes it stiffer nearly so
much as some of the other stuff welded in. 

On the other hand, I'd personally want a good roll bar in my cab before
I put it on the track (even though the PCRs says you don't have to do
this if the car is stock).

My decision? I sold the tops for a net of about $10k. MUCH smarter than
hacking up my car...

Stan

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 02:30:22 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 356 Questions

Dear Tom:

          Your Zenith Carbs may suffer from a worn acc pump diaphragm (or one
that has been replaced with an inferior red rubber gizmo instead of the
Original Leather). This can cause low flow to the nozzles. Also, the
injection nozzles are rather small and need to be blown out exceedingly
thorougly. Make sure the WD-40 comes out of the nozzles in a strong stream-
and blow in both directions.  Also- the adjustment rod can be
lenghtened/shortened to adjust the volume of fuel from the acc pump nozzles.
And note that there are THREE positions that you can attach the top of the
vertical rod to. As you progress inward, the volume injected goes up. If you
have the vertical rod on the hole furthest out, try moving it in to the
middle position. Then measure the amount of fuel ejaculating from the acc
pump nozzle. (Though you need a special calibrated collector to do this, it
can be made from an eyedropper in a pinch.)
     Incidentally, if you have a Super Carb, you should have 220 Air
Correction Jets (the big brass ones as viewed when looking down inside the
big hole in the top of the carb).  Looking further down the hole at the
venturis, you should see a "28" cast into them. (Normals have 24mm Venturis
with 230 Air Correction Jets and C's have 210 Air Correction Jets with 28mm
Venturis.
     As to plugs, I like Bosch  W5AC's on an Unknown Engine (they're
NON-extended tip so have the greatest chance of not being hit by a piston).
On engines I know (or have built), I like the Bosch W6BC's, with the extended
tip. On Super-90's I like the W225T-7 plugs, but they're exceedingly rare
these days, so I only use them on Super-90's.

 KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro

Porschephiles #1096                         Tue Jan 24 12:26:50 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 24 Jan 95 01:02:34 PST
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: More on Russell Racing School


Bill Van Bibber asked, ". . . what are the opinions of you racers out there on 
the various driving schools?" 
 
While I'm not a racer and I haven't been to any of the other schools for 
comparison, I did take the three day Russell Racing School "Techniques of 
Racing" course last winter at Laguna Seca and had the time of my life! 
 
The Formula Fords seemed to be very well-maintained, there was a lot of seat 
time, and by the end of the three days all thirteen people in the class were 
lapping Laguna Seca with confidence and steadily lowering their lap times . . 
. in the rain! 
 
While I was definitely in the slower half of the class, that didn't diminish 
the excitement or the feeling of accomplishment when I finally found the grove 
and knocked a dramatic 10 seconds off my best lap time to that point. 
 
There's nothing like having your instructor standing at the start-finish line 
applauding to make you feel like a million dollars! 
 
I would heartily recommend the experience to anyone who has even the slighest 
interest in racing . . . for the pure fun of it if for no other reason. 
 
By the way, upon successful completion of the course all you need to do to is 
join SCCA ($55) and pass the physical to be eligible to obtain your SCCA 
Regional ($45) or National ($100) Competition License. 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@us.oracle.com) 
1962 356B Super90 Cabriolet 



------------------------------

Date: Tue, Jan 24, 1995 8:44 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: First Turbos

I tried, Lord *knows* I tried....  I bit my tongue and clenched my few 
remaining teeth...but that old devil makes me jump right back in...

> Peter Albrecht says "Bob Joyce mentions the superchargers used on
> Auburn/Cord/Duesenbergs. These are a completely different animal from
> turbocharging. The first production automotive _turbos_ were definitely GM
> units...."

and he's right, they *are* completely different animals.  Rephrase Pete's 
comment this way: "The superchargers used on A/C/D are completely different 
animals than the superchargers used on the GM cars"

As I noted privately to someone who shall remain forever anonymous (Bob Joyce),
the difference between the mechanically driven supercharger and the exhaust
gas driven supercharger is *quite* significant.  Perhaps I didn't make the
point adequately clear to my learned, but anonymous correspondent.  The 
significance is that the switch to turbocharging made, for the first,
all the attendant blessings of supercharging to the hoards of the unwashed 
(well, me for instance).  Prior to GM's introduction of the Buick/Olds in '62
(OK, I still remember it as '61, but what can I say?), supercharging was only 
found on *Big* ticket items not available to the hoi-polli (e.g., MBz 500 K 
series, "Blower" Bentleys, A/C/D...you get the picture).

Today, thanks to the pioneering efforts of General Bullmoose, turbos can be 
found within the reach of nearly everyone.  Now ask, where can you buy a 
(mechanically driven) supercharger?

> I agree completely with you on Ludvigsen's article.  Like everything else he
> has done, this one is first-rate.
> 
> Also, I want to thank you for your contribution to English-language Porsche
> literature.  The translation of Conradt's "356 Porsche" is outstanding, and
> certainly makes the book widely available to an appreciative audience.

Now *that* is wisdom, but what would one expect from a man with the class,
perspicacity and all-around good taste he demonstrates in being the original
owner of a '65 356C?  (Not to mention, being a member of this erudite list...)

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora
'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 09:41:50 EST
From: James J Dempsey <jjd@spserv.bbn.com>
Subject: Re: Legislation Alert--SB2050 

> 	I wish you Californians would get control of your gov't. Now 
> everybody's leaving CA and crowding us here in CO. I am even starting to 
> see air polution here in Vail valley! (Mostly from the woodburning 
> fireplaces, though).

And worse, other states look to CA to decide what legislation to
adopt.

For example, a bunch of New England states (incl. my state, the
Peoples Republic of Massachusetts) have decided to adopt California's
air-cleanliness rules soon.

There will be no such thing as a 49-state car anymore...

Those of you looking at the problem legislation mentioned in the
previous messages and saying "Good thing that isn't happening here"
better think again.  If it goes over in CA, it is likely to be seen in
other states soon.

As Peter Albrecht suggests, I wish there was an NRA for motorists...

		--Jim Dempsey--
		jjd@bbn.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 10:46:37 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: steering rattle

Kristian writes:

        I get a very noticeable rattle felt in the steering wheel as 
well as some clunking when going over very rough roads, such as washboard
or packed snow.  Any good ideas of the usually culprits for this?  Where
are the first places to check, perhaps there are some rubber bushings
that could be worn?
======================
Kristian:
	when I first bought my 944, I also had a very hard rattle when I went
over a bump on the road. I would shake the whole steering wheel. It turned
out to be a bad strut. It had leaked all its fluid and was not working!

Easy way to check would be to look around the strut/spring/hub for signs of
wetness/embedded dirt. Also you can bounce the offending corner up/down
to check the strut.

You could also have have bad ball joints. I think in your car, they are 
removed by drilling pop rivets out and using bolts for the new ones.

One more thing to check, would be the upper strut bearing. THis is where the
strut mounts to the body. They have some needle bearings and a rubber mount.

I changed all those parts on my car. Big difference!
Hope this helps...

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 15:41:06 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Superchargers on current production motors



When the VW Corrado was first announced - around 2-3 years ago, an option
for the v6 engine was a trick combination supercharger. I recollect that
it used both a belt and exhaust gas drive, the idea being to get better
low revs torque from the belt, then benefit from the turbo at higher revs. 

I don't know if they ever went production on that jobby.

Pete

| From   : Peter Diffey         |

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 10:20:53 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: RE> First Turbos

        I know that this isn't an *automotive* use for them, but I
recall from my researches into WWII aircraft (especially fighters)
that many used a "Turbo-supercharger" to get adequate high-altitude
performance.  Not sure if it was exhaust-driven, but that's what
they called 'em.
        They also had the "dial-a-boost" feature that you can find
in some aftermarket Turbo set-ups.

- --DD

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 10:11:45 -0600
From: jeff@arion.com (Jeff Mayzurk)
Subject: Re: Superchargers on current production motors

>When the VW Corrado was first announced - around 2-3 years ago, an option
>for the v6 engine was a trick combination supercharger. I recollect that
>it used both a belt and exhaust gas drive, the idea being to get better
>low revs torque from the belt, then benefit from the turbo at higher revs.
>
>I don't know if they ever went production on that jobby.

Never heard of anything like that, but for the first two years of the
Corrado's production, it was available in the U.S. *only* with a 1.8 liter
G60 (G-lader supercharger, 60mm diameter) motor. The 8V motor made just
over 150bhp, but was later dropped completely in favor of the much nicer
VR6 motor. In Europe, a smaller version of the G-lader supercharger was/is
also available on the VW Polo.

Anyone how the G-lader differs from a Roots blower or any other type of
belt-driven sueprcharger? I don't remember the details but supposedly it's
just as efficient but without the parasitic drag of a "conventional"
blower.

Other production cars I can think of that use belt-driven superchargers:
MkI Toyota MR2, Ford Thunderbird SuperCoupe, various late-model Buicks with
3.8L motor, probably more.... no Porsches, though.


- --
Jeff Mayzurk
<jeff@arion.com>



- --
Jeff Mayzurk
eljefe@mail.utexas.edu

Date: 24 Jan 95 12:11:45 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Restoring steering wheels

Hi, Ted.
 
Restoring wheel -- I didn't find green stuff underneath, I found gray stuff
underneath, apparently a lacquer primer, and black plastic (Bakelite?) below
that. I first built up the worn down finger ridges with epoxy, using two
brass templates (circumferential and radial) to check the profile while filing
and sanding to shape (very tedious and involved). Once the shape was correct
and smooth, I primed with a heavy coat of SEM Prime, intended for bumpers
and various plastic car bits. That was sanded down with 400 grit. Then about
8 layers of BASF R-M black acrylic lacquer with suitable thinner and the
right flash time. After overnight hardening, two more light coats with
mostly thinner. Bake in oven for a couple of hours. Polish out using 2000
grit wet sanded, and Glasurit polishing compound. Absolutely
indistinguishable from an unused wheel. It will take you about 2 solid days
of work.
 
Pete

Date: 24 Jan 95 12:11:50 EST

BOB356@aol.com

OK, you're right, turbochargers are a subset of all superchargers. I guess

first with a car application, although I think they were used on big trucks
long before that.
 
Thanks for your comments on the Conradt book.

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re: 912E #1 update:gonna keep it!
Author:  Bob356@aol.com at internet
Date:    1/23/95 7:12 PM


Jay, don't put a radio in that car!  The cover plate itself is relatively 
rare, and should be retained.  Also, putting in a radio means finding a 
correct, contemporary (and working) model to install, drilling a hole in the 
body for an antenna, and cutting holes in the interior for speakers.  Do the 
restoration correctly, regardless of how it affects the convenience of 
driving the car.  I hope the expense doesn't discourage you soemwhere down 
the road.
Bob Joyce
1965 356SC (an original, one-owner car) 
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper


------------------------------

Date: 24 Jan 95 12:11:53 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 questions

 
Bob Joyce correctly points out that if you work the throttle linkage too
slowly, you will just get drops, not a squirt of fuel from the accelerator
pump.
 
The syringe idea is pretty good. You can also pay some money to get an
official glass vial which you will probably drop down the throat anyway if
you don't make a little wire holder for it. Performance Products, Stoddard,
and others carry these.
 
The manual calls for a squirted volume of 0.2 to 0.3 cc, for TWO STROKES of
the accelerator, per squirter. Rapid strokes, all the way to the stop.
This applies to both the 1600 and 1600 Super. The volume is adjusted by
turning the tiny turnbuckle on the short vertical link to the accelerator pump.
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 10:26:23 -0700 (MST)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 95 12:55:15 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Help, have severe vibration at idle 86 - 944

>  My '86 944 really vibrates from idle to about 1200 rpm.
> I had thought motormount but wiggling engine seems to look
> like they are ok. Any suggestions? Is there a retrofit replacement?
> I priced oem and went into sticker shock. Are they some kind of 
> hydrolic shock? Are they difficult to replace? The haynes manual is
> rather cryptic on this point. Thanks in advance to any tips you might have.
> 

Yep, bad motor mount.  Probably the one on the passenger side, by the
exhaust.


Wiggling won't show whether it is good or not.  There is a procedure in the
factory service manual, but the real test is:

1) Steering wheel shakes at idle.
2) Steering wheel stops shaking at about 1600-1800 rpm.

Fix: Replace it with the latest motor mount, about $115 new from OEM.

Tips, have someone with an alignment rack with dollies do it.  He can do it
in about an hour, if he's good.


- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 95 13:09:00 PST
From: Shafer Kirk <ShaferK@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: 944 rear underbody ground connections


Poking around under the rear of my '88 944 I found two badly corroded ground 
connections, one on each side of the underbody just in front of the 
trans/diff unit.  These ground wires also have what I assume is a 
power/signal partner wire along side going to somewhere further in the rear 
of the car.  This car has 137K miles and has seen more than its fair share 
of salt - but I pamper it a little more these days.

What system do these ground connections pertain to?  Have not yet procured a 
fiche machine with which to view my recently acquired fiche manual set. 
 Haynes nearly useless.  I would not expect rear tail light wiring to be 
routed along the underbody so I'm guessing fuel pump power, trans/diff 
switches?

This car has a multi-year chronic problem of stumbling at idle and under 
acceleration in cold ambient conditions irrespective of engine compartment 
temp.  Snow has kept me from test driving since I reworked these grounds to 
see if it improved anything - it's a long shot.

Thank you to anyone's response.  Mail me direct [shaferk@indy.tce.com] and 
I'll post ONE summarized response.  Bandwidth is a terrible thing to waste.

Kirk
'88 944
'88 900S "Troll" (sacrificial salt car)
'94 900S (SO's Troll)

succeeds in implementing other crazy states follow!

BTW, as editor of the San Diego Region BMW CCA newsletter, I believe 
there are a number of people organizing to combat this bill in 
addition to selective boycotting of the sponsors.  Please contact me 
direct for more info.  We "lost" the front man, director(?) of the San 
Diego Auto Museum, but I believe the momentum is building.  It has 
been a heated discussion in every Board Meeting since November.

If you own a car of modle year *1982* or later, it is considered "old" 
in this bill proposal. Thought you might like to know.
===================================================================== Fahr 
schnell, sei vorsichtig, hab Spass

Date:         Tue, 24 Jan 95 13:15-0500
From: Ken.Stanton@QueensU.CA
Subject:      Water cooled. Oil light troubles...

High folks. Perhaps one of you has been down this road before and could lend
a hand. My $$931 is preserving itself quite well by leaking oil all over its
underside. It appears to be starting from that invisible point at the back of
the head where the sending unit for the oil pressure guage is located. The
guage seems to be working. The idiot light is not working. The book shows
part numbers for an oil pressure light switch and a sending unit for the guage.
Since the light is not working I suspect the switch for the light may be
the source of the oil leak. Now the tricky part: I can see (sorta) the sending
unit for the guage at the back of the head although it looks like it would be
one hell of a job to replace, but I do not see the switch for the light.
Where did they hide it?? And (b), how does one access the stuff back there
to replace it if they in fact hid it near the guage sending unit? Looks to
me like at the very least the distributor drive housing has to come off in
addition to all the usual stuff up by the firewall. Suggestions?
Please email me directly as I have not yet signed on again to the list. I
will be likely be moving to a new address soon so I have spared Stan the
extra task of switching my alias around ;-)

Cheers. Ken.Stanton@QueensU.CA
     '81 924 Turbo aka White Car From Hell.

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 12:05:40 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 track car

> I have a 1975  914 2.0 with a siezed engine. The enging has webber
> carbureators.  The car has oil coolers and 911 sc brakes. It had a six and
> now has a 4 again. I want to build a car for autocrossing and track events. 

As previously noted, I'm real big on making sure you pick where you're
going to play *FIRST*, then decide on how you're going to do it...
If you have 911 brakes, that probably means that you have 911 front
suspension and God only knows what sorts of other mods, which means you're
*WAY* deep in the weeds as far as being competitive. That would be an
SCCA FP autox car, or a GT-3 (with a 4) or GT-2 (with a 6) race car; for
PCA, it will depend on where you live as to how you're classed.

Bottom line, if this is your first attempt at doing things like this,
give up on two concepts: 1) having the "right stuff" and (2) being
competitive. It just won't happen. What *CAN* happen is that you'll
get a lot of seat time, learn a lot about how to drive, what other people
are doing, etc, and most importantly HAVE A LOT OF FUN!!!

> 1) Will a carbureated engine make the same amount of power as a injected
> engine?

Done right, no way in hell. Done the way most people do it, however, carbs
make more power because people either don't know how to tune FI or
won't spend the money for the right parts.

*HOWEVER*, if you're going road racing in SCCA, you must run carbs in
any class this car might be in. So you gotta figure that part out first...

> 2) Should I consider using a good running injected 1.8 that I have?

YES!!! That will get you in the car, get you some seat time, and let you
think about what you really want to do. Work on improving *YOUR* times
not on "beating people" or "buying a win". You can do that with a 
used lawnmower engine, it does NOT require a 962 under the hood...


> I have a machine shop that I can use so only the parts are a cost factror.

Sure, once you get past the skills to set things up right, etc....
Look at what people who are winning NATIONALLY do in the classes that
your interested in. And don't forget that lots of us hang out on this
list...

Stan

------------------------------

Date:         Tue, 24 Jan 95 13:27-0500
From: Ken.Stanton@QueensU.CA
Subject:      CIS/Ice Cream Machine

One other thing is getting on my nerves wrt operating a $931 during the
cold months. Under _EXTREMELY_  cold conditions, ice forms around the air
sensor plate and bogs the whole thing up in a big way. Kelvin Ross and I
had a most evil experience last winter making this discovery but that is
another [lengthy] story :-)
Anyhow, under the worst conditions, it coats the entire air filter and filter
housing right on through to the throat of the turbo with ice cream. A nasty
thought when you visualize what a freed chunk of ice could do to a turbine
at high speed.  Anybody else had this trouble? Any easy solutions?
Again, please email me directly at Ken.Stanton@QueensU.CA.
Thanks folks. Ken.

P.S. Anybody have any experience with fusion welding to repair cracked
manifolds, heads, combustion chambers, other bits and pieces? A mechanic
here tells me wonderful things about it so I am hopeful about repairing
all those cracked $931 manifolds. (The exhaust manifold was available
for the small price of about $1200 the last time I checked. _ALL_  $931's
have cracked exhaust manifolds and usually cracked intake manifolds as well.
It's just one of those lovely *features* )

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 95 12:17:04 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Bought a 944-now the questions begin!

| From: "Colin O'Keefe"  <oreilly@crl.com>
|
| On this model, is the coolant fan supposed to
| come on regularly in traffic?  The temperature gauge is always about in
| the middle when on the highway, but it goes past the 3/4 mark in traffic
| and the fan comes on.  The fan always goes off when the gauge has gone
| back to 1/2.

This sounds normal. The fan shouldn't be coming on when cruising but it
will run when in stop and go traffic.

| I will be changing the coolant soon- I think it's been over
| a year.  By the way, I have some new Prestone in a yellow bottle that the
| Kragen people say is phosphate free.  The label say's it's OK for
| aluminum engines.  Is this right, or should I be looking for the grey
| bottles that have been mentioned here?

Others have stated that the grey is the only Prestone that is actually
phosphate free. I decided to not take any chances and bought
Autobahn coolant from the dealer (and paid dearly for it!). If you
flush the system, you will need to bleed it after refilling. Bleeding to
remove trapped air is simple but tricky. Ask if you want more info.

| Now that the big things are done, I want to start concentrating on some
| of the minor mechanical and cosmetic  details:
| - Anyone know how the rear hatch release switch fits together?  My switch
| triggers the hatch release when it's barely touched, then has to be
| wobbled before it shuts off the power.  I've disconnected it for fear
| that it will pop the back while I'm driving.  Maybe it's missing a part?
| Anywhere I can order a new switch to solder in there?

The hatch switch is the same basic part as the window lift switches. No
soldering necessary as they plug into a receptacle. I tried repairing
one with no luck so I replaced it with a good condition used one.
You might want to check with George Bueselinck of 944 Ecology
(bbs!George.Beuselinck@intel.mhv.net).

| - The cruise control stalk was taken apart when I got the car.  I have
| all the pieces....  Anywhere I can get a diagram of how they fit
| together?  I don't feel comfortable doing this by trial and error.

I have the factory service manuals for the 944, but since the interior
of the early 944's are the same as the 924, one would need the 924
service manual for that. Was the cruise stalk actually unplugged and
completely removed? The steering wheel might need to be removed
to put it back together, but it is not hard to remove the wheel if you have
the right sized socket.

Good Luck with your new toy!

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 95 12:24:35 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Help, have severe vibration at idle 86 - 944

| From:  <beaton@rb.unisys.com>
|
|  My '86 944 really vibrates from idle to about 1200 rpm.
| I had thought motormount but wiggling engine seems to look
| like they are ok. Any suggestions? Is there a retrofit replacement?
| I priced oem and went into sticker shock. Are they some kind of
| hydrolic shock? Are they difficult to replace? The haynes manual is
| rather cryptic on this point. Thanks in advance to any tips you might have.

Yup, bad motor mounts. The dealer is way too expensive. Zim's and
Vertex have the best prices; about $120 apiece. They are in fact
hydraulically damped shock absorbers. The right hand side usually
goes first because of the exhaust heat although on my '84 with 130K
miles both were bad. An experienced mechanic with the correct tools
can do both in about 2  hours. While not technically difficult, it is not
a good first project for the budding amateur mechanic. There have
been quite a few messages on this topic, so there is probably some
good info in the archives.

    Eric

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 12:35:51 -0800 (PST)
From: Ryan John Cousineau <rcousine@sfu.ca>
Subject: Re: Early Turbos


> Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 21:50:54 -0500
> From: Bob356@aol.com
> Subject: Re: First Turbos
> 
> Peter Albrecht says "Bob Joyce mentions the superchargers used on
> Auburn/Cord/Duesenbergs. These are a completely different animal from
> turbocharging. The first production automotive _turbos_ were definitely GM
> units...."
> 
> Peter, as I said privately to someone else who responded in a similar
> fashion, the writer side of me relishes debate on the semantics of words, but
> the engineer side is less enthusiastic.  There is a reason Karl Ludvigsen
> titled his article "The Origins of Supercharging", rather than "The Origins
> of Supercharging and Turbocharging", even though he discusses turbocharging
> extensively.  Any device that pressurizes the intake side of an engine is
> properly a "supercharger", whether it is driven by exhaust gases or by other
> means.  Engineers refer to the latter as "superchargers" and to the former as
> "turbo-superchargers".  You'll notice that Ludvigsen uses the terms
> "turbosupercharger" and "turbocharging" frequently in his article
> (particularly on pages 189-197), but always correctly in the broad context of
> supercharging.  He makes it clear that turbines driven by exhaust gases are
> just another means to an end.  I suspect (though I certainly can not confirm)
> the term "turbocharger" was dreamed up in some marketing maven's office,
> rather than in an engineering department.  So, no, Pete, they are not
> completely different animals: one is simply a subset of the other.
> 

I'm a bit ambivalent here. Turbochargers and Superchargers accomplish the 
same end (raising air pressure over atmospheric) with pumping systems 
(which distinguishes them from ram-air systems), but the engineering of 
each is quite different. A supercharger typically turns at some 
ratio of engine speed, ie relatively low rpm. A turbocharger is turning 
much faster (I'm not sure about the exact numbers, you'd probably know 
better. Is 50k rpm out of line?). The upshot is the two devices are 
rather different animals. Not as different from each other as ram air is 
from either, but I think the engineering differences are more significant 
than you suggest.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 15:47:53 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 1972 Irish Green


Dear Archie,

Assuming you have an original dual indicator arrow tach in your car, go to
the back of the tach and with the switch in the right hand, turn position
check the black with white wire for ground. If it is not grounding, go to the
back of the column where the turn signal leadd exits and again check the
black with white wire for grounding (car on or off). If it doesn't ground
(quickly check the left in a like manner to see if it does) then plug in a
new switch.

Archie, there are thousands of 914 parts we have not listed in the catalog.
Always rest assured we have everything you need to perfectly restore your
914. The rear window guide you need is a part sold only with the side glass;
it is not available individually and we have not had enough call to have the
part made. Make sure it is not in the bottom of the door - look carefully. I
have missed them before! If you then still need the part, it is unfortunately
expensive (45.00 used) and in short supply. We have it if you need it.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 15:46:09 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Aftermarket Wheels


Dear Tommy,

We always use the Forza because it resembles the factory 935 wheel. Easily
mounted (the hub requires a spacer), it is one of the nicest aftermarket
wheels we have seen for a 914.

Send me your address and I will send you something of interest.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 95 16:05:00 PST
From: Shafer Kirk <ShaferK@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: Re: FW: Bought a 944-now the questions begin!



>Bleeding to
>remove trapped air is simple but tricky. Ask if you want more info.
>
>Good Luck with your new toy!
>
>    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red




"...simple but tricky."   Hmmm....."...easy but hard."   WHAT!!!

All I do is loosen the air bleed screw as the engine warms (with heater 
control on MAX heat) and wait til the bleeder spews pure, steady coolant 
(not foam, bubbles, etc.).  Then I close the bleeder screw.  Done.  Are 
there more "tricks" I don't know of?  Please expound.  I don't want to blow 
up my cooling system.

I did have a little engine temp trouble at a 90 degree track event last July 
(temp needle at very top of OK range) so maybe I do have air in my cooling 
circuit or something.  I also had an overly rich coolant mixture - more 
antifreeze than H2O - which I learned recently is not a smart idea for 
efficient heat removal.

Kirk
'88 944

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 95 15:49:58 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; modifying 912e vin #1, whats OK


       Theres hardly a thing that you could do to your 912 that would
     be impossible to restore back to concours condition later...at a 
     price...Even something like putting in a JC Whitney Sunroof could
     conceivably be replaced or repaired. 912 and 911 donor parts just ain't
     that hard to find...

       If a change makes you happier to drive the car, do it. New seats, 911
     gauges, an a/c system that works...all good fun. In my own opinion,
     adding a whaletail and fiberglass 930 flares isn't a good idea from 
     taste or practicality, but if anyone ever wanted to restore it to 
     Pebbles Beach Concours condition (not likely, I think) unless you
     throw away everything you pull off or take a Stihl saw to the chassis,
     it can be redone. Restorers have resurrected cars much worse off 
     without the parts supply legacy that these high-production Porsches 
     have.... 

       The one thing you might consider is shelving your #0003 engine,
     though. I don't know how expensive cores are but that original case
     is the one thing you'd have trouble finding a replacement for....
     And if it needs to be rebuilt, why not start off with another core ? 
     Ditto any kind of replacement part (master cylinder, alternator, starter
     etc) don't ever give them back as a core for a rebuilt part. Keep them
     even after they go bad. 
                                    
       Enjoy your car, but don't get obsessed with it. Its all only sheet
     metal and unique facts are more fun than value. Pano had an article
     on early Vin 911s, my favorite had over 300k miles on it. Truly a car
     that had been loved. 
     
        Lee A. owner of the only Flying V guitar Gibson shipped in '74 
                (but who cares ??)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 13:30:21 -0600
From: smaardyk@rs6000.houston.wireline.SLB.COM
Subject: Turbo-superchargers on Aircraft


From Dave Darling:

>>         I know that this isn't an *automotive* use for them, but I
>> recall from my researches into WWII aircraft (especially fighters)
>> that many used a "Turbo-supercharger" to get adequate high-altitude
>> performance.  Not sure if it was exhaust-driven, but that's what
>> they called 'em.
>>         They also had the "dial-a-boost" feature that you can find
>> in some aftermarket Turbo set-ups.

Last summer I had a tour of the newly restored B-17 owned by the local
chapter of the CAF - even got to stand very near the side of the runway
during its take-off roll.  What a thrill!

Anyway, the B-17 has a two-stage system for boost.  The first stage
is a turbocharger driven by exhaust gases.  The second stage is a
supercharger which is built onto the engine and gear-driven from the
crank shaft (or maybe flywheel).  I can't remember just how they are
used but I believe the CAF 'Colonel' said they were controllable
from the cockpit.


------------------------------

Date: 24 Jan 1995 16:41:14 -0500
From: "Mohr Bob" <mohr_bob@po.gis.prc.com>
Subject: Bart and Petards

bc> Magnus Ottenstrom hoists ol' Bart by his own Petard: 
bc> 
bc> (don't ask me to explain what that means, the explanation in my
bc> dictionary dosen't make a bit of sense to me either...):

     Let it work;
For 'tis sport, to have the engineer
Hoist with his own petard; and it shall go hard
But I will delve one yard below their mines,
And blow them at the moon.
                       Hamlet. III, iv.

A petard was an iron weapon  of sorts, filled with gunpowder  fastened to
gates, barricades, etc. to blow them up.  Danger was that person who fired the
weapon could get blown up (hoisted) by the the explosion, IOW beaten with his
own weapon.

And francophones would recognize petard as slang meaning fart.

and fart rhymes with  <vbg>...well I don't think Otto was going that far .

Bob

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 16:00:48 -0700 (MST)
From: Wilson Luther <Luther.Wilson@Colorado.EDU>
Subject: Re: Bart and Petards

Webster's third New International explains petard as deriving from the 
Middle French "venting of intestinal gas." Since that was probably the 
meaning prevalent at Shakespeare's time, I prefer the interpretation 
taught me by my college English professor, lo those many years ago: Raised 
by his own fart. I ahve heard several alternative explanations, both 
nauticul and explosive, but have never been able to locate anything that 
would verify them linguistically. Let's stick with raised by his own 
flatulence--the image is perfect.  

On 24 Jan 1995, Mohr Bob wrote:

> bc> Magnus Ottenstrom hoists ol' Bart by his own Petard: 
> bc> 
> bc> (don't ask me to explain what that means, the explanation in my
> bc> dictionary dosen't make a bit of sense to me either...):
> 
>      Let it work;
> For 'tis sport, to have the engineer
> Hoist with his own petard; and it shall go hard
> But I will delve one yard below their mines,
> And blow them at the moon.
>                        Hamlet. III, iv.
> 
> A petard was an iron weapon  of sorts, filled with gunpowder  fastened to
> gates, barricades, etc. to blow them up.  Danger was that person who fired the
> weapon could get blown up (hoisted) by the the explosion, IOW beaten with his
> own weapon.
> 
> And francophones would recognize petard as slang meaning fart.
> 
> and fart rhymes with  <vbg>...well I don't think Otto was going that far .
> 
> Bob

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 20:51:46 -0500
From: Eastnor@aol.com
Subject: Roots vs G-Charger, et al

The Roots supercharger (originally developed for diesel trucks) is termed a
'positive-displacement' supercharger.  This simply means that for every
revolution of the supercharger (two vanes) a specific volume of gas (exhaust
on early trucks, intake air when used on 'blown' street or race engines.  The
G-charger and other centrifugal 'blowers', 'kompressors' and the like vary
their output volume with speed, at some rpm they are their most efficient and
pass the most gas.   Positive displacement superchargers have the
considerable advantage of NO lag, they simply feel like bigger displacement
engines.

Leckband


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 17:55:49 -0800
From: "Volney Spalding" <vol@espresso.corp.sgi.com>
Subject: rear window defoggers

pfilers (with early 70's cars):

This is for folks with early "1-stage" rear-window defrosters:

I've been working on mine lately and here is the net:

I get power to the back glass, but the individual lines on the window
seem to have built up too much resistance because when you test
with ohmeter there is continuity at the edges of the glass (where
the lines are bright and shiny) but you lose continuity as you
move in toward the center (where the lines look weak and have a
cruddy black color).

I looked at a used glass that also failed Ohm test.  I'm wondering
what the chances of any of those older units lasting 20+ years with
lines intact.  Any of you out there have *working* 1 stage defrosters?


Option 1:	Keep looking for used 1 stage unit that passes Ohm test.

Option 2:	Upgrade to newer "2 stage" unit with lines that cover most
		of the glass instead of narrow band 1 stage unit.
		Used ~$175.00 plus associated relays and wiring to upgrade.

Option 3:	Buy *new* backglass at ~$800.00: not bloody likely. (used
				$100.00).

I would like to do option 1 since it is closest to the "if it ain't broke
don't fix it" ethic and loathe the specter of changing the wiring to make
2 stage work.  Call me crazy but the old "simple up-grade with normal hand
tools" hasn't worked for me *lately*.

Advice and sedatives appreciated,

Vol

- -- 
Volney Spalding							R 2 4
Silicon Graphics, Inc.						| | |
MTV California 415.390.2879					-----
vol@corp.sgi.com						| | |
								1 3 5

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 22:18:28 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: Bought a 944-now the questions begin!

At 10:36 pm 1/22/95, Colin O'Keefe wrote:

>On this model, is the coolant fan supposed to
>come on regularly in traffic?  The temperature gauge is always about in
>the middle when on the highway, but it goes past the 3/4 mark in traffic
>and the fan comes on.  The fan always goes off when the gauge has gone
>back to 1/2. I will be changing the coolant soon- I think it's been over
>a year.  By the way, I have some new Prestone in a yellow bottle that the
>Kragen people say is phosphate free.  The label say's it's OK for
>aluminum engines.  Is this right, or should I be looking for the grey
>bottles that have been mentioned here?

Hi Colin.

I have been told by several Porsche mechanics that Prestone in the yellow
bottle (or any other antifreeze that contains phosphates) should definitely
not be used in the 944 engine and the reason for this is that it will
deteriorate and weaken the head gasket. I use VW Autobahn antifreeze and I
think it's great (better than even the grey bottle Prestone).

>1984 944  Yeah!

Congrats on your 944 (from a fellow '84 944 owner no less !!!). I hope you
have as much fun with your as I have with mine.


regards,
trev.


===============================
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

'90 Mitsi Eclipse Turbo - "Red Bill"
'93 S.O. unit - "Denise"
'94 Child unit - "Emma"

Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 09:12:57 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: re: short shift mods




The consensus seems to be that the '73 and later tower with the
factory short shift modification is the best setup. It greatly
improves the precision and feel of shifting - but don't expect
to speedshift a 915 transmission.

Thanks for the other points of view on this issue. That's what
makes Porschephiles such a good resource.


Reid

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 23:37:50 -0500
From: YoramGuy@aol.com
Subject: Re: Handbrake Turns

First to Justin:
In front drive cars other than older SAAB 900's, handbrake is an invaluable
device to get the damn thing to turn in the snow.
Best technique is to keep the ratchet button pressed with your thumb, and
modulate the lever, steering and throttle during the corner as required to
control yaw.  Doesn't work well on cars with foot parking brake (i.e.,
Mercedes - but doesn't need it due to RWD; Taurus SHO).
NEVER do this in the dry - you'll flat-spot your rear tires.
Have been using this technique in the snow whenever possible/needed, hundreds
of times, many years, often as a safety measure - no damage possible unless
you loose the car (which is quite difficult).

...And to Magnus Ottenstrom:
AMEN!!  I have over 160k miles on my '86 900 Turbo since new, and it is hard
to replace (and not just because it isn't worth much money any more...), and
my wife's '88 Volvo 745 Turbo is equally satisfying (both with some
tweaks..).
Long live the Swedish fleet and genius!!

Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI.
...Still Looking for an '87 Carrera Coupe...

Mike Willis writes

What gets me is that they have this vast bureaucracy to reduce auto
emissions, at the expense of the little guy -- you and me. A thousand here
and a thousand there and pretty soon you're talking real money. And it's the
Feds mandating this, right?  While we are paying extra for all that
emissions equipment on our cars (which is all well and good and noble) those
same Feds, in the form of th U.S. Marine Corps, set off huge gasoline fires
with regularity at the Tustin Air Station, to practice fire drills. I'm not
talking small fires here; I'm talking black clouds spreading over half of
Orange County. And the California Clean Air Nazis can't do anything 'cause
it's a Federal thang. Do as I say, not as I do.
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 23:25:03 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: RE: trolls & superchargers

>
>>From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
>
>>attempts at streamlining, Cd only 0.28. Later examples of the streamlining
>>craze are the experimental cars built by Paul Jaray, the production
>>Hanomag, and of course the Beetle which led to the Porsche 114 which led
>>to the 356 which was really just a first attempt at a 911 and there you
>>are...
>> 
>>Speaking of an earlier thread about turbocharging and all, Ferry Porsche
>>used to tool around during the war in a Beetle with a supercharged VW engine
>>designed, I think, for stationary use at high altitudes.
>> 
>>Pete
>>
>
Pete,
I've read that as early as 1937 Professor Porsche experimented with 
a twin carb. Roots supercharged VW. You mentioned the 114 which I 
understand were really drawings 114, 114K1 and 114K2 (all three drawings 
show a midship engined car). The two successor had reference numbers 115 
and 116 with 115 having a supercharger and 116 a bored out VW 1.5 litre 
(or liter) power plant.

Just before the war three cars were built on revised 114 drawings that were 
known as 'Project 64' or 'Type 64'. I understand only one survived but I'd
I hav'nt been able to find any further information about these cars.
'The Porsche Book' by Lothar Boschen & Jurgen Barth has three beautiful
photos of one of the Type 64's (It looks like the result of a
marriage between a 356 and a 911.) IMHO. (But that would be an egg before
a chicken would'nt it)

 
Kit Christopher Jungmannn
Northern Systems, Inc. 
jungmann@swcp.com              (Snail Mail): Northern Systems, Inc.
                                             P.O. Box 14368
69-912                                       Albuquerque, NM 87191
86-Golf

Hmm.  I've got an early 73 targa with a non-functional rear defroster.  It

connectors but that seems to be it.  Gasket leakage keeps the connectors wet 
this time of year so I thought I'd wait until spring to resolve this.  I 
have to pull the glass to paint the car and I'll be replacing that 
recalcitrant seal.
