Date: Tue, 24 Jan 1995 22:41:11 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Porsche WSC car



With less than 2 weeks before the 24 Hours of Daytona, IMSA today changed
its regulations for turbocharged WSC cars (Porsche is the only such entry).
Copied below is the announcement. Thought you'd be interested. Anyone got an
Internet address for IMSA?

Larry Wilson

**********************

TAMPA, Fla. (January 24, 1995) -- IMSA announced today adjustments to the
regulations for turbocharged World Sports Cars running in the Le Mans
category at the 1995 Rolex 24 at Daytona.  Mandatory air intake restrictors
were decreased in diameter to 45.5 mm for single turbos and 32 mm for twin
turbos.  Minimum weights for turbocharged Le Mans World Sports Cars were
increased 100 lbs. to 2050 lbs.

The IMSA World Sports Car formula does not allow turbocharged engines for
competition in the domestic EXXON World Sports Car Championship.

Parallel regulations for the 1995 24-Hours of Le Mans include a turbocharged
World Sports Car option.

A provision for these "Le Mans" cars was included in the regulations for the
1995 Rolex 24 at Daytona to help garner international propagation of the
IMSA World Sports Car concept.  Le Mans cars competing at Daytona are not
eligible to earn EXXON World Sports Car Championship points.

As announced in the original Daytona regulations, IMSA reserved the right to
adjust the initial specifications for Le Mans World Sports Cars at any time
preceding the event.  After a careful and extensive review of available
data, IMSA has decided that the potential of such engines exceeds original
estimates and that a legislated reduction in performance was required.

In Addendum #3, in addition to the technical specifications noted in the
announcement, the "turbo boost pressure as measured by IMSA must not exceed
1 bar (14.5 psi) over actual atmospheric pressure."

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 24 Jan 95 22:45:00 PST
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Evaporating hazardous waste


For those of you who asked about what happens when things like brake fluid, 
solvents, and anti-freeze evaporate....

It varies with the chemical.  Certainly it beats pouring it out on the 
ground.  Anti-freeze (ethylene gycol) reacts vigorously with any oxidant, 
like oxygen.  Since I work where I do (Environmental Studies) I guess I'd 
better find out how each of the usual automotive nasties ends up.

I'll check on anti-freeze, brake fluid, the usual solvents and whatever else 
comes to mind.  If anybody wants to know about other automotive wastes, send 
me a suggestion and I'll see what I can find.

Caveat:  Ultimate disposition of some of these things may not be known. 
 Which, of course, makes it even scarier.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 1995 11:59:27 +0100
From: Kristian Simsarian <kristian@sics.se>
Subject: heel&toe and the 914 and 924



	So I have the same question as the first person did with his
914.  On the 924 the brake is much higher than the gas peddle and the
gas peddle is hinged at the bottom, so it does not work so well to push
with your heel unless your foot is small enough to get completely
sideways.  My conclusion is that they have not really designed the foot
layout with this in mind.

This was much easier, for example, on my Triumph Spitfire where the
brake sat barely an inch from the gas and level with it and the gas hung
down on a link from above - then it was simple, in fact most new drivers
hit both peddles by accident and would complain they were too close.
Supposedly there were some racing layouts were one peddle was actually
above the other (confirmations?).


K

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 07:15:12 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: '85/2 944 - Factory Alarm Key

> My '85/2 944 has the keyhole in the driver's rear quarterpanel
> that I think is a factory alarm/ignition cutoff.  What it
> doesn't have is the key.  Can a dealer replace the key, or should
> I try PCNA?  

Try your dealer first...If he says that he cannot/will not help, then call
PCNA.  You will probably have to replace the entire switch.

> 
> Since I've never had the key, I don't even know if its
> operational.  Is there a simple something to look
> for, like a fuse in the fuse box, that indicates
> if this is actually a factory alarm and not some
> after market doodad that is no longer functional?

Probably is the factory alarm in that position.  You can check by removing
the black trim piece (pry with a small screwdriver) and removing the switch
locknut.  The switch then comes out the inside of the quarterpanel through
the black plastic air vent.  If the switch says VDO on it, it's factory.

You can check the funtionality of the alarm system by jumpering the two
connectors together and seeing if your car will no longer start or if the
alarm goes off.

Good luck.
- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

for more exciting purposes.

Date: Wed, Jan 25, 1995 8:42 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Legislation Alert--SB2050 

Hi John,

In message <m0rX7HL-0007vpC@db.erau.edu> John Wise writes:
> As I was sitting waiting at a "left turn only on arrow" intersection while
> there were no cars in sight coming in the other direction, 

Must be something in the coffee, but this triggered one or two neurons in my
(alleged)brain to dump this:  One night in '64, I was over at the house of
one of my German friends in Wiesbaden, who had "Vorsicht Kamera" (the
German edition of Candid Camera, complete w/Alan Funt) on the tube.

The episode shown was filmed in a park somewhere (probably Munich), with
the obvious intent of spoofing the well-known reputation of Germans to be
*very* obedient folks where law or regulation is involved.

The set-up was at a long foot path (with a 10' high hedge on the left),
that was intersected by another foot path, perpendicularly on the right.
The VK crew set up a couple of very professional white lines across the
intersection on the main path, about 5' on either side of the intersection,
complete with pedestrian traffic lights (walk, don't walk), then hid the
controls and got out of sight to film.

They must have shown about 20 takes of people strolling vigorously down the
main path (from either or both directions), who, when the VK crew would hit
the "Don't Walk" light, would *slam* on the brakes and stop.  And stand
there. And look around, very puzzled, obviously wondering what the hell was
going on here.  *But* not proceeding until the light changed to "Walk". In
the entire bit, only one guy "busted" the light, and even *He* stopped
first.  He looked around, everywhere, *very* furtively and *only* when he
was sure that no one would see him, did he continue on (*Very* rapidly). 
It was a scream!  

*Not* that there's any message here) (wink, wink; nudge, nudge, Know what I 
mean?  Know what I mean? 
 
> Do we have any systems or traffic engineers - or anyoneelse - in the group
> who could comment?

Ummmmm...

Cheers,

Bart Chambers

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 09:03:30 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; superchargers vs. turbochargers

      One reason crank-driven superchargers made a comeback might have been
   for emissions. Apparently turbos reduce the ultimate temp or warmup 
   speed of the catalytic converter, the cat doesn't become effective
   until its hot. This is why Ford doesn't have a turbo available today.

      This is also a problem on the Oxygen sensor, as it has to be 600'
   before it operates okay (and so at startup the system is open
   loop). This was improved by the 3-wire sensors, including a heating
   element to warmup the sensor quickly. There have been proposals like
   this to heat up the Cat before startup to make it effective quicker,
   which matters like crazy to OEMs since their smog test is performed
   on cold engines where every misfire hurts. 

        There are a couple great books on engine management, the Bosch book
   is very good but even better is book by the same publishers on 
   Ford engine management, forget the name.

     Re; a past thread on adding the Paxton type superchargers to a 911,
   the Ford book posts a rule of thumb that  3.7 psi of turbo/supercharged
   boost is equal to a Point of compression ratio; i.e., a 911 which 
   normally has 9.8:1 compression really looks like 11.8:1 at 7 lbs boost.
   The old rule of thumb is that you double horsepower for every 15 pounds 
   boost. When Porsche introduced the 930 their race cars were 235hp/liter. 

     Re; comment of adding a supercharger to a 928, Koenig already did it
    with twin superchargers mounted over the cam towers.  I've wondered why
    turbos never caught on with 928s but imagine the problem was finding
    room for the plumbing (though I've heard its been done for 450hp
    from the 4.5 liter motor).

              Lee A (still fiddling with power valves and jet sizes...)

Date: 25 Jan 1995 15:24:44-GMT
From: ye79 <ye79@gec-mrc.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Legislation alert

Pete writes:
> Mike Willis writes
>  
> >Automobiles are but one source of pollution.
>  
> What gets me is that they have this vast bureaucracy to reduce auto
> emissions, at the expense of the little guy -- you and me. A thousand here
> and a thousand there and pretty soon you're talking real money. And it's the
> Feds mandating this, right?

The other thing that seems to be almost universally ignored is the
resources required, and pollution generated, in the production of a
new car. I've heard (can't remember where) that around 50% of the
pollution caused by the average car throughout it's lifetime is
generated during manufacture. We're doing the Earth a favour by
preserving our cars for as long as possible.

I don't understand why this is never taken into account.

Chris Willis

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 10:34:55 EST
From: tynor@atlanta.twr.com (Steve Tynor)
Subject: heel&toe and the 914 and 924

Kristian Simsarian <kristian@sics.se> wrote:

| 	So I have the same question as the first person did with his
| 914.  On the 924 the brake is much higher than the gas peddle and the
| gas peddle is hinged at the bottom, so it does not work so well to push
| with your heel unless your foot is small enough to get completely
| sideways.  My conclusion is that they have not really designed the foot
| layout with this in mind.

In my experience, "heel/toe" is a misnomer. My technique (and I gather
most others) is really, "side-of-foot/toe". Cheesy ASCII graphics:

           +-------+     +-------+
           |    . .|..   |       |
           |  .       .  |       |
           | .         . |       |
           +-.          .|       |
              .          .       |
                .         .      |
                  .        .     |
                   .        .    |
                    .       .    |
                    .        .   |
                    .        .   |
                     .       .---+

I brake with my big toe (with about three toes worth of the foot on the
pedal), and sort of roll the foot to the right to blip the throttle with
the side of my foot (at about the instep - the heel is not on the
throttle). In fact, after braking and transitioning to full throttle, I
just roll my foot off the brake completely and end up pressing the
throttle with the side of my foot.

Many people have complained about the brake pedal being "too high" -
don't forget that on the track or in an autocross, you'll be braking a
lot harder than you do on the street: that lowers the brake pedal
relative to the throttle pedal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Porsche is a two syllable word.
  '74 914 2L (silver being overtaken by rust) [toy car]
  '87 951    (guards red) [track animal and daily driver]
  no cats

Steve Tynor		Internet: Steve.Tynor@atlanta.twr.com

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 10:25:19 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: heel&toe and the 914

>> > Heel on gas pedal (yeah, that thing on the back end of your foot) and
>> > toe on brake. Works fine...
>> More like ball-of-foot on brake, side-of-foot on gas for me...
>> Stan
>
>Yeah, this is certainly something that depends in detail on the size
>and shape of your foot and on the model and year of your car. The 1970
>1.8 914 I am referring to (which is no longer available for my use)
>had a long gas pedal that I could work with the heel of my foot, while
>on the gas with the toe. This also works in my 1961 VW Beetle, and some
>911s.

I do it the same way as Stan (essentially side to side, not really 
"toe and heel"), and have done it that way in 911's, 914's and 944's.
This may be helped by a decent sized shoe. I have seen people with small
shoes appear to have more problem with side-to-side. I believe that the
original poster's problem was that the pedals were at a different level.
This can make side-to-side more difficult, although not impossible,
given practice. Another alternative is to do some adjusting. There
is some latitude in the gas pedal position on a 914 through the
threaded end of the throttle cable. Make sure you readjust the pedal
stop so that it stops the PEDAL exactly at full throttle if you try
making this adjustment. The brake pedal actuating rod (connecting
the pedal to the cylinder) also has a section of threaded rod screwed
into a clevis which could adjust the height of the brake pedal. At
least some of the Porsche shop manuals say not to adjust this, so of
course I wouldn't be able to comment on the suitability of adjusting
the pedal height that way. For any threaded rod adjustment, make sure
at least a length equivalent to 1.5-2 diameters of the rod have thread
engagement.

BTW, if you do any adjusting, and you plan to drive your car on the 
track, don't adjust it for equal pedal heights with dainty little
street brake applications. When you really stomp on that pedal at
the end of a long straight, after a bunch of similar previous stops,
the brake pedal is going to go much lower. I would adjust it so you
can still toe/heel (e.g. side/side) after significant street practice
with the brake pedal as high relative to the gas as possible, to give
you the greatest possible range of brake pedal positions where you can
still toe/heel on the track.

The key is lots of practice under non-stressful conditions on the street.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date:     Wed, 25 Jan 95 11:06:34 EST

> This legislation is in response the a Federal Mandate to clean up the
> Air. I agree that the air needs to be cleaned up. Automobiles are but
> one source of air pollution. Maybe we need to ban cigarettes...

Recently, AAA has released a study that concluded that automobiles are NO
LONGER the #1 source of air pollution (at least here in studied cities
here in the NE) and in some cases, cars are not even the #2 problem.

They concluded that further tightening of pollution control laws [new cars] 
are non-productive, not the problem anymore, stupid, etc...and that AAA
will lobby against them.

Source:  A news article in a recent issue of the "AAA Newspaper" that
members get.  Mine's been recycled - if anyone has a copy still...

> gas peddle is hinged at the bottom, so it does not work so well to push
> with your heel unless your foot is small enough to get completely
> sideways.  My conclusion is that they have not really designed the foot
> layout with this in mind.

Not really completely sideways, although it is a bit unnatural-feeling at
first. What I try to do is to get the heel to land about 1 to 2 inches
above the hinge at the bottom of the gas pedal, which gives quite a lot
of pedal action for very little heel motion, and the brake pedal falls
a bit towards the back of the ball of my size 12 extra-wide foot.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 1995 12:15:15 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: heel&toe and the 914

The plane of the brake and accelerator pedals are not necessarily the same
when at rest. The accelerator needs to have its limits of travel (full in
 -full out) intersected by the plane of the brake pedal in its DEPRESSED
 position, because that is where it will be when you heel and toe and that is
the fulcrum , if you like, of the lever that is blipping the accelerator.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 09:26:00 PST
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: 914 wiper shafts and rust, need help


Try oxalic acid for the rust stains.  If you used Deltron it shouldn't harm 
the paint, but I'd test a hidden section first.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 11:24:33 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; compression/turbos 


 >>     Re; a past thread on adding the Paxton type superchargers to a 911,
 >>   the Ford book posts a rule of thumb that  3.7 psi of turbo/supercharged
 >>   boost is equal to a Point of compression ratio; i.e., a 911 which
 >>   normally has 9.8:1 compression really looks like 11.8:1 at 7 lbs boost.

>ok.  so how much compression can I get away with on an otherwise stock
>911SC which currently (from memory) has an 8.5:1 cr ?  What is the limiting
>factor ?

> Martin C. Walker                                        martinw@eapi.com

    The result of too much compression is predetonation. A longer duration
 camshaft, higher octane fuel, a richer mixture, or less ignition advance will
 reduce the chance of detonation at any given compression ratio. New engine
 management neatly incorporates the knock sensor, which will retard ignition
 if it senses vibration in the 5-8khz range;  essentially it optimizes 
 ignition for whatever grade fuel you are running. Newer engine management
 can actually isolate the cylinder that it pinging and retard it  
 individually. Pretty slick...
    Twin-plugs let you run less advance since the flame propagates from 2
 directions.  A friend did this on his 3.2l 914, getting 10.5:1 compression
 for him meant fly-cutting the case and barrels, trimming back the chain
 housings then bending the tensioner arms (and of course, starting off with
 pistons that wouldn't collide with his Garretson cams. Forget any cam with
 your CIS pistons). Then, the only alternative for the 2 plugs was the $1200
 Bosch distributor and $350 cap, nowadays aftermarket ignitions are available
 (like the Electromotive).  
    My other non-P car runs 9.5:1 on cheapest fuel I can run and works
 fine, no pinging. But it is jetted very rich. Alone, a compression ratio
 change of a point will probably give you negligible power bump, maybe 
 1 or 2%.  Compression  ratio changes are important if you start adding a
 lot of cam, but then to offset what dynamic compression the cam -lost-.
    Low-vacuum or any boost means you have to retard ignition timing, the
 "MAP" (manifold absolute pressure sensors which measure vacuum) or the
 "MAF" (mass airflow which measures actual quantity of air) detect the actual
 loading on the car and try to hit the first setting for mixture/ignition
 timing (then let the Knock sensor avoid damage from pre-ignition). Retarding
 the ignition works against you at high speed, since the flame still takes
 tens of crank degrees to propagate across the piston you can't get your
 spark out early enough (Pfilers with modified 944 turbos complain about 
 higher power but lower RPM). I don't know if or how a tuner gets around this
 except maybe with different fuels (i.e., how DOES an F1 car run 14,000  
 rpm....)

   Lee A, '48 chevy pickup with 216/6 at 6.7:1 cr. 1'btdc intake timing....



------------------------------


Porschephiles #1100                         Wed Jan 25 18:47:46 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 09:36:31 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Blowers of all types.


Been reading all the stuff on Supercharging and turbocharging. Verrrry
interesting!!

Anyway, you forgot one insideous contraption, the power recovery turbine
which was used on various Wright and Pratt & Whitney aircraft engines
(and others). This gizmo let the exhaust gasses spin a turbine 
which was connected to the crankshaft. Some claimed an 8% to 10% 
recovery. The engines had two stage superchargers, the last stage being 
used only at cruising altitude. These little bastards broke frequently,
so there was a decoupling box to keep from freezing the engine.

Supercharger speeds. Depending on the application, the supercharger
can be underdriven (slower than crankshaft speed) or overdriven 
(faster than crankshaft speed). Most applications are slower or
equal to cranshaft speed. In the hot rod world, what ever works.

Turbos are governed by flow and flow coupling to generate boost. The 
vanes will cavitate on both the driven and compressed sides. The trick
is to design the vanes to couple and provide boost without cavitation.
The wastegate helps by prventing overboost and back pressure, which can 
"stall" the drive side. Aircraft have a big advantage as the power 
settings and throttle response are fairly slow and aren't too badly
affected by turbo lag.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 1995 12:40:49 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Re: Water cooled oil light-Ken

Hi Ken,
	I had that same problem a year ago with my '77 924, and it turned 
out to be my head gasket! :^(  You may be luckier than I though.  As far 
as the oil pressure sensor, it went bad on me too, and it IS possible to 
pull it with the head still on.  Look and see if your unit has two 
connectors poking out of it.  If its like mine, it will, and this means 
that both the light and the guage run off the same unit.  I don't know 
why they say there are separate ones.  My suggestion would be to first  
replace this unit, since it gets less accurate with age, with one for a 
Rabbit with VDO guage package.  Its the same unit and it can be had at 
many VW parts stores for about $25 (vs about $75 for Porsche).  Get a  
copper O-ring to help seal it.  To get at it, slide an open wrench (Size?) 
behind it from underneath and SLOWLY inch it out by reversing the 
wrench every turn.  There's JUST enogh room to do it and it takes some time 
but it can be done.  Hope this works, let me know if you fix it or have 
any more questions!  
Jay Karolyi
'76 Alpine White 912E VIN#1
'77 lima bean green 924

Date: Wed, Jan 25, 1995 12:57 PM

The day I turned 16 (oh, that halcyon day), I naturally rushed down to the
city hall in Augusta, GA and took my driver's license exam.  This rigorous
test had ten (count 'em, ten!) True/False questions and required the aspirant
to successfully drive two blocks, turn left for one block, back, and and back 
to the starting point without hitting a Policeman.  In my haste, I ran the 
stop sign at the first intersection (sleepy part of a <then> sleepy town).

The ...er, "examiner" riding with me asked "Son, why didn'tcha stop at that
there Stop sign?"   "I didn't see any Stop sign" sez I.  "Well, be more
observant in the future" sez he, and gave me my license without further
adieu.  And I didn't even have a Porsche (note clever group relevance inserted
gratuitously...)

But I'm feeling *Much* better now... and I *do* have a Porsche now (ibid).

> driver training in the us (based on the driver training I received here, and
> on experience w/other drivers/driver training here and abroad) is focused
> soley on
> 1) operating the vehicle within the white lines.  

Er, Martin; I hate to be the one to break the news to you, but they clearly
have dropped that skill from the cirriculum, at least in the national capitol
area...(where most cars are delivered with the popular "Turn Signal Delete"
option).

Cheers,

Bart Chambers

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 10:26:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re: Engine Fires


Kit wrote:

>Pete,
>
>Do you drive an electric or non combustible fuel automobile ? If not then
>you should not underestimate your risks of a fire.

Very true....

My '75 914/6 project came from an insurance auction.  It was written
off due to an engine fire.

My previous '73 914/4 suffered from an engine fire which my brother
and I successfully put out - the only damage was a pair of screwed
Dellorto carbs.

My friend's 914/4 burned to the ground last week.  The car was completely
destroyed.

Yes....engine fires can happen.  Change your fuel lines at regular intervals
and inspect them for leaks often!!!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 17:57:09 GMT
From: kh@wg.icl.co.uk (Kevin Hughes)
Subject: Re: re:rear window defogger


This may sound stupid BUT try the switch connections for the second stage - I
had to strip the ventilation(!) blower out to get at mine behind the wiper motor
and what did I find? - the spade connector had "dropped off". Simply reconnected
it and it all worked fine - this was after months of tracing wiring and checking
fuses and relays initially from the garage where I baught it and then by me
when they gave up.

  If you try this and find a black wire with green stripe with a male spade
terminal just "hanging around" and you find out what its for I would love to 
know - I've got one which does nothing - not earthed not live EVER.

Kevin

1980 930

Peter Albrecht writes:

> We need a big, established lobby organization. Until somebody like the AAA
> decides it is profitable to go in on something like this, nothing is going
> to happen.
 
Car & Driver or R&T recently had a related comment to make in it's letter from 
the publisher (I think that's what the column is called - is Williams his 
name?).

The column was talking about special interest groups & how specialty magazines 
such as C&D & R&T were aimed at a specialist interest group - people 
interested in cars!

OK, so that's pretty obvious. What struck me, having read the article, was 
this: if C&D & R&T have a paying audience (we the car enthusiasts) what better 
organization to lobby on our behalf than these C&T & R&T?

They frequently publish articles bemoaning the 55/65 limit & the fact that 
this is a revenue issue rather than a safety one. These columns usually 
include a comment about the NMA suggesting readers join but that's about as 
far as they go.

Why don't these two auto mags pick up the gauntlet, march to DC as true 
lobbyists & put the case to Congress as eloquently as they do each month in 
their magazines? They have a large audience behind them - more so than the 
NMA. They have a lot of money. What more do they need?

Am I'm missing something obvious here - are they afraid of losing their 
advertisers? It just seems so obvious: C&T & R&T writers don't like the 55/65 
policy & we, their paying readers, don't like it either. Surely, with two such 
motivated parties, this combination can't lose?

John

pump will stop spewing gas onto the flames. Makes it tough to put 
out. Don't ask me how I know ;-).

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 13:01:23 PST
From: pat@cor.cerfnet.com (Pat Hohl [5607])
Subject: Aircraft turbo/superchargers

Dear P-philes;
Turbo chargers are routinely used in modern
recip aircraft engines to increase intake manifold
pressure when operating at atlitude.  This it to make
up for the loss of power w/ thin air.  They are not
typically used to get MORE power from an engine, but rather
to get RATED power at altitude.  Many WWII aircraft used
superchargers for the same reason, and also to get EXTRA
power for take-off or dog-fight for a very short duration.

 -pat

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 1995 16:55:54 -0500
From: Fred Pack <fhp@unipress.com>
Subject: 944 heel & toe

I found that the 944 gas pedal is just too low to hell&toe easily.

I checked to learn if the 944 gas pedal can be 'raised'. It can't. (I hear
that the 911 gas pedal is adjustable.)

So I extended the height of the pedal:  I cut 3/4" thick of plywood in the
shape of the pedal, put a piece of metal on top of the wood, and sandwiched
the metal, wood, and original rubber gas pedal together with nuts&bolts.

Presto! The gas pedal is substantially higher and easier to heel & toe.

Fred Pack					fhp@unipress.com
UniPress Software				phone: (908) 287-2100
2025 Lincoln Highway				fax:   (908) 287-4929
Edison NJ 08817					http://www.unipress.com/

'89 944S2
'73 914 2.0L

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 13:56:18 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Clean Air Backlash

How topical!  Today's Wall Street Journal carries a front page story
"Not In My Garage -- The Clean Air Backlash":

[copyright (I presume) 1995, The Wall Street Journal.  Used in private,
without permission; please DO NOT re-post.]

PITTSBURGH -

"Motorists balk at everything from having to use gasoline nozzles that
catch excess fuel vapors to buying a new blend of gasoline that trims
tailpipe emissions.  They refuse to subject their cars to a new type of
exhaust test, even thought the testing centers have already been built.
And they don't want electric cars, either."

"'They're like hyperactive children,' says Joseph Minott, the somewhat
exasperated executive director of the Clean Air Council in Philadelphia.
'They just keep shouting 'NO NO NO,' no matter what's suggested.'"

"If Pittsburgh were an isolated case, it wouldn't be a problem.  But it's
not.  The Clean Air Act - the broad federal law that gave rise to all
those things Pittsburghers hate - is under attack across the country.
In Maryland, angry motorists recently marched on the statehouse,
demanding a halt to that state's new emissions-testing program.  Drivers
in the New York area can listen to radio talk-show hosts gripe about how
reformulated gasoline [...] may be harming their engines and is
generally a dumb idea dreamed up by bureaucrats.  Business is also
complaining.  A push is on among corporate executives to halt a
requirement that companies find ways to get more workers to join car
pools.  Pennsylvania has yanked Philadelphia out of that program as a
result of the resistance."

...and so on.  Check it out.  Looks like a replay of the late-70's 
anti-metric-system backlash to me...

 -Ed

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 16:42:36 -0700
From: "Drew A. Spencer" <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Re: IMSA: Porsche withdraws from Daytona 24 Hours


> 

> 	PORSCHE WSC TEAM WITHDRAWS FROM 24 HOURS OF DAYTONA
> 		    DUE TO SUDDEN RULES CHANGE
> 

> RENO, NEVADA, January 25, 1995 -- As the rsult of a surprising change
> in regulations made on Tuesday, January 24, by sanctioning body IMSA
> which affects the two open-cockpit Porsche WSC category sports proto-
> types, the Stuttgart sports car maker has decided not to field a factory
> team in the 1995 edition of the 24 Hours of Daytona on February 4 and 5.
> The change in regulations at such short notice is so sever that Porsche 

> would not be able to compete on an equal footing against Ferrari, its
> greatest rival.  Porsche AG deeply regrets the IMSA decision as this
> represents a sever setback for efforts to establish an attractive world
> series for sports cars.  Porsche AG, active in the IMSA series since the
> early 1970s, does not pursue motor sport as an end in itself, and will
> continue to enter only events which allow reliable conditions for all
> competitors.
> 

> The new IMSA rule change for the two WSC Porsches has resulted in a
> reduction in the size of air restrictors of the twin-turbo engines from
> 34.5 mm to 32 mm, and an increase in vehicle weight from 1,950 lbs to
> 2,050 lbs.  Calculations made by Porsche engineers have shown that the
> air restrictor reduction will result in a decrease of about 80 hp in
> power output, from 540 to 460 HP.  With this new power figure, the two
> WSC Porsches would lap at least four to five seconds slower than their
> competitors.  Calculated over the 24-hour race distance, this would be
> a disadvantage of at least one hour.  These are conditions Porsche is
> unable to accept.
> 

> During the official preliminary tests at Daytona at the beginning of
> January, Porsche allowed IMSA officials to view vehicle data and had 

> also disclosed power curves.  IMSA officials then confirmed the data
> was fully in accordance with the regulations.  This makes the sudden
> about face by IMSA even more incomprehensible.
> 

> Porsche remains committed to motor sport, and will continue to compete
> in the future in view of the challenges racing poses for both man and
> machine.  However, Porsche will not participate in events where un-
> reliable regulations make entries an incalculable risk.  For Porsche,
> sport means fair competition between all entrants.


- --
- --------------------------------------------------------
Drew Spencer              EMAIL: Drew_Spencer@novell.com

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 1995 16:24:57 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: LPR Awards

Watts Wong Wacing Worst Wevolution Award is the actual title of the Loma
Prieta award that I received. The award got its name from the antics
(spinning) of Henry Watts and Dave Wong. It is generally used to poke fun
at the particular driver. It is kind of a compliment for first year
autocrosser to receive.

This is an award that Henry Watts (the guy that wrote "Secrets of Solo
Racing") chooses the recipient of each year. I won the award because of my
dazzling display at one autocross last year at the Laguna Seca paddock.
There was this one hairpin that I could not get right all day, at least not
during a lap that counted. On two different occasions I had spectacular
spinouts sending cones (9 or 10) flying all over the place.

I did have a have the 7th best time with an entry of 100. So its not like I
stunk up the place. This turn just had my number all day.

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

Date: 25 Jan 95 19:26:20 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Steering wheel restoration

Nick Bullow asked about the steering wheel horn contact button and the
rubber thingy that acts as a spring for the horn button.
 
The Stoddard catalog lists them as 914.347.831.00 and 901.347.823.01
respectively. Your local dealer may have them too, if not Stoddard is at
38845 Mentor Ave., Willoughby, OH  44094-0908, USA, fax (USA) 216-946-9410.
 
I looked this up because I thought it might be the same part as used in the
356, but those have different numbers, 644.347.831.05 for B/C and
644.347.836.05 for B/C.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 25 Jan 95 19:26:24 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Legislation alert

 
John Wise asked about pollution while waiting for a light to change.
 
In many cities in California, inductive loops are embedded in the pavement
to sense cars waiting to make a turn or waiting for a light. If there is no
car in the left turn lane, sometimes the left turn arrow never comes on.
Etc.
 
In Europe, some cities have pictogram signs telling you to turn off the
engine while waiting for a light. Some car makers (VW?) have demonstrated
commuter cars that kill the engine instead of letting it idle (I know, I
know, there are Porschephiles who think their cars do that but aren't
supposed to...) and then relight the fires when the gas pedal is touched.
 
Bart Chambers describes a German Candid Camera episode with stop lights for
people. Somebody once pointed out that if you put a stop light in the middle
of the Sahara, Germans would stop for it. (You could try this closer to home
in Death Valley. Lots of Germans insist on visiting "Dett Velly.")
 
Martin Walker says put in roundabouts. Roundabouts take up too much space,
are dangerous in the hands of incompetent American drivers, and won't handle
as much traffic as a conventional intersection. A quaint British custom that
won't work here.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 19:39:53 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: IMSA Rule Changes

Dear Lynn,

I have been a follower of IMSA events for a long time now.

It pains me to see IMSA changing the rules again, at the last minute before
a major event, the 24 Hours of Daytona.

Yes, it would be nice for Ferrari if their vehicles were competitive. Yes,
it would be nice if Porsche was not so expert at finding loopholes that give
them a competitive edge. Yes, it would be nice if you could make a racecar
out of a pig.

The problem for any race team is the intransigency of the sanctioning body,
allowing the advantage written into the rules at the beginning of the season
to be written out at a whim.

I am saddened to see that Porsche is withdrawing their WSC cars from Daytona.

IMSA, Porsche, Ferrari, and the racing devotees are all hurt by this
decision.

Thanks for reading this far...


- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 19:43:31 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: your mail

> 
> A few questions.
> 
> 1) When did Porsche start galvinizing cars?

On 944 cars, in 1983, when they started making them.  I hear that they
started in 1977-78 on 911 cars. 928s are aluminum, so doesn't matter.

> 2) Are there different methods of galvinization? ( i.e. I know the GEO Metro 

> is galvinized but I imagine GM uses a different method on the Seville)

Probably, but most galvanization is properly a cathode/anode operation with
a solution of zinc in suspension...

> 2a) is galvinization a word? <g>

Yes...

> 3) Are all auto makers galvinizing?

No, that's why you see very few 10 year old swedish cars...  (g)


- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Porschephiles #1101                         Thu Jan 26 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 25 Jan 1995 18:48:42 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Porsche and IMSA

> I guess I'll just offer myself up as flame bait here.  Why can't/won't 
> Porsche come up with some variant of one of their non turbo production 
> motors for IMSA's WSC?  

As they say, if you don't know what the answer is, the answer is: MONEY.

Certainly in this case. Development of a new motor --- which is what you're
talking about even if you base it on an old one -- is a VERY expensive 
undertaking. Particularly if you don't trust the sanctioning body not
to change the rules on you. A wise choice in this case.

Stan

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 10:31:52 PST
From: lingren@lambo.alldata.com (Loren Lingren)
Subject: legislation


- ----- Begin Included Message -----

From zicaro Wed Jan 25 09:45:33 1995
Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 09:45:33 PST
From: zicaro (Joseph Zicaro)
To: lingren
Subject: legislation
Content-Length: 1162

The potential implications of this bill, SB2050, and the "pilot" program it describes are far reaching. Sounds to me, after reading the summary of the bill being proposed, that this will affect ALL vehicles, new and old! Note in the fourth paragraph, the "bill" would require 

	"a decal disclosing the smog index, as
	defined, for each vehicle, as determined by the state board, to
	be affixed to a new motor vehicle.

And the other text seems to imply that the "Smog Index" is the total quantity, by mass, of pollutants that a vehicle is allowed to emit between smog tests. The text also implies that the "Smog Index" will be different for older cars than for new cars. Depending on what the "Smog Index" is set at for new vehicles, we could all be paying the Gov't. by the mile to drive our cars! We already pay the Gov't per gallon for our gasoline. More than 1/3 the price of gasoline is consumer TAXES, plus there are also manufacturers taxes imposed on the oil companies! Just more evidence that all this is not about pollution or the environment, but power and money, further increasing the size, scope, and cost of an already out of control government.


- ----- End Included Message -----

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 1995 17:05:05 -0800 (PST)
From: Tim Flint <tflint@netcom.com>
Subject: 944 non-OEM Radiator?


Hi P-philes,

I'm about to buy a new radiator for my 83' 944.

I saw a "heavy duty" non OEM radiator made by Autotechnik in the 
Performace Products catalog. The ad says that the radiator is made of 
brass and copper, and is rebuildable. The thing sells for $439.
This price sounds a little high, but it may make your engine last longer.

Questions:

Do any of you have any experience with these radiators?

Could the brass/copper construction have some sort of corrosive reaction 
with the aluminum block?

Any thoughts or advice appreciated.


Tim

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 19:37 CST
From: eley@sccsi.com
Subject: The forgotten 968

I've resisted as long as I can.  I recently purchased a *new* 1995 968 from 
a local dealer for $8000 under sticker price (maybe some of you have seen 
the ads in Autoweek).  The car is fabulous in all respects. The dealers are 
*dying* to clear out their remaining 968's.  If anyone is interested in this 
car, and can afford 34K or so, *do it now*!  I predict that a few years will 
pass (maybe until that cold day in hell) before you can buy a new Porsche 
for 34K.  Thinking about that Boxter for 40K?  Good luck.

The 968 is the real thing (I'm sure the 944 guys and gals know what I'm 
talking about).  It's made (or was) on the assembly line right next to the 
911's.  It even smells like my old 912 on the inside!  It's fast, it handles 
as close to perfection as I've experienced, it looks great...

Anyway, I just needed to get this off my chest.  I never see 968's mentioned 
here. Now I will.  Thanks.  Get one while you can.  

Bill Eley
'95 968

My 944's windshield seems to get foggy quite easily; I was wondering if 
anyone has ever tried using that "never-fog" product by the people who 
make rain-x. The only reason I hesitate to try it is that in my manual it 
states that SOME cars of my model year ('87) have a "Sekurit-flex" coating 
on them. What exactly is this coating, and how can I tell if my car has 
it?  ... I take this section of the manual with a grain of salt -- it 
later advises cleaning the glass with the well-known carcinogen BENZENE!  
... don't they have lawyers in germany? :)

///--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Adam Farkas
University of Michigan Medical School
Ann Arbor, MI

Porschephiles #1102                         Thu Jan 26 11:18:15 CST 1995
Porschephiles #1102                         Thu Jan 26 11:18:15 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 03:19:30 -0500
From: JamesD1415@aol.com
Subject: Please Don't Steer Me Wrong

951 has dreaded power steering rack leak.  Rebuilt rack installed = $900, per
mechanic's estimate.  Porsche enthusiasm exceeds current financial
wherewithal.
   Question:  Can I disconnect the steering pump belt and go manual--or is
this a foolish plan which will result in the destruction of the steering
mechanism.  Alternative suggestions and cash donations also welcome.
  TIA for all help.

Jim D.



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 03:27:31 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: W225-T7 gap

Dear Wulf:

            I checked about 100 of my  T7 plugs and it's Very Interesting.
All the W225-T7 plugs I checked had a  0.7mm gap recommended. However,  some
of the W175-T7 plugs had a 0.9mm gap recommendation while others had a 0.5mm
gap!  The W175's with the  0.5mm gap were the ribbed plugs while the W175's
with the 0.9mm gap were the smooth insulator type. There were also a few
slightly later W225-T7's, also having the later Bosch number of W5B along
with a number of 0 241 245 526  that had a  0.6mm gap.  NONE of my plugs had
a 0.8mm gap!

    Go figure!
  And:
KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!!!
The Maestro


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 03:42:07 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 356 T/O Bearings

Dear Walter:

      The Main Difference in the T /O bearings in the 356B and 356C is
related to the attachment position on the clutch cable arm. The 356C attaches
nearer the fulcrum and thus causes a greater movement of the clutch shaft and
T/O bearing. That's why the 356C T/O bearing has a shorter distance from the
"ears" to the lip. The 356B T/O bearing and clutch cable attachment point is
the reverse. A 912 T/O bearing is in BETWEEN, and can be made to work on
EITHER 356B or 356C, provided you do a little "machining" on the  support for
the "ears" of the 912 bearing and on the top, front side, otherwise the 912
 T/O bearing will hit the studs/bolts that hold the guide tube in place. 

Hope this helps.
KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 11:24:20 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Legislation alert


Pete writes:

| Martin Walker says put in roundabouts. Roundabouts take up too much space,
| are dangerous in the hands of incompetent American drivers, and won't handle
| as much traffic as a conventional intersection. A quaint British custom that
| won't work here.

American drivers would perhaps become somewhat disturbed at the infamous 
"Magic Roundabout" located at Hemel Hempstead, here in the UK. This roundabout 
is extraordinary in the sense that it is composed of one large roundabout
and about seven smaller "satellite" mini-roundabouts. The organisation of
this beastie means that you can circulate round it in *EITHER*
direction. This can induce an out of body type experience 
in first timers because each exit onto the roundabout is via
a mini roundabout, so you can turn left and give way to traffic coming
from the right around the mini-roundabout and circulate clockwise round the
central roundabout in the outside lane with the mini-roundabouts
to your right, OR, you can turn right onto the mini-roundabout still giving 
way the the right and circulate counter clockwise around the large roundabout 
on the inside lane with the mini-roundabouts on the right! All you have
to do is to repeat the mantra "give way to the right", and all
but the terminally clueless eventually succeed. Sounds like `murkin
drivers would have no problem with this, because it does not matter
which way you go round, and if they can cope with a complex rule base
like "green = go, red = stop" then "give way to the left" should be
well within the normal distribution of ability.

Regards

Ben




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 07:25:00 PST
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: RE: heel&toe and the 914 and 924


Nice picture BTW:
     Anyway, I "toyed" with learning this technique with my 944.  The 
spacing between the edge of the brake pedal to the edge of the accel. pedal 
seems a little big.  I wear 10-1/2 or an 11 shoe (depending on the shoe) and 
still find it hard to get a good feel for the brake while trying to blip the 
throttle.  It feels like my foots going to slip off the brake at an 
inopportune time.  Its odd with reasonably big feet like mine that have 
trouble like this.
     Someone mentioned the brake being too high, and it would probably be 
alright during heavy braking.  I would agree, except on the street, I rarely 
find an opportunity to brake this heavily and practice.  (Besides you don't 
want to scare the passenger)
     Are other P-cars like 911's, 914's, 928's better in this regard to 
pedal placement.

David B.
'89 944
 ----------

   In my experience, "heel/toe" is a misnomer. My technique (and I gather
   most others) is really, "side-of-foot/toe". Cheesy ASCII graphics:

              +-------+     +-------+
              |    . .|..   |       |
              |  .       .  |       |
              | .         . |       |
              +-.          .|       |
                 .          .       |
                   .         .      |
                     .        .     |
                      .        .    |
                       .       .    |
                       .        .   |
                       .        .   |
                        .       .---+

   I brake with my big toe (with about three toes worth of the foot on the
   pedal), and sort of roll the foot to the right to blip the throttle with
   the side of my foot (at about the instep - the heel is not on the
   throttle). In fact, after braking and transitioning to full throttle, I
   just roll my foot off the brake completely and end up pressing the
   throttle with the side of my foot.

   Many people have complained about the brake pedal being "too high" -
   don't forget that on the track or in an autocross, you'll be braking a
   lot harder than you do on the street: that lowers the brake pedal
   relative to the throttle pedal.

   =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

------------------------------

Date:     Thu, 26 Jan 95 7:56:38 EST
From: "Hugh A. Huntzinger" (CCAC-LAD) <huntzing@PICA.ARMY.MIL>
Subject:  911 heater blockage: hose?

Don't you hate those sudden funny "hot electrical motor" smells?
Last night, a slight whiff is how it started in my '85 911 coupe.

The problem is that the heater system - passenger's side only is dead,
both the vents to the windshield and to floor. 

Driver's side heat is OK, as is the "vent" system on BOTH sides (up & down).

Looking at the heater cables, both driver's & passengers side _seem_ OK.

If the passenger's side is broken (closed), then I wouldn't know how to
tell, for not only has the amount of drag to move it remained the same,
but with the blower switch on, when the passenger's lever is pushed all
the way down (off and with driver's already off), the blower DOES turn
off like its supposed to, regardless of its dial switch position.


Does this sound like maybe I've lost a passenger-side-only hose
connection, a broken cable or a blockage?  The car had been sitting idle
for 3 weeks; hope I didn't have a critter crawl up somewhere and die...


Just looking for whatever help can be offered,


 -hugh

Nice picture BTW:
     Anyway, I "toyed" with learning this technique with my 944.  The

seems a little big.  I wear 10-1/2 or an 11 shoe (depending on the shoe) and 
still find it hard to get a good feel for the brake while trying to blip the

David B.

 ----------

   In my experience, "heel/toe" is a misnomer. My technique (and I gather
   most others) is really, "side-of-foot/toe". Cheesy ASCII graphics:

              +-------+     +-------+
              |    . .|..   |       |
              |  .       .  |       |
              | .         . |       |
              +-.          .|       |
                 .          .       |
                   .         .      |
                     .        .     |
                      .        .    |
                       .       .    |
                       .        .   |
                       .        .   |
                        .       .---+

   I brake with my big toe (with about three toes worth of the foot on the
   pedal), and sort of roll the foot to the right to blip the throttle with
   the side of my foot (at about the instep - the heel is not on the
   throttle). In fact, after braking and transitioning to full throttle, I
   just roll my foot off the brake completely and end up pressing the
   throttle with the side of my foot.

   Many people have complained about the brake pedal being "too high" -
   don't forget that on the track or in an autocross, you'll be braking a
   lot harder than you do on the street: that lowers the brake pedal
   relative to the throttle pedal.

problem, unless you're stopped, then a big wrestle. good luck.

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 10:10:14 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: Of 944 Turbos and Wastegates

Hi All;

All the recent talk about Turbocharging raises a question about my '89 944 Turbo 
(note the deft tie-in).  Between about 0.8 to 1.0 bar pressure (as measured by 
the in-dash pressure gauge), I hear a loud exhaust resonance in my car which 
sounds like a valve chattering.  At least I assume it is exhaust related.  Could 
this have anything to do with the wastegate opening and closing?  Could someone 
explain to me how the wastegate operates and what its purpose is?  Is this a 
normal sound heard on all/some/other 944 Turbos?  It is consistent in every gear 
at any speed.

This noise has been bugging me since I got the car last August.  I have assumed 
it is normal, but other thoughts are welcome.  Thanks in advance.

Tracy Meyer
tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 10:23 EST
From: bartonc@infi.net (Barton P. Chambers)
Subject: WSC95 Rules re Porsche

Greetings,

I've recently read the new rules you...ummmm, ahhhhh, *fine* people have
passed to restrict the performance of the recently announced Porsche
entrant.

The world owes you a debt of gratitude for saving us from the spectre of
competition from an engine that dares to be different.  Heck-fire, if
them ol' Germans want to run with the big dawgs, let 'em design and build
a new engine that's jest like all the rest.  If they can't afford to do
that, t'hell with 'em.  The *Sport* is better off without 'em.

*Nice* work, boys and girls!  I'm sure that, in your infinite wisdom,
you've noticed that I'm probably the sole person in the world that would
like to see Porsche participate in this series, much *less* do so on a
competitive basis.

You've doubtless also observed that I drive an older Porsche, and thus
reasonably concluded that I *seldom* purchase any measurable quantities
of consumable items of any *value*; and with unerring logic, you've
(doubtless, correctly) deduced that my custom would therefore be of
little value to purveyors of things automotive.

Naturally, even though many people respond to churlish behavior by
refusing to extend their custom to those engaging in, or sponsoring such,
the loss of custom from such unreasonable folk will be inconsequential
and have no impact.  And shoot, even if you and your sponsors lose the
custom of a few soreheads, what matters is that you did the *right*
thing. Why, *Heaven* forfend, the idea of lettin' Porsche compete under
the rules as they were announced might make 'em competitive ...(shudder)
the mind boggles! (...the sound of a mind boggeling...)

and Not (he says, with all the sincerity he can muster) that anyone would
think that *your* recent rules aimed at making the Porsche entry
uncompetitive could be considered "Churlish" by any *reasonable*
person... Stupid, sure.  Dastardly, well... OK.  Contemptible; definitely!

But "Churlish"...(OK, OK, "Churlish").

Have a wonderful life,

Bart Chambers

Cheers

Bart Chambers
Frau Dora, Blonde
'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (stealth Quattro, Alpenweis

Hi Arthur,

In 1975 with the 1976 model (but maybe some late 75s got it too, you know
how Porsche introduces changes in mid-model...)

metal.

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 11:11:02 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Of 944 Turbos and Wastegates

I would describe it as more of a "chuffing" sound, and its is indeed your
friend the wastegate. It opens to allow excess boost to escape out exhaust.
Excess boost you say? No such thing you say? The turbo is designed to
optmize power in some way, meaning that under certain conditions more boost
is generated than they can really handle, so out the exhaust it goes. I've
heard of waste gates sticking in the closed postion. They make a lot of
power, for a little while. Love that sound!


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 16:47:46 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Legislation Alert--SB2050


There is one problem with round abouts - they work well when the flow of 
traffic is equal in all directions, however they tend to work badly in 
tidal traffic flows, because the odd car coming in from the right side 
(in UK) has priority. if you have cars arriving at about 80 yd gaps at 40 
mph, no one from the major flow can pull out, so the major flow backs up.

And contrary to US opinion, no bstar will ever slow up to let people pul 
out from the major flow.

This is especially true for "mini round abouts" where the minor flow of 
traffic can take the round about without slowing.

What would really improve the flow on these round abouts is speed bumps 
on the round about entrance - this would also make it safer for pedestrians.

+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 11:51 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Of 944 Turbos and Wastegates

Tracy Meyer asked recently:
All the recent talk about Turbocharging raises a question about my '89 944 Turbo 
(note the deft tie-in).  Between about 0.8 to 1.0 bar pressure (as measured by 
the in-dash pressure gauge), I hear a loud exhaust resonance in my car which 
sounds like a valve chattering.  At least I assume it is exhaust related.  Could 
this have anything to do with the wastegate opening and closing?  Could someone 
explain to me how the wastegate operates and what its purpose is?
- ---

As I understand wastegates (in my limited, English-major way), they are a basic
pressure-relief valve, like a pipe sticking out of the intake with a flap on 
the end.  This "flap" (valve) is held closed by a spring with a pre-set tension.
Once the boost reaches (or exceeds) a predetermined limit, the pressure of the
air on one side of the valve exceeds the pressure exerted on the flap by the
spring, the flap opens and lets the excess pressure bleed off until it is low
enough that the spring can close the flap again.  (In the "evil" turbo mods, the
pressure exerted by the spring can be changed, increasing or decreasing the
pressure at which the waste gate operates.)  My guess is that the chattering
you hear is the wastegate flap opening and closing at its rated pressure as the
individual pulses flowing through the exhaust spin the impeller just enough to
raise the pressure above the wategate's limit.  I'm sure a *real* engineer
could tell you if the chattering is directly related to your engine speed, a
harmonic thereof, or if it's determined as a function of the diameter of the
waste gate valve, the rated pressure and the overpressure, but my wife's not
here at the moment...

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)
'87 944S

I have to concur with Pete.  There were a couple of roundabouts in 
Smashachusetts, near Cape Cod that I had to negotiate.  Mass. drivers had 
serious problems dealing with forward progress in a more or less straight 
line, never mind any type of arc.  I lived in R. I. and rte.95, the main 
freeway thru the state had a lot of off/on ramps along some sweepers in 
Providence. Suicide city!!!People haven't yet grasped the concept of staying 
in a lane and negotiating a curve.  Triple lane changes in traffic at speed 
are normal fare for Mom in the station wagon with the kids and dog in the back. 
 
We Americans are wed to our cars.  There are few alternatives except for a 
very few metropolitan areas that are viable.  Let's quit pushing people into 
other forms transportation that don't exist and build some damn roads where we 
need 'em.  New cars are pretty clean and the older dirtier ones are going to 
fix themselves over time (they'll go away).  Write your local representatives! 
and remind them that we're going to continue to throw the bums out until we 
get bums that can do it right.

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 10:54:00 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: Legislation alert

>
>American drivers would perhaps become somewhat disturbed at the infamous 
>"Magic Roundabout" located at Hemel Hempstead, here in the UK. 
>
   Work send me to Hemel Hempstead last October for three weeks and I had the
opportunity to experience the "Magic Roundabout" first hand.  I rented a 
brand new BMW 316i(which handled very nicely even though it lacked punch) and
spent time driving back and forth from Hemel Hempstead to Leicester.  
   I only found myself on the wrong side of the road once or twice and this 
was only on empty roads.  Having the driving console on the right side of the
car makes driving on the right-side of the road much more natural.  It did,
however, take some time to train my left hand to shift.  What better to 
practice on than a rented car!

   A co-worker related his story of driving in England(he has also spent time
in Hemel Hempstead).  Bound and determined to master English driving the first
evening(after making numerous mistakes I might add), he spent 30 minutes 
driving on the "Magic Roundabout"!  He figured if the could master it than he
could handle anything and it worked.

   I particularly like the "single carriage" roads which have a protocol all
of their own...

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 12:10:26 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Please Don't Steer Me Wrong

Yes, you can disconnect the belt and all will be well.  Except your 
upper arm muscles may get a little sore, and the excessive pressure you 
apply to the steering wheel may annoy the leather.  I've been driving 
this way for about 4 months.

Beware of rebuilt racks; I installed one and it barely lasted a year.  
The shaft must be polished to new specification in order to avoid seal 
damage, but this is not done in many cases.

A friend of mine got a *new* ZF rack installed, from ZF directly, for a 
price thought to be well below $900 (he can't recall exactly).  You can 
do this job yourself but the job is difficult at times.  I wouldn't 
recommend it unless you're fairly experienced and you have a good range 
of tools.

		JBS

+-------------------------------+
>| From   : Peter Diffey         |

IMSA has also just changed the rules for the Porsche LMWSC car, lowering the
boost (and the boom, I guess). Fearful that the car which was significantly
slower than the lead Ferraris in testing would run away with the 24 hour, the
changes robbed the team of an estimated 50 horsepower. 
Walkinshaw (and Porsche) has pulled the team from the race. As someone who
has constructed a car for an IMSA series only to have the rules changed at
the last moment, I can sympathize with the Porsche factory. Why build a car
when rules stability is such a volatile concept? Indeed, as a fan I was
looking forward to the Porsche/Ferrari/Ford/Olds showdown--which now won't
happen. It's really unfortunate that IMSA has made a decision which is only
another incident which could keep Porsche out of sports car racing.

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 10:10:14 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: Of 944 Turbos and Wastegates

Hi All;

All the recent talk about Turbocharging raises a question about my '89 944 Turbo 
(note the deft tie-in).  Between about 0.8 to 1.0 bar pressure (as measured by 
the in-dash pressure gauge), I hear a loud exhaust resonance in my car which 
sounds like a valve chattering.  At least I assume it is exhaust related.  Could 
this have anything to do with the wastegate opening and closing?  Could someone 
explain to me how the wastegate operates and what its purpose is?  Is this a 
normal sound heard on all/some/other 944 Turbos?  It is consistent in every gear 
at any speed.

This noise has been bugging me since I got the car last August.  I have assumed 
it is normal, but other thoughts are welcome.  Thanks in advance.

Tracy Meyer
tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 10:23 EST
From: bartonc@infi.net (Barton P. Chambers)
Subject: WSC95 Rules re Porsche

Greetings,

I've recently read the new rules you...ummmm, ahhhhh, *fine* people have
passed to restrict the performance of the recently announced Porsche
entrant.

The world owes you a debt of gratitude for saving us from the spectre of
competition from an engine that dares to be different.  Heck-fire, if
them ol' Germans want to run with the big dawgs, let 'em design and build
a new engine that's jest like all the rest.  If they can't afford to do
that, t'hell with 'em.  The *Sport* is better off without 'em.

*Nice* work, boys and girls!  I'm sure that, in your infinite wisdom,
you've noticed that I'm probably the sole person in the world that would
like to see Porsche participate in this series, much *less* do so on a
competitive basis.

You've doubtless also observed that I drive an older Porsche, and thus
reasonably concluded that I *seldom* purchase any measurable quantities
of consumable items of any *value*; and with unerring logic, you've
(doubtless, correctly) deduced that my custom would therefore be of
little value to purveyors of things automotive.

Naturally, even though many people respond to churlish behavior by
refusing to extend their custom to those engaging in, or sponsoring such,
the loss of custom from such unreasonable folk will be inconsequential
and have no impact.  And shoot, even if you and your sponsors lose the
custom of a few soreheads, what matters is that you did the *right*
thing. Why, *Heaven* forfend, the idea of lettin' Porsche compete under
the rules as they were announced might make 'em competitive ...(shudder)
the mind boggles! (...the sound of a mind boggeling...)

and Not (he says, with all the sincerity he can muster) that anyone would
think that *your* recent rules aimed at making the Porsche entry
uncompetitive could be considered "Churlish" by any *reasonable*
person... Stupid, sure.  Dastardly, well... OK.  Contemptible; definitely!

But "Churlish"...(OK, OK, "Churlish").

Have a wonderful life,

Bart Chambers

Cheers

Bart Chambers
Frau Dora, Blonde

'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (stealth Quattro, Alpenweis

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 11:11:02 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Of 944 Turbos and Wastegates

I would describe it as more of a "chuffing" sound, and its is indeed your
friend the wastegate. It opens to allow excess boost to escape out exhaust.
Excess boost you say? No such thing you say? The turbo is designed to
optmize power in some way, meaning that under certain conditions more boost
is generated than they can really handle, so out the exhaust it goes. I've
heard of waste gates sticking in the closed postion. They make a lot of
power, for a little while. Love that sound!


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 16:47:46 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Legislation Alert--SB2050


There is one problem with round abouts - they work well when the flow of 
traffic is equal in all directions, however they tend to work badly in 
tidal traffic flows, because the odd car coming in from the right side 
(in UK) has priority. if you have cars arriving at about 80 yd gaps at 40 
mph, no one from the major flow can pull out, so the major flow backs up.

And contrary to US opinion, no bstar will ever slow up to let people pul 
out from the major flow.

This is especially true for "mini round abouts" where the minor flow of 
traffic can take the round about without slowing.

What would really improve the flow on these round abouts is speed bumps 
on the round about entrance - this would also make it safer for pedestrians.

+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 11:51 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Of 944 Turbos and Wastegates

Tracy Meyer asked recently:
All the recent talk about Turbocharging raises a question about my '89 944 Turbo 
(note the deft tie-in).  Between about 0.8 to 1.0 bar pressure (as measured by 
the in-dash pressure gauge), I hear a loud exhaust resonance in my car which 
sounds like a valve chattering.  At least I assume it is exhaust related.  Could 
this have anything to do with the wastegate opening and closing?  Could someone 
explain to me how the wastegate operates and what its purpose is?
- ---

As I understand wastegates (in my limited, English-major way), they are a basic
pressure-relief valve, like a pipe sticking out of the intake with a flap on 
the end.  This "flap" (valve) is held closed by a spring with a pre-set tension.
Once the boost reaches (or exceeds) a predetermined limit, the pressure of the
air on one side of the valve exceeds the pressure exerted on the flap by the
spring, the flap opens and lets the excess pressure bleed off until it is low
enough that the spring can close the flap again.  (In the "evil" turbo mods, the
pressure exerted by the spring can be changed, increasing or decreasing the
pressure at which the waste gate operates.)  My guess is that the chattering
you hear is the wastegate flap opening and closing at its rated pressure as the
individual pulses flowing through the exhaust spin the impeller just enough to
raise the pressure above the wategate's limit.  I'm sure a *real* engineer
could tell you if the chattering is directly related to your engine speed, a
harmonic thereof, or if it's determined as a function of the diameter of the
waste gate valve, the rated pressure and the overpressure, but my wife's not
here at the moment...

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)
'87 944S

I have to concur with Pete.  There were a couple of roundabouts in 
Smashachusetts, near Cape Cod that I had to negotiate.  Mass. drivers had 
serious problems dealing with forward progress in a more or less straight 
line, never mind any type of arc.  I lived in R. I. and rte.95, the main 
freeway thru the state had a lot of off/on ramps along some sweepers in 
Providence. Suicide city!!!People haven't yet grasped the concept of staying 
in a lane and negotiating a curve.  Triple lane changes in traffic at speed 
are normal fare for Mom in the station wagon with the kids and dog in the back. 
 
We Americans are wed to our cars.  There are few alternatives except for a 
very few metropolitan areas that are viable.  Let's quit pushing people into 
other forms transportation that don't exist and build some damn roads where we 
need 'em.  New cars are pretty clean and the older dirtier ones are going to 
fix themselves over time (they'll go away).  Write your local representatives! 
and remind them that we're going to continue to throw the bums out until we 
get bums that can do it right.

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 10:54:00 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: Legislation alert

>
>American drivers would perhaps become somewhat disturbed at the infamous 
>"Magic Roundabout" located at Hemel Hempstead, here in the UK. 
>
   Work send me to Hemel Hempstead last October for three weeks and I had the
opportunity to experience the "Magic Roundabout" first hand.  I rented a 
brand new BMW 316i(which handled very nicely even though it lacked punch) and
spent time driving back and forth from Hemel Hempstead to Leicester.  
   I only found myself on the wrong side of the road once or twice and this 
was only on empty roads.  Having the driving console on the right side of the
car makes driving on the right-side of the road much more natural.  It did,
however, take some time to train my left hand to shift.  What better to 
practice on than a rented car!

   A co-worker related his story of driving in England(he has also spent time
in Hemel Hempstead).  Bound and determined to master English driving the first
evening(after making numerous mistakes I might add), he spent 30 minutes 
driving on the "Magic Roundabout"!  He figured if the could master it than he
could handle anything and it worked.

   I particularly like the "single carriage" roads which have a protocol all
of their own...

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 12:10:26 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Please Don't Steer Me Wrong

Yes, you can disconnect the belt and all will be well.  Except your 
upper arm muscles may get a little sore, and the excessive pressure you 
apply to the steering wheel may annoy the leather.  I've been driving 
this way for about 4 months.

Beware of rebuilt racks; I installed one and it barely lasted a year.  
The shaft must be polished to new specification in order to avoid seal 
damage, but this is not done in many cases.

A friend of mine got a *new* ZF rack installed, from ZF directly, for a 
price thought to be well below $900 (he can't recall exactly).  You can 
do this job yourself but the job is difficult at times.  I wouldn't 
recommend it unless you're fairly experienced and you have a good range 
of tools.

		JBS

+-------------------------------+
>| From   : Peter Diffey         |

IMSA has also just changed the rules for the Porsche LMWSC car, lowering the
boost (and the boom, I guess). Fearful that the car which was significantly
slower than the lead Ferraris in testing would run away with the 24 hour, the
changes robbed the team of an estimated 50 horsepower. 
Walkinshaw (and Porsche) has pulled the team from the race. As someone who
has constructed a car for an IMSA series only to have the rules changed at
the last moment, I can sympathize with the Porsche factory. Why build a car
when rules stability is such a volatile concept? Indeed, as a fan I was
looking forward to the Porsche/Ferrari/Ford/Olds showdown--which now won't
happen. It's really unfortunate that IMSA has made a decision which is only
another incident which could keep Porsche out of sports car racing.

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 10:04:47 -0800
From: "Volney Spalding" <vol@espresso.corp.sgi.com>
Subject: re:rear window defogger

Kevin writes:

> This may sound stupid BUT try the switch connections for the second stage - I
> had to strip the ventilation(!) blower out to get at mine behind the wiper
> motor and what did I find?  - the spade connector had "dropped off".  Simply
> reconnected it and it all worked fine - this was after months of tracing
> wiring and checking fuses and relays initially from the garage where I baught
> it and then by me when they gave up.

Aha!  Kevin has defined a *rare* rare example of how Occam's Razor occasionally
applies to electrical work in old sports cars.  Note that it only applied
*after* he spent months of due diligence looking for the *likely* problem.

My theory is that Occam and Murphy have collaborated to come up with a
Particularly Devious Natural Law wrt care and feeding of Sports Cars:

If you go in thinking Occam, Murphy will prevail.  If you assume Murphy,
(if it can be difficult, it will, etc.) you should have gone with
Occam.

Repeat as necessary.

Call Bart's pharmacist in acute cases.

In my case, there is power to the glass, so Occam is no help here.

Also, whereas Kevin had to go around the blower, etc., in old cars you can
simply remove the speaker grill and reach in to the switch. I did this because
the glow light in the switch was burned out).

Vol

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 11:52:40 -0500
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: 951 fog-light replacement/upgrade

My driver's side fog-light is out.  What should be a fairly simple replacement
looks like another of my fix-it misadventures.  One of the 4 bolts holding the
light was so rusty that the head snapped off with very little force.  Time to 
get out the drill, start drilling, tough to drill dead center, start chewing 
up the plastic tab where the bolt sits in.  <sigh>.

Anyway, has anyone upgraded their fog lights for higher output?  Can the stock
wiring/relay handle the higher power?  Anyone replaced the 'extra' reflector 
with a dual-bulb set-up?  If so, then I'm thinking of installing a second 
switch to control the second 'high-intensity' driving light while maintaining 
the stock light for normal highway use.  In rural Pennsylvania where street 
lights are not common, I could use more light to see the various wildlife 
likely to be sitting on the road esp on the winding back roads taken at P-car 
speeds.  I realize I'd have to switch these off momentarily to avoid blinding 
oncoming traffic.  Then again, I could use the high-beams but I'm looking for 
a longer beam.  It's winter and I need to 'fix' something on my P-car so I 
don't go nuts.  

P.S. Anyone knows if ESPN will broadcast the Rolex 24-hours at Daytona?  I 
believe it was on live last year at selected times.

TIA,

Steve J.

'87 951 
Still looking for '73/'74 914 2.0 for autox/track car  

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 13:04:53 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: roundabouts in NJ


We have many many roundabouts here in New Jersey, mostly left
over from colonial horse and wagon days. Drivers here seem to
negotiate them pretty well, although lane discipline is non-
existant. I think they would work well with some sort of public
service messages on TV telling people how to politely enter and
exit. 

The thing I like about them is that during non-peak hours, they
make great skid pads :-) :-) :-)   Enter hot, trail brake (did
I say that?) snatch a lower gear, hang the tail out, and exit 
"at speed" with right foot steering -- WeeeeeHaaaaa!

I noticed that the last couple of times I was in the UK, a good
percentage of the drivers go straight over the mini-roundabouts
(those 2 meter dots) Is this new traffic policy or a shameful
degradation of driving morals?

 - Reid

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 11:17:15 -0700
From: "Drew A. Spencer" <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Re: Porsche and IMSA



Begin forwarded message:
> [SNIP]
> +-------------------------------+
> >| From   : Peter Diffey         |
> 

> IMSA has also just changed the rules for the Porsche LMWSC car, lowering the
> boost (and the boom, I guess). Fearful that the car which was significantly
> slower than the lead Ferraris in testing would run away with the 24 hour, the
> changes robbed the team of an estimated 50 horsepower. 

> Walkinshaw (and Porsche) has pulled the team from the race. As someone who
> has constructed a car for an IMSA series only to have the rules changed at
> the last moment, I can sympathize with the Porsche factory. Why build a car
> when rules stability is such a volatile concept? Indeed, as a fan I was
> looking forward to the Porsche/Ferrari/Ford/Olds showdown--which now won't
> happen. It's really unfortunate that IMSA has made a decision which is only
> another incident which could keep Porsche out of sports car racing.
> 


IMHO, Ferrari probably pressured IMSA to do this...

Ferrari made a big investment in IMSA by building the 333 SP and has been
a key to helping to make WSC at least a partial success.  Ferrari also 

seems to have some degree of control over the rules (witness Ferrari 

pushing back on rev limit rules that IMSA attempted to impose mid season
last year which IMSA backed down on when Ferrari threatened to pull out).
We can debate all day whether this is "right" or not, but Ferrari DID make
a significant financial commitment to WSC which Porsche doesn't appear 

to be willing to make.  OTOH, there are some who say that Porsche could
possibly have won the race even with the HP deficit due to possible 

reliability problems with the 333SP's powerplant which was designed primarily
for sprint racing.  They'd probably run the sprint motors for qualification
then de-tune them for the race itself creating more parity with the Porsche
than can be determined solely by testing times.  I wished Porsche/TWR would
have toughed it out anyway...

One other somewhat conspicuous absence from this race is the Porsche
GT-2.  I'm not that familiar with IMSA's GT-class rules, but I thought
the GT-2 would fit IMSA's GTS specs?

Drew
