courage to pull out, then drives like stink and does all he can to stop 
others pulling in front of him.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 14:04:58 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 fog-light replacement/upgrade

> My driver's side fog-light is out.  What should be a fairly simple 
replacement
> looks like another of my fix-it misadventures.  One of the 4 bolts 
holding the
> light was so rusty that the head snapped off with very little force.  
Time to
> get out the drill, start drilling, tough to drill dead center, start chewing
> up the plastic tab where the bolt sits in.  <sigh>.
Sounds as if the original hardware's been replaced.  Those screws 
shouldn't rust - at least, mine look like new, and they're 8 years old 
(stored during winter).

> Anyway, has anyone upgraded their fog lights for higher output?  Can 
the stock
> wiring/relay handle the higher power?  Anyone replaced the 'extra' reflector
> with a dual-bulb set-up?
Yes, Yes, Yes, in that order.  I measured voltage drop across the 
wires, using a stock 55w bulb and my current 100w bulb.  The power 
dissipation increase was modest, and there's a separate wire & fuse for 
each high beam line - very good quality design.  I'm using stock 
wiring, with higher fuse ratings.  My driving lights (Euro units) are 
100w also, with a dedicated relay.  They come on parallel with the main 
beams.  I've also modified the guts of the little square black module 
in the fuse box, so the fogs stay on regardless of main/dip beam setting.

So, with dip beams on everything's normal and other drivers aren't 
blinded.  But when I switch on the highs, I get 400w of light!  (This 
is dangerous during the dry season, as some grass and trees may catch 
fire...)  :-)

		JBS

Date: 26 Jan 95 12:04:29 PST

Ahhhhhh, yes....

There is nothing so wonderful as that feeling right after you purchase one
and are tooling down the road with that unmistakable ear-to-ear grin (that
can't be wiped off).  To top it off, it *could* be the best deal I've made
on ANY car, let alone a Porsche....

While we were looking for an early SC to play at the track and do tours,
etc. with, an ad popped in the Houston Chronicle:

'84 Carrera, Black/Tan, very clean, must see....  $14,560

For those of you in the Houston area that saw this and didn't call,
well.....

What I found was:

One owner sunroof coupe in excellent condition, 117K miles but with double
the routine maintenance and records -- Trans rebuilt w/ new clutch at 98K.
 AND the BEST part:

It has Factory:
Carrera Spoilers
Short Shift
Limited Slip
Sport Shocks
Full Leather (actually taupe color)
Climate Control
Alarm, etc. etc.  (even has a cellular phone])

Oh, I almost forgot the VERY best part; he sold it to me for  (are you
sitting down?) $11,500....

There IS a God...

 -Scott Jessen -- can't wait for work to end today...
sjje@chevron.com

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 16:38:30 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: 912E #1 Oil Leaks!!! Best rebuilds?

Greetings Porsche Dwellers,
	I was driving the 912E home from work and noticed it was smoking 
even more than usual.  Rings getting more worn I thought.  Come out to 
drive to work the next morning and behold, the River Jordan sprang forth 
from my car!  The River of Oil seeped from a lower crankcase seal and ran 
down my driveway leaving a HUGE stain.  Back to commuting in my 924 (my 
912E looked much cooler!).   
	First  question, how do you get oil stains off your driveway and second 
of all, most importantly, what do I do for a rebuild.  This thing has 
146K miles on it (and no one installed a radio?? :^) so it needs a 
thorough going over.  914 2.0 engines are rebuilt similarly aren't they?  
Who does the best most original job, and how much can I expect to pay?  
I'll pull the engine myself.  About the radio that generated much 
response: I'm leaving it the way it is--original and using a small radio 
powered by cigarette lighter to listen to tunes.  I'm not going to be 
paranoid about my car, I'm just going to enjoy it while keeping it as 
original as possible. Thanx!!!   

Jay Karolyi

'76 912E ( feel like Uncle Jed with all this gosh-durn oil on my property!)
'77 924 still my baby!
'96 Boxster (maybe they'll trade me one for my #1...dreamin on...)

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 14:16:53 -0800 (PST)
From: Ted Rodgers <rodgers@indigo01.akctr.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Clean Air Backlash

Motorists should rebel at the continuous erosion of our liberties.  HOV
lanes are a good example of how the person who likes to work late or come
in early when necessary is discriminated against, in favor of the person
who ALWAYS works the same, but just enough hours.  They also discriminate
against people like my wife who has to help her aged parents after work,
and can't carpool.  Of course they could always go on welfare and a social
worker nurse could drive 30 miles each way to help, all at taxpayer
expense.  Now in Seattle they're trying to take away parking from
employers to force people into carpools. 

Dennis Simanaitis in the latest Road and Track makes an apropos comment 
about how social engineering and social disease both involve getting screwed.

My $.02.

Ted Rodgers

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 14:36:13 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Of 944 Turbos and Wastegates

A couple of folks have responded that the noise may be the waste gate
and went on to say that the waste gate relieved intake manifold pressure
by opening it to the atmosphere. Hmmm. The waste does regulate
intake manifold pressure, but unless the 951 differs from other Porsches,
it does so by controlling the exhaust pressure to the turbine. When intake
boost goes too high, the waste gate opens so that exhaust gases are
routed from the exhaust manifold directly to the tail pipe, bypassing
the turbine.

BTW, I noticed that one of the Daytona entries is a 968 turbo. Too
bad Porsche hasn't tried to get US DOT approval for a street version
in the US. I understand that a non-race version is sold for street use
in Europe.

Another Daytona Porsche is a GTS-1 turbo 911. I wonder if that is
the new, factory 993 GT. Anyone know?

    Eric

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 17:07:55 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: 912E #1 Oil Leaks!!! Best rebuilds?


Your car has a VW 411 engine.

Anyone who does VW engines can rebuild yours. You should try to use the
same quality parts that were used at the factory. I wouldn't get
excited about making changes from the stock configuration/specs unless
they came from someone who really know what was going on. Guys who soup
up VW dune buggies in their garage on weekends might not be the best
way to go.

I support your decision to keep the car basically original. It's really
in your best economic interest. 

Having to do a engine rebuild after buying an older 911/912 is not
unusual. This is the reason quite a few are sold. At least you get to
control the rebuild..not the PO. It is a good idea to take photos when
the engine is apart. This will be comforting to the next owner if you
decide to sell the car before the next 146K miles goes by.

**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 15:16:49 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: RE: Bart and Petards

From the "Dictionary of Cultural Literacy":

"hoist with one's own petard"

Idioms

To be caught in one's own trap: "The swindler cheated himself out of most
of his money, and his victims were satisfied to see him hoist with his own
petard." A "petard" was an explosive device used in MEDIEVAL warfare. To be
hoisted, or lifted, by a petard literally means to be blown up.

Scott


>Subject: Bart and Petards
>

>besides the well known ones about the military engineer's device and the
>French fart. It was also supposed to mean farting loudly in church, and
>everybody knows it was you...
>
>Confucius say, man who fart in church sit in own pew.

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 16:24:11 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: 931 brake master cylinder

Well, I finally solved the part dilemma; the cylinder that I needed was
the one listed in Chilton and in the Porsche book (477.611.017), but
my local part supplier had the wrong part in the right box!!

So I'm happy to say that two weeks, four cylinders and two rebuild
kits later, the car runs (and stops) like new again. :-))

Thanks to Mike and Jim P for their help with the numbers.

 -mike   '80 931  fire engine red

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 95 19:17:51 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: re: Smog legislation (long)

Once more into the (potential) fires.  If any of the following was mentioned 
in digest #1101, I apologize for the duplication.  Said digest arrived here 
but empty.

I have been a bit surprised that nobody has mentioned the car crushing 
programs that were -- and perhapsstill are -- in effect in CA and PA.  These 
programs are promoted as removing old smog-monsters from the road thereby 
reducing the amount of air pollution.  For a while you could find pictures 
of ecology-minded ex-owners standing in front of their flattened, ex-autos 
with a several-hundred dollar check in their hands.  It went without mention 
that the program was/is sponsored by at least one automobile manufacturer 
and petrochemical company all of which receive "pollution credits" for 
stationary sources.  Put simply, if they destroy a mobile pollution source, 
they receive an additional grace period for reforming their manufacturing 
plants.  There is no reduction in air pollution, merely a transfer from one 
source to another.

Chris Willis asks (probably rhetorically) why they (whoever *they* are) 
never mention the amount of pollution generated during the manufacture of 
the car.  Because this would offend large businesses that donate 
astronomical amounts of money to political campaigns.

Brian Foster suggests boycotting the companies that support this kind of 
legislation which is a good idea if you can find an insurance company or oil 
company that doesn't.  You still need both to run your old(er) car.

Sounds like a conspiracy.  Someone call Oliver Stone.

Finally, on the subject of hoisting by one's own petard . . .  It was 
mentioned that autos are *not* the leading cause of air pollution.  Quite 
true.  In fact the leading source of unburnt hydrocarbons is . . . cattle!  
Leads to some interesting images.  A pasture full of cows with catalytic 
converters sticking out of their orrifi;  a confused state emmisions tech 
(one eyebrow up ala John Belushi) with gas analyser probe in hand confronted 
with the hindquaters of an equally confused bovine . . .  Maybe it's just 
me.  I'm in Wisconsin.

     Bill
     wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu

Porschephiles #1104                         Fri Jan 27 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 20:37:22 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Never-Fog

Never-Fog works for me. I don't have the best heat in the old 911 and it 
takes a while to come up, so I have used this stuff for several years 
with good success. I do find that it doesn't last all that long, and that 
if you don't clean the inside with a regular cleaner about once a month 
it tends to leave a residue that makes matters worse. But if I apply it 
regularly to a clean windshield it sure helps on those wet cold mornings!
Dave Christiano, Springfield, Missouri
1974 914/6 3.0 liter
1976 911S (soon to be for sale)
1986 930 (soon to be on the road)

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 20:53:55 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 912E #1 Oil Leaks!!! Best rebuilds?

> >Your car has a VW 411 engine.
>
> The engine IS NOT A VW 411 it is based on the 411 but is a 914 2.0 
> engine. Do not let a VW mech rebuild it. Take it to someone who 
> specializes in Porsches.

Mike is 1000% right. The 412/411 engines are *NOT* the same as
the 914 2.0s which are *NOT* the same as 912Es.

If possible, fine someone that's worked on a 912E. If that's not possible,
*PLEASE* find at least a 914 expert. *DO NOT* use "Bob's Pretty Good
VW Shop"...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 22:51:20 -0500
From: LouKrieg@aol.com
Subject: Re: Blowers of all types.

>The wastegate helps by prventing overboost and back pressure, which can 
>"stall" the drive side. Aircraft have a big advantage as the power 
>settings and throttle response are fairly slow and aren't too badly
>affected by turbo lag.
>
>Jim Pasha
>

Affect is relative; on the Piper Turbo Arrow IV I used to fly, the wastegate
is fixed in position (no DME to control it!).

The technique on takeoff was to advance the throttle to a position determined
by experience, watch as the boost came up (monitoring the Manifold Pressure
gauge) and then "tweak" the throttle to the target manifold pressure, while,
of course, doing all the other things required during the early part of a
takeoff roll. Overboosting was considered VERY bad practice (likely to exact
its own retribution from the miscreant, or at least the next pilot to fly the
ship!), while less than optimal boost resulted in a longer takeoff roll and
soggy climb-out. The effect of turbo lag in this case was to cause a
wandering path down the runway as the pilot compensated for the extra power
coming on rapidly (which requires additional right rudder to balance the
aircraft's left turning tendency, for reasons too non-automotive to go into
here).

I suppose the first automotive turbochargers must have had simple, fixed
wastegates as well, no?

Lou Krieg
'87 951 Ocean Blue Metallic
'90 VW Corrado G60 Tornado Red
'95 Jeep Grand Cherokee Moss Green

Date: Wed, 25 Jan 1995 14:02:14 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: No Porsche WSC car



Thought I would share two items that went out on the Internet today to all
PCA regional editors (now numbering 34 regions in PCA) who have subscrbed
(free) to the PCA Editors Mail List.

Larry Wilson
***************************

Porsche WSC Team Withdraws From 24 Hours of Daytona Due To Sudden Rules
Change

RENO, NEVADA, January 25, 1995 --- As the result of a surprising change in
regulations made on Tuesday, January 24, by sanctioning body IMSA which
affects the two open-cockpit Porsche WSC category sports prototypes, the
Stuttgart sports car maker has decided not to field a factory team in the
1995 edition of the 24 Hours of Daytona on February 4 and 5. The change in
regulations at such short notice is so severe that Porsche would not be able
to compete on an equal footing against Ferrari, its greatest rival. Porsche
AG deeply regrets the IMSA decision as this represents a severe setback for
efforts to establish an attractive world series for sports cars. Porsche AG,
active in the IMSA series since the early 1970s, does not pursue motor sport
as an end in itself, and will continue to enter only events which allow
reliable conditions for all competitors.

The new IMSA rule change for the two WSC Porsches has resulted in a
reduction in the size of the air restrictors of the twin-turbo engines from
34.5 mm to 32 mm, and an increase in vehicle weight from 1,950 lbs. to 2,050
lbs. Calculations made by Porsche engineers have shown that the air
restrictor reduction will result in a decrease of about 80 HP in power
output, from 540 HP to 460 HP. With this new power figure, the two WSC
Porsches would lap at least four to five seconds slower than their
competitors. Calculated over the 24-hour race distance, this would he a
disadvantage of at least one hour. These are conditions Porsche is unable to
accept.

During the official preliminary tests at Daytona at the beginning of
January, Porsche allowed IMSA officials to view vehicle data and had also
disclosed power curves. IMSA officials then confirmed the data was fully in
accordance with the regulations. This makes the sudden about face by IMSA
even more incomprehensible.

Porsche remains committed to motor sport and will continue to compete in the
future in view of the challenges racing poses for both man and machine.
However, Porsche will not participate in events where unreliable regulations
make entries an incalculable risk. For Porsche, sport means fair competition
between all entrants.

Courtesy Porsche Cars North America
Bob Carlson, General Manager, Public Relation

********************************

Commentary:
IMSA Throws Curve At Porsche
by Larry Wilson

On January 24, almost the eve of the February 4 and 5 24 Hours of Daytona,
the sanctioning body, IMSA, announced they would change the regulations for
the race by imposing additional restrictions to turbocharged World Sports
Cars running in the Le Mans category. Since the two Porsche WSC95 cars were
the only such cars entered, it was clear who IMSA had targeted. Porsche AG
reacted promptly January 25 by withdrawing from the race.

The five-paragraph IMSA press release included, "As announced in the
original Daytona regulations, IMSA reserved the right to adjust the initial
specifications for Le Mans World Sports Cars at any time preceding the
event.  After a careful and extensive review of available data, IMSA has
decided that the potential of such engines exceeds original estimates and
that a legislated reduction in performance was required." No where in those
five paragraphs did IMSA mention the name, Porsche.

It's hard to imagine what "data" IMSA relied on when making this decision.
It surely was not timing data compiled during the January 7-9 IMSA Test Days
at Daytona. The best time of the weekend went to car #30, Ferrari 333SP
(Taylor, Moretti, Salazar, Theys) with a lap time of 1:43.624. Fifth-fastest
car of the weekend was car #35, Porsche WSC95  (Andretti, Wollek, Goodyear)
with a time of 1:45.985. Sixth was the other Porsche WSC95, car #36 (Stuck,
Boutsen, Brabham) at 1:47.276. Although not said publicly, IMSA reportedly
believed Porsche had "sand-bagged" during the Test Days so as not to incur
additional restrictions. These rumors did not detail just how IMSA reached
this conclusion. Maybe the "data" that got IMSA's attention came from
Maranello.

Of even greater consequence in the IMSA announcement was the line, "Parallel
regulations for the 1995 24-Hours of Le Mans include a turbocharged World
Sports Car option." Porsche announced previously its intention of entering
the 24 Hours of LeMans with their new cars. Since the only way "in" was
through the IMSA turbocharged WSC option class, IMSA's rule change also
applies at LeMans. And, if Porsche believes its cars have been rendered
uncompetitive at Daytona, they will undoubtedly reach the same conclusion
with respect to LeMans and withdraw from that race.

In any case, it's sad. What could have revived the excitement of sports car
racing world-wide is now gone -- shot down by a sanctioning body in the U.S.
that forgot to read its own January 19 race-hype that promised Mario
Andretti, Geoff Brabham, Bob Wollek, and the revival of the Porsche vs.
Ferrari wars of past years. Also shot in this unseemly episode is the foot
of IMSA, a self-inflicted wound.

Forwarded message:
Subj:    Transmission Lockup
Date:    95-01-22 16:29:06 EST
From:    Carrera3
To:      porschefile@tta.com

My '77 Carrera 3.0, with 915 tranny, sometimes suffers what seems to be a
lock-up that I can only describe as being in locked in reverse and
concurrently accessing any of the other gears.  As example, if I shift into
first or any forward gear, there is absolutely no movement at all; but if I
shift into neutral I can move in reverse.  So far this has happened only
while shifting FROM reverse and the "cure" is by repeated/firmly shifting out
of reverse until the lockup disengages.  So far mechanics only go "Hmmm", so
I'm reluctant to commit $$ when the repairer appears stumped - in the
meantime, I can manage with the "annoyance" as long as it doesn't appear to
be moving to permanent.  Any ideas?

Porschephiles #1105                         Fri Jan 27 12:27:46 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 23:14:31 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: IMSA's Response



Here's IMSA's response (race commercials snipped) to the Porsche WSC
withdrawal. Please note, in the last paragraph, who receives IMSA's "major
focus."

Larry Wilson

*****************
From the International Motor Sports Association (IMSA)
Contact:  Lynn Myfelt, (813) 877-4672

TAMPA, Fla. (January 26, 1995) - The International Motor Sports Association,
Inc. (IMSA) regrets the withdrawal of two of the four Porsche Le Mans World
Sports Cars entered for the upcoming Rolex 24 at Daytona, February 4-5.

However, IMSA stands by its decision to make performance adjustments to the
Le Mans World Sports Cars.  As announced in the original Daytona
Supplementary Regulations, IMSA reserved the right to adjust the initial
specifications for Le Mans World Sports Cars at any time preceding the
event.

IMSA's major focus remains on the season-opening race and the IMSA EXXON
World Sports Car and EXXON Supreme GT teams committed to running the entire
1995 IMSA season.

*****************

      I just had to reply to this, since my dad had a 411.  If memory serves 
me, I believe the block was the same between the engines.  But anyway, I own 
a VW AND a Porsche and get a little upset seeing VW's constantly being 
maligned.  No offense to actual 914 owners, but my impression over the years 
is that the poor 914 has been maligned as a poor man's Porsche (or a rich 
man's VW), and now I hear people sticking up for it and saying no VW 
mechanic is worthy of working on one.  I would suspect that many German-car 
mechanics have worked on both at some point in time.  Just because its a VW 
doesn't make it cheap.  Many parts are every bit as expensive as Audi or 
Porsche parts.
     As much as some folks seem to despise VW, you can't get away from the 
family resemblance.  So instead of fighting it to the death, be proud of 
your cars' roots.  I am.

David B.  
'89 944 (proud owner)
'81 Rabbit (just as proud owner)

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 10:30:20 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Of 944 Turbos and Wastegates

Doug,
If you can hear your wastegate bleeding off exhaust gas you probably have a
problem. (this does not apply to 930's etc.). If you are running a straight
pipe without cat then maybe you can hear it. I've owned a few turbo's and
I've never heard any noise from the wastegate except with my track car that
has a modified exhaust system. And yes I do get on the boost once in a great
while.
It is not uncommon for the exhaust system to decay at the waste gate piping
where it runs into the cat. You really don't want an exhaust leak, which is
what I expect you'll find, at that point in your system. Take a hard look at
it.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
10:20 am

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 95 10:37:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 89 944 Turbo allignment for racing


Hi Eric,

I don't think there's a pat answer to your alignment question, specifically
the camber.  It will depend on what else you do with the suspension and
on the kind of tires you use.

The only way to really tell is with a pyrometer, which is used to measure
the temperature profile across the width of a tire's tread.  If you are
thinking of PCA events at Lime Rock, you could hook up with me -- I
have a pyrometer and would be happy to help out.

Yes, if you lower the car, stiffer springing may be needed to keep from
bottoming out the suspension.  Again, depends on tires and how hard
you push the car.  I don't remember the stock rate.  I think it's 28 N/m,
and forget the conversion to lb/in.  Remember that negative camber is
used to compensate for positive camber changes induced by
suspension travel.  So stiffer springs => less induced camber => less
need for static negative camber.

As a sample point and for what it's worth, I have a 944S.  I use about
2.25 degrees negative in the front, 1.5 negative in the rear.  The car's
suspension has 200# front springs, 23.5 mm rear torsion bar (yours is
25.5, I think), 1-1/8" front sway bar set back 36mm from full loose,
a 7/8" rear bar run at full stiff, and some of the rubber bushings have
been converted to solid ones.  Handles well, and the pyrometer
readings are very flat across the tread face.

Hope this helps,

Kevin Gross

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 10:33:07 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 912E #1 Oil Leaks!!! Best rebuilds?

>      As much as some folks seem to despise VW, you can't get away from the 
> family resemblance.  So instead of fighting it to the death, be proud of 
> your cars' roots.  I am.

It's not a question of pride, it's one of COMMMON SENSE. There are damn
few parts that a VW Type II 2.0 (*NOT* even the 411/412 engine, which 
was only seen in the 1.7 config) share with a 914 or 912E. The heads
are different. The cam is different. The timing is different. The
pistons are different. Even the case is slightly different.

This is like saying that anyone who can work on high-voltage power lines
should be able to fix your computer because they share a common 
heritage and some parts (like say copper wire, PVC insulations, maybe
some odd bits of silcon, etc).

I my wife owns the nicest '73 Standard Beetle I've ever seen -- and has 
since 'late '72. Used to own a lot of early Type Is and IIIs, including
a Type III Karman Ghia, some split-window Beetles, etc. Rather than
deriding the heritage, I *REVEL* in it. 

It's just that I also know when it's appropriate to say "this is the same"
and when it isn't.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 10:46:13 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 912E #1 Oil Leaks!!! Best rebuilds?

> I can accept the engine delivered in a new 1976 VW 411, and a new 1976
> 912E are not precisely identical. But does anyone know where the 1976
> 912E engine was manufactured (inside the Porsche factory or inside the
> VW plant)? Just what is different(pistons/cams/etc)?

First, think 2.0 Type II, *NOT* 1.7 Type IV. It's *GENERICLY* called
a Type IV engine, but the late Type IVs area all really used in Type IIs
even though they're called Type IVs; the Type IV just didn't last real
long as a product...

Case, crank, con rods, misc external parts (some cooling sheet metal,
oil cooler, fan, filler cap, etc), misc internal parts (oil pump, crank
gears, pushrods, lifters, oil pressure relief, etc) are identical.
The 914 and 912E have Porsche designed heads, different valve gear,
very different sheet metal, and other slight internal differences that
would be easy to call to mind if I were standing over a split case...
The 914 have three different EFI setups, and the 912E is different still.
This means the induction system, including plumbing, fuel lines, injectors,
brains, wiring, distributor, etc. are ALL DIFFERENT and not interchangable
even with the 914!

> It would be helpful to know what is unique about the 912E engine that
> makes competent, professional VW shop/mechanic a bad choice for the
> rebuild. 

The theory is that because the parts are interchangeable, that the
skills should be. The 914/912E are very different to set up. A high
quality VW "speed shop" like Berg, Kawell, Linenger, etc. should be
able to do this right, because you really need to "blueprint" the engine
in some respects - check the valve timing, maybe modify the cam gear to
adjust it to be right, set the pushrod length, etc. You also *REALLY*
need to know the AFC EFI used on the 912E. It's similar to, but very
diffferent from, the AFC used on both the late Type Is and the 1.8 914s.

> Because 912E was only made for a year, finding someone who has
> done many rebuilds could be difficult.

Yup. You got it. Which is why I offered as a second choice finding a
shop that's done a lot of 914s. *MAKE SURE* they have the 912E
supplement to the 911 manual set!!!

Stan

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 09:30:59 -0800
From: ero@ix.netcom.com (Harold Williams)
Subject: Re: Are Early 930s Grenades?

I would suggest that the prices for the turbos you've seen reflect them 
needing some major work. They are expensive to repair, and I think the 
maintainence is a little more than a 911. The difference between the 
76-77 turbos and the 78 and newer ones seem to be, the newer ones have 
bigger brakes, bigger intercoolers and aren't as nervous as the 76-77's.
I bought a 78 about 1 1/2 ago for 20k. Since then I've invested(not 
voluntarily) $13k for repairs. I repeat repairs, no upgrades. The 
Porsche shop that did the pre-purchase inspection ( my mechanic was 
vacation, and I was impatient) didn't do a very good job. They felt the 
car would need about $5-6k worth of work within the next two years. I 
was o.k. with that. Imagine my surprise when the price doubled and I 
needed all within a year. I would suggest that if you were going to up 
grade the 76-77s to 78 and newer specs that you just get a '78 or newer 
one. I also think that most any older turbos are going to need some 
major work, unless one found someone who stuck alot of money into one 
and was willing to part with it cheap, highly unlikely. I talked to a 
guy who bought a '79 930 with 6k original mi. He drove it for a few 
weeks and pulled a head stud, apparently the original owner didn't store 
it correctly, what ever that means. $5k later it's on the road again. 
I've seen it for sale recently.
The good news is dispite the high cost, the car is such a gas, and I 
would and will own another. Next time I'll be alittle more patient. 
The're are good ones out there.
Harold
78 930
68 crewcab

ped on the hood of my car for a few days.  I immediately took it to a friend's

didn't come off.  In fact, it ate through the paint.  I reported it to the camp
us security, who took pictures of the damage and filed a report.  They told me
to get an estimate, and I did- $1,200(to do it right).  I submitted this to the
campus lawer's office and they said that they would get in touch with their ins
urance.  They said that they might not be liable because I have to prove that
the school could have prevented the damage from happening.  Does anyone have
any thoughts on this?  I think that they could have noticed this big leak and
patched it up or put a sign "don't park here".  There are always maintenance

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 17:58:09 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Blowers of all types.


Ref turbo arrows and fixed waste gates -

To the best of my ken waste gates are always spring loaded, pressure from
the inlet manifold depresses a spring and opens the gate, the main purpose
isn't to reduce back pressure, this is an unfortunate consequence rather
than an evil, it's purpose is to keep the compression ration down below
the point at which detonation occurs, which for gasolene is around 18:1. 1
bar boost on a 8:1 engine obviously gives compression of around 16:1... 

The waste gate in older cars were never directly controlled by the DME,
you would either need a solenoid to open the waste gate - not exactly fail
safe, or would need a solenoid to hold the waste gate closed, if the
solenoid was driven by a transistor the DME would be getting hot!! 

I understand that some turbos now have solenoid operated wgs - dubious 
benefit, personally I like simple reliable systems, wires and hot engine 
parts do not mix well.

SAAB and probably most other manufacturers go close to the 18:1, and to
stop over boost use a knock sensor on the engine, I am not exactly
sure how the knock sensor works, but its action is simple, it feeds info
to the DME, and in the same way as over revs, this cuts a proportion of
the engine sparks. 

Regarding waste gate chatter, if a pressure operated waste gate is changed
out, for example if someone wishes to fit a wg with a different boost
limit, it could be that the new wg has less hysteresis. The wg pressure
feed pipe size has a considerable effect on the wg characteristics- ie a
thinner pipe increases the hysteresis. A wg with a different pressure

I think the reasons that turbo aircraft do not use electronic knock 
elimination are quite obvious - electrics complexity/reliability.

Lou - flying a turbo arrow and running a p-car must count as conspicuous 
consuption - you lucky son of a gun.



+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 95 10:38:31 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: 914 sheet metal

>Date: Thu, 26 Jan 1995 10:48:33 -0500
>Reply-To: Alex Noordergraaf <noorder@btg.com>
>Subject: Best source for 914 sheet metal


>I followed the recent thread on the best sources for 356 replacement metal
>with great interest, and am interested in similar information for the 914s.
>Does anyone have experience with 914 replacement parts from the different
>vendors?  Specifically: Stoddard, Restoration Design, Doc & Cy's, Tweeks,
>Zims, and GPR.  Stan recommended Mill Supply a while back - does anyone have
>a phone number?  I am going to need quite a few pieces: both rocker panels,
>jack support plates, outer rocker panels, etc and would like make sure I get
>the THICKEST replacement pieces available.  I have spoken with the people at
>Zims and they said that their 914 source is domestic US.  Is there only one
>manufacturer for 914 parts?  Anyone that I should avoid?

>Alex Noordergraaf [noorder@btg.com]

>'73 914 (no engine) [going under the rust-repair knife]
>'73 914 2.0 [lurking under car cover]
>[three complete 914s in boxes in the garage (back yard actually :-)]

During the rustoration of my '73-914, I used parts from Tweeks, Restoration
Design, Parts Werks, and Automobile Atlanta.

The thinnest was Tweeks, the thickest was Parts Werks.  But I guess the
Parts Werks parts don't count; they were frame stiffeners.

All the parts fit.  The Tweeks parts needed tweeking.  The Parts Werks
frame stiffeners were a chore.

They ONLY parts that were galvanized were from Automobile Atlanta.  And
one other good thing:  I bought the entire "rust-from-the-battery-typical-
914-kit" from AA, and was allowed to return the unused parts.

The torch-surgeon for my car said to avoid "Pacific-Rim" steel.  Too
thin, and not enough carbon.

Give George a call.  Good steel, good fit, galvanized.  Tell him I want
a discount for this blatant plug.  :)

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1106                         Fri Jan 27 18:02:51 CST 1995
Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 10:42:53 -0800
From: William Oldham <oldham@EECS.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: 912E rebuilds

I recently did the rebuild on mine (at 225K miles, with a
previous known rebuild at ~140K mi) and here is what I found out:
1) The case bore and crank journals were well within spec
So I did NOT grind or align bore... be
careful if someone wants to do that...check diameters yourself
2) The rods were perfect 
3) No broken rings
4) One very badly damaged valve seat  (the cause of the rebuild...
which was brought about by a dishonest mechanic dropping a screw in
to generate business)
5) Lots of cracks in the heads and lots of evidence of previous
welding on the heads, presumable at the time of the first rebuild.

At that time the engine rebuilders supply guys advertising the Pano
sold 912E kits  (pistons &cylinders, bearings, gaskets, some clutch
parts) for about $550 so I started with that.  The real problem was
the heads.  That will be your problem too.  I could not find any
used heads better than mine, and the "authorities" said mine were
not rebuildable.  Not wanting to pay the enormous cost of new heads,
I kept searching and found the Germans parts and resoration guys in
San Luis Obisbo CA who have a guru welder.  They did indeed do a
beautiful job and the volumes all matched.

The car was terrific after rebuild  (I have since sold it, and have
heard no complaints.)

Be sure to do the sheetmetal and the sound insulation when the engine
is out.

Date: Tue, 17 Jan 1995 10:57:31 -0500 (EST)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: 951 Sunroof Problems

I have an '87 951 with an electric sunroof. About 6 months ago, it 
started giving me problems. When the roof is closed down tight, it won't 
open again. It seems as if it's sticking; after the switch is pressed 20 
times, it opens. When I don't close it all the way tight, the roof goes 
up and down with no problem. This leads me to believe the switch is OK 
and the motor is, too. What is causing the "sticking"? I appreciate any help.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 02:44:07 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: Paint damage

>A couple of days ago I walked up to my 928 and noticed a big "stain" on the
>hood of the car.  The problem is that most of it didn't come off.  In fact, 
it ate >through the paint. ..... an estimate, and I did- $1,200(to do it right).
>Sean  '80 928


Sean,
Definitely try to get this problem taken care of with your school first.  It 
is always best if the bill is coming out of their insurance.  If you can't 
get this problem resolved, however, and you have to foot the bill yourself, 
you may want to consider self-repair.  If you are at all handy, and are 
interested in tackling such a project, you could save some bucks.  

I assume that since you said "it ate through the paint" that it is beyond a 
compounding job.  Usually the largest and  most expensive aspect of minor 
body/paint repairs is the prep work.  This is not terribly difficult or 
extremely skilled work.  It is just very time consuming, tedious, and 
boring.......hence its high cost.  One of the smartest routes to take is to 
carry out the prep work yourself, and make arrangements for a reputable 
body/paint shop to merely spray or "shoot" the hood with the new paint.  
This should be considerably less expensive, and who would take greater care 
in prepping YOUR car than YOU?  If this idea appeals to you, I'd recommend 
hitting the library/book store for one of the many books on minor body 
repair.  One word of caution, check with the body shop first on the brand of 
prepping agents to use so as not to cause chemical conflict with their 
particular paints.  Overlooking this detail could cause a disaster.

Andy

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 15:32:20 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Roundabouts

Rob Yasek says, " As a matter of course, when sitting at a light here ... and
it changes, I will generally make sure there isn't someone sailing through
the first few milliseconds of "new red light"."

Ah, yes, this is defensive driving in the finest Porsche manner, and is a
practice that all drivers of fine machinery should learn.  It is part and
parcel of the "defensive" package: keeping an eye on the rear view mirror
while braking; looking both ways twice before proceeding through a stop sign;
inspecting the pavement ahead for stray bolts, muffler bits, and pickup
tailgates; and, looking for the least convenient parkig space in the least
accessible corner of the mall or airport parking lot.

In regard to roundabouts, and speaking as a former resident of the U.K. and
an engineer who studied traffic control as part of the curriculum, there is
no doubt roundabouts are better than garden-variety intersections for
improving traffic flow.  With careful design they can handle a tremendous
number of vehicles.  You eventually reach a point, however, where something
else is required.  Just a few weeks ago I found one of those in London,
somewhere near the north end of Park Lane, and I swear it's responsible for
the mild stroke I'm presently recovering from!

Bob Joyce

1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 13:07:09 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Of 944 Turbos and Wastegates 

Jerry944T@aol.com wrote:
> If you can hear your wastegate bleeding off exhaust gas you probably have a
> problem. (this does not apply to 930's etc.). If you are running a straight
> pipe without cat then maybe you can hear it. I've owned a few turbo's and
> I've never heard any noise from the wastegate except with my track car that
> has a modified exhaust system. And yes I do get on the boost once in a great
> while.

OTOH, my 931 has a clearly audible transition into the overboost.  On
the 931, the wastegate pipe plumbs into a point halfway back through
the cat.  When that puppy opens up, my exhaust tone changes to more of
a roar... a sweet and very satisfying sound!

 -mike   '80 931   fire engine red

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 16:22:13 -0500
From: conrad@lcc.stonehill.edu (Claudia Conrad)
Subject: Re: OUCH!

Luther's note about the guy who hit a car, then left a note saying he
wasn't leaving his name and address reminded me of an incident a few
years ago.

My husband and I went to the formula one race in Phoenix.  We went out
to dinner with a group of friends, and we all witnessed a truck hitting
a car parked in the lot.  The guy got out of the truck, and proceeded 
to write a note and leave it.  At least he thought we witnesses would
think that.  Our group, after he drove away, looked at the note.  He had
scribbled nonsense on the back of a child's spelling test.  Well, our
group was happy to add to his gibberish his license plate number,
a description of him and his truck, a note explaining what he had done,
and our phone numbers in case the victim wanted witnesses for the
prosecution.

None of us every heard from the victim, but we like to think the hit-and-
run scumbag got what he deserved.

Claudia Conrad
1973 Carrera RS
1971 914-6

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 95 16:28:43 EDT
From: "Bill Elwell" <B.Elwell@zds.com>
Subject: re: Smog legislation/Car crushing


     >I have been a bit surprised that nobody has mentioned the car
     >crushing programs....
     
     The most offensive part of the car crushing program is how poorly the 
     implementation achieves the program's goals.  Let me explain.
     
     The car crushing program is an attempt at removing polluting vehicles 
     from our roads.  Crushed cars earn "pollution credits" for the 
     corporate sponsor(s) of the program.  The rules state that only 
     "regularly driven" cars are to be crushed.  This makes sense.  If you 
     crush an old junker that hasn't run for years, you have not improved 
     the pollution situation.
     
     Now for reality.  What kind of cars do you think people bring to these 
     crush for cash sessions?  You guessed it!  Old junkers that haven't 
     run in years.  Most folks get the cars running well enough to drive to 
     the crusher.  Others tow the car until they get within a few blocks of 
     the crusher.  No pollution solution here.
     
     Bill Elwell

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 95 13:07:25 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: 944 non-OEM Radiator?

| From: Tim Flint  <tflint@netcom.com>
|
| I'm posting this again because I didn't get one response, the
| manufacturer claims that the temp never goes above the first line on the
| temp gauge even on a hot day.
|
| Any thoughts?

One obvious reason for not getting an answer is that no one on the
list may know the answer. For example, I do not know if there is a
potential for a galvanic reaction between aluminum and brass/
copper (pun intentional).

However, I do know that engines are designed to run best in a
particular temperature range. Running too cool can be nearly
as bad as running too hot. I am sure that Porsche designed the
cooling system to match the cooling needs of the engine. So,
unless the engine has been modified to produce significanly
more HP, or you are towing a trailer, then you shouldn't need
additional cooling.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

| Tim
|

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 95 13:33:19 PST
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  951 Sunroof Problems

Rick,

Sounds like the micro switch at the front of the sunroof (under the
small black trappiziod) is acting up.  Next time it sticks, try 
wiggling the plastic cover with a very small screwdriver. If this 
makes it open, you can either replace the switch, or do like I did
and clean the contacts.

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 16:38:04 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Indexing Spark Plugs in 911 eng

Hi,

I am confused as to how to align the spark plug in a 911
engine for indexing. Many people say "the electrode gap
should be towards the piston" but this does not seem
possible in a 911 engine- the center electrode is pointing
towards the top of the piston, with the outer (bent) 
electrode at a nearly 90 degree angle away from the
top of the piston.

As best as I can tell, the electrode gap should be pointing
towards the center of the combustion chamber. The 911 plug
is not in the center of the chamber, but comes in at an angle
from one side.

Also, some people recommend "towards the intake valve",
which makes some sense. Maybe between the intake valve
and the center of the CC? About 2:00 on the bad ASCII 
picture of the head with valves below? I think anywhere 
from 2:00 to 4:00 is probably OK.

          INTAKE

         (      )
plug  O
          (     )

          EXHAUST

Manufacturer claims are not always reliable.

My temp gauge stays steady at the mid point except when I am flogging my 83
944 at the track on a very hot day (>100 degrees F)..

There is nothing wrong with the stock cooling system on an early 944, except
the plastic bits...

YMMV

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 17:37:22 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 non-OEM Radiator?

Back in my sailboat racing days were were always careful not mix brass and
aluminum rudder fittings. (This was in the late fifties when aluminum alloy
[thats aluminium for the educated among us] was just replacing brass in
common usage)

Even in fresh (river) water they would set up a healthy electrolytic action
that resulted in the destruction of aluminum fitting. Granted, these fittings
were in direct contact and immersed in water whereas your radiator is removed
from the block BUT I wouldn't want to risk it.

Will Hartje

84 944
Lola T342
Cessna 172

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 17:42:44 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: Paint damage

>Yeah, I have considered doing it myself.  Even the paint guy said that it would
> be at LEAST half as much!  But, if insurance will pay for someone else to do
>it, I've got better things to do.  But, it looks like I'd better start looking
>for some paint repair books!  The paint shop said that it is extremely difficul
>t to remove the bumper/nose of the 928.  So, I don't know how I would tackle th
>at, not being extremely well studied in mechanics.  Thanks for your advice!
>Sean


In response to your response I will say this: 

It is difficult to understand exactly what damage has occurred, and where, 
without being able to see it with my own eyes.  You initially said the 
damage was on the hood.  Did it seep onto other body panels or the front 
nose?  Unless this is the case, there should be no need to remove the 
bumper/nose (which I'm sure is a significantly difficult task).  Perhaps the 
body shop guy told you that to scare you away from the idea of doing it 
yourself (e.g. more bucks for them).  If the damage is confined to the hood, 
the repairing and repainting can be performed with the hood on or off of the 
car, and should not involve any other panels.  The rest of the car would 
simply be masked off when repainting the hood (if it were left on the car), 
or the hood could easily be removed from the car for seperate painting..  
Assuming you would repaint the hood the same color as the rest of the car, 
there is no need for a whole car repaint.  Since your car is 15 years old 
(assuming it still has original paint) you will almost inevitably experience 
some degree of "two-tone" finish.  This very often occurrs in a panel 
repaint due to the aged and oxidized old paint contrasted next to vibrant 
new paint.  Aside of repainting the entire car (more expensive), the only 
real remedy for such a condition is to have the rest of the car 
professionally machine polished by a competant body shop or a good auto 
detailing company.  When done correctly, a thorough compounding/polishing is 
the ONLY way to "save" and restore a worn finish.  This process will allow 
any new paint to blend much more convincingly with an old finish.  

In the end, take everything a body shop man says with a grain of salt.  You 
must realize those guys are in the business to make money.  Unfortunately 
the quality of body shops ranges from superb to extremely poor, and it is 
the consumer's job to find out which.  Always remember that YOU are in 
CONTROL when dealing with a body shop working on YOUR car (even if insurance 
is paying), and don't be afraid to make them aware of that fact.  It is 
definitely to your advantage to fully check out a potential shop before work 
starts.  Even ask to see the work bays, etc.  It may save you from getting 
burned in the end.
Let me know if you have any questions.  Good Luck

Andy


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 15:13:48 -0700
From: stephenk@lmc.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Re: Paint damage

Andy writes:

>there is no need for a whole car repaint.  Since your car is 15 years old 
>(assuming it still has original paint) you will almost inevitably experience 
>some degree of "two-tone" finish.  This very often occurrs in a panel 
>repaint due to the aged and oxidized old paint contrasted next to vibrant 
>new paint.  Aside of repainting the entire car (more expensive), the only 
>real remedy for such a condition is to have the rest of the car 
>professionally machine polished by a competant body shop or a good auto 
>detailing company.  When done correctly, a thorough compounding/polishing is 
>the ONLY way to "save" and restore a worn finish.  This process will allow 
>any new paint to blend much more convincingly with an old finish.  

Have the car (or at least the hood ) compound polished before sending the
hood out to be repainted.  This will allow the body shop to send the hood
out to their paint supplier for computer matching of the tint.  When I need
the right side of my 22 year old 914 repainted, the shop polished the
dickens out one of the doors and sent it to their paint supplier.  The
resultant match was outstanding.

Stph

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 95 18:59:45 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: Roundabouts


Text item: Text_1

For my $.02 roundabouts are great fun to drive when traffic is light and are the
best (least restrictive)control of traffic over a wide range of traffic 
densities. Yes you can clog them but only when density gets too high, much 
higher than Pete would have you believe. You also need the correct "Yield" 
policy. If you really want to have fun try L'Etoille at rush (or any other) 
hour, where the priority a' droite gets you on fast but then ...........
Boston is (was?) also fun where eye contact means 'I yield'.
I have always been at a loss to understand why most American drivers obey and 
work with the unwritten Protocol of the four way stop (a unique American 
phenomena I believe) in a very efficient manner and yet are totally unable to 
understand a rotary.
Ben thanks for the memories, good night Dougal, goodnight Florence, goodnight 
Dylan, goodnight Zebardy.........................

neil_nw_walker@ae.ge.com

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 19:10:54 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: 911 SC Rear speaker size ??

>        Anyone know what brand name / size speakers will fit in to the rear 
>quarter panel on a 78 911 SC ?,  Performance products has Pyle 4x6 speakers 
that
>are suppose to fit under the quarter panel without having to cut the panel.
>
>        Will other 4x6 speaker brand(s) fit in the space without cutting ?
>       
>        Any recommendations on speaker brands ?
>
>        Thanks much in advance.
>
>G
>78 911 SC
>
The easiest way to check what size you need is to actually measure the hole 
itself or the old speakers ( if there are any).  Your fitment is probably a 
4x6, but some 911's have 5x7's.  It is best to check before purchasing.  
There are many other brands of 4x6 's on the market.  Some of the metric 
"4x6 's" will drop in without modification.  These include the Kenwood 
KFC-463-V  metric 4x6 's or the Polk  MM 4620 metric 4x6 plates.  Another 
important measurement to check is the overall depth of the speaker.  Other 
brands may fit with slight modifications to the mounting area, such as a 
mounting baffle or simple bracket.  Keep in mind that any competant 
installer at a specialty shop or electronics chain store should have no 
difficulty in custom mounting a speaker to fit in that area (for a 
reasonable price) if you are not interested in such an install job yourself. 
 Most of the speakers you will find in that size are coaxial drivers, but if 
you are willing to spend a bit more, a pair of 4x6 plates should yield 
better sound.  Plates are composed of a small midrange and a tweeter mounted 
side by side, rather than in a concentric fashion as with coaxials.  Another 
piece of advice is to look to an electronics retailer/chain store for 
speakers.  You will find comparable or better equipment to that in 
Performance Products, at a much better price to quality ratio.  An important 
note in auditioning speakers in the store--an old rule states "if YOU can't 
hear a difference between model A and model B, then don't spend the extra 
money!".  A great source of Mid-Fi aftermarket stereo replacements is the 
Crutchfield catalog.  They have a great tech dept. and excellent return 
policy.  Call 1-800-955-9009 for a catalog.

The following is a brief list of some of the available brands on the market 
currently manufacturing 4x6's.  All of these are descent brands, but you 
must decide what cost to quality of sound ratio you want to achieve.  I have 
starred those brands that, in my opinion, are toward the higher end of the 
spectrum in terms of sound quality.
Hope this was of some assistance.  Let me know if you have further questions.

Advent
Alpine  *                  
Altec Lansing  *
Blaupunkt
Boston Acoustics  *
Infinity  *  
JBL
Jensen
JVC
Kenwood
MTX
Pioneer
Polk
Pyle
Sony


Andy,
EIA Certified Mobile Electronics Installer

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 18:12:34 -0700
From: sas@indirect.com (Steve Sapareto)
Subject: Re: Thread on 944 Cruise Control (long)

I've been a listener now for a month and finally decided that I can 
contribute something.  Please forgive the extensive bandwidth and revival of 
an old thread.  Mine (both) and most of the 944s that I know seem to have 
failed cruise controls with the same intermittent problems as previously 
described.  The following is taken from the Service manuals (a Xmas gift 
from my brother who has an '86 951 with 260k miles (he did most) on the 
origninal engine (with chip and adjustable cam - I told him its like giving 
steroids to a 90 yr old man, but it does run really fast!)
     The cruise control unit on the 944 is a completely electronic unit.  It 
is essentially the same on both early and 85/2 models.  The system consists 
of 4 components: 1) the control switches on the directional stem on the 
steering column, 2) the control unit located behind the small cover panel 
above the gas pedal (the unit sits directly over the middle hump), 3) the 
drive unit (under hood behind the front passenger strut support) and 4) the 
clutch switch (near the top of the clutch pedal).
Initial checks:
     1.  Check the cable from the drive unit to the gas pedal.  It should be 
adjusted so the the roller just touches the gas pedal, not tightly when off. 
 If it is tight it will interfere with the throttle returning to idle.
     2. Check fuse (No. 8), this is the same fuse as the brake lights.
     3.  Check the function of the brake lights, if both lights are out 
terminal 8 of the control unit will not get proper voltage.
     4.  Check function of the clutch switch. It should be closed when 
resting and open when the clutch pedal is pressed (see voltage checks 
below).  Manual says 4mm of pin extending when closed. (Damned if I can 
measure this!)
Testing of the Multi-pin plug for the cruise control unit:
     1. With ignition off, pull the multi-pin plug from the control unit.  
There are two screws that hold the unit in.  Remove the screws and pull the 
unit parly out to get at the connector.
     2.  The terminals are numbered left to right looking at the face of the 
connector with the cable to the right, odd on top (1-13) and even on bottom 
(2-14).
     3.  Voltage checks (using terminal 12 as ground):
               terminal 1 = battery voltage
               terminal 3 = battery voltage and 0 volts when control switch 
"off" on control stalk
               terminal 4 = 0 volts and battery voltage when control switch 
"on/accelerate"
               terminal 6 = 0 volts and battery voltage when control switch 
"memory (set)"
               terminal 8 = 0 volts and battery voltage when brake pedal pressed
               terminal 14 = battery voltage and 0 volts when clutch pedal 
pressed
               terminal 11 (Hall pulse generator) when turning left front 
wheel (Jack up car) the reading should rise and drop from less than 1 volt 
to more than 6 volts  per revolution
Testing of the Multi-pin connector at the drive unit:
     1. With ignition off, disconnect the plug to the drive unit
     2. Resistance checks (on connector on drive unit).
               terminal 1 to 7 (engine resistance)  = 3 to 15 ohms
               terminal 2 to 4 (potentiometer) = 2 to 4 kohms
               terminal 2 to 3 (pot. sliding contact) = 2 to 4 kohms
               terminal 5 to 6 (drive clutch actuator) = 30 to 40 ohms
If all tests above are OK, check the wire harness between the control unit 
and the drive for continuity.  These are (drive unit terminal to control 
unit terminal):
1 to 10,  7 to 7, 4 to 9, 3 to 13, 6 to 8, 5 to 5, 2 to 12

        The 85/2 control unit is located on the left side of the drivers 
footwell (above the hood release).  It has 2 connectors, one goes to the 
drive unit, so all tests can be made from these connectors. Connector 2 has 
a coding pin in terminal 3 to insure proper connection.  The corresponding 
pin assignments are:
Plug 1
t1= Speedometer signal
t2 = Brake lights (battery voltage)
t3 = control "off"
t4 = "Terminal 15"(battery voltage)
t5 = control "resume"
t6 = control "on/accelerate"
t7 = "terminal 31"(ground)
 
 Plug 2
 t1 to t2 (Drive clutch actuator) = 30-40 ohms
 t4 to t7 (potentiometer) = 2-4 kohms
 t5 (engine positive) to t6 (engine negative) = 20-30 ohms

The speedometer connection is quite different on the 85/2 since it is not 
connected to a Hall pulse generator.  It can be tested 2 ways:
     1. With ignition off measure about 1 volt below battery voltage between 
term. 1 and battery positive.  With ignition on about 4 volts at 50 km/hr 
driving speed.
     2. An easier test:  Unlock sunroof (ignition off).  Drive at 5 km/hr 
roof should automatically lock (this insures that the speedometer signal is 
present and working). Now measure continuity between roof lifting relay 
terminal A and term. 1 to verify that the control unit is getting the signal..
     If all of these tests are OK, then you need to replace or repair the 
control unit.
***************************
Steve Sapareto <sas@samaritan.edu>
'85  944 (my 2nd)

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 20:52:48 -0500
From: Cdaar1@aol.com
Subject: Re: Paint damage

>In Massachusetts, we would file with our own insurance company >and THEY
would go after who ever was responsible.  We would be >liable for the
deductable as a maxumum.

In general, your insurance company would deal with THEIR insurance company,
and the companies would attempt to agree as to the extent of your respective
liabilities.  If the insurance companies agree that the school (or whoever)
is 100% liable, you are likely to get your deductible refunded.  Otherwise,
 the costs are apportioned according to your respective liabilities  (Believe
it or not, I am writing in English!)

------------------------------

Date: 27 Jan 95 21:17:12 EST
From: Byron Short <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 S2 Maiden Cone Voyage

Ok, so it was only about 10 degrees (that's Farenheit folks!).  So it's
the middle of winter in Colorado.  That's no reason to pass up my first
opportunity to try out my new '90 944 S2 M030 at a local autocross.
 
First surprise was the 245-45-16 BFG rubber stayed square for the entire
first run.  (Did I mention it was cold out?)  Despite the square tires
the car was incredibly quick, very tossable, and extremely easy to bring
back from ludicrous slip angles.  My very first run was a time which Bob
Klingler (defending nat'l champ in CS Miata R--and the guy to whom I
placed 2nd last year) could never match.  To say the least, I was
surprised at the relative ease at which the car can be made to go fast. 
Three of the four runs were within a .6 second band, so it should be easy
to stay consistent as well.    

I need to learn to drive with ABS!  Funny thing, the turns where you know
you need to drop say 30 mph it's easy enough to use the ABS to advantage.
But many turns require only a 10 mph drop in speed, and the temptation
for me was to make sure I felt the ABS pulsation assuring me that my
braking was at optimum levels.  But unless I learn to move my left foot
faster this results in dropping too much speed.  Methinks the best
approach is to forget about having ABS, drive like normal and try to not
even notice when the pedal pulses vs when it doesn't.  Comments?
 
A curiosity:  my 87 turbo sits almost as low as my 944S2 after adjusting
the S2's M030 front perches all the way down.  I thought the M030 car
should be considerably lower than the turbo...are my turbo springs sagged
out?  Or do S2's just start that much higher than turbos?  
 
I love the car so much I just ordered it an enclosed trailer!  Anyone
interested in a really nice 16' flatbed trailer?  Mine will be available
in March.  Tie downs specifically placed for 944 (but easily moved), less
than 1 year old, about $400 below what I have in it.  Delivery possible.
E-mail me for more details.
 
Byron
 
87 944 Turbo  Daily driver (even in the snow)
90 944 S2     Autocrosser and trailer-dweller

Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 18:51:26 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: No Porsche WSC car



I know this topic might be tiresome, but I just had to share some "posts" to
the CompuServe Motorsposrts Forum on the Porsche WSC car. I've deleted the
names to protect the "innocent."

This is a BIG topic out there, so keep those cards and letters going to:

Lynn Myfelt, IMSA Communications Director
71220.3211@compuserve.com

Larry Wilson

*********************************

1) Would it be possible for someone at RIS to collect the messages posted
here about the rules change and subsequent withdrawal of Porsche and forward
them to IMSA via email?

I sent a message myself 10 mins ago. Hope everyone else will too! I don't
think they realize the significance to fans!

2) It is truly remarkable that IMSA still can't get their act together. Most
of us have wanted them to make the series as big as it can be, but it still
doesn't seem to be in the cards.

Gee...could it be that Ferrari are calling the shots here? Now I certainly
understand IMSA wanting one of their own cars to win, but come on!! 

Porsche has once again invested a ton of dough in preparing a car to compete
in the long races based on the rules printed. I also know how badly Porsche
wish to compete on a fair basis and from my own past experiences know too
that they wished to show IMSA their hand. Guess that wasn't good enough.

My greatest concern is...On what basis did IMSA make this decision? I've
heard all kinds of rumors, but know from drivers that the car couldn't have
any real down force since it was bog slow in the chicane among other places.
So it had decent top speed, as do the Ferrari's. Particularly when Ferrari
trimmed the car out for the big numbers. I guess that IMSA will slow the
Ferrari's cause they smoke Dyson's car on the banking? Not likely!

Not only do I question any reasons to slow the car (oh...I did forget that
the Porsche came within two seconds of the Ferrari's best but who's keeping
track?) but without any true basis, like a race, how do they justify
anything? They sure hosed the car. 

Like my past year in SCCA's WC, the Porsches were constantly being accused
of having too much power 'cause of our decent top speed. But except for
SCCA's crack scrutineers no one took into account the 911 has no frontal
area. Might this be part of the Porsche's WSC advantage?

I've also heard all kinds of off handed rumors about power. The silliest
part is that all the numbers I've heard are the same OR MORE than we used to
run in the unrestricted days. Unlikely. There is no reason for anyone to
think that a Turbo engine can't be controlled, IF the sanctioning body wants
to do so responsibly.

All of this is so very sad and avoidable.

3) I think what you are seeing here is IMSA protecting what little it has
left.  Take into consideration the fact that Skip Barber has taken his
series to SCCA, Firestone has withdrawn their support (Toyo's $ deal isn't
as large), and what you have is a sanctioning body with two series being
buoyed by Ferrari $ (WSC & 355 Challenge). 

4) As a mechanic at TWR who has worked on the Porsche program for the past 3
months,I am very disappointed personally not to be going to Daytona.We have
done alot of hard work and not to get any reward for it by racing is very
hard to accept.Once again the fans are the ones that suffer.

5) Please let me voice my strong displeasure with the actions taken by IMSA
rule-makers last Tuesday (1/24/95) when they decided to place additional
restrictions on the TWR Porsche WSC LM cars.

Most people, who feel the same as I, do not understand nor care about IMSA's
rationale or whatever data that might have been relied on in making this
belated decision. All they understand is that at the last minute IMSA acted
with incredible unfairness and pulled the rug out from an entry that would
have added much excitement and interest to the race and to the Endurance
Series. 

The IMSA explanation placed great reliance on the "lawyer-language" in your
general rules that allowed you to make changes to the WSC LM rules as late
as race-day. But do you really expect most race fans will see that as merely
an effort to enforce equity?

You had an opportunity to explain your actions in plain language -- and you
declined. Instead, you left many with a nagging question of whether your
"focus" on the needs of series-regulars goes beyond the standards of
fairness expected from most sanctioning bodies.

I'm very sad about this whole episode. I usually download the hourly
standings of long-distance races from the Motorsports Forum. Not this
time.

several Porsche 944 books/manuals that I have)

is shaped more like a 924, not the 928's, but is this enough to tell?
I examined the fuel injection, but I have nothing to compare it too.
It has the "telephone dial" wheels, which came with the sport suspension
package.  Are there any easy ways to distinguish between the two.

(i.e. for under ~$1000) to replace the current bumber with a turbo's?

   3.  There are several minor problems with passeneger side door.  The
power window switch (for this side only - driver side control of the 
passenger winodw works) does not work.  Also, the exterior latch does not
release - the door can only be opened if you pull _very_ hard, but there
is no problem opening it from the interior.   Is the removal and 
re0installation of the interior door panel "easy" and/or possible?

noisy.  Should I use any type of lubricant to quiet it (silicon, lithium etc)?

negative.  I am looking at Pirelli P600 (215/60 15)  Are these the
correct tire size (car didn't come with it's manual)?

Porschephiles #1108                         Sun Jan 29 17:02:24 CST 1995
Porschephiles #1108                         Sun Jan 29 17:02:24 CST 1995
Date: Sat, 28 Jan 95 01:11:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re: 901 and 915 trannys


Hi Peter,

Well, I'm back home now and looked up some tranny info
for you.  Check out:

 - Bruce's book - it has a section on transmissions
 - European Car, Oct '94 - section on 901 trans (really an Automotion
ad in disguise!  Good for learning how the trans goes together
though)
 - European Car, May '93 - focus on 915 trans oil problems and
why the trans wears out.
 - VW & Porsche, Oct '88 - focus on 914 trans (901) and also
discusses differences between the 901 and 915 trans.  Shows
a picture comparing the 901 and 915 pinion.

Basically, the 915 trans has bigger "guts" and can therefore
handle more power.  You wanted a "rule of thumb" - I'd stick
with Porsche's recommendation and go with the 915 trans
for a 2.4 and larger engine.  I know a guy who uses a 901 trans
in his 2.7L 914/6, but then the 914/6 configuration isn't as
hard on the R&P due to the new direction the ring rotates
towards the pinion - they get much better oil coverage.

If you had a *REALLY* big engine, the choices would seem
to be a G50 or a 915 with an oil pump and spray bar to lube
key areas inside the trans - or with a setup like on page 205
of Bruce's book where there are 6 hoses spraying oil on the
5 meshing gear points and the ring and pinion.  Nice picture,
Bruce - I want one!!!!  :-)

Well, if you had a 901 trans you just *HAD* to use with a larger
engine, think about installing an "oil-spray-lube-system-thingy"
to spray oil at the meshing gears and R&P.  It'll help it last
longer.  Then all you'd have to worry about is snapping the
mainshaft or twisting 1st gear off the shaft due to excessive
torque.  Well....I did say "larger" engine....  :-)

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 10:39:57 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Open letter to IMSA

Dear IMSA,

I believe you have made a BIG mistake by altering your rules at the last
minute to specifically exclude Porsche WSC cars from the Daytona and Sebring
races. Since they were the only turbo powered entries, you cannot deny that
this was a Porsche-specific move.

IMSA is an organization that was made on the back of Porsche; that you cannot
deny.  Without their cars in the early years, IMSA as we know it would not
exist if it would exist at all.  Porsche has not always won either; witness
the demise of the GTP category when Nissan then Jaguar dominated.

You had a chance this year of having interesting endurance races between
Ferrari and Porsche, something not seen since the early 70's, and you blew
it.  If Ferrari can make their cars last, they will now dominate both Daytona
and Sebring, just like they did last season after their introduction.  Is
this what you REALLY want?  If you don't have enough money to buy a Ferrari,
you can't win.  I thought this was supposed to be cheaper racing then GTP.
 You can't call Ferrari's cheap. They certainly don't fulfill the INTENT of
your rules. So what is the hangup with Porsche?

I find it amazing that IMSA is so frightened of a car maker that uses a 30
year old engine design and has not had a successful entry in prototype IMSA
racing in years.  In fact, their recent history in Indy car racing and
Formula One show that they are not all-conquering as apperently you fear.
They have not had the advantage of a year like Ferrari to tweak their cars.
They already had other significant rule disadvantages.  You COULD have chosen
to let them run Daytona as-is and make "adjustments" between Daytona and
Sebring based on actual race results. You COULD have used the experience to
see if turbo powered cars could be a regular member of IMSA's new series, and
have REAL excitement in your regular season playing off of the
Ferrari-Porsche rivalry.  But for some reason you ran scared.  

This whole episode is a duplicate of the first attempt by Porsche to enter
the Indy 500 in the 70's, only to have a last minute rule change exclude
them.  I thought IMSA was bigger than that.

All in all it make me wonder how much Ferrari is paying IMSA to have
exclusive rights to win.  Ferrari intimidated IMSA last year on the rev limit
issue and kept on winning.  Did they threaten to withdraw support of IMSA if
Porsche could play on a field already tipped in favor of Ferrari?

I urge you to reconsider your move.  It may not be too late to admit an
obvious mistake, and the racing fans of the U.S. and the world would think
better of you for it. Intel learned from their mishandling of the Pentium
computer chip situation.  Maybe you can also learn!

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

Date: 28 Jan 95 11:24:06 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Bart and Petards

 
Kyle's comments about lighting them off brought back memories of one of the
zero-level conversations from my college days. (Zero level = they can't get
much lower than this...) Several mechanical
engineering types sitting around, discussing the process of lighting off,
er, petards. We concluded that it could be hazardous to your health, because
if you weren't able to maintain the proper speed of the, uh, gas stream, it
could backflash and cauterize your insides. The proper fix would be to
surgically install a flame arrestor screen. Some stainless steel mesh would
do, or for the budget minded, cut a piece from a 356 SC air cleaner (same
idea: flame arrestor).
 
The empirical discovory by Kyle that lightin' 'em off reduces the, uh,
olfactory offense MUST BE KEPT A CLOSELY GUARDED SECRET. If this gets out,
the California Air Resources Board will require that all patrons of Mexican
restaurants show that they have had CARB-approved thermal reactors (may be
able to use discarded mid-70s Porsche parts) installed in their shorts
before they are permitted to order from the menu.
 
Pete

Date: 28 Jan 95 12:25:28 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Never-Fog and Porsche windshields

 
Adam Farkas asked about anti-fogging agents, Sekuriflex windshields, and
cleaning them with benzene (a known carcinogen).
 
I think the Sekuriflex windshields have to be marked as such somewhere, like
on the etched or silkscreened-on label. They have a plastic inner layer,
which you should be able to feel with your fingernail (in some out of the
way corner).  They're pretty rare, I think, so odds are you don't have one.
 
The benzene for cleaning the windshields is probably an unfortunate
mistranslation. In Germany, "Waschbenzin" is just mineral spirits (paint
thinner, turpentine).
 
Pete
