Date: 28 Jan 95 12:47:36 EST
From: "Byron D. Short" <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Turbo Wastegates & Oddities

Peter Diffey writes...

>To the best of my ken waste gates are always spring loaded, pressure from
>the inlet manifold depresses a spring and opens the gate... 

>The waste gate in older cars were never directly controlled by the DME,
>you would either need a solenoid to open the waste gate - not exactly >fail
safe, or would need a solenoid to hold the waste gate closed, if >the solenoid
was driven by a transistor the DME would be getting hot!! 

>I understand that some turbos now have solenoid operated wgs - dubious 
>benefit, personally I like simple reliable systems, wires and hot engine 
>parts do not mix well.

Well sorta.  Your explanation of the system doesn't quite fit the 944's.  The
944 Turbo has a line going from intake manifold to KLR (just like the DME,
except it's only worried about the turbo and related).  That line is measured
for pressure inside the KLR itself; the KLR then converts this to an electric
signal for use by the boost gage, and of course, to determine if this boost
pressure is too high.  If the boost is below the prescribed pressure for the
rpm, and if the knock sensor isn't sending knock messages to the brain (and the
sun, moon & stars are properly aligned), then the KLR does nothing, allowing the
boost to continue to climb.  Of course if there's a leak in the system somewhere
or if the turbo isn't operating correctly, the boost may not climb at all.  Once
the KLR senses maximum boost for the rpm, it sends a pulse of electricity out
the line to the cycling valve.  This valve is located under the intake manifold,
visible between intake runners 3&4, cylinder shaped, about 2" in diameter, two
inches tall, the top is usually tan, and it has the two wire electrical
connector on top.  The cycling valve has three vacuum/pressure lines running to
it at the bottom of the valve.  One is the input line, one is a line to the
wastegate, and the third is a by-pass line.  When the boost is below max all the
air going into the cycling valve from the input line is directed through the
by-pass, which returns it to the intake system--no loss in pressure and no
wastegate movement.  When the boost hits or exceeds max, the cycling valve
directs the pressure from the input line to the wastegate line.  This, of course
opens the wastegate, venting some boost pressure.  In the 944, it takes only
about .3 bar in the wastegate line (referred to as base charging pressure in the
various manuals) to push open the spring, however, we're trying to get .65 +-.05
bar boost.  In order to permit this much boost the KLR "flutters" or "cycles"
the cycling valve very rapidly, making the wastegate flutter as well.  

The "chuffing" sound the original writer mentioned is very possibly the sound of
this wastegate flutter.  It's hard to guess how loud this sound should be, but
in my car it's only occasionally perceptible at all.  I don't think I disagree
with Peter that this sound could indicate some leakage--however, if you're
getting full boost any leakage must be in the exhaust bypass pipe, where it's
not effecting performance just yet.  In time it could allow faster deterioration
of the wastegate, so you'd want to fix it if you do find a leak.  If you don't
find a leak, and if you're getting full boost, then it's possible your wastegate
is sticky and making more noise than most, or just that you have better hearing
than the rest of us!

To determine if your car is pulling the correct amount of boost, start by
finding out what is the static barometric pressure.  Turn the key to "on", but
don't start the car.  Your boost gage should register 1 bar if you are at
sea-level, less as you climb in altitude.  Here in Colorado (my house is at
about 6500 feet), I get about .75 static bar.  Now add the .65 bar boost to
that.  So at sea level a properly working 944 Turbo (with stock chips) should
make a maximum gage reading of 1.65 bar +-.05; at my house I get about 1.40 on
my gage at max boost.  Remember also, that the turbo doesn't always keep up with
the engine's air consumption in first gear, so it's difficult, if not downright
impossible to get full boost in first.  Better to use third gear, and hold the
car back with the brake at 3500 rpm (this is the method detailed in the workshop
manuals). Be sure not to overheat the brakes.  On 86-88 cars (non S) max boost
should be available at 3500 rpm, then it tails off slightly (down to .45 boost
pressure) from (relying on memory here) 4500-6000 rpm.  A lot of aftermarket
chips get more power by simply not dropping that .2 bar, but I'm leery of
whether or not they listen to the knock sensor to determine how safely they are
managing all that boost.

BTW, the previous thread about adding a turbo to a 912 as an "altitude
compensator" mentioned that these were very low boost, "only" .5 bar.  This is
almost as much as the 944 Turbo gets, and the 944 has been modified extensively
to take the stress!  Yikes!

Byron

87 944 Turbo	Daily driver, an underrated snow car.
90 944 S2 M030  Autocrosser & trailer-dweller

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 14:45:06 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Re: Newbie buying a 911

>I am brand new to this list.  I am planning on buying a late '80s 911 Cab or
>Targa in the next few weeks.. I am having a hard time choosing between a Cab
>or a Targa.

I love my '87 Cab!

Good things:
Virtually no wind noise with top up.
Top material very durable.
Easy to operate (mine's electric)
Styling (I love the way the Cab looks- top up or down).
Very large grin factor w/ top down

Bad things:
I''ve become obsessive about keeping the (expensive) plastic rear window
scratch-free and clear.
Snap-on boot takes time to install (I know, it's not necessary, but it looks
great!)
Body flex. I don't drive aggressively enough to notice the diminished
handling qualities, but just entering a driveway at an angle causes lots of
creaks, so I know it's flexing 'n bending.
Costs more $$$

The Targa's a great design in terms of engineering, etc. But for some reason,
I'm not crazy about it's appearance. But what do I know about looks, I use to
love my 914.

IMHO, buy the Cab Chuck!

Michael K.



------------------------------

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 14:45:18 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Of Chips & Mass Flow Sensors

This little episode has left me with a bad taste in my mouth and it has taken
me some time before I could talk about it, but I think I'm ready now...

A couple of months ago, I mailed a check for several thousands of dollars to
AutoMotion and received back an Autothority (sp?) chip and mass flow sensor
for my low mileage '87 911.

I took the chip and sensor to my local mechanic for installation. The
mechanic gave me a reasonable estimate for the installation. This particular
mechanic has a good reputation: he's says he's installed chips before, he's
active in PCA events, blah, blah, blah. He tells me however, had I purchased
the same chip and mass flow sensor from him for full retail, his installation
price would have been a flat fee. But I saved a couple of bucks by purchasing
the chip and sensor directly from AutoMotion, so the mechanic's installation
price was only an ESTIMATE.

So, while my car's in the shop, the mechanic calls me and says that he's
having problems with the chip and there doesn't seem to be any installation
instructions in the box. I call AutoMotion and they have no idea what I'm
talking about. Then I call Autothority and they FAX my mechanic the
installation instructions. The mechanic is still having problems and after
several calls to Autothority, he consults directly with the chip designer.
Still no luck. 

Next, Autothority sends the mechanic another chip. The mechanic installs the
new chip and I get my car back, but the mechanic tells me that he thinks
there still might be a problem. It seems that when he was testing the car,
every once in a while it would run full rich and stall. Yes, that sounds like
a problem to me, too. He tells me he's out of ideas, but to drive the car for
a while and to let him know if I experience any problems.

Anxious to see what my three thousand bucks bought me, I drive the car to a
section of road that I drove before the chip and sensor was installed to
check my third gear 50 to 100 mph time. The car seems to be running fine so I
let 'er rip. To my astonishment, my time-13.1 seconds-is exactly the same as
it was BEFORE the chip and sensor. Hmm. After driving around town for a while
pondering the implications of all this, the engine goes full rich and stops
dead. I have the car towed back to the mechanic and tell him to put the old
chip and sensor back on. He does so and hands me a bill for almost three
times his original estimate-because of the extra troubleshooting he had to
do-and then has the nerve to tell me that he thinks I gave up too easily!

I sent the stuff back to AutoMotion. End of story. Now, whenever I see an add
for Autothority chips and sensors, I grind my teeth and do a slow burn. 

Comments?

Michael K.

'87 911 Cab.





------------------------------

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 14:49:51 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Re: Engine Fires

>My '75 914/6 project came from an insurance auction.  It was written
>off due to an engine fire.

>My previous '73 914/4 suffered from an engine fire which my brother
>and I successfully put out - the only damage was a pair of screwed
>Dellorto carbs.

>My friend's 914/4 burned to the ground last week.  The car was completely
>destroyed.

I've seen lots 914 engine fires. You're lucky to have extinguished your '73
with only minor damage. Once the fire gets going, all the water and dry chem
in the world won't touch it. Halon works well if you catch it in time.
Porsche issued a recall on the 914 around '78 - '80 as a result of the
numerous fires that were being reported. I believe they modified the battery
case is some way to prevent rain water from overfilling the cells and
dripping acid onto a fuel line directly below, which was the cause of the
fires.  

I recall responding to an engine fire and seeing the unopened recall letter
sitting on the dashboard of a (formerly) pretty 914.  I recognized the letter
as I had received mine in the mail the prior week. 

Michael K.

'73 914 (gone but not forgotten)
'87 911 Cab. (hasn't see the light of day for five weeks. Big storm created
potholes the size of swimming pools here in Santa Barbara. Let's get going,
CalTrans!)

> From porschephiles-request@tta.com Fri Jan 27 16:56:48 1995

> Hi,
> 
> I am confused as to how to align the spark plug in a 911
> engine for indexing. Many people say "the electrode gap
> should be towards the piston" but this does not seem
> possible in a 911 engine- the center electrode is pointing
> towards the top of the piston, with the outer (bent) 
> electrode at a nearly 90 degree angle away from the
> top of the piston.
> 
> As best as I can tell, the electrode gap should be pointing
> towards the center of the combustion chamber. The 911 plug
> is not in the center of the chamber, but comes in at an angle
> from one side.
> 
> Also, some people recommend "towards the intake valve",
> which makes some sense. Maybe between the intake valve
> and the center of the CC? About 2:00 on the bad ASCII 
> picture of the head with valves below? I think anywhere 
> from 2:00 to 4:00 is probably OK.

>

>

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 17:24:42 -0500
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: re;maiden voyage..

Byron;

    Abs on S2's is great for autocrossing, as you mentioned on large braking
needs it allows for more controlled slowing of the car with full control and
you can concentrate on you line instead of avoiding brake lockup. However
remember that ABS is not a substitute for traction, as I have learned with
worn tires the stopping distance will increase  possibly beyond your turnin
point.  An interesting point which was brought up at a recent Zone 1 Pca
meeting is how does ABS react when a car spins and how do you control it, any
ideas???

                               Steve Ross
                               90 944 S2

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 17:24:49 -0500
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: Re;New 944 Owner

In answer to your 85 944 questions

1. Sounds like an early 944 easiest way to tell are the gage faces yellow if
so it is early style.

2. Forget the bumper unless you find one in a junkyard for peanuts

3.  Rt side window seems like a switch real easy to replace, door panel is
also simple just be careful with the clips around the edges of the panel
don't break the vinyl material, while you in there lube the runners for the
window.  The outer door handle is released by a large philips head screw on
the door post then pull it outward at the rear and try to lube, it that does
not fix it then you may have either a linkage rod disconnected ( easily seen
with door panel off) or the handle itself ( a VW part) is broken.

5.  Yes 215/60 15 is the stock size but why Pirelli tires they are overpriced
poor performance and in my experience poor quality, a better bet is BFG,
Yokohama, Bridgestone in a good high performance street version.

                        Steve

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 95 01:11:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re: 901 and 915 trannys


Hi Peter,

Well, I'm back home now and looked up some tranny info
for you.  Check out:

 - Bruce's book - it has a section on transmissions
 - European Car, Oct '94 - section on 901 trans (really an Automotion
ad in disguise!  Good for learning how the trans goes together
though)
 - European Car, May '93 - focus on 915 trans oil problems and
why the trans wears out.
 - VW & Porsche, Oct '88 - focus on 914 trans (901) and also
discusses differences between the 901 and 915 trans.  Shows
a picture comparing the 901 and 915 pinion.

Basically, the 915 trans has bigger "guts" and can therefore
handle more power.  You wanted a "rule of thumb" - I'd stick
with Porsche's recommendation and go with the 915 trans
for a 2.4 and larger engine.  I know a guy who uses a 901 trans
in his 2.7L 914/6, but then the 914/6 configuration isn't as
hard on the R&P due to the new direction the ring rotates
towards the pinion - they get much better oil coverage.

If you had a *REALLY* big engine, the choices would seem
to be a G50 or a 915 with an oil pump and spray bar to lube
key areas inside the trans - or with a setup like on page 205
of Bruce's book where there are 6 hoses spraying oil on the
5 meshing gear points and the ring and pinion.  Nice picture,
Bruce - I want one!!!!  :-)

Well, if you had a 901 trans you just *HAD* to use with a larger
engine, think about installing an "oil-spray-lube-system-thingy"
to spray oil at the meshing gears and R&P.  It'll help it last
longer.  Then all you'd have to worry about is snapping the
mainshaft or twisting 1st gear off the shaft due to excessive
torque.  Well....I did say "larger" engine....  :-)

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 10:39:57 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Open letter to IMSA

Dear IMSA,

I believe you have made a BIG mistake by altering your rules at the last
minute to specifically exclude Porsche WSC cars from the Daytona and Sebring
races. Since they were the only turbo powered entries, you cannot deny that
this was a Porsche-specific move.

IMSA is an organization that was made on the back of Porsche; that you cannot
deny.  Without their cars in the early years, IMSA as we know it would not
exist if it would exist at all.  Porsche has not always won either; witness
the demise of the GTP category when Nissan then Jaguar dominated.

You had a chance this year of having interesting endurance races between
Ferrari and Porsche, something not seen since the early 70's, and you blew
it.  If Ferrari can make their cars last, they will now dominate both Daytona
and Sebring, just like they did last season after their introduction.  Is
this what you REALLY want?  If you don't have enough money to buy a Ferrari,
you can't win.  I thought this was supposed to be cheaper racing then GTP.
 You can't call Ferrari's cheap. They certainly don't fulfill the INTENT of
your rules. So what is the hangup with Porsche?

I find it amazing that IMSA is so frightened of a car maker that uses a 30
year old engine design and has not had a successful entry in prototype IMSA
racing in years.  In fact, their recent history in Indy car racing and
Formula One show that they are not all-conquering as apperently you fear.
They have not had the advantage of a year like Ferrari to tweak their cars.
They already had other significant rule disadvantages.  You COULD have chosen
to let them run Daytona as-is and make "adjustments" between Daytona and
Sebring based on actual race results. You COULD have used the experience to
see if turbo powered cars could be a regular member of IMSA's new series, and
have REAL excitement in your regular season playing off of the
Ferrari-Porsche rivalry.  But for some reason you ran scared.  

This whole episode is a duplicate of the first attempt by Porsche to enter
the Indy 500 in the 70's, only to have a last minute rule change exclude
them.  I thought IMSA was bigger than that.

All in all it make me wonder how much Ferrari is paying IMSA to have
exclusive rights to win.  Ferrari intimidated IMSA last year on the rev limit
issue and kept on winning.  Did they threaten to withdraw support of IMSA if
Porsche could play on a field already tipped in favor of Ferrari?

I urge you to reconsider your move.  It may not be too late to admit an
obvious mistake, and the racing fans of the U.S. and the world would think
better of you for it. Intel learned from their mishandling of the Pentium
computer chip situation.  Maybe you can also learn!

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: 28 Jan 95 11:24:06 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Bart and Petards

 
Kyle's comments about lighting them off brought back memories of one of the
zero-level conversations from my college days. (Zero level = they can't get
much lower than this...) Several mechanical
engineering types sitting around, discussing the process of lighting off,
er, petards. We concluded that it could be hazardous to your health, because
if you weren't able to maintain the proper speed of the, uh, gas stream, it
could backflash and cauterize your insides. The proper fix would be to
surgically install a flame arrestor screen. Some stainless steel mesh would
do, or for the budget minded, cut a piece from a 356 SC air cleaner (same
idea: flame arrestor).
 
The empirical discovory by Kyle that lightin' 'em off reduces the, uh,
olfactory offense MUST BE KEPT A CLOSELY GUARDED SECRET. If this gets out,
the California Air Resources Board will require that all patrons of Mexican
restaurants show that they have had CARB-approved thermal reactors (may be
able to use discarded mid-70s Porsche parts) installed in their shorts
before they are permitted to order from the menu.
 
Pete

oil companies, beer companies, tobacco companies, etc. Tell them you were
interested in the race until Porsche pulled out. Now you're going to go play

way to change things is to approach it from that direction -- who controls
the money. Change their minds, and you change the rules.

the ESPN coverage of same? Those should be our first targets for nastygrams.

Date: 28 Jan 95 12:25:28 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Never-Fog and Porsche windshields

 
Adam Farkas asked about anti-fogging agents, Sekuriflex windshields, and
cleaning them with benzene (a known carcinogen).
 
I think the Sekuriflex windshields have to be marked as such somewhere, like
on the etched or silkscreened-on label. They have a plastic inner layer,
which you should be able to feel with your fingernail (in some out of the
way corner).  They're pretty rare, I think, so odds are you don't have one.
 
The benzene for cleaning the windshields is probably an unfortunate
mistranslation. In Germany, "Waschbenzin" is just mineral spirits (paint
thinner, turpentine).
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: 28 Jan 95 12:47:36 EST
From: "Byron D. Short" <73324.3534@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Turbo Wastegates & Oddities

Peter Diffey writes...

>To the best of my ken waste gates are always spring loaded, pressure from
>the inlet manifold depresses a spring and opens the gate... 

>The waste gate in older cars were never directly controlled by the DME,
>you would either need a solenoid to open the waste gate - not exactly >fail
safe, or would need a solenoid to hold the waste gate closed, if >the solenoid
was driven by a transistor the DME would be getting hot!! 

>I understand that some turbos now have solenoid operated wgs - dubious 
>benefit, personally I like simple reliable systems, wires and hot engine 
>parts do not mix well.

Well sorta.  Your explanation of the system doesn't quite fit the 944's.  The
944 Turbo has a line going from intake manifold to KLR (just like the DME,
except it's only worried about the turbo and related).  That line is measured
for pressure inside the KLR itself; the KLR then converts this to an electric
signal for use by the boost gage, and of course, to determine if this boost
pressure is too high.  If the boost is below the prescribed pressure for the
rpm, and if the knock sensor isn't sending knock messages to the brain (and the
sun, moon & stars are properly aligned), then the KLR does nothing, allowing the
boost to continue to climb.  Of course if there's a leak in the system somewhere
or if the turbo isn't operating correctly, the boost may not climb at all.  Once
the KLR senses maximum boost for the rpm, it sends a pulse of electricity out
the line to the cycling valve.  This valve is located under the intake manifold,
visible between intake runners 3&4, cylinder shaped, about 2" in diameter, two
inches tall, the top is usually tan, and it has the two wire electrical
connector on top.  The cycling valve has three vacuum/pressure lines running to
it at the bottom of the valve.  One is the input line, one is a line to the
wastegate, and the third is a by-pass line.  When the boost is below max all the
air going into the cycling valve from the input line is directed through the
by-pass, which returns it to the intake system--no loss in pressure and no
wastegate movement.  When the boost hits or exceeds max, the cycling valve
directs the pressure from the input line to the wastegate line.  This, of course
opens the wastegate, venting some boost pressure.  In the 944, it takes only
about .3 bar in the wastegate line (referred to as base charging pressure in the
various manuals) to push open the spring, however, we're trying to get .65 +-.05
bar boost.  In order to permit this much boost the KLR "flutters" or "cycles"
the cycling valve very rapidly, making the wastegate flutter as well.  

The "chuffing" sound the original writer mentioned is very possibly the sound of
this wastegate flutter.  It's hard to guess how loud this sound should be, but
in my car it's only occasionally perceptible at all.  I don't think I disagree
with Peter that this sound could indicate some leakage--however, if you're
getting full boost any leakage must be in the exhaust bypass pipe, where it's
not effecting performance just yet.  In time it could allow faster deterioration
of the wastegate, so you'd want to fix it if you do find a leak.  If you don't
find a leak, and if you're getting full boost, then it's possible your wastegate
is sticky and making more noise than most, or just that you have better hearing
than the rest of us!

To determine if your car is pulling the correct amount of boost, start by
finding out what is the static barometric pressure.  Turn the key to "on", but
don't start the car.  Your boost gage should register 1 bar if you are at
sea-level, less as you climb in altitude.  Here in Colorado (my house is at
about 6500 feet), I get about .75 static bar.  Now add the .65 bar boost to
that.  So at sea level a properly working 944 Turbo (with stock chips) should
make a maximum gage reading of 1.65 bar +-.05; at my house I get about 1.40 on
my gage at max boost.  Remember also, that the turbo doesn't always keep up with
the engine's air consumption in first gear, so it's difficult, if not downright
impossible to get full boost in first.  Better to use third gear, and hold the
car back with the brake at 3500 rpm (this is the method detailed in the workshop
manuals). Be sure not to overheat the brakes.  On 86-88 cars (non S) max boost
should be available at 3500 rpm, then it tails off slightly (down to .45 boost
pressure) from (relying on memory here) 4500-6000 rpm.  A lot of aftermarket
chips get more power by simply not dropping that .2 bar, but I'm leery of
whether or not they listen to the knock sensor to determine how safely they are
managing all that boost.

BTW, the previous thread about adding a turbo to a 912 as an "altitude
compensator" mentioned that these were very low boost, "only" .5 bar.  This is
almost as much as the 944 Turbo gets, and the 944 has been modified extensively
to take the stress!  Yikes!

Byron

87 944 Turbo	Daily driver, an underrated snow car.
90 944 S2 M030  Autocrosser & trailer-dweller

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 14:45:06 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Re: Newbie buying a 911

>I am brand new to this list.  I am planning on buying a late '80s 911 Cab or
>Targa in the next few weeks.. I am having a hard time choosing between a Cab
>or a Targa.

I love my '87 Cab!

Good things:
Virtually no wind noise with top up.
Top material very durable.
Easy to operate (mine's electric)
Styling (I love the way the Cab looks- top up or down).
Very large grin factor w/ top down

Bad things:
I''ve become obsessive about keeping the (expensive) plastic rear window
scratch-free and clear.
Snap-on boot takes time to install (I know, it's not necessary, but it looks
great!)
Body flex. I don't drive aggressively enough to notice the diminished
handling qualities, but just entering a driveway at an angle causes lots of
creaks, so I know it's flexing 'n bending.
Costs more $$$

The Targa's a great design in terms of engineering, etc. But for some reason,
I'm not crazy about it's appearance. But what do I know about looks, I use to
love my 914.

IMHO, buy the Cab Chuck!

Michael K.

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 14:45:18 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Of Chips & Mass Flow Sensors

This little episode has left me with a bad taste in my mouth and it has taken
me some time before I could talk about it, but I think I'm ready now...

A couple of months ago, I mailed a check for several thousands of dollars to
AutoMotion and received back an Autothority (sp?) chip and mass flow sensor
for my low mileage '87 911.

I took the chip and sensor to my local mechanic for installation. The
mechanic gave me a reasonable estimate for the installation. This particular
mechanic has a good reputation: he's says he's installed chips before, he's
active in PCA events, blah, blah, blah. He tells me however, had I purchased
the same chip and mass flow sensor from him for full retail, his installation
price would have been a flat fee. But I saved a couple of bucks by purchasing
the chip and sensor directly from AutoMotion, so the mechanic's installation
price was only an ESTIMATE.

So, while my car's in the shop, the mechanic calls me and says that he's
having problems with the chip and there doesn't seem to be any installation
instructions in the box. I call AutoMotion and they have no idea what I'm
talking about. Then I call Autothority and they FAX my mechanic the
installation instructions. The mechanic is still having problems and after
several calls to Autothority, he consults directly with the chip designer.
Still no luck. 

Next, Autothority sends the mechanic another chip. The mechanic installs the
new chip and I get my car back, but the mechanic tells me that he thinks
there still might be a problem. It seems that when he was testing the car,
every once in a while it would run full rich and stall. Yes, that sounds like
a problem to me, too. He tells me he's out of ideas, but to drive the car for
a while and to let him know if I experience any problems.

Anxious to see what my three thousand bucks bought me, I drive the car to a
section of road that I drove before the chip and sensor was installed to
check my third gear 50 to 100 mph time. The car seems to be running fine so I
let 'er rip. To my astonishment, my time-13.1 seconds-is exactly the same as
it was BEFORE the chip and sensor. Hmm. After driving around town for a while
pondering the implications of all this, the engine goes full rich and stops
dead. I have the car towed back to the mechanic and tell him to put the old
chip and sensor back on. He does so and hands me a bill for almost three
times his original estimate-because of the extra troubleshooting he had to
do-and then has the nerve to tell me that he thinks I gave up too easily!

I sent the stuff back to AutoMotion. End of story. Now, whenever I see an add
for Autothority chips and sensors, I grind my teeth and do a slow burn. 

Comments?

Michael K.

'87 911 Cab.





------------------------------

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 14:49:51 -0500
From: Michael959@aol.com
Subject: Re: Engine Fires

>My '75 914/6 project came from an insurance auction.  It was written
>off due to an engine fire.

>My previous '73 914/4 suffered from an engine fire which my brother
>and I successfully put out - the only damage was a pair of screwed
>Dellorto carbs.

>My friend's 914/4 burned to the ground last week.  The car was completely
>destroyed.

I've seen lots 914 engine fires. You're lucky to have extinguished your '73
with only minor damage. Once the fire gets going, all the water and dry chem
in the world won't touch it. Halon works well if you catch it in time.
Porsche issued a recall on the 914 around '78 - '80 as a result of the
numerous fires that were being reported. I believe they modified the battery
case is some way to prevent rain water from overfilling the cells and
dripping acid onto a fuel line directly below, which was the cause of the
fires.  

I recall responding to an engine fire and seeing the unopened recall letter
sitting on the dashboard of a (formerly) pretty 914.  I recognized the letter
as I had received mine in the mail the prior week. 

Michael K.

'73 914 (gone but not forgotten)
'87 911 Cab. (hasn't see the light of day for five weeks. Big storm created
potholes the size of swimming pools here in Santa Barbara. Let's get going,
CalTrans!)

> Hi,

> I am confused as to how to align the spark plug in a 911
> engine for indexing. Many people say "the electrode gap
> should be towards the piston" but this does not seem
> possible in a 911 engine- the center electrode is pointing
> towards the top of the piston, with the outer (bent) 
> electrode at a nearly 90 degree angle away from the
> top of the piston.
> 
> As best as I can tell, the electrode gap should be pointing
> towards the center of the combustion chamber. The 911 plug
> is not in the center of the chamber, but comes in at an angle
> from one side.
> 
> Also, some people recommend "towards the intake valve",
> which makes some sense. Maybe between the intake valve
> and the center of the CC? About 2:00 on the bad ASCII

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 17:24:42 -0500

Subject: re;maiden voyage..

Byron;

    Abs on S2's is great for autocrossing, as you mentioned on large braking
needs it allows for more controlled slowing of the car with full control and
you can concentrate on you line instead of avoiding brake lockup. However
remember that ABS is not a substitute for traction, as I have learned with
worn tires the stopping distance will increase  possibly beyond your turnin
point.  An interesting point which was brought up at a recent Zone 1 Pca
meeting is how does ABS react when a car spins and how do you control it, any
ideas???

                               Steve Ross
                               90 944 S2

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 17:24:49 -0500
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: Re;New 944 Owner

In answer to your 85 944 questions

1. Sounds like an early 944 easiest way to tell are the gage faces yellow if
so it is early style.

2. Forget the bumper unless you find one in a junkyard for peanuts

3.  Rt side window seems like a switch real easy to replace, door panel is
also simple just be careful with the clips around the edges of the panel
don't break the vinyl material, while you in there lube the runners for the
window.  The outer door handle is released by a large philips head screw on
the door post then pull it outward at the rear and try to lube, it that does
not fix it then you may have either a linkage rod disconnected ( easily seen
with door panel off) or the handle itself ( a VW part) is broken.

5.  Yes 215/60 15 is the stock size but why Pirelli tires they are overpriced
poor performance and in my experience poor quality, a better bet is BFG,
Yokohama, Bridgestone in a good high performance street version.

                        Steve

Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 22:17:19 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: 930 Camshafts (clearance)

I am ready to replace the stock cams in the new (newer) '86 930. The 
heads have been milled, although it is hard to figure exactly how much. I 
have measured some SC heads that seemed to be a bit deeper in the head 
dome but yielded about 40/1,000 (i.e. 1 mm) less clearance from the 
seating surface to the edge of the valves. Assuming this is correct, how 
much cam can I safely use? The SC and 964 cams have significantly more 
lift and are a little wider, but since the valve clearance with the 930 
flat top pistons should be within plus or minus 25 degrees of TDC, does 
it really make any difference? All the cams are similar within this 
range. Somebody please wake me up! Thanks.
Dave Christiano, Springfield, Missouri

Date: Sun, 29 Jan 1995 09:45:44 +0500

> Anyway, has anyone upgraded their fog lights for higher output?  Can the stock
> wiring/relay handle the higher power?  Anyone replaced the 'extra' reflector 
> with a dual-bulb set-up?  If so, then I'm thinking of installing a second 
> switch to control the second 'high-intensity' driving light while maintaining 
> the stock light for normal highway use.  In rural Pennsylvania where street 
> lights are not common, I could use more light to see the various wildlife 
> likely to be sitting on the road esp on the winding back roads taken at P-car

existing good fog light.  I did this and it worked grat.  The two
assy's are identical with the eexception if the block - off replaced by
relector / adjustor assy.  With a spring and screw you can fabriacre
all needed parts.

kiled themon wit the high beams or via separate switch.

Date: Sun, 29 Jan 95 16:48:13 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Help..I screwed Up my pop-off valve installation!!


Godamn.

I e really was being carefull..I read all the emails, read the
instructions, looked at my engine, looked at the neighbours
911, measured, remeasured, and then did the deed..I drilled.

Well, the 2" hold is perfect, in the right spot, but...I did not
releize how much the bit was lower that the hole saw..When I was
finished with the drilling, I managed to put a 1/4" hole right
through the top of the little gizmo inside the airbox...a perfect

Date: Sun, 29 Jan 95 21:37:34 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 turbo cooler waterpump

Well the easy way to check this is to swap the relay with a known good 
one.  It's highly probable that the relay's the culprit, since if it 
was the thermostat the pump would never stop, even after pulling the 
relay and reinserting it.

Do you have any 951 friends, or does the dealer have a car sitting 
around you could swap with?

		JBS

Date: Sun, 29 Jan 1995 22:48:48 -0500
From: NG_COLE@ACAD.FANDM.EDU (Nicholas Cole)
Subject: 914 FI and Cool Logic

Hi p-car fans,
In my quest for the perfect solution for a rebuild motor swap options for
my beloved 914 I have come across an interesting artical in 'Kit Car'. Cool
Logic FI from CB performance. Heres the claim a 2110cc VW motor (doesn't
give type number) with 8.5:1 compression C.B. magnum heads 268 degree cam
with 423 lift developes 117 hp at 6500 rpms and peak torque at 4500 with
carbs. Same motor with with CBs FI makes 138 hp at 6000 rpms and peak
torque at 5000 rpms.
        The FI kit consists of a custom ECM (brain) four 40mm throttle
bodies 4 injectors to fuel rails manifolds fuel rails fuel pressure
regulator filter throttle posistion sensor MAP sensor temp sensor oxygen
sensor wiring harness with weather pack conections and all hardwear relays,
fuses and brackets are included (they claim). The say its only slightly
harder than carb instalations due to the need to weld O2 sensor into
exhaust. Price is 1500-2000 bucks. They stress that this system is far
better than Porsche and early VW FI. They claim that the older Porsche FI
and VW are open loop systems and theirs is closed. This is what they rest
their claims of better performance. In adition these test were done with a
catalitic converter installed giving emission scores that are aceptable to
the infamous C.A.R.B.
        Any thoughts. This is for a street 914 2.0l. My plan right now is
euro pistons and FAT FI cam the rest bone stock. This modern FI system
interests me. IS it just hype? I shot off a letter to them for more info so
I may post more info if anyone is interested.
Thanks for reading this long mesage any input would be appreciated.
Nick

Date: Sun, 29 Jan 1995 22:37:43 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 FI and Cool Logic

You only thought your question was long... Grab a pot of coffee, have a
seat, and take notes... And not just the 914 guys -- this is about making
more power, various "buy more power" claims, and life in general...

> In my quest for the perfect solution for a rebuild motor swap options for
> my beloved 914 I have come across an interesting artical in 'Kit Car'. Cool
> Logic FI from CB performance. Heres the claim a 2110cc VW motor (doesn't
> give type number) with 8.5:1 compression C.B. magnum heads 268 degree cam
> with 423 lift developes 117 hp at 6500 rpms and peak torque at 4500 with
> carbs. Same motor with with CBs FI makes 138 hp at 6000 rpms and peak
> torque at 5000 rpms.

I'm familiar with this system, but have not actually laid hands on it.
Their claims would be on a Type I, in general. I don't think there's a 
Type IV kit yet, and the 914 linkage has to be backwards from the "regular" 
Type IV anyway, so that's another factor (== more cost, too...) I *have* 
used the Berg/HALTECH system which makes similar claims. I've also
gotten *more* HP out of the stock EFI, and engineered my own EFI system
a few years ago, BTW...

> In adition these test were done with a
> catalitic converter installed giving emission scores that are aceptable to
> the infamous C.A.R.B.

Yeah, right. Unless it's CARB *certified*, however, that's a big "who cares".
Please check that in the literature, and call CARB to check the certification
number and approved applications.

> This is for a street 914 2.0l. My plan right now is
> euro pistons and FAT FI cam the rest bone stock. 

Sounds like a very good plan to me.

The stock EFI is remarkably effective. Air comes in, gas gets applied, and
you go on down the road at a pretty good clip. You get about 100 HP on an
otherwise stock 914 2.0  using the Euro P&C set.

So, question number one: assume all claims are correct. Is 17 HP worth
$2k?

Question number two: realize that the EFI makes *ZERO* difference in
the equation, except in its ability to respond with more agility to
*OTHER* engine changes (higher compression, more cam in particular).
What are the other mods, and what are their costs?

Question number three: given the other mods needed, and the heat from
the extra HP, what do you need to do to keep your engine alive more
than 10k miles and what is THAT going to cost you?

Question number four: given all this extra cost, is there maybe another
cost? Like how drivable is the car on the street now? Have you just spent
a ton of money on something that no longer meets your basic objective?

You see, to make that extra power, you gotta do something different. Every
time you do something different, you are forced to deal with all of the 
costs and problems associated with, well, re-engineering the engine.
Competent race shops do that all the time. Less competent race shops just
do engine rebuilds all the time from blowing up or breaking engines from
having NOT DONE THE MATH.

Anecdotal item: I have a 2.0 914 with stock bore, stock stroke, factory
EFI. It's been heavily tweaked, as it's a race car. It's legal for
SCCA IT and PCA D2 road racing, and is NOT a street car. Still, it's
interesting to note that it makes over 150 HP on pump gas, and more
on race gas where I can advance the timing a bit more... 

Summary:  you don't need more "tech" to make more power, you just need 
to know how to use what's there.

Stan

Date: Sun, 29 Jan 95 22:03:03 -0800
From: Cornelius_Verburg@mindlink.bc.ca (Cornelius Verburg)
Subject: 944 non-OEM Radiator?

P-files:

Tim Flint wrote:

>
> I'm about to buy a new radiator for my 83' 944.
>
> I saw a "heavy duty" non OEM radiator made by Autotechnik in the
> Performace Products catalog. The ad says that the radiator is made of
> brass and copper, and is rebuildable. The thing sells for $439.
> This price sounds a little high, but it may make your engine last longer.
>
> Questions:
>
> Do any of you have any experience with these radiators?
>
> Could the brass/copper construction have some sort of corrosive reaction
> with the aluminum block?
>
> Any thoughts or advice appreciated.


Last winter when I replaced my coolant, my 944 sprang leaks from both the
water pump and the radiator. I wasn't sure about the radiator, so I took it
to a rad shop for testing. $C30 later I knew for sure - it leaked from
exactly where I thought it would. The rad shop owner offered to build me a
custom brass/copper radiator using my old on as a template. "How much?" I
asked. "How much for a new Porsche radiator?" he replied. I'd already
priced an OEM replacement at a local parts dealer and told him how much
($C300+) and surprise surprise, he said "I'll build you a custom rad for
$C300 less the $C30 you've already paid for the test." He then went on to
tell me about how plastic tanked rads failed too easily and showed me a
Volvo rad that he said was worth $900 and that he'd been asked to build a
brass/copper rad to replace it. I wanted to think about it - I was worried
about fit, didn't even think about aluminium vs. brass/copper - and went
away. I called around and found a used rad for $150 and drove for an hour
each way to pick it up. I had it tested for $30 and it failed too. "Are you
sure you don't want me to build you a real rad, I used to run a stock car
team, you know, and we built all our own rads - and they work real good."
"No, I've still got to think about it... ." I talked to a few people at
work - didn't know y'all yet - who know cars and they recommended the sure
thing *and* remain true to Porsche. and that's what I did. No new leaks
yet.

That's the long of it. Sounds like your price is way out of whack since you
can divide $C by about 1.4 to 1.5 to get $US. I ended up paying $C295 + 14%
tax for my OEM rad. It fit and worked right first time.

If anyone's still reading, I would like to know more about the effects of
phosphates on the 944 cooling system. I used the yellow bottled Prestone
since it the label said it was safe for Aluminium engines. In light of
recent comments, I'm not so sure now.

Con

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 14:32:05 +0100
From: Pierre Fournet-fayard <fournet@ilm.loria.fr>
Subject: Re: Roundabouts (long)



Neil wrote:

> If you really want to have fun try L'Etoile at rush (or any other) 
> hour, where the priority a` droite gets you on fast but then .........


In France (and in UK too), the priority is given to the people on the
roundabouts *except* in Paris.

There, it's the other method: you have to give way to people coming from your
right side.  So people that want to go on the roundabout have priority and not
those who want to leave !

IMO, the first solution is the safest and the best to avoid traffic jam on the
roundabout.  You can't get in if there's no room for you.  It have to first let
people get out and then others come in.

The second solution, used in Paris, is not efficient when it's crowdy (the round-
about looks like a mess) and is *very* dangerous when the traffic is normal or
light.

Tourists: be carefull!  In Paris, people have not right of way when they are on
your right side: they simply rush, without caring if you'll stop !


My $0.02:  if you want to survive to the roundabout's jungle in Paris, try my
method:
( disclaimer: this is the way I do it.  I don't say it's the *best* solution)

 - rush on the roundabout, other people will let you come in,

 - stay on the very right side of the round,

 - when you see the next crossing with an avenue, you'll see all lot of people
stopped (they're letting people from their right pass).  Try to reach the posi-
tion on the rightest side,


                         \
                          \
                           \
                            |
                            |
                            ----------------------

                               <---   people are coming from the right

                            -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -
      X     X          Y <--   the place you should try to reach
          X  X  X      O
           X  X  X     U
                X  X 
      X                     ----------------------
                            |
                            |
              ^             /
   other cars |            /
   waiting                /
                         /


   ( drawing the intersection of a roundabout and an avenue is so
   difficult for an non-ascii-wizard-drawer ! )


 - go as soon as possible and then you'll have right of way untill the other
crossing,

 - don't forget to leave the roundabout where you have to !

 - NEVER stay close to the the center of the roundabout.  That's the best way to
turn and turn and turn without beeing able to leave the roundabout.


'70 Pierre F-F.

Please note that this should only be employed in Paris, where roundabouts have
the `priorite a droite' (give way to your right) and where they are *big*
roundabouts.

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 95 09:23 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: New 944 owner :)

From: Steve "THRUD" Cook <steve@prism.nmt.edu>
	   The car has 74k miles on it and still runs very well, but there are 
	several questions I have. (I have been unable to find the answers in
	several Porsche 944 books/manuals that I have)
	    1.  I still don't know if it is a 85 1/2 or just an 85.  The dash
	is shaped more like a 924, not the 928's, but is this enough to tell?
	I examined the fuel injection, but I have nothing to compare it too.
	It has the "telephone dial" wheels, which came with the sport suspension
	package.  Are there any easy ways to distinguish between the two.

AFAIK, if it has the 924-style dash, it's an 85/1.  I think the dash is one of
the big changes they made.  I'm not sure if there's any other simple way to
tell.  VIN, probably, but I wouldn't know where the line of demarcation is.
	
	   2.  I really like the 944 Turbo front bumber style. Is it possible
	(i.e. for under ~$1000) to replace the current bumber with a turbo's?

Good news: Performance Products lists the turbo bumper conversion at $449 in
their spring/summer '94 catalog.  Bad news: the light kit to complete the
conversion is >$700.  Not sure if you really need the light kit, my guess is
there will probably only be one light you can't get, but it'll be only available
as part of a kit.  Maybe check w/ auto recyclers (love those p.c. phrases!) in
your area or the back of Pano and see if you can get a front bumper and light
package.

	   3.  There are several minor problems with passeneger side door.  The
	power window switch (for this side only - driver side control of the 
	passenger winodw works) does not work.  Also, the exterior latch does not
	release - the door can only be opened if you pull _very_ hard, but there
	is no problem opening it from the interior.   Is the removal and 
	re0installation of the interior door panel "easy" and/or possible?

I'm sure it's possible, not sure how easy it is.  I have to take my driver's
side door apart to fix the lock sometime this spring, but I haven't taken the
plunge just yet.  Get a copy of the Euroselect parts catalog -- it shows a lot
of exploded diagrams of various 924/944/928 assemblies.  Not sure if it shows
the door (I don't think so) but it's a nice book to have.
	
	   4.  The suspension squeaks.  It seems to handle well, but it is just
	noisy.  Should I use any type of lubricant to quiet it (silicon, lithium etc)?
	
Sorry, can't help you here.  I think Wurth makes a grease that other owners
have recommended, but I don't recall any details.

	   5.  The previous owner didn't have it aligned reqularly, so I need to replthe rear tires.  I had it aligned (~$100) and had the camber set slightly
	negative.  I am looking at Pirelli P600 (215/60 15)  Are these the
	correct tire size (car didn't come with it's manual)?  
	
Yep, that's the size (assuming you've got the same 7" phone dials I have).  I
just bought a set of Comp T/As and I regret not going with the 225/50R15 size.
Something to think about if you want to go racing...  You might also want to
head down to your dealer and see if you can get a replacement owner's manual.
It's tough figuring out how to get the sunroof off without one!

Congratulations on your new car!

- -- Tracy Nelson
'87 944S

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 09:52:50 -0500 (EST)
From: Peter J Wales <pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net>
Subject: Re: Of Chips & Mass Flow Sensors


I haven't seen any comments about the Autothority system on the net, so 
maybe I haven't been paying enough attention. However,some time ago, we 
decided to develop a system to compete with the autothority system and 
decided that the easiest way to go would be to switch from mass air to 
speed density and work entirely from manifold pressure. This would allow 
the restrictions ofthe mass air meter to be removed entirely. We did 
get  a system developed and proven in Europe and then lost interest in 
it when we couldn't find a 911 locally to test it out on.

Now we have this system lying around and this thread has prompted me to 
resurrect it. The question is, does anyone want to  
try it out. It needs someone with mechanical knowledge because I do not 
want to get into the questions of who is paying the mechanics fees. We 
will proivide all ofthe support needed from here and at the end of the 
day, the volunteer may keep the system free of charge if they want to. If 
it works as well as the Autothority system, they probably won't want to:)

There are no guarantees, except that it won't cause any damage to the car 
and nothing needs changing, which can't be changed back in a few minutes. 
I would initially suggest wiring it in and testing it wiithout removing 
the existing MAF sensor from the car. That way, if there are any 
problems, it can be returned to stock easily.

Any volunteers?


Peter Wales
Superchips Inc

front rubber seal from the corner where the targa top meets the windshield
and the triangular door window .. down to the point where the rubber seal
meets the hollow door seal rubber.  Please measure from the top of the

original seal is approx. 22" long in this section.  So far I've

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 08:56:57 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Ceramichrone cylanders

> As a pilot I've become famaliar
> to the term 'ceramichrone' as used as a cylinder treatment for the aircooled 
> aviation motors. supposedly it keeps the engine from runing too hot and 
> increass the engine life somewhat. What I was wondering is this: Can the 
> Ceramichrone treatment be utilized on the flat-4 & 6 motors successfully? 
> would it be worth concidering?

I'm not  a pilot, but am pretty familiar with such coatings. In "serious"
racing circles, it's pretty much the rule of the day.

There are basicly four types of coatings in use routinely:

* teflon coatings for increasing oil shedding properties of parts,
* high-pressure teflon coatings for moving part contact surfaces
  like bearings and journals,
* semi-metalic ceramics for heat sheilding (like the ceramichrome you 
  mention), typically used on piston tops, valve faces, combustion
  chambers, etc
* high-gloss high-temp ceramics used for heat sheilding, (like Jet-Hot)
  used for exhaust ports in heads, and header systems.

For a race engine, you really need all of this if you're running in a pro
series. Your competition has it, you need it to maintain parity. Does it
make the car faster, last longer, etc??? Yes. Absolutely. You can even 
measure it on the dyno and engine life clock. Can you "feel" it?? Not
really, except in the wallet...

For a street engine, the high-pressure teflon coatings are always a good
idea, but it's not really a requirement or even necessarily better
than not doing it. I just feel more comfortable with it in some cases.

My vendor of choice for all this stuff is Polymer Dynamics in Houston, TX.
They do a lot of work for IMSA, SCCA, NASCAR, IROC, etc. and have a very
good reputation.  Swain Tech is also reputed to be good, but PD is local
and I can go grab them by the twisty bits when they screw something up.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 09:06:02 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Of Chips & Mass Flow Sensors

> decided that the easiest way to go would be to switch from mass air to 
> speed density and work entirely from manifold pressure

I don't want to go poking holes in something I haven't seen personally, 
but this is close enough to something that I spent a LOT of time chasing
and spent a  LOT of money on, so:

The problem with this is often answering the question "which manifold
pressure". Both Kevin Gross and I had *ENDLESS* trouble making the
Electromotive TEC system work with high-butterfly throttle bodies, until
we discovered that it required a common plenum, at which point we
both lost interest for what should be obvious reasons. In fact, the
guy I was doing this work for said that if there was someone I didn't
like that I could *GIVE* them the Electromotive unless I *REALLY*
didn't like them in which case I should *SELL* it to them...

Similar issues apply to any other system based on manifold pressure.
At face value, it looks like a replacement for a DME, which leads to
the question  of "why bother". If you're going to an aftermarket programmable
EFI, then you *REALLY* want to be able to use high-butterflys or 
slide-valves. If you can't do that, then well, why not modify a factory
system?

Stan

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 95 10:42 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Ceramichrone cylanders

stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks) poked his head in to say:
	[ In regards to "ceramicrone" (?) cylinder coatings ]
	I'm not  a pilot, but am pretty familiar with such coatings. In "serious"
	racing circles, it's pretty much the rule of the day.
	
	There are basicly four types of coatings in use routinely:
	
	* teflon coatings for increasing oil shedding properties of parts,
	* high-pressure teflon coatings for moving part contact surfaces
	  like bearings and journals,
	* semi-metalic ceramics for heat sheilding (like the ceramichrome you 
	  mention), typically used on piston tops, valve faces, combustion
	  chambers, etc
	* high-gloss high-temp ceramics used for heat sheilding, (like Jet-Hot)
	  used for exhaust ports in heads, and header systems.

Does anyone still use the <picture a mind drawing a blank here> technology that
Kawasaki was using in the mid-70s?  They were inserting wires into the center
of the combustion chamber then running N volts at N amps (where N is large)
through them to vaporize them and deposit the plasma on the cylinder wall.
They used some cycle of nickel/nichrome, stainless steel and ???.  They were
said to provide great lubrication and heat dissipation, but racers were
disappointed because you couldn't bore the cylinders out.

Has this become passe in today's Kevlar-composite/ceramic-lined World Of The
Future?

Regards,
- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)
'87 944S

Date: Mon, Jan 30, 1995 12:56 PM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Newbie buying a 911

In message <950128144505_2615115@aol.com>  writes:
> >I am brand new to this list.  I am planning on buying a late '80s 911 Cab or

> I love my '87 Cab!

> Good things:
> Virtually no wind noise with top up.
> Top material very durable.

I'm a roger on everything to this point, and although my top is manual, I'd
say it is as easy as the electric, if not easier.

> Styling (I love the way the Cab looks- top up or down).
> Very large grin factor w/ top down

Amem, brother, Amen!

> Bad things:
> I''ve become obsessive about keeping the (expensive) plastic rear window
> scratch-free and clear.

and beware of folding it when the weather is near freezing.  The entire top
must be disassembled and removed to replace that window.  $10 material, $600
labor (no foolin')

> Snap-on boot takes time to install (I know, it's not necessary, but it looks
> great!)

I'd regard it as necessary, especially if you want to keep the top looking 
nice.  BTW, the cover has two kinds of snaps, the regular snap, and the
kind with a knob that you must  Lift and hold while you fit the thing over
a post, then release (and push down on, to ensure secure engagement).  I don't
know what the later are called (*expensive* if you ignore the proper proceedure
for securing them and have to replace one or two).

also, if you get the tonneau cover which replaces the normal boot, that's cool
also (and a real pain in the *ss to mess with, but it *is* cool)

> Body flex. I don't drive aggressively enough to notice the diminished
> handling qualities, but just entering a driveway at an angle causes lots of
> creaks, so I know it's flexing 'n bending.

Body flex pretty much makes it a street only (read, uncompetitive on the track)
except for Driver's ed.  But, who cares?  Give me a sunny day and a good road,
it doesn't *get* any better than that!
> Costs more $$$
> 
> The Targa's a great design in terms of engineering, etc. But for some reason,
> I'm not crazy about it's appearance.
 
[snip]

> IMHO, buy the Cab Chuck!

what he said!

Cheers,

Bart Chambers

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 14:04:52 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: just let the wheel go

  >W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research wrote:

  >"Very skilled 911 drivers say that if you do get the car out of shape
  >simply let the wheel go, keep the power on and it will sort itself out"

Don't think I like this idea.  Though I have heard this advice given as
a foolproof way of getting an aircraft out of a spin !

Friend of mine was spinning an airplane inverted and couldn't recover,
after struggling with it for a while he decided it was best to leave.
He let go of the controls and started wiggling the canopy open, while
he was doing this the airplane recovered by itself.

Not sure I'd want to try that in a car though, for one thing you're a
little too low to get your 'chute open properly before you hit the ground.

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 14:14:05 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Ceramichrone cylanders

> Robert Priddy asked:
>   I have been wondering this for sometime now. As a pilot I've become famaliar
> to the term 'ceramichrone' as used as a cylinder treatment for the aircooled a
>viation motors. supposedly it keeps the engine from runing too hot and increass
> the engine life somewhat. What I was wondering is this: Can the Ceramichrone t
>reatment be utilized on the flat-4 & 6 motors successfully? would it be worth c
>oncidering?
>   I'd really appreciate it if anyone who flies higher than surface level could
> give me some insight. thanks.

ok, here's what I know.

cermichrome is a brand name of a process that was invented (by a britisher
I think) for mercruser outboards years ago.

instead of having a soft cylinder wall and hard rings it goes the other way
and has a hard cylinder wall and soft rings.  it's basically an evolution
from chrome cylinders.  in cyl walls in general you have lots of little
grooves, a certain number of a certain size crossing at certain angles all
supposedly optimized differntly for different engines.  in soft steel cyls
these are honed in.  in chrome the plating charge is reversed quickly at
the end of the plating process to cause the plating to crack.  in ceramic/
chrome these are little tiny chips of ceramic pressed into the cylinder
wall while the chrome is still soft.  the quality control is done (i think)
by shining a beam of a known thickness down the cyl wall and counting the
reflections from the ceramic.  it's not 100%, only one pass each cylinder.

I have recently (after much deliberation) had this done on my Lycoming
O-320-E2G (with the high comp. pistons mod).  Several of my flight have
also had this done.  the cv (no hard evidence) is that oil consumption
is lowered, perhaps wear, who knows.  have seen no difference in temps.
my experience is that oil consumption is lower, but who knows whether it's
because of the cermichrome cyls or just because it's a "new" engine.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 11:27:38 PST
From: Greg DesBrisay <gd@dac.cellnet.com>
Subject: Re: 356 in need of help 


Did you put larger jets in your carburetor when you put in the larger
cylinders?

A carburetor will spit and pop when the mixture is too lean.  The
larger cylinders draw more air through your carburetor than do smaller
cylinders at the same rpms and make the fuel mixture leaner if the
amount of gas isn't increased to compensate.  Your idle mixture
adjustment will allow your carburetor to add more gas to the engine at
idle and low rpms, but at higher rpms the only way to add more gas to
the mixture is by increasing the size of the jets.

I believe the best way to find the correct jet size for your engine
with big bore kit is to put the car on a chassis dyno, but I'm sure
others on this list have lots more experience doing that than I.  (In
the Bay Area I understand that Rockwell Motor Sports in San Jose does
a good job at this.)

Perhaps someone else can give us some pointers?

Hope this helps!

Greg DesBrisay
'67 912


> From: Snarkler@aol.com 
>
> I'm new here, and I've got a question.  I put in a set of Big Bore
> 86mm's in my '62 356 B , and now it "spits & pops" at about 3000
> rpm's?  I've replaced plugs,points,cap, etc., Carbs are Zeniths,
> Everything looks right?.  What am I missing here?  I'm not real
> knowledgeable on the "In's & Out's" of these little fellas so,
> constructive suggestions would be appreciated.  Thanks..

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 95 12:00:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Making and external oil thermostat


Hi gang,

A friend of mine has no cash and is planning on making
his own version of an external oil thermostat similar to the
$140+ versions sold by a variety of people.  (No flames
please....I've heard them all about how Porsches and
no money don't mix!)

His plan is to use the factory 911 thermostat which sits inside
the engine (since a friend of his has about 50 of them laying
around).  He thinks all he needs is to have a block of
aluminum milled to the dimensions of the round factory
piece with 4 threaded holes for the fittings and a couple
of mounting tabs.

He found a good machine shop that will provide the aluminum
and do the millwork for about $40 CDN ($29 US).  The factory
thermostat will slip-fit into the block with an o-ring seal and
will screw into place.

As long as there are no leaks, does this sound feasible?
Did he miss anything?

Thanks,

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 12:52:29 -0800 (PST)
From: allanh@handmadesw.com (Allan N. Hessenflow)
Subject: Re: just let the wheel go

Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517 wrote:
> Don't think I like this idea.  Though I have heard this advice given as
> a foolproof way of getting an aircraft out of a spin !

Hmmm, it doesn't work in all airplanes either (and probably not for all
spin modes of any particular aircraft for that matter).  The first planes
I did spin training in would recover on their own if you stopped fiddling
with them, but then we switched to another type that required very
positive action to stop the spin (and I wasn't doing inverted spins...).

Anyway, if you have tons of room so you're not going to hit anything, it
might work in a 911.  But then it wouldn't really matter what you did.  I
suppose you just might recover faster by letting go of the wheel in some
situations - at least it would eliminate DIOs (driver induced oscillation).
I have successfully reversed the direction of a spin in a 911 before
(unintentionally of course)...

allan

- -- 
Allan N. Hessenflow     allanh@handmadesw.com

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 16:49:30 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Brighter Headlights - NOT

I've often seen the ads for "brighter headlights" in the back
of autoweek, so got a pair for my Grand Cherokee V-8, hoping
they would work great on such a high vehicle.

The bulbs are the "9004" style used in most vehicles nowadays.
They have 50 watt low/100 watt high or 80/100 available. I got
the 80/100, as I use mostly low beam around town here.

The bulbs are PHEOBUS brand, made in Korea (yuk). I got mine from
Performance Products' Panorama ad much cheaper than the autoweek
prices. These are the same brand as some if not all of the ones
advertised in Autoweek.

Anyway, there was really no noticable difference in brightness with
these bulbs. There is no way these are putting out 100 watts. I used
the "real" Cibie halogen headlights (H4) years ago in my 914, when they
were not legal in cars, only motorcycles (they were not sealed beams,
but had replaceable bulbs). They made a huge difference, much brighter
than these on the Jeep.

So I guess these bulbs are OK as a replacement if you blow a bulb, but
don't waste your money on them as an upgrade. And we'll see how long
they last.

Also there is a problem with the new non-sealed beam headlights
today. I noticed the 2 year old headlights on the Jeep were getting
dirty (cloudy?) inside already. I wonder how they will be 10 years
from now, or if they can be cleaned? They are pretty well sealed,
but grime gets in anywhere it can I guess...

Mike Piera, AnalogMike@aol.com  '72 911S '73 914/2.0

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 95 16:37:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.ncr.com>
Subject: RE: Gold welding lenses


Hi Kyle,
I hope you get this message before you are gone for good....

A friend of mine bought a welding handbook and in it was
a statement like "Don't use the 'gold' type of welding lenses"
because if it is scratched, UV can now enter your eye through
that scratch since the gold is the part that protects your eyes.

It seems a little more "dangerous" to use your favourite lens
than a regular dark shade 9 or 10 lens.

Hmmm....just letting you know.  I think the book was one put
out by HP.

Take care of yourself....and good luck with your 914 rustoration.

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

  Allan, relax man.  I'm just off-the-net, not leaving planet earth (N'yuk, 
n'yuk, n'yuk).
  -It got to be too much during school. . .since my employer is footing the 
bill, I feel
like I should give 'em a fair workday.  And all my other spare time is 
consumed doing
homework.  (I'm a freshman in college -at 40!)
  But that wont last forever, once I find the handle on the semester, I will 
be back.

  As to the 'Omni-View'. . .  Yeah, I knew the job was dangerous when I took 
it.
  But those #6 shades work great (and last a long time) when sandwiched in
plastic plates.  I just replace the plates, and the shade remains like 
perfect.
  I dont even dust them off (wash with soapy water) so they dont  get 
scratched!
  Yeah, if scratched, they leak UV.  I am well aware of that hazard in 
conjunction
with using these special shades.  The gold is just vapor deposited, and VERY 
thin.
  -just another caveat to watch for.

  Waaayyy back when I was shooting the breeze with the welding shop guys, we
talked extensively about the Omni-View shades.  Apparently, the amount of 
power
in the arc is the key factor in how light a shade one can get by with.  For 
us
Pudknockers with <100 amp MIGGERS, the arc power level is low enough that a
trick lense like a shade 6 or 7 (gold Omni) is just fine!!!    BIG arc 
machines
with well over 100 amps of arc current would demand the extra filtration a 
#10 shade provides (but these are available in gold film too).

  The Omni-view shade uses a UV filtration method that differs from standard
shades in that the shield plate contains the light attenuation, and the gold 
film provides UV filtration.  Since the film 'blocks' the UV, the shade 
itself can be less dark and still provide suitable protection.  That is why 
a scratched shade is a throwaway.

  Thanks for the concern!
  -and nice to hear from you!
                                  ***  Kyle is off the net       ***
                                  ***  -but his ears are on  ***
                                  ***  -use direct email.      ***
                                  ***  kehler@smtplink.wichitaks.ncr.com 
 ***
                            -kyle   'just another MIGging pudknocker'

Bob356@aol.com sez:

|> Ceramichrome anywhere.  Which end should it be on? <G>

Bob,

when you aerotow.  That is called an "airplane", and the mechanical thermal
it uses to tow you aloft often will have ceramichrome cylinders.

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 95 14:04:07 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: 951 oil scum question

Hello Phellow Philes;

I need opinions on a problem I noticed while adding oil to my '89 944 Turbo 
today.  Upon inspecting the oil level this morning, I found that I was about 
half way between the upper and lower marks on the dipstick.  I decided to add 
about half a quart of Castol Syntec 5W-50.  When I removed the oil filler cap, I 
found a yellow scum on the underside of the filler cap and some around the 
inside of the oil filler tube.  There was no similar scum on the dipstick.  On 
my last oil and filter change about 1K miles ago I switched from Mobil 1 
synthetic 15W-50 to Castrol Syntec 5W-50.  Prior to that the car had whatever 
the dealer put in (non-synthetic).

Have any of you synthetic oil users experienced similar problems of scum 
'growing' in your oil after oil changes?  Any thoughts would be appreciated.  
Thanks in advance.

Tracy Meyer
tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 17:02:55 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: FWD> K&N Filters Concern

        This came from the Volvo list by way of the Honda list.
I believe that a number of philers use K&N filters, so this would
be of interest...
        This is *not* intended to be flame-bait!  Just an FYI
about *one* company's testing of these filters.


>Subject: K&N Filters Concern
>Status: R
>
>
>I picked up the following on one of the general automotive
>bb services.  I sent an email to the author asking permission
>to copy it here and he said ok.
>
>Basically what he is reporting is that in the commercial
>vehicle company he works in they found much higher wear in
>K&N filter equipped engines.
>
>I'm certainly not trying to start a flame war, and don't
>have any big personal opinion visa-vis K&N filters, but
>I thought that this point of view might be worthwhile
>as I know many Volvo owners use and or consider using
>K&N filters.
>
>******************************************************************
>
>Subj:  K & N filters
>  To:  John M. Saturday, January 21, 1995 5:14:10 PM
>From:  George Morrison
>
>John:  If I wrote "subjective" I meant "objective"..  I was
>responsible for evaluating re-usable air filters
>for a major construction/mining company that had
>hundreds of vehicles ranging from large earthmovers
>to pick-up trucks and salesmen's cars.  This study
>was embarked upon due to the fact that we were
>spending upwards of $30,000 a MONTH on paper air
>filters.  Using them one time then throwing them
>away..  I inititated the study in that I was convinced
>that a K&N type filter or oiled foam would save us
>many dollars per year in filter savings, man hour savings,
>and of course engines as these would filter
>dirt better than paper. (yes, I had read the K&N ads and was
>a believer)
>
>Representative test units were chosen to give us a
>broad spectrum from cars right through large front
>end loaders.  With each unit we had a long history
>of oil analysis records so that changes would be
>trackable.
>
>Unfortunately, for me, every single unit having
>alternative re-usable air cleaners showed an immediate
>large jump in silicon (dirt) levels with corresponding
>major increases in wear metals.  In one extreme
>case, a  unit with a primary and secondary air cleaner,
>the secondary (small paper element) clogged
>before even one day's test  run could be completed.
>This particular unit had a Cummins V-12 engine
>that had paper/paper one one bank and K&N/paper on
>the other bank; two completely independent
>induction systems.  The conditions were EXACTLY
>duplicated for each bank yet the K&N allowed so
>much dirt to pass through that the small filter became
>clogged before lunch.  The same outcome occured
>with oiled foams on this unit.
>
>We discontinued the tests on the large pieces almost
>immediately but continued with service trucks,
>formen's vehicles, and my own company car. Analysis
>results continued showing markedly increased
>wear rates for all the vehicles, mine included.
>Test concluded, switched back to paper/glass and all
>vehicles showed reduction back to near original levels
>of both wear metals and dirt.  I continued with
>the K&N on my company car out of stubborness and at
>85,000 miles the Chevy 305 V-8 wheezed its
>last breath.  The top end was sanded badly; bottom
>end was just fine.  End of test.
>
>I must stress that EVERYONE involved in this test
>was hoping that alternative filters would work as
>everyone was sick about pulling out a perfectly good
>$85 air cleaner and throwing 4 of them away
>each week per machine...
>
>So, I strongly suggest that depending upon an
>individual's long term plan for their vehicles they simply
>run an oil analysis at least once to see that the
>K&N or whatever alternative air filter is indeed working
>IN THAT APPLICATION...  It depends on a person's priorities.
>If you want performance then indeed the K&N is the
>way to go but at what cost???
>
>And no, I do not work for a paper or glass air
>filter manufacturing company nor do I have any affiliation
>with anything directly or indirectly that could
>benefit George Morrison as a result..
>
>******************************************************************

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____
                          (  _             _  >    |_____|___|__/____|_
Dave Darling               ~' `~~~~~~~~~~~' `~      _____|   |       |
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov `~'           `~'

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 19:41:23 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: 924/44 door panel removal EZ!!!

Hello Porschephiliacs,
	In response to the new 944's question about door panel removal, 
its a cinch :^)  I did it yesterday afternoon to repair my locks, and it 
took about 15 minutes.  Just unscrew your map pocket and speaker and two 
exposed bolts.  Then starting at the front bottom corner, firmly pull the 
clips out of the door one by one.  Oh yeah, theres one screw also behind 
the door handle, and the window crank must be removed by pulling the 
cover sideways to reveal the single bolt.  Finally, just lift up on it 
and its off!  Have fun!

Jay Karolyi

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 20:18:45 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Sold 912E #1 :^( Had to do it!

It is a sad day in my life as a Porschephiliac,

     Due to financial difficulties (can you say BILL COLLECTORS??!!) I 
had to sell 912E #1.  A VW mechanic who also owns a '76 914 2.0 offered 
me $12,000 for it as is, and considering my situation its the only way to 
go.  I know the guy, and he will take good care of it and wants to 
restore it to concours original condition.  Its better the car be in the 
hands of someone who has the means to restore it proprerly.  Though I 
didn't intend the car as an investment, doubling your money in two weeks 
isn't bad.  I can see the headlines now "Porsche saves owners credit 
record".  I told him about how helpful this list has been, so he might 
get a Net account and join the list.  He's going to tow it away tomorrow, 
and my garage will be empty of its spirit.  Yes, I still have my 924 but 
its not the same.  I only wish I was rich enough to keep it, and I'll get 
along OK with my "budget" Porsche.  Here's to a lost opportunity.

Jay Karolyi
'76 Alpine White 912E #1 ( soon to be a memory :^{
'77 Lima Bean Green 924 (may it live forever!!!)

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 20:27:25 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: 951 oil scum question

  >Have any of you synthetic oil users experienced similar problems of scum 
  >'growing' in your oil after oil changes?  Any thoughts would be appreciated.  

not a sythetic user but I have seen a buildup of what I assume is an
oil/water emulsion (yellowish waxy residue) on the inside of my oil
cap and inside the filler neck.  This is only in the last couple of
months.  I believe this is due to low temps, wet air and the fact that
my (911) engine doesn't reach operating temps quite on my short (10
minute) commute on these cold days.  I'm guessing this is simply
water condensation inside the filler neck which will go away if/when
then weather gets warmer or if/when I get the engine nice and hot for a
prolonged period of time.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 18:01:56 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: 951 oil scum question

Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov wrote:
> Have any of you synthetic oil users experienced similar problems of scum 
>'growing' in your oil after oil changes?  Any thoughts would be appreciated.  

I have used Mobil 1 15-50 in my 931 for the past 3.5 years.  I have
never seen this yellowish 'scum' on the filler cap (or anywhere else).

My turbo does produce the characteristic light brown 'milkshake foam'
in the oil return and breather lines (one of which vents at the oil
filler cap), but that sounds like something different.
