Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 18:19:29 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: 931: Oil in the PCV air

A recent thread reminded me of this question to those with the turbo
blooded P-cars...

My 931 air filter usually dies a premature death because of oil
mist/vapor that is blown into the filter box by the PCV line.  ( With
the engine hot and running and the box open, I can see 'smoke' issuing
from this tube, and it coats my entire induction system with a brown
varnish.) This, despite the fact that the PCV line contains an oil/air
separator canister.  I use Mobil 1 15/50 oil. 

Should I explain this as:
1) Normal behavior for a 14 year old engine,
2) a result of the turbo oil frothing, or
3) abnormal, such as from a clogged drain line or separator??

Anyone with similar experience or other wisdom?


 -mike   '80 931 fire engine red... and soaking wet, inside and out :-(

From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)

>found a yellow scum on the underside of the filler cap and some around the 
>inside of the oil filler tube.  There was no similar scum on the dipstick.  On 

Just make sure that isn't anti-freeze. Check if there's scum in your
radiator overflow tank. If so, I'd get it checked. The seals in the oil
cooler could have shrunk with the change in oil <shrug>. It happened to
quite a few early '87's, though they were non-turbo's.


Hoping that not's it,
Craig.

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 20:44:22 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911 Update

> Does anyone have an opinion on "updating" an older 911 to the newer body
> components and wheels?  I am considering an upgrade (because I can) and am
> interested in some opinions. I would start with the wheels and body flares
> etc... and would not necessarily go the turbo look (i.e. flares front and
> back) but maybe just the SC flares in back and the C2-Turbo wheels.

I've baby-sat three pre-SC to Carrera upgrades in the last year, including
the 3.2 with DME, the flares, brakes, etc. It *can* be done, it's a
giant pain in the ass. Before doing this,I used to think that I wanted
a '73T body with a 3.2, flares, 15x7&8s, 930 brakes,etc. Now I realize
that if I had a '73 T, I'd keep it stock -- re-do the MFI, re-do
the engine but leave it at 2.4, but mainly leave it stock.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 16:33:50 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re:[3]: 911 SC Rear speaker size ? (long)


Here's some more info. G:

>Andy:
>        Thanks much for your advice, I do have some more questions though....
>
>The easiest way to check what size you need is to actually measure the hole 
>itself or the old speakers ( if there are any).  Your fitment is probably a 
>4x6, but some 911's have 5x7's.  It is best to check before purchasing.  
>There are many other brands of 4x6 's on the market.  Some of the metric 
>"4x6 's" will drop in without modification.  These include the Kenwood 
>KFC-463-V  metric 4x6 's or the Polk  MM 4620 metric 4x6 plates.  Another 
>important measurement to check is the overall depth of the speaker.  Other 
>brands may fit with slight modifications to the mounting area, such as a 
>mounting baffle or simple bracket.  What is a mounting baffle ?


Sorry about the confusion.  Simplistically speaking, a baffle is any panel 
into which a speaker is mounted.  A custom baffle board can be made to allow 
a speaker to fit into a space where it would otherwise be too small.  The 
important thing to remember when mounting speakers, that the front of the 
cone should be separated from the back of the cone.  That is to say that if 
you were to hold a raw speaker in the palm of your hand, that the front of 
the cone would NOT be separated from the rear.  Only once a speaker is 
mounted into some sort of baffle (a board/panel with a hole in it the size 
of the speaker) are the front and rear properly separated.  When the cone of 
an operating speaker resonates back and forth it creates waves of compressed 
and rareified air (sound waves) on BOTH the front and back sides of the 
cone.  These waves are out of phase, however, (i.e. 180 degrees apart with 
respect to time) which will cancel each other out if they are not physically 
separated some how.  In other words, the front of the speaker must play into 
a different "air space" than does the rear of the speaker.  This separation 
is accompolished through the use of a baffle board, into which the speaker 
is mounted (this is the same reason why home speakers come mounted in 
"boxes" or "cabinets").  If the space where you wish to mount the speakers 
does not closely conform to the size of the speaker itself, you need to 
fabricate a "baffle board" ( such as 0.25 inch plywood ) with a 4x6 hole, 
then mount it to the car, and in turn the speakers are mounted to the board. 
 You should take care in mounting speakers to seal the mounting lip of the 
speaker to the panel on which they are mounted ( weather stripping foam 
works well ) to prevent front to back air leaks.  This discussion may be 
more than you were looking for, but hopefully it will help you achieve 
better sound.  Believe it or not, the small details can make the difference 
between a good install and a poor job.  If you are unsure as to whether you 
need a baffle board or not for your specific car, most pro installers are 
more than happy to give a bit of free friendly advice after looking at your car.


>I guess I wasn't too clear with my question, which is, do all 4x6 speakers 
>have the same DEPTH ? (ie, as long as it's a 4x6 speaker, will it fit in my 
>rear deck with no modification to the deck ) ?


NO! ABSOLUTELY NOT.  That is why it is important to measure not only the  
length x width, but also the depth of BOTH the speaker and the car.  If 
these numbers conflict (in any one of the three dimensions), then the 
speakers won't directly fit the mounting hole.  That is why I said that a 
"mounting baffle" might work to adapt a speaker to a particular opening.  
Not only can a baffle be used to help fit a speaker into an opening, but by 
varying the thickness of the baffle (i.e. 0.25 inch wood, 0.5 inch wood, 
0.75 inch wood) it can act as a shim to effectively decrease the depth of 
the speaker that must recess into the opening.  

>I actually installed a Kenwood deck / CD changer with front speakers only 
>this weekend, only took 5 hours .... sounds pretty good, I'm not totally 
>concerned with perfect sound quality, as I have Targa so it's not really an 
>ideal aucostic environment to begin with.


Just a little aside, there is nothing like a small, high-quality, hi-fi amp 
used to power your system to help overcome the road/engine noise in your 
car.  Unless you only listen when parked, the higher power will allow you to 
hear music at regular levels much more clearly and distortion free than with 
the 3-5 watts supplied with many decks.  That was just something for you to 
ponder.  Everybody says that they are not concerned with sound 
quality.......until they hear a true hi-fi system, and it gives them a 
perspective for comparison.  Just some more brain food.


>Most of the speakers you will find in that size are coaxial drivers, but if 
>you are willing to spend a bit more, a pair of 4x6 plates should yield 
>better sound.  Plates are composed of a small midrange and a tweeter mounted 
>side by side, rather than in a concentric fashion as with coaxials.  Another 
>piece of advice is to look to an electronics retailer/chain store for 
>speakers.  You will find comparable or better equipment to that in 
>Performance Products
>
>Thanks, I kindda figure that, I wasn't going to order outta them, I just got 
>the speaker size from their catalog.
>
>thanks again...
>
>G
>78 911 SC


Hope this answered more questions than it raised.  If you have any more 
questions, send them this way!

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 01:13:39 -0500
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: Newbie buying a 911


On Jan. 27, Chuck McCurdy writes:

> I am having a hard time choosing between a Cab
> or a Targa. I would appreciate any comments, suggestions, warnings, offers to

Chuck, 
   I have to put in my (obviously biased) vote for a Targa.  Reasons:

 -For some reason, I like having a ragtop that doesn't LOOK like a ragtop.
 People are generally surprised when I take off the top.  Not that a serious 
 thief would be thwarted, but the kids down the block might not figure out 
 that they can just put a knife through the Targa.  The cab is too obvious.
 I prefer a bit of understatement.

 -I like having a real, glass rear window that can be scraped of snow, has
 a defroster, gives excellent rear viz (better than a coupe?).  

 -I really like the look, but this is clearly subjective.  (I also like the cab,
  but I'll take the Targa.)  But then again "Degustibus non est desputandum,"
  (or is that "Chacon a son gout" ?)

 -While it has been pointed out that resale values for cabs are high, this means
 that you have to PAY more to get one (right?).  

Cons:
 -My seals are beginning to leak up front. 
 -Sometimes there are no substitutes for a full-blown ragtop.

   As a final thought, there is one thing I really like about my P-car.  It
is a *practical* supercar.  Great looks, handling, acceleration, cornering, 
etc.  But it doesn't have the driving position of an F1 racer (like a Lotus),
it can carry enough luggage for a two-week trip for two (unlike a Ferrari),
can seat one or two in the back in a pinch (unlike a 'Vette).  Hell, mine
can run happily on regular gas.  Somehow the Targa fits into that niche 
better than a cab does.  Full glass? Yes.  Open top?  Sure. As structurally 
stable as a taxi?  Well....did I mention the full glass?

Paul F. Lyman 
'82 911SC Targa (natch'!)

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 03:04:13 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 356 in need of Help

Dear Mr. Snarkler:

          If you used the Big Bore Kit with a  356B Head AND you only used
only  one thin (0.25mm, .010") copper base gasket, then the pistons may be
hitting the spark plug electrode, especially if you used extended tip plugs
like the Bosch W6BC.   Check your old plugs to see ifin the gap has veen
drastically reduced! 
      If the plug gap is OK, try  checking the timing first (should be 3-5
deg static advance and 30-35 degrees Total High Speed advance (above 3000
RPM). Then, after that's done, try adjusting the mixture screws of the
Zeniths. If you  find one mixture screw that doesn't adjust well, you may
have a clogged idle jet. A quick test for a bad carb or cylinder is to find a
long, straight, deserted road, pop off one linkage arm and drive on one carb.
It'll drive poorly of course, but should get to 45-50 MPH. (My engines are
able to break the National Standard of Mediocracy on one carb.) If you get up
to 45-50, stop. Replace linkage arm, pop off the other one and drive on other
carb.  If the car don't go no mo', you've got a bad carb on that side. 
If one carb will only do 25 MPH, you have a bad cylinder. Pull off one plug
wire on that side. If you pull of the Bad one, it'll still do 25. If you pull
off the Good plug wire, it won't move!  
    This is my Binary Search tyechnique to find out which Carb or cylinder is
bad with only a couple of tests.
  KEEP THE 356 FAITH!
The Maestro


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1113                         Tue Jan 31 13:37:13 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 03:19:25 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: Re:   931: Oil in the PCV air  

This problem sounds more related to poor engine oil control than to a turbo
related problem. The oil from the turbo just dumps out into the (top of the)
oil pan and should not go into suspension (hence ending up in the air
filter).  My 931 also shows signs of oil on the filter  - though not to the
same extent that your car does Mike.  Does your car smoke at all?  (maybe on
gear changes or during high boost conditions - maybe needs new rings?)
As an aside, EBS (Engine Builders Supply or something), who advertises in
European car has a high(er) performance rebuild kit available for the 931
with 8.0:1 CR pistons - for $700 which is not too bad - I am not sure what
else is included in this kit though.  I sent for their catalog several months
but have had no response yet.  When I rebuild someday I will consider some
sort of [quality] alternative to the stock bits.  What would a set of stock
931 pistons cost I wonder?

MIKE.
1977 924 (as faithfull as ever)
1980 931 (Intercooler project put on hold for now due to technical
problems...)

way you can replace just the inserts works pretty well.

just let me know.  But I've had good luck with the Bosch blades over the 
years.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:53:06 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 oil scum question

This is moisture trying to escape your oil pan.  It accumulates from 
high humidity levels typically, and is fairly common.  Make sure you 
change the oil frequently to remove this moisture (and other dirt, 
etc.) from the oil.

Sometimes water in the oil is caused by a head gasket or oil/water 
intercooler seal leak.  If this is happening you'll see/smell 
antifreeze in the oil, and maybe oil scum in the antifreeze tank.  The 
fix for these problems is more involved.

		JBS

- ----------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:55:39 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

I've been down this road too, Adam.  The best thing to do is fork out 
for real Bosch arms & blades.  The blades can be had for around $8 - 
$11 /pair, and the arms, last I checked, were around $25 (dunno if 
pair/single).  You may be able to get arms from a used parts place.

Don't get the aftermarket "aerodynamic" blades; they're actually worse 
than stock and have MORE lift at speed, and are less effective.  I 
removed a set of these for a friend who bought them based on the sales 
pitch, and tossed them based on engineering.

		JBS

Just about anything except engine (which was also a basket case)

I will sell the new parts for 25% below what I paid from Automobile 
Atlanta. I will sell the used parts cheap.

	Please, no smart alec messages about how dumb I was to order all 
the above and then not use them! At least the 7 runs REAL good.

					Kim



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 08:54:25 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Re: Help..I screwed Up my pop-off valve installation!!


A small update.

I have determined (been told?) that the "gizmo" that I drilled into
was the cold-start fuel distribution manifold. It only appeared in 
81 (going by memory here...it was around then anyways) onwards. This
is why I did not see one in my neighbours 76S, or most of the people
on the net did not have one who have put in the valve. 

Anyways, the distribution manifold apparently was Porsche's solution
to reduce the amount of fuel in the airbox when the cold-start
(7th injector :-) ) was active. This is why the occurance of blown
air boxes is much less in the late model SC's, even though they 
still use CIS.

The hole is not that bid, and does not go **through** the manifold.
I am attempting an experiment using Locktite Copper gasket sealer
on some test cases. I have found a source for stubby stainless 
sheet metal screws, so I have used one of these in a test piece 
of sheet metal with the Locktite. I have also experimented with 
just using the locktite by it self, filling the hole like a plug.
I am also going to try forming a plug with the locktite, and then
us the locktite to seal that plug in the hole.

**Sigh**. I have used a combination of magnets, shop vac and sticky
tape to clean up all the metal shavings. There really was not that 
many in the box anyways, and it appears to be pretty clean now.
I have very little black plastic shavings in the air box because I
was using the shopvac while drilling the hole. 

The cold-start manifold must be no more than 1/2" below the bottom 
of the drill site...I would have realized that if I would have
read Mr. Anderson's book more carefully..of course you only see
it after the fact!

Anyways, I will keep you posted.

Mike
83 911SC 

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 09:56:04 -0700 (MST)
From: Wilson Luther <Luther.Wilson@Colorado.EDU>
Subject: Re: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

I had to replace the wipers on my 89 944 right after I bought it. The

dealer. There should be acouple in Ann Arbor.
Luther

between 900 and 1100 rpm for about 15-20 secs.  If I restart it soon after
the engine is turned off, either hot or cold, it starts right up.

like it should start right away.  Any ideas?

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:01:32 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: ,84 Euro Carrera for sale

> Which makes me finally ask a question I've been stewing over for a while. 
> How easy is it to replace the rear fender on a 911SC?  I know the fronts
> are more or less a bolt on affair, but what about the back and the
> roofline, etc.?

I got to watch my 911SC get new rear fenders, new rear cross-piece and
a significant amount of cut-and-paste done after a woman doctor pushed
a Caddy Eldorado into me at about 45 MPH while I was waiting for a light
to go from red to green....

That was *NOT* simple do it yourself job. Those fenders are seam welded into
place, and replacement is NOT trivial. The guys that did my work were very
very good, and it still took about 3 months to get the car back.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:01:54 pst
From: Brian_Foster_at_ASTISHR@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Sometimes you have to just sit and enjoy...

This past Sunday I was motivated to re-organize the garage -- don't 
know why, but there was something in the air.  After a morning of 
running around shopping for baby wallpaper and gadgets, I was ready 
for a change.

I started off with the left side and was finished within the hour.  I 
went to push the 356 out of the garage and saw "Murphy..." sitting in 
the passenger seat next to "Secrets..." (Earlier in the week I was 
checking if the engine had seen a previous overhaul...).  So I sat 
down, opened to a page at random and started reading.

Two hours later, my wife found me still sitting in the 356, smile on 
my face, the book open in front of me, and the righthand side of the 
garage not even touched.  She laughed and inquired how the Super Joke 
was going -- I had no clue!  I tried to explain, but I don't think she 
understands...:(

There is something about the smell, ambiance, character, or?! of your 
special friends sitting in the garage.  The mixture of leather, oil, 
racing fuel, and rubber serves as an aphrodisiac that some get, some 
don't -- who cares?!  I enjoyed my Sunday afternoon "driving" the 356 
w/o ever leaving my garage!

Thanks for listening, hope you get "it", and have a great week!!
===================================================================== 
Fahr schnell, sei vorsichtig, hab Spass
Brian Foster
88 Land Rover Range Rover
(one of the following two cars must be sold or traded for nice 4-door BMW by 
March!)
74 BMW SCCA/ITA 2002Tii
64 Porsche 356SC

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:09:36 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: FWD> K&N Filters Concern

> This note, which was forwarded to me days ago by a friend, is pretty much
> why I stopped reading rec.autos.tech.  Too many kids with nothing better to
> do that make shit up and see if anybody figures it out. Suurre, oil
> impregnated filters pass more dirt, uh huh. That's why every dirt racer just
> about in existence runs one of these or a K&N style -- they LIKE to put dirt
> thru their motors]  They can win major offroad events this way.  Yeah,
> right...  Send me accredited test results and not made up no-name bullshit
> and I'll listen....

Actually, Scott exposes a very good point here, one that I keep trying to make
every chance I get: just because something is good for racing does not mean
that it's even *USEFUL* for the street.... What you can tolerate in a full
race engine is very different that you want in a street engine. Why? Because
you're going to be tearing that engine down and rebuilding it with pretty
good frequency. At least once a season. Maybe more like every race if you're
talking IMSA or one of the serious pro series. That's just what you do.

So only getting say 10k miles of engine life due to a crappy air filter
is *NO BIG DEAL*... Here's the math: 10,000 miles at an average 100 MPH
is 100 hours of operation which is 3 to 5 times longer than the engine
lives *ANYWAY*!!!! So just because you use K&N on racing engines doesn't
mean *ANYTHING* about how good they are for the street!!!!! On the
other hand, a filter that keeps your engine *PERFECT* (yeah, right) for
100k miles is going to be *WORTHLESS* on a race car, because you will 
be losing some flow efficiency, and you can't afford that. Period.

>  -Scott Jessen -- and why, yes, I have raced a fair bit off road now that you
> ask...  Oh, and I run K&N on my tow vehicle and ITG dual-density oiled foam
> filters on the 911...

Yeah, I run the K&Ns on my race car too, and *HIGHLY* recommend the ITG filters
for carb applications when racing...

Street, that's another can of beans entirely... Factory air and oil filters
ONLY (but would highly consider the Canton/Meca oil filter for street use).

Stan

------------------------------

100% galvinized metal was incorporated into the 911.  We have gotten
conflicting information ranging from 1977 to 1984.  I know that it
started with 1980 on the 924, one would think earlier with the 911 -
does anyone have the hard facts?

Date: Tue, Jan 31, 1995 12:50 PM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Galvinized 911s started when?

Kristian Simsarian writes:
> 
> 	A friend of mine is looking for an early 80's SC or Carrera. In
> a snowy cold climate like this we have often wondered when exactly the 
> 100% galvinized metal was incorporated into the 911.  We have gotten
> conflicting information ranging from 1977 to 1984.  I know that it
> started with 1980 on the 924, one would think earlier with the 911 -
> does anyone have the hard facts?

(the Late) Dean Batchelor said 911's were galvanized starting in '76.  I posted 
this a week or so ago, and Bruce Anderson questioned me on it.  As I told Bruce,
I can't lay my hands on the book to look up the reference. but I remember it
pretty clearly, as that's one of the issues that was important to me when I
was searching for my toy.  Bruce told me that the issue is pretty controversial,
so I infer that the reference may not be correct.

Hey! you get what ya pay for...

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora
'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 10:03:28 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Crankcase Cottage Cheese


Hi all, 

The phenomonom you describe is a form of condensation of oil vapor that
also occurs in 911 dry sump tanks. This occurs because the driving cycle 
is such that the oil does not reach full operating temperature to 
outgas the watervapor that condenses from short cycle driving.

For Mike Weilman and 924 Turbo owners, there is an oil trap 6 inches
from the air cleaner but 18 inches from the block. It almost never gets
hot enough to vaporize the water condensation, the normal purge cycle
of the vapor traps moves this white-ish goo onto the air cleaner element
ruining the element. I have removed the trap and cleaned it.

Pulsing vapor is caused by the pulses of the pistons displacing air in
the crankcase. Dark, oily vapor indicates blow-by, not good. Clear or
whitish vapor is condensation, just getting warmed up to get out of the 
system. Driving on the freeway for an hour or so should get things warm
enough to get rid of the condensation.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 14:25:32 -0500
From: Ron911car@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1109 Mon Jan 30 02:00:04 CST 1995

letting the wheel go can be a life saver,if u posse the skill. i have used
this technique many times at low and high speeds.i dont know where or how i
learned it but i can tell u that it really works.u see cars want to naturally
go straight,so when the force going side ways is so strong it becomes all
most impossible to to hold the wheel.the wheel will actually snap back to the
straight position!the important part is to stay on the power and remember to
grab back hold of the wheel!. if u lift be sure to get right back on the
power ultimately u want to stay on the power.if u lift and dont get back on
the power,round and round u go (just ask russ) P.S.this  also works in
motorcyling.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 11:26:10 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: 911 Jacking Points


There was a thread a while back about optimal jacking and jack 
stand points for a 911. I don't know if it came to a satisfactory 
conclusion, but the January issue of the Pacific Northwest 
Region's PCA Newsletter has an article by Allan Caldwell in 
which he suggests jacking and stand points for all Porsche 
models.  For the 911/912/930 he suggests:

For the Front:	Jackpoint - Front Cross Support Box Beam
			Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Covers or Body Hoist 
					Pads

For the Rear:	Jack Point - Engine with woods block
			Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Ends



Bob Spindel
'72 911E

Neil wrote:

In 1961, with my wife and two kids, we picked up our new 356B Coupe at
Sonauto dealership in Paris. None of us had ever been in a Porsche before
(except to see if the kids fit in the back), much less driven one. We made
two wrong turns and immediately found ourselves in L'Etoile at lunch hour.

Can't remember how many revolutions we made. Went into it as a terrified
Porsche novice -- came out of it as a Porsche race driver. At least, I
thought so at the time . . . .

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 03:19:25 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: Re:   931: Oil in the PCV air  

This problem sounds more related to poor engine oil control than to a turbo
related problem. The oil from the turbo just dumps out into the (top of the)
oil pan and should not go into suspension (hence ending up in the air
filter).  My 931 also shows signs of oil on the filter  - though not to the
same extent that your car does Mike.  Does your car smoke at all?  (maybe on
gear changes or during high boost conditions - maybe needs new rings?)
As an aside, EBS (Engine Builders Supply or something), who advertises in
European car has a high(er) performance rebuild kit available for the 931
with 8.0:1 CR pistons - for $700 which is not too bad - I am not sure what
else is included in this kit though.  I sent for their catalog several months
but have had no response yet.  When I rebuild someday I will consider some
sort of [quality] alternative to the stock bits.  What would a set of stock
931 pistons cost I wonder?

MIKE.
1977 924 (as faithfull as ever)
1980 931 (Intercooler project put on hold for now due to technical
problems...)

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 07:46:00 PST
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?


     Before you rush into this, I thought I'd add my 2p worth.  I believe 
the Bosch (=Autobahn at your friendly VW/Porsche/Audi dealer) are the best 
blades I've used and seen.  They are a little expensive but I think they 
hold up well over time.  Besides, new arms couldn't be cheap.  I think the 
way you can replace just the inserts works pretty well.
     If this seems to be my personal opinion and no one out there likes, 
just let me know.  But I've had good luck with the Bosch blades over the 
years.

David B.

inserts.)

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:53:06 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 oil scum question

This is moisture trying to escape your oil pan.  It accumulates from 
high humidity levels typically, and is fairly common.  Make sure you 
change the oil frequently to remove this moisture (and other dirt, 
etc.) from the oil.

Sometimes water in the oil is caused by a head gasket or oil/water 
intercooler seal leak.  If this is happening you'll see/smell 
antifreeze in the oil, and maybe oil scum in the antifreeze tank.  The 
fix for these problems is more involved.

                JBS

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:55:39 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

I've been down this road too, Adam.  The best thing to do is fork out 
for real Bosch arms & blades.  The blades can be had for around $8 - 
$11 /pair, and the arms, last I checked, were around $25 (dunno if 
pair/single).  You may be able to get arms from a used parts place.

Don't get the aftermarket "aerodynamic" blades; they're actually worse 
than stock and have MORE lift at speed, and are less effective.  I 
removed a set of these for a friend who bought them based on the sales 
pitch, and tossed them based on engineering.

                JBS

- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 08:54:25 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Re: Help..I screwed Up my pop-off valve installation!!


A small update.

I have determined (been told?) that the "gizmo" that I drilled into
was the cold-start fuel distribution manifold. It only appeared in 
81 (going by memory here...it was around then anyways) onwards. This
is why I did not see one in my neighbours 76S, or most of the people
on the net did not have one who have put in the valve. 

Anyways, the distribution manifold apparently was Porsche's solution
to reduce the amount of fuel in the airbox when the cold-start
(7th injector :-) ) was active. This is why the occurance of blown
air boxes is much less in the late model SC's, even though they 
still use CIS.

The hole is not that bid, and does not go **through** the manifold.
I am attempting an experiment using Locktite Copper gasket sealer
on some test cases. I have found a source for stubby stainless 
sheet metal screws, so I have used one of these in a test piece 
of sheet metal with the Locktite. I have also experimented with 
just using the locktite by it self, filling the hole like a plug.
I am also going to try forming a plug with the locktite, and then
us the locktite to seal that plug in the hole.

**Sigh**. I have used a combination of magnets, shop vac and sticky
tape to clean up all the metal shavings. There really was not that 
many in the box anyways, and it appears to be pretty clean now.
I have very little black plastic shavings in the air box because I
was using the shopvac while drilling the hole. 

The cold-start manifold must be no more than 1/2" below the bottom 
of the drill site...I would have realized that if I would have
read Mr. Anderson's book more carefully..of course you only see
it after the fact!

Anyways, I will keep you posted.

Mike
83 911SC

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:01:32 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: ,84 Euro Carrera for sale

> Which makes me finally ask a question I've been stewing over for a while. 
> How easy is it to replace the rear fender on a 911SC?  I know the fronts
> are more or less a bolt on affair, but what about the back and the
> roofline, etc.?

I got to watch my 911SC get new rear fenders, new rear cross-piece and
a significant amount of cut-and-paste done after a woman doctor pushed
a Caddy Eldorado into me at about 45 MPH while I was waiting for a light
to go from red to green....

That was *NOT* simple do it yourself job. Those fenders are seam welded into
place, and replacement is NOT trivial. The guys that did my work were very
very good, and it still took about 3 months to get the car back.

Stan

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:01:54 pst
From: Brian_Foster_at_ASTISHR@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Sometimes you have to just sit and enjoy...

This past Sunday I was motivated to re-organize the garage -- don't 
know why, but there was something in the air.  After a morning of 
running around shopping for baby wallpaper and gadgets, I was ready 
for a change.

I started off with the left side and was finished within the hour.  I 
went to push the 356 out of the garage and saw "Murphy..." sitting in 
the passenger seat next to "Secrets..." (Earlier in the week I was 
checking if the engine had seen a previous overhaul...).  So I sat 
down, opened to a page at random and started reading.

Two hours later, my wife found me still sitting in the 356, smile on 
my face, the book open in front of me, and the righthand side of the 
garage not even touched.  She laughed and inquired how the Super Joke 
was going -- I had no clue!  I tried to explain, but I don't think she 
understands...:(

There is something about the smell, ambiance, character, or?! of your 
special friends sitting in the garage.  The mixture of leather, oil, 
racing fuel, and rubber serves as an aphrodisiac that some get, some 
don't -- who cares?!  I enjoyed my Sunday afternoon "driving" the 356 
w/o ever leaving my garage!

Thanks for listening, hope you get "it", and have a great week!!

- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:09:36 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: FWD> K&N Filters Concern

> This note, which was forwarded to me days ago by a friend, is pretty much
> why I stopped reading rec.autos.tech.  Too many kids with nothing better to
> do that make shit up and see if anybody figures it out. Suurre, oil
> impregnated filters pass more dirt, uh huh. That's why every dirt racer just
> about in existence runs one of these or a K&N style -- they LIKE to put dirt
> thru their motors]  They can win major offroad events this way.  Yeah,
> right...  Send me accredited test results and not made up no-name bullshit
> and I'll listen....

Actually, Scott exposes a very good point here, one that I keep trying to make
every chance I get: just because something is good for racing does not mean
that it's even *USEFUL* for the street.... What you can tolerate in a full
race engine is very different that you want in a street engine. Why? Because
you're going to be tearing that engine down and rebuilding it with pretty
good frequency. At least once a season. Maybe more like every race if you're
talking IMSA or one of the serious pro series. That's just what you do.

So only getting say 10k miles of engine life due to a crappy air filter
is *NO BIG DEAL*... Here's the math: 10,000 miles at an average 100 MPH
is 100 hours of operation which is 3 to 5 times longer than the engine
lives *ANYWAY*!!!! So just because you use K&N on racing engines doesn't
mean *ANYTHING* about how good they are for the street!!!!! On the
other hand, a filter that keeps your engine *PERFECT* (yeah, right) for
100k miles is going to be *WORTHLESS* on a race car, because you will 
be losing some flow efficiency, and you can't afford that. Period.

>  -Scott Jessen -- and why, yes, I have raced a fair bit off road now that you
> ask...  Oh, and I run K&N on my tow vehicle and ITG dual-density oiled foam
> filters on the 911...

Yeah, I run the K&Ns on my race car too, and *HIGHLY* recommend the ITG filters
for carb applications when racing...

Street, that's another can of beans entirely... Factory air and oil filters
ONLY (but would highly consider the Canton/Meca oil filter for street use).

Stan

- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 18:19:39 +0100
From: Kristian Simsarian <kristian@sics.se>
Subject: Galvinized 911s started when?



        A friend of mine is looking for an early 80's SC or Carrera. In
a snowy cold climate like this we have often wondered when exactly the 
100% galvinized metal was incorporated into the 911.  We have gotten
conflicting information ranging from 1977 to 1984.  I know that it
started with 1980 on the 924, one would think earlier with the 911 -
does anyone have the hard facts?


Thanks,
Kristian

- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, Jan 31, 1995 12:50 PM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Galvinized 911s started when?

Kristian Simsarian writes:
> 
>       A friend of mine is looking for an early 80's SC or Carrera. In
> a snowy cold climate like this we have often wondered when exactly the 
> 100% galvinized metal was incorporated into the 911.  We have gotten
> conflicting information ranging from 1977 to 1984.  I know that it
> started with 1980 on the 924, one would think earlier with the 911 -
> does anyone have the hard facts?

(the Late) Dean Batchelor said 911's were galvanized starting in '76.  I posted 
this a week or so ago, and Bruce Anderson questioned me on it.  As I told Bruce,
I can't lay my hands on the book to look up the reference. but I remember it
pretty clearly, as that's one of the issues that was important to me when I
was searching for my toy.  Bruce told me that the issue is pretty controversial,
so I infer that the reference may not be correct.

Hey! you get what ya pay for...

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora
'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 06:29:05 -0500 (EST)
From: POVI@delphi.com
Subject: help..need source for custom pistons made up !

some 97mm pistons made up for a project motor oim working on
using new 97mm turbo liners, any help would be greatly
appriciated...joe

- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 10:03:28 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Crankcase Cottage Cheese


Hi all, 

The phenomonom you describe is a form of condensation of oil vapor that
also occurs in 911 dry sump tanks. This occurs because the driving cycle 
is such that the oil does not reach full operating temperature to 
outgas the watervapor that condenses from short cycle driving.

For Mike Weilman and 924 Turbo owners, there is an oil trap 6 inches
from the air cleaner but 18 inches from the block. It almost never gets
hot enough to vaporize the water condensation, the normal purge cycle
of the vapor traps moves this white-ish goo onto the air cleaner element
ruining the element. I have removed the trap and cleaned it.

Pulsing vapor is caused by the pulses of the pistons displacing air in
the crankcase. Dark, oily vapor indicates blow-by, not good. Clear or
whitish vapor is condensation, just getting warmed up to get out of the 
system. Driving on the freeway for an hour or so should get things warm
enough to get rid of the condensation.

Jim Pasha

- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 14:21:01 -0500

to the fellow(s) who belive a targa is only good for the street or track
events; there is truth in those words,but u can virtually eliminate the flex
by installing a roll cage.i have had great success in a targa in club racing
beating every coupe in 8 club races!as well as setting the indexes.P.S.if i
was to buy another it would be a coupe!

- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 14:25:32 -0500
From: Ron911car@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1109 Mon Jan 30 02:00:04 CST 1995

letting the wheel go can be a life saver,if u posse the skill. i have used
this technique many times at low and high speeds.i dont know where or how i
learned it but i can tell u that it really works.u see cars want to naturally
go straight,so when the force going side ways is so strong it becomes all
most impossible to to hold the wheel.the wheel will actually snap back to the
straight position!the important part is to stay on the power and remember to
grab back hold of the wheel!. if u lift be sure to get right back on the
power ultimately u want to stay on the power.if u lift and dont get back on
the power,round and round u go (just ask russ) P.S.this  also works in
motorcyling.

- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 11:26:10 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: 911 Jacking Points


There was a thread a while back about optimal jacking and jack 
stand points for a 911. I don't know if it came to a satisfactory 
conclusion, but the January issue of the Pacific Northwest 
Region's PCA Newsletter has an article by Allan Caldwell in 
which he suggests jacking and stand points for all Porsche 
models.  For the 911/912/930 he suggests:

For the Front:  Jackpoint - Front Cross Support Box Beam
                        Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Covers or Body Hoist 
                                        Pads

For the Rear:   Jack Point - Engine with woods block
                        Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Ends



Bob Spindel
'72 911E

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 14:33:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: Re: Galvinized 911s started when?


>>Kristian Simsarian writes:
>>
> >      A friend of mine is looking for an early 80's SC or Carrera. In
>> a snowy cold climate like this we have often wondered when exactly the
>> 100% galvinized metal was incorporated into the 911.  We have gotten
>> conflicting information ranging from 1977 to 1984.  I know that it
>> started with 1980 on the 924, one would think earlier with the 911 -
>> does anyone have the hard facts?

>Bart Chambers writes:
>
>(the Late) Dean Batchelor said 911's were galvanized starting in '76.  I 
posted this a week or so ago, >and Bruce Anderson questioned me on it.  As I 
told Bruce, I can't lay my hands on the book to look up >the reference. but 
I remember it pretty clearly, as that's one of the issues that was important 
to me when I >was searching for my toy.  Bruce told me that the issue is 
pretty controversial, so I infer that the reference >may not be correct.

I originally asked the question and Bruce Anderson responded that _full_ 
galvinization started in '78 on the 911. Bart responded that _partial_ 
galvinization started in '75 with the '76 model year.

Arthur E. Golden
AGolden@Pepsi.com
1988 944S (fully galvinized)

metal.

of corrosion probably won't interest him.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:58:29 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Roundabouts



Neil wrote:

> If you really want to have fun try L'Etoile at rush (or any other) 
> hour, where the priority a` droite gets you on fast but then .........

In 1961, with my wife and two kids, we picked up our new 356B Coupe at
Sonauto dealership in Paris. None of us had ever been in a Porsche before
(except to see if the kids fit in the back), much less driven one. We made
two wrong turns and immediately found ourselves in L'Etoile at lunch hour.

Can't remember how many revolutions we made. Went into it as a terrified
Porsche novice -- came out of it as a Porsche race driver. At least, I
thought so at the time . . . .

a)  Get off the gas. 
b)  Get on the gas.  
c)  Keep the gas where it is.
d)  Get on the brakes (presumably implying off the gas).
e) Something other than any of the above.

What is the recommended action (both pedals and steering) ?

some more meat back there.  What's the current thinking on sizes, sticking 
with the factory 16" wheels.

Thanks in advance for your help.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 03:19:25 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: Re:   931: Oil in the PCV air  

This problem sounds more related to poor engine oil control than to a turbo
related problem. The oil from the turbo just dumps out into the (top of the)
oil pan and should not go into suspension (hence ending up in the air
filter).  My 931 also shows signs of oil on the filter  - though not to the
same extent that your car does Mike.  Does your car smoke at all?  (maybe on
gear changes or during high boost conditions - maybe needs new rings?)
As an aside, EBS (Engine Builders Supply or something), who advertises in
European car has a high(er) performance rebuild kit available for the 931
with 8.0:1 CR pistons - for $700 which is not too bad - I am not sure what
else is included in this kit though.  I sent for their catalog several months
but have had no response yet.  When I rebuild someday I will consider some
sort of [quality] alternative to the stock bits.  What would a set of stock
931 pistons cost I wonder?

MIKE.
1977 924 (as faithfull as ever)
1980 931 (Intercooler project put on hold for now due to technical
problems...)

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 07:46:00 PST
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?


     Before you rush into this, I thought I'd add my 2p worth.  I believe 
the Bosch (=Autobahn at your friendly VW/Porsche/Audi dealer) are the best 
blades I've used and seen.  They are a little expensive but I think they 
hold up well over time.  Besides, new arms couldn't be cheap.  I think the 
way you can replace just the inserts works pretty well.
     If this seems to be my personal opinion and no one out there likes, 
just let me know.  But I've had good luck with the Bosch blades over the 
years.

David B.
'89 944 (BTW,  thanks for reminding me.  I probably need to replace the 
inserts.)
 ----------
   From: porschephiles-request
   To: porschephiles
   Subject: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?
   Date: Monday, January 30, 1995 11:56PM

   I just had a wiper blade fall apart on me today (how embarrasing) I guess 

   the blades were--- umm-- kinda old.. When I tried to get the universal
   ANCO blade replacement, it wouldn't fit (it was too wide).. the arms
   don't have a brand name stamped on them, so i'm at a loss as to what kind 

   of replacement blades to get.. SO.. I'm going to replace the arms. Anyone 

   have any preference as to a type? i noticed a slew of 'aerodynamic'
   styles at the parts shop today..  do most perform
   similarly? and, is it a simple affair to snap 'em into place on a 944?
   thanks in advance.
   adam
   '87 944

Date: 31 Jan 1995 08:50:25 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: Re: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

I think they are (usually) a very expensive place to buy parts but
I just purchased (Bosch) replacement blades from Automotion for 
$3.96 each.  That's less than I pay for Anco blades down at the 
autoparts store.  I have a flyer that says they are having a %20 off 
sale on all parts Feb 7 through 10.  944 blades are $4.76 ea. 
There number is 1-800-777-8881
 vrooom,
 Chris
P.S. By blades I mean the metal and the rubber (not just the rubber "blade").

 - ----------------------------------------

I just had a wiper blade fall apart on me today (how embarrasing) I guess 
the blades were--- umm-- kinda old.. When I tried to get the universal 
ANCO blade replacement, it wouldn't fit (it was too wide).. the arms 
don't have a brand name stamped on them, so i'm at a loss as to what kind

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:53:06 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 oil scum question

This is moisture trying to escape your oil pan.  It accumulates from 
high humidity levels typically, and is fairly common.  Make sure you 
change the oil frequently to remove this moisture (and other dirt, 
etc.) from the oil.

Sometimes water in the oil is caused by a head gasket or oil/water 
intercooler seal leak.  If this is happening you'll see/smell 
antifreeze in the oil, and maybe oil scum in the antifreeze tank.  The 
fix for these problems is more involved.

                JBS

> synthetic 15W-50 to Castrol Syntec 5W-50.  Prior to that the car had

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:55:39 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

I've been down this road too, Adam.  The best thing to do is fork out 
for real Bosch arms & blades.  The blades can be had for around $8 - 
$11 /pair, and the arms, last I checked, were around $25 (dunno if 
pair/single).  You may be able to get arms from a used parts place.

Don't get the aftermarket "aerodynamic" blades; they're actually worse 
than stock and have MORE lift at speed, and are less effective.  I 
removed a set of these for a friend who bought them based on the sales 
pitch, and tossed them based on engineering.

                JBS

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 08:54:25 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Re: Help..I screwed Up my pop-off valve installation!!


A small update.

I have determined (been told?) that the "gizmo" that I drilled into
was the cold-start fuel distribution manifold. It only appeared in 
81 (going by memory here...it was around then anyways) onwards. This
is why I did not see one in my neighbours 76S, or most of the people
on the net did not have one who have put in the valve. 

Anyways, the distribution manifold apparently was Porsche's solution
to reduce the amount of fuel in the airbox when the cold-start
(7th injector :-) ) was active. This is why the occurance of blown
air boxes is much less in the late model SC's, even though they 
still use CIS.

The hole is not that bid, and does not go **through** the manifold.
I am attempting an experiment using Locktite Copper gasket sealer
on some test cases. I have found a source for stubby stainless 
sheet metal screws, so I have used one of these in a test piece 
of sheet metal with the Locktite. I have also experimented with 
just using the locktite by it self, filling the hole like a plug.
I am also going to try forming a plug with the locktite, and then
us the locktite to seal that plug in the hole.

**Sigh**. I have used a combination of magnets, shop vac and sticky
tape to clean up all the metal shavings. There really was not that 
many in the box anyways, and it appears to be pretty clean now.
I have very little black plastic shavings in the air box because I
was using the shopvac while drilling the hole. 

The cold-start manifold must be no more than 1/2" below the bottom 
of the drill site...I would have realized that if I would have
read Mr. Anderson's book more carefully..of course you only see
it after the fact!

Anyways, I will keep you posted.

Mike
83 911SC

I got to watch my 911SC get new rear fenders, new rear cross-piece and
a significant amount of cut-and-paste done after a woman doctor pushed
a Caddy Eldorado into me at about 45 MPH while I was waiting for a light
to go from red to green....

That was *NOT* simple do it yourself job. Those fenders are seam welded into
place, and replacement is NOT trivial. The guys that did my work were very
very good, and it still took about 3 months to get the car back.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:01:54 pst
From: Brian_Foster_at_ASTISHR@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Sometimes you have to just sit and enjoy...

This past Sunday I was motivated to re-organize the garage -- don't 
know why, but there was something in the air.  After a morning of 
running around shopping for baby wallpaper and gadgets, I was ready 
for a change.

I started off with the left side and was finished within the hour.  I 
went to push the 356 out of the garage and saw "Murphy..." sitting in 
the passenger seat next to "Secrets..." (Earlier in the week I was 
checking if the engine had seen a previous overhaul...).  So I sat 
down, opened to a page at random and started reading.

Two hours later, my wife found me still sitting in the 356, smile on 
my face, the book open in front of me, and the righthand side of the 
garage not even touched.  She laughed and inquired how the Super Joke 
was going -- I had no clue!  I tried to explain, but I don't think she 
understands...:(

There is something about the smell, ambiance, character, or?! of your 
special friends sitting in the garage.  The mixture of leather, oil, 
racing fuel, and rubber serves as an aphrodisiac that some get, some 
don't -- who cares?!  I enjoyed my Sunday afternoon "driving" the 356 
w/o ever leaving my garage!

Thanks for listening, hope you get "it", and have a great week!!

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:09:36 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: FWD> K&N Filters Concern

> This note, which was forwarded to me days ago by a friend, is pretty much
> why I stopped reading rec.autos.tech.  Too many kids with nothing better to
> do that make shit up and see if anybody figures it out. Suurre, oil
> impregnated filters pass more dirt, uh huh. That's why every dirt racer just
> about in existence runs one of these or a K&N style -- they LIKE to put dirt
> thru their motors]  They can win major offroad events this way.  Yeah,
> right...  Send me accredited test results and not made up no-name bullshit
> and I'll listen....

Actually, Scott exposes a very good point here, one that I keep trying to make
every chance I get: just because something is good for racing does not mean
that it's even *USEFUL* for the street.... What you can tolerate in a full
race engine is very different that you want in a street engine. Why? Because
you're going to be tearing that engine down and rebuilding it with pretty
good frequency. At least once a season. Maybe more like every race if you're
talking IMSA or one of the serious pro series. That's just what you do.

So only getting say 10k miles of engine life due to a crappy air filter
is *NO BIG DEAL*... Here's the math: 10,000 miles at an average 100 MPH
is 100 hours of operation which is 3 to 5 times longer than the engine
lives *ANYWAY*!!!! So just because you use K&N on racing engines doesn't
mean *ANYTHING* about how good they are for the street!!!!! On the
other hand, a filter that keeps your engine *PERFECT* (yeah, right) for
100k miles is going to be *WORTHLESS* on a race car, because you will 
be losing some flow efficiency, and you can't afford that. Period.

>  -Scott Jessen -- and why, yes, I have raced a fair bit off road now that you
> ask...  Oh, and I run K&N on my tow vehicle and ITG dual-density oiled foam
> filters on the 911...

Yeah, I run the K&Ns on my race car too, and *HIGHLY* recommend the ITG filters
for carb applications when racing...

Street, that's another can of beans entirely... Factory air and oil filters
ONLY (but would highly consider the Canton/Meca oil filter for street use).

Stan

pretty clearly, as that's one of the issues that was important to me when I
was searching for my toy.  Bruce told me that the issue is pretty controversial,
so I infer that the reference may not be correct.

Hey! you get what ya pay for...

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 10:03:28 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Crankcase Cottage Cheese


Hi all, 

The phenomonom you describe is a form of condensation of oil vapor that
also occurs in 911 dry sump tanks. This occurs because the driving cycle 
is such that the oil does not reach full operating temperature to 
outgas the watervapor that condenses from short cycle driving.

For Mike Weilman and 924 Turbo owners, there is an oil trap 6 inches
from the air cleaner but 18 inches from the block. It almost never gets
hot enough to vaporize the water condensation, the normal purge cycle
of the vapor traps moves this white-ish goo onto the air cleaner element
ruining the element. I have removed the trap and cleaned it.

Pulsing vapor is caused by the pulses of the pistons displacing air in
the crankcase. Dark, oily vapor indicates blow-by, not good. Clear or
whitish vapor is condensation, just getting warmed up to get out of the 
system. Driving on the freeway for an hour or so should get things warm
enough to get rid of the condensation.

Jim Pasha

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 14:25:32 -0500
From: Ron911car@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1109 Mon Jan 30 02:00:04 CST 1995

letting the wheel go can be a life saver,if u posse the skill. i have used
this technique many times at low and high speeds.i dont know where or how i
learned it but i can tell u that it really works.u see cars want to naturally
go straight,so when the force going side ways is so strong it becomes all
most impossible to to hold the wheel.the wheel will actually snap back to the
straight position!the important part is to stay on the power and remember to
grab back hold of the wheel!. if u lift be sure to get right back on the
power ultimately u want to stay on the power.if u lift and dont get back on
the power,round and round u go (just ask russ) P.S.this  also works in
motorcyling.

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 11:26:10 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: 911 Jacking Points


There was a thread a while back about optimal jacking and jack 
stand points for a 911. I don't know if it came to a satisfactory 
conclusion, but the January issue of the Pacific Northwest 
Region's PCA Newsletter has an article by Allan Caldwell in 
which he suggests jacking and stand points for all Porsche 
models.  For the 911/912/930 he suggests:

For the Front:  Jackpoint - Front Cross Support Box Beam
                        Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Covers or Body Hoist 
                                        Pads

For the Rear:   Jack Point - Engine with woods block
                        Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Ends



Bob Spindel
'72 911E

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 14:33:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: Re: Galvinized 911s started when?


>>Kristian Simsarian writes:
>>
> >      A friend of mine is looking for an early 80's SC or Carrera. In
>> a snowy cold climate like this we have often wondered when exactly the
>> 100% galvinized metal was incorporated into the 911.  We have gotten
>> conflicting information ranging from 1977 to 1984.  I know that it
>> started with 1980 on the 924, one would think earlier with the 911 -
>> does anyone have the hard facts?

>Bart Chambers writes:
>
>(the Late) Dean Batchelor said 911's were galvanized starting in '76.  I 
posted this a week or so ago, >and Bruce Anderson questioned me on it.  As I 
told Bruce, I can't lay my hands on the book to look up >the reference. but 
I remember it pretty clearly, as that's one of the issues that was important 
to me when I >was searching for my toy.  Bruce told me that the issue is 
pretty controversial, so I infer that the reference >may not be correct.

I originally asked the question and Bruce Anderson responded that _full_ 
galvinization started in '78 on the 911. Bart responded that _partial_ 
galvinization started in '75 with the '76 model year.

Arthur E. Golden
AGolden@Pepsi.com
1988 944S (fully galvinized)

Craig Z.

Porschephiles #1116                         Tue Jan 31 14:41:17 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 14:37:46 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Pop-valve installation from hell

>From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
>Subject: Re: Help..I screwed Up my pop-off valve installation!!

>I have determined (been told?) that the "gizmo" that I drilled into
>was the cold-start fuel distribution manifold. It only appeared in
>81 (going by memory here...it was around then anyways) onwards. This
>is why I did not see one in my neighbours 76S, or most of the people
>on the net did not have one who have put in the valve.
 snip

>The hole is not that big, and does not go **through** the manifold.
>I am attempting an experiment using Locktite Copper gasket sealer
>on some test cases. I have found a source for stubby stainless
>sheet metal screws, so I have used one of these in a test piece
>of sheet metal with the Locktite. I have also experimented with
>just using the locktite by itself, filling the hole like a plug.
>I am also going to try forming a plug with the locktite, and then
>us the locktite to seal that plug in the hole.

 snip
>Mike
>83 911SC

    This "manifold" was on earlier cars than the SC, my original '75 box
    didn't have it but a '77 box did.

     Why not just leave the hole in it ? It sounds like you run much
    more risk ingesting a screw or lump of epoxy then just letting
    the hole stay there.  Unless you find a problem with it, I'd leave
    it. (Screw ingestion is one of the only killers 928s have, in fact
    you can look at the changes in the air-filter box on those cars and
    watch how the factory tried to avoid it).

     Or, take apart the box and remove the manifold entirely. If earlier
    cars didn't have to have it your SC should probably work without
    it.  Don't risk a head and cylinder for this.

         Good luck-Lee





------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 12:41:46 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Oil Scum

Re: oil scum in winter

My '83 SC always has some yellowish oil-water emulsion around the filler
neck in winter, anytime average outside temps are below 45F or so.  More
after short trips, less after long trips, but always there.  Water vapor
is always coming out of the crankcase, and this is the first
cold spot that it hits (on its way to being sucked back into the intake
manifold).

It looks to me like a lot of this crud must drip back down the filler
neck into the oil tank.  This has never seemed optimum to me... but then
I was reading an article in R&T (or some such) in '89 or '90 where the
factory ran a squad of Porsche cars up to the north end of Alaska in
winter... to see how they'd hold up I think.  I remember that at about
40 below the 911 had trouble with *water condensing in the
crankcase vent hose and freezing to a solid plug*... until they got some
heater duct and routed the tailpipe back to blow hot exhaust on the vent
hose... then it was on to Pt. Barrow.  (You Minnesota winter drivers
might want to take note...)

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org

p.s. that same article had a wonderful quote from Porsche's R&D
chief, something to the effect that "your car must have steel in it...
the driver must be able to feel the razor edge".  Does anyone remember
this or have the actual quote?

Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

Adam,

        Try to get Bosch arms if you can. I tried putting cheap wipers on 
my 944 and they just didn't clear the screen properly.

        Porsches usuallly come with Bosch arms and its worth replacing them 
with the same brand if you can find them.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 11:48:00 PST
From: "Lai, Hubert" <hl@msmail.orsil.ubc.ca>
Subject: 951 Wheels


Does anyone have a set of wheels that they would like to sell for a 1989 944 
Turbo S?  (Aren't all 1989 944 Turbos the "S" model?)

I have a friend with this model car and he wants to get a second set of rims 
at a reasonable price for use in the winter.  He wants to mount snow tires 
on them.  This would allow him to make the occasional weekend trip up to 
Whistler (We live in Vancouver.) without risking life, limb, and sheet 
metal.

The wheels need not be perfect, but they shouldn't be completely unseemly. 
 Scrapes and scratches are okay, but major gouges or truly disgusting levels 
of corrosion probably won't interest him.

Direct all replies to me.  Thanks in advance!

  Hubert Lai
  hl@orsil.ubc.ca

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:58:29 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Roundabouts



Neil wrote:

> If you really want to have fun try L'Etoile at rush (or any other) 
> hour, where the priority a` droite gets you on fast but then .........

In 1961, with my wife and two kids, we picked up our new 356B Coupe at
Sonauto dealership in Paris. None of us had ever been in a Porsche before
(except to see if the kids fit in the back), much less driven one. We made
two wrong turns and immediately found ourselves in L'Etoile at lunch hour.

Can't remember how many revolutions we made. Went into it as a terrified
Porsche novice -- came out of it as a Porsche race driver. At least, I
thought so at the time . . . .

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 14:00:48 -0600
From: Richard Hocking <hocking@cig.mot.com>
Subject: Tail Happy 911s

What with the recent thread on whether to let go the controls when in
a spin, I was wondering what the expert drivers out there recommend
when you start to lose the tail of your 911 ?

a)  Get off the gas. 
b)  Get on the gas.  
c)  Keep the gas where it is.
d)  Get on the brakes (presumably implying off the gas).
e) Something other than any of the above.

What is the recommended action (both pedals and steering) ?

Richard Hocking
'87 911 Targa  [ RICK GB 1 ]

Date: Tue Jan 31 11:06 EST 1995
From: "Haas, Gene" <haasge@uh2309p02.daytonoh.NCR.COM>
Subject: TIRES FOR 930


Howdy Y'all,

Moving to Dayton, OH from San Diego is a weather shock.  Especially for the 
P700Z's on the Turbo.  On the rare occasions that it has been in the 
slippery stuff, I might as well be wearing slicks.

Overall, I've not been happy with the P's.  They require constant balancing, 
and have an extremely harsh ride.

What's the experience and recommendation for a better all around tire for 
Midwest weather and less harshness?

Also, on size, the rear stock size 225's are nice, but I think I could use 
some more meat back there.  What's the current thinking on sizes, sticking 
with the factory 16" wheels.

Thanks in advance for your help.

................GH

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 03:19:25 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: Re:   931: Oil in the PCV air  

This problem sounds more related to poor engine oil control than to a turbo
related problem. The oil from the turbo just dumps out into the (top of the)
oil pan and should not go into suspension (hence ending up in the air
filter).  My 931 also shows signs of oil on the filter  - though not to the
same extent that your car does Mike.  Does your car smoke at all?  (maybe on
gear changes or during high boost conditions - maybe needs new rings?)
As an aside, EBS (Engine Builders Supply or something), who advertises in
European car has a high(er) performance rebuild kit available for the 931
with 8.0:1 CR pistons - for $700 which is not too bad - I am not sure what
else is included in this kit though.  I sent for their catalog several months
but have had no response yet.  When I rebuild someday I will consider some
sort of [quality] alternative to the stock bits.  What would a set of stock
931 pistons cost I wonder?

MIKE.
1977 924 (as faithfull as ever)
1980 931 (Intercooler project put on hold for now due to technical
problems...)

just let me know.  But I've had good luck with the Bosch blades over the 
years.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:53:06 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 oil scum question

This is moisture trying to escape your oil pan.  It accumulates from 
high humidity levels typically, and is fairly common.  Make sure you 
change the oil frequently to remove this moisture (and other dirt, 
etc.) from the oil.

Sometimes water in the oil is caused by a head gasket or oil/water 
intercooler seal leak.  If this is happening you'll see/smell 
antifreeze in the oil, and maybe oil scum in the antifreeze tank.  The 
fix for these problems is more involved.

                JBS

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:55:39 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

I've been down this road too, Adam.  The best thing to do is fork out 
for real Bosch arms & blades.  The blades can be had for around $8 - 
$11 /pair, and the arms, last I checked, were around $25 (dunno if 
pair/single).  You may be able to get arms from a used parts place.

Don't get the aftermarket "aerodynamic" blades; they're actually worse 
than stock and have MORE lift at speed, and are less effective.  I 
removed a set of these for a friend who bought them based on the sales 
pitch, and tossed them based on engineering.

                JBS

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 08:54:25 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Re: Help..I screwed Up my pop-off valve installation!!


A small update.

I have determined (been told?) that the "gizmo" that I drilled into
was the cold-start fuel distribution manifold. It only appeared in 
81 (going by memory here...it was around then anyways) onwards. This
is why I did not see one in my neighbours 76S, or most of the people
on the net did not have one who have put in the valve. 

Anyways, the distribution manifold apparently was Porsche's solution
to reduce the amount of fuel in the airbox when the cold-start
(7th injector :-) ) was active. This is why the occurance of blown
air boxes is much less in the late model SC's, even though they 
still use CIS.

The hole is not that bid, and does not go **through** the manifold.
I am attempting an experiment using Locktite Copper gasket sealer
on some test cases. I have found a source for stubby stainless 
sheet metal screws, so I have used one of these in a test piece 
of sheet metal with the Locktite. I have also experimented with 
just using the locktite by it self, filling the hole like a plug.
I am also going to try forming a plug with the locktite, and then
us the locktite to seal that plug in the hole.

**Sigh**. I have used a combination of magnets, shop vac and sticky
tape to clean up all the metal shavings. There really was not that 
many in the box anyways, and it appears to be pretty clean now.
I have very little black plastic shavings in the air box because I
was using the shopvac while drilling the hole. 

The cold-start manifold must be no more than 1/2" below the bottom 
of the drill site...I would have realized that if I would have
read Mr. Anderson's book more carefully..of course you only see
it after the fact!

Anyways, I will keep you posted.

Mike
83 911SC

I got to watch my 911SC get new rear fenders, new rear cross-piece and
a significant amount of cut-and-paste done after a woman doctor pushed
a Caddy Eldorado into me at about 45 MPH while I was waiting for a light
to go from red to green....

That was *NOT* simple do it yourself job. Those fenders are seam welded into
place, and replacement is NOT trivial. The guys that did my work were very
very good, and it still took about 3 months to get the car back.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:01:54 pst
From: Brian_Foster_at_ASTISHR@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Sometimes you have to just sit and enjoy...

This past Sunday I was motivated to re-organize the garage -- don't 
know why, but there was something in the air.  After a morning of 
running around shopping for baby wallpaper and gadgets, I was ready 
for a change.

I started off with the left side and was finished within the hour.  I 
went to push the 356 out of the garage and saw "Murphy..." sitting in 
the passenger seat next to "Secrets..." (Earlier in the week I was 
checking if the engine had seen a previous overhaul...).  So I sat 
down, opened to a page at random and started reading.

Two hours later, my wife found me still sitting in the 356, smile on 
my face, the book open in front of me, and the righthand side of the 
garage not even touched.  She laughed and inquired how the Super Joke 
was going -- I had no clue!  I tried to explain, but I don't think she 
understands...:(

There is something about the smell, ambiance, character, or?! of your 
special friends sitting in the garage.  The mixture of leather, oil, 
racing fuel, and rubber serves as an aphrodisiac that some get, some 
don't -- who cares?!  I enjoyed my Sunday afternoon "driving" the 356 
w/o ever leaving my garage!

Thanks for listening, hope you get "it", and have a great week!!

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:09:36 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: FWD> K&N Filters Concern

> This note, which was forwarded to me days ago by a friend, is pretty much
> why I stopped reading rec.autos.tech.  Too many kids with nothing better to
> do that make shit up and see if anybody figures it out. Suurre, oil
> impregnated filters pass more dirt, uh huh. That's why every dirt racer just
> about in existence runs one of these or a K&N style -- they LIKE to put dirt
> thru their motors]  They can win major offroad events this way.  Yeah,
> right...  Send me accredited test results and not made up no-name bullshit
> and I'll listen....

Actually, Scott exposes a very good point here, one that I keep trying to make
every chance I get: just because something is good for racing does not mean
that it's even *USEFUL* for the street.... What you can tolerate in a full
race engine is very different that you want in a street engine. Why? Because
you're going to be tearing that engine down and rebuilding it with pretty
good frequency. At least once a season. Maybe more like every race if you're
talking IMSA or one of the serious pro series. That's just what you do.

So only getting say 10k miles of engine life due to a crappy air filter
is *NO BIG DEAL*... Here's the math: 10,000 miles at an average 100 MPH
is 100 hours of operation which is 3 to 5 times longer than the engine
lives *ANYWAY*!!!! So just because you use K&N on racing engines doesn't
mean *ANYTHING* about how good they are for the street!!!!! On the
other hand, a filter that keeps your engine *PERFECT* (yeah, right) for
100k miles is going to be *WORTHLESS* on a race car, because you will 
be losing some flow efficiency, and you can't afford that. Period.

>  -Scott Jessen -- and why, yes, I have raced a fair bit off road now that you
> ask...  Oh, and I run K&N on my tow vehicle and ITG dual-density oiled foam
> filters on the 911...

Yeah, I run the K&Ns on my race car too, and *HIGHLY* recommend the ITG filters
for carb applications when racing...

Street, that's another can of beans entirely... Factory air and oil filters
ONLY (but would highly consider the Canton/Meca oil filter for street use).

Stan

 - ------------------------------

(the Late) Dean Batchelor said 911's were galvanized starting in '76.  I posted 
this a week or so ago, and Bruce Anderson questioned me on it.  As I told Bruce,
I can't lay my hands on the book to look up the reference. but I remember it
pretty clearly, as that's one of the issues that was important to me when I
was searching for my toy.  Bruce told me that the issue is pretty controversial,
so I infer that the reference may not be correct.

Hey! you get what ya pay for...

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 10:03:28 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Crankcase Cottage Cheese


Hi all, 

The phenomonom you describe is a form of condensation of oil vapor that
also occurs in 911 dry sump tanks. This occurs because the driving cycle 
is such that the oil does not reach full operating temperature to 
outgas the watervapor that condenses from short cycle driving.

For Mike Weilman and 924 Turbo owners, there is an oil trap 6 inches
from the air cleaner but 18 inches from the block. It almost never gets
hot enough to vaporize the water condensation, the normal purge cycle
of the vapor traps moves this white-ish goo onto the air cleaner element
ruining the element. I have removed the trap and cleaned it.

Pulsing vapor is caused by the pulses of the pistons displacing air in
the crankcase. Dark, oily vapor indicates blow-by, not good. Clear or
whitish vapor is condensation, just getting warmed up to get out of the 
system. Driving on the freeway for an hour or so should get things warm
enough to get rid of the condensation.

Jim Pasha

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 14:25:32 -0500
From: Ron911car@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1109 Mon Jan 30 02:00:04 CST 1995

letting the wheel go can be a life saver,if u posse the skill. i have used
this technique many times at low and high speeds.i dont know where or how i
learned it but i can tell u that it really works.u see cars want to naturally
go straight,so when the force going side ways is so strong it becomes all
most impossible to to hold the wheel.the wheel will actually snap back to the
straight position!the important part is to stay on the power and remember to
grab back hold of the wheel!. if u lift be sure to get right back on the
power ultimately u want to stay on the power.if u lift and dont get back on
the power,round and round u go (just ask russ) P.S.this  also works in
motorcyling.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 11:26:10 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: 911 Jacking Points


There was a thread a while back about optimal jacking and jack 
stand points for a 911. I don't know if it came to a satisfactory 
conclusion, but the January issue of the Pacific Northwest 
Region's PCA Newsletter has an article by Allan Caldwell in 
which he suggests jacking and stand points for all Porsche 
models.  For the 911/912/930 he suggests:

For the Front:  Jackpoint - Front Cross Support Box Beam
                        Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Covers or Body Hoist 
                                        Pads

For the Rear:   Jack Point - Engine with woods block
                        Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Ends



Bob Spindel
'72 911E

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 14:33:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: Re: Galvinized 911s started when?


>>Kristian Simsarian writes:
>>
> >      A friend of mine is looking for an early 80's SC or Carrera. In
>> a snowy cold climate like this we have often wondered when exactly the
>> 100% galvinized metal was incorporated into the 911.  We have gotten
>> conflicting information ranging from 1977 to 1984.  I know that it
>> started with 1980 on the 924, one would think earlier with the 911 -
>> does anyone have the hard facts?

>Bart Chambers writes:
>
>(the Late) Dean Batchelor said 911's were galvanized starting in '76.  I 
posted this a week or so ago, >and Bruce Anderson questioned me on it.  As I 
told Bruce, I can't lay my hands on the book to look up >the reference. but 
I remember it pretty clearly, as that's one of the issues that was important 
to me when I >was searching for my toy.  Bruce told me that the issue is 
pretty controversial, so I infer that the reference >may not be correct.

I originally asked the question and Bruce Anderson responded that _full_ 
galvinization started in '78 on the 911. Bart responded that _partial_ 
galvinization started in '75 with the '76 model year.

Arthur E. Golden
AGolden@Pepsi.com
1988 944S (fully galvinized)
