Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 12:56:16 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 913 924 Turbo Static Compression


Mike, 

The 1979-80 924 Turbo (US only) has a static compression of 7.5:1. the
1981-82 924 Turbo (US only) has a static compression of 8.0:1. It is
highly recommended that any 1979-80 that needs piston replacement use
the 1981-82 piston, size fitted per bore needed.

FYI, all Euro 924 Turbos and 924 Turbo Carreras use 8.5:1 static 
compression, with a different boost profile in the wastegate. These 
pistons work well, remember that the real compression goes to about
11.5:1 under full boost. There is no knock sensor, so be careful.

Jim Pasha

- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 12:59:22 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles FAQ for February

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+             PORSCHEPHILES - FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS              +
+                  (last revised January 20, 1995)                    +
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This is the FAQ for the Porschephiles list.  It is posted regularly,
once a month at or near the start of the month.  There are undoubtedly
additions, changes, etc., needed.  Your input is solicited in improving
the FAQ.  Send any comments to the address at the end of the FAQ.

Changes this month, courtesy of Philip Katz, include some guidelines 
for posting to the list, some additions to the list of Porsche models
and other useful suggestions.

=======================================================================

Questions answered in this FAQ:
  What is Porschephiles?
  How does Porschephiles work?
  Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?
  What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?
  Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?
  How do I submit administrative requests?
  Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?
  What else is available in the tta.com archives?
  Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
  What about splitting the list?
  What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?
  Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?
  I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?
  How can I find out more about the car I own?
  What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?
  What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
  What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?
  What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?
  What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?
  What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?
  What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?
  Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?
  Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
  Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?
  Who maintains this FAQ?

=======================================================================

What is Porschephiles?

     Porschephiles is an Internet mailing list centering on the Porsche
automobile in all of its incarnations.

=======================================================================

How does Porschephiles work?

     This list is being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming 
mail to the whole list at once.  The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  To send a message to the 
whole list, mail to

                porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative 
issues, send mail to

                porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request"
address.  The list is also available as a digest, where you get a
compilation of the day's messages once per day, rather than getting
all of the individual messages. This seems to be a win for people with
slow mail links or who are just too busy to stay current. If you want
to convert to (or from) the digest, send mail to the "porschephiles-
request" address above.

=======================================================================

Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?

     The moderator is:
          Stanley P. Hanks
          Principal, 
          Technology Tranfer Associates
          P.O. Box 2087
          Bellaire TX 77402-2087

     (He got tired of living in Houston, TX and working in Edison, NJ,
so moved back...)

          Houston: e-mail: stan@tta.com, 
                   voice:  (713) 661-2084 

     His Porsches currently include:  
          '64 356 SC (daily driver)
          '74 914 2.0 (SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)

=======================================================================

What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?

     There are a lot of members on the list.  It's small enough to be 
effective, and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and
sets of experience.  You ought to be able to ask any question you like,
although it's probably a good idea to look it up yourself if you can and
save the net bandwidth.  Keep the diversity of the list in mind before 
you decide to not ask a question, or if you get flamed for asking an 
"obvious" question.  Diversity -- it's a *feature*...

=======================================================================

Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?

     Beyond using normal good sense and discretion, you can submit
whatever you like that is relevant to Porsches.  You might want to use
descriptive "Subject" lines, including the model number when it is
relevant (e.g., "944 S2 Fuel leak query").  Your submissions would be 
easier for others to read if you make sure that your mailer wraps 
lines of text at 80 characters or less.

=======================================================================

How do I submit administrative requests?

     Send them, and ONLY them, to the "porschephiles-request" address 
(porschephiles-request@tta.com), or to Stan directly.  

=======================================================================

Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?

     Archives are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/archives.
Archives in six subdirectories (90, 91, 92, 93, 94, 95) each of which 
has the archives for that year, in UNIX compress format.  There are no
older archives available.  While it might seem like a good idea when
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before,
there are OVER 13 MEG of archives.  DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE
TIME.  And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or Stan
may have to take access away.  Also, DO NOT ask Stan to mail you
archives.  To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY
mode in FTP.  On receipt you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program,
or equivalent, to restore to textual format.  Mac and Windows versions
of "uncompress" are available via FTP from /pub/porschephiles/programs.


=======================================================================

What else is available in the tta.com archives?

     FAQs: In the FAQs directory there is this FAQ and there are FAQs 
for specific Porsche models (so far there's one for 914s and one for 
the Carrera models -- feel free to contribute one on YOUR favorite 
Porsche).  These are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/FAQs.
 
     Images: All sorts of Porsche images for your viewing pleasure,
mostly in .gif format.  There's also a directory called "UPLOAD" where 
you can deposit your own images for inclusion in the collection.  If 
you add any images, please include a file called "from.<username>", 
where <username> is your login ID, that describes the files if possible.

     PCA racing info: The PCA Club Racing Newsletter is now on-line,
thanks to the tireless efforts of the editor.  This is available by FTP 
in the directory tta.com:/pub/porschephiles/PCA/ClubRacing.  The 
newsletters are available both in PostScript and in Windows Write 
format.  If this is useful to you, send your thanks to the editor, Tom,
at "tt911@ibm.net".
 
     MiscInfo: Various other interesting bits of information potentially
useful to Porschephiles.
 
     Survey: The questionaire and results (when compiled) of the 
membership survey.

     And as usual, Monthly-Update, RULES, and Whos-Who, which get 
updated on a monthly basis.

=======================================================================
 
Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
 
     Yes, WWW access is through http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html.
The FTP restriction above applies to major downloading of stuff from the
archives, not WWW access.  Suggestions for improving the WWW pages
would be welcomed, as well as experienced help in doing so.

=======================================================================

What about splitting the list? 

     Various proposals surface now and then about splitting the list 
into components based on car model, activity types, or other divisions?  
Stan's reply to these suggestions is as follows:  

     "I just want all you Faithful Readers to understand: there are only 
two votes that count. Mine, and anyone who's willing to pay me to change 
my mind or operation or whatever.
 
     "Posted rates around here are $75/hr for automotive engineering 
projects, $125/hr for information technology consulting, and $2k/day for 
expert witness engagements.  Just so you know where the bidding starts..."

     In other words, the list *WILL* **NOT** be split.

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?

     The Who's Who is a listing of those who receive Porschephiles and 
who have responded to the offer to be listed.  It lists the owners, 
their state/country of residence, their car's year and model, and
their net address.  The list is updated when people send Stan the
information, and when he has time to update the list.  He sends it out
on a monthly basis to the list.  Only Porsches are listed, so don't
send your Alfa Zagato or your Buick GN in to be included.  Send
submissions or changes to "porschephiles-request@tta.com."

=======================================================================

Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?

     Several different clubs are available, depending on your interests
and location:

          Porsche Club of America.
          P.O. Box 10402
          Alexandria VA 22310
          Telephone: +1 703 922-9300

The main US Porsche club; see below for more information.

          Porsche Club Great Britain
          Ayton House
          West End
          Northleach
          Gloucestershire
          England GL54 3HG
          Telephone: +44 451 860792
          FAX: +44 451 860011

The Porsche club in Great Britain, obviously.

          Porsche Owners Club
          P.O. Box 9000-277
          Seal Beach, CA  90740
          +1 310 784-5653.

Based in Southern California, the focus of POC is time trialing and 
racing.

          356 Registry Inc.
          27244 Ryan Rd.
          Warren, MI, 48092
          Telephone +1 313 558-3692

For 356 enthusiasts around the world.  $20 per year and cheap at twice
the price (Vic Skirmants' racing column is worth that, as are the
classifieds).  5000 happy members can't be wrong!

          914 Owner's Association
          100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
          Palm Springs CA 92262
          Telephone: +1 619 325-6583

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries.  Dennis Deeds published the 
club newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly.  Membership is $22 a 
year.

          Early 911S Registry
          PO Box 363
          West Point, PA 19486
          Telephone: +1 215 652-701 (day), +1-215-287-5083 (evening)

Contact Vern Lyle.  Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter.  
Dedicated to all early 911S models.

     A more complete list of Porsche US regional and other special 
interest groups, from the January 1994 Porsche Panorama, is on tta.com,
in /pub/MiscInfo/sigs.

=======================================================================

I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?

     The Club affiliates you with a local region based on where your
ZIP code falls on their territory map.  You *CAN* request to join a
specific region, and you can specify an affilate region or dual
membership in another region.  The local regions put on many different
events, some social, some educational, some driving or compeition
oriented.  The annual gathering of the whole membership, the Porsche
Parade, features competition for the national championships in many
events, seminars, a GREAT goodie store, and one of the most fun weeks
you'll experience.

     To join, you need to have a Porsche VIN number and be able to claim 
you're an owner, a co-owner, or hold a lease on a Porsche.  That may
seem restrictive, particularly if you want to join the club to get
access to Panorama, the club magazine, for purposes of FINDING a car...
In such case, it's suggested that you purchase a modest fraction of a
friend's car for say $5 or so, hence becoming a co-owner.  Just don't
tell them you did that or where you got the idea...

     Once you have a VIN number, there are four ways to join:

     1) Send a letter to the national office saying that you want to 
join, with your name, address, car info and a check for $36 to:

        Porsche Club of Americia.
        P.O. Box 10402
        Alexandria VA 22310

     2) Call them up at +1 703 922-9300, roughly between 9:00 to 5:00
EST (GMT - 6).  If you have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number
handy, you can do it over the phone.  (Otherwise, they'll send you an
application which you can mail in with your check.)  This is the FASTEST
way, and if you need to be a member *RIGHT NOW* to go to an event that
is members only, this is your best bet.  Don't count on using this
method the week of or before Parade...

     3) find someone active in your local region.  *MANY* of the regions
are represented on the Porschephiles list, so that's a good place to
start.  Once you have found someone, get them to put you in touch with
the local region membership chair, they can give you the form, and off 
you go.

     4) National membership chair Nann Weissenberger is also on the
list, and is reachable via e-mail at "nannw@aol.com".  She'd be more 
than happy to help you out.

=======================================================================

How can I find out more about the car I own?

     If you own a North American Porsche, Porsche Cars North America 
will, for a fee of $20, research the original bill of sale for your car
and give you a Certificate of Authenticity stating the facts and 
figures for the car as it was delivered to the dealer.  If you're 
interested, contact: 
          Howard Adams
          PCNA
          P.O. Box 30911
          Reno Nevada 89520-3911
Include a copy of your title or registration as proof of ownership.
It takes 2-3 weeks depending on backlog.  A similar service is
available in Great Britain from Porsche Cars Great Britain, for about
30 pounds Sterling.  Porsche AG can also perform a similar search.

     It's also possible to get dealers to run a search for warranty and
other repairs for your car.  Some authorized dealers will search PCNA 
files for warranty and other maintenance records on specific cars.  
This data base apparently only goes back to sometime in the mid-1980s.  
It's not known how widespread this practice is among dealers; some will 
search only for warranty work done, while others also provide 
information about routine maintenance and repairs.  Ask your dealer.

=======================================================================

What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?

     The following list was extracted from _Illustrated_Porsche_Buyers_
Guide_, _Porsche_Specials_, _Cars_Are_My_Life_, _We_At_Porsche_, and
the article "Project Porsche, The Early Years" in the June '83 issue of
_Thoroughbred_&_Classic_Car_.  
It includes only more or less complete automobiles designed by
Ferdinand Porsche or by the Porsche factory.  Components (engines,
transmissions, etc.) have not been included.  Additions and corrections
are welcomed:

      "1" - Lohner-Porsche electric car, 1900; Ferdinand's first design,
            but not part of the "official" model sequence.
       7  - Wanderer passenger car, 1.7-liter, 6-cylinder engine, 1930; 
            the first official model, chosen to convey impression of 
            prior experience.
       8  - Wanderer 8-cylinder saloon design, 3.5-liter engine, 1931.
       9  - Second Wanderer 8-cylinder prototype, supercharged, 1931.
      12  - Zundapp small car, 5-cylinder radial rear-engined, 3 built.
      22  - Auto Union P-Wagen Grand Prix car, 4.3-liter, V16 engine, 
            1932-1937.
      24  - Zundapp three-wheel vehicle.
      27  - Mathis-Ford Saloon.
      32  - NSU prototype (Volkswagen forerunner).
      52  - Auto Union sports car based on P-Wagen GP car, 1934.
      60  - Original Volkswagen prototype, renamed KdF (Kraft durch 
            Freude, or strength through joy, by Adolf Hitler), basis 
            for the postwar Volkswagen, 1934-1941; the 60K10, a variation 
            of the 60, was a sports coupe built for the later cancelled 
            Berlin-Rome race, 1939. 
      61  - Another Volkswagen prototype, a narrower version of the 60.
      62  - Volkswagen-Kubelwagen (bucket car) cross-country prototype.
      64  - KdF-based sports car, 3 built, 1937-1938.
      65  - Volkswagen for driving schools.
      66  - Volkswagen for export, right-hand drive.
      67  - Volkswagen for invalids with steering column gear change.
      68  - Volkswagen Post office delivery van, model A, 1939.
      80  - Mercedes-Benz land speed record car, 44.7-liter V12
            Daimler-Benz engine, 1938-1939.
      81  - Volkswagen Medium Van, 1939.
      82  - KdF-based military Kubelwagen, 1939-1940.
      86  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen with 4wd, 6 built.
      87  - 4-wheel-drive version of Kubelwagen, 1939-1941.
      88  - Volkswagen delivery van on Kubelwagen chassis, model B, 1939.
      90 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      94 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      97  - Daimler-Benz heavy lorry.
      98  - Volkswagen amphibious car.
     100  - Panzer Leopard tank, 2 prototypes, 1939.
     110  - Volkspflug Small Tractor.
     111  - Small Tractor (2-cylinder engine).
     112  - Further development of 111 above.
     113  - Further development of 111 above.
     114  - F-wagen, 1.5-liter sports car prototype, 1.5-liter V10
            twin-ohc water cooled mid-engined coupe, 1938-9.
     115 -  1.1-liter supercharged Volkswagen mid-engined coupe, 1938.
     116 -  1.5-liter Volkswagen mid-engined coupe.
     128  - KdF-based amphibian Schwimmwagen, 1940-1941.
     130  - Tiger Tank (Jagpanzer) "Ferdinand".
     138  - Volkswagen Amphibious Car (version 2).
     155  - Half Track version of Kubelwagen.
     164  - Six-wheel lorry.
     166  - Volkswagen amphibious car (production version).
     182  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen (production version).
     187  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen 4wd (production version).
     205  - 180-ton Maus tank, 1942; two built, never saw action.
     245  - 18-ton multipurpose tank, 1942.
     293  - Caterpillar tractor.
     312  - Tractor with petrol engine.
     323  - 11-hp diesel tractor, 1946.
     328  - Tractor, 28 hp. engine.
     340  - Wheelbarrow.
     355  - Volkswagen delivery van.
     356  - The original Porsche sports car, the first to wear the
            Porsche name, 1948-1965; various engine and drivetrain 
            components and numerous styling variations existed.
     360  - Cisitalia 4-wheel-drive Grand Prix car, 1947-1948.
     370  - Cisitalia 1.5-liter sports/touring car, 1947.
     425  - 20 bhp diesel tractor.
     514  - LeMans car, also called 356SL, 1951.
     524  - Improved 356 prototype with mechanical injection, 1951;
            not economically feasible to take to production.
     530  - Experimental 4-passenger Porsche, 1951-1952.
     534  - Volkswagen Small sports car.
     540  - Porsche America Roadster.
     541  - Special sports version of 356.
     542  - Studebaker Saloon 1952-1954.
     550  - Mid-engine, 2-seat sports/racing car, the car that James 
            Dean died in, 1954; the 550A was a redesigned 550 with a
            tubular space frame, 1956.
     597  - Jagdwagen (Hunter) 4-wheel-drive vehicle, 1954-1955.
     621  - Porsche single-cylinder tractor (allgaier).
     622  - 2-cylinder tractor.
     623  - 3-cylinder tractor.
     624  - 4-cylinder tractor.
     633  - Studebaker saloon prototype.
     645  - Sports/racing car, "Mickey Mouse," 1956.
     675  - Small Volkswagen 1955-1959.
     691  - Porsche 550 RS (1956)
     695  - Porsche predevelopment (T7) for 911.
     702  - One man Helicopter.
     718  - Bergspyder sports/racing car (RSK), 1957; the 718/2 was a 
            1.5-liter single-seat racing car (F-2), 1959.
     726  - Volkswagen Saloon 1958.
     728  - Small Volkswagen 1957-1961.
     737  - Porsche outboard motor.
     753  - Porsche 1.5-liter 8-cylinder Formula 1.
     764  - Volkswagen 6-cylinder saloon.
     787  - Grand Prix car, 1961.
     804  - Grand Prix car, 1962.
     806  - Leopard Tank.
     814  - Leopard Tank.
     901  - Prototype 6-cylinder sports car, basis for 911, 1963; 
            changed to 911 for production because of conflict with 
            Peugeot numbering scheme.  6 prototypes built.
     904  - Mid-engine competition GT coupe, with various engines in 
            1963-1964, 100+ built, some for street use. 
     906  - Competition sports coupe (space frame), 1966-1967.
     907  - Sports/racing coupe, various iterations, 1967-1968.
     908  - 3-liter, 8-cylinder competition car, various bodies,
            1968-1970.
     909  - 2-liter hill climb spyder, 1968.
     910  - Sports racing coupe, different configurations, 1966-1968.
     911  - Porsche's flagship.  Built from 1964 (excluding the '63
            901 prototype) in numerous variations through the 993.  
            Rear-engined, air-cooled, boxer six-cylinder engine.
            Many engine variations have existed through its long life, 
            from the original 2-liter car to the 3.8-liter RS.
     912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
            in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1966 through
            1969; 912E in '76 was a revival with engine from the 914.
     914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between
            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6
            was a Porsche-built variant with a two-liter 911 engine
            inserted in place of the four-cylinder engine and other
            refinements.
     916  - Projected 2.4-liter version of 914/6, 1971.  Was apparently
            used in competition by the factory.  Also, a few examples 
            of an 8-cylinder (908-based) version supposedly exist.
     917  - 12-cylinder competition car, famous for Le Mans and CanAm
            victories; various iterations, 1969-1973.
     924  - The first of the water-cooled front-engine cars, built from
            1976 to 1988.  Originally with a four-cylinder, Audi-derived
            engine; updated in mid-86 as the 924S with the 944 drivetrain;
            has the best aerodynamic shape of any street Porsche.
     928  - The high-end car produced from 1978 to present, V8 in the
            front, water-cooled, has grown from an original 4.5-liter
            to 5.4 today.
     930  - Turbocharged 911, homologation and street version of the
            racing 934.
     931  - Turbocharged 924, sold in 1980-1982.
     934  - Group 4 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1975-1976.
     935  - Group 5 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1976.
     936  - Group 6 turbocharged spyder, 1976.
     937  - 924 Carrera GT.
     939  - 924 Carrera GT Le Mans.
     944  - Front-engined, water-cooled inline four-cylinder car, with
            nearly perfect 50/50 weight bias.  Sixteen-valve and
            turbocharged versions were produced.  Produced from 1982
            through 1991. 2.5-liter displacement, except for a 2.7-liter
            eight-valve 944 model in 1989 and the 3-liter 944S2.
     951  - The turbo version of the 944.  Built from 1985 to 1991.
     956  - GT racing car, loosely based on 911; 1982-1983.
     959  - Supercar 911 derivative; 2.85-liter, four-valve, twin cam,
            dual turbochargers, all-wheel drive; not street-legal in US.
     961  - Racing version of the 959.
     962  - GT racing car based loosely on 911; used in endurance racing 
            and IMSA GTP; 1984.
     964  - The 911 Carrera 2 and Carrera 4, introduced in 1989.
     968  - Rebirth of the 944 series in 1992 with revised styling.  A 
            noteworthy feature is variable valve timing.
     986  - The Boxster, due in Sept. '96, the newest hope for Porsche's 
            future.
     993  - The latest iteration of the 911, introduced in 1994.

    1764  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1834  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1866  - Volkswagen successor.
    1906  - Leopard tank.
    1966  - Volkswagen small car prototype.
    2539  - "Save" ambulance.
    2567  - "Orbit" fire fighting system.
    2708  - Cart.

=======================================================================

What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
 
     General answer:  Buy the latest one you can afford of the model you
like.  Within models, there are certain years that are generally thought
of as more reliable or otherwise desirable, and others that have proved
troublesome over the years.  If you have questions about a particular
model, ask the list.  (We are looking for contributors to write about 
specific models.  Contributions, which may be too lengthy to include 
here, will be stored at tta.com and available via FTP.  Dave Darling has
gotten the ball rolling with a summary for the 914.  Feel free to 
contribute regarding your favorite model.)

=======================================================================

What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?

     There are several kinds of events organized and run by Porsche
clubs and organizations:

     Autocrosses.  These normally occur in a large parking lot or other 
relatively flat, open area.  The lot is filled with traffic cones that 
define a course.  Only 2 or 3 cars are on the course at the same time, 
and never at the same location on the course.  You race against the 
clock, and your times are compared to others in your class.  Classes 
are organized so that you compete against similarly-configured cars of 
about equal capability, ranging from box-stock to extensively modified.
Autocrossing is probably the safest and cheapest way to go fast in your 
Porsche (or any other car for that matter).  In some parts of the 
country, autocrosses are called slaloms.

     Time Trials.  These are also timed events, but they usually take
place on an actual race course.  They are often held in conjunction
with Track Events.  The time trial, like the autocross, is not against
other cars at the same time but against a clock.

     Driver's Education.  These events are held at a race track (but not
during a formal race meeting).  Multiple cars are on the track at the 
same time.  Instructors ride with the students, who are taught to drive 
at speed safely.  The US PCA has a basic set of rules and various PCA 
regions have their own rules which don't differ much from each other.  
Usually, the only modification to the car is a fire extinguisher that is
mounted metal to metal.  Students and instructors must wear an approved 
helmet.  

     PCA Club Racing.  This is racing in the traditional sense, in that
there's a full complement of cars, a definite start and finish, and
head-to-head racing.  The concept is similar to the various vintage
racing events that are becoming so popular; the idea is to preserve your
car and those of others while racing against each other.  If you don't 
race responsibly, you are not allowed to race.  There's a policy
governing this that is referred to as the 13/13 rule.  Under this rule,
if a driver is judged to be at fault in an incident that results in
damage to his car or another (no matter how small), he's out of that
particular event  and on probation for the next 13 months.  If in that
probation period that driver is again determined to be at fault in
another incident with damage, he's out of club racing for the next 13
months.  Equipment requirements include the fire extinguisher, a cut
off switch, an approved roll bar, and a five point seat belt harness.
There are several of these around the country.  You should have 
experience with autocross and driver's education events under your 
belt before you jump into this kind of racing.  Contact your local
club racing officials to get copies of rules, needed equipment, etc.

=======================================================================

What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?

     BTDT = Been there, done that
      BTW = by the way
      FAQ = Frequently asked questions (but you knew that)
      FTP = file transfer program
     FWIW = For what it's worth
     IMHO = In my humble opinion
      IMO = In my opinion
      IOW = in other words
      PAG = Porsche AG, the mother company back in Stuttgart; "AG"
            stands for "Aktiengesselschaft," which means that the 
            company has publicly traded stock
     PANO = Not an acronym; this stands for Porsche Panorama, the PCA 
            national monthly magazine
      PCA = Porsche Club of America, the major US/Canada Porsche
            enthusiasts organization
     PCGB = Porsche Club Great Britain OR Porsche Cars, Great Britain
     PCNA = Porsche Cars North America (Reno, NV), the US importer
     PMJI = pardon me for jumping in
      POC = Porsche Owner's Club, the *other* US Porsche owner's group;
            in the past they have been more competition-oriented than 
            PCA, which has many interest groups participating
     ROFL = rolling on the floor laughing
  ROFL,PP = rolling on the floor laughing, peeing in my pants (!)
     RTFM = read the f**king manual (for some, "read the Ford manual")
      TIA = thanks in advance
     TTFN = tata for now
     TTYL = talk to you later
      WWW = World Wide Web
     YMMV = Your mileage may vary
      <g> = grin
     <bg> = big grin
    <vbg> = very big grin
      :-) = Smiley face (turn your head 90 degrees to the left to "read"
            it); various iterations exist using different ASCII 
            characters
    
=======================================================================

What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?


     Excellence -
       Independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Many of the same
       authors you see in Panorama, less jingoistic in their praise
       for everything PCNA brings to market.

       US rates: $20 one year, $35 two years, $49 three years
       foreign (incl. Canada): US$27 one, $49 two, $69 three years

       Excellence
       Circulation Dept.
       P.O. Box 1529
       Ross, CA  94957
       telephone: 415-382-0580


     Christophorus -
       Porsche AG's official magazine.  Very good source of some
       technical information about their cars and technology.
       Beautiful magazine.

       US rates: US$28 surface mail, US$40 air mail

       Porsche AG
       Editors, Christophorus
       Porschestrasse 42
       D-70435 Stuttgart
       Germany
       FAX: D-711/827-6245


     European Car -
       Formerly "VW & Porsche", now devotes some bandwidth to other
       European cars, esp. BMW.  Lots of technical how-to's, but
       biased by "placed" articles from advertisers - beware!

       US rates: $18.80 one year, $28.20 two years
       Canada: $26.80 one year, $44.20 two years, includes GST
       foreign: $28.80 one year, $48.20 two years

       Argus Publishers Corp.

What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?

     Be aware when buying a part in the aftermarket that it may or may
not be the same part you would get from Porsche.  This holds true even
when the part carries the "correct" Porsche part number, and when it
carries Porsche's parts trademark.  The following suppliers, listed
alphabetically, have been praised by various Porschephiles:


     Andial
     3203-3207 S. Shannon St.
     Santa Ana, CA  92704
     telephone: 714-957-3900
     FAX:       714-957-9332

     Porsche's official agent for competition parts and products in 
     the US.  Catalog $6.00.


     Automobile Atlanta
     505A South Marietta Highway
     Marietta, GA 30060
     telephone: 404-427-2844
 
     The most comprehensive catalog of 914 parts.  Higher-than-average
     prices.  Catalog $5.00.  (Also a 924 catalog?)

     sister company to Weltmeister, whose suspension kits they carry.
     Free catalog.

=======================================================================

What references exist for detailed Porsche technical information?

There are many books and manuals available, and the right one for you
depends a lot on your interests and your particular car.  Porsche
publishes a Workshop Manual for all late model cars, as well as
various Technical Specification booklets.  Your local dealership's
parts manager can show you a catalog of technical literature
available from PCNA.

The Porsche Club of America periodically assembles all of the technical
articles which have appeared in Panorama into a new volume of their
Upfixin der Porsche series.  These are available from PCA's executive
office.

What follows is a list of some of the more popular and often-cited
books.  This list is not exhaustive, but provides a starting point.  
If you want information about other books, ask the list.  (Note:
Information about water-cooled cars is lacking; those with favorites
should submit them to one of the names at the end of this FAQ.)

     Bruce Anderson
     Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
       ISBN 0-87938-269-4
     Motorbooks International

     Duane Spencer
     Porsche 356 Performance Handbook  
       ISBN 0-87938-417-4

     Dr. Brett Johnson
     The 356 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-08-0
     The 911 and 912 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-00-5
     The 914 and 914/6 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-01-3
     Beeman Jorgensen Inc.

     Charles O. Probst
     Bosch Fuel Injection & Engine Management
       ISBN 0-8376-0300-5
     Robert Bentley, Inc.

     Fred Puhn
     How To Make Your Car Handle
       ISBN 0-912656-46-8
     HP Books

     Harry Pellow 
     The ABC's (and 912's) of Porsche Engines
       ISBN 0-941210-04-9
     HCP Research (408) 727-1864

     Peter Morgan
     The Porsche 924/944 Book
       ISBN 0-85429-764-2
     Haynes Publishing Group


There are also Haynes manuals available for most models.  While the
Haynes manuals tend to be very weak on specifics having to do with
different model years and variations, they are good at teaching how-to
procedures for different maintenance and repair tasks.

=======================================================================

Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?

     This is Stan's response:  "Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE 
THAT ISN'T JUST PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil.  Or as Bruce 
Anderson commented about something else, "a cash flow device."  Slick-50
is *evil* if you have an engine with an aluminium case.  Guess what we 
all have, eh?  There is a bit of info on it via anonymous FTP in tta.com
in /pub/porschephiles/MiscInfo.  Additionally, many of these additives 
use teflon.  DuPont (the inventors of Teflon) have stated categorically 
that teflon is useless in such applications."
 
=======================================================================

Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
 
Yes. There are many luminaries in the Porsche world on this list.  If
something is relevant to them, they'll typically respond to you
privately.  Their participation is greatly valued, so respect their
privacy and don't try to draw them out in the open.  If they want to 
say something to the list as a whole, they'll do so.

=======================================================================

Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?

     The FAQ is stored on tta.com in the /pub/porschephiles/FAQs 
directory, filename general-FAQ.  The version stored there will be 
the same one sent out monthly.  (There's also a FAQ that's specific to
the 914; other specific FAQs are welcomed, if anyone wants to contribute
to the archives.)

=======================================================================

Who maintains this FAQ?

     The FAQ is maintained by Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil).  I have
a 1972 911T as my daily driver.  Anyone who wants to contribute can do
so.  Contributions, revisions, and suggestions for new items are always
welcomed.  I peruse the list for potential additions, but don't be shy 
about sending suggestions directly to me.

=======================================================================

Date:         Tue, 31 Jan 95 16:32:30 EST
From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SS8299A@american.edu>
Subject:      911 or MR2

A friend of mine wants a 911, but can't afford one.  He has heard a lot of good
 things about the '91 and later Toyota MR2 Turbos.  Does anyone have experience
 with these cars?  How do they compare to Porsche handling?  He said that there
 was a suspension problem with the MR2 that would cause the tail to swing out
 do a nose plow (sounds 911-ish!) during  hard driving.  But, that otherwise,
the car is a mid engine pocket rocket (and a great deal $).  Any responses are
welcome!  Sean  '80 928

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 13:10:55 -0800
From: William Oldham <oldham@EECS.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Plated Alloy Cylinders

The discussion on "Ceramichrone" reminded me that we have a jig
for plating 356 cylinders, a jig made up by Richie Lukes.  Richie
either used it or planned to use it to replate alloy cylinders
like super90's etc, and if I remember right he had chrome in
mind.  It sounds like from the discussion there may be
someone in the airplane technology business that actually has
access to such a process.  Or is there still "sprayed iron"
technology out there somewhere?  The 356 group here in the
SF Bay area would like to know about any leads in that
direction; as I said we have Richie's jig and certainly lots
of old  alloy cylinders needing new inner surfaces.

Bill Oldham
356 B's and C


- ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 13:06:00 PST
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: I want to buy a '72 911T, need advice.


First of all, is this an "S" targa or a "T" targa that's been modified? 
 What do you mean when you say "S" package?  All of the standard S items 
were available as options on the T and E.  For example, my 73 T targa has S 
gauges and trim, but not the brakes.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

86 1/2 928S Iris Blue (not mine for long...)
73 911T Targa Oxidized Blue
67 MBZ 230
50 Willys CJ3A
 -
>Subject: I want to buy a '72 911T, need advice.
>Date: Tuesday, January 31, 1995 10:52AM
>
>        I am a first time newsgroup poster, so I apologize if I seem a
>little green.  My questions center around a car I might be interested in
>buying.  I have come across a 1972 911 Targa for sale from a gut in Kansas.
>It has the "S" package, aftermarket stainless exhaust, small amount of rust
>showing in the front end, and about 70,000 mi. on the odo.  Asking price is
>about $7,000.
>
>        My questions are these:
>
>Was '72 a "good" year for the 911T?
>
>With this limited amt. of info, how can I determine the relative value of
>this car sight unseen?  (I'm in Seattle, BTW.)
>
>Given these parameters, is it possible to find a good price to offer?
>
>Please feel free to email any advice or tips, warnings, etc.  Thanks in
>advance!

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 14:37:46 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Pop-valve installation from hell

>From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
>Subject: Re: Help..I screwed Up my pop-off valve installation!!

>I have determined (been told?) that the "gizmo" that I drilled into
>was the cold-start fuel distribution manifold. It only appeared in
>81 (going by memory here...it was around then anyways) onwards. This
>is why I did not see one in my neighbours 76S, or most of the people
>on the net did not have one who have put in the valve.
 snip

>The hole is not that big, and does not go **through** the manifold.
>I am attempting an experiment using Locktite Copper gasket sealer
>on some test cases. I have found a source for stubby stainless
>sheet metal screws, so I have used one of these in a test piece
>of sheet metal with the Locktite. I have also experimented with
>just using the locktite by itself, filling the hole like a plug.
>I am also going to try forming a plug with the locktite, and then
>us the locktite to seal that plug in the hole.

 snip
>Mike
>83 911SC

    This "manifold" was on earlier cars than the SC, my original '75 box
    didn't have it but a '77 box did.

     Why not just leave the hole in it ? It sounds like you run much
    more risk ingesting a screw or lump of epoxy then just letting
    the hole stay there.  Unless you find a problem with it, I'd leave
    it. (Screw ingestion is one of the only killers 928s have, in fact
    you can look at the changes in the air-filter box on those cars and
    watch how the factory tried to avoid it).

     Or, take apart the box and remove the manifold entirely. If earlier
    cars didn't have to have it your SC should probably work without
    it.  Don't risk a head and cylinder for this.

         Good luck-Lee





 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 12:41:46 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Oil Scum

Re: oil scum in winter

My '83 SC always has some yellowish oil-water emulsion around the filler
neck in winter, anytime average outside temps are below 45F or so.  More
after short trips, less after long trips, but always there.  Water vapor
is always coming out of the crankcase, and this is the first
cold spot that it hits (on its way to being sucked back into the intake
manifold).

It looks to me like a lot of this crud must drip back down the filler
neck into the oil tank.  This has never seemed optimum to me... but then
I was reading an article in R&T (or some such) in '89 or '90 where the
factory ran a squad of Porsche cars up to the north end of Alaska in
winter... to see how they'd hold up I think.  I remember that at about
40 below the 911 had trouble with *water condensing in the
crankcase vent hose and freezing to a solid plug*... until they got some
heater duct and routed the tailpipe back to blow hot exhaust on the vent
hose... then it was on to Pt. Barrow.  (You Minnesota winter drivers
might want to take note...)

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org

p.s. that same article had a wonderful quote from Porsche's R&D
chief, something to the effect that "your car must have steel in it...
the driver must be able to feel the razor edge".  Does anyone remember
this or have the actual quote?

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 13:00:20 +0000
From: katz_p_m <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk>
Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

Adam,

        Try to get Bosch arms if you can. I tried putting cheap wipers on 
my 944 and they just didn't clear the screen properly.

        Porsches usuallly come with Bosch arms and its worth replacing them 
with the same brand if you can find them.

Regards,
Philip

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:58:29 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Roundabouts



Neil wrote:

> If you really want to have fun try L'Etoile at rush (or any other) 
> hour, where the priority a` droite gets you on fast but then .........

In 1961, with my wife and two kids, we picked up our new 356B Coupe at
Sonauto dealership in Paris. None of us had ever been in a Porsche before
(except to see if the kids fit in the back), much less driven one. We made
two wrong turns and immediately found ourselves in L'Etoile at lunch hour.

Can't remember how many revolutions we made. Went into it as a terrified
Porsche novice -- came out of it as a Porsche race driver. At least, I
thought so at the time . . . .

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 03:19:25 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: Re:   931: Oil in the PCV air  

This problem sounds more related to poor engine oil control than to a turbo
related problem. The oil from the turbo just dumps out into the (top of the)
oil pan and should not go into suspension (hence ending up in the air
filter).  My 931 also shows signs of oil on the filter  - though not to the
same extent that your car does Mike.  Does your car smoke at all?  (maybe on
gear changes or during high boost conditions - maybe needs new rings?)
As an aside, EBS (Engine Builders Supply or something), who advertises in
European car has a high(er) performance rebuild kit available for the 931
with 8.0:1 CR pistons - for $700 which is not too bad - I am not sure what
else is included in this kit though.  I sent for their catalog several months
but have had no response yet.  When I rebuild someday I will consider some
sort of [quality] alternative to the stock bits.  What would a set of stock
931 pistons cost I wonder?

MIKE.
1977 924 (as faithfull as ever)
1980 931 (Intercooler project put on hold for now due to technical
problems...)

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 07:46:00 PST
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?


     Before you rush into this, I thought I'd add my 2p worth.  I believe 
the Bosch (=Autobahn at your friendly VW/Porsche/Audi dealer) are the best 
blades I've used and seen.  They are a little expensive but I think they 
hold up well over time.  Besides, new arms couldn't be cheap.  I think the 
way you can replace just the inserts works pretty well.
     If this seems to be my personal opinion and no one out there likes, 
just let me know.  But I've had good luck with the Bosch blades over the 
years.

David B.
'89 944 (BTW,  thanks for reminding me.  I probably need to replace the 
inserts.)

Dave forwarded on a note blasting K&N and foam type oiled filters versus
paper filters in a purported "test" by and unnamed "major" construction
firm....

This note, which was forwarded to me days ago by a friend, is pretty much
why I stopped reading rec.autos.tech.  Too many kids with nothing better to
do that make shit up and see if anybody figures it out. Suurre, oil
impregnated filters pass more dirt, uh huh. That's why every dirt racer just
about in existence runs one of these or a K&N style -- they LIKE to put dirt
thru their motors]  They can win major offroad events this way.  Yeah,
right...  Send me accredited test results and not made up no-name bullshit
and I'll listen....

 -Scott Jessen -- and why, yes, I have raced a fair bit off road now that you
ask...  Oh, and I run K&N on my tow vehicle and ITG dual-density oiled foam
filters on the 911...

ASP 911 -- bad'er than ever for '95....

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:53:06 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 oil scum question

This is moisture trying to escape your oil pan.  It accumulates from 
high humidity levels typically, and is fairly common.  Make sure you 
change the oil frequently to remove this moisture (and other dirt, 
etc.) from the oil.

Sometimes water in the oil is caused by a head gasket or oil/water 
intercooler seal leak.  If this is happening you'll see/smell 
antifreeze in the oil, and maybe oil scum in the antifreeze tank.  The 
fix for these problems is more involved.

                JBS

 - ----------

dipstick.  On

> synthetic 15W-50 to Castrol Syntec 5W-50.  Prior to that the car had 
whatever

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:55:39 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

I've been down this road too, Adam.  The best thing to do is fork out 
for real Bosch arms & blades.  The blades can be had for around $8 - 
$11 /pair, and the arms, last I checked, were around $25 (dunno if 
pair/single).  You may be able to get arms from a used parts place.

Don't get the aftermarket "aerodynamic" blades; they're actually worse 
than stock and have MORE lift at speed, and are less effective.  I 
removed a set of these for a friend who bought them based on the sales 
pitch, and tossed them based on engineering.

                JBS

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 08:54:25 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Re: Help..I screwed Up my pop-off valve installation!!


A small update.

I have determined (been told?) that the "gizmo" that I drilled into
was the cold-start fuel distribution manifold. It only appeared in 
81 (going by memory here...it was around then anyways) onwards. This
is why I did not see one in my neighbours 76S, or most of the people
on the net did not have one who have put in the valve. 

Anyways, the distribution manifold apparently was Porsche's solution
to reduce the amount of fuel in the airbox when the cold-start
(7th injector :-) ) was active. This is why the occurance of blown
air boxes is much less in the late model SC's, even though they 
still use CIS.

The hole is not that bid, and does not go **through** the manifold.
I am attempting an experiment using Locktite Copper gasket sealer
on some test cases. I have found a source for stubby stainless 
sheet metal screws, so I have used one of these in a test piece 
of sheet metal with the Locktite. I have also experimented with 
just using the locktite by it self, filling the hole like a plug.
I am also going to try forming a plug with the locktite, and then
us the locktite to seal that plug in the hole.

**Sigh**. I have used a combination of magnets, shop vac and sticky
tape to clean up all the metal shavings. There really was not that 
many in the box anyways, and it appears to be pretty clean now.
I have very little black plastic shavings in the air box because I
was using the shopvac while drilling the hole. 

The cold-start manifold must be no more than 1/2" below the bottom 
of the drill site...I would have realized that if I would have
read Mr. Anderson's book more carefully..of course you only see
it after the fact!

Anyways, I will keep you posted.

Mike
83 911SC 

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 09:56:04 -0700 (MST)
From: Wilson Luther <Luther.Wilson@Colorado.EDU>
Subject: Re: 944 Wiper Arms - preferenes?

Adam--
I had to replace the wipers on my 89 944 right after I bought it. The 
blades are narrow. I finally found an auto parts store that specialized 
in European cars and got a set that fit. Bosch parts. Last resort, try a 
dealer. There should be acouple in Ann Arbor.
Luther

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:03:20 PST

between 900 and 1100 rpm for about 15-20 secs.  If I restart it soon after
the engine is turned off, either hot or cold, it starts right up.

like it should start right away.  Any ideas?

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:01:32 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: ,84 Euro Carrera for sale

> Which makes me finally ask a question I've been stewing over for a while. 
> How easy is it to replace the rear fender on a 911SC?  I know the fronts
> are more or less a bolt on affair, but what about the back and the
> roofline, etc.?

I got to watch my 911SC get new rear fenders, new rear cross-piece and
a significant amount of cut-and-paste done after a woman doctor pushed
a Caddy Eldorado into me at about 45 MPH while I was waiting for a light
to go from red to green....

That was *NOT* simple do it yourself job. Those fenders are seam welded into
place, and replacement is NOT trivial. The guys that did my work were very
very good, and it still took about 3 months to get the car back.

Stan

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 09:01:54 pst
From: Brian_Foster_at_ASTISHR@ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Sometimes you have to just sit and enjoy...

This past Sunday I was motivated to re-organize the garage -- don't 
know why, but there was something in the air.  After a morning of 
running around shopping for baby wallpaper and gadgets, I was ready 
for a change.

I started off with the left side and was finished within the hour.  I 
went to push the 356 out of the garage and saw "Murphy..." sitting in 
the passenger seat next to "Secrets..." (Earlier in the week I was 
checking if the engine had seen a previous overhaul...).  So I sat 
down, opened to a page at random and started reading.

Two hours later, my wife found me still sitting in the 356, smile on 
my face, the book open in front of me, and the righthand side of the 
garage not even touched.  She laughed and inquired how the Super Joke 
was going -- I had no clue!  I tried to explain, but I don't think she 
understands...:(

There is something about the smell, ambiance, character, or?! of your 
special friends sitting in the garage.  The mixture of leather, oil, 
racing fuel, and rubber serves as an aphrodisiac that some get, some 
don't -- who cares?!  I enjoyed my Sunday afternoon "driving" the 356 
w/o ever leaving my garage!

Thanks for listening, hope you get "it", and have a great week!!
=====================================================================

March!)

 - ------------------------------

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 11:09:36 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: FWD> K&N Filters Concern

> This note, which was forwarded to me days ago by a friend, is pretty much
> why I stopped reading rec.autos.tech.  Too many kids with nothing better to
> do that make shit up and see if anybody figures it out. Suurre, oil
> impregnated filters pass more dirt, uh huh. That's why every dirt racer just
> about in existence runs one of these or a K&N style -- they LIKE to put dirt
> thru their motors]  They can win major offroad events this way.  Yeah,
> right...  Send me accredited test results and not made up no-name bullshit
> and I'll listen....

Actually, Scott exposes a very good point here, one that I keep trying to make
every chance I get: just because something is good for racing does not mean
that it's even *USEFUL* for the street.... What you can tolerate in a full
race engine is very different that you want in a street engine. Why? Because
you're going to be tearing that engine down and rebuilding it with pretty
good frequency. At least once a season. Maybe more like every race if you're
talking IMSA or one of the serious pro series. That's just what you do.

So only getting say 10k miles of engine life due to a crappy air filter
is *NO BIG DEAL*... Here's the math: 10,000 miles at an average 100 MPH
is 100 hours of operation which is 3 to 5 times longer than the engine
lives *ANYWAY*!!!! So just because you use K&N on racing engines doesn't
mean *ANYTHING* about how good they are for the street!!!!! On the
other hand, a filter that keeps your engine *PERFECT* (yeah, right) for
100k miles is going to be *WORTHLESS* on a race car, because you will 
be losing some flow efficiency, and you can't afford that. Period.

>  -Scott Jessen -- and why, yes, I have raced a fair bit off road now that you
> ask...  Oh, and I run K&N on my tow vehicle and ITG dual-density oiled foam
> filters on the 911...

Yeah, I run the K&Ns on my race car too, and *HIGHLY* recommend the ITG filters
for carb applications when racing...

Street, that's another can of beans entirely... Factory air and oil filters
ONLY (but would highly consider the Canton/Meca oil filter for street use).

Stan

Date: Tue, Jan 31, 1995 12:50 PM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Galvinized 911s started when?

Kristian Simsarian writes:
> 
>       A friend of mine is looking for an early 80's SC or Carrera. In
> a snowy cold climate like this we have often wondered when exactly the 
> 100% galvinized metal was incorporated into the 911.  We have gotten
> conflicting information ranging from 1977 to 1984.  I know that it
> started with 1980 on the 924, one would think earlier with the 911 -
> does anyone have the hard facts?

(the Late) Dean Batchelor said 911's were galvanized starting in '76.  I posted 
this a week or so ago, and Bruce Anderson questioned me on it.  As I told Bruce,
I can't lay my hands on the book to look up the reference. but I remember it
pretty clearly, as that's one of the issues that was important to me when I
was searching for my toy.  Bruce told me that the issue is pretty controversial,
so I infer that the reference may not be correct.

Hey! you get what ya pay for...

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora

'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 10:03:28 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Crankcase Cottage Cheese


Hi all, 

The phenomonom you describe is a form of condensation of oil vapor that
also occurs in 911 dry sump tanks. This occurs because the driving cycle 
is such that the oil does not reach full operating temperature to 
outgas the watervapor that condenses from short cycle driving.

For Mike Weilman and 924 Turbo owners, there is an oil trap 6 inches
from the air cleaner but 18 inches from the block. It almost never gets
hot enough to vaporize the water condensation, the normal purge cycle
of the vapor traps moves this white-ish goo onto the air cleaner element
ruining the element. I have removed the trap and cleaned it.

Pulsing vapor is caused by the pulses of the pistons displacing air in
the crankcase. Dark, oily vapor indicates blow-by, not good. Clear or
whitish vapor is condensation, just getting warmed up to get out of the 
system. Driving on the freeway for an hour or so should get things warm
enough to get rid of the condensation.

Jim Pasha

Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1109 Mon Jan 30 02:00:04 CST 1995

letting the wheel go can be a life saver,if u posse the skill. i have used
this technique many times at low and high speeds.i dont know where or how i
learned it but i can tell u that it really works.u see cars want to naturally
go straight,so when the force going side ways is so strong it becomes all
most impossible to to hold the wheel.the wheel will actually snap back to the
straight position!the important part is to stay on the power and remember to
grab back hold of the wheel!. if u lift be sure to get right back on the
power ultimately u want to stay on the power.if u lift and dont get back on
the power,round and round u go (just ask russ) P.S.this  also works in
motorcyling.

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 11:26:10 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: 911 Jacking Points


There was a thread a while back about optimal jacking and jack 
stand points for a 911. I don't know if it came to a satisfactory 
conclusion, but the January issue of the Pacific Northwest 
Region's PCA Newsletter has an article by Allan Caldwell in 
which he suggests jacking and stand points for all Porsche 
models.  For the 911/912/930 he suggests:

For the Front:  Jackpoint - Front Cross Support Box Beam
                        Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Covers or Body Hoist 
                                        Pads

For the Rear:   Jack Point - Engine with woods block
                        Jack Stands - Torsion Bar Ends



Bob Spindel
'72 911E

Porschephiles #1121                         Tue Jan 31 16:28:41 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 31 Jan 95 16:27:19 EST
From: tynor@atlanta.twr.com (Steve Tynor)
Subject: re: Tail Happy 911s

Richard Hocking <hocking@cig.mot.com> wrote: 

| What with the recent thread on whether to let go the controls when in
| a spin, I was wondering what the expert drivers out there recommend
| when you start to lose the tail of your 911 ?
| 
| a)  Get off the gas. 
| b)  Get on the gas.  
| c)  Keep the gas where it is.
| d)  Get on the brakes (presumably implying off the gas).
| e) Something other than any of the above.
| 
| What is the recommended action (both pedals and steering) ?

The recommended technique is: go to your nearest PCA/BMWCCA driver's
education event or autocross school. Do not pass go. As with most
driving techniques, controlling an immenent spin requires precise
control inputs - it's not likely that you'll be able to read a book (or
read this email) and then be able to use this info with out some
practical training.

Weight transfer in a spinning / out of sorts car (911, 914, 944, it
doesn't matter) is a complicated thing: the worst thing you can do is
your #a or #d (they're effectively the same thing). Your car is starting
to spin: that means that you've lost traction on the rear wheels. If you
deccelerate (by braking or letting off the gas), you transfer more
weight off the rear wheels and to the front - making it worse!  This is,
unfortunately, the instinctive reaction. The correct response is to
steer slightly into the direction of the skid (anyone whose driven on
ice has done this) and get on the gas (but not enough to spin the
wheels: we're trying to transfer weight back to the rear wheels so that
they'll stick: if you spin them, what's the point?). This must be a very
quick, instinctive response. After making the correction, you need to
anticipate that the rear wheels will start to stick again. It'll happen
very quickly. When they do, you'll get a gob of weight transfer from one
side of the car to the other, causing the car to suddenly start to turn
the other way (a "fish tail"). Just as (it feels more like "just
before") the rear wheels start to stick, you must remove the steering
correction and straighten the wheel.  This is why most cars that spin
usually end up at the inside of the track: the driver didn't compensate
for the weight transfer after the initial slide was `caught'.  If you
overreact in the first place (the initial steering into the skid), it
makes the recovery that much harder (since the lateral weight transfer
is that much more violent).
 
If you've lost control, however (once the car has rotated to the point
that you have no hope of recovery), you're best bet is "IN A SPIN: BOTH
FEET IN" (hard on the brakes - press in the clutch and hang on until the
car comes to a stop).

I can't emphasize enough the importance of driver's ed - don't try this
without some instruction. It'll make you a better driver, and you'll
have a blast!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Porsche is a two syllable word.
  '74 914 2L (silver being overtaken by rust) [toy car]
  '87 951    (guards red) [track animal and daily driver]
  no cats

Steve Tynor		Internet: Steve.Tynor@atlanta.twr.com
Tower Technology	UUCP:     twratl!Steve.Tynor
			WWW:      http://www.cm.cf.ac.uk/Tower/

------------------------------
