Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 16:53:24 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: 91(4) electronic advice (?)

Here's some info for you Greg:


>  >Hope this answered more questions than it raised.  If you have any more
>questions, send them this way!
>>Andy
>>(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)
>
>Andy,
>
>I read with interest your post on Porschephiles of 911 speakers, etc.
>Wondering if I can solicit some advice, or if you have any, re: my '75 914.
>I have what I assume to be the original radio/8-track in the dash.  The
>radio "works", but not well, and the 8-track... well, who knows?  Speakers
>are two in number, in the doors, what look to be 4x6 (don't know if that's
>the metric, but would assume so).
>
>I live in Wash. DC, and sometimes park on the street, and so right now I'm
>safe with the 8-track in the dash.  What I would LIKE to do is change the
>speakers to something better (and I guess just leave it as the two, nothing
>else... this'll be DIY, and I'm not electronics expert/stereo installer)
>and leave the 8-track in the dash, and instead connect/hook-up a radio/cd
>player underneath the dash...something that is removeable and not easily
>seen (since this is not a daily driver, but more for weekend and short
>trips).  I COULD go for the cd-in-the-trunk changer, but dislike the $$ put
>into it.  Also thought about going for the high-power cassette deck, and
>hooking up my portable cd player to it.
>
>So my questions:  anything you would suggest?  Will I get enough power for
>road noise/wind with the two speakers?  Do you still suggest a pre-amp?
>
>Thanks.  -Greg
>
>gnyce@nas.edu
>"If you really want to develop the feeling that the world is out to get
>you, spend some time commuting by bicycle."  -Bill Byrne
>
>
Actually you have a number of options.  In the audio world, an 8-track would 
generally be considered a "dinosaur".  You have a good plan, however, with 
hanging onto it.  I too live in the Northern Virginia area and would 
consider you brave for parking *any* car on the streets of our nations 
capital.  What many people don't realize, however, is that often the best 
form of security system to prevent stereo theft is none at all (theft of the 
whole car is another car).  Keep in mind that if a thief doesn't *know* you 
have a stereo system than he/she won't waste time fooling with your car to 
find out.  He/she will move on to more obvious victims.  In the industry 
this is reffered to as "stealth" installation.  It involves install 
techniques that attempt to completely hide any signs of an aftermarket 
stereo system.  This means that your plan to keep the ol'  8-track in the 
dash is a good one.  What is often done is that the stock head unit is 
disconnected (thus rendered inoperable), and a modern head unit (tape or CD) 
is mounted elsewhere in the car.  As you suggested, possibly under the dash 
out of view, or sometimes the glove compartment makes a good location (look 
around for potential places--I am not very familiar with the interior of a 
914).  Some higher end models even include infra-red cordless remote 
controls that can be used to operate difficult-to-reach head units while 
driving.  The majority of cassette and CD head units available today are 
either "pull-out" removable units, or the convenient "detachable-face".  
Also, at the extreme spectrum, it is possible to build what is called a 
"false front".  In this, the face or front (displays/buttons) of the stock 
head are surgically removed from the guts of the unit, and reassembled to 
look exactly like the stock head without the rear guts.  This "dummy face" 
is then placed over the front of the new head for disguise.  I have 
performed several such operations, and if done correctly, can provide a 
convincing anti-theft device.  

About the cassette, just ask yourself this question: How often do I really 
listen to tapes as oppossed to the sound quality of CD's?  Let your budget 
and the size of your tape vs. CD collection dictate which you choose.  I too 
agree that trunk changers are often cost-prohibitive, but you can get very 
simmilar performance from a dash mounted unit minus the multi-disc 
convenience.  IMHO I'm not a big fan of portable CD players in the car 
because only the most expensive models usually have adequate shock 
prevention (especially with a rough riding car), and they are often 
difficult to operate while driving.  Take your portable with you in the car 
sometime and see how it fares against road bumps.  

With the speakers, follow the advice I gave G in the earlier thread you 
read.  A basic speaker swap is usually a pretty straight forward DIY task as 
long as you replace with the same size speaker (measure to be sure).  Also, 
make sure you replace with the same polarity among your wires (i.e.  
positive wire to positive speaker terminal; negative wire to negative 
speaker terminal).  

It is really your own preference as to whether you will have enough power 
depending on how loud you listen to your music, if you drive with the 
windows down, etc.  See the earlier post I made to G regarding amplifiers.  
If money is tight you may want to consider purchasing a "high-power" 
cassette or CD head unit.  These units will offer you between 10-15 watts 
per channel of  *continuous* (don't confuse with peak power ratings), rather 
than the usual 3-5 watts of a conventional head.  If you want more *juice* 
then an outboard amp is the way to go.  You may be confused by the 
difference between a pre-amp, and an amplifier.  A pre-amp is actually a 
tiny amplifier inside your head unit that creates the low-level "signal" 
voltage that is sent to an external amplifier (or directly to the amp in the 
head unit that powers the speakers).  The external amp is fed this signal 
voltage, and in turn *amplifies* that signal and sends it on to the speakers.  

I hope this helps.  I open to any other questions you might have.

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 21:44:04 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re: Galvinized 911s started when

Arthur Golden <agolden@pepsi.com> said :

>I originally asked the question and Bruce Anderson responded that _full_ 
>galvinization started in '78 on the 911. Bart responded that _partial_ 
>galvinization started in '75 with the '76 model year.

I'm not one to doubt Bruce, but my '72 is partially galvinized. The entire
floor and most of the bottom is galvinized, so if you see a '72 or later with
a rusty floor it is a basket case. Also I would bet money that the '76s
are about as fully galvinized as any 911. Porsche had a '76 body (I think)
outside of their factory unpainted as a display to show how good the
galvinization was.

Mike Piera '72 911S Targa

"Pound for pound, a '72 911S is more powerful than most cars twice their
size"
 - Mighty dog
